Pop history is full of instances of bands creating new identities to free themselves from the imagined strictures of their old ones. The Beatles had Sgt. Pepper’s; Prince had Camille; Beyoncé had Sasha Fierce; Garth Brooks had
column4: 00.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Chris Gaines. Parkay Quarts have been billed as an “alter-ego” of the smart
column5: scrappy punk band Parquet Courts
column6: but the term seems off: While “alter-ego” implies a different side of the same person—Superman to Clark Kent—Parkay Quarts are effectively Parquet Courts’ two frontmen and principal songwriters
column7: Austin Brown and Andrew Savage
column8: filled out with help from assorted friends
column9: including Jackie-O Motherfucker’s Jef Brown and Bob Jones
column10: from the band Eaters. Alongside PCPC—Parquet Courts’ collaboration with the muddy psychedelic band PC Worship—Parkay Quarts seems less like an attempt to devise a new identity than to blur the edges of the one they already have.

column1: Content Nausea was proudly recorded on four-track cassette
column2: that old saw of indie cred and self-reliance in the pre-digital era. The recording is humid and a little sloppy; the songs are occasionally in rough shape
column3: with scaffolding showing. Both Austin and Savage are expert mimics—the kind of songwriters who suggest a rich and variegated past without ever seeming like slaves to it. Listen to Content Nausea—as with Parquet Courts’ great Sunbathing Animal
column4: which came out only six months ago—and you’ll hear Richard Hell
column5: the Minutemen
column6: the B-52s
column7: the Raincoats
column8: Pavement
column9: Talking Heads
column10: and an entire history of bands who took the nervous energy of early rock'n'roll and launched it into more oblique orbits. But people said the same thing about the Strokes almost 15 years ago
column11: you might be thinking. They did
column12: and they were right then too. Such is the great wheel of time. (Not that Parquet Courts are all that much like the Strokes—they are brainier
column13: funnier
column14: more severe and less likely to go over at barbeques.) And so we arrive once again at the indie-rock analog to a bistro burger: Something simple and familiar made with enough invention to make you feel like the tradition still has room to grow.

column1: Content Nausea—what a title! Song after song
column2: Savage and Brown bark their anxieties about modern life with enough wit to suggest that they’re aware of the convention and enough passion to suggest that they feel those anxieties anyhow. “This year it became harder to be tender/ Harder and harder to remember/ Meeting a friend/ Writing a letter/ Being lost/ Antique ritual/ All lost to the ceremony of progress
column3: ” Savage says on the title track
column4: his voice flat and intense
column5: the beat poet unspooling his revelations over free jazz. And then comes the caveat: “Ignore this part
column6: it’s an advertisement/ These people are famous
column7: I’d trust 'em!”

column1: Are any of these lyrics specifically about 2014
column2: a year in which you can walk into a bar and see someone wearing glasses connected to the Internet? Not really. Like Sunbathing Animal
column3: Content Nausea keeps its symbols flexible and vague. Sometimes the vagueness seems a little lazy
column4: sometimes just ironic—rather than preoccupying itself with the actual stuff of modern life
column5: Nausea is preoccupied with albums preoccupied with the stuff of modern life. But like all traditionalists
column6: closeted or out
column7: Parquet Courts seem of the mind that these changes—dial-up to smartphones
column8: missile launchers to drone strikes—are superficial. The only difference between now and then is the shape of the toy
column9: not how we use it or what it does to our brains.

column1: Nausea is easier to listen to than Sunbathing Animal in part because it seems less ambitious. Four of its tracks are around a minute long; one is a so-so cover of ""These Boots are Made For Walkin’"" (itself a punk staple as ubiquitous as the safety pin); one is basically spoken word over noise—a reminder that for all the band’s nervous intensity
column2: they’re basically bookworms. If they belong in a tradition of New York punk—an ambition Savage has talked cannily about in interviews—it’s the tradition of people like Tom Verlaine and Richard Hell and Patti Smith
column3: stalking moonlit streets in ripped jeans with Rimbaud and Baudelaire tucked into their unwashed armpits
column4: less concerned with smashing the state than with cutting through the red tape that holds them back from the wilderness within
column5:
romantics who tried to forge ahead by clawing back to the source.

column3: confrontation with Captain Beefheart’s music produces polarized and extreme reactions. Take two Rolling Stone reviews from the era
column4: both of which mention 1969's Trout Mask Replica : one reaction was akin to Montezuma’s Revenge—“I about puked…what is this shit?”—while in another
column5: Lester Bangs crowned the album “a total success
column6: a brilliant
column7: stunning enlargement and clarification of his art…the most unusual and challenging musical experience you’ll have this year.”

column1: Decades have done little to mitigate such responses
column2: and Trout remains as barbed as a blowfish. As a gateway to Captain Beefheart's singular amalgamation of country blues
column3: psychedelic rock
column4: free jazz
column5: and beat poetry
column6: it puts off as many listeners as it draws in. Which is a shame
column7: in part because rock produced only one figure like Don Van Vliet. He was equal parts inscrutably gruff and warm
column8: and he could be both room-clearing and mesmerizing onstage; the impregnable imagery in his lyrics slid to reveal a sly commentary
column9: and he was able to both howl like a wolf (or Howlin’ Wolf) and purr like a cat. It’s not that he re-imagined Delta blues or Ornette Coleman’s harmolodics (not to mention gamelan or lute music or proto-punk) as much as he took them all in and then presented every angle at once
column10: the closest rock music could get to cubism.

column1: Beefheart’s genius can be more easily gleaned on Trout Mask Replica’s 1970 follow-up Lick My Decals Off
column2: Baby
column3: taut and streamlined where the former sprawls and splays. Unfortunately
column4: it's languished out of print since the early CD era and now reappears as the first disc of Sun Zoom Spark: 1970 to 1972
column5: a handy 4xCD compilation (disc four a fascinating set of outtakes and unreleased material) that captures the good Captain’s cagey albeit failed move towards mainstream rock acceptance. Rather than the impenetrable poses of TMR
column6: Decals finds Beefheart at his wiliest and most playful
column7: a new persona that takes centerstage across this album as well as its follow-ups
column8: The Spotlight Kid and Clear Spot. As the critic Robert Palmer once noted: “The dada-dabbling surrealist has become the teasing
column9: tantalizing back door man who entices crazy little things with almost drooling gusto.” Take the title track
column10: where he shoves aside the Beatles’ boyish sentiments with lines like: “Rather than I want to hold your hand/ I wanna swallow you whole/ ‘n I wanna lick you everywhere it’s pink/ ‘n everywhere you think.” He's no longer the trench-coated
column11: trout-masked weirdo in a corner.

column1: It’s a strange guise for Van Vliet
column2: but the mischievousness of songs like “Space-Age Couple” and “I Wanna Find a Woman That’ll Hold my Big Toe Till I Have to Go” (not to mention a line that rhymes “dinosaur” and “Dinah Shore’s shoes”) succeeds because of the Magic Band behind him. Featuring TMR holdovers John “Drumbo” French
column3: Bill “Zoot Horn Rollo” Harkleroad
column4: and Mark “Rockette Morton” Boston
column5: augmented by the addition of former Frank Zappa member Art Tripp on marimba
column6: Decals shows off a Magic Band so tight so as to be spring-loaded
column7: as fearless as a daredevil stunt team (check this rare live footage of this short-lived group). On this concise album
column8: death-defying time changes and complex chords abound. There are also two stunning
column9: contemplative and complicated solo guitar compositions
column10: “Peon” and “One Red Rose That I Mean”
column11: that sound at once stately and knuckle-breaking to play.

column1: A song like “Bellerin’ Plain” contains multitudes in its three and a half minutes. It starts with a tough serrated guitar riff that soon unspools as Drumbo’s closed hi-hats and quick drum rolls keep finding more space even as Van Vliet’s surrealist bark about railroad brakemen and black smokestacks pushes to the fore
column2: the music itself metallic and clacking like a train. A considered yet dense bass solo not unlike something from a John Coltrane side comes in before Beefheart and band lurch back. There follows a double helix of marimba and guitar that contains the DNA for most '90s post-rock in its 45 seconds. The band returns with even more fury
column3: one of the Captain’s Albert Ayler-shrieking solos flares up and carries the song out.

column1: Soon after Lick My Decals Off
column2: Baby
column3: John French was out again
column4: the band was reconfigured
column5: and Captain Beefheart signed to Warner Brothers
column6: where across two albums from 1972 (The Spotlight Kid and Clear Spot) it sounds like he was being groomed to be the next Van Morrison. But after many albums of being difficult and diffuse
column7: a slightly more mainstream Beefheart is a fascinating beast. Some edges of his sound are sanded
column8: the Martian blues inherent in the guitars decidedly more grounded. The squalls of soprano sax and shenai are shelved
column9: Van Vliet’s force-of-nature voice lowered
column10: revealing it be a more cracked and nuanced instrument as a result. Obtuse as his lyrics could be
column11: there were traces of the real world tucked in there
column12: with nods to ecological concerns
column13: garrulous people
column14: female empowerment. Familiar blues tropes are upended to reveal new imagery
column15: the “Babe I’m Gonna Leave You” re-imagined as a merman returning to the ocean on “Grow Fins”.

column1: Produced by Ted Templeman (who would go on to discover Van Halen)
column2: Clear Spot is Beefheart perfectly balanced between his aslant sensibilities and the desire for radio play
column3: as on “Circumstances” and the transcendent roadhouse rock of “Big Eyed Beans From Venus”. “Too Much Time”
column4: replete with horns and backing vocals sounds like a lost track from James Taylor or Bob Dylan circa “You Angel You”
column5: is the pop move where Beefheart began to alienate his fanbase. But whether you heard “Her Eyes Are a Blue Million Miles” on the Dude’s headphones during The Big Lebowski or here for the first time
column6: it remains the Captain’s loveliest
column7: most heartrending creation.

column1: Nothing here became a hit or brought Beefheart any closer to popular acceptance. Instead
column2: Clear Spot ultimately marked the end of this particular era of Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band
column3: as they would depart once they discovered his shifty accounting practices
column4: leaving him to assemble a group dubbed “the Tragic Band” by critics for his next two disowned albums. When Van Vliet returned to the critics’ good graces at the end of the '70s
column5: it was as the hard-edged
column6: irascible crank. This slightly sweeter
column7: gentler Beefheart was dropped like a mask
column8:
rarely glimpsed again.

The entire planet has been issued an ultimatum by the United Nations
column3: the elderly are getting arrested for the crime of feeding the homeless
column4: and a guy who campaigned on this is about to become Senate majority leader. Which is to say: the past two weeks have amounted to a perfect marketing rollout strategy for Final Days
column5: the fourth and most cataclysmic album to date from Brooklyn post-industrial prophet Sean Ragon and his swelling Cult of Youth congregation. Since debuting in 2007 as a solo acoustic mission
column6: Ragon has been gradually adding more members
column7: not to just elaborate upon his neofolk-rooted sound
column8: but to seemingly recruit soldiers for war. But on Final Days
column9: he’s not so much fighting to save the planet as our collective sense of empathy—because without the latter
column10: the former is essentially doomed.

column1: From day one
column2: Cult of Youth songs have followed a similar structural trajectory—solitary acoustic strums introduce Ragon’s sonorous croon
column3: before his playing turns incrementally intense and his voice explodes into a self-immolating shriek. What’s changed over the years is his means of getting there. On 2012’s Love Will Prevail
column4: the addition of drummer Glenn Maryansky and violinist Christiana Key helped smooth the journey from calm to chaos
column5: and seemed to channel Ragon’s rage into positive change; on that album’s penultimate track
column6: ""To Lay With the Wolves""
column7: he even signed off by declaring
column8: ""I fell in love/ In love with the world."" But
column9: following a crippling bout of paranoia and a brutal street beating that left him hobbled for months
column10: Ragon’s faith in humanity was destroyed anew. So while Final Days showcases a newly expanded five-piece chamber-punk formation—electric-guitarist Christian Kount
column11: bassist Jasper McGandy
column12: cellist Paige Flash
column13: and drummer Cory Flannigan—it proves to be a much gnarlier
column14: nastier record than its predecessor. Rather than continue the sophisticating process introduced on Love Will Prevail
column15: Final Days answers Ragon’s righteous indignation with the tsunami-sized sonic maelstrom it’s always been begging for.

column1: True to its wide-screened scope
column2: Final Days unfolds like a film told in flashback
column3: with the eerie opening soundscape ""Todestrieb"" presenting a desolate
column4: post-apocalyptic scene (instrumentation includes a cannibalistic symphony of ""human skull"" and ""bodies""
column5: with some guest molestation courtesy of Iceage’s Elias Bender Rønnenfelt) that the subsequent vocal-driven songs subtly inch us toward. And just as a track like ""Dragon Rouge"" gradually builds from deceptively idyllic folk-song overture toward a cataclysmic
column6: string-screeching climax
column7: so too does Final Days’ sequence as a whole
column8: frontloading more concentrated blasts of fury to set up the more imposing
column9: expansive set pieces of the album’s second act.

column1: For Ragon
column2: the road to hell is paved with grave intentions: domineering organized religions
column3: morally bankrupt politicians
column4: resource-depleting multinational corporations. But his mythic
column5: allegorical language transcends the trappings of finger-wagging protest folk
column6: giving songs like ""No Regression"" and the stormy
column7: nine-minute ""Sanctuary"" the biblically charged vigor of late-’80s Bad Seeds. And by dealing in folkloric metaphor rather than name names
column8: Ragon’s able to focus his ire on the real enemy: the insidious apathy toward the Machiavallien machinations that transpire in the corridors of power. As the percussive onslaught of ""Sanctuary"" hits its feedbacked fever pitch
column9: Ragon repeats the mantra ""some of us are scared to death of things the rest ignored
column10: a dispiriting acknowledgment that his enraged invective won’t get through to the people that need to hear it the most; in this bleak light
column11: the windswept shanty ""Roses"" feels less like an optimistic sign of life in the cracks of the pavement than a wilted bouquet left at the gravesite of humanity. But as a now happily married Ragon recently revealed to Noisey
column12: immersing yourself in such a despairing headspace can prove oddly therapeutic and invigorating—and
column13: likewise
column14: Final Days’ exhilarating
column15:
cathedral-toppling spectacle could prove to be the career game-changer that ensures his band remains a cult no more. 

"|19867.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19867-cult-of-youth-final-days/|8.1|Stuart Berman

Like his contemporary—and occasional label boss—Dan Snaith
column2: Chaz Bundick is a curious and intellectual pop craftsman whose heart can’t help but push him toward the dancefloor. As part of the chillwave vanguard making blurry
column3: wistful electronic pop at the tail end of the '00s
column4: he wrote songs like “Blessa” and “Talamak” under the name Toro y Moi
column5: staining slow-motion house party jams with young adult angst; even as he graduated to more cosmopolitan
column6: mature songwriting with follow-up efforts Underneath the Pine and Anything in Return
column7: his interest in danceable music lingered
column8: and he refracted it through the prisms of funk (like on the winning ""Still Sound"") and R&B. While his star continued to rise
column9: he quietly released a handful of singles under the name Les Sins
column10: pulling from the sounds of French touch and British bass music on songs like ""Lina"". The humbly covered Michael is his first full-length as Les Sins
column11: and it finds Bundick turning away from his thin
column12: genial voice and natural melodic gifts
column13: choosing instead to embrace rhythm and lean
column14: shadowy beat construction.

column1: Bundick has name-checked influences like German producer Danilo Plessow (who records deep house as Motor City Drum Ensemble) and Four Tet in interviews surrounding the release of Michael
column2: and the similarities between their work and his are evident throughout the record. He likes to cobble beats together from a wide assortment of percussive samples
column3: including fragments of his own familiar voice that have been chopped up and warped beyond recognition
column4: and he’s more than willing to craft hooks and engaging passages using unconventional means and sounds. Opener ""Talk About"" and highlight ""Bother"" both hang on aggressive spoken samples
column5: the former cribbed from Nas cut ""One Love"" and the latter delivered by Bundick himself; the skittering ""Toy"" is built around a spectral
column6: cycling flute-ish melody that’s tonally incongruous given the menace of the rhythm that surrounds it. Choices like this grant the record a playfulness and lightness that serve to balance its darker
column7: occasionally amelodic tendencies.

column1: With that said
column2: the best moments on Michael are the ones that hew closest to Bundick’s work as Toro y Moi
column3: which remains his flagship project. If you imagine a spectrum anchored at either end by the sonic extremes Bundick has explored—perhaps a piece of lounging
column4: bachelor pad pop like ""How I Know"" at one end
column5: and the shocking
column6: guttural assault of Michael’s ""Call"" on the other—it’s clear he does his best work somewhere near the middle. The irresistible ""Why""
column7: featuring vocalist Nate Salman
column8: would slot in perfectly alongside dance-oriented Anything in Return highlights like ""Harm in Change"" and ""Rose Quartz"" if Bundick was singing it instead
column9: and it’s the most memorable moment on Michael by a wide margin. A handful of songs scattered throughout the album’s back half succeed in large part because they embrace tones and textures that Bundick is clearly comfortable deploying
column10: from the spacey synth line gliding through ""Bellow"" to the bold
column11: bright piano melody that stars on closer ""Do Right"". These tracks feel distinct and separate from his work as Toro y Moi
column12: but without completely forgoing the skills and unique palette that makes those songs stand out. And although Michael is likely destined to end up a minor effort in Bundick’s expanding catalogue
column13:
his talent and radiant passion for new musical ideas and a wide breadth of sounds render the album a worthwhile effort for even casual listeners.

"|19977.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19977-les-sins-michael/|6.6|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21161/homepage_large.6ad5b03f.jpg|Let's Cry and Do Pushups at the Same Time|31554.0|Torn Hawk|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2014-11-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:02.427642|"

What are we actually talking about when we talk about nostalgia? Taylor Swift’s Polaroid album cover for 1989? Ghostbusters? The Beatles? Nirvana? Limp Bizkit? Illmatic? Nostalgia is fascinating and infuriating because of how specific it is: my nostalgia is not your nostalgia. But when it’s used correctly and on the right person
column2: it’s an emotional weapon
column3: able to warp hazy memories into strong feelings.

column1: Let's Cry and Do Pushups at the Same Time is Luke Wyatt's second album as Torn Hawk this year
column2: and stylistically
column3: it builds directly on the previous release
column4: Through Force of Will. Wyatt’s still playing with the emotional resonance of his own specific memories
column5: and nostalgia is still a primary factor
column6: but it's tempered by a breathy
column7: new age smoothness that rounds out the jagged edges of his older material.

column1: It’s not quite spa-ready easy listening though. The drums on ""Lessons From the Edge"" lurch and shuffle under layers of digital murk
column2: like a low-res jpg blown up way too big. Wyatt still loves layering and twisting triumphant guitar lines that are bound to remind you of whatever your favorite movie featuring an underdog coming out on top is
column3: or failing that
column4: a surf magazine from 1989.

column1: But it’s not all triumph. Wyatt skews dark on occasion: ""Because of M.A.S.K."" is a neon-lit journey through a dystopian present
column2: and ""Return to the Pec Deck"" sounds like two different Torn Hawk songs playing at once. It’s unsettling and weirdly funny. Yet it still feels like Wyatt is holding back. Each record he releases brings him closer to facing nostalgia head on: both the nostalgia inherent in the sound of his music
column3: and the nostalgia people that write about his music saddle him with. But how deep does he want to go? <i>Pushups
column4: as dense as it is
column5: is a breezy listen. Easy to play on repeat
column6: and easy to find moments of crystalline beauty that don’t have to mean anything more than what they are.

column1: Let's Cry and Do Pushups at the Same Time is often beautiful
column2: and that’s all it really needs to be
column3: but Wyatt’s been plugging away at this sound for long enough that it feels like he’s making a larger point about the way we engage with our own memories of pop culture—or at least questioning them. It’s impossible to tell if he’ll ever come to any conclusion. If he even wants to come to any conclusion
column4: but there are a couple things that are certain: Wyatt’s managed to take something as idiosyncratic as the way pop culture tangles up with our memories of the past and make a universal sound out of it. Ultimately
column5:
Wyatt has made a sadly triumphant album that questions how our minds remember what they remember. What will happen when he stops asking and starts answering?

"|19912.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19912-luke-wyatt-lets-cry-and-do-pushups-at-the-same-time/|7.3|Sam Hockley-Smith

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21256/homepage_large.de7eef66.jpg|Broke With Expensive Taste|29999.0|Azealia Banks|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Prospect Park']|2014-11-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:03.430405|"

It’s been three years since Azealia Banks sprung up from the New York underground fully formed with ""212""
column2: her confrontationally profane lead single. ""212"" was the seed for all of the triumph and adversity that followed—the prodigious rap skills
column3: the casual genre-bending
column4: and the bratty disdain for authority. In its wake
column5: Banks charted a career path typical of a budding rap talent. She dropped the promising
column6: beat-jacking pre-album mixtape (2012’s unrelenting Fantasea) and the compact retail EP of brash originals (2012’s nostalgia tripping 1991). She navigated through mettle-testing beef with her peers. The tiffs were negligible as long as the music was nourishing
column7: and for a while Azealia’s war on the rap establishment was excitingly disruptive.

column1: But as work on her Interscope Records debut commenced
column2: Banks hit a tight spot. The deal soured as her new tracks were met with indifference from label liaisons. Her uncompromising social media demeanor landed her in quaffs both hysterical (See: her merciless ribbing of T.I. and Iggy Azalea) and injurious (that time she defended her right to call Perez Hilton a gay slur)
column3: but vocal criticism of Baauer
column4: Pharrell
column5: and Disclosure began to cost her profitable collaborators. Her early career goodwill nearly spent
column6: Banks finally caught a break: Interscope let her out of her deal with the rights to all the songs she’d recorded during her tenure there. Broke With Expensive Taste arrived this month with very little fanfare
column7: its release announced with a simple tweet. Its lengthy gestation is
column8: of course
column9: its chief foible. Older material accounts for roughly half the tracklist
column10: and some of it doesn’t mesh well with the fresher
column11: weirder stuff around it. It helps to see Broke With Expensive Taste
column12: then
column13: as an anthology
column14: The Portable Azealia Banks.

column1: Three songs in
column2: it’s clear why Interscope didn’t know what to do with the thing. Opener ""Idle Delilah"" bursts in effortlessly crossing elements of house
column3: dubstep
column4: and Caribbean music. It’s followed by ""Gimme a Chance""
column5: a bass-heavy post-disco romp that takes a hairpin turn into smooth merengue halfway through
column6: as Banks flits from rapping and singing in English to perfect unaffected Spanish. ""Desperado"" borrows a beat from early 2000s UK garage whiz MJ Cole’s ""Bandelero Desperado"" as Banks puts on a rap clinic
column7: flaying adversaries in a flow so neat you might miss the fact that every piece of every line rhymes. Her voice is often the sole unifying force from track to track here
column8: and it’s easy to see a label’s trepidation about pushing this thing on listeners who haven't followed her every move. ""Nude Beach a Go-Go""
column9: for instance
column10: a late album collaboration with Ariel Pink
column11: is every bit the what-the-fuck moment it sounds like on paper.

column1: By the end of Broke With Expensive Taste you’ll come to see Azealia Banks as a dance pop classicist underneath the flailing. The capable but unfussy approach to melody on deep cut confections ""Soda"" and ""Miss Camaraderie"" as well as Fantasea holdover ""Luxury"" and the massive ""Chasing Time"" showcase Azealia as a singer who’s studied her Robin S. and Technotronic. Coupled with her bullish rhyme skills
column2: Azealia’s chops as a house vocalist make for a true rapper-singer double threat. (Credit is due to Drake and Nicki Minaj
column3: but both sound like they picked up singing on the job.) She’s an angel on the choruses
column4: but for the verses in between
column5: she’s a formidable spitter whose flash and flow are unmistakably Harlem.

column1: The party line among hip-hop aficionados is that New York rap currently lacks a distinctly New York identity. There’s some truth to it. The city’s biggest success stories of late involve locals breaking out by spicing Big Apple grit with outside flavors
column2: from A$AP Mob’s Texas screw fixation to French Montana’s trap circuit traction to Nicki Minaj’s day-glo EDM daze. But the scene in 2014 can’t look like it did in 1994 or even 2004
column3: and it’s becoming increasingly clear that the Statlers and Waldorfs pining for a new age of rappity boom bap wouldn’t notice a new New York if it came up and offered them molly in a Brooklyn bar bathroom.

column1: Well
column2: Azealia Banks is it
column3: and Broke With Expensive Taste is a reminder that the corner of Harlem that she claims is walking distance from both Washington Heights and the Bronx
column4: where you’re as likely to hear hip-hop booming out of apartments and passing cars as freestyle
column5: reggaeton
column6: house
column7: or bachata. It’s a quick subway jaunt away from the landmark clubs where ball culture persists
column8: as well as perennial dance parties at Webster Hall and the glut of eclectic Lower Manhattan concert venues. Broke With Expensive Taste glides through all of these
column9:
just like the faithful 1 train sampled on ""Desperado"". Both album and the artist revel in the freedom of a New York City where divisions between these sounds and scenes have ever so slowly ceased to exist.

When Antony Hegarty stepped onstage at London’s Barbican in early November 2006 to perform Turning

column5: remained both perplexing and compelling. Hegarty had captured seldom-told stories of gender confusion and romantic impermanence in 10 songs that seemed to breathe grace instead of air. He’d been an unknown upstart signed to the label of fringe hero and early booster David Tibet when he issued his debut just five years earlier. But for <i>Bird
column6: Hegarty had assembled a cast of apropos icons—not only his refined and intricate Johnsons
column7: but also Lou Reed and Boy George
column8: Rufus Wainwright and Devendra Banhart
column9: four singers who’d also flirted with liminal identities. Rather controversially
column10: those tunes had even <a href=""http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4217140.stm"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">taken Britain’s top music prize
column11: the Mercury

column13: besting Coldplay
column14: M.I.A. and the nationalistically sore losers of Kaiser Chiefs. The Guardian called him a ""former choirboy turned cross-dresser."" He was
column15: suddenly and unexpectedly

column1: Turning

column3: is the work of someone who has been given a sudden
column4: conspicuous platform. As Antony and his band worked through songs from his first three albums and an assortment of shorter sets
column5: a dozen transsexual
column6: transgender
column7: or simply androgynous women—""beauties
column8: Antony has long called them—turned slowly with the help of an elevated
column9: mechanized circle. Many of these characters reappear throughout Hegarty’s career. Dr. Julia Yasuda speaks and plays Morse code during Bird interlude ""Free at Last""; longtime collaborator Johanna Constantine has appeared in Antony’s album artwork and is the striking star of his ""Epilepsy is Dancing"" video.

column1: Positioned just to the side of the stage
column2: Atlas funneled live video of their bodies and faces through a web of effects and projected it behind the ensemble. It is an audacious and illustrative concept
column3: a synesthetic design that uses humans to portray Hegarty’s songs about dignity and survival
column4: to boost the hypothetical into the empirical. (Atlas’ video for ""You Are My Sister"" is a simulacrum of the show.) Though conceived and premiered for the Whitney Biennial in April 2004
column5: this full international tour was the byproduct of Hegarty’s post-Mercury cachet. Suddenly
column6: he had the ability to do more than play shows in London
column7: Rome
column8: Braga
column9: Paris
column10: and Madrid. He could stage them
column11: too. Captured throughout the European run and issued almost exactly eight years later
column12: this new CD-and-DVD package finally opens those shows up for a wider audience.

column1: You might smirk at the thought of another live Antony album
column2: since this is the third of his career and second since the release of his most recent studio LP
column3: 2010’s Swanlights. (It’s arguably the third since then
column4: too
column5: as he issued an onstage collaboration with Italian singer Franco Battiato last year.) But this is
column6: to date
column7: his quintessential live release
column8: capturing a set that toggles carefully between the band’s luxurious sounds and his urgent songs. The Johnsons are in their most measured and exquisite phase
column9: giving new life to cuts familiar from Hegarty’s catalog. They add tension (and a touch of ""Crazy in Love""?) to the start of ""I Fell in Love With a Dead Boy"" before indulging a perfectly pregnant pause that leads to the song’s big reveal. And three years before the number’s release
column10: they lean hard into ""Kiss My Name""
column11: Parker Kindred’s drums dancing with delight alongside Rob Moose’s electric lead. The auspiciousness of the occasion plays in Hegarty’s voice as complete confidence. He masters these takes. His voice dips and dives with the strings of ""Bird Gerhl""
column12: finding the soul gusto he can sometimes miss in the studio. And as he drives into the wordless shouts at the climax of ""Hope There’s Someone""
column13: you feel his call for solidarity on an instinctual level. This isn’t delicate subject or even delicate material
column14: he seems to say; it’s real life.

column1: The accompanying film
column2: however
column3: tries to do too much
column4: in turn missing the simple
column5: genius focus of the conceit. Unequal parts concert footage
column6: interviews between the beauties and Antony
column7: backstage logistical shots and motivational speeches from the singer himself
column8: Turning never explores an acute angle. The performances are beautiful
column9: with the figures and distortions of the women transforming songs like ""Rhythm of Your Love"" and ""Daylight and the Sun"" into beautiful
column10: ad hoc short films. Many of these numbers come cut with conversations with the models
column11: talking variably about issues with parents
column12: childhood wishes for a penis
column13: struggles with discrimination
column14: and moments where they discovered self-worth in their particular identity. There are stunning moments
column15: as when Joey Gabriel discusses communities of trans vagrants—""a transgender jigsaw puzzle
column16: she says—in Boston while the band rises high through ""Hope There’s Someone"".

column1: But unless you’re familiar with Antony’s orbit or you’re willing to do some independent study about who these people are
column2: you’re left feeling as though you know a little about a lot of vaguely connected performers. They’re rarely called by name
column3: and you have to work to keep them separate between scenes. Antony speaks no more than the beauties themselves
column4: but because of each woman’s cursory survey
column5: he emerges as the film’s anchor
column6: offstage as on. For a piece that aims to celebrate the value in diversity and self-worth
column7: such an anonymous effect actually negates the point.

column1: Not long before Antony and Atlas took Turning to Europe
column2: the filmmaker interviewed the singer for a conversation in BOMB Magazine. They talked about Catholic school and singing
column3: drums and diaries. They also talked about Turning and their impressions of the work’s value. ""What it whittled down to for me in the end was tableaux
column4: Antony said. ""Staring at something that I thought was beautiful and magical
column5: something transcendental
column6: which for me is usually moving across androgyny toward the feminine.""

column1: Watching and listening to Turning nearly a decade later
column2: tableaux feels too specific and stationary
column3: as though the work were only a to-scale model of the difficulty and progress of LGBTQ rights that both Antony and Atlas had witnessed in long lives as New Yorkers. Still
column4: despite the film’s issues
column5: and despite the relative slow motion of Antony’s current output
column6: this concept feels as revelatory and salient now as it did then. Even if Atlas’ effects feel dated less than a decade later
column7: this is no period piece. At a time when one court says yes or at least “no comment” to gay marriage only for another to say no
column8: and when women can’t criticize a multi-billion dollar industry without receiving death threats
column9: the idea beneath Turning remains one of vital empowerment. And whether he’s singing about polar bears or sexual orientation
column10: that’s long served as Antony’s most implicit message. Now
column11:
it spins forever.

Celestial Shore is just a fancy way of saying “space beach”—which is apropos given that the Brooklyn band’s second album
column2: Enter Ghost
column3: casts a cerebral lens on that mid-'90s indie-rock moment when seemingly every aspiring wool-toqued act had a nonsensical name like Space Beach. But it’s also a perfect summation of their contradictory aesthetic
column4: with sundazed lyrical meditations pining for a balmy
column5: breezy paradise that’s forever on the horizon
column6: but ultimately obstructed by the distracting bustle and suffocating noise pollution of unrelenting urbanism. Celestial Shore songs are like a Club Med advertisement… plastered on the side of a bus that’s just sped through a puddle and doused you in slush on a dreary January morning.

column1: Given their jazz-school chops
column2: Celestial Shore have always abided by a policy of “why settle for three chords when 17 will do?” On their 2013 debut 10x
column3: their quirks and tics felt like genial gesticulations in sync with a post-Dirty Projectors world
column4: while the backing vocals of the since-departed Lorely Rodriguez (aka rising synth-pop diva Empress Of) provided a calming counterpoint to the songs’ architectural-degree complexity. With the band now pared down to a trio featuring guitarist Sam Owens
column5: bassist Greg Albert
column6: and drummer Max Almario
column7: Enter Ghost untangles the knottier aspects of the band’s sound
column8: but the 90-degree kinks are still very much visible. They haven’t so much focused their songwriting approach as harnessed their fidgety energy into more powerful spurts
column9: with the band’s intricate interplay emphasizing their pop instincts rather clashing against them.

column1: In its most spirited stretches
column2: Enter Ghost imagines the new
column3: more poised album we have yet to receive from the recently reunited Unicorns
column4: with songs like “Now I Know” and “Same Old Cult Story” story striking a similar balance of winsome
column5: '60s-psych melodies and structural instability. As was the case with 10x standout “Valerie” (not a Steve Winwood cover)
column6: the highlight here is a customized ode to another girl already mythologized in the rock canon that’s slotted into the second-batter position: “Gloria” rides a Doolittle bass groove into a big-Deal chorus
column7: though the real hook isn’t Owens’ ascendant
column8: airy sigh
column9: but the labyrinthine yet oddly catchy chord progression running circles around it. And as the wistful “Weekenders” proves
column10: sometimes the most startling thing this tightly wound band can do is just chill out for a minute: the song’s compulsive verses give way to a gorgeous anti-chorus of whispered
column11: daydreamy incantations and jangly strums that repeat and recede like ocean waves softly cresting onto the sand.

column1: However
column2: even on a lean 33-minute record
column3: Celestial Shore struggle to maintain a consistent balance of inspired and insolent. Momentum sags amid the sludgy terrain of “Shell Shocked” (where Albert’s vaporous vocals and Owens' pig-squealed guitar-playing sound like they belong in different songs)
column4: while the lumbering psych-rock of “I Hide” and smash-and-grab garage-punk of “Pass Go” don’t so much throw curveballs as wrecking balls
column5: toppling their shaky structures with forced freakouts. But in the same way that they can unnecessarily derail solid songs
column6: Celestial Shore can also instantly transform the staid into something splendorous
column7: like when the twee solipsism of closing lullaby “Goodbye” blossoms into a kaleidoscopic cluster of barbershop harmonies. So while Enter Ghost abruptly turns elation into frustration and back again
column8: for Celestial Shore
column9: disorder is the norm—after all
column10: at the space beach
column11:
sinking and swimming are one and the same.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21045/homepage_large.4ec4bed6.jpg|The Other I|30092.0|2:54|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bella Union']|2014-11-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:05.174127|"

Every disappointment begin with an expectation. Case in point
column2: 2:54.  The Thurlow sisters made a strong impression with initial singles ""Cold Front"" and ""Got a Hold""
column3: evoking a more bottom-heavy and emotionally distant Cure in their stadium-goth status. But despite being no better or worse than most records of its ilk
column4: the Thurlow sisters’ self-titled debut was perceived as a bummer. Their promising start dulled within the context of 2:54 after it became apparent the band currently had little to offer besides their heavily stylized and insubstantial sulk
column5: which actually works in the favor of The Other I; adjust your expectations accordingly and it's much tougher to be let down.

column1: That said
column2: The Other I has a slightly different character than its predecessor
column3: as the Thurlows acknowledge the prevailing trends of the past two years and skew more ""pop"" in a way that rarely feels like calculated troubleshooting. Granted
column4: ""pop"" doesn’t mean sharp melodies
column5: accessible lyrics
column6: or a discernible personality here. But rather than emphasizing low-end churn
column7: the vocals and drums are pushed to the fore
column8: which puts every song on The Other I in a position to succeed. Colette Thurlow can project and generally sound confident when maxed out
column9: though her vocals serve as more of an appliance than an instrument: they can bring the heat
column10: they’re just rarely given anything to cook. Cranking the drums also proves a wise choice
column11: as these songs are most likely to be distinguished by rhythm alone—""Blindfold"" has a saucy
column12: tom-heavy pulse that nods to ""Let the Music Play"" or ""Come Go With Me""
column13: they edge towards country and western on ""The Monaco"" and trade stricture for Fleetwood Mac shuffle on ""Pyro"".

column1: But as with 2:54
column2: the band shows an extraordinary ability to sound alluring within the first 30 seconds of any song without building on it at all. The positive qualities of The Other I makes it sound like it’s carved from marble—dense and somehow delicate
column3: cool to the touch
column4: blinding whites and swirled blacks
column5: translucent and glazed
column6: luxurious and intimidating. Consequently
column7: it’s about as easy to engage as a statue.

column1: Which is to say it’s completely without edge
column2: regardless of how you define it—hooks
column3: abrasion
column4: tension
column5: whatever. These sort of standards might seem unfair
column6: as 2:54 aren't necessarily projecting ""We mean it."" There is no screaming
column7: they don’t try to rock in a way that hits with visceral force
column8: the Thurlows never make it obvious that they’re confessing anything. Listen close enough and they just might
column9: though. During the chorus of ""Blindfold""
column10: Colette appears to crack just the slightest bit—""A soulful face is looking back at me
column11: she begins
column12: and the following line can be heard either as ""I’m turning quick
column13: losing my pose"" or ""I lose my pulse."" Whatever it is
column14: there’s that brief possibility of finding relief in letting her guard down. She later bellows
column15: ""I don’t want to find my way back home
column16: which can actually raise expectations for the next time out. 2:54 have built a palatial structure on The Other I
column17:
but they still have yet to lay out a welcome mat.

It's a little wearying that Bob Dylan's burst of creativity in the spring and summer of 1967 is still getting tapped; it would be nice if
column3: for instance
column4: a single artist had had a moment within the past couple of decades that was both as musically fertile and as exhaustively catalogued
column5: mythologized and picked over. But there The Basement Tapes are—an ever-brighter star in the Boomer firmament—and here we are
column6: as their glow increases from a distance of 47 years.

column1: The six-disc Basement Tapes Complete set that Dylan released last week isn't even the whole story. At some point in the past couple of years
column2: Dylan found a stash or two of lyrics from the Basement Tapes period that he apparently didn't get around to setting to music at the time (or
column3: if he did
column4: apparently didn't bother to play with the Band at Big Pink). Producer T-Bone Burnett was appointed to do something with them
column5: and assembled a kind of new Traveling Wilburys to write and perform music for them: Elvis Costello
column6: Jim James
column7: Marcus Mumford of Mumford & Sons
column8: Rhiannon Giddens of the Carolina Chocolate Drops
column9: and Taylor Goldsmith of Dawes.

column1: This isn't the first time somebody else has written music for Dylan's words—the first example may have been Ben Carruthers and the Deep's 1965 single ""Jack o' Diamonds""—and two of the original Basement Tapes' highlights
column2: ""This Wheel's on Fire"" and ""Tears of Rage""
column3: were completed by members of the Band. Dylan himself participated in a similar project three years ago
column4: completing Hank Williams' unfinished lyric to ""The Love That Faded"" for The Lost Notebooks. Williams
column5: though
column6: didn't live to finish that album's songs. Dylan's just not so much the guy who wrote the lyrics on Lost on the River any more. (He's moved on: the set list on his current tour includes only four of his pre-1997 songs
column7: not counting a Frank Sinatra cover.)

column1: These Dylan texts are
column2: literally
column3: throwaways
column4: but they come from a period when he was writing spectacular throwaways. The baffled breakup songs ""Golden Tom - Silver Judas"" and ""Kansas City"" would both be as perpetually quoted as
column5: say
column6: ""You Ain't Goin' Nowhere"" if they'd appeared on record in the '60s. (The latter features some perfect Dylanoid backhands a la ""Positively 4th Street"": ""You invite me into your house/ And then you say you gotta pay for what you break!"") And
column7: as always
column8: Bob's a magpie: the title of ""Duncan and Jimmy"" riffs on the folk tune ""Duncan and Brady""
column9: and ""Hidee Hidee Ho"" owes its hook to Cab Calloway's ""Minnie the Moocher"".

column1: A project like this is a treacherous one for its artists
column2: though. To try to sound like Dylan is to come up short of the mark
column3: and to try to not sound like Dylan can betray the material. So the New Basement Tapes hedged their bets
column4: each writing music for the old lyrics on their own
column5: which is why the 20 tracks here (on the ""deluxe"" edition
column6: released at the same time as an impoverished 15-track version) include a few lyrics that show up twice in radically different settings. Most of the songwriters err on the side of avoiding Dylanish cadences—Goldsmith's settings
column7: in particular
column8: are bland adult-contemporary stuff
column9: and his lack of puckishness means that when he gets to a phrase like ""I have paid that awful price
column10: it lands with a dull clunk.

column1: It also seems like a mistake to take these songs as seriously as the NBT's sometimes do. ""Spanish Mary""
column2: for instance
column3: is a chain of stock phrases from old ballads
column4: shuffled until sense falls away from them (""in Kingston town of high degree""?)
column5: but Giddens sings it as if it's a meaningfully dramatic narrative. (To be fair
column6: the funereal Giddens/Mumford setting of ""Lost on the River"" that closes the album is one of its high points.)

column1: The MVP of this group turns out to be Elvis Costello
column2: who treats Bob as a band member who didn't happen to show up to the jam that day. Costello's already started playing a few of his collaborations with 26-year-old Dylan live
column3: including ""Matthew Met Mary""
column4: which isn't even on this album. His two-minute take on ""Married to My Hack""
column5: whose lyric is basically just Dylan flexing his rhyme chops
column6: is a rapid-fire monotone rant in the vein of ""Subterranean Homesick Blues""; he bellows and snarls his way through ""Six Months in Kansas City"" as if it was one of his own minor rockers.

column1: Nearly every track on Lost on the River has a couple of memorable moments: a marvelous turn of phrase
column2: a brief Jim James guitar meltdown
column3: an instant of the band members discovering how their voices can harmonize. But what it lacks is the casual joy of Dylan's Basement Tapes—music that was made almost literally in a woodshed
column4: with no thought at the time to releasing it. Dylan and the Band had the luxury of freedom from expectations and the luxury of being allowed to make something trivial. For all its power and commitment
column5:
Burnett's supergroup doesn't.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21103/homepage_large.c5c8c3bc.jpg|Sonic Highways|1534.0|Foo Fighters|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['RCA']|2014-11-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:05.946933|"

Foo Fighters have now been Dave Grohl’s chief concern for 20 years. The first 10 were spent minting the band’s platinum-plated modern-rock sound
column2: and the subsequent decade was spent trying to remold it… only to have it settle back into its predictable color and shape. Indeed
column3: it’s hard to distinguish one Foo Fighters album from another
column4: since they all draw from the same well of arena-punk fist-pumpers
column5: gentle comedown ballads
column6: and arm-swaying sing-alongs that fall somewhere in between; as their Greatest Hits compilation made all too clear
column7: a Foos song from 2007 sounds an awful lot like one from 1997. To his credit
column8: Grohl seems well aware of the fine line between being unerringly consistent and relentlessly formulaic
column9: and has tried to provide each new record with a fresh narrative. But these strategies have essentially amounted to hanging different frames around an unchanging picture—like a double-album opus that simply segregated the Foos’ habitual whispers and screams
column10: or a back-to-the-garage throwback seemingly designed for garages big enough to house private jets.

column1: That said
column2: Grohl's latest plan to drum up interest for a new record could be his most ingenious: make the most elaborate
column3: expensive EPK in music history and have HBO distribute it. Sonic Highways is the name of both the Foos’ eighth record and an accompanying
column4: eight-part TV series documenting its ambitious
column5: cross-country production process
column6: with the band (alongside Butch Vig) recording each of its eight songs in a different city. It effectively blows up the concept of Grohl’s 2013 film
column7: Sound City
column8: to a national scale: visit a renowned musical mecca
column9: speak to the legends that put it on the map
column10: and hope some of their mojo rubs off onto new recordings.

column1: As a documentary
column2: the Sonic Highways series takes full advantage of Grohl’s unique status as a punk-spawned celebrity to deftly intertwine mainstream and underground rock histories. For instance
column3: so far we've seen how Chicago-blues icons like Buddy Guy and noisy nihilists like Big Black were both fueled by the same impoverished necessity
column4: or how hardcore pioneers Minor Threat and go-go greats Trouble Funk shone a light on the Washington that lurks in the shadow of Capitol Hill. As a promotional film for a new Foo Fighters album
column5: however
column6: it makes you wonder why its trailblazing subjects’ transgressive influence didn’t seep into the sound of final product.

column1: Though it's all relative
column2: Sonic Highways is the most adventurous Foo Fighters album to date
column3: but it bends their trusty template in ways that bear little relation to the project’s underlying musical-history-tour gambit. (It’s not like hanging out with Bad Brains inspired a sharp left turn into light-speed D.C. hardcore
column4: or digging up Roky Erickson’s roots in Austin has introduced sunbaked psychedelia into the mix.) Rather
column5: at eight tracks and 42 minutes
column6: Sonic Highways is paradoxically the Foos’ leanest record while boasting their most sprawling compositions
column7: taking a more scenic route to their usual destinations.

column1: Where most Foo Fighters songs have shown their hand by the first chorus
column2: the highlights here gradually build up in step-like fashion: “Something From Nothing” may boast a typically teeth-clenching Foos climax
column3: but it rides a surprisingly funky (if uncannily Dio-esque) organ groove to get there; “What Did I Do?/God As My Witness” stays well within Grohl’s power-pop pocket
column4: but its stop-start/two-part structure suggests Big Star’s “Back of a Car” given a musical-theater makeover. And even songs that travel a straight-and-narrow path have a welcome sense of patience about them
column5: revealing new melodic nuances along the way (like on the dreamy jangle-pop of “Subterranean”) or
column6: in the case of ""Congregation""
column7: unexpected dynamic shifts: what starts off as a standard-issue
column8: cruise-controlled rocker in the “Learn to Fly”/“Times Like These” mold acquires a more intense energy
column9: thanks to an extended soul-stomping breakdown buoyed by Zac Brown’s finger-picking.

column1: But given the great logistical effort that went into the album’s creation—and the fanboy reverence Grohl exhibits toward his interview subjects on each ""Sonic Highways"" episode—it’s unfortunate that the regional essence of a given a song is barely perceptible without the televised exposition. Beyond illustrating that upbeat pop-punk is an odd forum for a discussion of the '68 D.C. race riots (see: “The Feast and the Famine"")
column2: the album boasts a bounty of special-guest ambassadors who are given little room to assert their personalities amid the Foos’ chromatic crunch: the New Orleans Preservation Jazz Band doesn’t have much to do on “In the Clear” but chirp up its mid-tempo riff; Joe Walsh’s bluesy fills get lost in the fast lane of “Outside”; and good luck parsing out the presence of Joan Jett on “I Am a River”
column3: a gaudy Macy’s Day Parade of a power ballad that
column4: just when you think can’t get any more overblown
column5: piles on a false ending and string-section finale. The composite cityscape seen on Sonic Highways’ front cover proves to be all-too emblematic of the album’s overall sound: a hodgepodge of aesthetic signifiers that get swallowed up into a monolithic whole.

column1: Watching ""Sonic Highways""
column2: you get the sense that the real purpose of the whole endeavor wasn’t so much to reinterpret the musical traditions of a given city as simply broaden Grohl’s lyrical perspective beyond his usual relationship-focussed ruminations and self-help affirmations. In some of the episodes that have aired so far
column3: we see a shot of Grohl sitting down after completing his interviews to write a song based on all the local lore he’s absorbed; the episodes then conclude with the Foos performing the resultant track
column4: as the lyrics—loaded with knowing references to “muddy water
column5: ” “the 13th floor
column6: ” and “bluebirds”—are splashed across the screen practically begging for I-see-what-you-did-there acknowledgement. Ironically
column7: in trying to tap into the mystique of America’s most storied cities
column8: Foo Fighters completely demystify their own creative process
column9: effectively turning the Sonic Highways project into a glorified homework assignment—educational
column10: perhaps
column11:
but laboriously procedural.  

"|19864.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19864-foo-fighters-sonic-highways/|5.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21172/homepage_large.0d230047.jpg|Asleep Versions EP|27655.0|Jon Hopkins|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2014-11-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:06.553724|"

There was plenty to love about the rhythms and melodies of Jon Hopkins' Immunity
column2: but its eight productions were especially captivating because of the depth and detail with which he constructed them. The Brian Eno protégé and collaborator allows no sample to go unaltered and no synth to go unprocessed; even the peripherals of Immunity are meticulous and substantial enough to reward closer listening. It's fitting
column3: then
column4: that Hopkins revisits his material on the Asleep Versions EP
column5: stripping it down and recontextualizing the subtleties in lush ambient compositions.

column1: Starting with Immunity's titular closer
column2: Hopkins re-works four Immunity highlights in reverse order
column3: taking care to dismantle the heavy crackle of beats which defined ""Form by Firelight""
column4: ""Breathe This Air""
column5: and ""Open Eye Signal"". The space left over from his excavation remains unfilled
column6: leaving simple piano chords
column7: pattering percussion
column8: field recordings
column9: and vocal elements enough room to realize their full potential. You learn when listening to the new version of ""Immunity"" that maybe Scottish singer King Creosote's humbling vibrato should've always had a place at the forefront of Hopkins' original mix.

column1: Recorded in Mosfellsbær
column2: Iceland (just outside of Reykjavik)
column3: Asleep Versions was conceived as a single piece of music
column4: and it works best that way. Each section of the 25-minute recording flows seamlessly together
column5: thanks largely to its shared wintry chill. Hopkins' characteristic attention to detail feels further pronounced when he treats such subtle shifts in tone with austerity and drama. ""Open Eye Signal (Asleep Version)"" drifts on seven minutes of glacial pads and choral voices before a lone piano surfaces to give the EP its serene finale. All of which is preceded by the slow-coming flurry in ""Breathe This Air (Asleep Version)""
column6: sounding like a restrained Tim Hecker with its crystalline synth flicker
column7: weighty bass drops
column8: and smears of tonal texture. Maybe Icelandic winters just bring a certain kind of frozen majesty out of electronic producers.

column1: Whether it's the pap-pap-pap of a live xylophone or muffled thuds and brittle ticks hinting at a rhythmic structure
column2: the record often feels haunted by Immunity's beats
column3: like ghosts unreconciled with their forcible extraction. That quality does well to diversify what might've otherwise been a typical addition to the lineage of ""ambient versions"" in electronic music
column4:
and helps complement Hopkins' brilliant fourth album by never trying to overshadow his original work.

Otis Redding and Phil Collins have little in common save for one trivial bit: they both began their respective careers as drummers. Pat Mahoney isn’t quite in that category yet
column2: but after watching his indefatigable energy (and running shorts) seated behind the drum kit as he powered LCD Soundsystem for a decade
column3: it’s startling to realize that the honeyed vocals heard on Museum of Love’s debut album belong to him.

column1: Even beyond that prominent role in the label’s flagship act
column2: Mahoney and bandmate Dennis McNany are already DFA family. The latter released a handful of singles as Jee Day
column3: lent a hand to Shit Robot’s We Got a Love
column4: mixed a Panthers single
column5: and even recorded a track for the Rapture. But rather than shade towards LCD’s sound
column6: Museum of Love pull from the playbook of DFA’s other big band
column7: Holy Ghost!
column8: favoring the timbres
column9: patch settings
column10: and smooth productions of elegant 1980s new wave and nu-romantic acts.

column1: After the minute-long instrumental opener ""Horizonlator""
column2: Mahoney’s voice is front and center on ""Down South""
column3: and it’s such a dead ringer for Bryan Ferry in his Roxy Music prime—right down to his aching near-sigh—that it makes you wonder how such a secret weapon was not deployed on an LCD single. Even during Nirvana's heyday
column4: Kurt Cobain let Dave Grohl sing on a B-side. And as Mahoney gets his voice to soar towards a falsetto and then swoop down into a lower register
column5: McNany has his battery of synths shadow him
column6: making for a dynamic track that keeps revealing new surprises across its runtime. But the favor is returned when Mahoney’s tireless disco hi-hat patterns entwine with McNany’s distorted thumb piano riff on the more uptempo polyrhythmic track ""In Infancy"".

column1: Gentle arpeggios open ""FATHERS""
column2: again buoying Mahoney’s heartbreaking falsetto
column3: which this time balances equal parts Ferry and Mark Hollis circa Talk Talk’s debut. Glints of other bands appear and withdraw throughout the album
column4: be it Art of Noise (check the ""Moments in Love"" exhalations in the background of ""Learned Helplessness in Rats (Disco Drummer)"")
column5: Spandau Ballet
column6: Level 42
column7: Ultravox and more
column8: but the duo is careful to not allow such grace notes turn into direct homages.

column1: The album’s centerpiece and first single ""The Who’s Who of Who Cares"" starts off as the perfect track to segue from something like Todd Terje’s ""Inspector Norse""
column2: a spry Italo synth riff augmented by a dry drum machine tock. Mahoney intimately coos as horns and female voices dart in and out of the mix. For a track with such insouciance in its chorus
column3: Mahoney nevertheless conveys the deepest sincerity.

column1: That crafty juxtaposition of conflicting sentiments also comes to the fore on ""Monotronic""
column2: a dreamy song that
column3: heard post-election
column4: seems to have gained resonance overnight. A jittery yet narcotized keyboard motif that could come from any Cluster album moves behind a sleepy Mahoney vocal
column5: who murmurs indolent first-world problem lines like: ""I wasn’t made for this much happiness"" and ""The waking world was never meant for me."" But as the song picks up momentum and starts to crest
column6: Mahoney’s voice pivots and midway through the track
column7: a deeper commentary comes into play: ""Welcome to our nation/ With its fatal concentration of wealth and loss/ All we know for certain is that we could bear the burden of waking up."" So when Mahoney comes back to the admission about ""this much happiness
column8:
that once-sweet voice now has just a hint of bitterness and resignation to it.

Mark Perro and Nick Chiericozzi are probably the last guys on Earth who need a side project. Not only has the band they co-founded
column2: the Men
column3: maintained a prolific rate of production (with five albums and two EPs in the past five years)
column4: they’ve been able to bend its sound to satisfy their every passing whim
column5: be it loogie-hocking scum-punk
column6: wood-cabin country rock
column7: atomic psychedelia
column8: or old-school '80s indie. And yet
column9: they’re not ones to spend their days off between tours getting caught up on ""The Walking Dead"". Much of their downtime since 2010 has been devoted to Dream Police
column10: where
column11: with the help of producer Kyle Keays-Hagerman and a trusty drum machine
column12: they’ve been workshopping song ideas that exist on the peripheries of the Men’s elastic sound
column13: but aren’t really suited to that band’s five-man attack.

column1: While Perro and Chiericozzi have previously issued Dream Police material in limited-edition cassette runs
column2: they couldn’t have picked a better time to release their first proper album for Sacred Bones. On last spring’s Tomorrow’s Hits
column3: the Men sounded like they were settling into a cozy
column4: classic-rock cul de sac
column5: sanding down the edges of their punk and country influences into an easy-going boogie. Though it was a notable adjustment
column6: it didn’t open up any unexplored avenues for the band. So the robotic rhythms
column7: laser-beam synths
column8: and industrialized guitar noise that form the foundation of Hypnotized introduce welcome new dimensions to Perro and Chiericozzi’s sonic palette
column9: and encourage a renewed streak of irreverent experimentation for a couple of guys who appeared to be digging in their heels. But while Hypnotized nudges Perro and Chiericozzi out of their established comfort zone
column10: it also has the effect of making you appreciate the tightened-up craft and finely curated song selection they exhibit with the Men.

column1: Hypnotized proves be a far more eclectic affair than initially suggested by its title-track single
column2: which is exactly the sort of electro-blooze stomp you’d expect from a couple of scruffy rockers tinkering around with synthetic beats. The spectrum here spans Teutonic post-punk to somber psych-folk (really
column3: pretty much every subgenre of rock except the arena-ready power-pop suggested by Dream Police’s Cheap Trick-nodding name)
column4: but several songs simply stretch out a one-note idea until there’s nothing more to do: the bass-grooved ""My Mama’s Dead"" imagines ""Hey Joe"" being half-remembered by a megaphone-wielding Mark E. Smith; ""John"" is a repetitious blues swing akin to the Stooges’ ""I Need Somebody""
column5: but sapped of the menacing desperation. And though Dream Police carry over the Men tradition of penning acoustic odes to girls
column6: the downcast lysergic lullaby ""Iris"" (appended with what can only be described in 2014 as ""beer-commercial guitar"") and highlands-bound hymn ""Sandy"" (a church-bell-clanging duet between Chiericozzi and Brooklyn artist Holly Overton) feel more random and out of place in this mechanized context than they would on a Men record
column7: suggesting Perro and Chiericozzi may need to start yet another
column8: folk-focused project to accommodate their unplugged urges.

column1: The most successful experiments here don’t simply add tech textures to Perro and Chiericozzi’s guitar grind
column2: but use them to reshape it
column3: and invest the duo’s muscular crunch with a more androgynous energy: ""Pouring Rain"" folds early-'80s skinny-tie standards like A Flock of Seagulls’ ""I Ran (So Far Away)"" or Martha and the Muffins’ ""Echo Beach"" into late-'80s post-hardcore screech
column4: while ""Let It Be"" is a glorious Neu!-wave instrumental that reroutes the Autobahn through the American heartland
column5: its synth-smoothed pave job nicked with countrified slide-guitar licks. Of course
column6: it figures that a couple of studious rock historians like Perro and Chiericozzi would cop a title that their heroes the Replacements likewise stole from the Beatles. But in this case
column7: the song is less an explicit tribute to the classics of yore than an embodiment of the title’s contented
column8:
live-and-let-live sentiment—and an indicator that Dream Police do their best work when roaming lawless fantasias.

If you recognize the name Elisa Ambrogio from her persevering role in noise-rock guerillas Magik Markers
column2: you’ll likely find the suggestion that the first song from The Immoralist
column3: her debut solo album
column4: be re-recorded by a major pop star in an expensive studio to be a ridiculous one. Sure
column5: as Magik Markers surpassed the half-decade barrier
column6: some of their songs pulled back on the earlier feedback and distortion
column7: the ruptured rhythms and full-band hysterics. BOSS
column8: for instance
column9: featured tunes that might have been college-rock singles for the right DJ
column10: like the slinking ""Taste"" or the build-to-burn piano tune
column11: ""Four/The Ballad of Harry Angstrom"". But as late as last year’s Surrender to the Fantasy
column12: Magik Markers had hardly normalized. That album opened with ""Crebs""
column13: a steady snarl that slowly interred itself in scorched-amp hiss and fuzz. Magik Markers are less active and aggressive than they once were
column14: but they’re still not exactly the kind of band you’d leave alone in a room with a potential pop hit and a mixing board. It might get messy.

column1: But ""Superstitious""
column2: which cracks open with quickened-pulse drums and radiant piano chords
column3: feels like the first draft of a song and structure suited for popular consumption—not blogs
column4: but the top of Billboard. For all of Magik Markers’ ripostes and pugnacity
column5: this is a disarming love song about falling for someone so deeply that you give up your lack of belief in the supernatural
column6: for fear of ruining what you’ve found. ""I cross my fingers
column7: baby/ I touch every tree
column8: Ambrogio sings
column9: multi-tracked but humble harmonies crisscrossing behind her. ""I block the paths of black cats/ To keep you loving me."" During the song’s four minutes
column10: Jason Quever’s marching-band drums push ahead of the piano
column11: and the background vocals grow bigger and bolder. But the tune barely changes
column12: treating the sweetly declarative refrain just like the illustrative verses. It feels like a full-band version of a tune begging to become electronic pop
column13: to explode into one final
column14: overloaded chorus. You can imagine Sylvan Esso or Phantogram pushing it to new heights
column15: or even Katy Perry during her days of Teenage Dream. Magik Markers never had a chance with this one.

column1: That introduction isn’t an outlier
column2: either: About half of The Immoralist suggests low-budget renditions of tracks meant for bigger spaces and studios. ""Stopped Clocks"" is an anxious
column3: agitated pop-punk romp
column4: where Ambrogio turns the jargon of paranoia into an irresistible hook over an irrepressible beat. And ""Reservoir"" drifts through aestival reverie
column5: steady piano chords
column6: and circling guitar riffs guiding her soft approach into romantic escapism. ""Taking hands
column7: making fools of ourselves
column8: she offers with alluring calm. ""I don’t want this no one else."" And with its aphorisms about death
column9: details about life and generally flawless hook
column10: you can imagine the haze and drone lifting from behind piano-and-cello closer ""Arkansas"" like morning dew
column11: moving the tune from the domain of Grouper to Sam Smith.

column1: But those budget hits and the appearance of Waka Flocka on the album’s cover as a stand-in for Ambrogio shouldn’t trick you into thinking she’s given up on her more plangent past. Even the most radio-ready songs warp in some way
column2: whether it’s the tidal harmonium drone that introduces that sweeping finale or the hard-angled
column3: distortion-pocked counter-riffs of ""Stopped Clocks"". Ambrogio slinks into the fragmented poetry of Body/Head for ""Kylie""
column4: a discursive and forlorn look at a former friend
column5: maybe a pretty party girl
column6: whose life has slipped into depressive solitude. During ""Clarinet Queen""
column7: Ambrogio alludes to her noise associations with a particularly brittle guitar solo
column8: here a crooked exclamation mark cut into the middle of an otherwise downcast number. By the time ""Far From Home"" ends
column9: it’s stumbled into drifting sections of gentle coos and cymbal crashes. But it builds in a fit of static and squall until
column10: by the end
column11: the song breaks into a rhythm-less shriek of guitar. Where Magik Markers might’ve once caught that jagged thread and ziplined toward a fisticuffs
column12: though
column13: Ambrogio simply moves along to ""Stopped Clocks"".

column1: If it sounds like Ambrogio is sitting on a fence during The Immoralist
column2: she is. She’s an exceptional songwriter
column3: with a touch for hooks that withstand production choices or context. This has been apparent in Magik Markers for at least half of that band’s life. But she also comes from a lineage of punk pranksters and art-rock iconoclasts
column4: musicians who’d rather destroy a song altogether than see it played too straight. Ambrogio
column5: at this point
column6: seems undecided
column7: and that’s for better and worse. That indecision turns The Immoralist into an intriguing listen
column8: a sort of garden of forking paths. Could she make a pop record in earnest
column9: or would she even want to? Or will her work always entail a measure of transgression
column10:
no matter the triumph of the material?

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21147/homepage_large.3829453e.jpg|Clark|4987.0|Clark|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2014-11-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:09.661998|"

The world is ending
column2: and Chris Clark is writing its soundtrack. In the 35-year-old electronic producer’s latest dystopian vision
column3: the Earth’s layers peel back with painstaking certainty while everything else bursts and pops in unrest. Temperatures flash between frostbite and flame. There are moments of unsettling calm
column4: only to be ruptured by bruised sky
column5: acid rain
column6: famine
column7: disease. Unknown beings attack
column8: armed with tones set to bewilder. Somewhere
column9: the sound of a muffled Billie Holiday acetate being mauled by a pack of lions echoes through the murk. There is last-chance dancing—or are those people just running away?

column1: As far as end-times scenarios go
column2: the one Clark sets forth on his eponymous seventh album is vivid. And while there’s plenty of terror to be found here
column3: Clark resonates because it pinpoints both the humanity and the nothingness that come along with complete dread; he knows that in order for annihilation to mean anything
column4: you have to care about what’s being annihilated. Because for every laser-burned bass kick and alien-probe synth
column5: forces of good cautiously look out from the rubble in the form of twinkling lullabies and melancholic piano loops. In cinematic sci-fi terms—and it’s hard not to think of this record as a kind of headphone IMAX experience—Clark is more akin to Alfonso Cuarón’s devastating infertility parable Children of Men than
column6: say
column7: Independence Day: ominous because its pulse feels all too real.

column1: At this point
column2: Clark has been translating his wracked emotions via machines—samplers
column3: software
column4: synths—for about half his life
column5: and Clark has him merging techno
column6: electro
column7: noise
column8: classical
column9: ambient
column10: and post-rock with the skill of a virtuoso. Growing up just outside of London
column11: he indulged in nascent omnivorous Internet-era listening habits
column12: giving time to indie rap
column13: Pavement
column14: and Squarepusher as a teen before Warp deemed him next-in-line to their mindful electronic throne at the start of this century. Though it was probably unfair to expect Clark to live up to the legacies of Aphex Twin and Boards of Canada
column15: it was also inevitable. But with his third album
column16: 2006’s Body Riddle
column17: he quietly did just that
column18: turning in an opus that moved the sounds of Warp’s classic 1990s roster forward
column19: mixing sensuousness and mechanics to create a 21st century cyborg touchstone.

column1: Owing to the mercurial nature of his tracks
column2: which often morph unexpectedly many times across just a few minutes
column3: follow-up Turning Dragon was nearly as excellent but utterly different
column4: trading in spectral atmosphere and hip-hop rhythms for a more full-on techno thrust. And after five years of frustratingly diffuse material that had the producer grasping at new styles and textures with mixed success
column5: Clark is a much-welcomed return that locates the midpoint between Body Riddle’s tangibility and Turning Dragon’s bulletproof sheen. The album adds a fresh layer of grandiosity that hints at festival-sized dance music or even Trent Reznor’s churning soundtrack work while never bowing down to any type of current trend. Clark is like Aphex’s comeback Syro in that it showcases a veteran artist living and breathing within a sonic space of his own creation—and the fact that no one would confuse the two records is a testament to Clark’s hard-won individuality.

column1: What’s always set Clark apart is his eclecticism
column2: dynamism
column3: and flair for the dramatic
column4: all of which is on fine display here. His tracks don’t drop as much as they slip or swerve
column5: forever off-balance. He’ll end a techno album with eight minutes of beatless
column6: sky-cracking ecstasy you’d expect to find on a Sigur Rós LP
column7: and it will make sense. He’s allergic to the idea of standard sounds and presets
column8: which is partly why we’re still talking about him 13 years after his debut. And unlike many of his more insular peers
column9: Clark can be open to sentimentality—not schmaltz as much as a belief in humanness and all its inexact wonder. In electronic music’s never-ending battle between man and machine
column10: he’s seeking a third way. “It's just far too easy these days
column11: ” he said in an interview earlier this year
column12: talking about the copy-and-paste replicability of so much modern composition. “I'm often inspired by the path of most resistance. Looking for those tiny snippets of error—machines being pushed into areas of behavior that seem wrong and unusable. There is real fruit there.”

column1: Rather than fighting the SoundCloud hivemind with real people playing real instruments
column2: à la Daft Punk’s Random Access Memories
column3: he composed Clark largely on a computer by himself in a barn in the middle of the English countryside
column4: cracking codes and inflicting glitches. As computerized watches and glasses inch toward ubiquity
column5: this idea of subverting machines to make them more human seems like a particularly worthy preservation strategy—and nobody does that quite like Clark. Yes
column6:
he makes music that sounds like the end of the world. But he also makes you want to live long enough to see what that will look like.
