Do Deerhoof ever get bored? In a revolving gallery of evaporative avant-pop weirdos
column3: they churn out album after distinctive album without ever breaching self-parody. As an aesthetic conceit
column4: ""weird"" only works as long as it's novel—if you're going to wallow in it for two decades
column5: you'd better be prepared to regenerate yourself constantly. But Deerhoof make music like a group of friends who never get sick of each other's jokes. Their 13th album
column6: La Isla Bonita
column7: is among their most accessible
column8: reaching for moments of escapism that never entered the frame on 2012's Breakup Songs.

column1: Between the album's title and the name of its first track
column2: ""Paradise Girls""
column3: La Isla Bonita promises tropical hues that it only delivers superficially. On a mechanical level
column4: it functions the way Deerhoof's music has always functioned: isolated lyrical snippets pop in and out
column5: refusing to cohere into a narrative
column6: while the guitar
column7: drums
column8: and bass alternately concoct blissful grooves and total disorientation. Deerhoof thrive in the space between the sugar you want and the acid you get.

column1: They're generous with their ironies on La Isla Bonita
column2: starting with ""Paradise Girls""
column3: a song that inverts its own premise. The title calls to mind women's bodies presented as set decoration for a steamy male utopia—ad copy for sleazy West Coast entertainment. Satomi Matsuzaki's lyrics counter that expectation by describing girls who make their very own paradise: ""Girls/ Who play the bass guitar...Girls/ Who are smart."" Rumbles of her bass mingle with John Dieterich's itchy guitar riffs and Greg Saunier's spacious drumbeats.

column1: Breakup Songs leaned heavily on anemic synthesizer sounds to round out its eerie
column2: space-age profile
column3: but with La Isla Bonita
column4: Deerhoof sink back into punk rock's bare bones just to see how much they can crank out of them. With a purely organic template behind her
column5: Matsuzaki's voice finds new pockets of space to fill
column6: which helps her nail in her nonsensical lines even deeper. Run through the sour
column7: bass-driven groove of ""Last Fad"" a few times
column8: and you'll have no idea how the words ""Baseball is canceled/ it is running late"" keep getting stuck in your head. It doesn't matter—they're there. Matsuzaki slips them in so skillfully you'll want to adopt them as a catchphrase for when everything goes wrong: ""Fuck it! Baseball is canceled!""

column1: The record's climax ""Black Pitch"" sweeps Deerhoof's tight patterns into a satisfying pop catharsis. It starts with something like a threat: ""We're gonna want you/ We're gonna want you/ We're gonna want you 24/7
column2: Matsuzaki insists. The riffs behind her stay nervous; Saunier's drums shift and shake. And then the song crests. Matsuzaki sings over herself as if from far away
column3: stretching her syllables until the backing drops out and it's just her and her own echoes
column4: alone in the void.

column1: A big part of Deerhoof's power comes from their inscrutability. They've got the rare talent of affecting emotion without supplying a direct line into any kind of inner narrative
column2: of inspiring release in the abstract. La Isla Bonita doesn't solve any mysteries
column3:
but it does cut some new faces on a band that feeds on its own newness. 

"|19917.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19917-deerhoof-la-isla-bonita/|7.6|Sasha Geffen

column1: <div><i>Money Sucks
column2: Friends Rule is Dillon Francis' first full-length after a string of EPs and singles that broke moombahton big (well
column3: bigger) in the States. And while there've been glimpses of what he can pull off when he's not in his usual flippantly goofy mode
column4: like the warm
column5: oddly moving electro-house sleeper ""Without You""
column6: this intended breakthrough album pushes him out to the wider world as the man that nuance forgot. He can put together crowdpleasing music that pushes all the right buttons at the right moments
column7:
and his lack of shame when it comes to giving his pop upbringing its due hints at the potential versatility of his status in a world where EDM is one of the few new ideas pop's stuck to recently. But it's hard to get to the core of what his music does and where its inspiration really comes from without his public persona's living-meme goofiness getting in the way. 

It happened to every youth-energy genre
column8: and lowest-common-denominator EDM isn't immune
column9: either: at some point
column10: a major player in the music eventually mistakes stupidity for rebellion. Now making stupid shit isn't a crime in itself. Subversive idiocy in action is when Country Joe & the Fish led Woodstock in a mass cheerleading effort to spell out the word ""FUCK"" before launching into their dark-humored
column11: fatalist 'Nam-War hillbilly eyepoke ""I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-to-Die Rag"". Not to bring it up as the fifty-thousandth example of attempting to prove how right-on the Baby Boom generation was or anything; It's just to note that Money Sucks has a track
column12: ""What's That Spell?""
column13: that lifts the ""gimme an F"" (and so on) from that cheer and is pretty much fine with leaving things there. We're at a point long after that word alone has seemed dangerous and long before we appear done with shipping soldiers overseas
column14: so what's the point?

column1: <div><span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">With an edgy jokester's built-in defense mechanism (what're you
column2: humorless?)
column3: coupled with his defiant belief that dropping a bunch of blatant pop crossovers into Money Sucks can still be a true-to-self move
column4: it's almost like he's daring purists and tightasses to roll their eyes.But if that's a source of cred for his fanbase
column5: it's going to have to make up for the cred lost with the album's directionless eclecticism. Never mind if it's a sellout or not—it's just a mess
column6: and makes Francis' claim in an early-October Billboard interview that an album of wall-to-wall club songs ""is not going to be interesting to anyone"" look tone-deaf. Does Twista's land-speed-record schtick fail to hide how little he (or anyone) has to say about hater-callout VIP-section fellatio trawling? Does Panic! At the Disco's Brendon Urie try to Jim Steinman his way through histrionic nonsense and assembled Springsteen/Stooges lyric lifts on ""Love in the Middle of a Firefight""? Do the Presets sound like an emergency airlift from 2005's indie-electro heyday dropped into the blankest caricature of that style imaginable?

column1: There's still a fair amount of stuff that fits more of what you might expect from a Mad Decent hedonist. And that's fine if you don't mind both-kinds-of-dense faux-Arabian rich-kid twerkbait (DJ Snake collab ""Get Low""
column2: which won't make you forget either 2003 or 2013 Lil Jon)
column3: grating vocal chops that careen through dizzying pitch shifts (""I Can't Take It"")
column4:
and an overwhelming reliance on building machine-gun crescendo/underwhelming drop structures that are five minutes from becoming the decade's big musical self-parody moment. Which is another joke not worth telling.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21123/homepage_large.de7ccd23.jpg|Mind Fair|30004.0|Mind Fair|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Golf Channel']|2014-11-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:11.386220|"

""I'm your New York City woman/ You're my New York City man
column2: goes the refrain of Mind Fair's ""Take Me to the Bridge""
column3: a kinda Fleetwood-Mac-gone-disco single the duo released this summer in anticipation of their debut LP. Those words may be true for guest vocalists Charmaine Baines and Lauren Faulkner
column4: but it'd definitely be a stretch to call Dean Meredith and Ben Shenton ""New York City men."" And that disconnect
column5: of course
column6: is part of the great charm of the Mind Fair project
column7: in which two Brits do their damnedest to pass as Americans. And not just any Americans
column8: but Downtown disco denizens of the 1980s—with a ragged Woodstock freak flag dangling from their back pockets
column9: for good measure.

column1: A quarter-century ago
column2: Meredith was a member of Bizarre Inc.
column3: a British acid house act that briefly served as an intermediary between the rave scene and the pop charts. Since then
column4: he has spent most of his career pushing in the opposite direction—not following electronic music's progress into the future so much as burrowing back towards a mythical
column5: prelapsarian moment
column6: pre-rave culture
column7: when disco and electronics and dub collided for the first time. If the search for the wellspring of soulful electronic dance music is something of a fool's errand
column8: perhaps that explains why he's come at it from so many angles: the dubbed-out disco of his group Chicken Lips; the even dubbier
column9: On-U-influenced Big Two Hundred; the Italo-flavored White Light Circus; and a dozen other bands and aliases
column10: many with the same small handful of associates
column11: like Andrew Meecham
column12: Steve Kotey
column13: and Ben Shenton.

column1: In the past three years
column2: Mind Fair have released nearly a dozen singles or EPs of woozy
column3: nostalgic dance music
column4: post-disco and proto-house. They established the outlines of their sound on their very first single: at one end
column5: the loosey-goosey disco of ""Kerry's Scene""
column6: complete with copious piano riffing and live electric bass; at the other end
column7: the unplugged
column8: back-porch blues of ""Mind Fair""
column9: complete with harmonica and acoustic guitar. With Mind Fair
column10: their debut album
column11: they dial up the rock quotient and really let their hair down. The album sounds like the product of a week locked in someone's apartment
column12: fueled by tequila and mushrooms
column13: and while it's unclear exactly who did what—along with their own machines and electric bass
column14: the album credits a handful of musicians for percussion
column15: ukulele
column16: and vocals—it scans as a joyful ruckus
column17: a communal frenzy.

column1: After an introduction of organ grind and fun-fair clang
column2: they dive straight into the fray with ""Green Fingers""
column3: a pulse-raising fusion of late-'70s disco/rap percussion—extra-dry drum-machine patterns overlaid with rolling congas—and searing acid rock guitars. It's reminiscent of Big Audio Dynamite and
column4: even more so
column5: James Blood Ulmer's 1984 single ""Eye Level""
column6: in which the jazz/funk/blues guitarist was accompanied by the Pop Group drummer Bruce Smith and On-U producer Adrian Sherwood. ""So Morose"" is another blues-heavy number
column7: this time with a far cleaner hook and a one-note bassline
column8: plus some organ riffing in the background. It's one of the album's most focused grooves
column9: and one of its best
column10: with a real first-thought-best-thought immediacy to it. Venturing further out
column11: ""Deutsche Bag"" drizzles tautly plucked guitar and a misty layer of Frippertronics over declarative tuned toms
column12: with distant chants and the odd splash of organ adding faint tone color. As it goes on
column13: the tonal center just disappears. It's not often you find a club track that's so unafraid to go for broke. Depending on the dosage in the punch
column14: it's not hard to imagine it reducing the dancefloor to a writhing mass
column15: naked and speaking in tongues.

column1: Given the jam-oriented structures and the limited tonal palette
column2: one's appreciation for the record will have a lot to do with one's predisposition for bluesy electric guitar over shuddering drum machines. ""Cursed"" repurposes the trills of Cymande's ""Bra"" over a ""Rapper's Delight""-inspired break and piles on ukulele and harmonica; ""U Got the Lovin'"" adds some flute to the mix. But there's enough variety to keep things interesting. ""Voodoo Train""
column3: with its wordless chants and grunts and mewls over oodles of rolling hand percussion
column4: evokes Arthur Russell and Matias Aguayo. ""Neon Carnival""
column5: with its clean-lined synth arpeggios and clipped sax bleats
column6: revisits Chicken Lips' groove-heavy stomping ground. ""Mushroom Blues""—the title is pretty much a dead giveaway—rolls out the acid-rock guitars over a ""Wax the Van""-style groove
column7: pretty much as good a way to close the album as any. Before that
column8: the bass-and-guitar counterpoints of ""Find Me at the Fair"" sound a hell of a lot like Minutemen
column9: and when's the last time you could say you heard their influence in a dance record?

column1: The one thing that feels missing is a proper singer. Despite the presence of four credited vocalists
column2: those vocals never play a central role—which is fine. But given the jammy
column3: freeform qualities of their playing
column4: Mind Fair could stand to have the occasional element to pull it all together. The melodic hook was what made ""Take Me to the Bridge"" so indelible. But give 'em time; theirs is a New York of the mind
column5:
rent-controlled and immune to gentrification. Nobody's going to be forcing them out any time soon. 

"|19883.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19883-mind-fair-mind-fair/|7.0|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21122/homepage_large.ee7ca7fb.jpg|A Song for Echo|30754.0|Ricardo Donoso|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kathexis']|2014-11-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:11.899196|"

A Song for Echo is something new for Ricardo Donoso. Since 2011
column2: the solo recordings of the Brazilian-born composer and producer
column3: a Berklee graduate and sometimes death-metal drummer
column4: have been concerned primarily with the expressive potential of synthesizers. Progress Chance
column5: Assimilating the Shadow
column6: and <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18745-ricardo-donoso-as-iron-sharpens-iron-one-verse-sharpens-anther/"" target=""_blank""><i>As Iron Sharpens Iron
column7: One Verse Sharpens Another brim with quicksilver frequencies
column8: gravelly formants
column9: and shimmering
column10: mirage-like washes of tone. Sometimes his sounds are reminiscent of physical instruments like pipe organs; more often
column11: they feel like signals picked up by a radio telescope
column12: or pure electricity poured through a sieve.

column1: Those records were just as concerned with the expressive potential of sequencers—hardware devices
column2: and sometimes virtual instruments
column3: used for triggering arpeggiated patterns of notes as well as the filters and effects that color them. Reduced to simple contrapuntal phrases
column4: Donoso's sequences came across like glistening series of dewdrops arrayed across spiders' webs vibrating in midair. Shorn of the drums that would scan as ""techno
column5: they felt less like dance music and more like perpetual motion machines. Earlier this year
column6: with Nitrogen Narcosis
column7: released under his Scuba Death alias on Seattle's Further label
column8: he delved more explicitly into dancefloor aesthetics—albeit slowed down by half and still almost percussion-free
column9: save for a dull kick drum buried deep in the mix. But here
column10: on the inaugural release for his own Kathexis label
column11: he switches up his process
column12: eschewing the safety net of repetitive beats and expanding his palette to include a wealth of electro-acoustic material of uncertain provenance.

column1: Divided into seven roman-numeraled parts
column2: the 29-minute album feels very much like a film score; it proceeds seamlessly from one segment to the next
column3: and it's heavy on atmosphere but light on song-like structure. And
column4: in fact
column5: it is a film score; Donoso's music is the accompaniment to Julie Nymann's film of the same name
column6: a re-telling of the Echo and Narcissus myth created specifically for a 360-degree surround-image projection in the Boston Museum of Science's Charles Hayden Planetarium. That immersive dimension helps contextualize the music's slow
column7: shifting movements.

column1: The album opens with resonant drones reminiscent of Seefeel's Succour; bells and plucked-metal synthesizers chime against a backdrop that might be airplanes buzzing high overhead. A thudding pulse lends a hint of dub techno; midrange arpeggios
column2: echoing Monolake's carefully sculpted arrangements
column3: flash like goldfish darting through muddy ponds. It's occasionally reminiscent of Vladislav Delay's early
column4: abstracted work; the massing drones and bowed bass and scraping sheets of metal also suggest the Haxan Cloak's waxy horror. As the album proceeds
column5: it builds into something almost overpowering—an enormous basso throb accompanied by the grating sound of knives being sharpened
column6: metal gates swinging back and forth in the wind; swollen reverb sings the wind-tunnel blues. And then
column7: like a storm passing overhead
column8: it all fades to silence.

column1: Speaking to Marc Masters and Grayson Currin for their column The Out Door
column2: Donoso described A Song for Echo as ""a springboard
column3: noting
column4: ""all the ideas on it are still very much segregated
column5: naked & exposed—much like Progress Chance was. Slowly
column6: over the next few releases—these building blocks will evolve into much deeper & developed structures."" There's plenty of room for him to develop the ideas broached here; rhythmically and texturally
column7: A Song for Echo sounds like he's just beginning to blaze a trail that leads beyond the limits of the Digitalis trilogy. But it's exciting to hear Donoso reconnecting
column8: however tentatively
column9: with the intensity of his metal band
column10: Ehnahre. If Echo is the sound of stormclouds massing
column11:
perhaps the deluge is just around the corner. 

"|19882.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19882-ricardo-donoso-a-song-for-echo/|7.5|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21182/homepage_large.363e0f58.jpg|Sings Christmas Carols|2331.0|Mark Kozelek|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Caldo Verde']|2014-11-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:12.372528|"

Timing is everything. We’ve known for a while that Mark Kozelek was going to be releasing a Christmas album before the end of the year
column2: but for much of that time Kozelek was riding a wave of goodwill following the release of (the still very good
column3: even if I’ve stopped bringing it up at parties) Benji. Now Sings Christmas Carols finally comes out and it feels like an unwanted present from the obnoxious uncle you try and avoid at family gatherings. What happened in between? Kozelek saw the reaction he got from a typically cranky and offhand comment about War on Drugs’ music bleeding into his own at a festival and somehow thought releasing not one but two songs about it a would be amusing to someone other than himself (plus a t-shirt with another insult). Suffice to say the joke isn’t funny anymore
column4: and Kozelek is looking pretty sad
column5: not to mention that he’s probably alienating new fans he may have acquired since Benji’s release. And now we’re supposed to allow him into our homes and into Mom and Dad’s 5xCD changer
column6: slotting his CD next to Dolly Parton and Nat King Cole and A Charlie Brown Christmas? If nothing else
column7: we can be thankful that Kozelek finished this album some time ago
column8: so he didn’t alter his version of “The Christmas Song” to include the line “Although it’s been said
column9: many times
column10: many ways
column11: War on Drugs can…”

column1: Anyway. If you can listen to Sings Christmas Carols and think
column2: “This too shall pass
column3: ” knowing that by Christmas 2015 Kozelek will have become bored of this game and we’ll have moved on to the next internet beef
column4: you may well enjoy this one. There’s no doubt Kozelek has a voice suited to the material
column5: that he comes up with solid guitar arrangements
column6: and generally imbues these songs with a sense of calm and contemplation. This is by and large a traditional Christmas album all the way
column7: something that you could play for your parents and have them say
column8: “Hey
column9: that’s better than the weird one you brought last year.” He layers his voice into a mini choir for the a capella on “O Come All Ye Faithful”
column10: throws a funny spoken word interlude into “Christmas Time Is Here” that pokes fun at his sad-sack persona
column11: and includes an overlooked Christmas-themed song into the mix
column12: the Pretenders’ “2000 Miles”
column13: which really should be a standard. It’s just voice and guitar throughout
column14: but Kozelek’s nylon string work is consistently engaging
column15: even as he falls back on some of his go-to fingerpicking patterns.

column1: But the album’s strengths—the relaxed vibe
column2: easy prettiness
column3: and earthy undercurrent
column4: all appropriate for a bloated eggnog buzz—happen to be qualities Kozelek can conjure at will. He has a weird way with covers; he can make any song sound like a Kozelek song
column5: but that’s a double-edged sword. When he tackles someone else’s music it almost always sounds good
column6: but there is rarely any depth
column7: and the actual content can seem irrelevant. Two previous covers collections
column8: the AC/DC set What’s Next to the Moon and Tiny Cities
column9: featuring Modest Mouse songs
column10: were more about domination than interpretation. Kozelek smothers the songs in his own aesthetic
column11: and the same holds true here. The main differences being
column12: Christmas songs lend themselves well to his particular concerns
column13: and not too many people are thinking about the deeper layers of meaning inside “O Christmas Tree”. Is it going to bump Low’s Christmas out of the rotation? Not likely. But it’s not bad
column14:
and it very well may sound better with each passing year.

"|19932.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19932-mark-kozelek-sings-christmas-carols/|6.8|Mark Richardson

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21126/homepage_large.861d05f7.jpg|Gentlemen at 21|31.0|The Afghan Whigs|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Mute'
column2:
'Rhino']|2014-11-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:12.850009|"

Greg Dulli sings about some fucked-up shit on the Afghan Whigs’ fourth album and major-label debut
column3: 1993’s Gentlemen
column4: a harrowing song cycle chronicling the death throes of a relationship. But when it came time to record “My Curse”
column5: one of the darkest moments on the album
column6: he didn’t think he had it in him. “I tried to sing it
column7: but it was kinda really impossible for me to do
column8: ” he told Loose Lips Sink Ships back in 2005. “It was too close to the bone. Basically I chickened out.” That’s a remarkable thing to contemplate: This is
column9: after all
column10: an album that serves as an emotional exorcism
column11: visceral and violent
column12: played by a band not known for its squeamishness. Rather than tackle the song himself
column13: Dulli enlisted Marcy Mays of the Columbus
column14: Ohio
column15: band Scrawl
column16: and she sings the absolute hell out of it. Her slurred
column17: scrawled vocals are tough-minded and defiant one moment
column18: freshly bruised and broken the next
column19: as she treads the tightrope between temptation and repulsion
column20: between pleasure and pain.

column1: “Curse softly to me
column2: baby
column3: and smother me in your love
column4: ” she all but begs
column5: as though she must summon the courage to get each syllable out of her mouth. “Temptation comes not from hell but from above.” It is
column6: to say the least
column7: a powerful moment
column8: but it also fulfills an important narrative function: If Gentlemen documents the demise of a romance
column9: then “My Curse” allows the woman to tell her own side of the story
column10: to call out the posturing in Dulli’s hyper-masculine lyrics
column11: to express explicitly the pain he is inflicting on her. Offering a new perspective on the album’s brutal sexual politics
column12: Mays reveals his outsize persona to be a ruse: a defense mechanism with which he can refract emotions too dark and messy and traumatic to face head on.

column1: Perhaps that’s why the album still sounds so vital and so fresh 21 years on. Removed from the alt-rock boom of the early '90s
column2: Gentlemen is both personal and unknowable
column3: cocksure yet deeply troubled—in other words
column4: so complicated and contradictory that we’re still trying to untangle its knots. Gentlemen at 21 offers some fresh insights into this song cycle
column5: but fortunately doesn’t remaster or repackage the mystery out of it. The album sounds sharper and a bit more dangerous
column6: those coiled guitars riffs more potent and Steve Earle’s drums wilder and more insistent. And the bonus demos and covers reveal the DNA of the album
column7: signaling not only the rock and R&B sources that inspired Dulli
column8: but also giving some insight into the band’s creative process before they trekked down to Ardent Studio in Memphis
column9: Tennessee.

column1: Memphis figures prominently on Gentlemen
column2: even if the album opens with the buzz of car wheels on the John A. Roebling Suspension Bridge in the band’s hometown of Cincinnati. The Afghan Whigs had long been incorporating the sounds and fashions of black soul
column3: funk
column4: and jazz into their buzzy indie rock
column5: which lent previous albums like 1990’s Up in It and 1992’s Congregation a sense of taut rhythmic urgency. The band had previously covered Al Green’s “Beware” and the Elvis hit “True Love Travels on a Gravel Road”
column6: and they chose Tyrone Davis’ “I Keep Coming Back” for <i>Gentlemen
column7: proving their well of influences went much deeper than the usual alt-rock fare. While their contemporaries drew from indie bands like the Raincoats and the Meat Puppets or from classic rock acts like the Who and Neil Young
column8: Dulli was much more interested in Stax and Motown
column9: in Curtis Mayfield and Isaac Hayes.

column1: On later albums
column2: these sources would become much more obvious
column3: but on Gentlemen they are buried in the mix
column4: evident in the strangled riffs on the title track and in the sensual drift of “When We Two Parted”. Drummer Steve Earle is crucial to this balance of styles and sounds
column5: keeping time as tight as the great Al Jackson Jr. but adding the fills and frills of showy rock drummers like Keith Moon. (Sadly
column6: this would be Earle’s final album with the band.) In this regard
column7: the covers included with Gentlemen at 21 prove more substantial than your typical bonus material
column8: not only providing a blueprint for the Afghan Whigs’ sound but also providing a sort of mixtape for the characters involved. It’s not hard to imagine Dulli’s narrator blasting the Ass Ponys’ “Mr. Superlove” for inspiration
column9: or tempting a lover with Dan Penn’s “The Dark End of the Street”
column10: or consoling himself with the Supremes’ “My World Is Empty Without You”.

column1: Over two decades Gentleman has most often been described as a “song cycle
column2: ” a term that distinguishes it from a concept album or a narrative album (although both terms are to some degree applicable). If that idea persists
column3: perhaps its due to the word “cycle
column4: ” which seems apt: Gentlemen ends more or less where it begins. Scene-setting overture “If I Were Going” opens the album with a slow fade-in finally interrupted by Earle’s stop-start drumbeat
column5: and “Brother Woodrow/Closing Prayer” closes the affair with a long
column6: cinematic fade-out
column7: with a dissonant cello echoing the migraine drone of the Roebling Bridge. The sequencing shapes the album beautifully
column8: creating a sense of emotional fatigue while only hinting vaguely at redemption. Thematically
column9: however
column10: that cycle implies a romantic fatalism
column11: as though every relationship is doomed to end painfully.

column1: That’s what makes Gentlemen at 21 such a compelling and necessary reissue
column2: even if the album has never been terribly hard to find. Living with this record
column3: whether for a few weeks or a few decades
column4: only repeats the pattern and makes the songs sound increasingly
column5: almost unbearably desperate. That urgency has not softened over time or even with the addition of bonus material. The early versions of these songs
column6: recorded at Ultrasuede Studio in Cincinnati
column7: show just how little they changed at Ardent
column8: although it’s unclear whether they burst out of Dulli’s brain fully formed or the band sharpened them. Perhaps the most intriguing bonus track is the Ultrasuede version of “My Curse”
column9: with Dulli singing lead. He toys with pitch and meter like a man with more to say than his voice can convey
column10: but he’s more engaged with the material than he sounds on later bootlegs like Time for a Bavarian Death Waltz. In fact
column11: he sounds relatively timid
column12: perhaps even beaten
column13: exhausted
column14: raw
column15: lowdown—as though he no longer possesses the hope or the courage to keep the cycle going. In a way
column16:
chickening out may be the boldest thing he ever did. 

"|19885.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19885-the-afghan-whigs-gentlemen-at-21/|8.7|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21212/homepage_large.71753999.jpg|HAERTS|32183.0|HAERTS|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2014-11-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:13.448307|"

If at all possible
column2: try listening to HAERTS’ cutting edge synth-pop without immediately wondering what kind of suspect genre gerrymandering resulted in them being “indie.” It's a more daunting task than usual considering their well-heeled
column3: camera-ready sound or the simple fact that a glance at their Facebook page has contact info for some of the music biz’s heaviest hitters
column4: some of which share the last name of guitarist Garrett Ienner.

column1: But what’s even the point of feigning outrage anymore
column2: we’re celebrating the 20th anniversary of a year when Candlebox and Live were successfully marketed as an alternative to anything—this is just the 21st century version of selling the drama. But we need to talk about something when we talk about HAERTS and more interesting than their anodyne music is this central paradox—it’s easy to think of thousands of people liking HAERTS and extremely difficult to explain how a single person could love them.

column1: They’re hardly alone in this aspect; they’re not so much a part of a wave than a crest between the retrospectively game-changing
column2: idiosyncratic
column3: helium-voiced future-prog of Passion Pit and MGMT and Chvrches/Haim's merger of modernist
column4: personable warmth and fashion mag gloss. HAERTS are indicative of the functional bands that currently fill the rosters of quasi-indies like Downtown
column5: Vagrant
column6: Glassnote
column7: and Neon Gold
column8: and functionality is enhanced by interchangeability—these are usually co-ed groups that look European but sound American (or vice versa)
column9: their picture gives you no immediate sense of who does what
column10: on stage they’re structured like rock bands but don’t really put guitars at the center
column11: so let’s just split the difference and call it “indie pop.” And this is the sound of “indie pop” in 2013 and
column12: no that’s not a typo. It’s not just the stylization of HAERTS’ name that already seems dated.

column1: So what does HAERTS give you that Wildcat! Wildcat!
column2: Strange Talk
column3: or their virtual twin St. Lucia (whose Jean-Philip Grobler produces) doesn’t? The main difference is that they’re even more willing to be serviceable towards some unknown
column4: greater purpose. HAERTS aren’t much for sloppy emotions
column5: edge
column6: or humor; while Nini Fabi is occasionally given a booster from an unseen cheerleading chorus
column7: she’s so earnest
column8: so committed to staying out of the way of big hooks
column9: she’s more akin to a middle manager than a frontwoman.

column1: A scroll through HAERTS’ tracklist reveals some serious truth in advertising: “Giving Up”
column2: “Wings”
column3: “Lights Out”
column4: “Call My Name”
column5: “All the Days”. The sentiments are so vague that the placeholder titles offer no assistance in helping you remember which one does the Tango in the Night
column6: which one shines like a midnight sun over “Midnight City”
column7: which one does a shuffling
column8: Chairlift-like ascension
column9: and which one (or several) have the same DNA as “The Mother We Share”.

column1: That said
column2: throw HAERTS on shuffle and it’s uniformly accessible and uniform
column3: period. You will hear a glimmering song about heartbreak that also sounds vaguely motivational. Quote any random lyric and it will also speak of heartbreak while sounding vaguely motivational. Do some WebMD research if you must before encountering “Hemiplegia”; its symptoms sound as mundane and relatable as those of the common cold
column4: no matter how much Fabi tries to impart meaning via repetition to  “No you can’t move up with your eyes down.” “Giving Up” echoes the unapologetic breakup austerity of “The Wire”
column5: but keeps its eye on the ball rather than fumbling
column6: which is a problem when a hook like
column7: “I’m giving up/ You say it’s now or never/ I’m giving up/ In time it’s for the better” needs some semblance of human error to resonate.

column1: So
column2: the supposed paradox of HAERTS is actually fairly easy to explain—bands of their ilk respect the craft that goes into pop music and aren’t shy about emulating its crisp
column3: moneyed sound. They’re just shy about risking self-disclosure
column4: anything personal that could be extrapolated into personality. Fabi may have experienced every single thing she sings about here
column5: but you never get a sense of who she actually is or how it felt. Even if HAERTS’ hooks sound like slam dunks in a vacuum
column6: they remind you of arguments as to why the NBA Slam Dunk Contest has become increasingly obsolescent—at this point
column7: it’s just 80s and 90s nostalgia
column8: there’s no room for innovation
column9: no charisma and
column10: most importantly
column11:
no realistic context to give it meaning.

"|19960.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19960-haerts-haerts/|5.8|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21003/homepage_large.244ae590.jpg|Release|27151.0|Cave|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-11-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:14.059053|"

Vintage space-rock is a finite resource. No matter how deep you dig
column2: there are only so many fuzzy riffs and analog synth squelches that can possibly be exhumed from the 1960s and '70s. If only for this reason
column3: Cave have a purpose in the world.

column1: Like Bitchin Bajas
column2: their Drag City labelmates (with whom they share members Rob Frye and Cooper Crain)
column3: the Chicago-based quintet do their best to expand the world’s limited supply of old-school zone-out sounds. The Bajas’ work pays tribute to the spacey and meditative tones of early minimalist composition and new age music. Cave’s music takes heavy influence from the gritty and repetitive sounds of krautrock and obscure global psychedelic music. Very often
column4: both bands' efforts provide a superior experience to the steady stream of era-appropriate reissues with which they must compete. After all
column5: they have the benefit of hindsight. Cave can deliver all of the good stuff—the hypnotic grooves
column6: the cosmic atmospheres—with less of the yodeling.

column1: Release collects out-of-print material from a number of the band’s non-album singles
column2: cassettes
column3: and limited edition CD-Rs—originally released on labels like Trensmat
column4: Static Caravan and Important—onto one LP
column5: with the earliest material stretching back to 2007.

column1: On its most recent full-length
column2: Threace
column3: Cave refined their approach and stripped down their sound with great results. Where some of the band’s earlier work sometimes sounded as if it had been haphazardly jammed into existence
column4: songs like ""Shikaakwa"" and ""Slow Bern"" were elegant and tightly focused
column5: getting maximum mileage out of minimal melodic information. Like the music of Neu! and Can
column6: Cave’s songs implied motion and stasis simultaneously through the use of repetition.

column1: The music on Release is a little rougher around the edges
column2: but don’t interpret that as ""worse."" Some of the tracks included here stand above the LP cuts the band was releasing at the time. They’re looser
column3: but also grittier and headier. ""Bobby’s Hash"" showcases Cave at its heaviest
column4: with screeching guitar solos and pummeling
column5: distorted drums. It’s well executed
column6: but free and freaky abandon isn’t necessarily the band’s strongest position. Unlike their pysch-rock revivalist forebears
column7: Comets on Fire—who lived and died by glorious freewheeling and freaky guitar solos—Cave’s music is most distinctive when the band is exercising restraint. On ""Butthash (Harsh Mellow Mix)"" Cave slowly expands upon a fuzzy
column8: cyclical guitar riff
column9: gradually fading in synth murmurs and additional percussion. Both drawn from the same 2012 single
column10: ""Party Legs"" and ""Thai I Am"" find the band moving toward the more economical sound they would employ on Threace
column11: switching from a hypnotic improvisation to more tightly structured compositions.

column1: Release is not Cave’s strongest record
column2: but it’s not a bad entry point. An odds and ends compilation
column3:
it provides a clear picture of the group's evolution from free-form psych-noodling toward its more sublime and trance-inducing current incarnation.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21029/homepage_large.514436ff.jpg|Livity Sound Remixes|31736.0|Livity Sound|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Livity Sound']|2014-11-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:15.347907|"

The reaction to a remix album in 2014 probably ranges somewhere from ""How quaint!"" to chirping crickets. They seem
column2: in large part
column3: a relic of the 1990s electronica boom
column4: a time when CDs were plentiful and well-funded major labels were trying to figure out how exactly to best peddle funky bleeps and bloops to a wider record-buying public. Remixes are still used as a way to boost the visibility of a young artist via a more famous remixer
column5: or to expand a track's reach by dressing it up in a different genre
column6: but it's more common these days to offer the material as a carrot for purchasing from a particular vendor or as a freebie to drum up interest. Underground labels
column7: as always
column8: seem content to issue mixes on vinyl
column9: for DJs and collectors. So the market isn't exactly saturated
column10: which is fine: it was always a slightly dicey proposition to bundle together re-imaginings by a disparate group of artists.

column1: Livity Sound is a small
column2: Bristol-based label/collective whose curious meld of techno
column3: dub
column4: and bass music proved popular with the type of progressive
column5: underground-leaning DJs. They were notable for their sound
column6: but also for the insular nature with which is was presented: tribal markings (since abandoned)
column7: monochrome labels
column8: and singles that featured different combinations of the three members (Peverelist
column9: Kowton
column10: Asusu) but no outsiders. Watching them conjure the sound live revealed a sense of ritual.

column1: With just nine (original) releases to their name—and none since they collected them on last year's excellent eponymous album—they might seem an unlikely mark for an album of Sumixes. But Livity's sound represents something of an ideal for remixers: potent and distinct enough to survive mangling but with plenty of cavities and null spaces to explore. The sound
column2: so deep-seated in the trio
column3: would best be expanded by a group of peers and sympathizers.

column1: The list of remixers is heavy on European veterans
column2: and while the names aren't big—UK techno don Surgeon represents the loudest choice—they're an imaginative group that share Livity's propensity for manically controlled aggression and tense rhythms. The remixers favor tweaks and refurbishments to outright deconstruction
column3: so Livity Sound Remixes is still largely a hard charging collection of throbbing bass and ratcheting snares
column4: albeit a collection that feels slightly less isolated as the familiar clang of techno and curves of house are sprinkled over the tracks like seasoning.

column1: There are some striking updates. Tessela takes the nimble breakbeat of Pev's ""Aztec Chant"" and plates it in chrome; Ghost-202 (Ron Morelli and Svengalighost) pervert ""Livity""'s bassline into a snarling
column2: distorted mess. Surgeon takes the halting rhythm of ""Raw Code"" and sets it like a broken bone
column3: offering rigidity and support. Berlin's Nick Höppner turns in one of the best mixes
column4: unearthing softness and patience in the quicksilver house of Asusu's ""Sister"". A Made Up Sound offer two remixes of Asusu's ""Velez""
column5: carefully pouring spacey synth noise into its crevices like someone preparing a sheet of cupcakes.

column1: There are times when austerity gets the better of Livity's sound
column2: like when MM/KM (Mix Mup and Kassem Mosse) remove titular
column3: wiggling synth melody
column4: one of Livity's rare playful moments
column5: from Kowton's ""More Games"". And while the lack of total teardowns by the remixers speaks to the resiliency of the original tracks
column6: Livity Sound Remixes is lacking in true curveballs (something that was less apparent when these tracks were released separately over the course of the year). Still
column7: Livity Sound Remixes serves as a welcome addendum to some of the most vital club music of recent years and a roadmap for placing this flinty
column8:
penetrating music into a broader context.

"|19796.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19796-various-artists-livity-sound-remixes/|7.4|Andrew Gaerig

The Modest Mouse of the 2000s was very of its time
column3: when indie rock was turning more porous and mainstream. The Moon and Antarctica from 2000 clothed their decrepit strains in major label finery and production by someone outside of their local bubble
column4: Califone's Brian Deck. The record also let in influences that were not yet entirely indie-approved
column5: such as dance music on ""Tiny Cities Made of Ashes"". Morbid lyrics and backmasked guitars notwithstanding
column6: ""Gravity Rides Everything"" was catchy enough to sell Nissan Quest minivans. Moon
column7: though clearly a classic now
column8: caused debates over whether Modest Mouse had ""sold out
column9: something people still earnestly fretted about as the Internet was upsetting old hierarchies.

column1: This commercial openness was quite a shift for a band defined by a sense of isolation in its own secret world. The Modest Mouse of the '90s had also been very much of its time
column2: when indie rock was less of a popular genre than a refuge from them. Weird bands from nowhere places strained their quirks through a punk filter
column3: and their styles were narrower but
column4: perhaps
column5: deeper than those of their polyglot descendants. Modest Mouse fit the mold. Formed by singer and guitarist Isaac Brock
column6: drummer Jeremiah Green
column7: and bassist Eric Judy in the Washington suburb of Issaquah
column8: they had a kind of insular
column9: visionary oddness.

column1: Modest Mouse quickly found purchase in the Pacific Northwest scene. In 1994
column2: they made their first EP with Calvin Johnson in Olympia for his twee-punk label K Records
column3: as well as a single for Seattle's Sub Pop. They also recorded the album Sad Sappy Sucker
column4: which sat on the shelf until 2001
column5: when it did indeed turn out to be their most K-style record—bright
column6: baggy
column7: and loose at the seams. During this time they veered off into a wilderness of their own devising
column8: debuting with the darker and tauter This Is a Long Drive for Someone With Nothing to Think About on Up Records in 1996. That and their second Up album
column9: 1997's The Lonesome Crowded West
column10: have just been reissued by Brock's Glacial Pace label. Both are excellent
column11: but it's the more fully formed Lonesome that consummates an era.

column1: From the start
column2: Modest Mouse were instantly recognizable: Judy's ropy bass and Green's drumming
column3: heaving from a caveman bash to a disco skip
column4: are indispensable to the rangy
column5: volatile sound. But it's the guitars that really define it
column6: so strange and particular—Brock's hearty riffs
column7: string bends
column8: harmonics
column9: and whammy-bar tremolo push up toward trebly extremes of panicked intensity. The songs break down into wheezes and coughs as the band pounds the ends of bars until they curl up like sheet metal.

column1: But they weren't completely ex nihilo. Like other '90s indie groups
column2: Modest Mouse reflected their region before pulling free from it on later albums. There's grunge in the whisper-scream dynamics here
column3: metal and punk in sections of breakneck thrash
column4: twee in the richly jangling acoustic guitars and in Brock's voice
column5: always petulant and pleading. There are also outlying indie touchstones—""Might"" sounds like Built to Spill if someone had knocked Doug Martsch on the head
column6: other songs evoke the Pixies by way of Pink Floyd. Even alt-rock is absorbed in the patchwork pop of ""Lounge""
column7: a medley of surf-rock
column8: hot jazz
column9: and chamber music with shout-rapped lyrics. But Modest Mouse were already fortifying their hermetic island on Long Drive
column10: where they pitted the jarring against the lulling in diverse ways.

column1: The great theme of both albums is travel
column2: or more essentially
column3: how motion through space feels. This is also intricately bound up with the physical geography Modest Mouse inhabited. The urban paranoia of post-punk seeps into wide-open rural
column4: looming industrial and encroaching suburban vistas
column5: all alike in their sinister
column6: hypnotic repetition. With the first words of Long Drive
column7: ""traveling swallowing Dramamine
column8: a sense of drugged conveyance through some grand monotony settles over us. We seem to glimpse empty landscapes with twisty bits of things blowing through them in the window of a train. Strip malls and parking lots
column9: monuments and steeples
column10: empty fields and dark forests scroll by in a purgatorial loop. This becomes overt on ""Convenient Parking""
column11: a dusty practice riff with broken springs.

column1: For Brock
column2: these enclosing physical confines are tantamount to mental ones; he's always moving forward without getting anywhere different
column3: and he confronts this existential emergency with disdain and terrified awe. The music cultivates its particular urgency by devising and then breaking free from psychic traps. ""From the top of the ocean/ From the bottom of the sky/ Well
column4: I get claustrophobic
column5: Brock bellows on Lonesome's ""Teeth Like God's Shoeshine""
column6: an image that would return in different form a few years later on ""Ocean Breathes Salty"". The earth and heavens are not mediums but inescapable masses
column7: crushing us in the seam where they meet. The feeling of being stuck in a small town inflates to cosmological proportions.

column1: Home-schooled in religious hippie communes
column2: Brock was primed for this visionary vocation. His lyrics are marked by a war between militant atheism and kind of crypto-Christian mysticism
column3: a tension that twists his perspective into strange shapes. On these records
column4: the pavement is steadily encroaching on the wild in ways that feel spiritually symbolic. Brock wants to wrench apart ground and sky
column5: prefabricated towns and consumer culture
column6: to find an exit hatch into some deeper
column7: more meaningful state of being which
column8: as he suspects on ""Exit Does Not Exist""
column9: is a fantasy.

column1: Modest Mouse never captured their particular rural paranoia better than on Lonesome's ""Cowboy Dan""
column2: a minor key dirge that takes us to a jet-black desert rustling below the occasional shooting star. It's a folkloric tale of a cowboy who tries to shoot down God as revenge for mortality
column3: with eerie calls and groans floating out of a vast
column4: breathing darkness. ""I didn't move to the city
column5: the city moved to me
column6: he cries
column7: via Brock's rabid goblin croak
column8: ""and I want out desperately
column9: a theme that first began to develop on Long Drive's ""Beach Side Property"".

column1: It's all about inverted insides and outsides: huge landscapes that feel like small cages
column2: civilizations that breed a savage misanthropy
column3: disbelief that feels like religion. ""Doin' the Cockroach"" begins with the elusive dichotomy
column4: ""I was in heaven
column5: I was in Hell/ Believe in neither but fear them as well."" Brock excoriates riders on the Amtrak for ""talking 'bout TV
column6: punctuating his condemnations with pleas to ""please shut up."" He also slips in one of the best of the obscure aphorisms that would come to increasingly infiltrate his litany of complaints: Some number of years ""down the road in your life
column7: you'll look in the mirror and say
column8: 'My parents are still alive.'"" I think it's about getting older
column9: but it's open to numberless interpretations
column10: all of them with the indescribable ambient menace of a bad dream.

column1: The Lonesome Crowded West fine-tunes forms that were introduced on Long Drive. ""Teeth Like God's Shoeshine"" and the sprawling ""Trucker's Atlas"" draw the erratic thrust of ""Breakthrough"" into sleeker
column2: more commanding arcs. ""Lounge (Closing Time)"" is a less novelty-based
column3: more structurally balanced version of ""Lounge"". And ""Shit Luck"" is even more potent than""Tundra/Desert""
column4: with two-note power chords growling up and down the neck in breakneck syncopation with wailing string bends. The record also refines some new looks that would soon be developed
column5: such as the scratchy rural funk jam of ""Jesus Christ Was an Only Child"" and tender
column6: ringing ballads such as ""Heart Cooks Brain"" and the gentle confessional ""Trailer Trash"".

column1: With Moon
column2: Modest Mouse caught a new wave of spacey psych-pop alongside the likes of The Flaming Lips
column3: and it let them out on a foreign shore: mainstream success. Good News for People Who Love Bad News (2004) went platinum
column4: produced hit single ""Float On""
column5: landed the band on SNL and earned a Grammy nomination. To me
column6: that was the last real Modest Mouse album—and even it was on the verge—as the personalities that made the group unique got diluted by new personnel
column7: i.e.
column8: someone as externally defined as Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr. We Were Dead Before the Ship Even Sank (2007) was the band's first number one album
column9: but it felt like an ending
column10: and only an EP of leftovers from the last two albums has emerged since.

column1: Lonesome came out right on the hinge between indie rock's regional phase and its global one
column3: the year I got my first email address
column4: and I still have the original LP I bought around then. Listening to albums you loved that long ago often feels like looking at old photos
column5: but the remarkable thing about these reissues is that their thrill feels contemporary
column6: a present sense of physical and psychological danger. Indeed
column7: something you notice in an almost manically retro indie music climate is a striking absence of nostalgia. Things are fucked now
column8: with no inkling that they were ever any better
column9: no state of grace to return to.

column1: The end of the '90s were packed with epochal last gasps of pre-Internet indie rock that came out just as Radiohead's OK Computer was becoming the avatar of the next
column2: more mainstream phase. Neutral Milk Hotel's In the Aeroplane Over the Sea
column3: Pavement's Brighten the Corners
column4: Elliott Smith's Either/Or—all exhausted blazes of glory
column5:
like light bulbs flaring brightest as they burn out. The Lonesome Crowded West stands tall and defiantly weird among them.

Ryan Hemsworth has mastered the social web. You can see it in his tweets
column3: which knowingly combine the sad teenager aesthetic with that of the semi-ironic
column4: in-crowd broducer. You can see it in his Secret Songs record club
column5: through which he's cultivated a community of bedroom producers in his likeness and given them access to a large audience. And you can see it on the guest list for his new album
column6: <i>Alone for the First Time
column7: which
column8: despite its name
column9: features contributions from popular Soundcloud artists and Secret Songs amateurs alike. But even if it’s not literal
column10: the title does justice to the major artistic step that this album represents. For better and for worse
column11: this is the Halifax producer’s boldest aesthetic statement to date
column12: and taking that kind of risk must feel something like striking out on your own for the first time.

column1: Hemsworth started his career playing two distinct roles. He produced songs for minor
column2: buzzing Southern rappers riding the cloud-rap wave and remixed the pop songs of the moment
column3: tricking them out with candy-colored synths and creaky drum machines. He was already about as collaborative as it’s possible to be: most of his work either featured someone else rapping or was a rework of a song that had been created by someone else entirely. But even his original tracks felt like the work of a producer who wasn’t yet sure what kind of music he wanted to make
column4: someone who was following cues from other artists. The Last Words EP from 2012 was catchy but scattered
column5: and last year’s Guilt Trips
column6: as refined as it was
column7: showed a reluctance to commit to any one style. (The exception to these projects was last year’s Still Awake EP
column8: the most direct precursor to Alone for the First Time.)

column1: Hemsworth was one of the early
column2: post-Girl Talk producers who reveled in the dissolution of genre
column3: and he dabbled in bedroom electronic
column4: candied R&B and Southern hip-hop without pledging allegiance to any of them. It was only when he fully embraced a fourth influence
column5: the 8-bit soundtracks to handheld video games of the '80s and '90s
column6: that he began to focus on refining a specific sound
column7: one that combined his pop instincts with the miniaturized melodies of that format.

column1: He’s been drilling down towards the essence of that sound for more than a year now. And the core he’s reached on the new album reveals a singer-songwriter bedroom pop by way of Final Fantasy. It’s unmistakably a winter album
column2: and would be recognizable as such even were its first single not titled ""Snow in Newark""; the album fairly bleeds nostalgia and comfort—listening to it feels like being swaddled with blankets and pillows. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column3: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">And for the first time
column4: it features Hemsworth working largely with original
column5: lyrical songs
column6: a jarring development for fans who originally came to him for his remixes or production.

column1: Hemsworth has made sport out of feeling vulnerable—his twitter is replete with references to him needing to snuggle—and his lyrics are generally in that mold. When they’re simple
column2: as on ""Walk Me Home""
column3: they can feel tender and lovely. The song’s refrain of ""Leave me alone
column4: leave me alone
column5: leave me alone
column6: there’s no room for me left in your heart
column7: is genuinely heartbreaking
column8: syncing nicely with an upswing of strings and what sounds like a live version of the drum machines he favors. But occasionally
column9: his songs can feel like transmissions of his twitter feed that have been scrubbed of all humor or irony. ""Snow in Newark"" is the best example of this phenomenon: the first verse is one of the album's wordiest
column10: but Hemsworth doesn’t use it to communicate details and the song ends up sounding both vague and precious
column11: reminiscent of a lesser Jack Johnson track.

column1: Songs like these will garner Hemsworth new fans
column2: but it’s jarring to hear someone with such a refined sense of structure still struggling with songwriting. It can be a relief then to reach a track on which a truly talented vocalist makes up for Hemsworth's lyrical shortcomings. ""Surrounded""
column3: which features the voice of the wonderful Angelino songstress <a href=""https://soundcloud.com/kotomi"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Kotomi
column4: is one of the most powerful tracks on the album
column5: and it feels like a natural extension of the R&B remixes that Hemsworth came up on. The singer’s voice breathes life into the lyrics like a good actor into a bad role—the preciousness of the words is swallowed by the power of her emotion and the frantic production that surrounds her voice echoes the track’s message.

column1: Tracks like ""Surrounded"" hint that the problem with Hemsworth’s songs is not necessarily the lyrics but rather his lack of confidence when it comes to doing those simple words justice. But the contrast between the amateurism of his songs is all the more jarring because he’s become such a sure-handed producer. Instrumental tracks like ""Blemish"" and ""Hurt Me"" are quintessential Hemsworth productions
column2: springy
column3: bubbly tracks that sound like they were produced for a Pallet Town after party. There’s an undercurrent of melancholy to each that’s balanced nicely by the chirpy synths and springy drums that have long been the producer’s forte.

column1: You have to hand it to Hemsworth for refusing to make the same song over and over again. He’s learning from the artists he’s meeting online
column2: going farther afield than ever before (the album features artists from all over the globe)
column3: and growing more comfortable in his role as someone who can create pop
column4: not merely tweak existing songs. Alone for the First Time is the furthest he's pushed himself
column5: and the growing pains on the album can be chalked up to the strain of trying new things
column6:
a kind of adolescent awkwardness that shows signs of maturing into something sophisticated and unique.

"|19952.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19952-ryan-hemsworth-alone-for-the-first-time/|6.0|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21217/homepage_large.da8337e8.jpg|Tecuciztecatl|1955.0|His Name Is Alive|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['London London']|2014-11-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:17.143845|"

Of all the bands to call British label 4AD home in the early '90s
column2: none are as inscrutable—or wholly unpredictable—as His Name Is Alive. While the band’s early peers (the Breeders
column3: Red House Painters) spent the better part of that decade honing singular aesthetics
column4: His Name Is Alive were intent on doing the opposite. Early albums like Livonia and Stars on E.S.P. flirted with everything from shoegazey ephemera to sun-bleached California dream pop
column5: but never lighted long enough on any one style to truly embody it. Warren Defever—the Michigan-based musician
column6: songwriter
column7: and mercurial heart of the band—embraces a kind of gleeful wanderlust
column8: a predisposition that only intensified after the band parted ways with 4AD in the early 2000s. In the years since
column9: Defever’s output has become even more of a willfully mixed bag
column10: encompassing everything from spooky R&B
column11: blown-out psych rock
column12: meandering instrumental compositions
column13: and—on 2007’s Sweet Earth Flower—an album-length tribute to free jazz saxophonist Marion Brown. Some 20 years deep into their career the only single thread twisting through all of His Name Is Alive’s music has been Defever’s own peculiar force of vision
column14: which makes exploring the band’s now expansive back catalog both a satisfying and weirdly schizophrenic experience.

column1: It should come as no surprise
column2: then
column3: that Tecuciztecatl—the band’s 14th full-length—is a thing both wonderful and extraordinarily strange. A concept record that comes with the worrisome descriptor of ""psychedelic rock opera
column4: Tecuciztecatl involves a proggy narrative about a young woman who discovers she is pregnant with twins—one good
column5: one evil—and must seek the help of a demon-hunting librarian. Each of the album’s nine tracks is written from the perspective of a different character and the whole melodrama is set to play out like the soundtrack to a gothic psych-rock horror movie that never actually was. (Additionally
column6: every edition of the record—be it on vinyl
column7: CD
column8: or digital download—is unique
column9: each with different mixes and tracklists.) Most records would surely collapse under the weight of this kind of conceptual pretense—the struggle of good versus evil as played out from within the womb! —but Tecuciztecatl succeeds due to the strength of the songs
column10: all of which still operate nicely outside the confines of the album’s bloody narrative.

column1: The album opens with “The Examination”
column2: a 13-minute opus comprised of simmering
column3: Yes-era synthscapes
column4: a chorus of flutes
column5: and—most flamboyantly—an arsenal of fuzzy
column6: overdriven guitar lines twisting around each other. As the song morphs from prog-rock anthem into something resembling a messy garage-funk jam
column7: vocalist Andrea Morici’s plaintive vocals provide a calming counterpoint: ""Look into my eyes/ Look into the light all around you/ Make yourself at home."" As opening salvos go
column8: it’s a doozy…and something the rest of the album never quite lives up to. Still
column9: tracks like ""Reflect Yourself"" and ""See You In a Minute"" play around with classic rock power riffing in ways that are both ridiculous and kind of perfect. Employing harmonious guitar solos that were apparently perfected by practicing along to an edit that Defever created of every Thin Lizzy guitar solo recorded between 1973 and 1983 (It’s a real thing. You can check it out on YouTube)
column10: much of Tecuciztecatl plays like a celebration of the kind of bombastic
column11: gatefold double-album sonic excess that marked '70s bands like King Crimson and Emerson Lake and Palmer.

column1: It would be easy for these sorts of rock opera theatrics to come across as jokey or ironically reverential
column2: but Defever's earnest commitment never wavers. Psych-rock noodlings aside
column3: it’s the more subdued tracks—the splish-splashy ""African Violet Casts a Spell"" and the pastoral vibes of album closer ""The Cup""—that not only sound the most like classic His Name Is Alive
column4: but also save the record from simply being a conceptual goof. Divorced from the album’s bizarro storyline
column5: ""I Believe Your Heart Is No Longer Inside This Room"" would still rank as one of His Name Is Alive’s most inspired tracks—a song that manages to simultaneously address birth and death while also incorporating an orchestral snippet of ""Joy to the World"" in a way that somehow makes total sense. No small feat.

column1: In the end Tecuciztecatl is an unusual treat because it manages to have it both ways. As an aspiring rock opera
column2: the album is sufficiently bombastic
column3: but it’s also surprisingly emotional. That the record can be both is a testament to Warren Defever’s kooky dexterity and his continued willingness to take big
column4:
weird conceptual risks—something that gets celebrated less and less within the increasingly homogenous landscape of what has come to be known as indie rock. Tecuciztecatl will certainly not be everybody’s cup of demon twin tea—and as albums go it is the very definition of a ""grower""—but those willing to spend time with it will are to be rewarded with what is a sometimes challenging but ultimately strangely beautiful listen.

"|19965.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19965-his-name-is-alive-tecuciztecatl/|7.6|T. Cole Rachel

'Pelagic']|2014-11-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:17.836430|"

Mono’s debut album
column3: 2001’s Under the Pipal Tree
column4: featured a few flourishes of cello amid its melodramatic
column5: guitar-driven post-rock. Since then
column6: the Japanese instrumental outfit has incrementally raised the presence of chamber sounds on their records
column7: to the point where their last two full-lengths—the 2010 live album Holy Ground and the 2012 studio album For My Parents—were swamped with symphonic fluff. It’s pretty enough
column8: but it also undercut one of the band’s initial strengths: tension. Crescendos and cannonades became as quaint as clockwork
column9: and the band’s magnificence was made mundane. The best that could be said of Mono is that they were impeccable self-editors.

column1: That hasn’t changed on The Last Dawn and Rays of Darkness
column2: two new studio albums being released concurrently. Spread between two discs
column3: the 10 songs feel more like an average Mono double-LP split in half and given two names. But there’s something at least nominally interesting about the way they’re divided: The Last Dawn continues along the orchestral arc that For My Parents followed
column4: while Rays of Darkness strips things down to the rock-quartet bone—and adds a couple of tiny surprises that don’t make up for an overall lack of spark.

column1: The Last Dawn is a dreary exercise in being as obvious as possible. With violin and cello as its crutches
column2: “The Land Between Tides/Glory” squanders a fantastic intro—Zeppelin-esque in tone
column3: shoegazing in execution—with percussive clichés and a corny piano coda. The candlelit keys on “Kanata” are even worse; there are 70s soap-opera theme songs with more emotive potency. Mono’s debt to Mogwai and Sigur Rós has never been hidden
column4: but the waltzing schmaltz of “Cyclone” could be the product of any Explosions in the Sky knockoff of the past 10 years. Make no mistake
column5: The Last Dawn is both sweeping and elegant
column6: full of grand melodic gestures and updrafts of euphoric distortion. You can hear the big punches coming from a light year away
column7: and that’s part of their power: They tug at the nervous system like circadian rhythms. But when the title track sleepwalks out of the orchestra pit and into the realm of noise-pop lullaby
column8: it might as well be the scratch of a pencil on a checklist.

column1: And
column2: Rays of Darkness is just inexplicably dull. On it
column3: Mono pulls off an impressive feat: smashing gargantuan swells of drama and volume into two-dimensional smudges
column4: as if they were bugs to be afraid of. The removal of a string section might seem like a brave move on their part
column5: especially after relying on its ostensible grandeur for so long—but they don’t substitute anything in its place except a higher setting on the fuzz pedal. “Recoil
column6: Ignite” isn’t bad by any means
column7: although its whale-song-through-a-Marshall-stack sound just sits in the midrange
column8: inert and suspenseless. Making background music this loud is an accomplishment itself
column9: even though “The Last Rays” confuses beige static with edgy experimentalism.

column1: A couple of guest artists help liven up two of the album’s four tracks: Calexico’s Jacob Valenzuela lends his trumpet to “Surrender
column2: ” and Envy’s Tetsu Fukagawa sings on “The Hand That Holds the Truth”. The former track is another case of missed opportunities; Valenzuela’s tone is dusty and ghostlike
column3: but all he does is follow the guitar for a few bars. Nothing will make you wish harder for Rob Mazurek’s punchy
column4: twisty trumpet on Tortoise’s “TNT”. Fukagawa’s vocals on “The Hand That Holds the Truth” are far more successful. True to form
column5: he howls a hole through the flimsy
column6: post-rock-patterned tissue of the song. If only the song pushed back—against him or anything.

column1: Post-rock works best when it embraces
column2: or at least acknowledges
column3: the subatomic friction within the conventional rock lineup. The same goes for cinematic music
column4: another genre that Mono have a leg in; without counterpoint and textural contrast
column5: it can slump into a pretty blob. These two new releases may be at attempt to point out some diametric dialogue at play within Mono’s music
column6: but the range is so constricted it doesn’t allow for much beyond meek agreement. There’s a lack of texture and energy to these two albums
column7: and also a lack of ideas; almost every song feels like a practice-space warm-up jammed and discarded by a far better band. At times in the past
column8: Mono have been that band
column9: and echoes of that exquisite urgency still surface here and there. It’s not enough. Mono have clearly evolved over the 13 years since Under the Pipal Tree—but if The Last Dawn and Rays of Darkness are any indication
column10:
that evolution is going around in circles.

Richard Dawson’s music often deals with death or disaster. The Newcastle singer-songwriter’s breakthrough album
column2: 2011’s The Magic Bridge
column3: features songs like ""Grandad’s Deathbed Hallucinations"" and ""Man Has Been Struck Down by Hands Unseen""
column4: as well as a ""Black dog in the sky/ Who pisses and slobbers all over the world."" When looking for inspiration for his follow-up (2013’s concept piece The Glass Trunk) Dawson began with a database search for ""death"" at his hometown museum. The album’s a capella ballads
column5: inspired by centuries-old news clippings
column6: tell tales of mutilated horses
column7: murder
column8: and the moors. His latest LP
column9: Nothing Important
column10: is no less morbid in its talking points
column11: but the tragedies described are less outlandish. The subject matter feels personal
column12: often uncomfortably so
column13: and Dawson always falls far from sentimentalizing or softening it.

column1: The primary sonic forces on the album are Dawson’s brittle
column2: crudely amplified nylon-string acoustic guitar—which recalls the timbre of UK free-improv giant Derek Bailey’s playing—and his fitfully expressive tenor voice
column3: which
column4: when not incited to the point of howling self-evisceration
column5: evokes Robert Wyatt’s. On other albums Dawson has explored his disparate musical tendencies separately from one another: Experimental drones
column6: folk sketches
column7: imitation field cries
column8: and free jazz diversions were relegated to separate tracks and even different releases. Nothing Important fulfills and extends the promise of this earlier work; incongruous stylistic elements are overlaid upon one another
column9: and packed into unwieldy but tightly-wrapped packages (particularly
column10: two dense
column11: 16-minute long compositions).

column1: The album’s lyrics begin with a birth
column2: but the time stamp suggests that it is not Dawson’s: ""I am born by Caesarean section at 9:30 AM/ In Princess Mary’s Maternity Hospital on the 24th May/ Sixty years ago today."" In a handful of lengthy verses—often fit to iambic rhythms and lilting melodies reminiscent of 16th-century madrigals—Dawson sketches painful but faint memories
column3: including the death of a baby and an uncle who reappears as a ghost. The choruses are explosive
column4: and derail easily (""I am nothing/ You are nothing/ Nothing important""). Running through a laundry list of mundane
column5: still-life images maddens the title track’s narrator to the point of surrendering: ""Why do they remain so clear while the faces of my loved ones disappear?"" Eventually Dawson’s voice trails off
column6: and the instrumental themes which hold the piece together reappear briefly—fatigued and sluggish—and fade. Full of unlikely musical juxtapositions and bizarre imagery (dark omens like ""a barracuda chewing on a chrysanthemum"" or ""a forking hairline seam of superglue through the Black Gate"") ""Nothing Important"" is perhaps Dawson’s most ambitious and affecting composition to date.

column1: ""The Vile Stuff"" is less nuanced: a slow-burning dirge based around a snippet of a sinister
column2: raga-like melody. Dawson’s lyrics center on a group of classmates (""year 7’s"") who suffer dire consequences after sharing a Coke-bottled slurry of mixed liquors on a fieldtrip. The humor here is pitch black
column3: similar to that of an Edward Gorey picture book: Dawson’s narrator and his fellow transgressors suffer fractured skulls and cheekbones
column4: stab screwdrivers through their hands
column5: and hop into bed with their teachers. The song culminates in a blistering cacophony of bowed harp drones (courtesy of Dawson’s frequent collaborator Rhodri Davies)
column6: funereal percussion and feedback—the sound is only as discordant and unpleasant as adolescence.

column1: Nothing Important is driven by an ongoing conflict between entropic impulsiveness and an almost classical sense of beauty and order. The music is frequently caught in a tug of war between melody and harmony. In the guitar instrumentals that bookend the album
column2: for instance
column3: Dawson always runs the risk of letting a particularly effusive riff overwhelm the chords and rhythms
column4: and topple the whole musical edifice into a series of fragmented stabs and melodic shards. The lyrics
column5: meanwhile
column6: alternate visions of despair
column7: pain
column8: and anger with moments of reconciliation and acceptance. The ritual drama of falling and picking one’s self back up again (taking ""responsibility
column9: as Dawson prefers in interviews) plays out in every element of this music
column10:
and is key to its elusive power.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21228/homepage_large.befc6c7b.jpg|Storytone|4693.0|Neil Young|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Reprise']|2014-11-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:19.343786|"

Even for an artist with the mercurial track record of Neil Young
column2: this has been a pretty strange year. Since turning 68 last November
column3: Young has become a tech startup figurehead
column4: an enemy of Canadian conservatives and oil companies
column5: a second-time author
column6: and a watercolor artist. He’s done a European tour with a modified Crazy Horse
column7: U.S. shows all by his lonesome
column8: and recorded a no-fi covers collection with Jack White. And perhaps most notably
column9: he’s divorcing his wife of 36 years
column10: and has been spotted canoodling with a notable ex-mermaid.

column1: Amid that manic activity
column2: the high concept of Storytone barely raises an eyebrow. Ten tracks recorded live in front of a 92-piece orchestra and choir or a jazz big band
column3: the project doesn’t fit neatly within either the acoustic or electric categories that have been the magnetic poles of Young’s career. But it also calls back to some odd moments from his discography: the orchestrated excesses of ""A Man Needs a Maid"" and ""There’s a World"" from Harvest
column4: with a dash of 1988’s largely forgettable This Note’s for You. Once again
column5: he’s fallen in love with the actress
column6: and only a symphonic scale will do.

column1: Unlike the Voice-o-Graph pops and crackles of A Letter Home
column2: which seemed like a classic Neil joke on the heels of his fidelity-obsessed Pono pitch
column3: Storytone spares no sonic expense
column4: with the arrangements set to maximum lush. So maybe call it A Little Touch of Schmeil in the Night
column5: even if the songs only sound like standards and Young is far from your typical crooner. A set of 10 songs predominantly concerned with the withering of old love and the promise of new—and
column6: as such
column7: haunted by his recent romantic tabloid escapades—Storytone is unabashedly melodramatic and earnest
column8: occasionally sounding more like the passions of a 17-year-old instead of someone on the brink of their seventies.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: aside from placing that unorthodox warble against a velvety backdrop
column3: Storytone plays it straight
column4: often veering into the deep schmaltz of a Vegas revue. The arrangements
column5: by Michael Bearden (who has worked with Michael Jackson and Lady Gaga) and Chris Walden (an arranger for Michael Bublé and ""American Idol"")
column6: are exquisitely produced but hollow
column7: gilding the songs without adding any thoughtful counterpoint. ""Who’s Gonna Stand Up?""
column8: Neil’s latest eco-anthem
column9: is given a dark
column10: cinematic urgency
column11: and the light countrypolitan stomp of ""When I Watch You Sleeping"" recalls the rustic sweep of 2005’s Prairie Wind
column12: but more typical are the harp and chime twinkles applied without subtlety to ""Tumbleweed"" or the Navy Pier blooze of ""Say Hello to Chicago"".

column1: Helpfully
column2: you can assess these additions thanks to Young providing solo versions of each track on the album’s deluxe edition—sparse near-demos on guitar
column3: piano
column4: and ukulele that come closer to the intimate sound of his recent
column5: rambling theatre sets. Stripped down
column6: the dark
column7: doubtful elements of ""Plastic Flowers"" or ""Say Hello to Chicago"" come to the fore
column8: Young’s tenor sounding vulnerable instead of overmatched. Here
column9: the contradiction of putting a protest song against fracking and fossil fuels right next to a song called ""I Want to Drive My Car"" is somewhat resolved
column10: as the latter gets a hushed version that makes Young’s autophilia sound more like an embarrassing addiction than a passion. But the solo versions of the more PDA material in the album’s back half make something of a case for their fancier counterparts
column11: leaving nothing to hide valentine lyrics unavoidably about Daryl Hannah (the “A Man Needs a Mermaid” joke writes itself).

column1: Despite the dual versions
column2: Storytone never finds a comfortable middle ground: the orchestral versions too maudlin
column3: the solo versions over-sharing. More so than the goofily overwrought Harvest tracks with the London Symphony Orchestra
column4: the flaws of Storytone throw back to Young’s restless '80s (or 2002’s Are You Passionate?)
column5: where genres were meticulously recreated but often a poor fit for his songwriting and performing strengths. For an artist who can make an orchestral roar with Old Black or twist an emotional knife on a pump organ
column6:
the extra gloss is subtraction by addition.

column1:
