If you’re someone who still secretly or not-so-secretly thinks remixes are just accessories to the originals
column2: I encourage you to listen to any of the raw material for DJ Koze’s Reincarnations Pt. 2. Koze doesn’t just move around what’s already there
column3: but takes some small portion or impulse within a song and creates an entirely new context for it. Usually
column4: the new context brings out a quality or shade in the music only hinted at by the original
column5: hence the word ""reincarnation"": The body is new but the soul is still the same. A Koze remix of a meatball might be a hamburger; his remix of a horse might be a car.

column1: Koze is playful
column2: which is nice because most of the artists he works with are not. Witness Ada’s ""Faith""
column3: a modest ballad sung by a choir of androids too tired to care anymore. In Koze’s hands
column4: it becomes a starlit torch song in some Palm Springs lounge; the androids still melancholy but now played for their sex appeal
column5: too. Or Herbert’s ""You Saw It All""
column6: which appears here as a Motown-style love letter that breaks into a clarinet solo played by someone who may not have ever played a clarinet before. (My favorite Koze remix is still of Matthew Dear’s ""Elementary Lover""
column7: which places a stern Germanic orator in the middle of what sounds like Club Med.)

column1: These are gestures that understand and dignify the source material but don’t let it restrict them. Often
column2: Koze seems like a boy pirouetting through the museum
column3: ornamenting treasures of antiquity with handlebar mustaches and tiny yellow birds. Even when his music isn’t outright funny
column4: there is something about it that feels casual and loose
column5: allowing stray beauty at the margins of the track—a breath
column6: a syllable—to blossom into a central hook. I still don’t know whether to pronounce his name DJ Cot-zuh or DJ Cozy
column7: and my guess is that the ambiguity is intentional.

column1: Reincarnations Pt. 2 collects his last six years; the first volume collected 2001–2009. Both are strong
column2: though the highlights on the first edition—""Elementary Lover"" or Battles’ ""Atlas""—are a little brighter. Like Todd Terje
column3: Koze is a Northern European prankster who built his reputation on remixes but whose own music gets better every time he decides to make it. Last year
column4: he put out Amygdala
column5: an album that had more to do with the history of psychedelic pop than with techno in the same way Terje’s It’s Album Time had more to do with film music and exotica than disco. If you have never heard Koze
column6: start there. His is a low-key beautiful world
column7: governed by bright colors
column8: round shapes
column9: and a gentleness that can seem meek but more often just seems like the byproduct of wonder. ""It is fairly easy to rock the house
column10: he told an interviewer in 2008
column11:
""but so hard to look out of the window.""

One of the many perverse tendencies of the Fall’s Mark E. Smith is his fondness for the live album. Wikipedia counts 31 live records by the band
column3: and that’s not including the handful of part-live/part-studio efforts that have appeared over the years. This album appears to fall into the latter category
column4: although details are scant. There are few clues as to what was recorded when. A couple of its tracks sound like studio creations—a thought confirmed by a number of posts on a Fall discussion board—while the live material is taken from a series of shows spanning 2008–2012. Even the release of it has been unusual
column5: with the album originally set to come out last year bearing a different title and track listing. Longstanding Fall fans will be used to such about-turns in approach
column6: such as the subtly different versions of The Real New Fall LP (Formerly Country on the Click) and Fall Heads Roll that surfaced when those albums were originally issued.

column1: The build-up to the release of Uurop VIII-XII Places in Sun & Winter
column2: Son barely befits such a low stakes addition to the Fall’s canon. It’s got the feel of a bootleg—the recording is at times horribly thin
column3: and the occasional snatches of audience chatter make it sound like the work of someone staggering drunkenly through the crowd with a barely concealed mic. Word has been good about the Fall’s live shows in the past few years
column4: especially when they returned to a double-drummer format. It’s typically contrary of Smith to document them like this
column5: with a song like ""Jetplane""
column6: the standout from Re-Mit
column7: sounding like it was recorded through a thick woolen blanket. It wouldn’t surprise anyone if Smith claimed to prefer it that way. The opening ""Wings (with Bells)"" and the later ""Reformation - Utrecht"" don’t fare much better in the audio stakes
column8: although the latter is at least an intense performance
column9: albeit one that sounds like it was recorded from a bathroom cubicle in the bowels of the venue.

column1: The two alleged studio recordings
column2: ""Auto 2014 Chip Replace"" and ""Amorator""
column3: are the worthiest additions to Uurop
column4: although both are little more than curios. Smith is in wonderfully hoarse form on the former
column5: where the drums stick to a neat Klaus Dinger clip
column6: Elena Poulou’s keyboards fizz in all the right places
column7: and an unexpected (if slightly ill-thought out) about-turn closes down the track. Neither of the songs make much sense here
column8: although this is an enterprise that doesn’t deal in logic
column9: especially as the commercial demand for poorly recorded live tracks is surely at an all-time low. Sometimes the grain of the recordings adds something; the leaden throb of David Spurr’s bass on “Irish” resembles someone shoveling through heavy mud
column10: while Smith’s over-loud and distorted vocal on the same track is suitably terrifying when it first lands. A typically acerbic ""Fifty Year Old Man"" and the following ""Wolf Kidult Man"" are highlights
column11: with both gaining a welcome layer of malice from being so grating in texture.

column2: the Fall released another part live/part studio album titled Interim
column3: the title of which made it feel like a stopgap. Uurop falls along similar same lines—unless there’s a surprise in store
column4: there will have been no new studio album from the band in 2014
column5: so this plugs a hole that didn’t really need filling in the first place. It’s a record that will most likely be listened to a few times by devotees then filed on a shelf or in a digital archive
column6: regularly getting thumbed past on the way to better material. Even people who were at these shows may have found their way to recordings of these moments already
column7:
or would rather not remember them this way.

Belief has been explored so often in music
column2: it’s become a cliché: The artist searches for meaning in the cosmos
column3: usually while grappling with the vestige of whatever faith he or she was raised in. The circumstances are different
column4: but the conundrum is always the same: How do you translate the most intimate
column5: infinity-grappling ponderings into songs that convey the micro and the macro of the matter
column6: answers to questions that have eluded the wise
column7: and enabled the ignorant
column8: for millennia? On Believer
column9: the debut full-length by Megafortress
column10: sole member Bill Gillim successfully charts a different course. He foregoes conclusions altogether and reframes the big questions as abstract
column11: almost mathematical contrivances. Then he threads his voice through them like a thief trying to pick a lock.

column1: For all the album’s well chilled minimalism
column2: Gillim’s voice is the most immediately striking thing about Believer. It’s virtuosic
column3: in its own way; his lyrics are delivered in neat
column4: easily graspable phrases and with piercing plainness
column5: but the notes are pure. He’s not trying to confound or mystify
column6: even though his range can plunge from heavenly falsetto to tormented moan. It doesn’t hurt that he gives his voice so much space. “Fear” is not only one of Believer’s most riveting songs
column7: it’s the album’s fullest exploration of Gillim’s scope. Round
column8: pulsing notes are coaxed from an upright bass while samples of saxophones split and reassemble around it. A piano skitters here; empty space yawns there. There’s a biomorphic falseness to the arrangement’s smooth
column9: curved surfaces
column10: but Gillim’s vocals breathe life into them. His lines are slow
column11: drawn out
column12: burdened with psychic weight. When he sings the word “fear” in an operatic register that would make Craig Wedren proud
column13: it’s one of the most arresting single syllables anyone’s committed to record all year. “Fear has come undone
column14: ” he intones narcotically
column15: and the absence of anything to replace it is just as terrifying.

column1: Besides his voice
column2: piano seems to be Gillim’s primary instrument. But where Perfume Genius’s Mike Hadreas and Grouper’s Liz Harris have made unique
column3: majestic use of the keys-plus-voice equation this year
column4: Gillim pulls back. He opts for tender clusters of chords
column5: allowing his songs to be driven more by synth hums and hovering blocks of nothing. “Pilot” works field-recorded loops of seagulls into its gaping
column6: throbbing
column7: extended metaphor for angels; eventually they’re indistinguishable from helicopter blades. The instrumentals “Beginning” and “Bogota” feel incidental
column8: treading the line between ambient and disposable. Mostly that’s because so many tracks on Believer seem as though they may be instrumental
column9: up until Gillim’s celestial voice wanders in; if he’s trying to toy with expectations
column10: it works at cross purposes to the record’s overall leap-of-faith prerequisite.

column1: The songs ""Never Becomer""
column2: ""Believer""
column3: and ""Murderer"" appear back to back on the album
column4: and those accusatory titles form a triptych. From agnostic to follower to apostate: Gillim presents portraits of discreet devotional forms
column5: then sets them up as a surrogate for a more sacred trinity. Accordingly
column6: they’re wildly incongruous pieces of a puzzle: ""Never Becomer"" is a voiceless meditation that spins around a shimmering synth arpeggio
column7: while ""Believer"" adds more sampled birdsong—along with bucolic splashes of water—to the album
column8: that is until it succumbs to a disjointed
column9: almost industrial creep. ""One hand for the Devil/ Same hand for the Lord
column10: Gillim sings
column11: and he comes within an inch of being too obvious. But he backs off on “Murderer"". Not only is it the most pop-forward track on Believer
column12: it lets its massive bass-snare beat etch out a vast territory of loneliness and unknowing that Gillim pegs as the heart of his spiritual confusion: ""No one to stand by my side/ No one to wait for me
column13: he pleads
column14: then he adds slyly
column15: ""I cannot make out your intentions/ But I know mine."" By that point
column16: the beat has ground to a halt and the synth hook has collapsed into an asthmatic drone.

column1: Dissonance and self-deconstruction dance at the edges of Believer
column2: although Gillim manicures that unease most gorgeously on ""Live in Grace"". It begins with him singing
column3: unaccompanied
column4: ""I can never recall your face/ But I know the sound of your voice/ Telling me to live in grace."" Keyboards seep in like shadows
column5: then ring like bells. The tension he creates is delicious
column6: a stasis between sinister and ecstatic
column7: and that’s only heightened when he sings ""Man with a thousand names/ But never just one to call when all alone""—especially seeing as how ""man with a thousand names"" could just as easily apply to God as to Satan. ""Climb if you wanna
column8: baby/ It’s the same as falling down
column9: he adds by way of summary. As beautifully simple as that sentiment is
column10: he puts a little twist in it on the way out
column11: and the bass line stumbles as it descends. Grace
column12: he seems to be hinting
column13: is not a state of being
column14: becoming
column15: or believing
column16: but some quantum cloud of all three. With Believer
column17:
Gillim is neither finding nor losing his religion. He’s groping in the heart-stopping hope of simply feeling the shape of it.

Were Obliterations born too late? The Southern California quartet have made an explosive hardcore-meets-'70s-swagger joint with Poison Everything
column2: their debut full-length for Southern Lord
column3: but the album comes at a time when rock music—guitar music
column4: even—is losing its cultural capital. Even if it inspires a few cheap ""rock is dead"" articles
column5: that isn’t necessarily a bad thing
column6: as rock and metal’s conservative wing has grown tiresome and irrelevant—see former W.A.S.P. guitarist Chris Holmes’ interview at this year’s Hellfest
column7: where he displays his bitterness about hip-hop replacing metal as the rebellious music of choice
column8: thus
column9: reducing his chances to ""make it"" in the States. Obliterations charge on anyway
column10: and Poison's energy makes it a vital record
column11: even if it’s somewhat out of step.

column1: Most of Poison is rock'n'roll as it should be—fuckin’ fast
column2: fuckin’ loud
column3: and ready with a joint and a case of whatever economy lager most litters your local punk house or DIY space (bringing Sierra Nevada to a house show? Get the fuck outta here!). Most songs are 2 minutes or shorter
column4: and they barely stop to mull over the damage they’ve inflicted. This isn’t pure nihilism
column5: however
column6: as there’s also an influence from political punk and grindcore bands like Discharge and Napalm Death at hand here. The cover art
column7: with its not-so-subtle references to Apple and Chase in Xerox black and white
column8: is the Scum of 2014. (That eye on the top right corner bears quite a similarity to the eye on Discharge’s Hear Nothing See Nothing Say Nothing
column9: too.) The lyrics deal with frustration from complacency
column10: depression
column11: and our decline into the apocalypse
column12: all of which could have appeared on a crust album from the '80s.

column1: When Obliterations set aside the blinding frenzy Poison blossoms like a carrion flower. ""Shame"" is the album’s slowest song
column2: but also one of the album’s best
column3: a Motor City banger in the tradition of Rob Asheton and Fred Smith. Opening with a brief wave of feedback before going into a groovy riff that carries a tough haziness
column4: ""Shame"" best combines the group’s voracious punkiness and feel for hooks. ""Open Casket"" also takes on a doomier approach
column5: though it’s closer to the Melvins than Sabbath. ""The Middle of the End"" shows a slightly different side of Obliterations’ Detroit obsession
column6: moving like Motown on nasty speed. Poison will not
column7: no matter what teary-eyed rock Jimmy Swaggerts would hope
column8: convince kids to burn their MacBooks and pick up Gibsons. It does
column9: however
column10: put forth scorched-earth attitude that is a common thread amongst the anger of youth
column11: disaffected or privileged or otherwise. That attitude should never diminish
column12:
even if the its voice changes.

The Venezuelan-born producer Alejandro Ghersi
column3: aka Arca
column4: has got a handful of releases to his name so far
column5: including 2012's Stretch 1 and Stretch 2
column6: a pair of bewildering EPs that threaded glassy digital synths with sped-up vocals and chopped'n'screwed stutterbeats
column7: all as twisted and contorted as the weird
column8: milky appendages pictured on their sleeves. Beyond that
column9: though
column10: Arca is best known as a next-generation super-producer
column11: or a potential one
column12: anyway. He's already produced some of FKA twigs' best work
column13: he's co-producing Björk's next album
column14: and he had a hand in four songs on Kanye's Yeezus.

column1: Ghersi's proper debut album
column2: Xen
column3: named for his ambiguously gendered alter ego
column4: shows that his brush with the big time has not softened him. Kick drums stutter and stumble; rhythmic patterns fall apart in mid-song. A few of the beat-oriented tracks
column5: like ""Fish""
column6: have come completely untethered from the rigid grid that usually governs electronic music's timekeeping. Sounding like a hardstyle rework of Laurie Anderson's ""O Superman"" made with a broken MIDI clock
column7: it flaps at the edges like a tarp with a busted tent pole. Aside from a few relatively placid sketches recalling Harold Budd or Vangelis' Blade Runner soundtrack
column8: the palette tends to emphasize hammered metal
column9: broken glass
column10: and melted plastic; plucked tones and bent notes and nails-on-a-chalkboard sheets of dissonance. (The strident synths of ""Tongue"" sound like they've been inspired by the shower scene in Psycho.) Taken as a whole
column11: it is an album about unstable unities
column12: things that cannot easily hold together
column13: wholes breaking to pieces and being put back together again in new and unfamiliar shapes.

column1: Even the pacing of the album seems to move in fits and starts. From the dramatic opener
column2: ""Now You Know""
column3: all elastic arpeggios and rocket-launch glissandi
column4: he feints left into the Harold Budd homage ""Held Apart""
column5: and from there it's on to the schizophrenic ""Xen""
column6: a song divided between metallic locust-swarm passages and Fairlight fantasias flecked with synthetic birdsong. ""Slit Thru""
column7: a downcast Dem Bow number
column8: gives way to the languorous and atmospheric ""Failed""
column9: a meandering synthesizer jam that wouldn't sound out of place on <a href=""https://soundcloud.com/visiblecloaks/fairlights-mallets-and-bamboo"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""><i>Fairlights
column10: Mallets and Bamboo
column11: a mixtape of Japanese ambient pop from the 1980s. From there
column12: the pizzicato string synths of ""Family Violence"" lead into the reggaeton-leaning ""Thievery""
column13: the closest thing to a single on the album. And so on
column14: all the way through the anticlimactic (but still exhilarating!) closer
column15: ""Promise""
column16: with its aimless string plucks and blast-furnace rumble. Xen feels less like a narrative arc than an amalgam of two- and three-minute chunks that might work just as well on shuffle. That's not a criticism. To the contrary: the album's mazelike shape is an indicator of how much lies beneath the surface. You really could get lost in this thing.

column1: It's been a while since it felt like there was anything really
column2: categorically new in popular music
column3: or even semi-popular music. As Simon Reynolds' Retromania argued
column4: the story of the century so far has mostly been one of collaging together the bits and pieces of earlier decades. Gradually
column5: however
column6: it is becoming clear that something is cresting the horizon
column7: and while it's too early to make out the particulars of its shape—this lumbering behemoth with the Teflon gleam and Transformer joints and image-mapping skin—it is getting closer.

column1: This new thing is not a genre
column2: exactly; call it a style
column3: a sensibility
column4: a veneer. It has to do with computers and digital sound and digital imagery. It has to do with representation and malleability
column5: the idea that sound and image can be stretched and twisted and copied ad nauseam. It revels in digital gloss and grit
column6: in bent tones
column7: in smeared and frozen reverb tails. Extreme compression
column8: schizoid pith: rap vocals broken down to monosyllables
column9: a single ""Huh"" as metonym for everything that's happened between the Sugarhill Gang and now. History reduced to a USB stick.

column1: It's not necessarily sci-fi in its themes—not
column2: say
column3: in the way that Detroit techno celebrated cybernetics and space travel—but there's still something inherently futuristic about its portrayal of technology as something tangible and even sensual
column4: its suggestion that data has texture and heft. It spins code into a second skin. (I realize that that description doesn't sound that far off from The Matrix—a 1999 film that
column5: these days
column6: we're likelier to read as kitsch than as prophecy—but this stuff is different; it's less Keanu than Cronenberg.) You can make out its traces in the work of people like Actress
column7: Oneohtrix Point Never
column8: Evian Christ
column9: FKA twigs
column10: Berlin's Janus crew
column11: and even PC Music
column12:
and it feels like it's coming to a head on Arca's Xen. The next few years—his next few years—are going to be interesting. 

"|19836.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19836-arca-xen/|8.4|Philip Sherburne

Our adult lives exist on a spectrum demarcated by domesticity and liberty. The stability of long-term companionship
column3: steady employment
column4: and home ownership comes at the expense of spontaneity
column5: adventure
column6: and wanderlust—and vice versa. Inevitably
column7: those residing on opposite ends of the spectrum start to long for what the other has. For the working musician—whose very livelihood is a function of perpetual financial risk and chronic displacement—those poles shift further apart with each passing year
column8: thus amplifying the cruel irony of trying to make a living so
column9: that one day
column10: they can enjoy a life that’s ultimately creeping further out of reach.

column1: While the old adage says ""there’s no place like home
column2: for Alex Zhang Hungtai home is no place. The music he’s produced as Dirty Beaches has amounted to an extended examination of the vagabond life
column3: one that he comes by honestly. (Well before he became a touring performer
column4: he had spent his formative years shuttling between Taipei
column5: Hawaii
column6: Montreal
column7: and all points in between.) While his 2011 breakthrough
column8: Badlands
column9: romanticized the lone-wolf lifestyle with its impeccably pompadoured inhabitations of early-Elvis and Suicide-schooled bad-boy archetypes
column10: the music he’s released since has focused on the flipside of that outlaw ideal: the constant sense of dislocation and isolation.

column1: His electro-shocked 2013 album
column2: Drifters and its soundscaped counterpart Love Is the Devil respectively captured both the hedonistic allure and homesick ennui of globe-trotting travel. But on Dirty Beaches’ latest release
column3: that feeling of disorientation and disconnection becomes all-consuming—to the point of obliterating his Dirty Beaches identity altogether. If Love Is the Devil was a series of impressionistic snapshots cataloguing the many far-flung locales stamped on Zhang's ever-crowded passport
column4: the all-instrumental Stateless captures the eerie sensation of waking up and not knowing where—or who—you are. After hearing this album
column5: you'll understand why Zhang recently announced he's retiring the Dirty Beaches concept: this is the sound of an artist who
column6: after years of nomadic musical exploration
column7: has reached the end of the road
column8: with nothing but open water before him and a desire to submerge himself completely.

column1: The pensive instrumentals on Love Is the Devil revealed Zhang's mounting interest in less theatrical
column2: more introspective modes of expression. With Stateless
column3: he finally achieves the state of pure anonymity that his work has been inching toward
column4: fashioning four extended pieces that do away not just with vocals and rhythm
column5: but identifiable melodic motifs altogether. As was the case with Love Is the Devil
column6: the song titles serve as highly evocative headers to blank diary entries—but where its predecessor offered some geographic cues to help frame Zhang’s free-form excursions (""Berlin""
column7: ""Alone at the Danube River"")
column8: Stateless deals in intangible
column9: existential messaging: ""Displaced""
column10: ""Time Washes Away Everything""
column11: and so forth. Even the one recognizable locale—""Pacific Ocean""—is defined by its imposing vastness.

column1: For all its seeming aesthetic and thematic open-endedness
column2: however
column3: Stateless proves to be the most focussed
column4: tightly orchestrated release in the Dirty Beaches canon. For one
column5: its two album sides share a similar arc
column6: opening with a relatively shorter piece—both of which clock in at exactly 7:27—that set up longer works surpassing the double-digits mark. And where the instrumentals on Love Is the Devil had a more roaming quality—with Zhang laying down wandering piano lines and serrated guitar shards as a gateway into his subconscious—Stateless is a work of deceptively serene
column7: slow-roiling tension
column8: liberated from traditional song structure yet claustrophobically contained at the same time.

column1: Recorded in his current homebase of Lisbon
column2: the album primarily features Zhang on synths and saxophone
column3: but
column4: in stark contrast to that combo’s new-agey connotations
column5: the tracks here are corroded in grainy
column6: greyscale textures. With Zhang’s staccato sax squawks woven into Colin Stetson-like oscillations alongside guest Vittorio Demarin’s trembling viola
column7: the opening ""Displaced"" resembles the foreboding intro to a Godspeed You! Black Emperor epic (shut your eyes and you can practically picture the accompanying Karl Lemieux projections)
column8: but lingers on the sense of encroaching dread rather than deliver the crescendo rock-out. On the title track
column9: layered synth drones form an oppressively thick mist under which Zhang’s saxophone murmurs are barely audible
column10: like foghorns emanating from some indeterminate location far off in the distance. For Zhang
column11: the ship is always arriving
column12: but never settling.

column1: Stateless’ second act eases up on the tension
column2: and in its place
column3: reveal subtle but forceful moments of emotional release: ""Pacific Ocean"" begins as a synth hum that’s as monochromatic and all-enveloping as the namesake body of water
column4: but Zhang gradually introduces affective chord changes that hint at all the wondrous subaquatic life that exists beneath the surface. And the immense 14-minute closer ""Time Washes Away Everything"" brings Demarin back for an exquisitely melancholic meditation whose intertwined
column5: synth-swaddled viola and sax sweeps constantly seem to be on the verge of flickering out
column6: before the embers come alight more brightly than before.

column1: If Love Is the Devil was intended to challenge the expectations of fans initially drawn to Zhang for the greaser persona and wild-child shrieks
column2: then Stateless—fitting for a finale—proves to be the ultimate test of their commitment. The album’s stationary sound and glacial pace
column3: ironically
column4: make it a more demanding listen than Dirty Beaches’ more outwardly confrontational
column5: punk-inspired previous releases. But coming from a musician who
column6: not too long ago
column7: could be easily slotted alongside other retro-fetishist garage-rockers
column8: Stateless feels less like a sad
column9: unceremonious farewell than the quietly triumphant completion of a mission
column10: the final step in an ongoing process of deconstructing Zhang's prefab persona into something pure and personal. Before the news broke of Dirty Beaches' demise
column11: Stateless sounded like an audio analogue to Zhang’s eternally unmoored existence. But now

Pianos Become the Teeth sound exhausted on Keep You. As well they should. For the better part of a decade
column2: they’ve created music of extreme emotional and physical engagement
column3: music tagged as “post-hardcore” because of the reverberating guitars and five-minute song lengths or “screamo” by the less self-conscious. Their 2009 debut Old Pride had a recording of Kyle Durfey’s mother describing the debilitating effects of multiple sclerosis on her husband
column4: a perversely calm moment because words were being spoken instead of yelled. Longevity isn’t expected out of the bands or the people in it
column5: and there are an equal number of former and current members of Pianos Become the Teeth. Several moonlight with Geoff Rickly’s hyperbolic
column6: great punk rock and roll swindle United Nations; by comparison
column7: that’s a fun band. And now here’s Keep You
column8: the result of Pianos Become the Teeth spending the past three years switching labels and drastically reconfiguring their sound
column9: consequently putting everything at risk. You will feel the burn.

column1: Keep You is Pianos' first album for punk heavyweight Epitaph
column2: which likely means it will be an introduction for many. If that’s your situation
column3: take a few listens to their previous highlights and know going in to Keep You that Durfey does not scream once. This is important for several reasons
column4: the least of which is that a lot of their older fans are pissed. Because it turns out that he can actually sing
column5: and in a rich
column6: resonant register rarely heard in indie rock and often associated with flannel-clad he-men of various stripes. But these are lyrics that require subtlety and range
column7: as Keep You edges towards acceptance following the four stages of grieving that preceded it. During opener “Ripple Water Shine”
column8: Durfey takes himself to task—“I'm still always slowly waiting for what follows/For what I've learned about being so defined by someone dying
column9: ” and going forward
column10: he does raise his voice
column11: but it never cracks. In this music
column12: you process and tolerate your inner turmoil rather than drowning it out.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: here’s drummer David Haik performing some of Pianos’ older material. He doesn’t do that either on Keep You; he’s just as active and dexterous
column3: but nowhere near as loud
column4: darting around “Repine” and “Ripple Water Shine”
column5: reminding the listener of the herculean effort they’re putting forward to repress their rage and how that could fail them; they probably won’t lash out
column6: but they might. And these are guitarists who haven’t lost their technical prowess either
column7: they just don’t have to play as fast or loud—Chad McDonald and Mike York rely on fingerpicked patterns and blunt-force chording to alternately constrict
column8: mesmerize
column9: soothe and bludgeon.

column1: So
column2: to recap—no screaming
column3: musicians of conservatory-level aptitude practicing extreme restraint
column4: and producer Will Yip doing his best Peter Katis impersonation
column5: keeping the vocals and percussion at the fore to establish intimacy in an otherwise hall-filling sound. Maybe Pianos Become the Teeth aspire to be the post-hardcore National? It’s not far-fetched when you listen back to the outsized
column6: half-sung “Hiding”
column7: which was included on a split 7” with Touché Amoré
column8: who would later cover “Available”. So Keep You is a progression more than a clean break
column9: and the best way to put yourself at the forefront of post-hardcore these days is to prove that you’re kinda done with it. If Keep You was intended as their way of separating themselves from Touché Amoré and La Dispute
column10: they’ve succeeded. But they're now just parallel to each other.

column1: Pianos’ craft is certainly at the level of Is Survived By and Rooms of the House
column2: which already feel like future standards
column3: but Keep You doesn’t have the same populist appeal. Everything here will bring a circle pit to a dead halt
column4: while melodic hooks and catharsis are scarce. Moreover
column5: Durfey isn’t a storyteller like La Dispute’s Jordan Dreyer
column6: nor does he speak in rallying cries like Touché Amoré’s Jeremy Bolm. Keep You’s lyricism bears a greater similarity to early Mark Kozelek
column7: captivating in its evocative detail and conversely
column8: prone to detail so personal
column9: it’s intimidating. Both aspects are prevalent during the stunning postmortem of “April”
column10: where Durfey drinks from a tin mug with an engraved date and even he’s unsure of its meaning—“What happened 7/31/76 that made them etch your name and the date?/ What'd I miss? It was a Saturday”. Even the person it’s addressed to is unclear—“I got your picture sitting on the sink...Water dripped and hit your cheek in the right spot/ It ruined my week
column11: when I just wanted to wash the filth off.”

column1: Emotionally pulverizing moments like these are so common throughout Keep You that it becomes something close to critic-proof. It’s certainly got its musical shortcomings
column2: but they that shrink in light of its potential to level those who can get past them. Whenever Durfey’s lyrics get too insular
column3: there’s the recognition that by giving so much of himself
column4: the best response is to give right back. Only Durfey and his family know the stories behind lines like
column5: ""I've never had that old Ed size/ I've never had Robert's prison guard skin""
column6: and
column7: ""How odd life would be if you had made it from Elmira to Kansas City/ Instead you cried the whole way
column8: punching the wheel home."" But you can relate if there are people in your past have been reduced to physical signifiers and the geographic signifiers are only relevant in your ability to understand the scale between them
column9: of leaving a suburb for the “big city” and being paralyzed with fear.

column1: When it seems like Keep You’s achromatic desolation is too unrelenting
column2: you catch a reference to memories formed in places like Arcade
column3: New York and Seven Valleys
column4: Pennsylvania. The latter is a town of less than 500 near the Maryland border; I’m guessing you’ve never been because damn near no one has. But if you’ve ever driven through anywhere in the rural mid-Atlantic
column5: particularly during this time of the year
column6: you might recognize the ache and strange hope in the barren trees
column7: endless fields and rundown building showing some kind of resilience in the middle of nowhere. It’s bleak and beautiful in the same way Keep You is
column8:
and it gives a lot provided you put your share of effort into it. And so you’ll probably feel exhausted after listening to Keep You; as well you should.

column3: Deptford Goth's Songs rings as lonely as breakup debris. The second LP from UK-based singer and producer Daniel Woolhouse
column4: Songs isn't quite the folksy confessional its title implies. This isn't Songs of Daniel Woolhouse; you won't find a ""So Long
column5: Marianne"" in its ranks. Instead
column6: Songs—maybe titled so simply as recompense for last year's punny Life After Defo—winds in tender and occasionally cathartic circles
column7: focusing on the fears that accompany an intimacy that's supposed to be permanent.

column1: I mean
column2: how do pessimists pair off? How do you put down your melancholy long enough to say
column3: ""Hey
column4: we'll probably like each other forever""? And once loneliness is legally written out of your record
column5: where do you put the sadness that mysteriously hasn't vanished now that you sleep next to the same person every night? Woolhouse's Songs circles through these problems of commitment as he tries to situate himself as one half of a stable whole.

column1: ""Every new day you can set on fire everything that you own
column2: Woolhouse sings on ""A Circle"". He can build a house
column3: he knows
column4: but not one that won't burn. This is a guy who's clearly in love and still can't help being a downer. ""I fell down/ Things all look bad to me
column5: he sings on ""We Symbolise"". ""Love stings
column6: everything goes
column7: he muses on ""The Lovers"". What's more
column8: he's got to weigh in his headspace with another person every day of his life. If there's danger
column9: it's shared
column10: for good or bad: ""I saw the weight in your eye in the corner of the night."" In marriage you get to be loved
column11: but you also have to be constantly seen.

column1: Behind his accented murmurs

column3: drums
column4: flutes
column5: and horns plop directly out of a keyboard

column7: of others sharing a room and playing with him. Surrounded by fakes
column8: Woolhouse sounds completely alone.

column1: It's there in his solitude that he can get at the roots of his worries. Woolhouse knows that for some of us

column3: he yearns to be better—to be the sort of guy who deserves the love he wants. ""Make me good
column4: he pleads on the beautifully revolving ""Near to a River"". ""Make me kind. Lift my body up. Make me kind."" He repeats the words like a mantra as the song overflows
column5: carrying him away on its surf.

column1: Even within the safety of companionship
column2: the outside world threatens danger. ""Find each other
column3: cause it's all we've got
column4: Woolhouse sings on ""A Circle"". When he gets far enough outside of his own head
column5: his expressions of love are charmingly simple: ""You're a human
column6: and I like you the best."" That's it. That's all there is. He cuts out the sparkle from romance
column7: knowing that it alone won't save him. But that doesn't mean he can't take root in it
column8: can't wear it like armor. ""We've got peace in us
column9: he concludes on ""Two Hearts""
column10: the first in the album's delicate two-song finish. ""Love
column11: love is enough."" Then
column12: on ""A Shelter
column13: a Weapon"": ""If you want me
column14: you can have me 'til the end of time."" There's no guarantee anything lasts that long
column15:
but he's willing to fight for something like forever.

Manchester's post-punk music scene in the early '80s had a rivetingly weird relationship to pop—grasping at the mainstream with one hand
column5: shoving it away with the other. A Certain Ratio started out as ascetic avant-gardists; their first single
column6: 1979's ""All Night Party""
column7: was beatless and entirely un-party-like. Then they picked up the smashingly sharp funk drummer Donald Johnson
column8: Jeremy Kerr got into slapping and popping his bass like he was Larry Graham
column9: and they started hanging out in New York City clubs—the same sort of conversion to dance music that their scenemates and (Factory Records) labelmates New Order were undergoing at the time. In 1980 and 1981
column10: ACR's singles ""Do the Du"" and ""Shack Up"" were even getting played at some of those dance clubs.

column1: After singer Martha Tilson joined up to give trumpeter Simon Topping a break from his reluctant position as frontman
column2: A Certain Ratio's six-piece lineup recorded and self-produced their third album
column3: released at the beginning of 1982. Thirty-two years later
column4: it still sounds like no other record: it's either that era's creepiest
column5: boggiest dance album or its funkiest smear of brittle art-noise.

column1: One axis of the Sextet-era band is Tilson
column2: who's as odd a vocalist as they could have picked. She's perpetually lagging behind the beat and beneath the pitches for which she's reaching
column3: and she swallows her words
column4: as if she's struggling to repeat them to herself. (Tilson's an acquired taste as a singer
column5: but awfully distinctive.) Topping's one major turn on the mic here is similarly strange: ""Skipscada""
column6: a two-minute flurry of Brazilian percussion and trilling whistles
column7: on which he scat-sings tunelessly
column8: rolling his R's with infectious glee.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Kerr and Johnson are doing their damnedest to play funk as hard as the Sugar Hill Records house band--hitting precise
column3: clipped grooves while their bandmates run interference with haphazardly flung splashes of atonal piano and dissonant horn bleats. ""Gum"" is produced like a good-time boogie track: Topping and Martin Moscrop's trumpets tootle out a soul-revue fanfare
column4: Johnson and Kerr punctuate every few lines with get-down flourishes
column5: and the whole band contributes to a samba breakdown. But everything's out of tune with everything else
column6: and Tilson's distantly wailing ""I'm sorrreeee... I can't remember your name..."" If anyone was waiting for another ""Do the Du""
column7: they'd have to keep waiting.

column1: What they'd have been waiting for
column2: actually
column3: was Sextet's centerpiece—just not in this form. On the album
column4: ""Knife Slits Water"" is a seven-and-a-half-minute
column5: two-chord mantra: Kerr works endless variations on a little bass figure as Tilson mutters about sex
column6: her voice doubled by an eerie pitch-displacement effect
column7: and somebody makes a bunch of prickly noise with a kalimba. By the end of 1982
column8: they'd re-record it as a single in the wake of Tilson's departure
column9: and the terrific and even longer 12-inch version (included here)
column10: sung by Johnson
column11: recasts the Sextet version's uncontrollable tremors as boogie fever.

column1: This new reissue appends a 13-track bonus disc to the original album. Besides the ""Knife"" 12-inch (and its B-side
column2: a near-instrumental Sugar Hill pastiche with the Kabbalistic title ""Kether Hot Knives"")
column3: it includes the ""Waterline"" single that introduced Tilson when it immediately preceded Sextet
column4: a couple of meandering dub experiments the band originally released under the name Sir Horatio
column5: and BBC radio sessions from 1981 and 1982. They all illuminate the band's curious fascinations and tensions in that period
column6: but Sextet itself—a gorgeous mess
column7:
slumped against the back wall of the best dance club in town—is no less mysterious for the illumination.

column1: It’s important to note that RTJ2 is an album—it’s on a real label and you can pay money to own it. And the transition from mixtape-to-album explains every progression El-P and Killer Mike have made in the past year. Think of it as the Hell Hath No Fury to Run the Jewels’ We Got It 4 Cheap—the latter were freewheeling collaborations that introduced commercially exiled veterans to a new audience of microphone fiends and completely reframed their public perception. The sequel feels more like a statement
column2: taking into account crucial constructs like sequencing
column3: judiciously granted guest spots
column4: and pacing. But Run the Jewels exchange Clipse’s unrelenting
column5: and highly specific mean streak for a righteous anger that has a gleeful
column6: conspiratorial edge—Run the Jewels get it and you get them.

column1: This is one of the more readily apparent aspects of Run the Jewels’ development as a functioning group; they were a festival act from the start and RTJ2 is a rare hip-hop record that sounds like it was created with live performance in mind. They’re two guys with dexterous
column2: booming voices over blaring production that’s percussive
column3: abrasive
column4: and dynamic. The first half is uncut aggression for any situation in transit
column5: the first thing you can reach for if you’re getting elbowed on the subway or cut off in traffic driving down I-85. As RTJ2 progresses
column6: it’s still the same detritus that filled El-P’s iron galaxy in the past
column7: only now

column11: try-hard ""Bombtrack""-style aggro braggadocio that doubles as the best verse of his life. On the whole

Both have been around long enough to recognize they share stages with EDM acts and fans with Future and Young Thug; rather than seeing them as threats
column3: they view them as inspiration and competition

They came of age during a time when ""the black CNN"" was actually something worth aspiring to and hip-hop isn’t the one that failed to keep up its end of the bargain; I don’t know if they finally found the plane or have moved onto 24-hour coverage of the ebola panic

column12: ""Go home

column12:
Run the Jewels 2 is in a class by itself.

column7: but that never seemed quite right to me—there was more lo-fi jangle and hiss to Mineral's songs

column9: Mineral were more aligned to the darker pop of mid-1990s indie-rock groups like fellow Texans Bedhead
column10: and they didn't strike me as quite so ""hardcore."" The connection with SDRE that did exist
column11: though
column12: was in the angsty
column13: acrobatic vocals of Chris Simpson
column14: which were in the same vein as Jeremy Enigk's
column15: but rougher.

column1: Take
column2: for instance
column4: the B-side to 1996's ""February"" 7""
column5: included on this new retrospective
column6: 1994-1998 - The Complete Collection. On it
column7: Simpson is about to visit his older brother (""It's good to know we haven't outgrown the love we shared as children"")
column8: and meet the woman that brother plans to marry. He talks about the secret language they shared at a young age
column9: when they dressed up as Batman and Robin for Halloween (""Everybody laughed at us and said we had it wrong 'cause you were the taller one"")
column10: and ends the track with all the force he can muster: ""She's beautiful/ And I know that you'll be happy/ So take this as my blessing/ Wrapped up with all the love that I can send/ 'Cause you are my brother/ My friend/ And my superior/ Till the end."" On paper it reads like a note you'd send to a sibling; in song
column11: it's towering.

column1: The emotions here are emo
column2: no doubt. This is the kind of music where people yell ""I stand on a building and throw up my arms to the sky/ I swallow my pride"" and ""This is the last song that I should ever sing/ Just one more time and I'll shut my mouth forever"" amid huge crashing guitars. Simpson sings about coming of age
column3: feeling unloved and embarrassed (""I bring it on myself/ I know I bring it on myself"")
column4: and also the innocence of youth
column5: being in love
column6: loving your family
column7: and what those connections and relationships mean. There are stabs at '90s DIY politics
column8: and he articulates being human and lost in great detail: ""When I'm finally naked and standing in the sunlight/ I'll look back at all of this selfishness and foolish pride/ And laugh at myself."" The melodrama
column9: in general
column10: is great
column11: and the music around it rises to the occasion. The songs are intense
column12: catchy
column13: over-loaded with feedback and beauty
column14: and meant to be yelled.

column1: Though they didn't release much
column2: their two proper albums are markedly different. The sound of 1998's EndSerenading was softer
column3: and more glistening than 1997's Power of Failing. It hinted at what Simpson would do with bassist Jeremy Gomez in their next band
column4: the Gloria Record
column5: and perhaps
column6: in retrospect
column7: suggests why the group went in two different directions: guitarist Scott McCarver and drummer Gabriel Wiley formed Imbroco then went on to found other projects separately. EndSerenading album was a pop
column8: and not a lo-fi or punk gesture
column9: and it's just not as compelling as Failing. It has plenty of good moments
column10: but it can also feel overthought and staid. Part of what makes The Power of Failing a classic is that its raw feel and execution matches its emotions.

column1: Mineral formed in 1994
column2: and released some singles and toured like crazy
column3: so Failing felt like a culmination. Conversely
column4: EndSerenading
column5: which they recorded with producer Mark Trombino (Blink-182
column6: Jimmy Eat World)
column7: felt
column8: at times
column9: like a lukewarm new beginning. They were supposed to do a third album for Interscope
column10: but
column11: of course
column12: it never happened. Which
column13: honestly
column14: is probably for the best. There's momentum on Failing that was already getting hemmed in on End
column15: not to mention the addition of labored song titles like ""LoveLetterTypewriter""
column16: ""TheLastWordIsRejoice""
column17: and ""&Serenading"". It's easy to imagine them becoming even shinier and more staid on a major label debut.

column1: Not to say End is a failure. Title aside
column2: ""LoveLetterTypewriter"" is an excellent
column3: moving opening track
column4: and one of their best. Simpson sings the words patiently
column5: and with more refinement than in the past (and
column6: honestly
column7: more like Enigk): ""Summer unfolded like a tapestry/ And you were there as you have always been/ There glowing where the sky meets with the trees/ Air softly crowing
column8: singing fears to sleep/ Will you ever know how much I love you for that?"" It's a constant build that crashes into the next track
column9: ""Palisade""
column10: a song that serves as climax and release before moving into another direction. It's an exciting one-two: these pieces pick up where Failing left off; the formula is updated
column11: but not abandoned. The same goes for the group-singing of the next song
column12: ""Gjs"". But then
column13: they take it down a few notches
column14: often ending up too mid-tempo and over-long. The music remains pretty
column15: and even knottier
column16: but feels less life-affirming.

column1: For instance
column2: the spacious
column3: ultimately clamoring ""&Serenading"" would be a good closer <span>(""When I was a boy I saw things/ That no one else could see/ So why am I so blind at 22?"")
column4: but instead of the gorgeously repeated finale (""the sound of the driving snow that drives me home to you"")
column5: it's the downtempo
column6: shimmering acoustics and humming vocals of the pretty-but-slight ""TheLastWordIsRejoice"" that serve as our exit. Like the forced titling
column7: it's inoffensive
column8: but feels unnecessary
column9: as do other grown-up touches on End. That line from ""&Serenading"" quoted above reminds you just how young these guys were
column10: though
column11: and why they might feel the need to ratchet it up on their sophomore record
column12: considering the attention given to the first.

column1: Not that it mattered
column2: of course. They ended and then
column3: as bands do now
column4: they reunited; this remastered two-disc compilation is a good way to hear it all in one sitting (the reissues are also available
column5: without the bonus tracks
column6: on vinyl). None of the alternate take bonus tracks here are especially riveting
column7: and the covers of the Psychedelic Furs' ""Love My Way"" and Willie Nelson's ""Crazy"" are mostly forgettable (the latter's actually pretty bad)
column8: but it's great to have the relative lo-fi ""Rubber Legs""
column9: from the 1997 (Don't Forget To) Breathe compilation
column10: the punked-up ""Sadder Star""
column11: which appears on the 1997 First Crush compilation
column12: and
column13: most importantly
column14: the 1996 ""February"" b/w ""M.D."" single
column15: which includes a couple of their best songs.

column1: When I listened to the Power of Failing in real time back then
column2: it was often on a cassette that I'd dubbed from the vinyl
column3: for when I was traveling. Because of that
column4: I always thought ""February"" and ""M.D."" were part of the proper record
column5: and was surprised to realize they weren't. That's just one example of how music becomes personal
column6: and shifts according to your own relationship with it. It's something you're faced with when the music of your youth keeps resurfacing
column7: and it can be weird
column8: but also somehow touching. For instance
column9: it's been good going back to these records so many years later
column10:
and realizing I find myself moved more by the songs about family than the ones about wondering on roofs alone.

Dej Loaf is not in the habit of writing checks she can’t cash. The 23-year-old Detroit native
column2: named for her high school footwear preference
column3: is matter-of-fact to the point where you can’t help but to trust her completely. Part of that comes from her not-so-distant backpacker past: Just Do It
column4: her self-released 2012 solo debut
column5: was full of Midwestern earnestness and diaristic boom-bap somewhere between Slum Village and popped-Polo Kanye. Stylistically
column6: that stuff couldn’t be further from ""Try Me""
column7: Dej’s sweet-and-sour breakaway hit that gently threatens to turn enemies into a variety of Italian delicacies—a track that garnered the attention of Drake and secured her a deal with Columbia Records. But though Sell Sole
column8: her first release in the spotlight
column9: is devoid of the literal college dropout jams of her debut
column10: that sense of confessional non-fiction lingers. As her songs have grown weirder
column11: her lyrics have kept that idiosyncratic bluntness and a repulsion for theatrics. When some hometown detractors ask
column12: early in the tape
column13: why she insists on stunting on them so hard
column14: her response is pragmatic: “I don’t know.”

column1: Sell Sole represents a transitional stage for Dej
column2: documenting the full gradient of her shift from straightforward raps to hustler’s nursery rhymes. This isn’t to say that her more traditional songs are lacking: she can rap
column3: as immediately evident in no-hook
column4: no-nonsense opener ""Bird Call"". Her voice is light and gauzy
column5: sometimes a little wispy but always clear and authoritative; lyrically she’s clever but restrained
column6: delivering deadpan jabs in a half-smirk (""Diamonds dancing like Omarion in You Got Served""). But though her rappin’-ass rapping is accomplished
column7: Dej seems to have sensed that these songs are not likely to have the impact of ""Try Me"". Sure enough
column8: the highlights of the tape are when Dej sings
column9: either in half-rapped hybrid (on woozy crew love number ""We Be On It"") or in full-on R&B mode (done best on ""Easy Love""
column10: the star-crossed soulmate of Chief Keef’s cult favorite ""Citgo"").

column1: Even in its most aspirational moments
column2: Sell Sole is clouded with a pervasive sense of mourning. Throughout the tape
column3: Dej recalls bits of herself she has lost
column4: most notably through the death of her father
column5: cousin
column6: and grandmother. There is no real climax
column7: no ""HYFR"" moment. Instead
column8: catharsis comes from the act of telling things as they are
column9: quietly absorbing the suffering in her surroundings and soberly reflecting them back outward. On ""We Be On It""
column10: when Dej borrows Beyoncé’s self-love rallying cry
column11: ""I woke up like this
column12: it’s rendered calm and almost existential: ""Okay
column13: here I am.""

column1: Dej’s cool realism and off-hand threats of violence have been compared to Chicago drill
column2: but Lil Durk is her only real peer in the genre. Durk
column3: too
column4: is a technically great rapper when the occasion calls for it
column5: though like Dej
column6: his best songs often don’t. Instead
column7: both have an improvisational knack for melody and a tendency toward unshowy
column8: personal lyricism. Her most direct influence
column9: though
column10: may be the late rapper/producer Speaker Knockerz. The quietly trend-setting South Carolina native developed a solid Midwest following before his unexpected death earlier this year
column11: and Dej’s ""On My Own"" in particular is a direct descendent of his uncharacteristically somber last single
column12: ""Lonely"".

column1: Wisely
column2: there are relatively few features here
column3: but the tape’s most prominent guests serve as a study in contrasts. On tape highlight ""Blood""
column4: known hyperbolist Young Thug
column5: whose power often lies in his gift for caricature
column6: acts as Dej’s foil; where Thug thrills with his unpredictability
column7: zipping from wistful sing-song to geeked-up double-time flow
column8: Dej’s comforting evenness keeps things planted firmly on earth. Most enlightening is the remixed version of ""Try Me""
column9: featuring guest verses from Remy Ma and Ty Dolla $ign along with an entirely revamped verse from Dej. Remy sounds right at home
column10: gladly assimilating into Dej’s universe
column11: but Ty’s contributions sound flat and unnatural. Though he traffics in a similar mode of rap-R&B hybridization
column12: his breed of detached
column13: fuck-your-feelings melodicism is a sore thumb in the midst of a tape so unguarded and unconcerned with coolness. Even if Sell Sole sometimes feels more like an artifact of transition than a polished final product
column14:
Dej’s emotional honesty feels vital.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21211/homepage_large.ea6e7cbc.jpg|Lifer|29803.0|Dope Body|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-10-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:27.523218|"

Did Dope Body really need to boldface its '90s fetish by naming a song ""AOL"" on their new album? The answer is no. They did it anyway. On Lifer
column2: the Baltimore band’s follow-up to 2012’s Natural History
column3: ""AOL"" is the most blatant reference to that bygone decade of dialup Internet and weirdo alt-rock that made In Utero sound safe. Drive Like Jehu
column4: Girls Against Boys
column5: Brainiac
column6: Chavez
column7: U.S. Maple: This is Dope Body’s deliciously warped version of '90s pop history
column8: and accordingly
column9: they’ve been able to pull that into a tight knot of noise that doesn’t actually sound too retro at all; there are sonic nods here and there
column10: some obvious and others of the Easter egg variety
column11: but mostly they’ve managed to refresh a subversive
column12: aggressively squirrelly approach to racket-making that never had the chance to become played out in the first place. ""AOL"" is as good an example as any on Lifer. It slinks
column13: thrashes
column14: boils over
column15: shrinks down
column16: gets jazzy
column17: and is stabbed with jagged hooks by singer Andrew Laumann
column18: who babbles and slurs while guitarist Zachary Utz surgically cripples his own riffs like a true '90s guitar antihero.

column1: Despite all that
column2: ""AOL"" is not the most thrilling demonstration of Dope Body’s prowess. A foaming-at-the-mouth intro lapses into a leaden breakdown; rather than dynamic
column3: it feels slapdash. Most of Lifer is better
column4: but there’s a marked drop in energy to the album as compared the band’s prior work. Yet somehow
column5: the record sprints along at a brisk pace; that velocity
column6: though
column7: doesn’t seem to go anywhere. ""Repo Man"" splits a simmering
column8: Fugazi-esque buildup with Laumann’s mush-mouthed
column9: vaguely angry poetics
column10: but none of it coagulates into a single focused hook or mood. On ""Nu Sensation""
column11: tar-pit guitar stews in its own mock-stoner-rock filth while the vocals meander
column12: ramble
column13: babble
column14: and attach to nothing.

column1: When Lifer clicks
column2: though
column3: it’s unkillable. ""Hired Gun"" slices open its own means of entry with Utz’s needling
column4: staccato harmonics; Laumann’s lax snarl hits peak slacker charisma
column5: and the swaggering riffage mixed with wah-pedal leads imagines J. Mascis jamming with Rocket from the Crypt. Things get downright punk on ""Toy""
column6: although the album’s angriest track
column7: ""Day by Day""
column8: scratches and swarms without fully blowing the hatch off. ""Rare Air"" is the album’s best song
column9: a snakelike sashay through pinging effects and a dub-worthy bassline from John Jones
column10: formerly of fellow Baltimore band Roomrunner. But even then
column11: Utz’s thick
column12: surfy riff could have come straight off a Pixies outtake. ""Wanna be original/ Don’t wanna be a wannabe
column13: Laumann sings
column14: and it’s not clear at all if the irony is lost on him.

column1: Laumann
column2: at his worst
column3: can lapse into a frat-scat leer that comes across unsettlingly like Anthony Kiedis; he goes there on the slinky
column4: smoky ""Echo""
column5: and it doesn’t help that in the lyrics of ""Toy""
column6: the three words ""under the bridge"" actually appear in that order. If Lifer were either catchier or crazier
column7: it would be far better. As it stands
column8: it feels like a placeholder
column9: something to pass the time until a more rounded
column10: less pastiche-leaning version of Dope Body gets dialed up. As soon as they figure out that they don't have to lift wholesale chunks of inspiration from any of their heroes in order to make their point
column11: they may find a way to more creatively harness their '90s worship. Until then
column12:
Lifer has just enough life of its own.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20968/homepage_large.f0a1cd0a.jpg|Then It All Came Down|31484.0|Wrekmeister Harmonies|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2014-10-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:28.134381|"

When the organ that begins Then It All Came Down first cuts through a stutter of static and becomes the kind of tone that will flood any space with luminous and stable sound
column2: the music seems instantly embryonic. That’s not in the simple sense that this low
column3: fluttering signal is the start of the second one-track album from the Chicago chamber doom-and-drone collective Wrekmeister Harmonies. And it’s not that this is the origin from which everything else unfolds. It’s that
column4: almost immediately
column5: you can sense where these 34 minutes might be headed before they’ve had the chance to grow beyond a single note. Recorded in a church and then re-recorded from playback in a lakeside lighthouse
column6: the organ seems haunted
column7: like a ghostlight fading in and out of the middle distance. It’s less outwardly threatening than eerie
column8: a warning to proceed with caution. Turns out
column9: that premonition is correct: The end of Then It All Came Down is a waking nightmare.

column1: Then It All Came Down takes its title from a 1973 Truman Capote interview with Bobby Beausoleil
column2: the budding entertainer-turned-murderer who the author called ""the key to the mystery of the homicidal escapades of the so-called Manson family."" But J.R. Robinson
column3: the mastermind of Wrekmeister Harmonies
column4: didn’t only lift the name of the Capote essay. He lifted its spirit
column5: or more exactly
column6: the key question behind Beausoleil and the Helter Skelter mob at large: How did a bunch of drug-doing
column7: orgy-inducing kids with visions of stardom and famous acquaintances turn so decidedly dark?

column1: In an accompanying essay that traces the links from Aleister Crowley’s credos and teachings to hippies
column2: Manson and the whole lot
column3: Robinson grapples with that lingering concern and its spiritual underpinnings. ""Rather than earning their spot in the sun by fighting their way through the darkness
column4: [Manson and Beausoleil] reversed the sequence
column5: starting with the positive and working towards the negative
column6: he writes. This piece
column7: which moves in the time of one sitcom episode from that docile drone into a noise-flanked doom fisticuffs
column8: is Robinson’s musical representation of such perversion. At the start
column9: Then It All Came Down suggests a world of possibilities; by its end
column10: the only available outcome seems to be some form of purgatory
column11: a nihilistic vacuum of supposed free will.

column1: The process
column2: then
column3: is obvious
column4: even predictable: Then It All Came Down moves from rather gentle tones to complete miasmic atonality. But the path between those poles is surprising
column5: stepwise and involved
column6: the chief feat of Robinson as a bandleader and composer. To complete this piece

column1: To match the colossal approach of his releases

What happens in the margins of the music Liz Harris makes as Grouper is often as important as the music itself. In a performance at Krakow's Unsound Festival earlier this month
column3: the rattle of a film projector added a layer of instant nostalgia to her murky swirls of voice and guitar. Much of the time

column5: no difference between foreground and background.

column3: Oregon
column4: musician since last year's The Man Who Died in His Boat. Here
column5: the incidental noises—crickets
column6: croaking frogs
column7: thunder and rain
column8: and
column9: at one point
column10: the unmistakable beep of a microwave oven that fired up after a blackout in the house where she was recording—serve primarily to underscore how stark the music is
column11: unadorned and pocked with vast silences. Ruins is Grouper's ""unplugged"" record
column12: essentially
column13: as much as that might sound odd for a musician who has always put acoustic guitar and piano and voice at the core of her work. Here
column14: however
column15: she foreswears the looping pedals and the innumerable layers of fuzz that are just as essential to her aesthetic. What we're left with is achingly beautiful and

column17: she often plays sitting down

column19: her face hidden in shadow—almost unnervingly direct.

column3: and rarely
column4: if ever

column6: she sings on ""Holding""
column7: her multitracked close harmonies reminiscent of Low circa The Curtain Hits the Cast. On the devastating ""Clearing""
column8: she sings
column9: ""Every time I see you/ I have to pretend I don't""; on ""Call Across Rooms""
column10: she has a change of heart: ""I have a present to give you/ When we finally figure it out."" (""The song is on one level very plain and literal
column11: about a letter I wrote for someone I loved and could not get along with
column12: she told Vogue.)

column1: Not everything is so explicit. In ""Clearing""
column2: she keeps her vocal range between the notes of her piano chords
column3: as though she were seeking refuge there
column4: and her wispy voice frequently dissolves into indecipherability
column5: like cold breath passing through a beam of sunlight. Her phrasing is tentative and guarded; even without recourse to her trusty loops
column6: she finds ways to muddy the atmosphere. Multitracking offers a way of hiding behind her own shadow
column7: and her foot rarely leaves the piano's sustain pedal
column8: even on the instrumental numbers.

column4: ritualistic drumbeat wreathed in the sound of distant frogs. And the closing ""Made of Air"" returns us to the drifting ambient world of Grouper that we're most familiar with. The latter dates back to 2004
column5: and it's of a piece with other material from that period
column6: like her 2005 album Way Their Crept
column7: where looping tones of uncertain provenance—Voice? Guitar? Keyboard?—swirled into a jellied haze. It doesn't necessarily fit with what's come before it
column8: but it's a welcome addendum to the album
column9: if only for its familiarity.

The last eight years of John Coltrane’s life were a period of astonishing creativity. In 1960
column3: he was leaving Miles Davis’ group after a stint during which it was widely understood to be among the greatest jazz units of all time. In 1967
column4: he was at the leading edge of free jazz
column5: creating abstract and unbelievably intense music that left the mainstream far behind. In between he recorded impossibly dense music with a big band (Ascension)
column6: ballads and standards albums with Duke Ellington and Johnny Hartman
column7: extended suites (A Love Supreme and Meditations)
column8: and had generally pushed jazz as far as it could go. And then
column9: in July 1967
column10: he was gone.

column1: During his brilliant run between 1964 and 1967
column2: Albert Ayler
column3: a fellow tenor saxophonist whom Coltrane admired tremendously
column4: seemed like he’d finally found the music he was meant to make. Coltrane was always searching. His music was never content with where it was but was always looking toward what it might be. This would be less interesting if not for the fact that this search is embodied in the sound itself. There’s always something left hanging in Coltrane’s later work—when it ends you feel not just everything that happened but also what might have happened but didn’t. And you sense that he felt same way. He famously told Miles Davis that he played so long because he didn’t know how to end his solos
column5: and Miles famously told him back
column6: “Take the horn out of your mouth.”

column1: Eight months before he died
column2: Coltrane played a gig at Temple University. It was recorded by the radio station but has only been heard in partial
column3: poor-quality bootlegs until this year
column4: when it was polished up and issued for this set. The music on Offering shifts between standard ideas of jazz and noise music
column5: regularly tipping over from chords and melody and harmony into the realm of pure sound. So I tend to experience music like this as a visceral thing
column6: something to be played loudly that can be both beautiful and frightening.

column1: The last two years of Coltrane’s life found him experimenting relentlessly
column2: perhaps aware
column3: on some level
column4: that he only had so much time to get it all in. He used extra bassists
column5: extra drummers
column6: new kinds of percussionists
column7: expanded ensembles. On this night in Philadelphia
column8: he had some of all these things: a couple of extra saxophone players he knew from the area as well as Umar Ali
column9: Algie DeWitt
column10: and Robert Kenyatta on percussion. I’m obligated to point them out because they are in the credits and they were an important part of this gig as the people in the room experienced it. But the truth is
column11: this recording
column12: all done through one microphone without much thought for posterity
column13: misses a great deal of sound from those extra drummers and percussionists and
column14: indeed
column15: from the pianist
column16: Alice Coltrane
column17: as well as the bassist
column18: Sonny Johnson. This set puts the focus squarely on the leader
column19: who was nearest the microphone
column20: and his playing—and vocalizing—made this a special night indeed.

column2: electric jazz was just around the corner; the music would later get denser and more intense
column3: it would mix with rock or go way over into the realm of abstraction. Coltrane himself seemed to be returning from the edge of chaos. Live in Japan
column4: recorded in July 1966 but not released in full until 1991
column5: was about as far “out” as he got
column6: stretching tunes that once lasted for eight or nine minutes to nearly 60
column7: and filling them with explosive atonal blowing. But by the time this set was recorded
column8: he was returning to Earth as if after an armageddon
column9: seeing what was left. He starts here with “Naima”
column10: a pretty tune written in 1959 that later became a standard. The harmonic structure is difficult to puzzle out
column11: but Coltrane plays with force and clarity
column12: in a melodic mode even as the tune differs from the familiar lines. It does
column13: however
column14: have Alice Coltrane’s longest solo
column15: an intense banging thing that reveals the nature of her genius. (She could be a superb soloist on two instruments as a leader
column16: but her distinctive voice never quite emerged in her husband’s band.) You have to use some imagination to hear the song inside of it.

column1: “Crescent” is almost unbearably intense
column2: the brittle shrieking egged on by someone yelling “Hey!” in the background. Melody and harmony are sacrificed at the altar of texture and feeling
column3: anger and joy bleed into sadness. Once in a while you can hear a cowbell in the background
column4: and you get a glimpse of what it might have been like to be here on this night. “Leo”
column5: one studio version of which was found on the Coltrane/Rashied Ali duo album Interstellar Space
column6: was another staple of Coltrane’s sets during this period
column7: and its hyper-bouncing opening theme sets the stage for a long and intense blowing session. This is Ali’s turn to solo
column8: and he does so beautifully
column9: the articulation of every hit coalescing into a blur of feeling
column10: his drums showing greater clarity when other instruments drop out.

column1: During the following track
column2: “Leo”
column3: something unusual happens
column4: a moment that has been mentioned extensively in the marketing of this release: Coltrane sets aside his horn
column5: and starts to vocalize
column6: singing phrases while beating on his chest to give his vocals an effect something like vibrato. The first thing that comes to mind with this gesture is that perhaps Coltrane had reached a point where his instrument couldn’t convey the feelings he had locked inside; it spilled out beyond the realm of technique
column7: and there should be no object between the expression and the reception. This is what I think of when considering a piece of music recorded eight months later
column8: by Albert Ayler
column9: at John Coltrane’s funeral
column10: when he gives over the last few minutes of his performance to ecstatic and tortured screams. But Coltrane was never quite as unhinged as Ayler
column11: he always tempered emotion with his intellect
column12: and his music
column13: even at its wooliest
column14: always had a sense of control. So Coltrane’s vocals are best heard as an extension in texture
column15: a musical expression as opposed to just an emotional one. And they do add much here—every time his voice comes in
column16: it’s disarming.

column1: By the time the record gets to the iconic “My Favorite Things”
column2: we’re reminded that Coltrane was doing some strange things with the tune by this point
column3: most notably starting it with a bass solo that lasted several minutes. You’re in a certain headspace as a music listener when you’re sitting through bass solos that go on for that long
column4: but when the tune finally kicks in
column5: it’s still fascinating to follow where Coltrane was taking this song. At points
column6: his soprano saxophone trills away on repetitions that suggest Steve Reich-like minimalism
column7: elsewhere the music leans toward noisy drone. “My Favorite Things” was a center of gravity that Coltrane would move around
column8: sometimes examining it from a distance
column9: taking in the beauty of the whole
column10: and sometimes veering so close to it he threatened to burn up. And while I wouldn’t put this version in the top 10 of ones I’ve heard
column11: it’ll never get old for me.

column1: Considering his stature in American music
column2: every note of John Coltrane’s music deserves release. That’s a given. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that every note has something for the broader music listening public. Offering passes that test
column3:
it’s both an “important” jazz release and one that’s actually enjoyable to listen to.
