Onstage during a Hollywood Bowl concert last year
column2: M83’s Anthony Gonzalez talked about how the veteran L.A. dream-pop band Medicine had influenced his music. Then he brought out Medicine’s leader Brad Laner to sing with him on M83’s “Splendor”—which makes sense
column3: seeing as how Laner guests on the 2011 studio version of the song. The gesture was a small one in the grand scheme of things—it’s a safe bet few in the audience recognized the name—but it’s also indicative of Medicine’s less than enviable position over the years: a band loved
column4: respected
column5: and imitated by musicians
column6: but minimally acknowledged beyond that. Like many groups in existence during the alt-rock free-for-all of the '90s
column7: Medicine had its shot at fame; signed to Rick Rubin’s American Recordings
column8: they appeared on the chart-topping soundtrack for The Crow (and in the movie itself
column9: along with Cocteau Twins’ Elizabeth Fraser). When that lottery ticket didn’t pan out
column10: the band broke up in the '90s
column11: then reformed for their 2013 comeback album To The Happy Few. But where To The Happy Few feasted on Medicine’s legacy with a desperate yet stately elation
column12: the band’s new full-length
column13: Home Everywhere
column14: just sounds desperate.

column1: Home Everywhere is a mess. It isn’t always a bad mess
column2: but far too often
column3: it is. Where To The Happy Few exercised impeccable taste and restraint in its attempt to probe every overblown trope of shoegaze and space-pop
column4: Home Everywhere piles them on. And on and on and on. The panning from left to right is juddering
column5: spasmodic
column6: panicky. Worse
column7: it works against the melodic euphoria Laner excels at; a little deconstruction goes a long way
column8: and Laner’s lost the plot. Songs like “The Reclaimed Girl” and “Move Along – Down The Road” aren’t psychedelic
column9: as that would imply at least the possibility of bliss. Instead
column10: Laner pumps so many samples
column11: filters
column12: noisemakers
column13: and modulators into the mix
column14: the band’s own instrumental source material is treated like something that should be anxiously covered up.

column1: Of course
column2: it shouldn’t; there are great tunes poking out of the tangle
column3: or at least great fragments of tunes. Too many of them in rapid succession
column4: actually
column5: or all at once. Laner’s longtime cohort Elizabeth Thompson twines her ethereal voice wonderfully around his on “Don’t Be Slow”; still
column6: it’s not enough of a lifeline to cling to as the music boils and manically pans around them. Making music that sounds like an orchestra of malfunctioning transistor radios at once is a noble pursuit
column7: and one that My Bloody Valentine consummated triumphantly; MBV have always been one of Medicine’s biggest inspirations
column8: and that hasn’t changed on Home Everywhere. But where MBV—and Medicine
column9: at their best—nervily harness those smears and blurs
column10: “Turning” renders that lovely paradox of abrasive dreaminess into stabs of spectroscopic strobe lights
column11: garbage-disposal bass
column12: and self-sampling to the point of bleary-eyed myopia. It doesn’t come off as experimental
column13: any more than it would to dump every chemical on the lab floor to see what happens.

column1: When Home Everywhere takes a deep breath
column2: though
column3: it’s incredible. “Cold Life” is spacious
column4: dynamic
column5: and eerily backmasked
column6: or at least backmasking is the aural illusion that Laner is trying and winning at evoking. It’s a gentle queasiness
column7: and it’s made all the more absorbing by Laner’s flowing
column8: melancholy vocals
column9: even though he sounds like he’s brazenly mimicking Elliott Smith for some reason. Similarly
column10: “They Will Not Die” and “It’s All About You” reign in the album’s sensory overload
column11: daubing it sparingly from time to time for maximum impact. At over 11 minutes
column12: the album’s cosmic-jam title track doesn’t justify its sprawl; it’s over about halfway through
column13: but someone forget to tell the band that. At this point in Medicine’s existence
column14: they’ve earned the right to get as excessive as they want—and in a way
column15: it’s thrilling to see a group that’s been around so long continue to go for broke with rapturous self-indulgence. Home Everywhere has every element needed to make a great Medicine album
column16:
only they’re deployed in gangling spasms and obsessive over-processing. If only they’d edited themselves a little more—or a little less.

Natalie Mering
column2: the brains behind the indie-folk outfit Weyes Blood
column3: has seen a great deal of the country in the past few years. She has toured as a member of noise-rock outfit Jackie-O Motherfucker and alongside Nautical Almanac
column4: although most listeners will recognize her robustly forlorn voice from Ariel Pink's Haunted Graffiti’s Mature Themes. After the release of her 2011 label debut
column5: The Outside Room
column6: she has wandered America like a Steinbeck character (anyone who adapts her stage name from a Flannery O’Connor novel will certainly be familiar with literary references). Mering tapped maple trees for syrup in rural Kentucky and studied herbs in the New Mexico desert. After a brief layover in Baltimore
column7: she settled into the New York music scene and signed with Mexican Summer.

column1: All of those experiences—from harsh drone to hallucinogenic herbology—come to play on her second album
column2: The Innocents (which is presumably a reference to the 1961 film adaptation of Henry James’ ""The Turn of the Screw""). The album plays like a picaresque of the Lower 48
column3: as Mering collects sounds and ideas along her journey and pieces them together into an album that has considerable scope yet is rooted in the personal. Drawing from Donovan and Joan Baez as well as Mark Linkous and Sonic Youth
column4: Mering blends the idylls of folk ballads and madrigals with the sonic abrasiveness of noise rock. Most of the songs feature just guitar and Mering’s rich soprano
column5: but on several tracks she manipulates the instruments to suggest music that is curdling
column6: fading
column7: transforming
column8: evolving right before our ears. Even the simplest and loveliest tunes
column9: such as “Requiem for Forgiveness” or closer “Bound to Earth”
column10: sound like they might be interrupted at any moment by waves of distortion.

column1: To indulge another literary reference
column2: the center will not hold. Things fall apart. There is no solid ground on The Innocents. The album opens with explosions in the distance
column3: a rhythm of destruction that portends something darkly ominous. Borrowing not just the music but also the topicality of '60s folk
column4: “Land of Broken Dreams” conveys a sense of immense dread as Mering sings about an America in fantastical disrepair—in particular
column5: the growing rift between what the country should be and what it actually is. “Stand by to believe in the land of the free
column6: whatever you want it to be
column7: ” she sings
column8: and it’s impossible to determine just how much irony is packed into that line. Are those explosions an echo of atomic testing in the 1950s
column9: or perhaps of the bombs planted by radical activists in the 1970s?

column1: The aftershocks of those opening explosions reverberate throughout the album. “Bad Magic” sets its delicate acoustic guitar theme against an ambient tape hiss
column2: as though Mering were self-consciously creating a new field recording. “Some Winters” opens with a warped piano
column3: its glissandos garbled and mutating
column4: as though Mering found the tapes buried deep in the snow—memories of an old affair made new. “I’m as broken as a woman can be
column5: ” she sings
column6: with a peculiar quiver in her voice. That vibrato
column7: it becomes clear
column8: is not part of the performance itself
column9: but a subtle distortion of the notes in the studio. It’s applied so sparingly that it’s impossible to determine where her voice ends and the manipulation takes over
column10: and the effect is thematically powerful and musically jarring. There’s no small thrill in hearing Mering both uphold and upend the conventions and even the pieties of folk music
column11: which means that while The Innocents may be her second album
column12:
it plays like a debut. These finely wrought songs introduce a fascinating and confidently subversive artist and offers a glimpse of the road she’s traveling.

Oozing Wound would like to let you know they’re not a thrash metal band. It’s easy to see where the confusion would arise: while the group has roots in Chicago noise rock
column2: last year’s Retrash owed as much to Voivod’s sci-fi weirdness as it did to crossover’s streetwise attitude. Oozing Wound weren’t trying to infiltrate a scene
column3: they just happened to make an inventive record most thrash revivalists couldn’t. A year after Retrash they return with their second record
column4: Earth Suck.

column1: Absurd humor has always been a part of Oozing Wound’s music
column2: and while that’s mostly manifested itself in the lyrics
column3: it extends itself into the actual riffs on Suck. Opener “Going Through the Motions Til I Die” leads off with a stonery passage that could be from a Red Fang song
column4: but just when you think they’re about to stroke their beards sensually and talk about how they’re “really into metal like the Sword
column5: ” they bring the most unchill hate.

column1: A stranger iteration of this comes on “Genuine Creeper”
column2: a homage and pisstake on black metal. The band’s gleeful warpath wouldn’t be appropriate for a BM song
column3: but those riffs are nothing but necro. And if a song about coveting a neighbor’s property isn’t blasphemous
column4: then what is? (If “Creeper” were on a lo-fi cassette
column5: collectors would be tripping over themselves to get what few copies existed.)

column1: Things take a turn for the doomier with “Hippie Speedball”
column2: which sounds like them joking around with fellow Chicagoans Bongripper
column3: thinking “oh yeah
column4: this slow and low thing is for chumps.” This
column5: like most of Suck
column6: shows the strength of letting Chicago’s wide range of metal and punk influence penetrate their sound and loosening things up. Even so
column7: Suck is more focused than Retrash
column8: most evident in better sequencing that balances the longer and shorter songs.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Suck is obsessed with selfishness and its consequences. The first line
column3: after all
column4: is “I’ve lost the will to live an honest life.” While these themes appeared on Retrash
column5: they were competing with heavily baked sci-fi pulp odysseys. Here
column6: Oozing Wound have largely dropped the sci-fi lyrics
column7: but not their rage. “Bury Me With My Money” leaves you with no pity for the toy-hoarding
column8: money-crazed lunatic vocalist Zack Weil conjures. It’s also the thrashiest number on the album
column9: with no use for subtlety. “Speedball” could be considered the aftermath of Retrash’s “Call Your Guy”
column10: where the promise of drugs as mind-expanding gives way to the harrowing realities of addiction. This is not the lust of power of “Money”
column11: but simply the crippling need to be “a thief in a palace of waifs” in order to survive.

column1: It all takes its toll on closer “False Peak (Earth Suck)”
column2: giving words to the album’s cover
column3: a multi-fisted assault on our worthless egg of a world. Oozing Wound have matured without losing sight of the frayed ends that make their music interesting. That growth is especially impressive given the length of time between Suck and its predecessor. The band didn’t need to be a part of a dying
column4:
irrelevant movement; they’ve got what it takes to make one for themselves.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21101/homepage_large.9ede7c75.jpg|With a Little Help From My Fwends|1504.0|The Flaming Lips|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-10-27 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:32.263215|"

Back in the mid-1980s
column2: the easiest way for underground bands to draw ideological battlelines separating themselves from their 1970s arena-rock antecedents was to appropriate their most hallowed songs for devious ends. And so we got J. Mascis moaning his way through Peter Frampton’s “Show Me the Way”
column3: the Minutemen chopping Van Halen songs in half
column4: Pussy Galore licking the burnt spoons littered throughout the Rolling Stones’ Exile on Main Street
column5: Sonic Youth swiping the title of CCR’s “Bad Moon Rising” for their Reagan-era state-of-the-union address
column6: and the Butthole Surfers grinding Black Sabbath’s “Sweet Leaf” into skunk weed. In this context
column7: what made the early
column8: garage-punk iteration of the Flaming Lips so strange was not their sordid subject matter
column9: disturbing cover art
column10: or 23-minute acid-rock jams. It was their contrarian reverence for tradition
column11: with the band dropping straight-faced covers of Led Zeppelin’s “Thank You” and Louis Armstrong’s “What a Wonderful World” into their repertoire for no other reason than they loved the songs.

column1: As the Lips scored sudden mainstream success in the early '90s with a fluke MTV hit
column2: their cover choices turned decidedly more esoteric
column3: as the band used their modicum of celebrity to shine a light on known artists’ lesser-known work
column4: reclaim new-wave novelties
column5: or to promote then-unheralded underground peers. But in the post-Soft Bulletin era—during which the Lips’ music became both more tonally serious and relentlessly experimental—cover songs have become a necessary salve through which the band can reassert their playful side and maintain the circus-like atmosphere at their concerts even when touring behind decidedly more downcast material.

column1: And ever since they trotted out old warhorses like “Bohemian Rhapsody” and “War Pigs” on their 2006 At War With the Mystics tour
column2: the Lips have seemingly been on a mission to modernize the entire classic-rock canon
column3: by curating full-album
column4: collaboration-heavy reconstructions of Pink Floyd and King Crimson milestones (with a Stone Roses debut-album redux thrown in to show they’re still fond of music made after 1980). But while such recurring retro-gazing exercises may seem antithetical to the adventurous
column5: boundary-pushing ethos the Lips displayed on 2009’s Embryonic and last year’s The Terror
column6: the mere task of making the most totemic (and
column7: by extension
column8: contemptuously overplayed) rock songs of all time seem fresh presents its own formidable challenge
column9: one they’ve answered by gradually shifting their cover-song approach from faithfully sacred to kill-yer-idols profane. Now comes the greatest challenge of all: tackling the Beatles’ Summer-of-Love soundtrack <i>Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band
column10: a generation-defining achievement so masterful that its very title has become the official shorthand descriptor for masterful achievements.

column1: The Lips aren’t the first to give Pepper a shake
column2: but even the post-punk/new pop makeover the album received on the 1988 NME-curated comp Sgt. Pepper Knew My Father—complete with Mark E. Smith warbling “A Day in the Life”—feels overly staid and deferential compared to what transpires here. And even by the standards of the Lips’ previous tribute-album overhauls
column3: With a Little From My Fwends is a colossal
column4: chaotic undertaking
column5: its 27-collaborator guest list bringing together pop singers (Miley Cyrus
column6: Tegan & Sara)
column7: fellow alt-rock veterans (J. Mascis
column8: Tool’s Maynard James Keenan)
column9: Bonnaroo royalty (My Morning Jacket
column10: Dr. Dog)
column11: indie phenoms (Foxygen
column12: Phantogram)
column13: and maverick MCs (Cool Kid Chuck Inglish)
column14: alongside the usual army of Lips affiliates like New Fumes and Stardeath & White Dwarfs. And where previous experiments were limited to Record Store Day releases or iTunes exclusives
column15: this one is a more widely publicized benefit album for the Bella Foundation
column16: an Oklahoma City-based animal shelter that provides crucial veterinary services to low-income pet owners. But while the charitable component lends With a Little From My Fwends a noble purpose beyond just being another Wayne Coyne-commandeered
column17: clown-car-filling amusement
column18: the end result occasionally suggests your time might be better spent revisiting the original album and making a direct donation.

column1: One of the great breakthroughs of Sgt. Pepper was how it used the recording studio to create a vivid
column2: three-dimensional sense of space and place
column3: bringing the lyrics to life in audio-storybook form. (Think of the live-concert ambience of the opening title-track “With a Little Help From My Friends” suite
column4: or the carnival-esque clamor of “Being For the Benefit of Mr. Kite!”; even the clarinet refrain of “When I’m Sixty Four” gives off the musty scent of a grandparent’s house.) But the Lips and Fwends go to town on these songs with little regard for thematic resonance or big-picture atmosphere. In the spirit of the aforementioned 80s-era indie cover-song desecrations
column5: these aren’t so much revisions as disembowelments that replace the guts of the originals with a tangle of short-circuiting exposed wires. And given that the Lips weren’t even around to supervise all of their guest contributions (Coyne and co. actually only appear on a handful of tracks)
column6: things undoubtedly get messy quick
column7: if not downright hazardous. With its scatterbrained
column8: kinder-pop take on the title track (which climaxes with an arrhythmic
column9: atonal guitar solo from J. Mascis)
column10: and a strangulated call-and-response between Wilco offshoot the Autumn Defense and Lightning Bolt’s Brian Chippendale (aka Black Pus) on “With a Little Help From My Friends”
column11: the project effectively gives Sgt. Pepper the shreds treatment.

column1: Of course
column2: even the most successful cover songs in pop history are inherently blasphemous—in that they suggest unexplored avenues that the original could’ve taken
column3: coax lurking undercurrents to the fore
column4: and cast the source material in an entirely new light. But the problem with a lot of these versions is that they’re unruly on just a surface level. Whether it’s the wobbly-kneed Dr. Dog/Morgan Delt/Chuck Inglish gang-up on “Getting Better”
column5: Maynard James Keenan’s inert
column6: industrialized “Mr. Kite!”
column7: or Def Rain and Pitchwafuzz’s vocoderized
column8: static-swirled “When I’m Sixty Four”
column9: the Lips’ Fwends are so intent on tripping up the songs’ rhythmic momentum and weirding up the basic melodies with hammy vocals that they ultimately reinforce their sturdiness. They’re trashing all the furniture in the house
column10: but not bulldozing any walls to open up new vantages.

column1: It’s the simple revisions that yield the greatest revelations. The Electric Würms—aka the Lips alter-ego aggregate that promotes Steven Drozd to lead vocalist—recast “Fixing a Hole” as a charmingly low-key psych-folk reverie that amplifies the song’s slow-percolating existential ennui; Stardeath’s stuttering synth-funk take on “Lovely Rita” is given a sly queer spin by guests Tegan and Sara (while their robotic delivery —coupled with the song’s mechanistic motion—craftily adapts the song to a modern world where parking enforcement is largely an automated process). And while Foxygen—with the help of MGMT’s Ben Goldwasser—stretch out the Sgt. Pepper title-track reprise to nearly triple the original’s length (making it even longer than the song it’s supposed to set up
column2: “A Day in the Life”)
column3: it’s transformed into precisely the sort of wiggy organ-pumped workout Billy Shears and the boys might have used to close down some imaginary festival set on the Isle of Wight.

column1: Ironically
column2: the seemingly most outrageous aspect of this entire endeavour—i.e.
column3: the mere presence of Miley Cyrus—proves to be its grounding force. On an album where everyone is trying way too hard to out-freak one another
column4: Cyrus—much like the Led Zep-loving Lips of the '80s—stands out by simply playing it straight (which feels strange in and of itself). Tellingly
column5: she’s entrusted with the album’s two most celebrated songs
column6: turning in effective duets with Coyne on a splendorous
column7: slow-motion surge through “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds” and a suitably mournful “A Day in the Life”
column8: where she handles an electro-ticked
column9: space-age update of Paul McCartney’s middle eight (and really does sound like she just woke up
column10: fell out of bed
column11: and dragged a comb across her head). Curiously
column12: the relatively reverential reading of the latter song leaves out its most notorious feature—that <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-Q9D4dcYng&feature=youtu.be&t=4m19s"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">dramatic
column13: sustained piano-pounded finale. The omission is both intentionally heretical (how can you end that song any other way?) yet oddly reverential
column14: suggesting that
column15: even if you’re subjecting one of the most revered albums of all time to sadistic sonic surgery
column16: some things are sacred. According to the eternally loopy logic of the Flaming Lips
column17:
reinforcing a spiritual connection to your greatest influence means cutting the chord. 

"|19862.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19862-the-flaming-lips-with-a-little-help-from-my-fwends/|5.5|Stuart Berman

Many black metal bands claim they're peerless or too brilliant for any ""scene
column3: but France’s Blut Aus Nord are one of the few who actually manage to stand above it all
column4: releasing some of the most triumphant and mind-bending black metal music since the mid-'90s. Led by Vindsval
column5: the band’s reclusive composer
column6: vocalist
column7: and guitarist (and sometimes sole member)
column8: they are the black metal equivalent of Aphex Twin
column9: in that never release the same album twice
column10: but release albums that sound like only they could have made them.

column1: Most bands are lucky to have one distinctive record
column2: or even a derivative album just original enough to merit positive reviews: Blut Aus Nord’s trajectory
column3: from the unforgiving frost of their debut Ultima Thulée (composed by Vindsval in his mid-teens)
column4: to the industrial nightmares of The Work Which Transforms God and the 777 trilogy
column5: is nothing short of astounding. Their newest offering
column6: Memoria Vetusta III – Saturnian Poetry
column7: like the other albums in the Memoria Vetusta series—1996’s Fathers of the Icy Age and 2009’s Dialogue With the Stars—is an exploration into grandiose melodic black metal
column8: and it's not only the strongest entry in that series
column9: but also continual proof that Blut Aus Nord remain unrivaled in this realm.

column1: On the surface
column2: moving in a more recognizable direction may seem like a regression
column3: especially for an artist praised for an unrelenting march towards new territories. But Blut Aus Nord have far from repeated themselves here. As great as Vindsval was on Thulée and the other two Memoria Vetusta records
column4: he’s a much more seasoned musician in 2014. Poetry boasts clearer production than the rest of Blut Aus Nord’s work
column5: which better showcases how much he’s poured into this. He layers his guitars so they become the strongest voices
column6: so much so that it’s not an issue that his growls are a little low in the mix. If pressed to find a standout track
column7: a difficult task with a record of this level
column8: ""Tellus Mater"" showcases his desire to reach the heavens
column9: letting riffs soar high without falling into the overwrought ""symphonic"" trap. Except for an ambient ""Prelude"" and a bridge in ""Forhist"" that recalls Thulée’s more tranquil moments
column10: this record hardly lets you rest.

column1: Blut Aus Nord have always been about transporting listeners into realms they could not fathom themselves
column2: realms that only an idiosyncratic personality like Vindsval could imagine
column3: and Poetry is no exception. Instead of disorienting you with dystopian-future chord patterns and alienation
column4: it overloads you with opulence.  <span>The beauty found here is intoxicating
column5: and you’ll feel a dizzying conqueror’s lust coming out. This is most evident in the use of choral vocals throughout the record; they’re uplifting
column6: and in the haze Poetry cloaks you in
column7: you think they’re deifying you. Even in rapture
column8: Vindsval can make a sharp turn into chaos
column9: which he does by tweaking his guitar playing on the last two songs
column10: ""Metaphor of the Moon"" and ""Clarissima Mundi Lumina""
column11: making his riffs feel more like apocalyptic prophecy. This shift is subtle
column12: and you may not catch it on the first listen
column13: but it gives Poetry a closing trajectory that ties it all together.

column1: Vindsval’s also found fresh blood in new drummer Thorns
column2: who’s played in a variety of other bands including Frostmoon Eclipse
column3: Glorior Belli
column4: and Deathrow. While he also contributed to Triunity
column5: a split with P.H.O.B.O.S. from earlier this year
column6: this record marks his real entrance into the band
column7: and even with such huge expectations on his shoulders
column8: he delivers a more than capable performance
column9: showing he can meet the demands of even the most bewildering musicians. Poetry wouldn’t have made sense with Vindsval’s electronic drum programming from the 777 series—those records were more industrial
column10: whereas this record is more recognizably black metal
column11: and a cold
column12: mechanical drum machine wouldn't work. There needed to be something with some blood behind it here
column13: something more ""natural."" He needed a human touch
column14: even if his music is otherworldly.

column1: It’s also worth nothing that few albums do justice to their cover art as Poetry does. The cover was designed by Kristian ""Necrolord"" Wåhlin
column2: most famous for the majestic sceneries of Dissection’s two classic albums
column3: 1993’s The Somberlain and 1995’s Storm of the Light's Bane
column4: and the exquisite chaos of Emperor’s 1994 landmark In the Nightside Eclipse. Vindsval’s layered compositions compliment the hypnotic and intricate details of Necrolord's work. Great music was made before the ""album experience"" and humanity’s need for music will live long after it
column5: but it’s still always gratifying to see a complete vision like Poetry come to life
column6:
especially in a body of work as masterful as Blut Aus Nord’s.

"|19945.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19945-blut-aus-nord-memoria-vetusta-iii-saturnian-poetry/|8.2|Andy O'Connor

Black Milk is a paradoxical artist
column3: one defined by both wild reinvention and stasis. To this point
column4: every other Black Milk album is a corrective
column5: somehow a refutation of the album that came before it. He keeps pressing reset and then playing the game the same: Tronic was his vaunted abandonment of vinyl fetishism for synthesizers; Album of the Year his embrace of live-band instrumentation; No Poison
column6: No Paradise his nightmare-filled stab at creating a '70s soul epic. But put them on shuffle and the delineations disappear—they all sound like Black Milk tracks. On If There's a Hell Below
column7: for the first time
column8: he consciously takes a sonic mulligan
column9: trading in the same murky Castlevania synth-lines
column10: wrecking-ball drums and dark-night-of-the-soul wails as its predecessor.

column1: So
column2: why does it sound better than that album? Because it's a new Black Milk record
column3: which always sound incrementally closer to some Ideal Black Milk Album that may or may not ever exist. This makes him a difficult artist to love
column4: but an easy one to like. He’s constantly halving the distance to his target
column5: getting closer but not quite getting there. But those infinitesimal improvements on Hell Below—indeed
column6: the very places where it remains static—show
column7: in some ways
column8: what that Ideal Album might look like.

column1: Most importantly
column2: he’s acknowledging where his talents lie. The old line on him is: great producer
column3: shitty rapper. If the dude could quit spitting double-time platitudes about getting faded backstage
column4: the thinking goes
column5: he’d release a great record. On <i>No Poison
column6: No Paradise
column7: though
column8: he dialed back his eagerness on the mic and let the beats breathe. This trend continues on Hell Below
column9: particularly on ""Story and Her""
column10: a sprightly
column11: smooth-jazz Tribe throwback that evokes Q-Tip more than Dilla. Over soft vibes
column12: Black Milk drops sing-song come-ons that tumble organically into a low-key verse. The lyrics are as trite and sanctimonious as can be (think Dizzee Rascal’s ""Jezebel"")
column13: but as the beat morphs
column14: halfway in
column15: to a keening
column16: insistent guitar lick
column17: Milk follows suit
column18: with a wide-open flow painted in blank space. The crooning intro melts into an almost spoken-word outro
column19: with a rhyme scheme that snaps into place as if only to tug the verse onward.

column1: He sounds
column2: in other words
column3: good on the track—a first for the emcee. He repeats the feat on the nearly 3-minute conclusion ""Up & Out""
column4: which is just a drum loop
column5: some scratches
column6: and a delirious
column7: stuttering mic performance. In both instances
column8: he raps in reverence of the beat
column9: letting his glorious drums hit without shouting punchlines over them. Elsewhere
column10: he resolutely does not screw up highlights like the proggy ""All Mighty""
column11: the dense
column12: clattering ""Quarter Water""
column13: or ""What It’s Worth""
column14: which recalls early Kendrick Lamar
column15: of all people
column16: in its tuneful sense of melancholy. He’s always seemed to want to be Black Thought
column17: but he comes across more like T.I. on the best parts of Hell Below
column18: saying very little but saying it well.

column1: The focus
column2: then
column3: stays on the production
column4: which is
column5: as usual
column6: an absolute feast. He’s grown fond of the mid-track left-field switch-up
column7: sometimes just for a bar or two (""Hell Below""
column8: ""Scum"")
column9: and of the short
column10: dusty outro loop (pretty much every track). While this might sound scattered
column11: in practice it’s just the opposite: He’s settled down a bit
column12: flicking between beats with Madlib’s ease. A lot of his earlier stylistic about-faces were because of an anxiety
column13: a tension between analog and digital production methods
column14: which a recent LP and EP (tellingly called Synth or Soul and Glitches in the Break) seem to have eased. He found the ghost in the machine
column15: and so he’s agitating less over realness—over fidelity to the ""old school"". The music on Hell Below is one big wistful wash of sound
column16: unified
column17: but full of idiosyncrasies. (Bun B
column18: for example
column19: raps atop a bed of trilling flutes.)

column1: We often talk about listening to Black Milk rap as the cost of entry for listening to Black Milk produce. That's cold
column2: but valid: his relatively flat collaborative work suggests that he saves his best beats for himself. But perhaps it’s also a mis-framing of the argument
column3: in light of Hell Below’s success. In an interview with Complex last year
column4: he referred to an incongruous blast of free jazz on <i>No Poison
column5: No Paradise as ""a Spike Lee movie … written via a rap song."" A more skillful emcee would recreate Lee’s sense of place and character with words
column6: but Black Milk needs the music to do the talking. On If There’s a Hell Below
column7:
he lets it.

column3: 29-year-old singer/rapper Ellinor Olovsdotter has hopped freely between dance music sub-genres. The Swedish polyglot who works as Elliphant released a solid
column4: energetic pop-rap debut EP last January only to follow it up with A Good Idea
column5: a garish
column6: Sweden-exclusive LP that ran the gamut from Björk-indebted industrial dance to pedestrian sample-based synth pop. She then went on to work with Diplo and co. at Mad Decent for this year’s Look Like You Love It
column7: an EP comprised of dubstep
column8: dancehall
column9: and punk-rap with assists from Skrillex. Still
column10: that frantic
column11: mixed-bag approach
column12: like A Good Idea before it
column13: lacked the unabashed vitality that the first Elliphant EP brought to the table. Olovsdotter has cited No Doubt and Portishead as early influences
column14: but her output thus far seems more informed by the former’s cultural pastiche rather than the latter's willful eclecticism.

column1: One More
column2: Olovsdotter’s latest release on Dr. Luke’s Kemosabe Records
column3: seems intended to temper the unfocused Look Like You Love It. The production across these five tracks
column4: while still filled with its share of glitchy electronic drops
column5: is more subdued than anything Olovsdotter’s done before. Here
column6: she seems more at ease settling into 4 a.m. cabs home at the end of the night rather than indulging in the bacchanalian club life her Mad Decent entry suggested.

column1: That half-sedate
column2: half-totally-wired vibe is best realized on the EP’s title track. With Lorde collaborator Joel Little handling production
column3: ""One More"" teems with sparse
column4: undulating synths as Olovsdotter trades verses with Danish pop upstart MØ about 24-hour taco spots and playing hooky from work. The call-and-response finale of ""One More"" switches the track from a modest
column5: pulsing lead single to a near-perfect anthem for getting faced with your best friend. Closer ""You’re Gone"" is of a piece with the title track
column6: taking similarly understated production and hoisting it up with a thumping boost of a chorus
column7: providing quality bookends to One More that suggest more of the EP than it's willing to dole out.

column1: The EP's middle section has the same flaws that crippled A Good Idea and Look Like You Love It
column2: namely lazy songwriting (""Never Been in Love"") and tired stabs at singalong melodies (the Doja Cat-assisted
column3: FIFA 15-soundtracking ""Purple Light""). Even ""Save the Grey""
column4: which shares its name with Olovsdotter’s conceptual activism project aiming to ""save the grey animals like elephants
column5: rhinos
column6: whales
column7: sharks
column8: and wolves
column9: tries for a sense of urgency and fails. Perhaps by the time Elliphant releases a debut LP stateside
column10: she’ll have found a more winning balance between the high energy of her party-starting anthems and the more introspective
column11:
hangover-friendly deep cuts.

On September 30
column2: Daniel Crespo
column3: the mayor of the Los Angeles suburb of Bell Gardens
column4: was shot and killed. It wasn’t a political assassination. His wife pulled the trigger. This event is utterly unrelated to Slow Dawns for Lost Conclusions
column5: the second album by the dreamy
column6: chamber-pop ensemble Bell Gardens. The group
column7: which was cofounded by L.A.’s Brian McBride (Stars of the Lid)
column8: chose their name years ago; their debut EP Hangups Need Company came out in 2010
column9: and their first album Full Sundown Assembly came out in 2012. But McBride has worked in soundtracks before
column10: and fate has decreed that Slow Dawns for Lost Conclusions can be viewed
column11: in an unhappily accidental way
column12: as the coincidental music to a tragedy.

column1: If the album wasn’t so magisterially moody
column2: it would be easier to ignore the parallel. But from the ghostlike balladry of “Darker Side of Sunshine” to the windswept strumming of “Take Us Away”
column3: McBride and Bell Garden’s other core member Kenneth James Gibson (formerly of Furry Things and now [a]pendics.shuffle
column4: dubLoner
column5: and Eight Frozen Modules
column6: among others) create cinematic
column7: big-vista threnodies dusted with tumbleweed Americana. The abstract
column8: conceptual wavecraft of Stars of the Lid is only an apparition on the horizon; Gibson’s ambient treatments are dyed sepia and dissolved into the album’s threadbare fabric. Gibson has never sounded more like a conventional singer-songwriter
column9: and his singing has improved vastly since Full Sundown Assembly. Not long ago
column10: he strained to hit the notes and tones he seemed to be groping for; on Slow Dawns standouts like “Silent Prayer” and “She Does”
column11: he navigates reverbed electric piano and tranquilized tambourine shakes with the easiest
column12: breathiest grace.

column1: Bell Gardens has fleshed itself out since Full Sundown Assembly
column2: and that expanded ensemble has led to a richer stratifying of strings
column3: pedal steel
column4: synth
column5: and trumpet (some of which is supplied by guests Lauren Chipman of the Rentals and Stewart Cole of Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros). It all forms a smothering
column6: gray-brown haze
column7: yet each element remains discreet and distinct
column8: from the crisp acoustic chords of the instrumental “Joan’s Ambulance” to the chem-trail synths of “Take Us Away”. The brief
column9: voiceless interlude “Avere” comes closest to scratching the group’s classical itch
column10: but even its funereal
column11: chamber-ready study in piano and violin sounds as if it’s being played under a Mojave palm.

column1: Eerily
column2: the late Mayor Crespo’s profile page on the City of Bell Gardens’ website has not been updated to reflect his death. It says he can still be reached at his city email address; it also states with tragic irony that “in 1986
column3: Mayor Crespo
column4: a young teenager
column5: married his high school sweetheart and has been married ever since.” Synchronicity can play a huge part in the way music is conceived
column6: executed
column7: released
column8: and heard. Slow Dawns for Lost Conclusions is no work of prophecy
column9: but it may be a more diffuse kind of premonition
column10: one that taps into some larger West Coast darkness.

column1: “Darker Side of Sunshine”
column2: “Joan’s Ambulance”
column3: “She’s Stuck in the Endless Loop of Her Decline”
column4: “Trust Lost Trust”
column5: “Take Us Away”: These song titles reflect the album’s slow
column6: sad flow of destiny and escape. A cover of Kris Kristofferson’s “Why Me” (billed here as “Why Me Lord”) is included as a digital-only bonus track; its hushed
column7: hymnal plea for release—“Jesus
column8: my soul’s in your hand
column9: ” Gibson sings over a shivering ablution of strings—would be gently devastating in any context. But especially this one. Slow Dawns for Lost Conclusions didn’t need an extra layer of portent and atmosphere hanging over its release. But it’s been given that layer anyway
column10:
and it only makes the songs feel that much more delicately heavy.

column1: Sleater-Kinney was consciously about rock'n'roll. Lou Reed sang for Jenny whose life was saved by rock; Ramones told us how Sheena became a punk. In 1994 there was no shortage of women plugging in—newly born classics included Hole's Live Through This
column2: Liz Phair's Exile in Guyville
column3: PJ Harvey's Rid of Me
column4: the Breeders' Last Splash—but the lineage of larger-than-life stars
column5: the deified behind-the-head-shredders
column6: still had few instances of women delivering rock-as-saviour meta-narratives themselves. Sleater-Kinney turned the machismo of hippie-blooded '60s and '70s rock on its head: covers of Springsteen and CCR
column7: homages to Kinks and the Clash
column8: Brownstein's Pete Townshend windmills and shin-kicking swagger
column9: Tucker's defiant declaration that ""I make rock'n'roll!"" A life-or-death seriousness is omnipresent with Sleater-Kinney
column10: but they never rejected rock's base desires—sex
column11: dancing
column12: proverbial milkshakes—although sometimes they vaguely mocked them. Sleater-Kinney stole from men what men had in turn stolen from the margins: electrified blues that all still made girls scream.

column1: The first Sleater-Kinney practice was in March of 1994. It was the spring that Kurt Cobain died. Hindsight paints it clear: Cobain's desire for a future-rock made by women dispersed into the universe. Brownstein and Tucker did Sleater-Kinney as a side-project to their respective bands
column2: the queercore power-chord screams of Excuse 17 and soul-baring punk of Heavens to Betsy. Sleater-Kinney fused these politicized sounds
column3: but as they grew—with affection for B-52's shimmy and Sonic Youth cool—they never let the punk rulebook limit their vision. Riot grrrl was fragmenting and they learned from its successes and failures—a radical streak pervaded their writerly Hüsker Dü-type storytelling—but they also fought to not be removed from the context of their foundation. The wiry blast of 1995's Sleater-Kinney is as good an indicator of Bikini Kill's influence as any feminist album since
column4: echoing their sound as well as an interest in making punk become activism.

column1: The debut is foremost a rejection of heteronormative sex
column2: as Tucker and Brownstein were reckoning with life inside their bodies as women who approached sexuality fluidly. There's a song about how much sucking dick sucks
column3: called ""How to Play Dead""—it began Sleater-Kinney's mission of showing how society can silence women and minimize their problems. The urgency is real; all of Sleater-Kinney was scrappily-recorded in one night
column4: on a trip to Australia

column7: Tucker gasps with visceral sarcasm. Call it clit-rock
column8: I guess; over hard-style riffs

column1: Sleater-Kinney continued feeding its appetite for destruction of archetypes on 1996's Call the Doctor. It improved their raw punk convictions in every way: more complex guitarwork
column2: more distortion to intellectualize
column3: more aggression and profound sadness. ""Why do good things never wanna stay?"" Tucker asks on ""Good Things""
column4: an earnest stomach-twister of a teardrop tune
column5: while the dire ""Anonymous"" wonders why its female protagonist is voluntarily unspoken. ""I Wanna Be Your Joey Ramone"" uses tradition to infiltrate and subvert—the riff could be Ramones pushing Stooges' ""I Wanna Be Your Dog"" into the red—to cleverly protest the worship of male icons and spur revolution: ""I wanna be your Joey Ramone/ Pictures of me on your bedroom door/ Invite you back after the show/ I'm the queen of rock and roll."" It's a two-and-half-minute rock'n'roll joyride deserving of a gender studies thesis.

column6: Chainsaw

(They despised the new proposition of a career-shifting iPod commercial.) The band stopped just as independent music was becoming more financially significant—2004 was the year future indie-Grammy-holders Arcade Fire landed—but traditional notions of integrity were also growing complicated. Brownstein was strangely prophetic: ""I took my money/ And bought me a TV/ TV brings me closer to the world."" This is music you make when you can sense it's one more hour 'til the walls close in.

(They despised the new proposition of a career-shifting iPod commercial.) The band stopped just as independent music was becoming more financially significant—2004 was the year future indie-Grammy-holders Arcade Fire landed—but traditional notions of integrity were also growing complicated. Brownstein was strangely prophetic: ""I took my money/ And bought me a TV/ TV brings me closer to the world."" This is music you make when you can sense it's one more hour 'til the walls close in.

column1: The first Sleater-Kinney practice was in March of 1994. It was the spring that Kurt Cobain died. Hindsight paints it clear: Cobain's desire for a future-rock made by women dispersed into the universe. Brownstein and Tucker did Sleater-Kinney as a side-project to their respective bands
column2: the queercore power-chord screams of Excuse 17 and soul-baring punk of Heavens to Betsy. Sleater-Kinney fused these politicized sounds
column3: but as they grew—with affection for B-52's shimmy and Sonic Youth cool—they never let the punk rulebook limit their vision. Riot grrrl was fragmenting and they learned from its successes and failures—a radical streak pervaded their writerly Hüsker Dü-type storytelling—but they also fought to not be removed from the context of their foundation. The wiry blast of 1995's Sleater-Kinney is as good an indicator of Bikini Kill's influence as any feminist album since
column4: echoing their sound as well as an interest in making punk become activism.

column1: The first Sleater-Kinney practice was in March of 1994. It was the spring that Kurt Cobain died. Hindsight paints it clear: Cobain's desire for a future-rock made by women dispersed into the universe. Brownstein and Tucker did Sleater-Kinney as a side-project to their respective bands
column2: the queercore power-chord screams of Excuse 17 and soul-baring punk of Heavens to Betsy. Sleater-Kinney fused these politicized sounds
column3: but as they grew—with affection for B-52's shimmy and Sonic Youth cool—they never let the punk rulebook limit their vision. Riot grrrl was fragmenting and they learned from its successes and failures—a radical streak pervaded their writerly Hüsker Dü-type storytelling—but they also fought to not be removed from the context of their foundation. The wiry blast of 1995's Sleater-Kinney is as good an indicator of Bikini Kill's influence as any feminist album since
column4: echoing their sound as well as an interest in making punk become activism.

It's a two-and-half-minute rock'n'roll joyride deserving of a gender studies thesis.

The band stopped just as independent music was becoming more financially significant—2004 was the year future indie-Grammy-holders Arcade Fire landed—but traditional notions of integrity were also growing complicated. Brownstein was strangely prophetic: ""I took my money/ And bought me a TV/ TV brings me closer to the world."" This is music you make when you can sense it's one more hour 'til the walls close in.

column1: The first Sleater-Kinney practice was in March of 1994. It was the spring that Kurt Cobain died. Hindsight paints it clear: Cobain's desire for a future-rock made by women dispersed into the universe. Brownstein and Tucker did Sleater-Kinney as a side-project to their respective bands
column2: the queercore power-chord screams of Excuse 17 and soul-baring punk of Heavens to Betsy. Sleater-Kinney fused these politicized sounds
column3: but as they grew—with affection for B-52's shimmy and Sonic Youth cool—they never let the punk rulebook limit their vision. Riot grrrl was fragmenting and they learned from its successes and failures—a radical streak pervaded their writerly Hüsker Dü-type storytelling—but they also fought to not be removed from the context of their foundation. The wiry blast of 1995's Sleater-Kinney is as good an indicator of Bikini Kill's influence as any feminist album since
column4: echoing their sound as well as an interest in making punk become activism.

(They despised the new proposition of a career-shifting iPod commercial.) The band stopped just as independent music was becoming more financially significant—2004 was the year future indie-Grammy-holders Arcade Fire landed—but traditional notions of integrity were also growing complicated. Brownstein was strangely prophetic: ""I took my money/ And bought me a TV/ TV brings me closer to the world."" This is music you make when you can sense it's one more hour 'til the walls close in.

column1: The first Sleater-Kinney practice was in March of 1994. It was the spring that Kurt Cobain died. Hindsight paints it clear: Cobain's desire for a future-rock made by women dispersed into the universe. Brownstein and Tucker did Sleater-Kinney as a side-project to their respective bands
column2: the queercore power-chord screams of Excuse 17 and soul-baring punk of Heavens to Betsy. Sleater-Kinney fused these politicized sounds
column3: but as they grew—with affection for B-52's shimmy and Sonic Youth cool—they never let the punk rulebook limit their vision. Riot grrrl was fragmenting and they learned from its successes and failures—a radical streak pervaded their writerly Hüsker Dü-type storytelling—but they also fought to not be removed from the context of their foundation. The wiry blast of 1995's Sleater-Kinney is as good an indicator of Bikini Kill's influence as any feminist album since
column4: echoing their sound as well as an interest in making punk become activism.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20748/homepage_large.b9159d06.jpg|The Cavern EP|30991.0|Inter Arma|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-10-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:37.349082|"

The long-form
column2: one-track EP always seemed like a requisite step for Richmond
column3: Virginia’s Inter Arma. Nominally a metal act
column4: they’ve anchored both of their full-length albums to itinerant bristling guitars and doubled-down drums
column5: with sections that plunged alternately into doom’s lurch and death’s leaps. At their best
column6: though
column7: Inter Arma function more as a gyre of genres than a unilateral machine; on last year’s standout Sky Burial
column8: they integrated electric psych sprawl and acoustic pastoral interludes
column9: working as five surly dudes not ashamed to admit that Led Zeppelin and Pink Floyd were more lifelines than mere gateways. Inter Arma
column10: however
column11: have never been all-inclusive. They plucked from the musical multiverse with an unapologetic ear for the grand
column12: where valleys implied multiple peaks and any sense of quiet only served to amplify the power to come. Despite its more staid moments
column13: Sky Burial aimed for overall ascent. On that eight-piece album
column14: where themes dissolved only to reappear
column15: the divisions between tracks sometimes felt like commercial concessions for the group’s big Relapse Records debut. It’s not hard to imagine its hour-plus runtime moving uninterrupted
column16: a direct line toward the heavens.

column1: They finally do that on The Cavern
column2: Inter Arma’s first single-song EP. Though the track lasts for 46 minutes
column3: it feels like a condensed and uncompromising version of the quintet’s prevailing vision. The band climbs a slope of increasing momentum
column4: where every step seems to find the action growing bigger and bolder. Though these kind of hour-long escapades can often suggest stunts by an act eager for a convenient concept and quick adulation
column5: The Cavern feels like what Inter Arma should have done all along—fade into a piece
column6: rip through an idea without hesitation
column7: fade out of the piece
column8: repeat. Written in 2009
column9: The Cavern predates both Inter Arma LPs
column10: but it was discarded until an employee at Relapse learned of its existence and urged the band to revisit it. After refining the composition
column11: they finally captured it during a long session last year in Tennessee before gilding it with violin from former U.S. Christmas member Meg Mulhearn and vocals from Windhand singer Dorthia Cottrell. It’s the kind of commanding performance that both Inter Arma albums have implied
column12: delivered now without hesitation or penance.

column1: The Cavern centers around a story of epic death: The protagonist wakes in a desert and lingers at the precipice of mortality until
column2: when the sun sets
column3: a light emerges from a cave tucked inside a solitary mountain peak. He crawls toward the luminescent oasis
column4: climbs inside and
column5: as he falls asleep
column6: realizes this will become his final resting place. As the song ends
column7: he gives over to darkness
column8: which takes the shape of a Persephone-like beauty “whose long hair veils her face.” Cottrell supplies the god voice during a gorgeous
column9: kaleidoscope-sky midsection
column10: her echoing vocals stretched between a nightmare and a daydream.

column1: The narrative prevents the ever-fluid Cavern from becoming too formless
column2: from shifting between moods or motifs without warning or reason. Sure
column3: parts emerge wholly unexpected
column4: such as an electrifying and Allman-like guitar turnaround that the band likes to revisit
column5: or Cottrell’s sudden and august arrival. But even those aberrations fit into the meticulously framed whole
column6: part of a comprehensive system. During the first 15 minutes
column7: for instance
column8: the band volleys between two sections—a slow
column9: swollen trudge and a quickened
column10: belligerent half-thrash; that’s when the subject first realizes he’s in peril
column11: stranded in an inhospitable clime. The same surroundings return for the finale
column12: when the hero realizes what he hoped was his salvation actually will be his downfall. The drums press harder
column13: and the once-sharp riffs of the guitar fray at their ends
column14: adding death’s door urgency. It’s a musical inclusio
column15: the signposts pointing to how things have gone from pragmatically bad to existentially black.

column1: The timing of The Cavern is fortuitous. Had Inter Arma released it ahead of both of their albums
column2: especially before the Relapse deal
column3: it’s easy to imagine the audacity being overlooked as a gimmick from a young
column4: anonymous act. But Sundown and Sky Burial broadcasted the range of Inter Arma
column5: or the limits to which they were willing to go to conjure an air of triumph. This reconfigured take on The Cavern
column6: which arrives after the band has had a chance to mature on the road and in the studio
column7: condenses and cements those elements
column8: never allowing for any sign of an easy exit. It’s their most riveting release to date
column9:
a simple story charged by a complicated sound.

"|19523.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19523-inter-arma-the-cavern-ep/|8.3|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20993/homepage_large.261c4518.jpg|Mass & Volume EP|5311.0|Pig Destroyer|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-10-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:37.884860|"

In 2006
column2: when Pig Destroyer recorded “Mass & Volume” and “Red Tar”—two songs that didn’t make it onto their astounding 2007 album Phantom Limb—they had no way of knowing those songs would one day become a memorial to a dead friend. But following the passing of Relapse Records staffer Pat Egan in 2013
column3: the progressive grindcore outfit bundled those two orphaned tracks as the Mass & Volume EP
column4: sold it digitally
column5: and donated the proceeds to Egan’s family. A year and a half later
column6: Mass & Volume is seeing the light of day as an official
column7: physical release. As a gesture of kindness to a departed comrade—Pig Destroyer have been a cornerstone of Relapse’s roster since their 2000 split with Isis—it’s beautiful. As a doom-ridden detour from the group’s typical blitzkrieg of dense
column8: hyper-literate grind
column9: it’s downright ugly.

column1: Unlike the frantic Phantom Limb—or Book Burner
column2: Pig Destroyer’s intervening album—Mass & Volume is slow. As in
column3: glacier-dragging-a-fallen-planetoid slow. In that sense
column4: it draws from the dour
column5: down-tuned slither of doom metal
column6: but it’s a far cry from either the antediluvian groove of Pentagram or the antiheroic songcraft of recent outfits like Lycus and Pallbearer. The EP’s first song
column7: “Mass & Volume”
column8: is clearly the sound of a grind band unhinging its jaw to accommodate the proportions of doom; most Pig Destroyer tracks do their duty in under three minutes
column9: while “Mass & Volume” weighs in at over 19. When Pig Destroyer decides to play doom
column10: however
column11: it’s best to assume it won’t go unexamined. All the requisite components are there: hovering feedback
column12: threatening riffs
column13: and chasms of pregnant space. But frontman J. R. Hayes unfurls his unintelligible tongue as if it’s the red carpet to hell
column14: a far more alien delivery than most doom bands
column15: and guitarist Scott Hull is just as apt to let his instrument drone
column16: disintegrate
column17: and ultimately eat its own tail as he is to actually summon a chord.

column1: “Red Tar” is only three times as long as your average Pig Destroyer song
column2: but those six and a half minutes are milked of every conceivable ounce of sludge. Here the EP finally resembles a Pig Destroyer 45 played on 33
column3: plain and simple
column4: with none of the compositional mutation on display in “Mass & Volume”. It’s the perfect complement; tighter and more coherent—inasmuch as Hayes and Hull’s mutual assured deconstruction could ever be called coherent—the song creeps from plateau to plateau
column5: leaving a trail of viscera in its wake. “Grief crawls in the shadow of time/ Try to keep in mind/ It’s all finite
column6: ” Hayes grunts in existential agony. Instead of seeming like some noble savage
column7: he’s a trapped animal
column8: snarling and soon to be gutted.

column1: The fact that “Mass & Volume” and “Red Tar” were amputated from the final version of Phantom Limb lends the two songs their own sick humor and grotesque gravity—qualities that
column2: not coincidentally
column3: Pig Destroyer specialize in. It’s left to the listener’s imagination to guess how appropriate the EP might be as a tribute to Egan. That shouldn’t matter
column4: of course; a good EP is a good EP
column5: and Mass & Volume fits that bill. Yet the circumstances surrounding any piece of music are not separable from the experience of hearing it
column6: and that’s how it should be. Pig Destroyer has long trafficked in the absurdism of mortality
column7: the profundity of body-horror
column8: and the contortion of metal tropes themselves. There’s a perverse soulfulness at the core of their music
column9: though
column10: and in slowing their berserk onslaught to a vulnerable slither
column11: Hayes and crew have turned Mass & Volume into something heart-stoppingly sorrowful. Pig Destroyer
column12: poignant? The notion isn’t as strange—nor
column13: as the EP demonstrates
column14: as forced—as one might think. Mass & Volume barely moves
column15:
but it’s definitely moving.

"|19763.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19763-pig-destroyer-mass-volume-ep/|7.4|Jason Heller

'Infectious']|2014-10-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:39.407459|"

These New Puritans are ""post-rock"" in an unusually literal way—since encrypting post-punk on 2008’s wiry
column4: caustic Beat Pyramid
column5: they’ve been an avant-garde band with a major-label budget
column6: integrating classical composition
column7: jazz instrumentation
column8: musique concrete
column9: primitive folk
column10: dancehall
column11: basically everything but rock'n'roll. More importantly
column12: while they’ve maintained something of a power trio lineup
column13: no one asks them a question so often posed to “rock bands”—“How are they going to pull this off live?” The apt comparisons to the otherwise incomparable Talk Talk are warranted
column14: as the creation of Hidden and Field of Reeds were similarly defined by the trio’s isolation—from trends
column15: from budgetary constraints and from the mundanity of the album cycle. Likewise
column16: they use near-mythical tales of studio trickery to tease fans rather than singles
column17: as Victoria’s Secret money gets funneled into Foley effects and falconry
column18: Britain’s lowest voice and eight-foot Japanese taiko drums. But if they are going to pull this off live
column19: These New Puritans aren’t ones to half-ass anything and so
column20: this is how we arrive at Expanded—performing with a 35-piece orchestra
column21: at ""Europe's largest multi-arts and conference venue.""

column1: This isn’t just the best means of presenting Field of Reeds live
column2: it might be the only way. Another commonality These New Puritans share with late-period Talk Talk is a status of being commercial non-entities in the States and believe me
column3: no matter how suave they look on stage
column4: this is awkward as hell in a rock club that might otherwise host
column5: say
column6: Finch or Marilyn Manson in 2014—earlier this year
column7: I saw an impeccable performance interrupted by Sunset Strip stragglers and a Brazilian guy on Molly who kept requesting “Elvis”. By comparison
column8: the polite clapping that accompanies Expanded may puncture the hermetic seal
column9: but it doesn’t take all of the air out; if anything
column10: it serves as a reminder that this is not a typical rock show.

column1: Jack Barnett has been forthcoming about his lack of instrumental or compositional knowledge
column2: but he is an exacting boss; these musicians are trained to not fuck up and they are not held to lower standards because These New Puritans are technically a pop band. So the alterations are minor
column3: if any: “Fragment Two” was Field of Reeds’ most conventional moment and that’s obviously relative. And so it’s subject to the most conventional effect of live performance
column4: which is that it plays slightly faster and looser than its studio counterpart. Meanwhile
column5: “Island Song” goes straight into the incantatory portion of its mesmerizing coda rather than teasing it out as it does on the record.

column1: Even the most inscrutable sounds on Field of Reeds evolved from an organic source and the most “how’d they do that?” moments are captured with startling clarity—the undulating
column2: magnetic resonator-piano melody that snakes throughout “Island Song”
column3: the hypnotic motifs of “Organ Eternal”
column4: the glass-shattering crescendo of “The Light in Your Name”. In fact
column5: Barnett and his charges are so adept at recreating the subtle complexities of Field of Reeds
column6: that they don’t just render Expanded a total misnomer. They call its entire reason for existence into question.

column1: With the exception of a two-minute “Intro Tape”
column2: These New Puritans play Field of Reeds almost verbatim—in its exact order
column3: with little
column4: if any variation from the original versions. So why listen to this instead of Field of Reeds? Barnett considers Expanded to be on the level of TNP’s albums and called these performances improvements over the originals; but it’s too close to call even for those who’ve completely immersed within Field of Reeds’ otherworldly environs
column5: which is even more disappointing than the typical refractory release
column6: i.e.
column7: the well-intentioned and often terribly-executed remix album. Considering the austerity of its arrangements and their open-ended structure
column8: Field of Reeds actually stands as a rare instance of a record that could lend itself to total teardowns.

column1: The price of admission is warranted once the record-setting basso profundo of “Field of Reeds” fades out; new composition “Spitting Stars” is another lovely
column2: pastoral collaboration with Graham Sutton
column3: but considering the long latency periods and wild deviations from one These New Puritans record to the next
column4: it’s likely an appendage to Field of Reeds rather than an indication of where they might go next. There are also two selections from Hidden
column5: the more intimidating
column6: less “orchestral” predecessor to Field of Reeds and the record that would have been better suited to this format.

column1: For all of its stunt sonics—smashed watermelons
column2: sharpened knives
column3: M.I.A. interpolations—much of it was proudly composed on cheap keyboards. As such
column4: “We Want War” embodies the entire timeline of human combat
column5: from sticks and stones to modern digital strikes. But with the addition of Portuguese fado singer Elisa Rodrigues and the orchestral replacements for those digital dancehall patches
column6: the textures of “We Want War” and proto-Yeezus banger “Three Thousand” are too cohesive
column7: sounding closer to the overblown bombast of Michael Bay or Metallica’s S&M.

column1: But it's more of a disappointment than a failure—at the very least
column2: it might serve as someone's introduction to These New Puritans. But there is precedent for bands just as studiocentric properly utilizing this style of live performance: Kraftwerk's Minimum-Maximum
column3: Portishead’s PNYC
column4: Spiritualized’s Royal Albert Hall
column5: October 10
column6: 1997: Live —and if Expanded doesn’t reach that level by any means
column7: at least it’s more worthwhile than the track-by-track
column8: aggressively redundant cash-ins of the Cure’s Trilogy or Depeche Mode’s Songs of Faith and Devotion Live. But if it takes a classic rock cliche to emphasize how far beyond rock These New Puritans really are
column9:
then Expanded is a total success.

"|19852.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19852-these-new-puritans-expanded-live-at-the-barbican/|6.4|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21078/homepage_large.c0f5078d.jpg|Flatland|31078.0|Objekt|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pan']|2014-10-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:40.042992|"

We've come to a strange chapter in the story of electronic music. Sounds that were long considered niche are now mainstream. It's an exciting space to be in
column2: as the possibilities of electronic music's history are basically endless
column3: but it's also somewhat confusing. Who and what do we talk about when we talk about electronic music? Where do we draw the line between what electronic music was and what it has become? And why
column4: if at all
column5: is it important to make these distinctions?

column1: No surprise
column2: then
column3: that 2014 has given us more questions about ""proper"" electronic music than answers. Young producers like Sophie and the PC Music camp contextualized contemporary dance and pop permutations in their own high-gloss chicken-or-the-egg scenarios; Aphex Twin reinvigorated his career with an album that bucks current trends (many of which he's at least partially responsible for) by ignoring them altogether; and hardworking elder statesman Brian Eno released two records with Underworld's Karl Hyde that expressly contradicted each other's sounds
column4: styles
column5: and creative processes. Thankfully
column6: much of this has made for thrilling
column7: provocative music
column8: and in ways that reward open-mindedness and conservatism in equal measure.

column1: This is the context surrounding Flatland
column2: the debut LP by TJ Hertz as Objekt
column3: and he seems keenly aware of it. Maybe that's because he's been a leader in the electronic music conversation since 2011
column4: when his first solo 12"" snuck up behind dubstep and yanked the rug out from under it. Though ""The Goose That Got Away"" and ""Tinderbox"" have very little to do with the sleek
column5: weighty tracks Hertz produces in his Berlin studio these days
column6: the deep technical knowledge that helped make them possible is still central to Objekt's musical identity. Here is an artist who studied electronic and information engineering at University of Oxford
column7: has developed software both personally and professionally (for tech giant Native Instruments)
column8: readily and openly shares tips
column9: tricks
column10: and advice with other producers
column11: and only further hones his craft with each intermittent release. Nevermind if Objekt has any solutions for the state of electronic music
column12: we have more to gain from knowing what he ponders and hearing how he manifests those thoughts.

column1: Though his approach to techno may appear clinical or overly academic
column2: Objekt's productions always feel animated and impulsive; Flatland is experimental to its core
column3: but it never considers polish and passion to be mutually exclusive. It's because Hertz can fashion fiercely tactile and resilient elements with textbook precision that the basslines in his menacing ""Dogma"" use your backbone like a seismometer. And it's how ""Ratchet"" projects Cybotron's Detroit electro-isms from cathode tube monitors into a 3-D virtual environment. As an intro
column4: ""Agnes Revenge"" dazzles with hi-def depictions of cryonized steel shattering ice blocks in ultra slow-mo
column5: which Objekt inverts and further details during the noxious seepage of ""Agnes Apparatus"". No matter if it's functioning as soundsystem armament or headphone oddity
column6: Flatland won't hesitate to travel down every avenue uncovered by the refined programming
column7: ingenious sound theory
column8: and liberal stylistic influences it was mapped with.

column1: Which is why the record sounds rooted in electronic music's history even as it carves out an alternate future. Learned perfectionist that he is
column2: Hertz knows the secrets of Drexciyan history
column3: Autechre's essential deep cuts
column4: Speedy J's trusty drum patterns
column5: and what makes Richard D. James a legendary producer—using such seminal influences not to revive the past
column6: but to reinvent it for his own purposes. The chugging thump in ""Strays"" may not have been made with an actual Roland TR-909
column7: nor the acid sequences of ""One Fell Swoop"" or ""Interlude (Whodunnit?)"" with a 303
column8: but Objekt can nonetheless capture each machine's warm
column9: gritty soul with his own digitial approximation. Hertz remains dedicated to his icons while subverting their methods because he does so with the avant-garde spirit passed down through their work.

column1: Throughout Flatland
column2: Objekt reclaims his genre's all-too-familiar affectations by making us hear them for the first time all over again. It's a rare album that sounds so vivid and transparent despite its densely intricate constructions. Stranger still
column3: it's one largely devoid of apparent melodies and climactic structures
column4: instead using pristine sound design and dynamically expressive arrangements in the way an expert orchestra plays a symphony's fluid notation. Flatland isn't remarkable for answering any of electronic music's questions
column5:
it's remarkable because it lets us consider them from a completely new perspective.

"|19840.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19840-objekt-flatland/|8.0|Patric Fallon

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21128/homepage_large.5dc7da4c.jpg|Tomorrow Was the Golden Age|32540.0|Bing & Ruth|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2014-10-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:40.719023|"

Tomorrow Was the Golden Age
column2: the beautiful second LP from Bing & Ruth
column3: isn’t “ambient music.” You wouldn’t be at fault for thinking as much
column4: though: at first approach
column5: the New York City ensemble’s music is the kind that seems to do the most when you’re not paying attention to it
column6: a series of swells and rustling melodic passages that unfurl patiently. At times
column7: it sounds quite sparse
column8: with just a central melody orbited by distant tones; Bing & Ruth have clearly taken their time on these recordings
column9: but by no means is this “slow” music meant for background listening. Instead
column10: Tomorrow Was the Golden Age teems with life the same way an inanimate city skyline is filled with people unseen to the naked eye. This music moves
column11: almost constantly
column12: and even when Bing & Ruth are seemingly sitting still
column13: their gears are whirring
column14: however silently
column15: on a different plane.

column1: The project is anchored by pianist and composer David Moore
column2: who’s been working in a variety of avant-classical mediums for a decade now (you can preview a variety of his smaller releases on his Bandcamp page). Bing & Ruth’s first album
column3: the 2010 LP City Lake
column4: was reminiscent of Sufjan Stevens’ own classical diversions
column5: a series of bright pieces that occasionally employed the human voice in tandem with chamber-ensemble arrangements. The debut was a relatively straightforward release
column6: but Tomorrow Was the Golden Age isn’t; aided by the addition of a tape delay tech
column7: the record’s nine compositions take on a trippy
column8: halo-effect shape
column9: every sonic abstraction and bent tone radiating a strange
column10: benevolent glow. For a suite that could be called “minimalist
column11: ” Tomorrow Was the Golden Age proves surprisingly tactile
column12: a shifting variety of textures that move from mossy to feather-delicate.

column1: For Tomorrow Was the Golden Age
column2: Bing & Ruth narrowed down their ensemble—two upright bassists
column3: two clarinets
column4: a cellist
column5: the tape-delay tech
column6: and Moore on piano—but while City Lake had a larger scope
column7: this new record feels heavier by design. Credit is due to clarinetists Jeremy Viner and Patrick Breiner
column8: whose bent notes are integral to this record’s many complexities; on opening track “Warble”
column9: they add a sense of dread to Moore’s rustling
column10: overlapping piano figures
column11: aiding greatly in the subtle melodic shifts taking place. On “Reflector”
column12: their instruments sound like ghosts heaving deep sighs in the wind
column13: pushing and sustaining against a decaying piano.

column1: “Reflector” is one of a few moments on Tomorrow Was the Golden Age where the melody that’s explored
column2: deconstructed
column3: and lingered-upon ends up sticking with you long after the track is over. The sense of humanity found in these compositions
column4: and the broad range of emotions they convey—longing
column5: contemplation
column6: muted joy
column7: confusion
column8: a quiet but deeply felt ecstasy—go a long way to make Tomorrow Was the Golden Age accessible. At times
column9: you can hear the New York trappings in Bing & Ruth’s music—conceivably
column10: this music could soundtrack busy city streets
column11: or the metropolitan sprawl’s dawn-hour emptiness. But Tomorrow Was the Golden Age
column12: one of the finest left-field releases of the year
column13: transcends geography
column14:
inviting you to close your eyes and build your own richly detailed world.

"|19887.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19887-bing-ruth-tomorrow-was-the-golden-age/|8.1|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21048/homepage_large.e3dfb906.jpg|Burnt Offering|5423.0|The Budos Band|['Global'
column3: Afrofunk-fueled instrumentals—titled
column4: tellingly
column5: The Budos Band
column6: The Budos Band II
column7: and The Budos Band III—where were the Budos Band to go? As great as their output has been to date
column8: the New York ensemble had more or less painted themselves into a corner. In truth
column9: there were many directions the group could have headed toward on their fourth album
column10: but they dauntingly chose the path of most imaginable resistance: doom metal. Rub your eyes all you want; it won’t change that sentence. The Budos Band’s new album is called Burnt Offering—and from its wizard-sporting cover on down
column11: it draws heavily from the late-'60s/early-'70s well of dark
column12: arcane proto-metal.

column1: To be perfectly clear: This is not your uncle’s Primus-shirted funk-metal. The majority of Burnt Offering is built on the same framework that the Budos Band has always used—elegantly simple guitar
column2: deep pockets of syncopation
column3: and bold shouts of brass—but here it’s been wreathed in the thick organ vamps of the bands that helped inspire metal
column4: namely Iron Butterfly and Uriah Heep. Those looking for kvlt cred won’t find it here
column5: nor should they; the album’s heaviest tracks
column6: like the fuzz-slathered “Aphasia” and the gutbucket-distorted title track don’t come anywhere near the metal orthodoxy of Pentagram
column7: let alone Black Sabbath. This is still Afrofunk of the Fela Kuti faith
column8: with “Tomahawk” being the most horn-splashed and intricately polyrhythmic of the bunch.

column1: When the delicate guitar intro of “Magus Mountain” drops into a propulsive
column2: blown-out low gear
column3: though
column4: it’s as if Sir Lord Baltimore is jamming with Maggot Brain-era Funkadelic. The fidelity is immaculately retro
column5: saturated and reverberating
column6: which lends an even more eerily anachronistic tone to simmering
column7: sinuous cuts such as “Black Hills” and “Turn and Burn”
column8: the latter of which lands the album in some swampy epoch of alternate history. “Into the Fog” more or less says it all; with organ chords transmogrified into haunted-house groans
column9: and monstrous stomps shuffling somewhere between Blue Öyster Cult's “Godzilla” and Fela’s “Zombie”
column10: the song is all meat
column11: zero subtext. Not that an album this earthy needs anything so subtle to get its freaky point across.

column1: Burnt Offering has its own kind of subtlety
column2: and most of it is in the interplay between meter
column3: genre
column4: and mood. When it falls a little flat
column5: on the tame
column6: muted “Trail of Tears” and “Shattered Winds”
column7: it still manages to register as better-than-average Afrofunk with a tasteful layer of filthy hard rock smeared on top. It's not a profound exercise in fusion
column8: and at times it seems the band might be amusing themselves at the expense of being taken seriously. But the most remarkable thing about Burnt Offering is that
column9: at its core
column10: it really isn’t all that much of a departure from what the Budos Band has always done. The neatest trick the album pulls off is in finding the unexplored commonality between Afrofunk and doom metal—deep grooves
column11: murky atmosphere
column12: hypnotic riffs—then playing them with joy and loopy abandon. Spooky
column13: funky
column14: freedom-loving fun: The chance to embrace something like that doesn’t come along often
column15:
and it’s to be cherished.
