column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20986/homepage_large.eeceacb3.jpg|Marigolden|30382.0|Field Report|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Partisan']|2014-10-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:41.959250|"

“Kiss me shy and I will love you like a lamprey
column2: ” Chris Porterfield sings on “Michelle”
column3: a downcast song on Marigolden
column4: the second release by his band Field Report. It’s an odd line
column5: jutting out from the song at an obtuse angle and snagging your attention—at least until you remember that a lamprey is a parasitic fish that lives by burrowing into the skin of its host. It’s not especially romantic imagery; in fact
column6: it’s possibly more visceral than Porterfield intended for such a gentle track. He certainly sings it like a love song. Marigolden is full of similarly head-scratching turns of phrases
column7: similes and metaphors that are aggressively poetic. “His tessellated love is all around
column8: ” goes “Enchantment”. On “Summons”
column9: Porterfield admits
column10: “I’ve been pissing coffee
column11: quinine
column12: and lime.” He might want to see a doctor for that.

column1: Porterfield may be best known as a former member of DeYarmond Edison
column2: the Wisconsin supergroup-in-retrospective that included Justin Vernon of Bon Iver and Brad and Phil Cook of Megafaun. It took him five years to pen the songs on his 2012 self-titled debut
column3: after which he toured constantly
column4: quit drinking
column5: and pared his band down to a tight quartet. If his former bandmates emphasize music over lyrics
column6: Porterfield deals with words over notes. Rooted in acoustic guitar strums
column7: sustained piano chords
column8: and post-Emma soundscapes
column9: these arrangements are spare and gentle and occasionally obligatory as they tenderly cradle the painstakingly wrought lyrics. When the band reach for something more
column10: however
column11: the results have a lot more personality: “Wings” layers instruments and synths against a steady rhythm to create a sort of rustic kosmische sound that could sustain a full album.

column1: But Field Report isn’t a band exactly. It’s every bit the songwriter project its anagram name suggests. Porterfield writes long
column2: word-dense songs that typically lack choruses and bridges
column3: but usually compensate with fluttery melodic lines and strong hooks. First single “Home (Leave the Lights On)” quickens excitedly around its bright and unabashedly sentimental refrain
column4: which conjures the exhaustion and excitement of the final leg of a long roadtrip: “Leave the lights on
column5: 'cause it might be nighttime when I get there.” As a wordsmith
column6: Porterfield is certainly distinctive
column7: at times insistently so. Nights are “bruiseblack” in these songs
column8: and women tend to “smell like saffron.” Such details are meant to evoke particular emotions and sensations
column9: but they tend to be distracting and meaningless beyond their own desperate desire to mean something.

column1: Marigolden fares best when it loses the florid similes and addresses character and story. On the piano ballad “Ambrosia”
column2: he recounts his wayward adolescence
column3: when he dipped Skoal with the sheriff’s son. “He was cruel to the other kids just for fun
column4: ” Porterfield recalls. “I never had the stones to tell him off.” That kid committed suicide “on a golf course with a gun
column5: ” and those details are horrifying in their specificity and banality. The song treats the kid’s depression and death not like a bully’s comeuppance
column6:
but more like the tragedy of someone who never earned forgiveness or redemption. This handful of lines contains an entire life—albeit one cut sadly short—and it’s easily the most affecting moment on the album. It should come as no coincidence that it’s also the passage with the simplest and most eloquently plainspoken lyrics. 

"|19757.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19757-field-report-marigolden/|5.3|Stephen M. Deusner

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21197/homepage_large.ed43c3a1.jpg|Soused|32590.0|Scott Walker + Sunn O)))|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2014-10-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:42.557101|"

You won’t need to pinch yourself awake: As if to ensure listeners that Soused isn’t some fantastic nightmare or haunted daydream
column2: Scott Walker and Sunn O))) begin their five-track
column3: 50-minute collaboration with a brief series of exclamation marks. Walker’s voice sweeps in with extreme operatic gusto
column4: delivering a set of simple
column5: sliding phrases over sparkling synthesizers. Dual classic rock riffs trail those hails
column6: like “Paradise City” abutting a scrap of “Heartbreaker”. And as it all fades toward silence
column7: Greg Anderson and Stephen O’Malley shatter the creeping calm with their expected amplifier army. To emphasize the madness
column8: the sound of an American bullwhip slaps at the back of the din. Yes
column9: Scott O))) is real
column10: and yes
column11: it is a touch ridiculous.

column1: In the wake of Lulu
column2: the intriguing but errant byproduct of a more famous elder leading a more famous metal act
column3: such a partnership felt like a joke someone might have made on a message board in 2011. Gabriel and Mastodon? Jagger and Down? Walker and Sunn O)))? Sure
column4: line them up
column5: but don’t assume that they will all net Lulu’s Warner Brothers deal. At least there was stylistic precedent for this hypothetical pairing. Though Walker was once a pop star
column6: his work later in life has been experimentally ambitious
column7: adding webs of dissonance to song cycles that explored discontent in dozens of guises. Even now
column8: his 1995 LP
column9: Tilt
column10: seems diabolically heavy and jarring
column11: employing unease as compositional exigency. Released only seven months apart
column12: his 2006 album
column13: The Drift
column14: and Sunn O)))’s Black One
column15: feel now like complementary surveys of the same seismic divide. Walker originally wrote “Lullaby
column16: ” Soused’s jarring and arching climax
column17: in 1999. His music doesn’t fear the dark.

column1: As legend has it
column2: Sunn O))) approached Walker a half-decade ago with a blind call for collaboration. He’d never heard them
column3: but they hoped he’d pen something to sing for “Alice”
column4: the orchestra-gilded finale of their 2009 LP
column5: Monoliths & Dimensions. He didn’t
column6: but he did become a convert to the band’s maximum-volume
column7: minimum-movement metal. He began writing new material with Anderson
column8: O’Malley and
column9: it seems
column10: both their instrumental and thematic tones in mind. Together
column11: they recorded those pieces earlier this year in London
column12: with several of Walker’s more customary contributors adding drums
column13: horns
column14: keyboards and electronics.

column1: Soused is billed to “Scott Walker + Sunn O)))
column2: ” an ostensible meeting of equals. On T-shirts
column3: the project is even playfully dubbed Scott O)))
column4: written in the same lower-cased
column5: bold-faced font that the electronics company and drone duo have long used. And as is his wont
column6: O’Malley designed the packaging for Soused
column7: an austere grayscale colossus guided by a system of holistic organization.

column1: But the music itself never tries to sell the conspiracy of equal and reciprocal collaboration. Sure
column2: Sunn O))) made the first move here
column3: but any real work required Walker’s acceptance and effort. This is
column4: then
column5: a Scott Walker album
column6: where Sunn O)))—Anderson
column7: O’Malley and longtime multi-instrumentalist and collaborator TOS Nieuwenhuizen—serve as a very large
column8: potent instrument within Walker’s band
column9: or maybe a set of them
column10: like a rack of guitars pulled from a closet. During “Brando”
column11: they follow him
column12: saturating the background but almost always ceding the spotlight. When he sings “A beating would do me a world of good
column13: ” Anderson and O’Malley bend inside his shadow
column14: taking the riff’s next step down.

column1: Anderson and O’Malley even flash back to their high-school days in Thorr’s Hammer
column2: or their subsequent separate bands
column3: for “Fetish”
column4: the album’s singular and brilliant flashpoint. Just before the song’s halfway point
column5: they’ve traced Walker’s voice only with ominous noise and tracked him with mid-range melodies. “He imagines he feels it
column6: tugging and clinching
column7: hears it rustling and rising
column8: ” Walker yells
column9: pausing suddenly as if to summon help. Sunn O))) answers
column10: matching the beat of drummer Ian Thomas with loaded guitar and low-lying bass
column11: like they’re an insurgent young doom band again
column12: racing toward a crossover crescendo. Later in the track
column13: they sprawl out beneath him
column14: their amps and instruments harmonizing obediently alongside screeching trumpet
column15: stuttering drums and stabbing static. They are
column16: perhaps for the first time
column17: part of a force greater than their own.

column1: Sunn O)))’s career has been defined by their search for ways to augment their riffs
column2: to make them bigger than simply big; but after 15 years and a half-dozen full-lengths
column3: they’ve yet to take the routes through which Walker pulls them here. The only prototypically Sunn O))) moment arrives during the back half of “Bull
column4: ” when they cycle a slow set of notes across occasional percussion and over scrambled field recordings. But it’s mostly a mid-record volume respite
column5: a break in the command of Walker’s stentorian elegance.

column1: Soused documents depravity and wanton desire
column2: or needing something—pain or the absence of it
column3: protection or the illusion of it
column4: privacy or the desecration of it—so bad it’s ripping your worldview into pieces. Walker empties volumes of data into those ideas
column5: pinballing between 17th century painting debates
column6: New Testament infanticide and Iroquois lullabies within the course of the shape-shifting “Herod 2014”. In less than a minute of “Bull”
column7: he moves from a string of screamed Latin imprecations to a recited text message
column8: reprinted in the liner notes as an iChat bubble. During “Brando”
column9: he details successive episodes in which the named actor was beaten
column10: shouting the elliptical list with an urgency that gives the sadomasochism a private power.

column1: Though Walker was once a sort of balladeer icon
column2: his lyrics trend toward the obtuse and ponderous. The words on Soused don’t forsake those qualities
column3: necessarily
column4: but there is a certain relatability and readability here
column5: as if this return to rock ’n’ roll has pulled him back toward earth. Despite the macabre battle between the innocent and the hunter of “Herod 2014
column6: ” Walker delights in the language
column7: using alliteration and end-rhyme to fashion what could pass for old-fashioned folklore. “The deer fly
column8: the sand fly
column9: the tsetse can’t find them
column10: ” he offers
column11: his voice cold but comforting
column12: like that of a wolf in disguise. “The goon from the Stasi  is left far behind them. Their delicate derma  won’t witness a ray.” In this new relationship
column13: Walker seems to have rediscovered a sometimes-hidden element of his own work—its playfulness and its perversity
column14: the coexistence of the smile and the frown.

column1: Is it selfish
column2: then
column3: to hope that this might be only the start
column4: the unlikely origin of a partnership that extends beyond a one-off album? Walker is
column5: of course
column6: infamously reluctant to talk about his future in making music
column7: and he can be rather chelonian with his output; much the same applies for Sunn O)))
column8: at its core a duo of dudes involved in a dozen other things. That’s one reason Soused feels more like an event and an experience than a vital
column9: persevering record for either party. It’s good and
column10: at times
column11: completely absorbing
column12: especially when Walker and the amplifiers seem to be fighting on the same side of a great battle. Soused is compelling
column13: almost inherently so
column14: but it’s not a classic. What if they gave this time to be more than a mere oddity
column15: so as to feel no rush to launch from the gates and exclaim that this is
column16: in fact
column17: real? We’ll probably never find out
column18: but we never thought we’d hear Scott O)))
column19:
anyway. 

"|19946.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19946-sunn-o-scott-walker-soused/|7.4|Grayson Haver Currin

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21189/homepage_large.c525a5d7.jpg|77|28186.0|Nude Beach|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Don Giovanni']|2014-10-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:43.223848|"

1977 is the year of punk’s genesis
column2: but it also endures as a signifier of authenticity brandished by listeners wishing for a return to those halcyon days of leather jackets
column3: sneered upper lips
column4: Sid Vicious on the street
column5: and disco on the outs. Anyone who’s palled around an underground venue as a young adult might recall
column6: with some reluctance
column7: groups of uncouth youths self-described as 77ers looking to cause trouble
column8: or at the very least
column9: reaffirm all that’s dirty and fun about true punx living. (Like binge drinking
column10: or knife crime.) The association is strange for Nude Beach
column11: a three-piece rock band that’s more MC5 than the Misfits who have named their third album 77 and produced a double album—the type of excess that the punks would’ve sneered at.

column1: Their nostalgia is more broad than specific. Pitchfork’s Steven Hyden described 2011’s II as hitting those familiar bar band touch points of “mid-period Replacements
column2: early Elvis Costello
column3: all-eras Tom Petty
column4: ” and much of that has stayed true the second time around. You could add bands like Big Star
column5: Cheap Trick
column6: and the Buzzcocks
column7: but why belabor the point? Bands like these are an inelastic good—as long as there are young men fueled by soft drugs and ennui
column8: there will be songs that sound warmer with each depleted case of Keystone Light. The singing
column9: which is handled by guitarist Chuck Betz and drummer Ryan Naideau
column10: has two modes
column11: screamer and slacker
column12: and works best in the former. Not that their musing about being stuck in neutral doesn't evoke a certain wistful je ne sais quoi
column13: but this “whatever’s good with me” attitude can get a little enervating. You’d rather hear someone explode.

column1: Explode they do like “Yesterday” and “For a While” and “I Can’t Keep the Tears from Falling”
column2: Betz’s guitar blaring brightly like an immaculately choreographed light display. “I Found You” is a particular standout—it’s the highway song War on Drugs would’ve written if their foot was mashed to the pedal. It sounds white hot
column3: and obviously derivative
column4: but it’s a good time. That’s where the band is most engaging
column5: because their songwriting topics are blissfully generic; not that we all can’t empathize with the passing of time (“Time”) or the quest for love (“I Found You”)
column6: but the lyrics are rendered with such unspecific detail that they’re nearly anonymous. (Two exceptions: “The Witness”
column7: which attempts to be conceptual
column8: and the winsome “Geoffrey’s Tune”
column9: a love song that appears to be sung toward another man
column10: but could just as well be about a cat.) I mean: “It’s So Hard”
column11: the eleventh track
column12: is followed three songs later with “It’s So Hard to Love You”. Is there some thematic connective tissue? Well
column13: sure
column14: but Brecht it isn’t.

column1: This would be less noticeable but for the fact that 77 is long; 18 tracks and 68 minutes
column2: and you’d think that if a band insisted on staying around for so long they’d have more to say
column3: or at least display more stylistic variation. Perhaps this is unfair; as they sing on “See My Way”
column4: “It's okay/ You don’t have to see my way.” (That’s an endearing feature here: Song titles that get right to the point.) And maybe it’s not always bad to want to have a good time without keeping your eye on the clock. Why begrudge their vibe? Their name
column5: Nude Beach
column6: refers to a place so casual that what was once erotic or salacious is cleaved of its politics or ideology. A place where it’s perfectly okay to just hang out
column7:
where everyone can have fun without too much trouble.

"|19938.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19938-nude-beach-77/|6.9|Jeremy Gordon

Disclosure’s Settle wasn’t just the best debut LP of 2013
column3: it was also the best dance-pop crossover record from last year; with no dominant trend in the sub-genre cropping up this year
column4: the Lawrence brothers have dominated 2014 by proxy
column5: too. Their rising success can be found in industry-shepherded superstar collaborations and dance veteran co-signs; they were also responsible for putting the most boring new pop star of the year on the map. All of which has lead to the music industry’s typically craven search to find something
column6: anything comparable when it comes to satiating the fuzzy-boots crowd’s sudden micro-thirst for vocal-driven house. It’s why UK producer Duke Dumont’s ebullient
column7: bursting “I Got U” could be found on U.S. pop radio earlier this summer
column8: and it also explains why the market has been flooded with knockoffs supposedly meant to catch some of Disclosure’s heat. If you thought the glut of post-dubstep singer/songwriter types or tortured alt-R&B auteurs proved tiring
column9: the 4/4 onslaught that mainstream pop is about to undergo could prove even worse.

column1: Recently
column2: the market’s been hit with two new artists in the Disclosure mold: first
column3: there was Gorgon City’s competent
column4: ultimately ineffective debut LP Sirens
column5: and now we have the debut album from Calgary's Kiesa Rae Ellestad
column6: Sound of a Woman. Kiesza's earliest music leaned toward folk
column7: and then she hooked up with producer and current collaborator Rami Samir Afuni
column8: who has written and arranged for the likes of LMFAO and Miley Cyrus. In 2012
column9: Kiesza and Afuni released the single “Oops”
column10: a pop trifle about unprotected sex that mixed bright
column11: MOR synth-pop with the requisite wub-wub elements that marked big-tent dance music at the time; at the top of this year
column12: they hit the pop bullseye forcefully with “Hideaway”
column13: a throaty blast that sounded like the duo’s attempt to remake Robin S.’ “Show Me Love” for the millennial crowd.

column1: A minor U.S. hit that went platinum in four European countries
column2: “Hideaway” was a stroke of low-level pop mimicry genius
column3: and Kiesza and Afuni are clearly aware of its winning formula: Sound of a Woman
column4: a record that proves as generic and bland as the catch-all title that adorns it
column5: is largely made up of attempts to recreate that song’s success
column6: right down to replicating its basic structure. Sometimes
column7: this works: the effervescent “No Enemiesz” finds Kiesza shouting over squiggles and a hollow
column8: pounding beat before hitting a chorus that utilizes her oversinging tendencies effectively
column9: while “Giant in My Heart” blooms into a satisfying 4/4 pulse that carries superficial charms similar to off-brand cereal.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: though
column3: Sound of a Woman fails to spark
column4: as its homogenous textures blend together to rob this music of the personality and emotion it has when done right. Kiesza and Afuni treat house music with all the studiousness of someone reading a textbook
column5: as evidenced by her sorta-viral
column6: sacrilegiously po-faced cover of Haddaway’s “What Is Love”. On one level
column7: they’ve committed cultural thievery of the laziest kind
column8: right down to European dance culture’s obsession with dusty
column9: pre-2000s hip-hop (the shiftless “Losin’ My Mind” and “Bad Thing”
column10: with respective features by American rappers Mick Jenkins and Joey Bada$$). Kiesza and Afuni come across as guests at a dinner party who couldn’t be bothered to bring anything and expect their presence to do the work for them.

column1: So Sound of a Woman’s most memorable moments are when the duo deviate from their established norm: “So Deep” is a brooding
column2: bleeping slow jam that
column3: midway through
column4: breaks into a moderately appealing 2step rhythm
column5: while ""Piano” soothes and swerves with the druggy melancholy of certain strains of R&B
column6: building to a pleading
column7: drum-assisted chorus that wouldn’t have sounded out of place on Jessie Ware’s 2012 debut Devotion. They’re capable
column8: pretty songs
column9: and like the rest of <i>Sound of a Woman
column10:
they don’t give any clues as to who Kiesza is. 

"|19933.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19933-kiesza-sound-of-a-woman/|5.2|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21164/homepage_large.6fb8c3c7.jpg|So It Is With Us|5035.0|Horse Feathers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kill Rock Stars']|2014-10-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:44.374183|"

There’s no way Horse Feathers could live up to a song title like “Violently Wild”
column2: the track that opens their fifth album. Over the last decade the Portland chamber-folk group
column3: led by singer-songwriter Justin Ringle
column4: has perfected a gently gothic sound reliant on stringed instruments
column5: painstaking compositions
column6: and muted emotions
column7: as though in direct opposition to the strummy histrionics of the Lumineers and Mumford & Sons. There’s always been something dignified in Horse Feathers’ restraint
column8: even if that didn’t make them an especially exciting band to follow. And the wear of so many depressive tunes apparently began to weigh on Ringle
column9: who followed up the tour for 2012’s Cynic’s New Year with an 18-month hiatus from music.

column1: That break was productive
column2: as So It Is With Us finds Horse Feathers tinkering with new sounds
column3: major keys
column4: faster tempos
column5: and different emotional textures. There are even drums here. So
column6: all things being relative
column7: “Violently Wild” is certainly the most violently wild the band has ever been. Rather than mopey
column8: Ringle’s vocals are heraldic. The music is more celebratory than mournful. The rhythm section sounds like it can actually hold a groove and make the song a kinetic show opener or closer. It’s a joyful noise: Horse Feathers perform the song like they’ve just discovered a new superpower.

column1: On each of their four previous albums
column2: all except debut Words Are Dead released on Kill Rock Stars
column3: Horse Feathers have emphasized rigid song structures and careful arrangements that blend guitar
column4: violin
column5: cello
column6: and voice into melancholy rural song suites. Broadening the tone of the music has opened up new possibilities
column7: which means Horse Feathers play more like a band and less like a Ringle solo project. Their palette is more expansive and more ambitious
column8: drawing elements from tango and doo-wop
column9: jazz and '50s pop. They plays songs like “Old Media” and “Small Melody” with real enthusiasm. “Dead End Thanks” in particular thrums with energy
column10: as Nathan Crockett’s violin spirals around Dustin Dybvig’s piano and pulls the song in unexpected directions.

column1: This is still a Horse Feathers album
column2: which means that underneath the liveliness lurks the same darkness that has informed all of the group’s material. “We’re out of tune
column3: you’ll be gone
column4: and I’ll be leaving soon
column5: ” Ringle promises on the sing-along chorus to “Violently Wild”
column6: singing darkly of marriage and commitment and the inevitable end that quells all arguments. Throughout his tenure
column7: Ringle has written eloquently—sometimes too eloquently—about gnawing disaffection and thwarted desires
column8: but the relative sunniness of the music on So It Is With Us suggests higher stakes: The dark makes the lighter sound lighter
column9: and the light makes the dark sound darker.

column1: “Tell me why do you try hangin’ on?” Ringle asks on “Why Do I Try” sounding like a man who might just stop. It’s arguably the most downcast song on the album
column2: as he wonders about the fate of his children
column3: yet it’s one of the band’s most subtly adventurous arrangements. Ringle lays down sharp staccato guitar licks that summon Steve Cropper
column4: and the band moves with a steadiness that gives the song a hymnlike feel
column5: at least until the woozy piano comes in like the ghost of Buddy Holly. As Ringle hits the high notes on the bridge
column6:
the song reveals itself as Pacific Northwest soul—which is something completely unexpected from Horse Feathers and a fine answer to the song’s central question. He sounds like a man with renewed faith.

"|19914.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19914-horse-feathers-so-it-is-with-us/|7.4|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20978/homepage_large.e9704fd0.jpg|Venus Armata|24563.0|Menace Ruine|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore'
column3: particularly of the folk and/or metal persuasion
column4: draw inspiration from medieval music. But most don’t hold a torch to Menace Ruine. Not that the Montreal-based duo comes off in any way traditional; on albums such as 2012’s Alight in Ashes
column5: singer/keyboardist Geneviève Beaulieu soaks her ancient-reaching plainsong in vats of boiling noise and a thickened black-metal reduction. Recently
column6: her voice has taken on varying shades of mysticism in her side project Preterite
column7: as well as her chilling appearance on James Blackshaw’s 2012 album <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16527-love-is-the-plan-the-plan-is-death/""><i>Love Is the Plan
column8: the Plan Is Death. Aided by instrumentalist/producer S. de La Moth
column9: Beaulieu has delivered the sixth and latest Menace Ruine album
column10: Venus Armata—and while it doesn’t vastly expand the band’s mist-shrouded domain
column11: it’s a potent elixir of Dark Ages alchemy and modern experimentalism.

column1: Venus Armata’s seven songs are split almost evenly between somewhat prettier and slightly more horrifying. Any overt gestures toward metal
column2: black or otherwise
column3: have been jettisoned on “Red Sulphur”
column4: in which Beaulieu’s sacrificial chants coil around gulping organ drones like serpents around a scepter. The percussion is synthetic and martial
column5: but it’s draped in enough mid-fi gauze to make it seem half alive. That liminal state of being is more eerily evoked in “Soothing but Cruel”. Where “Red Sulphur” carries a sylvan
column6: romanticized folk air
column7: “Soothing but Cruel” is grinding
column8: oscillatory
column9: and proto-industrial—shards of distortion splinter and stab as Beaulieu trills in a lilting tongue that sounds simultaneously ancestral and alien. That paradox seeps into every fiber of Venus Armata
column10: from Beaulieu’s rickety
column11: looped-calliope keys to the modal circularity and  sonorous portent of her melodies. If Nostradamus had spoken through Nico
column12: the result might have resembled “Venus Armata
column13: ” the album’s 16-minute
column14: grimoire-worthy title track.

column1: Whatever occult undertones Venus Armata may possess
column2: they’re sliced open and laid bare across “Soften Our Evil Hearts” and “Belly of the Closed House”. Both are saga-length
column3: incantatory meditations
column4: but their shrillness is distilled into an icy shimmer that’s more visceral than spiritual. Beaulieu’s stained-glass voice is layered on top of its own ghost on “Soften Our Evil Hearts”
column5: forming an unholy fugue
column6: although that echoed distance isn’t as riveting as her intimate performance on “Marriage in Death”. Amid slow-motion bursts of dissonance and space
column7: her voice wanders like a lost soul. At 9 barely modulated minutes
column8: in never seems to end
column9: and that purgatorial stasis says more about marriage and death as ritualistic constructs than it does about their everyday reality. Not that Menace Ruine would ever stoop to the mundane. On Venus Armata’s most spine-tingling song
column10: “Torture of Fire”
column11: Beaulieu bleats beatifically
column12: while a plodding
column13: ominous beat throbs behind her like an onrushing apocalypse. When she pauses
column14: there’s no mercy to it. It’s just a chance for the bleak
column15: acidic static to foam up to the forefront.

column1: In an interview in 2008
column2: Beaulieu spoke expectantly of a planned collaboration with Merzbow that has yet to surface. Strangely enough
column3: each Menace Ruine album since that time has inched closer to imagining what exactly such a collaboration might look like. That’s not to say Venus Armata is anywhere near as skull-rattling or hermetically exacting as Merzbow; if anything
column4: the album’s closest alignment is with Beaulieu’s fellow-traveling singer/keyboardist
column5: Jarboe. But Beaulieu’s narrow scope—in essence
column6: hurdy-gurdy-like hymns manifested as post-industrial ambience—is blown out to cosmological proportions. There are universes bottled inside Venus Armata
column7: or at least Beaulieu and de La Moth play as if there are
column8:
and the reverence with which they funnel their awe is downright liturgical. Venus Armata doesn’t stand on ceremony; it drowns itself in it.

"|19749.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19749-menace-ruine-venus-armata/|7.4|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21070/homepage_large.20eecdee.jpg|Master Mix: Red Hot + Arthur Russell|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Yep Roc']|2014-10-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:45.638660|"

It's both wonderful and frustrating that so much of Arthur Russell's music is incomplete or open-ended. Russell supposedly left behind something like a thousand tapes
column2: many of them not-quite-finished recordings or variations on particular songs
column3: when he died from AIDS-related complications in 1992. He was one of the great geniuses of New York City music—a brilliant melodist and even better catalyst who brought together the Downtown experimental music scene
column4: the disco world
column5: and the singer/songwriter tradition. And
column6: as beautiful as his solo voice-and-cello recordings are
column7: he also thrived on giving collaborators raw material to explore and shape: the long list of artists with whom he recorded includes Talking Heads
column8: Allen Ginsberg
column9: François Kevorkian
column10: and Peter Gordon.

column1: All of that suggests that his music would make for a hell of a tribute album
column2: which is true of this double-CD set–a half that consists of covers of the songs that were more or less open-ended when Russell recorded them. Robyn's take on ""Tell You (Today)""
column3: a giddy disco jam by Russell's short-lived group Loose Joints
column4: concentrates it from a seven-minute sprawl to a 3:45 pop shimmer; she sings it like it's her favorite song in the world
column5: even stumbling over a line exactly the way Loose Joints' Joyce Bowden did. Hot Chip approach ""Go Bang"" as a set of modular components rather than a stable composition—arguably the same way Russell treated it when he recorded it with Dinosaur L—and arrange them into a big tent to hold a disco party inside.

column1: Blood Orange goes even further in that direction
column2: attempting to hybridize bits of Loose Joints' disco classic ""Is It All Over My Face"" and Russell's orchestral piece ""Tower of Meaning"". It doesn't quite jell
column3: but it's at least in the spirit of Russell's own why-not attitude. There's a previously unreleased song included here
column4: too: Ernie Brooks (who played with Russell in the Flying Hearts)
column5: Peter Zummo (who recorded minimalist instrumental music with him)
column6: and Liam Finn's contribution to Master Mix is the exquisite ""This Love Is Crying""
column7: which they picked up from an old rehearsal tape.

column1: Russell's recordings are enormously idiosyncratic
column2: and a lot of Master Mix's contributors try to normalize his music: sanding off his bristling electric cello tones
column3: hammering repeated phrases into choruses
column4: singing with dramatic intonation in place of his ethereal reserve. (The major exception is Lonnie Holley
column5: whose four brief ""interludes"" here abstract Russell pieces further.) That often works just fine
column6: surprisingly. Russell's ""Eli"" was a rhythmless
column7: wounded shout into the darkness; the version by Rubblebucket and Nitemoves doubles its duration
column8: snaps it to a foursquare beat
column9: replaces the cello with misty rock instrumentation
column10: and ends up recalling mid-'80s Cocteau Twins. Sam Amidon tweaks World of Echo's stream-of-consciousness piece ""Lucky Cloud"" into something that might be sung around a campfire rather than murmured alone in a dark forest. Scissor Sisters' ""That's Us/Wild Combination"" slicks up and modernizes the arrangement from Russell's Calling Out of Context
column11: emphasizing how similar it is to their own music.

column1: Where this collection falters is in its second half
column2: with a string of artists covering Russell's more straightforward songs—the three-minute guitar-pop tunes that mostly ended up on his posthumous collection Love Is Overtaking Me. Glen Hansard
column3: Thao & the Get Down Stay Down
column4: and the Autumn Defense perform Russell's songs precisely as their author did
column5: in the same key and at the same tempo
column6: without singing them quite as elegantly. Those are the sort of ""tributes"" that are purely gestural
column7: honoring songs by showing up for them rather than by reshaping them. But one of the things that made Russell's work special (and
column8: arguably
column9:
kept him from completing so much of it) was his conviction that there was always more to discover within it.

"|19833.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19833-various-artists-master-mix-red-hot-arthur-russell/|7.3|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21098/homepage_large.33d9b491.jpg|IX|91.0|...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Superball']|2014-10-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:46.474551|"

Trail of Dead IX. Sure
column2: it doesn’t quite roll off the tongue like Queen II
column3: Zeppelin III
column4: or Chicago 17. But
column5: 20 years into their rollercoaster run
column6: Trail of Dead can wear that nine like a badge of honor
column7: considering there was a time when it didn’t look like they would make it far past album number three. And though bandleader Conrad Keely has said the new album’s title is really just a reference to a planet featured in Frank Herbert’s Dune
column8: it nonetheless speaks volumes about the band’s current state—like the very Roman numeral that comprises it
column9: IX suggests the arrival at a crossroads. At this point
column10: Trail of Dead have lived out every narrative in the rock'n'roll playbook: the promising debut
column11: the real-deal follow-up
column12: the career peak
column13: the spectacular crash
column14: the failure to relaunch
column15: the reconstruction
column16: the encouraging show of strength
column17: and the valiant return to form. But where their discography to date has seen violent swings from discordant punk to lavish prog and back again
column18: with IX
column19: they opt to let the pendulum rest gently in the middle.

column1: Trail of Dead’s current four-piece lineup—instrument-swapping co-founders Keely and Jason Reece
column2: plus bassist Autry Fulbright II and guitarist/drummer Jamie Miller—has been in place for almost as long as their name-making 1998-2003 formation. And after two albums (2011’s Tao of the Dead and 2012’s Lost Songs) that reinstituted Trail of Dead’s primordial crash-and-burn guitar carnage
column3: with IX
column4: the solidified band is feeling confident enough to take another stab at the cinemascopic
column5: candelabra-lit pop that defined Trail of Dead’s muddled mid-period output
column6: but this time with a lesson-learned sense of restraint. So while IX sees Trail of Dead rolling out the piano and enlisting a string section once again (the album contains not one
column7: but two interstitial chamber-rock crash-endos)
column8: in this case
column9: the ornate touch-ups don’t come at the expense of the band’s roiling energy.

column1: It takes the band a few tries to get the balance just right—IX opens with a trio of mid-tempo guitar-churning
column2: drum-thundering tracks that are too controlled to fully erupt
column3: and too heavy-handed to showcase their melodic graces. (In particular
column4: “Jaded Apostles” sees Keely adopting a theatrically overwrought vocal to infuse the song with an intensity that its lumbering
column5: Celtic-reeled gallop can’t muster.) But IX gradually loosens up and simmers down without diminishing its dramatic intent: the careening “Lie Without a Liar” and “The Dragonfly Queen” pledge allegiance to the “(Don’t Fear) The Reaper”/”So. Central Rain (I'm Sorry)” school of sinister jangle-pop; “The Ghost Within” is a celestial ballad in the vein of Madonna’s “Clair de Lune” or “Sigh Your Children”
column6: and a reminder that behind Trail of Dead’s apocalyptic attack beats the bruised heart of a mid-’90s emo act (and there’s no better time than now to reapply it on their sleeves). And in contrast to the cultural critiques that formed the conceptual framework of their most recent records
column7: IX feels like a more personal work
column8: focusing on intimate exchanges that better suit its more refined presentation. Most affecting is centerpiece track “Bus Lines”
column9: wherein Trail of Dead’s fantastical
column10: globe-spanning universe gets distilled to a simple
column11: poignant portrait of backpack travel and homesickness
column12: the song’s pent-up emotion unleashed in a Siamese Dream-y coda of phased-guitar fireworks.

column1: That towering climax serves as the launch-pad into IX’s more epically scaled home stretch
column2: with Reece’s jugular-bulging “Lost in the Grand Scheme” reverting to Trail of Dead’s familiar pattern of firing up
column3: flaming out
column4: and rekindling for an even bigger bang. But the closing “Sound of the Silk” proves a more slippery beast than its sunrise-summoning psych-pop initially suggests
column5: leading us through a drum-circle breakdown and spoken-word change-up en route to a fierce finale that sees Keely and Reece locking into a call-and-response clamor. In essence
column6: the song is Trail of Dead’s entire discography condensed into an “in case you missed it” highlight reel of paisley-patterned melody
column7: jammed-out indulgence
column8: and steroid-pumped punk. While the band may have struggled in the past to reconcile their post-hardcore roots with their art-rock ambitions<i>
column9: more often than not
column10:
IX marks the spot. 

"|19859.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19859-and-you-will-know-us-by-the-trail-of-dead-ix/|7.2|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21165/homepage_large.9ac458d5.jpg|Love Ain't No Mystery|32304.0|Lewis|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Summersteps']|2014-10-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:48.004392|"

2014 has been a busy year for a ghost from the 1980s. First came Light in the Attic's reissue in May of the 1983 LP L'Amour
column2: by the mysterious
column3: apparently-untraceable figure called Lewis (supposed real name: Randall Wulff). Then in July
column4: a second artifact was discovered in a warehouse: a 1985 album called Romantic Times
column5: credited to Lewis Baloue. When Light in the Attic reissued that
column6: they also claimed to have found the man himself
column7: or at least someone who looks like a decades-older version of the suave gent who graced those '80s album covers.

column1: Even before that encounter
column2: rumors circulated about more Lewis recordings
column3: made under the name Randy Duke in the late '90s at a studio near Vancouver called Fiasco Bros. An engineer named Len Osanic confirmed these were indeed by Lewis/Wulff
column4: and recently released some of them digitally as a 12-track album called Love Ain’t No Mystery
column5: later licensing them to Summersteps Records for a cassette with three additional songs. Since the voice on these tapes is unmistakably that of the man who made L’Amour and Romantic Times
column6: and Osanic says the release is approved (he’s been friends with Wulff since the early '00s)
column7: it seems fair to call this the third Lewis album.

column1: In many ways
column2: though
column3: Love Ain’t No Mystery occupies a different universe than its predecessors. Where '80s Lewis was smooth as silk—an enigmatic soft-rock savant—'90s Lewis is raw and direct. His subject matter is still love
column4: but he’s shifted from seduction and romance to heartbreak and loss
column5: and he wants to tell you about it without filters. Hence the music is much sparser: just voice and guitar
column6: without the synths and beats that added texture to L’Amour and Romantic Times. Lewis’ singing retains a shy
column7: retreating quality
column8: but it’s much higher in the mix
column9: and where his voice once could disappear
column10: it now rarely takes breaks. He massages phrases obsessively and repeats lines like mantras
column11: as if he can find answers by asking the same question over and over. (Osanic claims Lewis often spent hours making subtly different variations of songs
column12: sitting silent for 10 minutes before starting each one.)

column1: This tireless repetition
column2: combined with the fact that Summersteps’ cassette lasts almost 90 minutes
column3: makes Love Ain’t No Mystery an endurance test. Most songs cross the 6-minute mark and feel longer; at their most hypnotic
column4: they’re as fascinating as infinity
column5: but in other places they just feel endless. The closest parallel to Lewis’ approach here is the lonely
column6: damaged blues of Jandek
column7: or perhaps the stretched melodrama of later-period Scott Walker. But Lewis doesn’t venture as far out as either; he never sounds like he’s going off the deep end or even staring over its edge. Oddly
column8: this makes Love Ain’t No Mystery prone to tedium
column9: since there’s not a lot of unpredictability in terms of song structure. Once you hear the first few musical phrases of a given track
column10: you pretty much know what you’re in for the rest of the way.

column1: The many moods Lewis conjures with his vocals
column2: however
column3: are harder to peg. He continually pushes and pulls his voice until it quivers and cracks
column4: abandoning conventional notions of pitch or melody if they get in the way of expressing emotion. But he also knows how to hold back
column5: how to hint and suggest rather than yell
column6: even when he’s not whispering. So the halting
column7: vaporous “I Was Not Shy” takes an opposite angle from the hoarse
column8: distorted blues of “I Come From Texas”
column9: but both arrive at convincingly geniuine feelings.

column1: The variety in Lewis’ singing is especially impressive given how close and unprotected it sounds. According to Osanic
column2: Lewis set up mics “so he could 'work' them by moving closer and sideways as if he was whispering in someones ear
column3: ” and even wore a special shirt that made the least possible noise when he shifted around. (Stories like that make you understand why some suggest the whole Lewis story is a hoax.) But the relentless in-your-ear aura doesn’t limit Lewis’ ability to convey feelings; in fact
column4: it seems to enhance it.

column1: All that compelling emotion is what connects Love Ain’t No Mystery to L’Amour and Romantic Times
column2: and shows their peculiar
column3: mesmerizing accomplishments were no flukes. Those two previous records are stronger works: subtler
column4: more complete
column5: weaving vocals and music into a richer whole. But even when his tactics are more simplistic
column6: Randy Wulff knows how to turn feelings into music
column7:
and that makes the discovery of Love Ain’t No Mystery a valuable one.

"|19915.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19915-lewis-love-aint-no-mystery/|6.6|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20988/homepage_large.4e10514a.jpg|We Are Time|9376.0|The Pop Group|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Freaks R Us']|2014-10-21 00:00:00|1980|2016-06-11 16:31:48.614410|"

As the fuzzy malaise of the 1970s slipped into the sharp
column2: cruel hope of the ’80s
column3: the burgeoning post-punk movement faced a choice: continue to engage the world in a confrontational way
column4: or adopt a more vague
column5: poetic mode of address. Is it better to turn your band’s entire body of work into one extended Marxist metaphor
column6: like Gang of Four
column7: or to embody a post-capitalist ideal of pop without openly acknowledging the injustice of the here-and-now
column8: like Scritti Politti? The Pop Group wanted it both ways—and for a brief time
column9: they had it. The British band’s two studio albums
column10: 1979’s Y and 1980’s For How Much Longer Do We Tolerate Mass Murder?
column11: upped the agit-funk panic while dipping into the slithery
column12: ambiguous depths of dub nebulosity. Frontman Mark Stewart penned leftist screeds
column13: then he babbled and screeched them so hideously that they ripped themselves to pieces. It was up to the listener to reassemble the shreds and try to make sense of them
column14: even as the brunt of their meaning was as clear as any Crass anthem.

column1: The Pop Group released a third and final full-length before breaking up in 1981
column2: but it wasn’t a studio album per se. We Are Time came out in 1980
column3: and it’s being reissued sans bonus tracks or anything else by way of bells and whistles. That is
column4: unless you count Cabinet of Curiosities
column5: a brand new collection of odds-and-ends that might as well be We Are Time: Part II. In the same way We Are Time does
column6: Cabinet of Curiosities gathers random studio cuts
column7: live versions
column8: and Peel Sessions recordings; the official studio versions of those songs originally appear on singles
column10: or For How Much Longer
column11: while others are exhumed legitimately for the first time via Cabinet of Curiosities. In that sense
column12: both collections are important: a few gaps are filled
column13: some hard-to-find tracks are unearthed
column14: and a tragically abbreviated discography is fleshed out. That said
column15: neither album substantively buttresses Y or For How Much Longer
column16: let alone threatens to knock them over.

column1: We Are Time has always felt like an admittedly big footnote to the Pop Group’s catalog
column2: and while that hasn’t changed with this bare-minimum reissue
column3: the album’s bursts of brilliance still sear. “Colour Blind” is one of 4 songs that were recorded as a demo not long after the band formed in 1978
column4: and it’s an astounding statement; this is the closest the sarcastically named Pop Group ever came to playing actual pop
column5: and the song’s loping
column6: cavity-riddled rhythm is smoothed over by Stewart’s gluey melody and a sweet-verse-acidic-chorus dynamic. It’s astounding how
column7: almost 40 years later
column8: it not only sounds more sophisticated than most post-punk circa ’78
column9: but also eerily contemporary.

column1: That can’t be said of the entirety of We Are Time. Another demo recording
column2: “Trap”
column3: is piercing
column4: punky
column5: and smeared with schoolboy conceits (“Burn all my books
column6: page by page/ Cut my flesh with a paper edge”)
column7: but it’s also pitched down the middle of the post-punk plate. For all its anxious stiffness
column8: it’s incredibly impassioned and perversely double-jointed; Minutemen cited the Pop Group as a major influence
column9: and “Trap” is solid proof of that. The live tracks are serviceable
column10: and show off the band’s formidable improv chops
column11: but the savage version of “Thief of Fire” misses the cooling counterbalance and atmospheric flourishes of Dennis Bovell’s dub production on Y
column12: which also presaged Stewart's post-Pop Group direction in New Age Steppers
column13: as a solo artist
column14: and collaborating with everyone from Adrian Sherwood to Daddy G to Factory Floor.

column1: Cabinet of Curiosities is the brand-new bookend to the decades-old We Are Time
column2: but seeing as how it draws from the same well of peripheral material
column3: it comes up shorter. That gulf is exemplified by the inclusion of an alternate studio version of the Pop Group’s most famous song
column4: “She Is Beyond Good and Evil”. It’s billed here as the “Original Version Previously Unreleased
column5: ” and it differs only slightly from the single/album version that’s become one of post-punk’s most durable manifestos (St. Vincent’s bracing
column6: faithful cover performed on ""Late Night With Jimmy Fallon"" in 2011 demonstrates just how prescient the Pop Group’s vision was). The Cabinet version
column7: though
column8: has lower highs and higher lows; Stewart doesn’t whoop or whisper as much
column9: and the cavernous aura that places the song in the same realm as Liquid Liquid and a Certain Ratio is nowhere near as huge.

column1: On the other hand
column2: it’s great to hear “Where There’s a Will”
column3: the band’s half of a 1980 split with the Slits (with whom the Pop Group shared a drummer); its sculptural disco
column4: free-jazz sax
column5: and pious debt to Parliament’s “Give Up the Funk (Tear the Roof Off the Sucker)” hit harder than ever. The live tracks and Peel Sessions of songs that first appeared on proper albums and singles are again inessential
column6: although that’s offset by in-concert recordings of two Pop Group songs that are previously unreleased in any form: “Abstract Heart” and “Karen’s Car”. The former lunges along on throbbing bass and a fractured jazziness
column7: even if its swagger is hamstrung by all the jarring shifts
column8: noodling fusion solos
column9: and an atypically lackluster set of lyrics from Stewart. The latter is a bit better
column10: at least compositionally; there are some intriguing ideas sticking out at odd angles from the feverish jam. Unfortunately it’s the one live track on either Cabinet or We Are Time that suffers from a muddy
column11: unforgiving recording.

column1: If the Pop Group can be faulted for anything
column2: it’s that Stewart’s precocious ambition was always a half step ahead of the band itself. That’s most dramatically heard on We Are Time’s “Amnesty Report II” and Cabinet of Curiosities’ “Amnesty Report III”. Both are variations on “Amnesty International Report on British Army Torture of Irish Prisoners”
column3: the B-side of the band’s second single
column4: 1979’s “We Are All Prostitutes”. The original version is a noise-collage scramble of static
column5: voices
column6: and the rubble of riffs; despite its challenging sound (and sidelong glance at Throbbing Gristle in regard to both sound and title)
column7: it’s the most artlessly preachy song the Pop Group ever made. “II” is more coherent than the single version
column8: but it still feels likes a sketch; “III” is simply a different mix
column9: and one that doesn’t fulfill any purpose other than fill out Cabinet’s already skimpy
column10: nine-track span.

column1: The most disappointing thing about Cabinet is that it’s being released as a standalone album
column2: when really it warrants little more than being bonus tracks on the We Are Time reissue. That doesn’t detract from the undimmed impact of these recordings after all this time. The Pop Group were unique among the major post-punk bands
column3: able and willing to clench up and cut loose with equal force—and to thread polemic into dream-logic poetry. The reissue of We Are Time and the release of Cabinet of Curiosities don’t diminish that fact
column4:
but they don’t amplify it much either. 

"|19759.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19759-the-pop-group-we-are-timecabinet-of-curiosities/|7.5|Jason Heller

column11: unforgiving recording.

column5: voices

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21163/homepage_large.1828bfa9.jpg|Tough Love|29991.0|Jessie Ware|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Universal Island'
column3: Tough Love
column4: there’s a deeply weird song that could potentially infiltrate the mainstream—not in spite of its sonic alien quality
column5: but because of it. “Keep On Lying” sounds like a gospel choir singing atop a chintzy keyboard stuck on the ""bossa nova"" setting
column6: yet it's easy to picture ""So You Think You Can Dance"" hopefuls popping-and-locking to it. This delicate balance is lightning-bolt brilliance that may not even strike once in a career for most artists
column7: but Jessie Ware has made the balance appear effortless several times already in her young career
column8: a talented pop vocalist who projects an interesting taste in music and a canny know-how in regards to the up-and-coming electronic producers she chooses to work with.

column1: Ware's musical vision revolves around genuine curation and experimentation when it comes to sounds that don't appear as often in today's pop music landscape. Sure
column2: there's plenty of divas who have embraced their quirky sides
column3: from Kylie Minogue’s Impossible Princess to Madonna’s Ray of Light to Katy Perry’s two-minute preoccupation with 1990s dance-pop vocalist CeCe Peniston last year. But rarely does a major-label pop singer sound as tasteful as Ware does
column4: especially while avoiding the sleepy trappings of Adult Contemporary. At its best
column5: Ware's music sounds truly exciting without sounding as if it's trying too hard to come across that way
column6: and as such Tough Love isn’t packed with explicit experimentation. Following her excellent 2012 debut Devotion
column7: Ware is engaging with a variety of genres that stand to introduce her to new
column8: different listeners with ears tuned to the mainstream. Some of these songs
column9: like the midtempo disco banger “Want Your Feeling” or the xx-smacking “Sweetest Song”
column10: properly fit Ware rather than coming across as the singer playing dress-up.

column1: On the other end of the spectrum
column2: top-40's hobbit du jour Ed Sheeran plays a key role with a co-writing credit on the swooning acoustic ballad “Say You Love Me”
column3: a soulful and catchy number that nonetheless doesn't exactly reinvent the pop-music wheel. That's a fine enough standard for many singers who are not Ware
column4: but her past work has suggested that she's better than that. The same could be said of the album’s most clichéd lyrical moment
column5: the BenZel-produced “Champagne Kisses”
column6: which sounds more like a Miguel B-side than the two Tough Love songs the R&B singer actually contributed to—namely
column7: the mushy “You & I (Forever)” and sexting-my-exes anthem “Kind Of...Sometimes…Maybe”
column8: the latter of which functions as the album's highlight.

column1: Part of the increased variety on Tough Love stems from a more diverse array of collaborators
column2: from producer Emile Haynie (Eminem
column3: Lana Del Rey) to Blood Orange's Devonté Hynes; it's also due to a wider emotional range of lyrical themes
column4: as well as an increased show of confidence on Ware’s part. Her music has moved past exuding the type of smoldering desire that borders just slightly on desperation
column5: moving into the territory of real
column6: messy love; accordingly
column7: her vocal power throughout the album facilitates this shift
column8: which speaks to her impressive versatility in this stage of her career. You get the sense that pretty much any style could be Ware’s if she commits to it
column9:
but for now it’s nice to hear her explore a level of sophistication as her star continues to rise.

The Best Day is not the first music Thurston Moore has released since becoming the most famous—and
column3: in some circles
column4: most reviled—divorcé in American indie-rock. It is
column5: however
column6: the first time he’s released a song-oriented album under his own name since his highly publicized split from long-time wife/bandmate Kim Gordon. And given that Moore’s traditionally used these solo albums to explore more intimate
column7: emotionally resonant songcraft than Sonic Youth’s gnarled guitar jams normally accommodate
column8: it’s not totally unreasonable to expect he’d use this opportunity to reflect upon the recent upheaval in his personal life in a more poetic way than contentious interview sound-bites allow.

column1: But with Sonic Youth officially on indefinite—or is it infinite?—hiatus
column2: The Best Day proves to be not so much a revelatory
column3: introspective antidote to Moore’s best-known band as a serviceable
column4: equally high-voltage substitute for it. The album may not approach the metal-meltdown extremes of last year’s one-off with Chelsea Light Moving
column5: but it does leave the drumstick-scraped guitars and humming amplifiers plugged in
column6: displacing the acoustic quietude of 2007’s Trees Outside the Academy and 2011’s Demolished Thoughts with a distinctly Sonic Youth-ian discord.

column1: Now a London resident
column2: Moore has built a backing band that’s a transatlantic mirror image of the Youth’s classic formation
column3: complete with a certified queen-of-noise bassist in My Bloody Valentine’s Deb Googe and a Lee Ranaldo-esque guitarist foil (James Sedwards of long-running U.K. math-punk trio Nought) schooled in both classic-rock tradition and avant-garde experimentation. (Playing the role of drummer Steve Shelley is… Steve Shelley
column4: who—given his unwavering Hoboken allegiances—is presumably being paid in frequent-flyer points.) As such
column5: The Best Day proves to be more of a demonstration of this line-up’s intuitive dexterity than a snapshot of Moore’s inner psyche—it's not so much a break-up album as a celebration of breaking free.

column1: Moore recently told Rolling Stone that
column2: from the album title to the quaint 1940s-era cover shot of his mom hugging a dog
column3: The Best Day is an album steeped in positivity
column4: with the implication that he’s having too much of a good time in his new life in England to dwell on the past. But it’s a contentment that’s not so much communicated in the lyrics—which adhere to a familiarly cryptic combination of street-hassle spiel and Catholic-block symbolism—as in the freewheeling spirit that permeates these recordings. (Ironically
column5: the few acoustic-based songs that seem to speak most loudly to Moore’s personal preoccupations—like the cassette fetishism of “Tape” and the grrl-power solidarity statement ""Vocabularies”—actually feature lyrics penned by London-based poet Radieux Radio
column6: with whom Moore previously collaborated on a 7''.)

column1: Showing off his newly minted supergroup like a recently acquired sports car
column2: Moore leads with his two most imposing
column3: open-ended tracks: Clocking in at a respective eight and 11 minutes
column4: “Speak to the Wild” and “Forevermore” bracingly announce Moore’s return to sprawling
column5: Sonic Youth-scaled guitar odysseys
column6: with an alluring
column7: live-in-the-room ambience that makes it feel like you’re curling up on the pillow weighing down Shelley’s kick drum. But these colossal songs emphasize what separates this line-up from Sonic Youth as much as the similarities. Even when compared to the Youth’s more even-keeled post-2000s output
column8: there’s an almost ominous steadiness to Shelley’s playing here
column9: as he and Googe lay down a locomotive
column10: locked-groove foundation for Moore and Sedwards' six-string entanglements that’s ultimately closer in spirit to CCR’s extended “I Heard it Through the Grapevine” overhaul.

column1: The FM-radio flashbacks don’t end there: the only way to make the title track’s Keith Richards worship more obvious would be to call it “Stones” (had Moore not already used that name a decade ago)
column2: while even the stripped-down “Vocabularies” is centered around a chugging riff oddly reminiscent of “Smoke on the Water”. But while the loose
column3: carefree nature of The Best Day supports Moore’s claim that he’s having “so much fun” playing with his new band
column4: the top-heavy sequence gives the album a lopsided feel
column5: with its two opening monster tracks establishing an immersive intensity that the shorter
column6: scrappier songs in its wake never quite recapture. (Though “Grace Lake”
column7: an instrumental that follows a similar chiming-to-churning course as way-underrated 1998 Sonic Youth epic “Wildflower Soul”
column8: comes close.) Tellingly
column9: in a recent interview
column10: Moore admitted he positioned “Germs Burn”—a more oblique manifestation of his unyielding Darby Crash obsession—as The Best Day’s closer not because its contrast of gleaming guitar jangle and hardcore-inspired staccato phrasing makes for a particularly dramatic finale
column11: but simply because he was unhappy with his vocal performance on it and wanted to bury it. All of which suggests that
column12: with The Best Day
column13:
Moore is really laying the groundwork for a better tomorrow.

Don't mistake Picture You Staring for anything more than a simple pop record. The second full-length from Montreal quartet TOPS comprises 12 examples of lithe
column2: bubbly songwriting that winks at you even as it tears up. Rarely clocking in over four minutes
column3: each song features the same sparse instrumentation (bass
column4: drum kit
column5: maybe two guitars
column6: sometimes a synth
column7: and vocals)
column8: as if the goal of their DIY recording sessions was to perfect a hooky single and a wistful ballad using only one set of tools. Fully enjoying TOPS' 43-minute LP hinges on how many times you'd like to hear them try.

column1: Picture You Staring considers itself an album of breezy AM radio hits
column2: despite having been written by people who were born well after that was a thing. Captain & Tennille and Harry Nilsson are ostensible reference points
column3: but it's less disingenuous to call the music what it is: post-Ariel Pink bedroom pop. That's not to say the Canadian band is aiming for Pink's spot
column4: as their sound is far too spry and lucid for such glammy psychedelia. No one would confuse ""Sleeptalker""'s heavy-lidded Danelectro fingerpicking and the funky skip of ""Easier Said"" for one of Pink's considerable high points
column5: but it's possible they'll eventually wind up alongside each other on hopelessly lovesick playlists.

column1: Variety is of little concern for TOPS
column2: so near-perfect songwriting and a dynamic tracklist is all the more important. The stunning ""Outside"" effortlessly reimagines Angelo Badalamenti's Julee Cruise-sung ""Falling"" theme from ""Twin Peaks""
column3: casting singer Jane Penny's waifish coo next to plush synth pads and wavering baritone guitar. But its quick three and a half minutes are soon missed
column4: as ""All the People Sleep"" tries drawing a drowsy grin onto the melancholic mood. Picking the pace back up for Picture You Staring's second half
column5: ""Superstition Future"" sets a nimble gait for its slinky guitar chords and singalong choruses to follow
column6: with varied success; anti-anthem ""Change of Heart"" uses breathless whimsy and keyboard flourishes with more economical precision than ""2 Shy"". TOPS return to weightless balladry for their dual finale
column7: but no matter how deeply affecting each one feels
column8: it's hard to reconcile that ""Driverless Passenger"" is essentially a guitar-led preamble to the whispering synth flicker of ""Destination"".

column1: The structure of ""Blind Faze"" makes a fitting metaphor for Picture You Staring. Bright-eyed and charming
column2: the song is built on a handful of earwormy riffs
column3: Penny's endearingly carefree melodies
column4: and an unassuming dance beat. A perfectly likeable set of sounds
column5: yes
column6: but it's preceded by a dazzling synth arrangement worthy of a standalone composition. The suite barely lasts over 15 seconds and is only revisited once
column7: when it lilts underneath the perky reprise closing the tune. Just as TOPS finish the song without exploring that theme any further
column8: so can ardent pop lovers appreciate reliable hooks
column9: pithy songwriting
column10: and familiar arrangements without much sublimity and innovation. But once those qualities do bubble to the surface
column11:
it's hard not to wonder why they don't show up a little more often.

If there’s a constant in Mark Lanegan’s personal and professional life
column3: it’s in his tendency to periodically flush out everything he knows. Booze
column4: heroin
column5: bands
column6: and collaborators have all framed his existence with some kind of meaning and then been tossed out
column7: sometimes returning
column8: sometimes remaining dead and buried. Blues Funeral—Lanegan’s stubbornly against-type 2012 album
column9: where he folded in
column10: of all things
column11: an impulse for electronica and a dash of New Romantic swagger—had started to look like an anomaly in his canon
column12: a bungled attempt at channeling unlikely influences that were then left to drift into the pool of past-life identities he’s accumulated. His 2013 covers record
column13: Imitations
column14: drew on work by Greg Dulli
column15: Nick Cave
column16: Kurt Weill
column17: and John Cale—in other words
column18: exactly the sort of influences you’d expect the former Screaming Trees frontman to be channeling. But here he is with another album as the Mark Lanegan Band
column19: which in part gets back to the feel he was chasing on Blues Funeral
column20: albeit with a more assured hand ghosting through it.

column1: The story behind Phantom Radio is of someone undergoing a unique conflict with his own past. On one hand it’s clear Lanegan wants to make a break from previous working methods
column2: writing faster
column3: more efficiently
column4: and embracing technology by recording on his phone. But he still has a clutch of older influences on his shoulder that he’s determined to rinse out in song
column5: including a wide array of styles from the '80s and '90s that were completely fenced off from his world in Screaming Trees. It’s not always the most palatable way to experience Lanegan
column6: especially when he channels the MOR-hop of Morcheeba on “The Killing Season”
column7: clumsily fusing it with lyrics that are straight out of his dead-eyed-drunk past (“I wear my old grey overcoat
column8: ” he growls
column9: as the song fades to a close). Lanegan has never come across as someone who’s at ease with his past or present
column10: so the heart of the struggle is familiar here
column11: even if the tools aren’t. It makes sense that Kurt Cobain was an ally in the grunge era—both often came across as being remarkably uncomfortable in their own bodies on stage.

column1: The common feel in a handful of songs here is one of mini symphonies
column2: condensed down into pocket-sized works that create a juxtaposition between Lanegan’s large and small inclinations. “Harvest Home” is one of the strongest works from a lyrical perspective
column3: but its execution is an odd mixture of flat
column4: tinny beats and swooping synthesized strings. It’s a trick Lanegan likes to repeat. “Floor of the Ocean” has a similar uplift
column5: undercut by a moodiness reminiscent of Echo and the Bunnymen circa “The Killing Moon”. On “Seventh Day”
column6: there’s an airy
column7: flute-driven ambience and a bed of electronics
column8: none of which are elements most longstanding Lanegan fans probably ever expected him to be working with
column9: but ones which he’s becoming increasingly at ease with judging from this album. “Waltzing in Blue” lands somewhere between the frigid melodrama of Joy Division and Beth Gibbons’ mournful darkness in Portishead
column10: with Lanegan providing the perfect male flipside to her damaged wail.

column1: Phantom Radio also provides plenty of moments that don’t startle
column2: with a generous portion of it anchored in the stripped-down sinking feeling Lanegan has fitfully returned to since The Winding Sheet in 1990. He throws out “Judgement Time” early in the record
column3: but it’s among his best on this collection
column4: getting back to something resembling the blackness of “Eyes of a Child”
column5: where the sheer coercion of his voice overwhelms from the second it’s introduced. It’s noticeable how Lanegan’s voice has become more brittle over the years
column6: becoming less like a drunk preacher who’s going to gut you and eat you and more like someone quaking in fear of an insufferable end. On the similarly bare “I Am the Wolf” and “The Wild People” you can hear the quiver in his voice
column7: feel the tremors in his hands. It’s not hard to conclude that this is the person Lanegan’s running from in his other material here
column8: although one thing he is remarkably good at across his body of work is letting in disarming moments of vulnerability
column9:
where he pulls you in to spectate upon the wreck of his life. On Phantom Radio there are just a few too many times when it's all dressed up in unnecessary complication.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21138/homepage_large.1ba0cfff.jpg|Pullin' Strings|32548.0|A-Wax|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Illburn']|2014-10-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:31:52.499549|"

California-born Aaron ""A-Wax"" Doppie was only 16 years old when he was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to 78 months in Washington State Penitentiary. During his time behind bars
column2: from 1996
column3: until 2001
column4: he became obsessed with music. He spoke about the experience in detail with Murder Dog's Deyu Ntebya in a 2009 interview: ""Early on when I first started rapping in prison I felt like I couldn’t actually word what I was trying to say
column5: he told Ntebya. ""I had been though a lot of experiences
column6: but I couldn’t put on the paper the way I saw it."" Now thirteen years deep into his career
column7: A-Wax remains a controversial cult figure
column8: publically defined as much by beef as music
column9: winning converts and turning off others in equal measure. But those early struggles learning to articulate his perspective must seem distant now; if his latest album
column10: Pullin' Strings
column11: is not the best gangster rap album of 2014
column12: it's certainly the most evocatively written.

column1: A-Wax is an old soul
column2: a craftsman in a messy era of perpetual mindspray. He owes a debt to a longstanding—and long undervalued—lineage of hip-hop writers. This includes his immediate progenitors the Mob Figaz—a Pittsburg
column3: CA-based hip-hop crew that was among the most influential in the last decade of Bay Area hip-hop—and their influences
column4: including 2Pac
column5: C-Bo
column6: and Cormega. A-Wax has had beef with the Mob Figaz for years
column7: or it's at least surfaced online in bitter accusations. A-Wax claims he's the messenger for his friends behind the walls (ask any Bay Area head about the veracity of A-Wax's claims
column8: and you get the carefully reframed answer of an agnostic: ""He thinks they're true."") But regardless of the bridges burned
column9: A-Wax has developed his own highly personal
column10: principled style. While he has been damaged
column11: his eye for subjectively truthful prose has not.

column1: His conceptual focus on Pullin' Strings is loneliness. This isn't 27-problems-only-introverts-will-understand lonely or heartbroken lonely or last-man-on-earth sci-fi flick lonely—this is a much more exhaustive desolation. For A-Wax
column2: it is an occupational hazard forced by circumstance
column3: the consequences and paradoxes of a life lived illegally. This loneliness comes accompanied by paranoia and anxiety
column4: fatalism and regret
column5: each amplified by the life-or-death stakes of his (former?) profession. A-Wax's alienation isn't expressed as mere trite sadness
column6: but through the prism of realism: calloused nonchalance
column7: self-effacing humor
column8: virulent bitterness
column9: and profound melancholy
column10: sometimes all at once. Weariness permeates the album. The betrayals and double-crosses don't sting with surprise; they are inevitable
column11: and linger like a dull bruise.

column1: If a world populated with personalities is splashed in color
column2: Pullin' Strings compliments its bleak isolation by drawing in high-contrast black and white. Sometimes
column3: when the light hits just right
column4: the backdrop takes on a sunset tinge. The production is sleek
column5: stripped down
column6: and often subtly melodic; the dominant sound is one of wistful somnolence. Fuzzed guitars are sanded to a smooth surface and the focus is tight. The moments that vary from this mean are still spare. Even tracks that lean belligerent gain their power from their potential for aggression

Kevin Morby's a wanderer

column10: ruminative delivery keeps you hanging on his every word. Still Life is steeped in Dylan's back-to-basics period at the turn of the '70s

column13: slightly rickety
column14:
offhandedly gorgeous.

Morby's a judicious lyricist
column15: able to flesh out a scene with just a few carefully-chosen details. The situations on Still Life never quite seem to have a fixed beginning or end

column20: yet he only gets to number three on this nine-item rundown before he begins to repeat himself. But you come away from ""The Ballad of Arlo Jones"" learning just as much about the guy telling the story as you do its subject; Morby's impassioned wails of ""He was my friend!"" suggest a longing for connection
column21: no matter how temporary.

column1: The short
column2: spirited ""Motors Running""

column4: gives you almost nothing in terms of backstory: ""We had just gotten started

column9: but I've gotta keep moving. Throughout Still Life

column1: All this roving has Morby thinking long and hard about impermanence; if travel is Morby's favorite subject

there's an ocean of regret lingering in his throat.

The title Still Life is both a nod—to a piece by New York pop artist Maynard Monrow—and something of a joke: Morby recently pulled up roots in Brooklyn and became a full-time Los Angelino. Throughout Morby's many travels

Morby manages to say everything he needs.

It's probably time to stop measuring Jimmy Tamborello's work as Dntel against the meter of the Postal Service—not to mention Life Is Full of Possibilities
column4: the LA-based producer's breakout solo record and catalyst for his auspicious team up with Ben Gibbard. Certainly
column5: his subsequent output as Dntel reflects as much; 2007's Dumb Luck was an awkward shadow of Possibilities at best
column6: and five years later
column7: Aimlessness proved that Tamborello's interest in vocal-centric glitch-pop singles had all but given way to macro views of the drowsy electronics hiccuping inside them. His latest full-length continues to tread similar terrain while eschewing proper guest vocals altogether
column8: and yet tethers its central theme to an evident misnomer in its title
column9: Human Voice.

column1: It's unsurprising that this album's title is so literal: Dumb Luck was a direct reaction to Tamborello stumbling into a goldmine with the Postal Service
column2: and the connotations of Aimlessness served both the half-decade gap between releases and its music's meandering arrangements. So by that logic
column3: Human Voice plays like a purging of the titular baggage Dntel has carried in his arsenal since 2001—it's no coincidence that the first ""vocal"" sound we hear is from the chintzy Casio SK-1 preset which gives the album and opening track their name. There are no real voices until the third track
column4: when the piano-wrapped footwork experiments of ""If I Stay a Minute"" reach a faint crescendo
column5: and even then its all backwards half-syllables and sonorant incidentals. ""Foraya"" does the same thing with a slo-mo loop over skipping house beats and Dntel's typically twitchy
column6: twittering synth lines
column7: sounding not unlike an unfinished Give Up demo. There's not one actual lyric to be found on Human Voice's eight productions
column8: and that's totally fine.

column1: It could be assumed that Tamborello wrote an album of strictly instrumental electronic music as an attempt to reclaim Dntel's musical identity from that giddy
column2: over-fed elephant that follows him onto every release
column3: and for the most part he has. The tender pads and modest harmonies of ""Fringes of Focus (Instrumental)""  are unmistakably Dntel
column4: and the misty-eyed and circuit-bent closer ""Ashby"" is blissfully pure early aughts Clicks & Cuts fare with heavy emotional undertones
column5: which is essentially what Possibilities' non-vocal tracks were extrapolating from in 2001. Admittedly
column6: it seems strange to call Human Voice a return to form
column7: but ""Bay Loop"" reappropriating ""Suddenly Is Sooner Than You Think""'s simple harmonium notes couldn't sound any less accidental in the song's sparse
column8: bleary arrangement. By shedding the weight of his past accolades
column9: Tamborello's given himself enough space to return to the music of his less-remembered successes. Human Voice gently nudges him back into the spotlight to speak his mind alone
column10: and even if his voice isn't the most exciting and innovative one in today's electronic music landscape
column11:
it is unmistakably his own.
