Even after three decades of relentless touring and over twenty album cycles
column3: Melvins laugh in the face of that thing some call a ""break"". Last year
column4: Melvins celebrated their thirtieth anniversary as a band
column5: and they released two records to mark the date: the covers album Everybody Loves Sausages  and Tres Cabrones
column6: which revived the band’s original 1983 lineup
column7: including original drummer Mike Dillard (who had never appeared on a proper Melvins LP up until that point). Shortly thereafter
column8: the band covered Butthole Surfers’ “Graveyard"" while giving away free ice cream to a crowd of kids in Chicago’s Humboldt Park as part of the A.V. Club’s “Undercover” series. Strangely enough
column9: that puzzling performance provides more evidence of the band’s staying power than Everybody Loves Sausages and Tres Cabrones combined. To see beloved oddball frontman King Buzzo excitedly croak “Free ice cream!” and toss chilly freebies to eager children
column10: as his bandmates (including Butthole Surfers bassist JD Pinkus) continue to pierce eardrums
column11: is telling what it is about the Melvins that continues to amaze: their untainted devotion to chaos
column12: rooted in a perverse Peter Pan complex.

column1: Considering their filthy
column2: flippant reputation and their shared affinities for black humor and gleeful racket
column3: a Melvins/Butthole Surfers crossover comes as no real surprise. The collaboration didn’t stop with ice cream trucks
column4: either: Pinkus supported Melvins on their recent tour

column6: a musical merger between the two bands that amplifies the uncanniness of that Chicago one-off. It’s also one of the catchiest Melvins record to date

column8: sickeningly sweet melodies built upon the bedrock of both bands’ usual scuzzy styles.

column3: but the underlying idea is rather static: taking the grotesque and defanging it by way of caricature to fuse the catchy with the creepy. The choppy new-wave guitars of “Brass Cupcake” initially comes across as the Cars updated for the Torche set
column4: but when the chorus kicks in and Buzzo screams
column5: “Because they’ve got a lot of mouths to feed!/ And their noses and their mouths will bleed!”
column6: dragging out his “e”s like a Saturday morning cartoon villain
column7: it’s clear that the band haven’t lost their fascination with B-movie thrills. On similarly grizzled cuts like “Sesame Street Meat” and “The Bunk Up”
column8: bloodlust and carnality take on a cartoonish guise
column9: conveyed through stomping percussion and jagged fretwork but
column10: in the case of the latter
column11: disarmingly pleasant shoegazey non-sequiturs (the sonic equivalent
column12: perhaps
column13: of Osborne’s ice-cream-tossing interlude). At times
column14: though
column15: the disparity between sweet and sour toes the line between clever and cloying: “You Can Make Me Wait” debunks any oddball theories that a Melvins song featuring vocoder vocals in the place of down-tuned guitars could possibly be a good thing
column16: drifting along lethargically until Leary pushes it along with a triumphant solo that comes across as too little
column17: too late.

column2: the two musicians play by Melvins’ down-tuned
column3: down-strummed house rules

column6: rather than impositions. In this regard

column1: By the time the record’s second half rolls around

column4: proves myopic. After ""Sesame Street Meat""
column5: the album's gnarled touches lose their menace
column6: swept away by one-dimensional bluesy cuts and jam-session rambling that engulfs longer tracks like""The Bunk Up""and ""House of Gasoline"". So it goes with Melvins—they're the musical equivalent of that endearingly wacky uncle who <span>believe in ghosts

column8: and punk rock. They can be a bit one-note sometimes

column10:
the world of heavy music just wouldn't be as fun.

It's difficult explaining what it was like in 1991. The popular summary of ""The Year Punk Broke"" involves Nirvana's Nevermind dominating Top 40 radio and shifting the way people listened to music. This is definitely true on one level
column3: but there were plenty of music fans of a certain age and temperament who were already digging deeper than that
column4: and continued hearing things the same way after ""Smells Like Teen Spirit"" became a sensation.

column1: But
column2: still
column3: it was a strange time for people heavily invested in the underground
column4: a pre-internet moment when indie groups didn't appear on late night TV as regularly as they do now
column5: you never gave much thought to advertising or PR
column6: and you could walk up to someone wearing a Jesus Lizard T-shirt and know you'd have a lot in common. So
column7: even if you didn't pay much attention to Nirvana's ascension
column8: when punk did break
column9: previously small bands were swept up and placed in a context they were unfamiliar with until that moment; as a result
column10: more people were coming to shows
column11: wearing those shirts
column12: and muddying the waters.

column1: In this era
column2: the Oakland-via-New-York punk trio Jawbreaker
column3: fronted by the charismatic Blake Schwarzenbach
column4: were one of the bands you built romantic and platonic relationships around
column5: a group that
column6: at their height
column7: felt more important than more basic
column8: run-of-the-mill acts in your record collection. (They themselves felt
column9: oddly
column10: like family—or at least very close friends.) As far as the pervasive grunge narrative and their place in the post-1991 world
column11: they toured with Nirvana in October of 1993 shortly before releasing their third
column12: most beloved album
column13: 24 Hour Revenge Therapy. That tour and the album led to a million dollar record deal with DGC and their fourth and final record
column14: Dear You
column15: which they recorded with Dookie producer Rob Cavallo and released in September of 1995.

column1: People weren't into that major label record
column2: to put it mildly. My girlfriend at the time smashed the promotional cassette copy I gave her and walked away in disgust. People were shell-shocked at the glossier production: I honestly saw a man with a Jawbreaker tattoo weeping at the record store where I worked. Schwarzenbach had undergone surgery to remove a polyp from his vocal chords before recording 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
column3: but we thought that's why his gnarled vocals sounded cleaner on Dear You. It didn't matter to us that the polyp had been painful
column4: and maybe life threatening—we'd lost our voice as he regained his. Part of it was the times—the post-Nevermind label feeding frenzy hitting people who thought they were immune to it—and part of it was because
column5: really
column6: they were more than just a band to people: Jawbreaker articulated why you got into punk
column7: and once you did
column8: why you stayed there. Like the musical companions to the punk rock zine Cometbus
column9: their songs felt like how-to manuals
column10: as well as holy writ.

column1: The biggest issue
column2: though
column3: was that 24 Hour Revenge Therapy was a punk masterpiece. When listening to Dear You now
column4: with clearer ears
column5: it obviously has merit—in fact
column6: it's a very good record—but at the time
column7: it was following the group's most beloved collection and folks were depressed. (When you listen to the two in tandem in 2014
column8: the shift remains marked
column9: and 24 is the stronger
column10: more memorable collection
column11: but Dear You does feel like a logical next move.)

column1: If 24 Hour Revenge Therapy were a book
column2: it's the kind you'd carry around in your pocket. Jawbreaker recorded the bulk of it with Steve Albini
column3: and did three of its songs with Bivouac producer Billy Anderson (Sleep
column4: High on Fire
column5: Melvins). Bivouac
column6: which they'd released in 1992
column7: was more progressive overall
column8: as the band expanded to writing ambitiously huge
column9: heavy songs. On 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
column10: they reined things in and offered up simpler
column11: punkier tracks
column12: hearkening back to the sound of the 1990 debut Unfun.

column1: The 11 songs hit on multiple levels—as catchy pop-punk anthems
column2: as well as first-hand documentation of what it meant to be involved in that world at that time. 24 Hour Revenge Therapy draws a landscape of people hopping into trains and house parties
column3: kids with chipped teeth drinking too much coffee
column4: kissing on roofs
column5: and fucking in bathrooms: ""We hung our clothes up on the floor and put our faith in a closed door."" Schwarzenbach's mix of punk poetry (""You don't know what I'm all about/ Like killing cops and reading Kerouac"")
column6: earnest feelings (""We're too smart to watch TV/ We're too dumb to make believe this is all we want from life"")
column7: and real-life details (""Remember our life?/ I did the dishes while you read out loud"") won people over. As did the gruff
column8: shredded vocal delivery
column9: which came off like Paul Westerberg (or Psychedelic Furs' Richard Butler) tearing into Crass.

column1: It's hugely romantic stuff
column2: in all senses of the word. The album opens with a song from the point of view of a broken-down boat that will never see the ocean again
column3: then fixates on the number 13 (on ""Jinx Removing""
column4: Schwarzenbach refers to himself as ""a superstitious hyperrealist"") and on losing your voice and your love: ""Someone said your name/ I thought of you alone/ I was just the same 20 blocks away.""

column1: Basically
column2: Schwarzenbach wrote about being Blake Schwarzenbach
column3: warts and all. On ""Condition Oakland""
column4: he howls ""Climbed out onto my roof/ So I'd be a poet in the night"" and makes like Young Werther: ""This is my condition/ Desperate
column5: alone
column6: without an excuse/ I try to explain/ Christ
column7: what's the use?"" On ""Do You Still Hate Me?""
column8: he sets one of his crystal clear scenes—""I have a picture of you and me in Brooklyn/ On a porch
column9: it was raining/ Hey
column10: I remember that day... And I miss you""—followed by a series of questions: ""Are you out there?/ Do you hear me?/ Can I call you?/ Do you still hate me?"" In the land of 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
column11: nothing and nobody sticks around
column12: but that doesn't mean you forget.

column1: The songs people talked about most
column2: though
column3: were probably ""Boxcar"" and ""Indictment""
column4: which predicted the aftermath of Dear You. Both are extremely catchy
column5: and feel like parts of a whole. The snappy ""Indictment"" opens with self-incrimination (""I just wrote the dumbest song/ It's gonna be a sing along"")
column6: a prediction (""All our friends will clap and sing/ Our enemies will laugh and be pointing"")
column7: and Blake's own two cents (""It won't bother me""). He goes on: ""We could be the next group that you rob... It isn't who you know/ It's who you burn/ It means nothing/ Selling kids to other kids/ If you think we changed our tune
column8: I hope we did."" ""Indictment"" is tongue-in-cheek
column9: but there's a lot of truth to it. Schwarzenbach dug the knife in deeper with ""Boxcar""
column10: which opens with the classic lines
column11: ""You're not punk and I'm telling everyone/ Save your breath
column12: I never was one"" and the sing-a-long chorus he promised in a song earlier: ""I was passing out when you were passing out your rules/ One
column13: two
column14: three
column15: four/ Who's punk?/ What's the score?"" Again
column16: always asking questions.

column1: Though Schwarzenbach was the cult hero
column2: it wasn't all about him: bassist Chris Bauermeister and drummer Adam Pfahler combined with Blake's serrated voice and guitar perfectly
column3: creating songs that felt refined and raw
column4: precise and shaggy. This is the sort of music where drum fills and bass lines function as major hooks; where the tone remains as lodged in your head as the words.

column1: This 24 Hour Revenge Therapy reissue
column2: which is out on Pfahler's label
column3: includes bonuses: dirtier alternative takes of the album tracks ""The Boat Dreams From the Hill""
column4: ""Boxcar""
column5: ""Do You Still Hate Me?""
column6: ""Jinx""
column7: and the outtakes ""First Step"" and ""Friends Back East""
column8: which were included on the compilation Etc. All are interesting in providing context for the proper album
column9: and it's worth hearing the different versions of otherwise familiar songs—like waking up earlier than normal and seeing the sunlight hit your kitchen in a way you hadn't before.

column1: Mostly
column2: it's just interesting to return to this music. Jawbreaker were never actually called ""emo"" at the time
column3: at least not in my circles
column4: but have been lumped in with the genre more than 20 years later. It's curious to see how the sound's been picked up and softened by the bands that came after—there are echoes of it
column5: but nobody's nailed Jawbreaker's snarling mixture of tender and tough. Regardless of how it's framed or reframed
column6: or what people decide to retroactively tag it
column7: the music on 24 Hour Revenge Therapy offers some of the most indelible examples of punk music crammed with emotion. These are life-changing songs that
column8: a couple decades later
column9:
still give goosebumps.

Adam Bainbridge is a member of a group of voracious
column4: industrious artists—among them Devonté Hynes
column5: Solange
column6: Sky Ferreira
column7: and Kelela—who consider themselves ""pop."" It's a group that values collaboration
column8: guesting on one another's albums and who
column9: increasingly
column10: are dipping their toes into popular music as producers and writers. “You’ll never guess who I just worked with
column11: ” is
column12: these days
column13: a popular volley between Bainbridge and his former flat-mate Hynes
column14: both now in-demand collaborators for more traditionally popular artists. They value the word ""pop
column15: presumably
column16: not because they want to be judged against current popular music but because defining yourself as a pop artist means never having to say you're sorry: you can work in whatever idiom you want
column17: with whoever you want
column18: in whatever manner. There's a freedom to pop music not availed to anyone who defines themselves as an indie rocker
column19: or a punk
column20: or a soul singer.

column1: One of the chief curiosities of Otherness
column2: Bainbridge's second album as Kindness
column3: is trying to understand what this freedom means in the context of his careful
column4: quiet compositions. Bainbridge's music sounds nothing like the current maximalist strain of popular music
column5: and it sounds only a little like certains kinds of popular music from decades past. It's more deliberate and varied than Bainbridge's debut album
column6: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16576-world-you-need-a-change-of-mind/""><i>World
column7: You Need a Change of Mind
column8: a pleasant indie-disco record lacking in ambition.

column1: Bainbridge aims higher on Otherness
column2: setting his sights on pristine studio gems. He expands his arrangements
column3: enlists collaborators (Hynes and Kelela chief among them)
column4: and dispenses with the cover songs that buoyed World. Bainbridge constructs his tracks largely with piano
column5: horns
column6: and bass
column7: free of guitar. His lyrical currency is that most pop of topics: love lost and found. On Otherness
column8: Bainbridge is a descendent of artists like Peter Gabriel
column9: Sting
column10: and Bryan Ferry: self-serious rogues who whipped the undomesticated wilds of jazz
column11: disco
column12: and R&B into digestible platters. Such is the M.O. of Otherness: throw everything at the wall
column13: very tastefully.

column1: Bainbridge is a standout producer
column2: and Otherness crackles with crisp filigrees and luxe baubles. The soft-pedaled funk of tracks like ""Why Don't You Love Me"" and ""With You"" show lovely restraint
column3: while welterweight breaks and brisk hi-hats keep ""World Restart"" and ""This Is Not About Us"" from blanching. ""I'll Be Back"" is a lavish
column4: slo-mo house lullaby. There is a rare clarity and fidelity to Otherness' arrangements.

column1: But
column2: beautiful as they are
column3: no one inhabits them. The only source of tension on Otherness is the disconnect between the album's sumptuous vistas and the dull songwriting that roams them. Otherness burdens its precision with unimaginative melodies and plodding tempos (""For the Young""
column4: ""It'll Be Ok""). Bainbridge moans wanly during ""8th Wonder"" (""I'm thinking about my baby now/ Yeah"") before interrupting the track with a jarring guest verse (during which M.anifest shouts out Tracy Chapman's ""Fast Car""
column5: lest you have any doubts about Otherness' smothering sincerity).

column1: Bainbridge
column2: doleful and even keeled on World
column3: opens up his voice here but proves too thin and affectless for the kind of soulful interjections he wishes upon ""This Is Not About Us"" and ""I'll Be Back"". When Robyn takes lead on the jaunty ""Who Do You Love?"" the effect is like removing your earplugs at a concert
column4: exposing yourself to an almost violent level of detail.

column1: Most irksome is ""Geneva""
column2: a musty
column3: choral ballad that consists largely of one line—""If you could read my mind/ You know what you'd find""—repeated mantra-like through the song
column4: something that initially scans as quiet reflection but quickly reveals itself to be gibberish (seriously: if you could read his mind—but you can't—you wouldn't even need to read his mind). ""Geneva""
column5: one trifle repeated ad nauseam
column6: is nearly six minutes long. Otherness is full of moments like this
column7: drawn-out tiltings at romantic windmills that too often resolve themselves in near parody. When Hynes and Tawiah trade deep questions on ""Why Don't You Love Me""
column8: they sound less like star-crossed lovers and more like two very confused people quixotically locked in song. ""With You"" features two sultry saxophone solos that mostly smack of The Simpsons and Bill Clinton.

column1: Pop music has plenty of tolerance for vapidity and emptiness
column2: but you've got to be able to sell it. Look no further than Hynes' ""It Is What It Is"" if you want an example of a banality contorted into substance. You wonder if Bainbridge recognizes that something's missing: ""Making pop music that’s less immediate than other engineered pop
column3: sometimes you need a helping hand that explains where it’s coming from or the emotional universe it lives in."" Maybe Otherness' emotional universe requires context
column4: but who other than Bainbridge would provide it? Otherness isn't just less immediate than other pop music; it's less self-aware
column5:
and way less fun.

More than a few eyebrows were raised last year when Bloc Party lead singer Kele Okereke released a two-track EP of functional dance music
column4: Heartbreaker
column5: on London club-house institution Crosstown Rebels. On the surface level Okereke’s stepping out as a dance producer was curious; it's not every day one of the more visible faces of 2000s UK indie steps behind the boards and starts churning out honest-to-God dance music on an honest-to-God dance label. But when it comes to explaining their existence alone
column6: Heartbreaker and this year’s Crosstown-released Candy Flip EP make more sense when situated in what Okereke’s been up to over the last six years. Bloc Party’s 2008 effort
column7: Intimacy
column8: flirted with dancey textures to varied effect; two years later
column9: Okereke stepped out on his own with proper solo debut The Boxer
column10: a grab-baggy collection of aggressive dance-rock that
column11: at points
column12: presaged the stomping fare that Skrillex and other American dubstep auteurs would popularize a few years later.

column1: The Boxer wasn’t a very good album
column2: but it was a hell of a lot better than Bloc Party’s defeated-sounding fourth record
column3: the 2012 effort Four. A brittle
column4: dry rock record that sounded as if the guys who made the youthful
column5: comparatively bright Silent Alarm seven years previous were battling a wicked hangover
column6: Four made the breakup rumors that surrounded Bloc Party at the time sound appealing. It also suggested that
column7: at least for the time being
column8: Okereke had fallen out of love with rock music
column9: an assumption bolstered by his second solo album
column10: Trick. The record represents an even more headlong dive into dance music than The Boxer
column11: with a decidedly different tone: Okereke’s swapped aggression for subtlety
column12: embracing the type of lush
column13: seedy big-room house music that
column14: fittingly
column15: Crosstown Rebels has made its name on.

column1: Trick is
column2: by far
column3: the most listenable and
column4: at points
column5: enjoyable music Okereke’s made this decade. Rock musicians dipping their toes into electronic waters isn’t new
column6: but rarely do they make the transition sound effortless
column7: and even more rare is the musician who can capably turn out stuff that sounds like it’s been blessed by the scene’s fixtures. That Okereke can claim success on both levels is
column8: in itself
column9: a small victory; compositionally
column10: the ten tunes are sound and smooth
column11: and if they were played for a listener under the false guise that Okereke simply contributed vocals to an established producer’s tracks
column12: that listener would be none the wiser.

column1: That said
column2: the mode of dance music Okereke is working in on Trick is one frequently criticized by both dance aesthetes and genre newcomers as sounding faceless
column3: and so it follows that Trick is nice with atmosphere
column4: but largely a non-entity when it comes to hooks. The few memorable hooks it has
column5: too
column6: are unfortunately the album’s weaker points: “Year Zero”’s insistent
column7: whining chorus isn’t made better by Okereke’s somewhat cringe-worthy lyrics. Okereke’s vocals have long possessed a stridency that worked well in the context of Bloc Party’s spiky
column8: stylish post-post-punk
column9: and when he breaks into the upper register in more subdued environs like the soft clicking thump of “My Hotel Room”
column10: the effect is grating. There are moments of vocal subtlety as well
column11: though
column12: that fare much better: dusky closer “Stay the Night” radiates sensuality
column13: Okereke’s upper register taking on a tone that’s a few shades darker to match his surroundings.

column1: Trick is a curious solo album because Okereke is more than content to take the backseat on his own tracks. Yasmin Shahmir
column2: who’s previously collaborated with post-Disclosure UK house-pop duo Gorgon City
column3: laces the percolating opener “First Impressions” gracefully
column4: while vocalist Jodie Scantlebury takes the lead on the wistful
column5: winding “Closer”
column6: one of a few highlights and a tune possessing a chorus that smacks of something Todd Terry might have come up with in the early 90s. These inspired collaborations
column7: along with more textural moments like the snappy diva shouts embedded in “Silver and Gold”
column8: suggest that Okereke’s a capable
column9: considerate producer that
column10: next time around
column11:
might do even better with more time behind the boards and less in front of a microphone.

In a curious case of happenstance
column2: right as Aphex Twin resurfaces for the first time in a decade with Syro
column3: two of the most crucial pieces of the Drexciya puzzle also reappear on shop shelves. Out of print for some 15 and 13 years respectively
column4: Drexciya’s first full-length album statement Neptune’s Lair and Transllusion’s debut The Opening of the Cerebral Gate have finally been re-pressed
column5: the latter with bonus tracks never before available on vinyl. On the surface
column6: there seems little to connect these early '90s contemporaries—that is
column7: the British cult-of-personality producer and two of the most obscure electronic music makers to ever call Detroit home. But the two acts shared labels
column8: and it’s almost impossible to imagine the idiosyncratic music of Richard D. James without the insular yet profound example of Drexciya.

column1: Masked and anonymous up until the death of James Stinson in September of 2002 from heart complications that signaled the end of the group
column2: the duo of Stinson and Gerald Donald left behind a staggering yet fragmented body of work. The group only released three full-lengths (with both Harnessed the Storm and Grava 4 being released in the months before Stinson’s death)
column3: Drexciya’s decade-long run of singles and EPs were singular in electronic music
column4: connecting the likes of Detroit’s Underground Resistance to European imprints like Clone and Tresor.

column1: They also presented a unified vision spanning across those singles and albums
column2: a world of sound that soundtracked a dystopian future while paying tribute to forefathers like George Clinton
column3: the Jonzun Crew
column4: Cybotron
column5: and of course Kraftwerk (see “Aquabahn”). While the excellent Clone series Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller painstakingly compiled and presented four volumes of Drexciyan music
column6: they never quite put together the backstory of the group. Nevermind that they grew up landlocked in Detroit—Donald and Stinson created a warped water world peopled with Darthouven fish men
column7: Stingray battalions
column8: and Lardossan cruisers shaped like giant squids.

column1: And how did such fish men wind up 20
column2: 000 leagues under the sea? Why
column3: via pregnant African women thrown overboard during the Middle Passage of course
column4: as brutal a creation story as any in modern music. Couched in such real-world horror is a layer of science fiction queasiness
column5: like touching fish flesh. As an early comp's liner notes described: “Are Drexciyans water-breathing aquatically mutated descendants of those unfortunate victims of human greed? Recent experiments have shown a premature human infant saved from certain death by breathing liquid oxygen through its underdeveloped lungs.”

column1: Drexciya’s bleak outlook was matched by a brutal strain of electro
column2: acid
column3: and techno across those initial 12”s. But what makes Neptune’s Lair and Stinson’s own The Opening of the Cerebral Gate great portals into that waterworld is that Neptune's 21 tracks temper those bludgeoning machinistic beats with other sounds: evocative acid tracks that take you deep inside your own mind
column4: spasmodic electro sprints
column5: strange interludes
column6: and the sort of off-kilter melodic bits that Aphex Twin would soon make his own.

column1: Monk chants and weird voices uttering “Drexciya” give way to the bubbly “Species of the Pod” that leads into the exquisite waterlogged funk of “Habitat 'O' Negative”
column2: “Bottom Feeders”
column3: and “Surface Terrestrial Colonization”. In contrast to the harder tracks that defined their '90s output
column4: the keys and 303s are nudged down from “incapacitate” to “intoxicate.” Even beatless sketches like “Draining of the Tanks”
column5: “Quantum Hydrodynamics”
column6: and closer “C to the Power of X + C to the Power of X = MM = Unknown” offer kaleidoscopic synth washes
column7: nuanced and textured like fragments of shells and sea glass made smooth in the tide.

column1: Even Stinson’s The Opening of the Cerebral Gate offers up a slightly more moderate variation on the Drexciyan template. “Transmission of Life” is built on a furious throb and submarine alarms and the unreal squalls of “Cerebral Cortex Malfunction” sound exactly like its title suggests
column2: but elsewhere Stinson tempers such overdriven tendencies. There’s the flickering keyboards that glide across the electro pulse of “Walking With Clouds”
column3: being at once heavyweight and effervescent. Other standouts like “Do You Want to Get Down?” and “Unordinary Realities” hint at the more downtempo direction he would explore as the Other People Place on the long out-of-print 2001 classic Lifestyles of the Laptop Cafe.

column1: What strikes me about revisiting Stinson’s music a decade-plus after his passing—despite clear antecedents in electro and acid—is how singular his vision was. Struggling with health issues as he finalized Drexciya and other solo projects
column2: the anger and bleak outlook of their earliest output gives way to acceptance and a sense of the sublime. What better way to convey the sense that life is but a dream than to coin an artist name like Transllusion
column3: a play on both ""translucent"" and ""illusion""? That such a sense of humanity can be conveyed via the programming of machines until they begin to sing speaks to Stinson’s genius. In much the same way that—after a decade of near silence—Syro reminds me that rather than the innovative aspect of Aphex Twin’s music
column4: what makes it stand the test of time is its irreducible sense of individuality
column5: it remains the same for Stinson and Donald
column6: and the music they made as Drexciya will endure
column7:
even if everything else gets submerged in the rising oceans.

column7: the British cult-of-personality producer and two of the most obscure electronic music makers to ever call Detroit home. But the two acts shared labels
column8: and it’s almost impossible to imagine the idiosyncratic music of Richard D. James without the insular yet profound example of Drexciya.

column1: Masked and anonymous up until the death of James Stinson in September of 2002 from heart complications that signaled the end of the group
column2: the duo of Stinson and Gerald Donald left behind a staggering yet fragmented body of work. The group only released three full-lengths (with both Harnessed the Storm and Grava 4 being released in the months before Stinson’s death)
column3: Drexciya’s decade-long run of singles and EPs were singular in electronic music
column4: connecting the likes of Detroit’s Underground Resistance to European imprints like Clone and Tresor.

column1: They also presented a unified vision spanning across those singles and albums
column2: a world of sound that soundtracked a dystopian future while paying tribute to forefathers like George Clinton
column3: the Jonzun Crew
column4: Cybotron
column5: and of course Kraftwerk (see “Aquabahn”). While the excellent Clone series Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller painstakingly compiled and presented four volumes of Drexciyan music
column6: they never quite put together the backstory of the group. Nevermind that they grew up landlocked in Detroit—Donald and Stinson created a warped water world peopled with Darthouven fish men
column7: Stingray battalions
column8: and Lardossan cruisers shaped like giant squids.

column1: And how did such fish men wind up 20
column2: 000 leagues under the sea? Why
column3: via pregnant African women thrown overboard during the Middle Passage of course
column4: as brutal a creation story as any in modern music. Couched in such real-world horror is a layer of science fiction queasiness
column5: like touching fish flesh. As an early comp's liner notes described: “Are Drexciyans water-breathing aquatically mutated descendants of those unfortunate victims of human greed? Recent experiments have shown a premature human infant saved from certain death by breathing liquid oxygen through its underdeveloped lungs.”

column1: Drexciya’s bleak outlook was matched by a brutal strain of electro
column2: acid
column3: and techno across those initial 12”s. But what makes Neptune’s Lair and Stinson’s own The Opening of the Cerebral Gate great portals into that waterworld is that Neptune's 21 tracks temper those bludgeoning machinistic beats with other sounds: evocative acid tracks that take you deep inside your own mind
column4: spasmodic electro sprints
column5: strange interludes
column6: and the sort of off-kilter melodic bits that Aphex Twin would soon make his own.

column1: Monk chants and weird voices uttering “Drexciya” give way to the bubbly “Species of the Pod” that leads into the exquisite waterlogged funk of “Habitat 'O' Negative”
column2: “Bottom Feeders”
column3: and “Surface Terrestrial Colonization”. In contrast to the harder tracks that defined their '90s output
column4: the keys and 303s are nudged down from “incapacitate” to “intoxicate.” Even beatless sketches like “Draining of the Tanks”
column5: “Quantum Hydrodynamics”
column6: and closer “C to the Power of X + C to the Power of X = MM = Unknown” offer kaleidoscopic synth washes
column7: nuanced and textured like fragments of shells and sea glass made smooth in the tide.

column1: Even Stinson’s The Opening of the Cerebral Gate offers up a slightly more moderate variation on the Drexciyan template. “Transmission of Life” is built on a furious throb and submarine alarms and the unreal squalls of “Cerebral Cortex Malfunction” sound exactly like its title suggests
column2: but elsewhere Stinson tempers such overdriven tendencies. There’s the flickering keyboards that glide across the electro pulse of “Walking With Clouds”
column3: being at once heavyweight and effervescent. Other standouts like “Do You Want to Get Down?” and “Unordinary Realities” hint at the more downtempo direction he would explore as the Other People Place on the long out-of-print 2001 classic Lifestyles of the Laptop Cafe.

column1: What strikes me about revisiting Stinson’s music a decade-plus after his passing—despite clear antecedents in electro and acid—is how singular his vision was. Struggling with health issues as he finalized Drexciya and other solo projects
column2: the anger and bleak outlook of their earliest output gives way to acceptance and a sense of the sublime. What better way to convey the sense that life is but a dream than to coin an artist name like Transllusion
column3: a play on both ""translucent"" and ""illusion""? That such a sense of humanity can be conveyed via the programming of machines until they begin to sing speaks to Stinson’s genius. In much the same way that—after a decade of near silence—Syro reminds me that rather than the innovative aspect of Aphex Twin’s music
column4: what makes it stand the test of time is its irreducible sense of individuality
column5: it remains the same for Stinson and Donald
column6: and the music they made as Drexciya will endure
column7:
even if everything else gets submerged in the rising oceans.

Wayne McGregor has great taste in ambient music. I saw his piece FAR a couple years ago
column3: and hearing Ben Frost's delicate yet concussive score
column4: then unreleased
column5: was as rich a part of the experience as watching the dance. McGregor has also commissioned music from the likes of Max Richter (Sum and Infra) and Ólafur Arnalds (Dyad 1909)
column6: and you can add to that list A Winged Victory for the Sullen

column1: If Stars of the Lid's music sounds like a hollowed-out 100-piece ensemble with ether for its innards
column2: AWVFTS is the opposite. Made from strings
column3: piano
column4: the occasional horn
column5: and electric guitars processed into ambient washes and scrawls
column6: it's all inner voices coiled together
column7: more classical than drone. The music is recorded in large spaces

column1: McGregor choreographs for a leading modern company
column2: London's Royal Ballet
column3: and
column4: occasionally
column5: Thom Yorke. Rather than making his experimental work challenging and his traditional work beautiful

column9: making ATOMOS louder and more mobile than its impeccably tentative predecessor—more volatile and disjointed

column1: If the first album was basically slow-moving

column5: is reshaped in accord with influential dance scorers Gavin Bryars and David Tudor. Slabs of hard
column6: bright organ-like tones arc powerfully over dark crags of bass. Strings twist in relentless screw-like figures or creep forward in inexorably widening harmonies. Electronic guitar tones are more pronounced
column7: forming rhythmic throughlines and pulses. Forbidding abstract landscapes rise up into plangent songs
column8: sub-frequencies crumbling apart beneath them.

column1: The best tracks
column2: such as ""I"" and ""VI""
column3: wrangle these maneuvers into an anxious
column4: dynamic
column5: almost symphonic sweep. All the song titles are Roman numerals—too bad
column6: as it deprives us of the duo's unusually self-mocking song titles. Grandiose ambient musicians are not known for their sense of humor
column7: so titles such as ""Steep Hills of Vicodin Tears""
column8: ""Requiem for the Static King"" and
column9: best of all
column10: ""We Played Some Open Chords"" (they did!) were refreshing. But there's still something curious about this tracklist. There is no ""IV"". What went wrong? I like to imagine that one day this lost track will surface

it brings a touch of mystery to a far better than average dance score that refines rather than suppresses the musical identity of its creators. Who will Wayne McGregor call on next? Tim Hecker's phone has got to be about to ring.

Around this time last year
column2: Margaret Chardiet almost died. Days before the noise artist was supposed to go on her first European tour
column3: doctors discovered a cyst so large it almost brought on organ failure. The subsequent surgery and healing process was long and intense. During the weeks of bed rest
column4: a dying man lay next to her in the hospital
column5: crying out for his daughter to join his side. For whatever reason
column6: she never showed up.

column1: In the rearview
column2: Chardiet’s situation sounds like hell
column3: and so does her latest album as Pharmakon
column4: Bestial Burden. In a recent interview with Pitchfork
column5: she described the theme of her second LP for Brooklyn-based label Sacred Bones as “[a] desire to show the body as a lump of flesh and cells that mutate and fail you and betray you—this very banal
column6: unimportant
column7: grotesque aspect of ourselves.” It’s a grim focus on the corporeal
column8: a lens that Chardiet has projected her nightmarish music through before; on last year’s Abandon
column9: the roaring final track was gruesomely titled “Crawling on Bruised Knees”
column10: the cover art a shot of Chardiet’s lower torso covered in maggots. On the cover of Bestial Burden
column11: she literally turns the inside outwards
column12: with grisly-looking butcher’s-shop organs placed accordingly on her upper torso and chicken talons glued to her fingers.

column1: Musically
column2: Bestial Burden is a considerable step forwards for Chardiet
column3: a feat that’s more impressive when considering that the genre she works in doesn’t necessarily call for artistic growth. Before releasing Abandon
column4: Chardiet established her presence with a run of small-press releases similar to many noise musicians past and present
column5: so that record wasn’t so much her debut as it was an introduction to a somewhat wider audience. If the depth-charge blasts of Abandon showcased an exciting emerging voice in experimental music
column6: Bestial Burden elevates Chardiet to an even more accomplished plane. The sense of control that she wields over this nasty
column7: fire-breathing music—a push-and-push-harder tension between pummeling rhythms
column8: swaths of power-electronics static
column9: and her impressive
column10: chilling howl—provides a sense of structure that makes this very out-there music easy to grasp for those outside of noise music circles.

column1: Still
column2: chaos reigns on Bestial Burden
column3: an album that sounds like anything but a safe space to inhabit. Chardiet’s steadier focus on rhythm provides a sound structure nonetheless annihilated by jet-engine roars
column4: bursts of mechanical heat
column5: and ear-bleeding screeches. Paradoxically
column6: the harshest and most alienating moments on Bestial Burden arrive when the record is at its quietest: album opener “Vacuum” practically serves as a portal into the record’s landscape
column7: as Chardiet’s vocal hyperventilation is backed by a undulating fuzzy drone that rubs against the ears like a drill to the teeth. “Primitive Struggle” lays wet
column8: heaving coughs over a heartbeat-like rhythm that eventually grows to an insistent thud
column9: bleeding beautifully into the death-march stomp of “Autoimmune”. By turning the human body’s failures into rhythmic tools at her disposal
column10: Chardiet has created the truest form of body horror.

column1: Fittingly
column2: her voice is the album's most expressive instrument
column3: at times recalling black metal’s pitchless burn. While her vocal approach on Abandon came across as sprawling and freeform in its presentation
column4: Chardiet takes the shape of a menacing furnace on Bestial Burden
column5: giving off blasts of heat and steam that are deeply felt even as they recede into the darkness. In the aforementioned interview
column6: Chardiet groused about the reception her difficult music receives: “When I put that out to someone and the only thing they can say is
column7: ‘Oh look
column8: it’s a girl screaming
column9: ’ I want to fucking kill them because I’m literally pouring my heart and soul out
column10: being so vulnerable.” On Bestial Burden
column11: her voice casts jagged
column12: threatening shadows
column13: but on a record that concerns itself with bodily disintegration
column14: Chardiet’s forcefulness is a necessary human constant.

column1: Her most surprising performance arrives on the album’s closing title track
column2: seven minutes of pulsing tones that culminates in tangled noise and mutated vocal strangulation. Before “Bestial Burden”’s satisfyingly destructive conclusion
column3: though
column4: Chardiet expresses herself in a way that stands apart from the rest of the six-track record; her voice sways and swerves with disorienting clarity
column5: sounding almost psychedelic with every half-spoken dispatch. Chardiet has played it straight previously when it comes to her vocals—her cover of “Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)”
column6: featured on Sacred Bones’ 2013 compilation Todo Muere Vol 4
column7: was surprisingly faithful to the original—but the wavy
column8: near-meditative form of “Bestial Burden” is
column9: at least for those who just arrived to the Pharmakon party a year ago
column10: unexplored territory. As a whole
column11: Bestial Burden highlights Chardiet’s ability to re-draw the boundaries of her own artistic approach
column12:
ripping out its guts and creating something new out of the decaying remains.

The release of Nirvana’s Nevermind in 1991 might have marked the death of grunge for those already in the know
column2: but it also sparked a chaotic rush from major label A&Rs to find the next big thing out of Seattle. Which meant…what exactly? It meant we got Candlebox and Seven Mary Three. It meant that Nevermind made a lot of people a lot of money
column3: and that needed to happen again
column4: and then more times after that too.

column1: Imagine being in a band in the Northwest then. Hoping to maybe do it full time so you don’t have to work your shitty job and can go on tour without feeling bad about leaving your life and any semblance of financial security behind. Then imagine some A&R rep coming to your town
column2: because it’s the Northwest
column3: and because you’re in a band with guitars and maybe those guitars have the right amount of fuzz on them so that
column4: if that A&R rep wants to pretend hard enough
column5: maybe you could be as successful as Nirvana. That was either exactly what you wanted
column6: or completely terrifying.

column1: I’m not claiming that Olympia-based Unwound (they were technically from the neighboring
column2: less hip town of Tumwater
column3: but one kind of bleeds into the other anyway) were ever going to be as big as Nirvana. No one could possibly think that. Nor do they seem like the kind band that would particularly enjoy overbearing major label interference. It’s more about what they did with what they had. If you’re part of a specific subset of music listener
column4: they are the pinnacle of a very specific type of insular rock music that is rigid and forward thinking and pushes boundaries even as it works within the system those boundaries have created.

column1: But every cult-favorite gets their due
column2: so here we are
column3: three box sets into Numero Group’s tireless retrospective. Knowing what we know now
column4: No Energy—which covers 1995’s The Future of What and 1996’s career-defining Repetition
column5: as well as an assortment of live cuts and B-sides from the era—is the buildup before the band’s swan song
column6: Leaves Turn Inside You
column7: a double album that touched on post-rock and modern classical and just about every other genre (including some that maybe were invented on that record) with all the autumnal verve of a group of musicians that seemed to suddenly realize they had been stockpiling so much constrained emotion for so long
column8: that all they could do was release it and then quit working together.

column1: No Energy is essential even without that information. Listening to these box sets in order (don’t do it all at once)
column2: Unwound’s growth is clear: they moved from scrappy punk band with interesting ideas to a musically precise machine
column3: harnessing feedback squalls
column4: goopy drums
column5: and guitars that sounded like they were repeatedly bashed against a brick wall
column6: in an effort to approach dark transcendental bliss through repetition and coiled tension.

column1: In the liner notes for No Energy
column2: drummer Sara Lund writes
column3: “We learned to communicate absolutely with our instruments
column4: and while we were playing together
column5: all personal tensions were erased. This band played with intention
column6: never intending anything specific beyond honest expression.” If you think about Unwound from this angle
column7: the band is cast in a spiritual light
column8: and it makes sense. So much of the music here
column9: from “Natural Disasters” to “Disappoint” to the fuzzed out tonal scrape of “Vern’s Answer to the Masses”
column10: is head-spinning and angry
column11: but very deeply so. Like Lund
column12: bassist Vern Rumsey
column13: and guitarist/singer Justin Trosper had made peace with whatever was roiling inside them by obsessively pushing it outward.

column1: You can hear it on “Corpse Pose”
column2: presented here in two forms
column3: and as close to a signature Unwound song as you’re going to get. A walking bassline is almost immediately cut through with stabs of guitar that sound like what would happen if grunge quit aiming for cheesy guitar solos and played around with post-punk’s empty space. On its own
column4: “Corpse Pose” makes a case for Repetition as the definitive Unwound album
column5: but that doesn’t mean it eclipses the other gems to be found on the second half of this set: “Lowest Common Denominator” lurches and sways
column6: with Trosper singing in a deadpan that leans toward simmering rage
column7: and “For Your Entertainment” is basically a preview of the Unwound that would come later: Trosper’s voice oscillates between a blocky scream and an elliptical monotone.

column1: The Unwound we hear on No Energy is a prime version of the band. They’re still straddling their punk roots and their experimental side with ease: dipping into dub on the soft
column2: completely bizarre-in-this-context “Sensible”
column3: playing with time signatures on the hectic “Murder Movies”. The songs here careen. This is the sound of a band that has no interest in saving any of their ideas for later
column4: or calming down to think about what they’re doing. Amidst all the sonic density
column5: there’s an audible joy of creation
column6: even in retrospect
column7: knowing that they would soon fall apart. Lund backs this up in the liner notes
column8: writing that as the band’s “personal bonds dissipated
column9: the music only got stronger.” She also mentions that communication was never their strong suit
column10: which is key to understanding how this band worked so well
column11: and also how it eventually stopped working.

column1: The one constant through every Unwound album is that the trio
column2: and assorted contributors
column3: worked with a set of unspoken
column4: nearly primal rules: feedback dissolves into nothing and riffs repeat hypnotically to the point that they sound like they’re about to crust over and splinter. Trosper
column5: Lund
column6: and Rumsey made music almost telepathically—they wrote on impulse and without pretension. They’re unique because they did this with so much control. Every note here sounds carefully considered
column7: and just as carefully
column8: every idea is left hanging before it can fully be seen through. There is no payoff except the lack of payoff. Once you accept that
column9: their music becomes meditative.

column1: Unwound are complicated enough to stay a cult favorite forever
column2: but Numero’s reissue campaign goes a long way to placing them in the context they deserve. Listening now
column3: they are still the kind of band that you can cherish deeply. They were so good at expressing alienation and discontent
column4:
that loving them said something about the way your brain worked and where you were willing to let your thoughts go. Nothing’s changed.

Kevin Drumm has been known to wield an iron fist on his recordings—records like Sheer Hellish Miasma
column4: <i>Impish Tyrant
column5: and Electronic Harassment are titled that way for a reason—but Trouble may punish you in different
column6: and sneakier
column7: ways. This is the quietest record I've heard since Bernhard Günter and Francisco Lopez's hushed microsound works from the turn of the millennium. It is so quiet that you'll need to turn the volume up very
column8: very loud to hear it well
column9: or indeed
column10: at all. In my case
column11: that involves several steps—one volume control on the laptop
column12: one on the audio interface
column13: and one on the DJ mixer that it all runs through on the way to a pair of studio monitors—as well as closing the window in order to shield Drumm's filament-like drones from the rumble of traffic outside. Suffice to say
column14: this is an album that requires some effort
column15: and part of that effort might involve just sitting still.

column1: I thought I might get some multi-tasking done—file maintenance
column2: email cleanup
column3: general absent-minded mousing around—while I sat and zoned out to a first run-through of what might be the Chicago noise musician's most ethereal recording since 2009's Imperial Horizon. But I had forgotten about the computer's default alert sounds
column4: and when I went to delete a document
column5: I was startled by the noise that suddenly tore through my speakers—a sound like boots crunching through snow
column6: almost painfully loud. The sound
column7: of course
column8: came not from Drumm's Worse than Burning Offal studios
column9: but from a lab in Cupertino. But it was tempting to imagine that moment of sonic violence as a part of the piece
column10: in a way. Kevin Drumm wants your full attention
column11: and he has mastered Trouble in such a way to practically guarantee it.

column1: Another
column2: perhaps better
column3: option is just to leave the album on in the background at a natural
column4: almost inaudible volume
column5: and let it sink in like incense. That's the same line of thinking behind Imperial Horizon's lone
column6: hour-long track ""Just Lay Down and Forget It""
column7: presumably. I can think of few passive listens that might be less taxing than this shimmering
column8: 54-minute piece
column9: divided into two halves and separated by a minute or two of actual
column10: total silence. As far as wallpaper music goes
column11: Brian Eno's Music for Airports scans as a clash of gaudy op-art prints compared to Drumm's almost invisible layer of atmosphere. Still
column12: per the title
column13: Drumm's disappearing act amounts to a kind of uneasy listening
column14: even at an almost imperceptible volume. This is the sound of fingertips slowly tracing crystal rims; of whale song heard from the opposite end of the ocean; of ghost trains braking in the dead of night. It is the sound of mountains slumping and mist settling. Its deathless peal is a dead ringer for the music of the spheres—all that friction
column15: all that reverb
column16: nothing but shivering frequencies
column17: from here to the ends of the known universe. It's the ghostly microwaves of cosmic background radiation.

column1: Despite Drumm's noisy reputation
column2: his music can be overwhelmingly sensual even at its loudest. Sheer Hellish Miasma's ""Hitting the Pavement""
column3: for instance
column4: is a full-body rubdown of distortion—part airplane engine
column5: part power sander
column6: yet still
column7: above all
column8: a welcoming embrace. And that goes a thousand-fold for the sublime Trouble
column9: an album that invites you to dive into its clutches with the promise of never hitting bottom. The noise floor is a very
column10:
very long way down.

The essence of Allo Darlin’s erudite
column3: sincere pop music is contained in the pronunciation of “Jägermeister"" that takes place just a few seconds into the record
column4: a wrangling that stuffs the word into a rhyme with “Spanish bar”: it’s a little goofy
column5: sure
column6: but it’s unabashed
column7: contributes to your sense of character and place
column8: and even feels a little bold in its own way. (You really need to commit to pronouncing a word like that.) Those are all qualities that end up characterizing the band’s third record
column9: We Come From the Same Place. Formed by a group of Australian expats in London around the turn of the decade
column10: the band began their career with two strong records chock-full of quirky
column11: culturally savvy songs
column12: flecked by lead singer Elizabeth Morris’ ukulele and her various passions: Johnny Cash
column13: Silver Jews
column14: “Woody Allen”. And while the band has some obvious sonic antecedents—the bookish
column15: thickly accented pop of groups like Belle and Sebastian and Camera Obscura
column16: the finely detailed English scenes of the Clientele—those records were proof positive that the potential for pastiche can always be transcended by quality songwriting.

column1: The band’s logistics have become significantly more complicated since the release of the 2012 sophomore effort Europe: Morris got married and left London for Florence
column2: a change that specifically impacted the composition of the album’s last three songs. The transitional period served as excellent songwriting fodder for a band that’s taken with the concept of change
column3: whether it’s in regards to time
column4: location
column5: or relationship status. They excel at finding glory and drama in transitional periods where characters’ perspectives begin to shift and warp

column1: Morris has a great touch when working with scene setting and small pieces of imagery—a row of crappy student bars on the rollicking “Kings and Queens”
column2: a foreign cityscape at night on “Santa Maria Novella”—which makes the album feel fully inhabited and lively. All of the world-building culminates in frank
column3: tightly written kernels of wisdom that sneak up on you and take your breath away. On “Kings and Queens”
column4: Morris admits that “I wanted to impress you/ And I think you knew”; on “Santa Maria Novella”
column5: written after her move to Florence
column6: she reflects: “And I know that no one likes a tourist/ I feel like I’m one here.” Perhaps the most devastating line is the one that hammers home the breathtaking “Angela”
column7: a would-be standard love story flipped into a tale of friendship and support and hammered home with the following couplet: “The hardest thing we ever have to learn / Is when those we love don’t love us in return.” It’s easy to find your own life detailed in these songs
column8: and they’re helped along by arrangements that are brisk
column9: propulsive
column10: and remarkably unadorned
column11: allowing the crackling drumming and pristine guitar melodies to shine.

column1: We Come From the Same Place is at its weakest when it occasionally slips away from real emotional impact into more cloying and saccharine territory. “Bright Eyes” follows aforementioned highlight “Angela”
column2: and while guitarist Paul Rains gives it his all in a duet with Morris
column3: his thick
column4: sweet voice atop big
column5: bright chords carries the potential to induce a sugar coma
column6: as does the chipped ukulele and severe tenderness of “Heartbeat”. It's almost impossible to imagine those who like their pop music sharp-edged to take to this album's rounded corners. Nonetheless
column7: the title of We Come From the Same Place sums up its comforts nicely: it’s a warm
column8: deeply rooted
column9: familiar statement indicative of a real
column10:
earned connection.
