column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21121/homepage_large.ba5b5e78.jpg|Salt EP|32458.0|Institute|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2014-10-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:03.205919|"

Upon first encountering Institute's first EP for Sacred Bones
column2: Salt
column3: you could be forgiven for mistaking it for a recording from the 1980s—maybe
column4: for instance
column5: material that didn't fit on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18856-killed-by-deathrock-vol-1""><i>Killed By Deathrock
column7: a Nuggets-like compilation of early- and mid-'80s post-punk
column8: deathrock
column9: and ""dark punk"" that the same label put out earlier this year. All the hallmarks of that vintage sound are there: the tinny snares
column10: rattling like an ice cube in a small plastic box; bass that sounds like plucked bridge cables; guitars that crunch like scrap metal sliding into rush-hour traffic. It's extremely close and far away all at once
column11: evoking chilly basement practice spaces draped in moth-eaten moving blankets
column12: and the atmosphere is deathly dry
column13: as though a packet of silica powder had spilled across Joy Division's Unknown Pleasures
column14: soaking up all the ambient reverb.

column1: Institute are of the here and now
column2: though; they hail from Austin
column3: TX
column4: and share members with Wiccans
column5: Glue
column6: Blotter
column7: and Recide. The project began as a set of four-track sketches made by singer Moses Brown
column8: and a full-band demo turned into Institute's six-song
column9: self-titled debut EP
column10: released in February on British Columbia's Deranged Records. The Giddy Boys 7"" followed
column11: on Katorga Works. Both of those records laid out the basics of Institute's sound in two and three-minute blasts
column12: tarnished and ragged
column13: with Brown's pained voice—part wail
column14: part sigh
column15: vaguely reminiscent of Darby Crash's wasted whine—as the cherry on the lopsided
column16: fist-mashed cake.

column1: The Salt EP builds upon that foundation in subtle ways. The production is just as tarnished
column2: just as ragged
column3: but the elements have snapped ever so slightly more into focus. The songwriting feels sharper
column4: and the hooks sink deeper. ""Salt"" opens the record on a high point
column5: setting a bassline that flashes back to ""She's Lost Control"" over rolling
column6: skipping
column7: ""tribal"" drums straight out of Siouxsie's The Scream. Whatever else Brown might be croaking
column8: in a voice so hoarse you want to give him hot lemon-and-honey water and tuck him into bed
column9: ""It don't mean shit!"" cuts clearly through the murk. ""Nausea""
column10: just a minute long
column11: flies by in a blur of hardscrabble bass-and-guitar counterpoints
column12: dissonant and sere. Gazing in the mirror
column13: Brown offers a bleakly deadpan take on the divided self—""He looks like me
column14: yet he mocks me/ We spend some time together
column15: we spend our lives together/ I desire the experience of a moment alone""—that builds to an climax of dashed hopes (""To be free/ Is the worst prison!"") with every glance in the looking glass.

column1: ""Familiar Stranger"" also carries an echo of Unknown Pleasures
column2: with a rickety twang that might be a particularly Texan response to ""Disorder"". Its structure is odd
column3: a set of eight- and 16-bar modules snapped together like an Erector set. It builds without ever reaching a climax
column4: and ends as though falling off a cliff—barreling ahead one moment
column5: and gone the next. Brown's multi-tracked voice sounds like it's been filtered through a broken microphone; he sounds broken
column6: which is part of what makes him such a compelling presence. On ""Immorality""
column7: he sounds like he's about to come undone
column8: swatting in the dark at images he'd rather hold at bay. He cites the painter Eric Fischl and gestures darkly at ""a sewer to drain swollen needs of Christian men"". When it comes to the cathartic chorus (""Immorality's neat!"")
column9: you don't know whether to laugh or cry.

column1: It all comes to a head with ""An Absence""
column2: the closing song
column3: and
column4: at just over four minutes long
column5: the record's longest by a considerable margin. It begins with ringing open fifths over a relaxed
column6: almost regal drumbeat
column7: the guitars like sheets of liquid glass. Brown's dejected voice is more sob than speech. The bass shifts for the chorus: a minor second
column8: sweet discord; you want to curl up inside it
column9: in a ball
column10: like a cornered animal
column11: shivering in time with the dissonance. We're back to Siouxsie territory with this one—it's a ragtag ""Jigsaw Feeling""
column12: maybe
column13: run through Sonic Youth's pedals circa EVOL or Sister. It's breathtaking
column14: particularly in its climax
column15: which feels like a bar of metal being wrenched from its fittings
column16: and it goes to the heart of Institute's obvious promise: for all their resemblance to deathrock and post-punk greats of yore
column17: there's nothing mannered or simulacral about them. They are as real as the lump in your throat and the salt under your nails
column18:
and their sting couldn't be sweeter.

"|19881.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19881-institute-salt-ep/|7.4|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21087/homepage_large.fcd762cc.jpg|Hell Can Wait EP|32145.0|Vince Staples|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam']|2014-10-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:04.053584|"

West Coast gangsta rap has enjoyed a lasting revival in the wake of Kendrick Lamar’s good kid
column2: m.A.A.d city
column3: with albums by Schoolboy Q
column4: YG
column5: DJ Mustard and others following its lead in advancing the quality and chart traction of narrative-intensive gang-life dispatches. good kid’s unblinking austerity went missing
column6: though
column7: as the infectious levity of Mustard’s airtight party anthems went national
column8: inspiring even Kendrick to inch over to the sunny side with his studiously motivational comeback single “i”. The lesson of good kid—that you could make radio without catering to it—seems lost as L.A. revels in a renewed commercial relevance.

column1: Long Beach rapper Vince Staples is sick of cheery street rap. “If you listen to shit about niggas being in a position where they have no hope
column2: there should be nothing at peace about that
column3: ” he said in a recent interview with Pitchfork. “There’s a way to do it where it’s listenable and likable
column4: but it shouldn’t just be some happy stuff.” Staples’ own body of work rests on a nervous axis between expressive
column5: imagistic wordplay and somber cynicism. There’s pessimism in the opportunism. There’s stress in the joy. At his peppiest—the chorus of “Feelin’ the Love”
column6: perhaps
column7: the closer on his just-released retail debut Hell Can Wait—he’s still waving at death: “Is you feelin’ amazing? Yeah I’m feelin’ the love/ Hope I get to take it with me when my living is done.”

column1: Hell Can Wait is a reminder that living is another word for cheating death. It’s bleak and maybe exasperating
column2: but the reality of the street is that babies gotta eat
column3: jobs are scarce
column4: and some people have to resort to tactics that risk death and imprisonment to make it through the day. There’s no wide-eyed good kid narrating the disorder in Staples' city
column5: just a realist making do with the available options. “Niggas from my home ain’t enrolled in the colleges/ Fuck a class
column6: junkies hitting glass
column7: get the money long
column8: ” Vince snarls on “65 Hunnid”. On “Screen Door” he balks at the popularity of imaginary gangsters
column9: asserting that his own home was rawer than any Hollywood adaptation: “Bobby Johnson ain’t my OG/ This ain’t no movie role/ Pops was off the OE/ Tripping
column10: getting his Tookie on.”

column1: In the middle of the EP Staples' ire sharpens into an icepick. “Hands Up” protests LAPD's use of excessive force (“They expect respect and nonviolence/ I refuse the right to be silent”) in a diatribe Staples swears isn’t about Ferguson. But in a climate where surveillance cam and cell phone footage have revealed law enforcement bullying and violence against black bodies for a near-daily operation
column2: “Hands Up”’s volatile objection to “Paying taxes for some fucking clowns to ride around whooping niggas’ asses” hits hard from coast to coast. Lead single “Blue Suede” is a curt rejoinder about gang violence being deadly too; the terse chorus—“New shoes with the blue suede/ Young graves get the bouquets”—folds a lifetime of adversity into just a few words
column3: a series of damning images cataloguing the disintegration of hope.

column1: That economy is Hell Can Wait’s guiding principle. Staples never wastes a word in exhibiting a hustler’s hard-won resilience
column2: and he’s abetted by producers that buoy his stories without overwhelming them. Leading the charge is Toronto producer Hagler (best known for a co-producer credit on Drake’s “Trophies”). Hagler gifts “Screen Door” and “Limos” their hypnotic poise
column3: but he truly shines on “Blue Suede”
column4: which sounds like a trap artist’s rendering of the moment Dr. Dre thought to slap high pitched Moog lines over breaks
column5: the resulting menace tracing a line of ancestry between L.A.’s riots and Raiders era and today. Elsewhere Lil Wayne associate Infamous effects a Nawlins death march for “65 Hunnid”
column6: and Staples' mentor and label head No I.D. outfits “Hands Up” with a guttural low end fitting of a song that could be considered a spiritual successor to “Fuck tha Police”.

column1: Hell Can Wait is a debut for Staples
column2: but it’s really a refinement
column3: the end result of a years long search for the right producer that spawned a string of good but not always great mixtapes and loosies. Even a casual listener could hear the spark—Staples' first fame came from getting the best of known mic terrorist Earl Sweatshirt—but his production values have finally caught up enough to push him past the scrappy sidekick division into the big leagues. In an era where signing to a major label can mean artistic regression
column4:
Vince Staples’ jump to Def Jam is a case study in the enduring merit of good old-fashioned artist development. The machine still works sometimes.

"|19849.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19849-vince-staples-hell-can-wait-ep/|8.5|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21069/homepage_large.3f3027cb.jpg|Hi Scores EP|410.0|Boards of Canada|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Skam']|2014-10-14 00:00:00|1996|2016-06-11 16:32:05.783005|"

Hi Scores wasn't Boards of Canada's first proper record. By the time it appeared in 1996
column2: the Scottish duo had released a minor armload of cassettes and 12-inches
column3: all of it in extraordinarily limited editions. But
column4: for all the general public knew
column5: it may as well have been their debut
column6: given the way it arrived like a bolt from the aquamarine.

column1: Even if you lived it
column2: it's getting hard to remember what it was like to discover music back then. But when Hi Scores began turning up in record bins
column3: not only were listeners unlikely to know much about who they were or where the record came from
column4: there were precious few ways of finding out. The snail-mail address listed on the insert sheet was just a P.O. box. A strip of Braille adorned the cover
column5: heightening the record's cryptic aspect. And the name of the label
column6: Skam
column7: lent a vaguely unsavory air to it all. On Hyperreal's IDM listserv
column8: it was ventured that Boards of Canada might be a synonym of Aphex Twin or Autechre or Mike Paradinas
column9: or some combination of them.

column1: It's useful to try to return to that state of ignorance
column2: if only because so many layers of myth have been woven around the duo since then
column3: a dense cocoon of fantasy and obfuscation. Some of that has been their own doing
column4: like the coded 12-inches they distributed on Record Store Day last year as a pre-announcement of Tomorrow's Harvest—Willy Wonka's golden tickets as re-imagined by William Gibson. And some of it seems to have been the result of an obsessive fanbase hopped up on rabbit holes and Easter eggs. (From the fan site bocpages.org: ""It has been suggested that the 'hi' of 'hi scores' could refer to the initials of BoC's alias Hell Interface."" Well
column5: yes
column6: quite; and so might we connect the duo's reclusive tendencies to the fact that one anagram of the group's name is ""A Bad Raccoons Fad"").

column1: But Hi Scores preceded all of that. There are ample clues of the kind of artists they'd become with Music Has the Right to Children
column2: released just two years later
column3: and not just because ""Turquoise Hexagon Sun"" is included here in an identical version. Five of the six tracks occupy the head-nodding
column4: mid-tempo range that remains the duo's narcotic wheelhouse. Sampled breakbeats drive most of the songs here
column5: but they sound different from the scratchy
column6: dust-encrusted breaks that instrumental hip-hop producers like DJ Shadow and DJ Krush were using around the same time; Boards of Canada's breaks snap and thud with a weirdly rigid motion
column7: and they're fleshed out with metallic drum-machine sounds
column8: like the boxy snares of ""Nlogax"" and the dry
column9: deflated hi-hats of ""Seeya Later""
column10: that glint dully against the murk.

column1: The duo's tonal tendencies were already well developed: all six tracks feature their trademark four-bar chord progressions and cycling contrapuntal melodies. The air is uniformly wistful
column2: full of chimes and shimmering arpeggios and buzzing
column3: tubular tones
column4: like singing ghosts heard through a drainpipe. And while they don't wade as far into the lysergic depths that would distinguish Music Has the Right to Children—all those hazy
column5: soft-focus tones meant to evoke the nostalgia of old nature films and washed-out Super 8—their synthesizers
column6: subtly detuned
column7: have a woozy
column8: watery feel
column9: slippery as something half-remembered. And on ""Turquoise Hexagon Sun""
column10: the sound of distant voices anticipates the playground concrète vibes of Music and Geogaddi.

column1: But Hi Scores might be most exciting for the way it breaks from their later work. The title track
column2: soaked in faraway buzz
column3: as though it had been recorded beneath high-voltage power lines
column4: offers up an overdriven growl that's reminiscent of Aphex Twin's ""Ventolin"". It's unusually muscular for them
column5: and the same could be said of ""June 9th""
column6: whose laser zaps and faintly industrial crunch recall Autechre and Disjecta. And the best track on the whole release might be ""Nlogax""
column7: a snapping electro cut with a break reportedly sampled from Indeep's ""Last Night a D.J. Saved My Life""; with the exception of the Hell Interface remix of ""Midas Touch""
column8: it's probably the funkiest thing Boards of Canada have ever done. And played back at 45 RPM
column9: it turns into shuddering
column10: head-spinning techno—a tantalizing example of a path the duo could have taken
column11: but never did.

column1: It's not quite clear why
column2: exactly
column3: Hi Scores is getting re-released now. (A publicist notes that this is Skam's 20th anniversary
column4: but that's debatable; 1994 was the year of the Autechre offshoot Gescom's self-titled EP
column5: but that record bore the catalog number of SKA002. SKA001
column6: the eponymous debut from Autechre in their Lego Feet guise
column7: dates to 1991
column8: and while almost nobody actually had the thing
column9: its existence was known
column10: or at least rumored
column11: by the mid-'90s.) Apparently
column12: Hi Scores has been remastered from the original DATs
column13: and while the digital promo doesn't sound much (if at all) improved from the previous digital version
column14: it's possible that the new edition of the vinyl will sound better than the original wax. But even that hardly matters much
column15: given that this will be the first chance for many of the duo's fans to get their hands on the 12-inch at all. And while it might have been nice to be treated to some previously unreleased material—supposedly
column16: there's still a trove of unreleased Boards music moldering on old cassette tapes—perhaps it's enough to have the original Hi Scores in all its crisp
column17: concise glory. While it wasn't their first record
column18:
it's basically the spark that would ignite their reputation—the ember that would go on to fuel the whole glorious campfire headphase. Long may it smolder.

"|19832.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19832-boards-of-canada-hi-scores-ep/|8.7|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21139/homepage_large.28ec45af.jpg|Festival of the Dead|29847.0|Cut Hands|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2014-10-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:06.526186|"

William Bennett
column2: former Whitehouse provocateur
column3: admits he got into working with elements of African and Haitian percussion by accident. The Cut Hands project started when Bennett was asked to DJ at Glasgow club Optimo
column4: where he delivered a set of Haitian Vodou music and heavily percussive African tracks (at ear-splitting volume
column5: natch) and was delighted at the effect it had on the audience. It’s a feeling that still lingers—this is the third album under the Cut Hands name following a series of quick fire releases
column6: some of which have appeared
column7: like this one
column8: on Kiran Sande’s London-based label Blackest Ever Black.

column1: It’s been a strange time for Bennett
column2: who has gained a marginally higher profile via the less challenging nature of Cut Hands
column3: but has concurrently had to fend off misinterpretations of his past work. In 2013
column4: he was even moved to make a statement that clearly outlined his personal beliefs. His take on cultural appropriation
column5: and whether he’s practicing it in Cut Hands
column6: is as forthright as you’d expect. In a 2011 interview with Sande
column7: Bennett claimed that parsing out “world music” as a separate form was a “condescending and patronising” practice that was antithetical to the way he sees music.

column1: All this adds up to a different form of confrontation to the one he practiced in Whitehouse; despite the “it’s-all-just-music” claims
column2: it’s hard to imagine that Bennett wasn’t expecting a few pointed questions thrown his way regarding his intentions for Cut Hands. Where that’s taken him on Festival of the Dead is into a curious cul de sac
column3: where he builds on what came before in tiny increments. It’s placid at times
column4: even skirting around ambient when he rolls out the solitary tones of tracks such as “Belladonna Theme”
column5: “Inlightenment”
column6: and “Fruit Is Ripe”
column7: which intermittently provide respite from the drill-like percussion elsewhere.

column1: Of the meatier material it’s in “The Claw” that Bennett finds most purpose
column2: where his signature hollowed-out drum sound is entwined with niggling percussive elements and a bass heavy groove. It’s a formula he returns to often
column3: with varying results. The former single “Damballah 58” is among the better examples
column4: especially when it’s galvanized by a sample resembling a ticking time bomb. Further tracks torn from a similar blueprint—“Vaudou Take Me High”
column5: “Madwoman (Festival Mix)”
column6: “Fire Ends the Day”—labor the point to the verge of redundancy
column7: especially as there’s a weight of similarly minded Cut Hands material already out there.

column1: Where Festival of the Dead works is by leaving markers that could potentially be followed and exploited at a later date. “None of Your Bones Are Broken” is one of the best tracks Bennett has recorded under this name; constructed from manic
column2: jungle-like backing that intersects with jarring string samples
column3: its a perfectly unharmonious meeting point of inter-continental ideas. Elsewhere there are hints of UK garage in the rhythms Bennett lends to his work
column4: but the overall feel is of a markedly barren place. It's like Bennett looked at clubland and saw an emptiness eating away at it from the inside—an interesting and possibly valid viewpoint
column5:
but not one that needs repeating ad infinitum.

"|19898.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19898-cut-hands-festival-of-the-dead/|6.5|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21175/homepage_large.48f1cb6e.jpg|As If We Never Won|5802.0|Kleerup|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Music Group']|2014-10-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:07.071497|"

Andreas Kleerup might turn out to have been the Zelig of late-'00s Swedish dance-pop. The Stockholm producer's surname originally appeared as the main artist on late-2006 single ""With Every Heartbeat""
column2: a string-draped beat ballad that went on to become a UK No. 1 for Robyn. His 2008 album
column3: simply titled Kleerup
column4: gave an early glimpse of now-U2-collaborator Lykke Li broadening the coy range of her debut album earlier that year. Neneh Cherry? The Swedish-born pop innovator made herself at home on Kleerup's debut
column5: too. Throw in connections to the Concretes (whose Lisa Millberg guests on Kleerup) and the Tough Alliance (his group the Meat Boys remixed 2004's ""Holiday"") and this erstwhile drummer is six degrees from just about any Swede you'd care to name. Going beyond Scandinavia for a second: Did I mention he did a remix for Lady Gaga?

column1: Kleerup's first major release since his self-titled debut went international in 2009 shows he still has fine taste in friends
column2: but it's a bit like being introduced to perfectly nice people at a party where the host isn't able or willing to help explain what you have in common. As If We Never Won
column3: the first of two mini-albums Kleerup plans to release in the next couple of years
column4: once again fixes undeniably talented Swedish vocalists to unabashedly warm-blooded synth-pop. This time
column5: though
column6: the combination just doesn't result in songs as fresh and appealing as ""With Every Heartbeat"" or Lykke Li team-up ""Until It Bleeds""; Kleerup doesn't turn out to be endlessly adaptable to the artists he's with
column7: after all. The result is a pleasant yet also mildly puzzling stopgap that fails either to show newcomers what all the original fuss was about or longtime fans why a proper follow-up has taken so long.

column1: Despite the long gap since Kleerup
column2: that album's '80s-immersed spaciousness has remained a common characteristic in more recent pop. So it's not that Kleerup sounds behind the times when he delves into operatic Euro disco with M83/Röyksopp vocalist Susanne Sundfør on ""Let Me In""—though the song's video
column3: which mainly focuses on Kleerup and his gear
column4: through occasional colored effects
column5: may speak to where his aesthetic is at these days. He broadens his palette a bit
column6: too: ""Rock U""
column7: a smoky collaboration with Niki and the Dove's Malin Dahlstrom
column8: winds up somewhere between the new Stevie Nicks album and Haim's ""Forever (Giorgio Moroder (Remix)"". And an appearance by constantly underrated former First Floor Power singer Jenny Wilson is always welcome
column9: arriving here in the cryptic
column10: mournful pulse of ""To Die For"".

column1: Still
column2: it's hard to shake the sense these all would have been lesser cuts on the debut album
column3: and nothing here lifts the full record out of its malaise. Opening instrumental ""Sad Boys""
column4: another one in the Moroder-Cerrone tradition
column5: works as a continuation of Kleerup-closing ""I Just Want to Make That Sad Boy Smile"" (sorry
column6: anyone reading this hoping for a Yung Lean tie-in). Kleerup's serviceable coo fails to catch a spark in the title track's vocoder-brooding duet with the Sounds' Maja Ivarsson
column7: as the two exchange generic phrases (""I'll never let you down / I'll keep on breaking down/ Signed
column8: sealed
column9: whatever""). Most perplexing of all is the finale
column10: ""Thank God for Sending Demons""
column11: a hoarse-voiced acoustic dirge that shares its title with a 2011 song by another Kleerup band
column12: Me and My Army
column13: but isn't a recognizable cover. At some point along the six degrees of separation
column14: a true sense of connection has been lost.

column1: Kleerup was
column2: however
column3: wise to use the mini-album format. The setting has recently been good to artists from the Knife and Röyksopp / Robyn to Best Coast
column4: and it's a reasonable length for a Kleerup release in an era when there's no need to fill out an entire CD (my CD version of the first album isn't even that old
column5: yet my computer can't play it anymore—MP3s prevail!). But the lack of time to get lost in a record's particular world makes it all the more important to have songs that resonate in their own right. Kleerup has been busier than you might've thought since 2008—along with the folk-leaning Me and My Army
column6: he released a Sweden-only Kleerup full-length
column7: 2012's Aniara—so it's possible he's saving his best stuff for the next mini-album. For now
column8: those interested in hearing the most essential post-Kleerup Kleerup music should probably go back to his production for Robyn on ""In My Eyes""
column9: from 2010's Body Talk: ""You put your dancing shoes on
column10: and you do it again."" Or
column11: you know
column12: kick off your Sunday shoes
column13:
whatever.

"|19925.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19925-kleerup-as-if-we-never-won/|5.7|Marc Hogan

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20929/homepage_large.0582e2aa.jpg|Meatbodies|32291.0|Meatbodies|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2014-10-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:07.715048|"

Mikal Cronin put on some killer live shows last year surrounding MCII
column2: but while he was singing beautifully and strumming his 12-string
column3: another longhair consistently threatened to steal the spotlight. Chad Ubovich
column4: the touring guitarist responsible for the huge solo on ""See It My Way""
column5: has undeniable chops. He's also the bassist for Fuzz
column6: and it's the same deal—he does a lot more than just slouch in the background and play the minimum. When this dude takes a solo
column7: you watch. Based on those sideman gigs alone
column8: it makes sense that his band Meatbodies got picked up by In the Red for a pair of singles and a long-player.

column1: Last year
column2: they released a very good self-titled cassette on Ty Segall's God? Records (as Chad and the Meatbodies). It sold out fairly quickly and
column3: in circles that care about those sorts of things
column4: became one of those instantaneous small batch collector's items. But with their debut LP
column5: it's more difficult to view the band as small-press ass-kicking upstarts. Meatbodies was recorded and mixed by Eric ""King Riff"" Bauer
column6: Bob Marshall
column7: and Chris Woodhouse (who
column8: between the three of them
column9: have worked on every Live in San Francisco release and most Segall
column10: Cronin
column11: Fuzz
column12: and Oh Sees records). The cover art was done by Fuzz and Slaughterhouse artist Tatiana Kartomten. Segall even plays drums and bass on a few tracks here. Meatbodies are embedded in that world
column13: and they're working within a formula that's proved successful for their more-visible peers. Comparisons are inevitable; the bar is high.

column1: Pro wrestling heels use the term ""B+ player"" about guys in Ubovich's position—rookies who put on a good show but aren't quite headliners. But he rips
column2: you see. He's always been a destroyer
column3: and on Meatbodies
column4: he also proves to be an ace rock'n'roll strategist. The tone here is set perfectly: 59 seconds of psychedelic sci-fi noise
column5: and then
column6: very suddenly
column7: Ubovich and Segall come in at full power
column8: electric guitars unrelenting
column9: with ""Disorder"". It's a loud
column10: exciting

Embedded within the detailed credits to Foxygen’s …And Star Power is this revelation from guitarist/band co-founder Jonathan Rado: “During our recording process
column2: our only true heated argument was over this song.” The identity of the song in question is immaterial; the very fact Rado felt the need to downplay any perceived infighting with vocalist/foil Sam France speaks volumes about the reputation their band has acquired—one that’s unruly enough to seemingly require some liner-note damage control. Following the release of 2013’s critical success We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic
column3: Foxygen seemed to pack a career’s worth of triumphs and travesties into a single album cycle—and
column4: as such
column5: …And Star Power translates all the exhilaration and exhaustion the band has experienced over the past two years into an unwieldy
column6: 24-song splatter that often sounds like a band at war with itself. It’s as if Foxygen is issuing a challenge to all the rubberneckers in the audience by saying
column7: “You think we’re a trainwreck? You ain’t seen nothing yet.”

column1: Coming from a band that has chalked up its many concert cancellations and onstage meltdowns to tour-induced fatigue
column2: …And Star Power aptly approximates the dislocating sensation of strung-out
column3: sleepless nights in posh hotel rooms that have had the Do Not Disturb sign dangling on the outer-door handle for several days
column4: with moments of lucid (if bleary eyed) introspection regularly giving way to flashes of fever-dream psychosis. The raucous opening warm-up exercise is titled “Star Power Airlines”
column5: a nostalgic nod to that bygone era when rock bands could become popular enough to acquire their own jet fleets
column6: but also a telling indicator of the many random recording locations—from the Chateau Marmont in L.A. to The Magic Shop in New York—that lend this album a whirlwind tour itinerary of its own.

column1: Despite its double-album girth
column2: …And Star Power feels less like a ’70s-rock masterwork than a ’90s indie patchwork in the tradition of Pavement’s Wowee Zowee
column3: Sebadoh's III
column4: the Olivia Tremor Control’s Dusk at Cubist Castle
column5: and Ween’s earliest brown-outs. This is an album you get lost inside—you don’t so much listen to its four-sided sprawl as free-fall into its increasingly deranged depths. Its kitchen-sink messthetic (parts of which were rendered in Rado’s actual kitchen) encompasses pristine power pop
column6: stoner country-rock
column7: a four-part title-track suite (overture included) that introduces the band’s punk-alter-ego-cum-pirate-radio-station Star Power
column8: space-age bachelor-pad synth doodles
column9: Lou Reed-copping junkie poetry
column10: acid-folk rambles reminiscent of Syd Barrett
column11: Feelies-esque jabber-jangle; and a song that sounds like Suicide crashing a Frankie Avalon/Annette Funicello beach party. And that’s all before we’ve even reached Side Three (the one accurately subtitled “Scream: A Journey Through Hell”).

column1: In its most fully realized moments
column2: …And Star Power is the album Todd Rundgren could’ve released between Something/Anything? and A Wizard
column3: a True Star
column4: its best songs striking an uncanny balance between the exquisite balladry of the former and the progged-out fantasias of the latter. True
column5: the Runt referentialism is beyond blatant: lead single “How Can You Really” is a perfect mirror reflection of “I Saw the Light”
column6: while “Star Power IV: Ooh Ooh” distills the candlelit intimacy of “It Wouldn’t Have Made Any Difference” into a quick post-coital cuddle. (The press release for …And Star Power actually summarizes the album’s ethos—“rock and roll for the skull""—by quoting Patti Smith’s original Creem magazine review of A Wizard
column7: a True Star. Even this band’s self-aggrandizement comes second-hand.)

column1: But for all their shameless appropriation
column2: Foxygen have become increasingly assured and accomplished songwriters
column3: outfitting standouts like “Coulda Been My Love” (the ironically serene source of the intra-band acrimony mentioned at the top of this review)
column4: “Cannibal Holocaust”
column5: and “Everyone Needs Love” not just with silken soft-focus melodies and heavenly harmonies
column6: but ever-evolving arrangements that steer the songs into surprising
column7: splendorous new directions without losing the throughline. At their best
column8: a Foxygen song is like that drunk who seems destined to topple over
column9: only to turn their stumble into a perfect pirouette.

column1: If We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic completed Foxygen’s long-gestating evolution from private recording project to proper band
column2: …And Star Power expands their universe to even greater degree
column3: placing them at the epicenter of a modern psych-rock constellation that includes the Flaming Lips
column4: Of Montreal
column5: White Fence
column6: and L.A. fuzz-popsters Bleached
column7: all of whom make guest appearances here. (And
column8: as if to acknowledge their place on the storied madcap continuum
column9: they give shout-outs to Skip Spence and Kim Fowley in the liners.) At certain points
column10: Foxygen’s generosity of spirit goes beyond merely accommodating a cameo to outright handing over the reins of their album to third parties: the brass-knuckled “Star Power III: What Are We Good For” begins with a Kevin Barnes dispatch live from the corner of Lexington and 125
column11: and Foxygen even admit in the liners they’re entirely not sure what he’s yapping about. The Lips’ Steven Drozd is credited with composing the analog-synth strut “Mattress Warehouse”
column12: while the adrenalizing freakbeat rave-up “Brooklyn Police Station” features White Fence’s Tim Presley in so many different capacities (bass
column13: guitar
column14: harmonies)
column15: it’s no surprise the song ends up sounding like it was plucked outright from one of his albums.

column1: Tellingly
column2: the self-produced …And Star Power is Foxygen’s first Jagjaguwar release made without their mentor Richard Swift behind the boards
column3: and while the album shows France and Rado can no doubt craft classic-rock-radio-caliber songs without his compositional expertise
column4: their reactionary attempts at punky aggression and noise experimentation come off as half-baked. Particularly in the album’s back half
column5:
it starts to feel like Foxygen decided to make 
…And Star Power a double album before writing the necessary number of songs to justify one
column6: stuffing the gaps with frivolous filler that wouldn’t be able stand on its own outside of the record’s crazy-quilt framework. And so the lo-fi doom-metal-drone-cum-garage-skronk of “Cold Winter/Freedom” (the wrought-iron gateway into the aforementioned “Scream” side) rambles on for six tuneless minutes
column7: while counterpart track “Freedom II” and “Talk” drive their Nuggets-schooled grooves into the ground through incessant
column8: nonsensical hollering and abrupt structural shifts that don’t so much yield a dramatic effect as betray their lack of direction. Such regressions may be intended to serve as the freaked-out flipside to …And Star Power’s more meditative material
column9: but Foxygen’s “Journey Through Hell” ultimately sounds less like therapeutic catharsis than aimless dicking around for yuks in the practice space.

column1: But for Foxygen
column2:
such violent pendulum swings prove to be the musical manifestation of an
eccentric spirit they once conveyed lyrically. What ultimately elevated We Are the 21st Century beyond mere classic-rock karaoke was France’s playfully wry observations
column3: which infused Foxygen’s retro affinities with a distinctly modern-day sensibility and irreverence. …And Star Power
column4: however
column5: works the other way: the anarchic sound world is grounded by more sobering songwriting
column6: with France’s once-prominent voice left to float in the psychedelic soup—which means you won’t find any instantly quotable zingers here on par with “No Destruction”. But while France’s words may be more nondescript this time out
column7: the band’s tumultuous recent history suggests platitudes like “You’ve got to hang on”
column8: “How am I going to make it with you?”
column9: and “Where must we go again to become friends?” are genuine
column10: necessary pleas for sanity and serenity.

column1: Accordingly
column2: the impenetrable “Cold Winter/Freedom” is preceded by an endearing little snippet of an eight-year-old France’s earliest recording forays
column3: wherein he acts as the on-air announcer for his own imaginary radio station. “Hold onto your butts and get ready!” little Sam declares
column4: and
column5: in essence
column6: …And Star Power is Foxygen’s attempt to recapture that sort of innocence and wide-eyed enthusiasm after a prolonged
column7: public struggle to keep their shit together. But the retroactive warning is nonetheless appreciated: …And Star Power is a long
column8: bumpy ride back to where Foxygen once belonged
column9: and
column10: at times
column11:
your butt is bound to feel sore.

Stars would likely be flattered if you called them “pop” and honored if you called them “sophisticated.” You shouldn’t have to choose between the two; as their previous collaborator/remixer Owen Pallett will be more than happy to tell you
column3: a lot of science goes into bubblegum. But since their 2004 breakthrough Set Yourself on Fire
column4: Stars made those terms seem mutually exclusive
column5: as their charms were obscured by haughty thematic concepts (In Our Bedroom After the War)
column6: doughy orchestration (The Five Ghosts) or astonishing self-regard (the abominable remix LP Do You Trust Your Friends?). Fortunately
column7: by 2012’s The North
column8: Stars decided to have fun again (or for the first time) and No One Is Lost finds them chasing base thrills with more even more gusto. But in micromanaging every celebratory aspect
column9: it raises the question of whether a party is still a party if Stars run through it.

column1: As opposed to its nostalgic predecessor
column2: No One Is Lost concerns itself with forward momentum
column3: beginning with its serendipitous recording atop the Royal Phoenix
column4: a now-shuttered Montreal gay disco. While the Phoenix was still in business
column5: the bass would make its way up to Stars' studio and they were motivated to “out-throb the throb.” And some of No One Is Lost qualifies as danceable
column6: if not exactly “dance music.” It’s simply a more extroverted look at the artisanal indie genres that one has come to expect from this band—melodramatic
column7: Smiths-derived jangle
column8: sophistipop
column9: blue-eyed Motown—though they strew triplet bass drum across the straight soul-clap of “A Stranger” like they might’ve heard DJ Rashad at some point.

column1: More to the point
column2: the narrators of No One Is Lost abide by a fatalism that’s the closest thing we’ll probably get to actual optimism on a Stars record: something along the lines of
column3: you’ll probably have to spend most of your days in a shit job or a boring relationship
column4: so make the night count. That’s the message of six-minute mission statement “From the Night”
column5: and as far as Canadian indie collectives paying homage to the transformative powers of sundown by fusing arena rock and Gloria Estefan
column6: well...it’s at least in the top two from the past year. But even if Stars can never truly cut loose
column7: they can offer the crowd an honest hands-up chorus and lack the earnestness that made Arcade Fire’s costume parties sound stiff.

column1: But as the album progresses
column2: that becomes a liability. If not earnestness
column3: you wish Stars could demonstrate the same kind of black-and-white
column4: life-or-death stakes in their music as their Montreal neighbors. If you’re gonna espouse a “live fast
column5: die young” philosophy
column6: you have to sound like you believe it too. This is less of a problem when Stars engage in their usual
column7: theatrical songwriting constructs and set pieces. The he-said
column8: she-said between Torquil Campbell and Amy Millan is too comfy to generate much friction at this point
column9: although the possible songwriting-as-lovemaking metaphor of “You Keep Coming Up” (""You gotta give it away/ So you can get it for free"") does at least provide wincing awkwardness.

column1: But when No One Is Lost tries to blend in with the youth
column2: Stars sound like professors rather than participants. The schoolyard shouts of “Turn It Up” sound out of character in all aspects
column3: though at least the title refers to the radio and not the 2013 colloquialism. And while “Trap Door” contains the most elegant choral melody
column4: Campbell’s critiques of hedonism’s inherent hollowness come off as smug
column5: sounding like someone who’s writing about the idea of it rather than the experience—“the kids in VIP are all looking for a family/ Their teeth are made of gold but their wallets are empty.” Gold teeth? Does Campbell still think people party like it's 1999?

column1: That's a more egregious example of how Stars' lyrics are pithy
column2: but facile
column3: lacking any kind of edge. The most problematic one comes when Stars deliver what should be the mic-drop
column4: valedictory address during the title track: “Put your hands up because everybody dies.” It reminds you that irony pervades this album from its title on down and that Campbell feels the best way to cope with the pervasive disorientation of being alive is
column5: “To get arseholed and listen to Dionne Warwick
column6: ” another arch quote demonstrating how “fuck it” is so carefully curated here. Is No One Is Lost even an album meant to be listened to in the very situations it writes about? While a fine enough record in its own right
column7: it’s more suited to fostering a discussion about the theoretical implications of our collective
column8:
impending doom than celebrating it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21090/homepage_large.69a5880e.jpg|I'll Be the Tornado|31582.0|Dads|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['6131']|2014-10-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:09.516133|"

About midway through Dads’ sophomore LP I’ll Be the Tornado
column2: drummer/vocalist John Bradley yelps
column3: “I want to be happy/ But I’m holding myself back.” As with most of his words here
column4: they’re plainspoken
column5: instantly quotable and derive power from context. For the New Brunswick duo
column6: Dads is their life if not necessarily a living—to juxtapose the tremendous emotional investment and inherent triviality of such a lot
column7: Bradley asks
column8: “If I can’t even afford a grave for myself/ Then why am I so afraid of dying alone?”

column1: As with most in their situation
column2: Dads justify things by placing a lot of importance on the actions of those closest to them and their interactions with these people
column3: i.e. “the scene.” This is a commonplace concern in punk rock
column4: so it’s notable that Bradley wants to be “happy
column5: ” not “true” or “real
column6: ” since he finds the people who take it upon themselves to set those standards are often the most full of shit; or
column7: as it’s memorably put later on during “You Hold Back”
column8: “You can’t go against the grain with no natural wood.” This is a commonplace observation as well
column9: but while most bands dealing in this subject matter assume the moral high ground
column10: Bradley’s willing to acknowledge that he’s part of the problem and he’s going to take his brain and his issues with him wherever he goes. It’s just strange that he accuses himself of holding back here
column11: because Dads put it all out there on this gut-spilling
column12: bold and progressive album.

column1: It’s a record of transitions in all aspects. Dads’ trajectory is obvious even before you hear a note of their music; compare the cover and album title from their 2012 effort American Radass (This is Important) to the wistful shot that graces last year's Pretty Good EP and the stylish
column2: muted artwork of I’ll Be the Tornado. Like their most accomplished peers
column3: Dads are synthesists
column4: honoring their influences without rehashing them and making an unspoken argument that late-'90s emo was never meant to be quarantined outside of “proper” punk or indie rock. Since they’re a duo
column5: guitarist Scott Scharinger handles lead
column6: rhythm
column7: and bass for Dads
column8: supplying fluid
column9: melodic passages that can stand on their own as evocative instrumentals
column10: a la Mineral or American Football. But Dads also account for the crowd-pleasing urgency of chunky power chords
column11: cathartic
column12: singalong choruses (“Chewing Ghosts”)
column13: call-and-response hooks (“You Hold Back”) and jangly college rock (“Take Back Today”).  Bradley’s vocals pierce through a clean and clear mix
column14: while his drumming boasts a fast-twitch athleticism that unified the Promise Ring and Braid with Modest Mouse and Les Savy Fav as an alternative from the slacker affectations and slapdash musicianship that defined indie rock a few years prior.

column1: But more importantly
column2: the pains of Dads’ personal evolution are detailed extensively in the lyrics
column3: and I’ll Be the Tornado inherits the annual The Execution of All Things Achievement Award from last year’s winner
column4: Waxahatchee; in other words
column5: it’s the album where the main goal
column6: if not sole purpose
column7: would appear to be providing the greatest number of potential LiveJournal/MySpace/Twitter status updates.  Bradley’s lyrics aren’t poetry
column8: and they’re not intellectual or referential
column9: but they are almost entirely composed of a clever variation of things you might find yourself saying in any real life situation. There’s just as much drama as there is sitcom material; when Bradley wants to be a part of a lover’s inside jokes on “But”
column10: it’s sweet
column11: but during the tense acoustic first half of opener “Grand Edge
column12: MI”
column13: he moans
column14: “I wanna tell you about my past...I wanna tell you about everything
column15: ” and the sentiment is somewhat threatening. You sense he’s someone with an insatiable urge to disclose his most intimate secrets and the knowledge that it always results in driving people away; but maybe not this time.

column1: Taken in concert
column2: lines like those create an ambivalence that gives the listener a sense of real stakes and humanity in I’ll Be the Tornado; you’re never certain whether Bradley’s confessing to being the good guy or a dick in any situation. During “Take Back Today”
column3: he confides
column4: “I wish you could’ve been there to have met my father/ When he wasn’t always in pain and some doctor’s new project.” But these moments are put up against the real pleasures associated with being an up-and-coming band (“I remember cities in sunsets that I never lived in/ But goddamn
column5: those days/ We were living it”) that are nonetheless fleeting and always leading to the next high: “I made my life into a competition/ Where’s my trophy mantle/ You sent clippings to an article I couldn’t begin to handle.”

column1: The resultant distance from security and trust makes Bradley’s heart grow fond—both “But” and “Fake Knees” slowly evolve to harmonized crescendos and hard lessons about embracing the imperfections in yourself and others. On “Fake Knees”
column2: a partner’s coffee breath and substance issues rattle around Bradley’s head
column3: little annoyances about to metastasize into dealbreakers
column4: before he remembers the warmth of sleeping together in tattered T-shirts and the bigger picture comes into focus—“I’m on a redeye crying over some fucking clothes”. But there are just as many cold
column5: hard truths about how some people just need to be cut out entirely. “Chewing Ghosts” turns the other cheek and it still comes across like a slap in the face anyway. Prior to the rousing affirmation of the chorus
column6: Bradley spits
column7: “Enemies come and enemies go/ Some burn dull enough just to fade away.” Not coincidentally
column8: “enemies” and “memories” rhyme in the same way ""punk"" and ""drunk"" do earlier in “Chewing Ghosts”; they’re not exactly synonymous
column9: but in Dads’ experience
column10: those concepts are inextricable.

column1: Even if the echoing post-rock of the seven-minute “Only You” makes it a bit too on-the-nose as an ""epic closer
column2: it serves as a proper way to decompress; leading up to that point
column3: Bradley finds himself obsessing over the past (“I won’t bury my dead/ I just trample the bodies”) and
column4: “Spending so much time in the future
column5: I forgot about the present.” That last line comes in a song called “Take Back Today”
column6: the title of which is the only thing that comes across as a piece of advice rather than one man relating his experience and hoping you understand. But you don’t have to be an artist to grasp how the pursuit of sobriety
column7: companionship and serenity can be at odds with a career or lifestyle that gives you every opportunity to go back to the old
column8: familiar and comforting misery. You’re only required to be a human being
column9:
and I’ll Be the Tornado is as accomplished and confident as a band can sound while sorting their shit out in public.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21000/homepage_large.1b42d42f.jpg|Absolutely Free|30797.0|Absolutely Free|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lefse']|2014-10-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:10.115838|"

The Absolutely Free nucleus of Matt King
column2: Moshe Rozenberg
column3: and Mike Claxton previously played with Toronto contorto-punk outfit DD/MM/YYYY
column4: a band whose unpronounceable name was commonly verbalized as “Day Month Year” but was originally meant to be substituted with the date of whenever they got together to play. The implicit message was that
column5: at a show (particularly those held in the sort of ad-hoc
column6: stage-less venues DD/MM/YYYY frequented) what matters is not so much the name of who’s playing as the commitment and intensity they put into the performance
column7: which should in turn forever burn a memory of a specific time and place into the lucky attendee’s blown mind. And while the music Absolutely Free creates is dramatically different than that of their former incarnation
column8: the underlying principle remains: It’s a band’s ultimate obligation to make their audience feel like they’re part of something special.

column1: Since forming in late 2011 just as DD/MM/YYYY announced its break-up
column2: Absolutely Free have confined their recorded output to a series of limited-run 12-inch releases (issued via Fucked Up guitarist Mike Haliechuk’s One Big Silence imprint) that have packed several album’s worth of ideas into prog-pop mini-suites. And their live performances to date have mostly steered clear of the traditional club circuit in favor of all-out happenings: the band celebrated their debut single “UFO” by leading audiences Pied Piper-style between nearby venues in Toronto’s Kensington Market neighbourhood
column3: performing a live soundtrack to The Day the Earth Stood Still and a set of their own material before throwing a video dance party modeled after 1990s-era MuchMusic-hosted high-school shindigs. And while the decision to release follow-up single “On the Beach” last October may have negated any opportunities for a fun-in-the-sun soiree
column4: Absolutely Free did the next best thing: perform a concert during a night-swim session at a local indoor swimming pool.

column1: D. Boon once cheekily described the Minutemen’s herky-jerky poli-punk as “scientist rock
column2: ” but Absolutely Free genuinely look and sound like the sort of band concocted in some sort of after-school lab experiment. Their stage set-up resembles a madcap workshop of effects pedals
column3: deconstructed drum kits
column4: melodicas
column5: buzzing analog synths
column6: and the sort of dense entanglement of wires that makes you worry someone’s going to get electrocuted. But the band’s self-titled debut full-length (produced by Haliechuk) bears the fully realized fruits of Absolutely Free’s endless experimentation
column7: yielding a compact 8-song
column8: 42-minute album that retains the band’s sense of intrepidity while travelling a more linear course.

column1: Where the group’s early singles favored extended ambient intros
column2: impulsive structural shifts
column3: and blown-out finales
column4: the songs on Absolutely Free tend to patiently linger on a single idea and see how it naturally evolves. Singing drummer Matt King’s vocals are also less of a driving force here; rather than lead the charge
column5: he seems more willing to let his existential ruminations reverberate out into the cosmos. But while the band have reined in some of the volatility that made those introductory singles so exhilarating
column6: there’s a cool consistency and newfound accessibility to Absolutely Free that makes it an easy
column7: enchanting front-to-back listen
column8: the songs locking together to form a smoothly contoured album arc. Even the most chaotic elements—like the spinning-radio-dial dissonance woven through the opening reverie “Window of Time”—eventually fuse into the album’s steady wavelength. That’s not to suggest Absolutely Free aren’t still shooting for the moon; they’ve simply activated the cruise control so that they can better savor the trip and enjoy the view.

column1: These are the sort of songs that oh-so subtly build a snowball into an icy boulder: the sleigh-belled
column2: drum-thumping pop of “Beneath the Air” and “Striped Light” initially suggest the sequel to Andorra that Caribou never made
column3: before gradually adding layer upon layer of counter-melodies and textural disorder to shatter any ’60s-retro illusions. “Burred Lens” works itself up into a pink-smoked synthphony as engrossing as anything on The Terror; “Earth II”—presumably a nod to the 1971 sci-fi flick
column4: not thenamesake doom-metal masterpiece—is the sort of deep-space kosmiche-rock odyssey that they’ll be blasting on the Orion in 2025 when cruising for other intelligent life in the universe.

column1: However
column2: the closing eight-minute epic “Spiral Jetty” suggests Absolutely Free’s newly holistic aesthetic is already being subjected to a deconstructive rethink
column3: with a jagged drum beat that cuts through the song’s glass-dome synth sheen and seemingly liberates the band from the more conventional song structures they imposed on themselves for much of the record. After all
column4: DD/MM/YYYY decided to break up the moment they felt their unpredictably spastic
column5:
instrument-swapping art-core attack was becoming a routine unto itself; don’t be surprised if the greater focus in effect on Absolutely Free is simply a means for the band to identify the peripheries yet to be explored.
