On a superficial level
column2: this collaboration between George Xylouris
column3: a lauded lute player from Greece
column4: and superb Australian post-punk drummer Jim White of the Dirty Three could be described as a cultural collision. But they work outside of their respective comfort zones
column5: transcending geographical boundaries to the point where it’s tricky to know where they’re coming from.

column1: Xylouris is the descendant of Greek music royalty. His uncle is Nikos Xylouris
column2: a national icon whose nickname is “archangel of Crete” because his songs are hugely influential and beloved
column3: and his dad is Antonis Xylouris
column4: a.k.a. Psarandonis
column5: a singer and lyra player who is well-regarded for pushing traditional folk music in new directions. George spent much of his childhood playing the lute and joining his father on his recordings and in concert; by using the lute as a lead instrument
column6: George
column7: too
column8: challenges musical expectations.

column1: White’s background
column2: on the other hand
column3: is decidedly post-punk; he co-founded the Dirty Three with Warren Ellis and Mick Turner in the early-'90s and went on to collaborate with Will Oldham
column4: PJ Harvey
column5: Nick Cave
column6: and many more. He's a magnificent
column7: multi-faceted
column8: and sensitive drummer with the perfect mix of ferocity and finesse.

column1: In Xylouris White
column2: the lute/drums configuration makes maps irrelevant
column3: at various points recalling Indian
column4: Eastern European
column5: African
column6: Middle Eastern
column7: Western
column8: and Mediterranean modes. There is jazz and punk here along with dashes of bluegrass
column9: klezmer
column10: and folk and yet it’s all conveyed seamlessly. At some points
column11: Xylouris’ approach to the lute recalls prepared guitar or fingerstyle practitioners like Glenn Jones
column12: himself a friend
column13: follower
column14: and collaborator of John Fahey. The searching and surprise of such exploration shines through in “Suburb”
column15: a virtuoso performance
column16: the lute bouncing back and forth between harmonic patterns and sturdy strumming
column17: simultaneously meshing with found and traditional percussion accents.

column1: Within the sequence of the record
column2: “Psarandonis Syrto” is sure-footed after Goats presents Xylouris White spending a couple of songs getting a feel for one another. Syrtos are traditional Greek dances that people bust out at parties and weddings but “Psarandonis Syrto” has a somber
column3: contemplative tone. On “Pulling the Bricks”
column4: each musical flourish is a gambit and a dare
column5: Xylouris leaning into his lute for a stretch of fast tremolo picking
column6: while White
column7: supportive yet minimal
column8: provides an up tempo pattern on a ride cymbal.

column1: It’s one of many instances on this record where pieces sound festive but brooding. “Old School Sousta” seems to be a sly piss-take at the Crete folk traditionalism that Xylouris employs in his busy
column2: insistent lute lick and that White bolsters
column3: mostly rolling tom drum thuds before the song climaxes with an off-kilter martial snare
column4: signifying a parade happily running its course.

column1: Xylouris and White are both capable of starting storms. When
column2: in their respective work
column3: they strike upon a moment where they wish to explode
column4: the jolt can be a remarkable feat of musical strength. Knowing this lends an eerie suspense to things like “Wind”
column5: which features some dense and dynamic interaction between the players but the builds are subtle. As the piece rumbles forth
column6: there are many instances where it feels like something huge is about to happen but the song teases and dissipates.

column1: The pensive joy within Goats stems from two musicians of seemingly disparate backgrounds
column2: communicating together with the tools they know best and as well as anyone else who has ever used them. Here though
column3: with new partners and parameters
column4: they’ve struck upon something challenging
column5: wholly inventive
column6:
and rewarding. 

"|19903.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19903-xylouris-white-goats/|7.4|Vish Khanna

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21132/homepage_large.7c5fcea2.jpg|Rips|32045.0|Ex Hex|[]|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2014-10-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:11.191473|"

You have to hand it to Ex Hex: they didn’t waste any time. Around this time last fall
column2: the Washington
column3: D.C.-based garage-pop trio
column4: lead by guitarist/singer Mary Timony
column5: had yet to play its first show. The only real evidence of the band’s existence was an early mix of the song “Hot and Cold”
column6: which Timony posted online
column7: then quickly removed. Within a month
column8: the band–which also includes bassist/singer Betsy Wright (Childballads) and drummer Laura Harris (Aquarium
column9: Benjy Ferree)—had joined up with Merge. By spring
column10: “Hot and Cold” had been remixed and released on a three-song single.

column1: And now
column2: only a year in comes Rips
column3: Ex Hex’s debut full-length. It’s the record of the summer
column4: albeit one that's arrived two months too late—a collection of perfectly lean power-pop tunes that evoke Tom Petty and the Runaways while conjuring the unruly energy of contemporary mid-fi bashers like Thee Oh Sees. Rips sounds fine on headphones or at home
column5: but it’s best enjoyed in the car where it’s possible to feel more perfectly tuned into the music’s steady velocity. The production is clean
column6: but not polished
column7: and the performances are tight. It doesn't sound like a record that was made in a hurry.

column1: An active musician since the early ’90s—first in Autoclave
column2: then in Helium
column3: and then as a solo artist—Timony hasn’t gotten her due in the last decade and change. After two solo records—Ex Hex (2005) and The Shapes We Make (2007)—were met with muted reactions
column4: she mostly called it quits on touring
column5: popping up only sporadically in groups like Garland of Hours and Soft Power. In 2010
column6: she joined Wild Flag
column7: a bi-coastal quartet that featured former Sleater-Kinney members Carrie Brownstein and Janet Weiss
column8: and seemingly caught a second wind. The band released one well-received full length and traveled extensively
column9: but quietly parted ways last fall. Wild Flag was a potentially tough act to follow for Timony
column10: partially because of the band's high visibility
column11: which was given extra charge through the ascendance of Brownstein’s comedy sketch show ""Portlandia"".

column1: So
column2: it’s heartening to find that Ex Hex is
column3: in a lot of ways
column4: a better band. Wild Flag's membership was split between D.C. and Portland and
column5: perhaps unintentionally
column6: the band's songwriting sometimes seemed to ping-pong between different sensibilities. Timony
column7: Harris
column8: and Wright seem more stylistically attuned to one another—after all
column9: they have a closer geographical relationship
column10: which enables them to practice regularly—and Wright's two contributions to Rips
column11: “How You Got That Girl” and “Radio On”
column12: both slot perfectly into the record's uniform
column13: neo-roller rink vibe.

column1: The songs look back to ’70s radio rock with some amount of yearning
column2: but Rips isn’t purely motivated by retromania. There’s a bit of environmental pressure built into this record: garage rock is adaptive music
column3: where minimum resources can yield maximum impact
column4: and it can thrive where rents are pricey and practice space is in short supply. You can write it with the people who are around
column5: it plays well in a basement and also on a stage
column6: and it’s easy to know when it’s working. If you can remember a garage rock song two minutes after it’s over
column7: then it’s probably a good one.

column1: All the genre demands is excitement
column2: and Rips is definitely exciting. It’s stripped down
column3: fast
column4: and physical; the songs mostly revolve around scrubby
column5: disappointing dudes and their failings
column6: but the message is never maudlin or tragic. Timony spent years speak-singing
column7: performing lyrics in a cool and detached tone that wavered in and out of pitch. But in Ex Hex
column8: she’s developed a more overtly melodic delivery. As a guitarist
column9: she’s playing a bit below her chops
column10: but her solos are tasteful and on point
column11: pitching up the emotional heft of a song once words won't cut it anymore.

column1: Over the years
column2: Timony's own musical style evolved into something fairly distinct
column3: a witchy-sounding and modestly mystical music that bred progressive rock and ’70s British folk with elements of D.C. post-punk. Some of that sound exists in Ex Hex
column4: too
column5: particularly in the modest pace of “Hot and Cold”
column6: but Rips mostly finds the band walking away from Timony's established voice and pushing toward something more direct and energetic—embracing the past
column7:
but also blowing things up and starting again.

"|19891.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19891-ex-hex-rips/|8.4|Aaron Leitko

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20899/homepage_large.71f12156.jpg|Heartleap|575.0|Vashti Bunyan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Cat'
column2:
'Dicristina']|2014-10-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:11.767934|"

Vashti Bunyan says that her third full-length album
column3: Heartleap
column4: will also be her last. Given her rate of production to this point
column5: we have no reason to doubt her. Bunyan’s first record
column6: Just Another Diamond Day
column7: came out in 1970 and quickly disappeared; later
column8: it was rediscovered
column9: developing a devoted cult among admirers of obscure folk. Following that renewed interest
column10: she dusted off the old Martin and recorded her second album
column11: Lookaftering
column12: in 2005. So that’s three full-lengths in 44 years
column13: which can be looked at in a few different ways. Given the nature of Bunyan’s art
column14: I’m inclined to praise her patience and her willingness to make music only when she feels like has something to say; in the era of the attention economy
column15: choosing not to put work in front of people
column16: to live a life away from the spotlight
column17: can be its own kind of statement. And if things turn out like she says
column18: Bunyan goes out on a high note: Heartleap is a subtle and beautiful album with a simmering intensity
column19: a perfect match of her hushed delivery and sharply observed vignettes that move between memories
column20: dreams
column21: and moments of quiet wonder.

column1: Heartleap would be a poetic place to end because
column3: Bunyan’s style of music has no particular cultural currency. In the middle of the last decade
column4: when the indie world was enamored with the Incredible String Band and The Anthology of American Folk Music and acoustic music that was both familiar and strange was in vogue
column5: Bunyan was drafted as a kind of godmother of a small movement. Her initial obscurity obviously added to her aura and Diamond Day became one of those records passed around like a secret; by the time she made the Prospect Hummer EP with Animal Collective in 2005
column6: her place in the landscape was secure
column7: and Lookaftering showed that she was capable of picking up where she left off. But Heartleap has no significant context surrounding it—it’s just a record
column8: one that doesn’t have the burden of making up for lost time. And the facts of its creation—Bunyan wrote and recorded much of it alone
column9: over the course of seven years—underscore the point
column10: making it feel like a low-stakes private dispatch
column11: one destined to reach the people it needs to reach.

column1: No one sounds like Vashti Bunyan
column2: in part because most people would be afraid to. Her voice is defined by its limitations
column3: hovering between singing and whispering
column4: but it’s also an instrument of great expressivity. Because she sings without vibrato in a quavering register
column5: it’s often described as “childlike.” This surely had something to do with her appeal in the mid-2000s freak-folk moment—Devendra Banhart and Animal Collective
column6: in particular
column7: forged an aesthetic out of regression
column8: privileging instinct and raw imagination. But Bunyan’s lyrics tell a different story
column9: one of graceful maturity and wisdom.

column1: Bunyan has said in interviews that she was intimidated when she was starting out because she felt she could never measure up to Joni Mitchell
column2: which is fair. But the truth is that Mitchell
column3: for all her genius
column4: could never do what Bunyan does: she crafts miniature worlds
column5: settings where small gestures can be imbued with great meaning. “Mother” offers an image of a girl watching through a crack in the door while her mother
column6: unaware that she’s being observed
column7: dresses and sings softly to herself. It’s the kind of moment that burns into all of our memories
column8: where nothing really “happens” but somehow we remember every detail; these snapshots are where our awareness of the world and our place in it expands
column9: just a little
column10: and few artists capture them as well as Vashti Bunyan.

column1: The act of perception is a recurring theme (“The Boy”)
column2: as is the limitation of language (“Gunpowder”)
column3: but the overriding subject is the mystery of life itself
column4: how we live and die
column5: what it feels like to be trapped inside of a body
column6: how we balance our need for human connection and our need for solitude. The backdrop for Bunyan’s songs could hardly be simpler and more minimal—bits of guitar and synth
column7: most of which she plays herself—but it’s all beautifully produced and clear
column8: the instruments doing what they need to do to get the songs across and nothing more.

column1: “I do remember what an old friend told me/ He said ‘don’t you go worrying about me
column2: I’m only sad as I want to be’
column3: ” she sings in “Holy Smoke”
column4: and it’s a fitting takeaway from this album
column5: and indeed Bunyan’s recorded output as a whole. Her work is a testament to the power of even the quietest music to help us feel things deeply
column6:
an experience that lasts for a few minutes that we can return to for a lifetime.

"|19673.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19673-vashti-bunyan-heartleap/|7.8|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21119/homepage_large.5531124d.jpg|Give My Love to London|1442.0|Marianne Faithfull|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Easy Sound']|2014-10-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:12.378148|"

“Give my love to London
column2: ” Marianne Faithfull sings on the title track to her latest album. At first it sounds like a friendly request
column3: but it soon becomes a threat: “The river’s runny bloody
column4: the towers tumbling down
column5: ” she sings
column6: not exactly horrified by the tableau. “I’m singing ‘Pirate Jenny’ as the blackship’s bearing down.” It’s a sly reference. The second most popular number form Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht’s Threepenny Opera (the first being “Mack the Knife”)
column7: “Pirate Jenny” is a stout song about bloody wish fulfillment: A bitter and beleaguered hotel maid imagines a marauding pirate ship destroying the city and murdering all the people who treated her so cruelly
column8: ending with Jenny escaping with the swashbucklers and scallywags.

column1: Faithfull famously performed the tune in the mid 1990s during a Threepenny revival in Dublin
column2: and her fascination with Weimar-era musical theater inspired her 1997 album 20th Century Blues
column3: which includes her best version of the song. On “Give My Love to London”
column4: Faithfull reimagines herself as Pirate Jenny returning to the scene of her greatest triumph and surveying a London still in ruins. Although the final verse resituates the song
column5: it’s not hard to imagine Faithfull as the conquering anti-hero
column6: especially considering how she was run out of the city in the late ‘60s for the same behavior that earned her male peers—including and especially Mick Jagger—their lucrative reputations as bad boys.

column1: And yet
column2: there is some affection in “Give My Love to London
column3: ” which was co-written with Steve Earle
column4: now a Londoner himself. Faithfull navigates the bouncy melody gracefully and generously
column5: evoking the easy bonhomie of old friends who have long put any ill will behind them. The song announces an album that will confront the past
column6: her own and our own
column7: as though trying to sever it from the present. This is not necessarily a memoir set to music
column8: mainly because these songs find Faithfull playing roles other than herself. As a result
column9: it’s her best and most daring album of this century
column10: featuring some of her heaviest and most haunting performances.

column1: Faithfull has spent most of the time since 20th Century Blues fashioning herself into rock’s grand dame
column2: an avatar of European decadence redeemed into something like old-world authority. Working with Britpop survivors (Damon Albarn
column3: Jarvis Cocker) as well as American alt-rockers (Beck
column4: Billy Corgan)
column5: she's made a handful of fine albums that persistently reinforce her reputation as a formidable interpreter of others' songs
column6: as if anyone still though otherwise. Before the Poison and Easy Come Easy Go may have put her in touch with a younger generation of artists who considered her both a hero and an influence
column7: but Give My Love to London is something else entirely. Working with Roger Waters
column8: Nick Cave
column9: Anna Calvi
column10: and a band that features Ed Harcourt
column11: Portishead’s Adrian Utley
column12: and members of the Bad Seeds
column13: she has created an album that bristles with danger and even roils with anger.

column1: But it also has moments of disarming humor. Toward the end of Give My Love to London
column2: she gingerly covers Leonard Cohen’s “Going Home”
column3: a late-career rumination on the nature of creativity. It’s a monologue delivered by a muse who considers Cohen “a lazy bastard living in a suit”—in other words
column4: a tool no different than a pen or quill. Faithfull does not replace his name with hers; instead
column5: she plays the muse herself
column6: claiming his triumphs as her own. It becomes a melancholic hymn to age and experience
column7: but more wittily
column8: it’s a funny and fitting turnabout for a songwriter who has repeatedly exploited his female subjects for his own spiritual gain (see
column9: for example
column10: “Chelsea Hotel No. 2”).

column1: Faithfull has always conveyed a sensual gravity with that gravelly voice of hers
column2: but the melancholy on Give My Love to London is tinged with angst and disaffection—perhaps inspired by her recent bout with cancer
column3: or the back injury that left her bedridden
column4: or just by a sense of alienation from a world that makes less and less sense by the day. For most artists of her generation
column5: such topicality can sound either haughty (Neil Young’s recent orchestral protest song
column6: ""Who's Gonna Stand Up"") or simply cloistered from the rest of the world (David Crosby’s latest album). But the theatricality of Faithfull’s performances lend weight to a song like “True Lies”
column7: with its pendulum guitar riff and accusing lyrics: “True lies from your twisted little mind!” she glowers
column8: her outrage absolutely withering.

column1: “Mother Wolf”
column2: which Faithfull co-wrote with Patrick Leonard
column3: may be her finest moment on Give My Love to London. It consists primarily of a single verse and chorus
column4: each repeated throughout the song
column5: but Faithfull sings each iteration with new dramatic emphasis. On the first time through
column6: she delivers the allegorical lyrics almost passively
column7: as though looking down on humanity from some high cloud. The next time
column8: she has descended to earth and become a human amid the earthly horror of war. Faithfull doesn’t sing so much as she spits the words
column9: her delivery grinding against the song’s meter. “How you disgust me!” she growls
column10: turning those syllables into something acrid and poisonous and fundamentally ugly. Her performance meets violence with more violence
column11: and the song’s pummeling pace and dark catharsis simultaneously underscore and undermine the song. The pirates are attacking London
column12:
and Faithfull is leading them onward. 

"|19879.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19879-marianne-faithfull-give-my-love-to-london/|8.0|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21179/homepage_large.a855e19f.jpg|Killing Season EP|7288.0|Kode9 & the Spaceape|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2014-10-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:13.897001|"

If first-wave UK dubstep had a voice
column2: it belonged to Stephen Gordon. From his teaming with Kode9 on the first-ever Hyperdub release to pivotal appearances on tracks by Burial
column3: the Bug
column4: and Martyn
column5: the poet and vocalist known as Spaceape lent his ten-ton doomsayer croak to dozens of definitive works of music and was positioned as the Linton Kwesi Johnson of the post-7/7
column6: surveillance-state UK. His death of cancer earlier this month was a saddening shock
column7: the second time this year after DJ Rashad's tragic passing that a Kode9-championed artist passed away within a week of a promising new EP.

column1: The main difference is that Spaceape knew he could be taken from us at any moment. The condition he had spent years living with informed his earlier work in ways that are only now becoming clear. Following the allusions in Kode9 teamup Black Sun (""Black Smoke"") and his 2012 self-released solo EP Xorcism (""He Gave His Body Over to Science"")
column2: the five-song EP Killing Season further addresses Spaceape's physical condition and his ways of not only coping with it but extrapolating his own state of health to the sense of unease and trepidation that everybody stares down sooner or later.

column1: Spaceape's voice is typically known for its deep resonance and chest-out intensity
column2: and his presence on these tracks brings a few different shades of that tension to the fore. There's a nuanced shift from the grinding
column3: exertion-wracked snarl of ""Chasing a Beast"" to the seething contemplation of ""Devil Is a Liar""
column4: frustration and foreboding shot through with a need to connect with the listener. But his fervor borders on pleading with ""Heart""
column5: the song that gives the EP its title and connects the tactile fragility of the human body to the forces that break it; here
column6: his anger is shot through with empathetic sorrow that carries through the remainder of the EP.

column1: Kode9's production has rarely sounded more in tune with his longtime collaborator than it does over these brief cuts
column2: his spacious yet bass-heavy minimalism laid out to powerful effect as it keeps Spaceape's sharply articulated delivery in mind. While the instrumental-vocal pairings in their music has often been rendered interchangeable by design—their live sets frequently switched up beats and acapellas for effect—there are allusions and juxtapositions on Killing Season that make the mindstate of the words and the music inseparable.

column1: The handful of cuts on this record play to both artists' strengths here
column2: particularly the sprinting-through-quicksand blues lope of ""Chasing a Beast"" and the decaying
column3: EKG-beep-inflected bass drone of ""Autumn Has Come"". But it's the briefest
column4: sparsest one that cuts right to the core: There's a brittle
column5: bell-like analog synth that chimes through the course of ""Pictures on the Wall
column6: acting as the song's only instrumental element. Whether it's sourced from the electric piano/guitar intro to Steely Dan's ""Deacon Blues"" or simply evokes it by loose resemblance
column7: Spaceape's bitter commentary on the ""tired old perceptions of human introspection""—taunting him from a hospital room he can't leave—feels like a clear-eyed but emotional counterpoint to the escapist boho romanticism of dying behind the wheel. Stephen Gordon didn't get the death he or anybody who heard his voice would have chosen. But his perspective on it—and the way it closes the book on a memorable
column8:
influential career—is what needed to be heard.

"|19929.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19929-kode9-the-spaceape-killing-season-ep/|7.8|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21144/homepage_large.2efd0fb0.jpg|Negative Qualities|31024.0|Single Mothers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hot Charity']|2014-10-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:14.458389|"

Another Saturday night
column2: and the last thing Single Mothers frontman Drew Thomson wants to talk about is fucking Henry Miller. Yet
column3: there he is
column4: cornered by comp. lit. majors
column5: prattling on about their vintage typewriters
column6: their well-stocked bookshelves
column7: and—horror of horrors—their theses. ""I don't care about your first editions
column8: Thomson vents midway through ""Marbles""
column9: a highlight among highlights from Single Mothers' debut LP Negative Qualities
column10:
before adding ""at least I don't pretend my whole life's held together by bookends.""

Kiss-offs
column11: kvetching fits
column12: and a self-awareness Thomson himself deems ""crippling"": if nothing else
column13: Negative Qualities is 2014's most aptly-titled LP. An airing of grievances in full-length form
column14: Negative Qualities takes all comers: from starry-eyed barflies to farmer's market-shopping Saturn drivers
column15: nobody comes out of Negative Qualities looking too hot. Certainly not Thomson; shortly after he's blah-blahed his way to the bar through the McSweeney's-spouting master's candidates
column16: Thomson's labeled himself a hypocrite
column17: the kind of part-time shitheel who sees ""the power in inflicting pain."" ""Tried to fight it
column18: tried to hide it"" goes one such self-examination
column19: ""but fuck it—I am who I am
column20:
and I'm not just gonna change.""

Thomson's lyrics are at once Single Mothers' main attraction and—for some listeners—their presumptive sticking point. It's rare to hear a lyricist lay out all their garbage in quite this fashion without putting a little more narrative distance between themselves and the words on the page. Thomson doesn't do that
column21: not really; on ""Ketamine""—in which he cops to assisted infidelity and dubs himself ""good at avoiding things and bleeding into the scenery""—he actually calls himself out by name
column22: leaving little question as to who's at the center of these songs.

column1: Throughout Negative Qualities
column2: a filter-averse Thomson does not exactly flatter himself; even the grand fuck-you he throws to a presumptive ex-lover on ""Money""—oddly enough
column3: the album's prettiest song—skirts an awfully fine line between cutting and petty. While it's safe to assume Thomson is exaggerating certain Negative Qualities for effect
column4: spending 26 minutes with Thomson's dirty laundry can leave one feeling a little unclean. Still
column5: with Negative Qualities spraying insults at anyone who dares get too close
column6: you're probably not supposed to like Thomson any more than he likes you. Like Nayvadius says
column7:
he's just being honest.

While Thomson rants
column8: Single Mothers rage. That nourish guitar and loud-quiet-loud (well
column9: maybe not ""quiet"") dynamics of ""Feel Shame"" and that atypically anthemic turn on closer ""Money"" notwithstanding
column10: Single Mothers' gnarled post-hardcore proves every bit as unrelenting as Thomson's lyrical bloodshedding. It's not long on subtlety
column11: but the music is nevertheless compelling
column12: a full-on tantrum rendered in headknock drums and skull-smashing guitar. At times
column13: this onslaught effectively drowns out Thomson's voice
column14: obscuring the finer points of his fuck-all-ya'll manifesto in a sea of feedback. But that synergy mostly works; you lean in closer
column15: only to be told to give the dude some space. Thomson's not a singer
column16: he's a screamer
column17: and in typically self-deprecating fashion
column18: he's complained in interviews about a lack of range in his normal register. Still
column19: for a guy who seems to see his larynx as a sparring partner
column20: he gets a surprising amount done with it
column21:
sneering and gnashing his way through these songs with an impressively deft balance of sarcasm and self-loathing.

Spending the better part of a half-hour inside Thomson's head might not be your idea of a good time
column22: and the unflinching—and frequently unflattering—Negative Qualities
column24: isn't pretty. But the biggest mark against Negative Qualities isn't that Thomson's offering up too much of himself
column25: but that he's snuck just a little too much of somebody else in there
column27: Hold Steady/Lifter Puller frontman Craig Finn. At times
column29: a fan—seems to be directly channeling Finn
column31: more biting Finn of Fiestas and Fiascos and Almost Killed Me. It's not just that so many of these songs are either set in bars
column32: or the shitty little apartments you return to when the bars close for the night; several of these songs treat the tavern as a tabernacle (""Bar lights look like halos/ Making all the chicks here look like angels"") or otherwise lift from Finn's frequent juxtaposition of sensations (""A soft pillow on hard pavement""). It's a little strange
column33: on a record so firmly embedded in Thomson's skull
column34:
to hear the occasional echo of somebody else's voice.

Still

some 40 seconds before ""Money""—and Negative Qualities—grinds to a halt. Might wanna save the Henry Miller talk for somebody else.

""All those brash young studs/ They have no idea what it’s like up here
column2: Danish punk Elias Bender Rønnenfelt moans over a rolling midtempo drag on the title track to Iceage’s brilliant third album
column3: Plowing Into the Field of Love. The line first scans as a refined upgrade of the band’s usual alienation—a dark basement swapped for an ivory tower. But it also has the same sardonic self-awareness that coats the instantly iconic video for Plowing’s first single
column4: ""The Lord’s Favorite""
column5: which featured the <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NHHEcmZtJvY"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">really
column6: really
column7: really ridiculously good-looking Rønnenfelt and his youthful comrades smearing lipstick on themselves
column8: taking champagne baths
column9: and enjoying cocktails with (d)ice in their glasses. ""Part of me wants to hurt you/ Tear in your hair/ But I don’t do that now
column10: the singer admits
column11: staring into the camera and lighting a cigarette as the band takes on tricky cowpunk shapes underneath his voice; it is
column12: at the least
column13: a unique approach to acknowledging newfound maturity.

column1: Indeed
column2: Plowing Into the Field of Love finds Iceage growing up on their own terms. Up to this point
column3: they’ve developed incrementally
column4: taking a knife to the rough-around-the-edges teenage fury of the 2011 debut LP New Brigade and cutting fresh
column5: sharp ribbons of flesh on last year’s refined sophomore effort You’re Nothing. Essentially a bolder
column6: somewhat brighter update of what came before
column7: You’re Nothing contained few hints of the baroque terrain that Iceage are traversing now. But the dense lockstep drone that closed out that record’s ""Morals"" suggested that Iceage could slow things down without losing their dead-eyed sense of passion.

column1: On Plowing
column2: Iceage make a radical shift away from their hack-and-slash past and towards what is
column3: for them
column4: unexplored territory—morose piano balladeering
column5: sprightly country-rock figures
column6: distinctly Irish-sounding drinking anthems. Their journey mirrors the transformation that the punks of the '80s underwent when devising the perfect alchemy of hardcore’s youthful burn and Americana’s weary shuffle (see Mekons
column7: X
column8: Meat Puppets). So Iceage aren’t exploring new sounds on Plowing
column9: culturally speaking
column10: but nothing they’ve done in the past five years suggested that they were capable of such a transformation. Despite the new approach
column11: Iceage still sound like themselves
column12: so when Asger Valentin’s mournful trumpet cuts through the rolling stomp of ""Glassy Eyed
column13: Dormant and Veiled""
column14: the most surprising thing about the instrument isn’t its mere presence
column15: but how at-home it sounds amidst the band’s newly considered arrangements.

column1: A sense of steadiness
column2: a measured approach to abandon
column3: marks Iceage’s transformation from a very good band to a Great Band on Plowing. While New Brigade contained bursts of unexpected melodic sweetness
column4: the gruesome You’re Nothing often sounded like it was held together with little more than congealed blood and matted hair. On Plowing
column5: the band swings to the opposite pole
column6: sounding threateningly tight even when walking the edge of full collapse
column7: similar to '80s-era Sonic Youth’s balance of control and dissonance. Dark piano chords serve as an anchor for ""How Many""'s buzzsaw guitars
column8: embracing a half-time tempo change at the song’s midsection that crashes through the burning scenery; ""Cimmerian Shade"" kicks off with a hollow pound courtesy of drummer <span class=""s1"">Dan Kjær Nielsen
column9: accented by guitars both brawny and thin-sounding that abrasively scrape against each other.

column1: Album centerpiece ""Stay"" somewhat hilariously opens as a waltz in 3/4 time
column2: speeding up uncontrollably at the command of Rønnenfelt’s most operative
column3: visually arresting lyrical aside on Plowing (""Hands/ Become thundering hooves"") before building to a furious burn that stands as Iceage’s finest moment of feral aggression. Plowing’s strangest moment
column4: then
column5: comes in the form of its most straightforward tune: ""Abundant Living""
column6: the record’s only sub-three-minute song that one could reasonably listen to while skipping down a sidewalk. Jakob Tvilling Pless wields a jaunty mandolin figure over the band’s besotted sway
column7: which takes on a Gaelic punk resemblance as Rønnenfelt promises in a miserable cadence
column8: ""I’ll bring it all down here with me/ Soaked in alcohol.""

column1: Rønnenfelt’s lyrics are front and center throughout Plowing—partially a result of his improved English
column2: as he told Pitchfork recently—and they paint the type of self-portrait you’d expect from a punkish youth in his twenties: fatalistic
column3: ferociously inquisitive
column4: drunk on the promise of tomorrow and even drunker on whatever’s flowing from the tap at this very moment. Images of absent fathers
column5: prison cells
column6: and drowning are evoked
column7: and the album’s parting line—""I am plowing into the field of love/ They will place me in a hearse""—reads as poetically grim as the limited perspective of youth allows. ""I have a sense of utopia/ Of what I truly ought to do
column8: Rønnenfelt proclaims in the middle of ""How Many""
column9: and that sense of gritted-teeth naïveté comes to define Plowing Into the Field of Love as a whole. This is the sound of Iceage finding a balance between getting older and seeking immortality by way of leaping into an abandoned-lot fire head-first. It’s beautiful and ugly at the same time and
column10: for now
column11:
Iceage have found their own unstable sense of peace.

"|19806.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19806-iceage-plowing-into-the-field-of-love/|8.5|Larry Fitzmaurice

It may not have maintained the low-key genre-fusing mystique that it had back in 2011
column3: but SBTRKT's highly enjoyable nexus of R&B
column4: bass music
column5: house
column6: and dubstep on his self-titled debut still sounds as sleekly well-balanced as it did four years back. The music's appeal hasn't changed
column7: but what it means has

column9: self-contained signature sound

column1: What SBTRKT means now
column2: however -- especially in the wake of a you-had-to-be-there live album and three underdone instrumental EPs tellingly named Transitions—is weighted down by the old expectation-dashing ""what could have been"" question. It's not always a given
column3: but the sophomore slump for rising artists pushing into pop crossover potential is frequent enough that even looking at the guest list for Wonder Where We Land looks like a warning that he's tried to mess with the formula Too Much Too Soon. And the music bears it out: if you think the idea of an album that tries to incorporate scene-stealing hip-hop and indie rock figures into a once emotionally nuanced style is ominous enough
column4: the execution is somehow even more chaotic.

column1: Let's dig to the core first: three years would be a long time to wait for a slight re-envisioning of what worked the first time
column2: but the finer points on this record nearly approach the better midpoints of the debut. Sampha's coolly ambivalent yet reservedly powerful vocals have always been one of the stronger elements in SBTRKT's arsenal
column3: and he's all over this record: Fighting against a subwoofer earthquake with multitracked
column4: reverb-blurred warmth that even makes the phrase ""what the fuck is that?"" sound cosmic on the title track
column5: trembling his way towards a punch-back chorus on ""Temporary View""
column6: alternately reining in and showing off his rangy melisma as he slides through the stripped-back disco-house of ""Gon Stay"". For an album that features one of Jessie Ware's best icily delivered leads since Devotion (""Problem (Solved)"")
column7: it's saying a lot that Sampha is the best thing going on this record.

column1: It's not saying too much
column2: though. The two best singers on the debut are
column3: perhaps not coincidentally
column4: the two best singers here
column5: while the bigger-name guests—the ones that stretch SBTRKT's sonic reach the furthest—just don't work. Ezra Koenig isn't exactly the most egregious feature here
column6: but the enigmatic jokiness of ""New Dorp. New York."" isn't done any favors by the free-associative lyricism. Are Black Israelites supposed to be wacky NYC cultural flavor? And is the line about ""baseball bats that never hit home runs"" a reference to threatening weaponry or just another joke at the Mets' expense? The two hip-hop crossovers trip up the album even more
column7: not so much because they're not that good but because they just don't click with the rest of the album: singer/rapper Raury's run-on restrained intensity brings a personal edge that isn't done justice by its ambiguous coffeehouse surroundings. As for A$AP Ferg's soul-baring
column8: shakily-singing turn on unlikely closer ""Voices in My Head""—detailing his self-medicating efforts to deal with his father's death—it feels so much like an ambush of untethered feeling that it pretty much washes away the more subdued pleasures of the Sampha
column9: Jessie Ware
column10: and Denai Moore cuts that precede it.

column1: With all the work to try and incorporate these far-afield guest vocalists aside
column2: it's worth noting that the production itself is more reliant on them than ever. Underneath them
column3: the music is often flat and unadventurous
column4: tasteful where it could stand to be raucous and rigid where it needs to be limber. A two-minute arpeggio-riddled uptempo cut called ""Lantern"" is the most energizing moment here
column5: as the rest of the backing tracks lean so heavily on darkly hovering minor-key bass murmurs
column6: gloomy piano chords
column7: and soppily distorted digital strings that it's easy to forget how intriguingly off-kilter some of his drums can be. From here on out
column8: expecting SBTRKT to promise anything in particular is going to feel like a gamble
column9:
and probably a pointless one. But at least it's clearer than ever that there's a side to him which he's stronger at expressing.

It was the Platonic ideal of a 2014 chart-topper (Mustard on the beat—check; cheeky interpolation of a throwback hit—check; benevolent but ultimately useless Drake remix—check)
column2: so it’s no huge surprise that “2 On”
column3: the star-making lead single from Tinashe’s debut album
column4: Aquarius
column5: proved to be a bit of a red herring. And while it’s still probably the best song of the Los Angeles singer/songwriter’s career
column6: ultimately that’s a good thing. Tinashe’s post-“2 On” rise may have seemed sudden (and especially glaring
column7: in a year where male voices overwhelmed the R&B charts)
column8: but the 21-year-old is hardly a rookie. After devoting most of her teenage years to the Stunners
column9: a Vitamin C-founded quintet that briefly toured with Justin Bieber
column10: she spent the last few years at work on a steady stream of promising
column11: if unpolished
column12: mixtapes recorded in her home studio. Those tapes—filled with dusky ballads for spooning a laptop and sounding quite at home among the glut of zoned-out
column13: “alternative” R&B artists—got her a deal with RCA Records
column14: but if the distance between her gently trippy mixtape work and the glossy ratchet-pop of “2 On” seemed potentially unbridgeable
column15: it’s because she never intended to bridge it in the first place. Instead
column16: Aquarius is an anomaly in an age of major label standardization: a debut done unmistakably on Tinashe’s own terms.

column1: Much of Aquarius feels like an ambitious extension of Tinashe’s mixtape tracks
column2: elevated to professional quality where they once felt muddled while leaving breadcrumb trails of idiosyncratic details leading back to her bedroom-producer past—distorted guitar solos
column3: eerie found-sound interludes
column4: somber spoken word bits. Sure
column5: sometimes it’s a little much: wide-eyed lines like “What is truth
column6: if truth is subjective?” read more like “Ever seen the back of a $20 bill on weed?” similar to peer Jhené Aiko
column7: another recent indie-to-major transitioner with a penchant for dorm-room stoner koans. Mostly
column8: though
column9: Tinashe’s polished her act without dulling her edge
column10: as the most interesting tracks on Aquarius come closest to approaching anything remotely like a radio hit—consider “How Many Times”
column11: a Janet Jackson-referencing
column12: late-'80s worshipping duet with Future so sultry it renders his shouty “Sh!t” flow as aphrodisiacal.

column1: But Tinashe's most straightforward songs come with dark subtexts. Production-wise
column2: second single “Pretend” has all the bite of an Avril Lavigne ballad playing during the break between ""Lizzie McGuire"" episodes (not necessarily a knock—somehow Detail’s mushiest productions are always his best) but the lyrics find Tinashe pretending her deadbeat boyfriend
column3: played by A$AP Rocky
column4: isn’t a scumbag so they can get it in a few more times. “All Hands On Deck”
column5: the album’s sole answer to “2 On”'s club-readiness
column6: has shadowy corners not often found in radio ratchetry
column7: and that’s not counting the song's pan-flute breakdown: what first reads as a blithe dance instructional swiftly devolves into caustic post-break-up stunting
column8: as Tinashe snarls
column9: “Kiss the old me goodbye/ She's dead and gone.”

column1: Though Tinashe’s held on to the self-reliant tendencies that guided her mixtape days
column2: the sense of disembodiment
column3: sometimes verging on aloofness
column4: that often present in her early work—a recurring pitfall of the production-driven “alt-R&B” she once fit into—is mercifully absent. Somewhat paradoxically
column5: too
column6: working with a bigger team has made it clearer than ever that ultimately
column7: she’s calling the shots; even with such a breadth of instantly recognizable collaborators
column8: from Mike WiLL Made It to Clams Casino to Devonté Hynes
column9: the vision remains wholly Tinashe’s throughout. As she’s shed the trappings of distinctly 2010s R&B for something less easily time-stamped
column10: she’s revealed a new and very telling set of inspirations
column11: unmistakably the product of coming of age in the Y2K era of R&B
column12: where Janet Jackson and Aaliyah gracefully countered choreography-happy
column13: big-budget smashes with flashes of something darker and deeply personal.

column1: Tinashe has a bit of the coy
column2: collected swagger of less canonical
column3: ""Total Request Live""-era mainstays such as Mya or Christina Milian
column4: too—especially in the sauntering “Thug Cry”—but for all that early-'00s worship
column5: Tinashe’s unshakeable faith in her own vision could only really pay off in a climate like right now
column6: where a record deal is hardly the end-all be-all to a legitimate career. If the risk-taking featured on Aquarius doesn’t pan out
column7:
she can do it herself—she already has—so why not use the momentum of the biggest song of your career to propel you in the complete opposite direction?

The centerpiece of Sam Amidon’s fifth proper record is a nine-minute song called “Lily-O”
column2: which opens with Amidon singing a lengthy a cappella epilogue about three suitors courting three ladies. It’s austerely quiet until two minutes into the song
column3: when a second instrument enters—a single crackle of electric guitar
column4: sharp and splintery
column5: like a log sparking in a fireplace. Amidon is settling in for a long story that is less about marriage and more about betrayal
column6: violence
column7: death
column8: and loss. “Lily-O”
column9: we soon learn
column10: is a murder ballad
column11: with one brutal stabbing followed by a long list of bequeathals. “Oh what will you leave to your brother John
column12: oh Lily-O?” he asks. “The rope and gallows to hang him on.”

column1: Despite the grimness of the subject matter
column2: Amidon never raises his voice
column3: preferring instead to deliver the tale with a calm that borders on psychopathic. He would rather let the other instruments express the characters’ hope and grief and outrage as best they can: that electric guitar gives way to a jittery acoustic strum
column4: which is joined by a skittering snare drum and some stray electronic bloops and bleeps. Sounding as though the song’s guts are spilling out
column5: the din is perhaps intended to evoke the psychological state of the murderer
column6: or to provoke some moral response in the listener. The players certainly are up to the task: Amidon is an accomplished banjo player and fiddler
column7: the scion of a family steeped in folk tradition
column8: and he’s joined by the ace rhythm section of bassist Shahzad Ismaily and drummer Chris Vatalaro. And that chiming
column9: slicing guitar is played by Bill Frisell
column10: the legendarily eclectic musician who has performed with John Zorn
column11: Ryuichi Sakamoto
column12: and Elvis Costello
column13: among too many others to list.

column1: So why does both “Lily-O” and the album of the same title fall so flat? Recording in Reykjavik with Valgeir Sigurðsson (who has produced albums by Björk and Bonnie “Prince” Billy)
column2: the makeshift band captured most of the album in single takes
column3: playing together in the studio and indulging only minimal overdubs. Rather than producing a more urgent album or at least one that sounds rawer or wilder in its performances
column4: Lily-O too often sounds distracted by small flourishes—the jazzy piano interlude between “Won’t Turn Back” and “Maid Lamenting”
column5: for instance—at the expense of variation and shape. These songs are all pitched in the same mode and the same mood
column6: as though each expresses the same dreamy reverie. As a result
column7: the whole is persistently wistful
column8: as its uniform tone overrides the nuance of the actual subject matter. In other words
column9: the sorrowful “Maid Lamenting” and the contented “Devotion” strike the same chord of melancholy as the work song “Walkin' Boss” and “Groundhog Variations”
column10: which is about frying and eating whistle-pig brains.

column1: Somehow
column2: Lily-O is Amidon’s most deliberate-sounding album
column3: despite the spontaneity of its creation. He’s a fine instrumentalist with a wily sense of rhythm
column4: especially when he bangs out the tricky patterns of “Pat Do This
column5: Pat Do That”
column6: but he can be a limited vocalist. Amidon sings every line in the past tense
column7: even if it’s not conjugated as such
column8: as though these songs are all memories fluttered around his brain during some lonely evening. The title track sounds like some repressed trauma gently resurfacing
column9: yet Amidon cannot make those horrors sound immediate or dangerous. Every drama and every emotion sounds like it is safely put away in the past
column10: with nothing to disrupt the present or to affect the living. On previous albums
column11: Amidon has scrambled our sense of time by including old-time covers of new-time songs like Tim McGraw’s “My Old Friend” and Tears for Fears’ “Head Over Heels”
column12: but there is nothing on Lily-O to break the spell these musicians have too carefully cast. In other words
column13:
there is nothing to get Amidon out of his own head or out of our collective past.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21053/homepage_large.c83f0f1d.jpg|Dark Space III I|32500.0|Darkspace|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Avantgarde']|2014-10-09 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:17.198499|"

When black metal bands speak of coldness
column2: they usually refer to unforgiving Scandinavian winters
column3: constructing them as both majestic
column4: icy kingdoms and as permafrost hells. Immortal set their infamous videos in Arctic environments and branded themselves as ""Blizzard Beasts""
column5: while the guitar tones of influential second-wave bands like Darkthrone and Satyricon resembled the winds of harsh winter storms; Imperial Crystalline Entombment took this obsession to its most absurd extreme
column6: cloaking themselves entirely in white and envisioning a new Ice Age with their sole album Apocalyptic End in White.

column1: Swiss trio Darkspace are concerned with a different coldness
column2: though—specifically
column3: the void and expansive unknown of the universe. Since their first (and only) demo in 2002
column4: Dark Space -I
column5: they’ve created and nurtured a style of black metal heavily indebted to dark ambient
column6: both in the punishing drone of their riffs and in the minimal
column7: chasmic soundscapes. Darkspace—comprised of Wroth and Zhaaral on guitars and vocals
column8: and Zorgh on bass and vocals—apply corpsepaint to their faces like fellow traditionalists
column9: but their appearance is slick and menacing
column10: as if H.R. Giger was their creative consultant. They’re a futuristic black metal group that’s interested in the heavens
column11: but not necessarily divinity. Dark Space III I is their latest album six years after Dark Space III
column12: and the new record represents an apt continuation of their signature style
column13: cementing them as one of the most daring and underrated names in black metal.

column1: III I is divided into three long chunks
column2: leading off with the 27-minute-plus behemoth “Dark 4.18”. Glitchy spurts crack the veneer of the Lustmord-like drone
column3: resembling space debris whizzing by. Pulsating drums enter just before a distant lead pattern
column4: and then the real punishment
column5: the oppressive
column6: almost speedcore-like rhythms
column7: set in. The drum machine gives “Dark 4.18” a mechanical blast that almost borders on EBM
column8: which connects the dots between black metal and electronic music
column9: genres that embrace repetition as a means to an end. “Dark 4.18” is not dance music
column10: mind you—the blasting is relentless
column11: with guitars howling in pain to the stars above. No band captures cosmic indifference better.

column1: One of Darkspace’s strengths is that they incorporate familiar metal elements and
column2: through their galactic lens
column3: render them foreign. They can’t help but be influenced by the mid-paced mastery of fellow Swiss resident and current Triptykon/ex-Celtic Frost frontman Tom G. Warrior
column4: which is plenty evident on “Dark 4.19”. The main riff is a groove held hostage
column5: almost too catchy for its own good; it almost threatens the concentration that III I demands of the listener. There's tapping solos far removed from instructional video wankery
column6: trailing towards parts unknown—rare flickers of light
column7: with no flash. Wroth is also the man behind Paysage d’Hiver (where he records under “Wintherr”)
column8: a project that focuses exclusively on the frostbitten side of black metal; here
column9: he mutates one form of coldness into another
column10: seamlessly.

column1: “Dark 4.20” finds Darkspace taking a meaner turn in their disorientation. The groove riffs sound choppier
column2: and the blasting only grows more cacophonic as the song progresses. There are faint screams and growls throughout
column3: which highlight Darkspace's tendency to de-emphasize vocals on III I. All three members are screaming into space
column4: but that’s a lot of area to cover
column5: and that helplessness is essential to Darkspace’s vision. At full speed
column6: the guitars create a choral effect that's louder and more capable of communicating a sense of terror than any human voice could. It all ends with another low-rumbling hum
column7: the nearly-quiet discomfort the album began with. There’s no comedown here—the battery stops
column8: its oxygen stripped.

column1: III I is not an album of convenience. Music this pitch-black demands a state of isolation
column2: from light and from people
column3: to be fully appreciated. This is an album that takes the listener through a seemingly endless mirror of our anxieties about what constitutes “beyond”—beyond life
column4: the Earth
column5: the sun swallowing us
column6: and our conceptions of black metal. III I asks a lot from its listeners
column7:
and it delivers one of the year’s best black metal albums in return.

"|19819.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19819-darkspace-dark-space-iii-i/|7.9|Andy O'Connor

Nika Rosa Danilova's Zola Jesus project has always had lofty ambitions

column1: If Taiga nods at pop
column2: it’s mostly in the songwriting–more streamlined
column3: less atmospheric–and Danilova’s vocals
column4: which are cleanly produced and more accessible. She’s mentioned studying Rihanna in particular
column5: and you can hear it in the low
column6: “Diamonds”-smacking strain of “Hunger” ; pop-approaching styles are evoked elsewhere in the vocal swoops and R&B curlicues of “Go (Blank Sea)”
column7: the steady handclaps of “Hollow”
column8: and the gentle-but taunting rhythm of “Dust”.

column1: Taiga's strongest moments actually come when Danilova's sights aren't explicitly set on pop music. True to its title
column2: “Hunger” sounds emaciated
column3: with fuzzy brass
column4: vague hints of a string section
column5: and exhausted
column6: skittish vocals; even the percussion break sounds like it’s been worn to the bone. Despite the pep-talky lyrics
column7: it doesn’t sound like an anthem so much as a mantra clung to
column8: half-breathless
column9: during a fight. (“I’m not getting younger/ I use it
column10: abusively
column11: ” is even more striking of a lyric when remembering that 25 is a fairly young age to mind the clock this desperately.) If “Hunger” sounds starved
column12: much of Taiga sounds over-full
column13: and not necessarily in a bad way: “Ego” calls back to Conatus by wielding film-score ambience to impressive effect
column14: and the opening title track sets the stage with atmospherics
column15: drops a drum-and-bass loop over it like sudden light
column16: then stops things short with an imposing tectonic plate of a brass theme.

column1: But too many songs on Taiga come across as filler—too small and formulaic to impress at ""taiga"" scale
column2: but too leaden to reach anthemic heights. “I wanted to make a huge pop song that would break in and reach people I've never been able to reach
column3: ” Danilova told Pitchfork earlier this year. In reality
column4: pop's never been that far of a reach for her
column5:
so what’s most frustrating about Taiga is how much more huge it could be.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21148/homepage_large.d4489ef0.jpg|Dubnobasswithmyheadman (20th Anniversary Remaster)|4418.0|Underworld|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Universal']|2014-10-08 00:00:00|1994|2016-06-11 16:32:18.506090|"

The path Underworld took to get to Dubnobasswithmyheadman
column2: their extraordinary “first” album in the second phase of the band
column3: was full of dashed hopes and improbable left turns. Karl Hyde and Rick Smith
column4: to this day the nucleus of the band
column5: were previously known for being in the synth inflected new wave band Freur
column6: whose “Doot-Doot” was a minor hit in 1983. A couple of albums as Underworld followed
column7: until that phase of the band flopped quietly to a close after a 1989 North American tour supporting Eurythmics. It’s unlikely many people noticed the band had gone on hiatus
column8: although Smith in particular appears to have seen it as a fresh start rather than an ignominious close. While Hyde stayed behind in New York
column9: hurtling toward anonymity as a guitarist in Debbie Harry’s band
column10: Smith was holed up in his studio in Essex
column11: arguably the birthplace of rave
column12: working on material with a much younger collaborator
column13: DJ Darren Emerson.

column1: The backwards way Underworld evolved was typical of similar UK acts of the era
column2: most of whom were similarly inclined toward blowing dance and electronic music out into bigger spaces. The Orb’s Alex Paterson backed into ambient music through stints as a roadie for Killing Joke and work as an A&R man; Primal Scream went from pleasant Byrds-inspired jangle merchants to acid glazed indie-dance pioneers; Norman Cook
column3: aka Fatboy Slim
column4: got his start playing bass in the politicized effete rock of the Housemartins. The effect worked in reverse
column5: too: the Prodigy were dyed-in-the-wool ravers who blew up by taking on certain characteristics of rock
column6: even hiring a live guitarist with the none-more-punk name of Gizz Butt. Underworld’s roots were also in rock
column7: giving them a sensibility that looked far beyond dance music's insular white-label culture
column8: coupled with an approach that was more album oriented than the average dance act. In short
column9: despite past mishaps
column10: their ambition was completely off the charts.

column1: It’s easy to ascribe this in retrospect
column2: but Underworld’s ascent fits perfectly with the surge of confidence that flowed through both overground and underground music in Britain in the early-to-mid '90s. You can hear it in the sharply defined angles of jungle and drum'n'bass
column3: or in the masterfully lethargic grooves of trip-hop
column4: or
column5: of course
column6: in the major Britpop acts. In 1990
column7: the KLF launched their “stadium house” trilogy (“What Time Is Love?”
column8: ""3 a.m. Eternal""
column9: “Last Train to Trancentral"")
column10: giving it a name that suggested house was moving beyond the club and chart environs it had largely existed in up to that point. They weren’t wrong; by the end of the decade
column11: bands such as Orbital
column12: the Prodigy
column13: and Underworld were headlining major stages at festivals in the UK. Dubnobass
column14: released in 1994
column15: is a key release in both that journey and the planet-sized thinking of EDM
column16: which plays out as a further manifestation of its ideas.

column1: This five-disc release offers an exhaustive trawl through Underworld’s archives from the era
column2: presenting a fuller picture of where the band were at immediately prior to the release of this record. There’s a disc of singles
column3: including vital pre-album tracks such as the version of “Dirty” released as Lemon Interrupt
column4: and the all-encompassing “Rez”—the latter such a strong part of their identity
column5: especially in its live incarnation all wrapped up in “Cowgirl”
column6: that it shows what riches they had on their hands that it didn’t make the final album. There’s also a disc of remixes
column7: a disc of unreleased takes
column8: and
column9: most curious of all
column10: an entire disc devoted to a series of live rehearsals that would become the Dubnobass tracks. The idea that these weren’t studio creations
column11: but actually came out of something approaching live improvisation
column12: feels improbable when hearing the strongly executed final product
column13: although it’s likely a key part in explaining how adept Underworld were at pushing this stuff out into a live context.

column1: The album itself has been considerably sharpened in its remastered form
column2: with Smith taking it to Abbey Road and subtly pulling out textures that occasionally sounded muted on the original pressing. Hyde’s lyrics can still be problematic
column3: with his cut-up style veering wildly between inspiration and moments of corniness
column4: although the force of ideas on Dubnobass largely covers up the lyrical patchiness in ways other Underworld albums haven’t always managed. Here
column5: he imbues the songs with a feeling of seediness
column6: of bad sex and nights slumped in regret
column7: giving the album a deeper undercurrent than something you can just get mashed off your face to in a club (although it also serves that purpose). Hyde’s at his best when lost in short mantras
column8: such as the repeating verses of “Spoonman”
column9: where he matches the trance-like flow of the music
column10: his voice tweaked so it barely sounds human at times
column11: becoming totally subsumed in groove and forward momentum.

column1: The stretch through “Spoonman”
column2: “Tongue”
column3: “Dirty Epic”
column4: and “Cowgirl” shows what acute listeners this band were
column5: but it also highlights how skilled they were at assimilating contrasting ideas into their sound. “Tongue” borrows something from the ambient drift echoing through chillout rooms at clubs during this time
column6: with Hyde multi-tracking his vocals in a way that makes him sound not unlike future collaborator Brian Eno. On “Dirty Epic”
column7: Underworld demonstrate their mastery of subtle builds and strange fusions
column8: cutting plinky-plonky house piano across needlelike bursts of electric guitar
column9: with Hyde’s central lyric (“I get my kicks on channel 6”) suggesting someone lost in a world as lonely as it is unsavory. “Cowgirl” remains their most carefully honed club banger
column10: drawing on screaming acid lines and dense drum patterns that feel like a precursor to LCD Soundsystem’s “Yeah”. It’s not hard to see some of Hyde in James Murphy and vice versa
column11: especially as both were old hands coming to this game
column12: bringing a dose of reflection to music that’s so often focussed solely on the now.

column1: There are highlights in the rest of the material here (the Irish Pub in Kyoto mix of “Cowgirl”
column2: the big beat workover of “Mmm...Skyscraper I Love You” in its “Telegraph 16.11.92” mix)
column3: along with things that are little more than historical curios (the 18-minute version of “Spoonman” on the rehearsals disc; the country-fied
column4: Thrashing Doves-indebted “Bigmouth” from the same disc)
column5: and an admirable willingness to put things out there that don’t appear to fit anywhere in their career (the lite pop/reggae of “Can You Feel Me?” on the disc of unreleased material
column6: which feels like an unexpected callback to the Freur era). It’s a well put-together set
column7: with a logic to each part that offers insight into Underworld’s working method
column8: but never falls into the kind of barrel-scraping to which reissues like this sometimes have to resort. Mostly it’s worth it to hear how hard Dubnobass still resonates: this was an album about community
column9:
about coming together through shared experiences—a chance to take club culture out of the club without losing a shred of nuance or sheer visceral excitement.

"|19906.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19906-underworld-dubnobasswithmyheadman-20th-anniversary-remaster/|9.2|Nick Neyland

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rosary']|2014-10-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:19.294366|"

The Vaselines have never been ones for opportune timing. Already disbanded by the time their debut album
column3: Dum-Dum
column4: was released in 1989
column5: ex-lovers-cum-ex-bandmates Eugene Kelly and Frances McKee should have by all conventional wisdom reconciled in the early ’90s to capitalize on their rarified standing as one of the most-covered artists in the Nirvana discography (a benefit that did at least trickle down to a short-lived major-label deal for Kelly’s post-Vaselines band Eugenius). Instead
column6: they waited until 2008—just enough time for their biggest claim to fame to lose its currency to a new generation of kids who may have a passing familiarity with “Smells Like Teen Spirit”
column7: but aren’t about to study Kurt Cobain’s record collection.

column1: After the now de rigueur reissue/reunion-tour cycle
column2: they released Sex With an X—their first new album in over two decades—to show that age had no maturing effect on their puerile innuendo and bashful blasphemy. The record also seemingly gave the band a proper burial
column3: putting a cap on a legacy they couldn’t have possibly imagined when they when they were strumming out lascivious lo-fi lullabies like “Rory Rides Me Raw”. After all
column4: the last song on X was titled “Exit the Vaselines”
column5: which
column6: beyond its knowing full-circle allusion to the 2009 early-recordings comp Enter the Vaselines
column7: left us with a pitch-perfect epitaph: “It’s only goodbye.” For a band that became indie rock icons by accident
column8: it felt like a suitably self-effacing note to go out on

column1: As it turns out
column2: there was still one matter of unfinished business to tend to. With no back catalog left to plunder and the comeback-LP angle already played
column3: the Vaselines have effectively returned with the 20th-anniversary reissue of an album that never existed—in other words
column4: V for Vaselines is the sort of radio-ready record Kelly and McKee might’ve released in 1994 had they stuck it out long enough to get signed by DGC
column5: hire Gil Norton as producer
column6: and score a fluke Buzz Bin hit to get sandwiched between Veruca Salt and Weezer in heavy MTV rotation. That may not be welcome news for those who fell in love with the Vaselines for their off-the-cuff intimacy and try-anything-once grab-bag experimentation
column7: but
column8: in stark contrast to the predictable ’89-throwback slackness of Sex With an X
column9: V for Vaselines is surprisingly the band’s punchiest
column10: most polished effort to date. (That motorcycle you see McKee straddling on the hilariously Tom of Finland-esque album cover isn’t just some sexually suggestive prop
column11: but the vehicle of choice for road-testing these power-pop pick-me-ups.)

column1: Reportedly inspired by a restoked appreciation for the Ramones
column2: V for Vaselines doesn’t so much approximate the bruddahs’ buzzsaw attack as their hooky immediacy
column3: to the point where a casual mid-tempo gallop like “Inky Lies” feels every bit as spirited and effervescent as asphalt-ripping rockers like “High Tide Low Tide” and “Number One Crush”. But while the Vaselines may never totally outgrow their affinity for tawdry metaphor (“There was a time when all I had was sorrow/ But I met you
column4: so I go boom with you”)
column5: V for Vaselines eases up on some of the cheekiness without sacrificing their charm
column6: whether it’s McKee acknowledging her preference for slow-motion living in a totally wired world (“I’m not in it to win it
column7: ” she admits on the careening “Earth Is Speeding”)
column8: or hearing this playfully combative former couple restage a lovers spat on the beautifully breezy ballad “Single Spies”.

column1: Even at a swift 34 minutes
column2: V for Vaselines doesn’t always adhere to Ramones-like standards of brevity—the songs here tend to follow a verse-chorus-verse-chorus-chorus-chorus pattern that can make even a three-minute thriller like “One Lost Year” feel a tad overlong. But maybe all that repetition is the Vaselines’ way of saying of enjoy it while it lasts—on the “Just Like Honey”-dipped closer
column3: “Last Half Hour”
column4: Kelly and McKee sign off by singing
column5: “Switch on
column6: switch off
column7: turn the lights low/ Final curtain
column8: end of the show.” Whether this is indeed the end or just the set-up ruse for their next comeback
column9:
V for Vaselines leaves a lasting pop smear.
