column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20759/homepage_large.083dee24.jpg|Familiar|1411.0|Excepter|['Rock'
column3: Familiar should be the sound of Excepter falling apart
column4: or at least picking up the pieces. In 2011 they lost member Clare Amory to cancer
column5: and her partner
column6: band member Nathan Corbin
column7: decided he couldn’t continue in the group without her. Founder John Fell Ryan and his wife and bandmate Lala Harrison Ryan moved from Brooklyn to Los Angeles
column8: then returned. It's been four years since Excepter's last full-length
column9: Presidence
column10: so it's reasonable to expect Familiar to reflect this disarray
column11: especially since their open-ended jams have always sounded on the verge of collapse.

column1: But Familiar turns out to be one of the most focused efforts in this idiosyncratic band’s 12-year history. Some tracks are practically pop songs compared to Excepter's standard wandering sound
column2: and even the more abstract pieces have distinct shape and purpose. Part of this is due to a plan conceived long before Amory passed away: to make songs with “familiar” instruments and melodies
column3: some even nodding to nursery rhymes. The group had only a week to record during a 2012 European tour
column4: so efficiency was at a premium; what makes Familiar impressive isn’t those goals (Excepter has veered toward conventional structure before)
column5: but that the results feel natural. There’s no sense of the band squeezing awkwardly into new costumes. Everything fits well; each sonic element is right where it belongs.

column1: This unforced unity is clearest when comparing more melodic tracks to looser siblings. Opener “Maids”
column2: with Lala’s ethereal chants riding a wave of cresting beat
column3: is their catchiest song since the ear-worming “‘Rock’ Stepper” (from 2006’s Alternation
column4: the only Excepter album that matches Familiar in sharpness). Yet “Same Address
column5: Different City”
column6: which sees John drooling like Mark E. Smith over meandering electronic squiggles
column7: manages to scale as high as “Maids”. Similar parallels emerge when you put new-wave-ish “Palace to Palace” next to mantra-like “Grinning in Your Face”: one relies on hook and the other on repetition
column8: yet both build momentum without wasting a single breath.

column1: The most thrilling example of Familiar’s laser focus comes on a seven-minute mini-masterpiece called “Destroy”. It's Corbin’s only contribution to the album
column2: a piece he recorded with Amory when she was ill
column3: in hopes of destroying her sickness with sound. Even though it was created separately from the rest of Familiar
column4: it fully encapsulates the record’s strengths. Spraying whirring noise and morse-like transmissions over a pile-driving beat
column5: “Destroy” is deceptively chaotic: jump to any point and it’s like waking up in a hailstorm
column6: but chart it from start to finish and a near-classical sense of order emerges
column7: with each element replacing its predecessor logically and mesmerizingly.

column1: As if to emphasize the structured-ness of Familiar
column2: Excepter closes the album with a cover of Tim Buckley’s 1970 ballad “Song to the Siren”. It’s the spot where the group most risks sounding like someone else
column3: but rippling keyboard and Ryan’s long moans wash the tune in Excepter vibes. Still
column4: it’s a daring move
column5: and makes it tempting to paint this album as a complete rebirth for a band who deserves one. But their journey hasn’t exactly been linear
column6: and they’re just as likely to throw a curveball next time as they are to continue down Familiar’s excellent
column7:
distinctive path.

"|19911.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19911-excepter-familiar/|7.8|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21033/homepage_large.9de589d0.jpg|Doomgrass|32486.0|Nocturnal Poisoning|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['The End']|2014-10-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:20.712908|"

For a musician who first staked his entire reputation on the shadows provided by pseudonyms
column2: Scott Conner is suddenly and certainly full of braggadocio. He spent 15 years hidden behind nested aliases: he was Malefic
column3: or the sole member of the one-man black metal mystery Xasthur
column4: and a one-time contributor to Twilight. But Xasthur released its last record
column5: the divisive Portal of Sorrow
column7: and Conner has since shed not just the corpse-painted nicknames but also the shield of distorted electric guitars
column8: primitive drums
column9: and hissing electronics that defined that band.

column1: Now
column2: credited under his own name (or
column3: at the very least
column4: “Scott C.”)
column5: he records thin
column6: sullen acoustic music as Nocturnal Poisoning. In liner note selfies
column7: he is clean-shaven and makeup-free. In interviews
column8: he is confident not only about his decision to leave black metal behind but also his technical progression as a fingerpicking summoner of the blues
column9: bluegrass
column10: and country. “Nocturnal Poisoning is actually more technical than Xasthur was
column11: ” he said in a recent chat with Noisey. “It’s just more mellow and doesn’t have any of my mediocre drumming.” To that end
column12: he titled the third Nocturnal Poisoning album in three years Doomgrass
column13: an illustrative portmanteau of doom metal and bluegrass. The creation and naming of a new genre from whole cloth? That’s a pretty heavy burden to wrap around the neck of any project
column14: especially the first album not to be self-released in a very limited edition. But Conner
column15: <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_One"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">who climbed inside a coffin to sing for Sunn O))) a decade ago
column16: has never been one for soft statements.

column1: But the results are embarrassing. Doomgrass is an interminable 14-track slog through inconsequential guitar instrumentals and croaked-and-groaned high-school diary entries
column2: laughably sung by Nocturnal Poisoning’s only collaborator to date
column3: Robert Nesslin. The previous Nocturnal Poisoning albums have been mostly inoffensive affairs of acoustic strum-alongs
column4: backed by modest percussion
column5: mild effects and Nesslin’s occasional vocal contributions. As he’d been with Xasthur
column6: Conner seemed comfortable with a defiant sort of primitivism
column7: where the music’s cumulative effect and feeling mattered much more than the compositional acumen.

column1: Doomgrass would be difficult to appreciate just as a neofolk record
column2: or even as a continuation of Death in June’s own shambling acoustic misery. Conner
column3: though
column4: is in the uncomfortable position of trying to pass off looped and delayed guitars as bona fide technical merit in two fields where skill can be difficult to fake. His “licks” are little more than a patchwork pastiche of sputtering arpeggios and bent strings
column5: dispatched with the kind of lightweight tone that suggests a college freshman learning the tablature to “Dancing Nancies” on a used Ovation. “Vagrant
column6: Seeker of Empty Treasures” vaguely recalls Doc Watson’s heavy thumb and swift fingers
column7: “Bet It All” the quick progressions of Clarence White. But there are entire skills absent from Conner’s set
column8: and they limit him to the insulting side of passable. Doomgrass suggests a translation where the interpreter
column9: though cocksure
column10: knows one language well but only has a rudimentary grasp of the second tongue.

column1: If that sounds rough
column2: wait until you hear the words
column3: and the way they’re sung. Conner wrote these lyrics
column4: which amount to little more than dire reflections scribbled in the back of a notebook during a lunch break. There are misery clichés galore—“Roses you never smell
column5: ” “Become yesterday’s news
column6: ” and so on—and the prevailing sense that Conner has been too busy learning how to complain about life to live. He trades the experiential focus of the folk music he appropriates for empty lines about no money and dirty cities. Nesslin does his best to give the words the gravitas they demand
column7: but his strained
column8: dark-blues croon is mostly funny
column9: as if he’s moaning these tunes from a toilet stall. Above the trebly guitar and light percussion of “Can’t Find the Sky
column10: ” he sings
column11: “Life is a phase and a failed test/ Wait for God to clean up the mess
column12: ” doubling his voice so as to sound doubly mean. Try not to giggle.

column1: Bluegrass
column2: blues
column3: and old-time music
column4: like most all other folk arts in the world
column5: can sometimes suffer assumptions that
column6: simply because they’re old
column7: they’re quaint and genteel. That is
column8: we tend to teach our children Mother Maybelle Carter’s big-time version of “Keep on the Sunny Side” rather than the apocalyptic meltdown of “When the World’s on Fire”
column9: which she sang long before with her parents. But that view is a bleached and sterilized reality
column10: of course
column11: one that doesn’t recognize the way that this music has long worked as an anchor in times of crisis. Bluegrass and folk music at large are nothing if not full of doom—hell
column12: <a href=""http://www.bluegrasslyrics.com/node/593"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Rank Strangers
column13: ” the standard of the bluegrass gospel canon
column14: essentially suggests that
column15: if you leave home for too long
column16: everyone you know will be dead (or at least gone) when you return.

column1: So every antediluvian form that Conner tries to wrangle for his woe has a well-established pedigree of melancholy
column2: but he seems to have missed that memo. That alone is not a reason to discount Conner’s attempt to weld doom metal to folk
column3: but it’s certainly a reason to hope he could have as much deference for one side of that equation as he seems to have for the other. And maybe Conner will get there
column4: since he seems newly devoted to practice
column5: perfection
column6: and building his repertoire piecemeal. Perhaps in a decade
column7: Doomgrass will be a foundation for something that actually deserves to be called that. But for now
column8: it’s hard not to hear these songs of self-pity and wish that
column9: like a rank stranger
column10:
Xasthur would simply slip back into the shadows.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20992/homepage_large.7bac2cc7.jpg|Our Love|947.0|Caribou|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge'
column2:
'City Slang']|2014-10-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:22.145877|"

Dan Snaith spent the first decade of his career attacking a wide range of genres with the intensity of an autodidact and the cerebral coolness of an academic. Back when he was still recording as Manitoba without fear of legal challenges from disgruntled punk veterans
column3: he dissembled the IDM of the late 1990s and early ‘00s on debut Start Breaking My Heart before moving on to kaleidoscopic
column4: colorful psychedelia on Up in Flames. From there
column5: it was on to chugging krautrock and rich
column6: melancholy ‘60s pop on The Milk of Human Kindness and Andorra
column7: respectively; the 2010 LP Swim
column8: cobbled together from leftover DJ set material and inspired by the sounds of deep house and contemporary club music
column9: grew his fan base further. Despite the huge breadth of sounds they explore
column10: these albums all share an essential playfulness and engrossing curiosity.

column1: It’s always been enjoyable to hear Snaith dive deep into a new passion and emerge with a new record awash in the ecstasy of influence: finely detailed
column2: in love with its inspiration
column3: simply tuneful
column4: and yet thematically complex. Our Love
column5: his first album as Caribou in four years
column6: is his first full-length that doesn’t come with a major shift from the sound of its predecessor. This is body music on the same general wavelength as Swim
column7: albeit slightly warped and refined. The differences
column8: then
column9: are deeper: this is Snaith’s most overtly personal record to date
column10: one that’s remarkable for its intimacy
column11: openheartedness
column12: and joy derived from basic human connection.

column1: Our Love is a quietly ambitious record
column2: despite its modest title: in documenting Snaith’s personal vision of love
column3: it seeks to render love in all of its universally complicated glory. It’s a warts-and-all depiction of a state of being that’s so often constrained to one or two facets in pop songs: obsession and disconnection
column4: passion and jealousy
column5: companionship and loneliness
column6: all given equal weight. From the outside
column7: Snaith looks the picture of domestic bliss
column8: or at least stability—he’s been married for 13 years
column9: and his first child was born in 2011—but many of Our Love’s lyrics hint at romantic trouble or marital discomfort. Nameless characters feel mistreated
column10: are haunted by lurking suitors and bad memories
column11: lament their broken love
column12: look towards the future; when they’re in love
column13: it’s with an intensity that verges on the maniacal. But it’s reasonable to conclude that the album’s songs aren’t near-direct transcriptions of events and feelings from Snaith’s life; instead
column14: they’re extremes pulled from the necessarily complicated life two people build together over years and years
column15: rich with joy but laden with baggage.

column1: In any long-term relationship
column2: there are moments of deadening melancholy where you feel like your organs have been put through an industrial shredder. It’s in those moments where you sniff at imagining your life completely different
column3: or even with someone else—fantasies enabled by intense emotional pain. And then
column4: somehow
column5: things get better
column6: and your heart is overflowing with love; you’re almost in disbelief
column7: thinking
column8: “How could I imagine a different life
column9: even for a second?” Our Love captures the zig-zag between these two poles with an authenticity and honesty few albums manage
column10: and the album’s excellent two singles
column11: “Can’t Do Without You” and “Our Love”
column12: focus on the latter sensation.

column1: The kind of complex
column2: slowly shifting relationship the album seeks to depict is mirrored by its own relationship to “dance music
column3: ” a term that’s broadly applicable to Our Love but awkward and inadequate upon closer examination. Snaith is an accomplished DJ
column4: remixer
column5: and producer
column6: and he has a rock-solid grasp on the mechanics of the dancefloor: he understands how to get people moving
column7: how to sustain intensity
column8: and how small moves behind the boards can yield surprising results. A good example is the way he uses dynamic variation on highlights “Can’t Do Without You” and “Back Home”
column9: using volume to make hooks hit that much harder. His 2012 record as Daphni
column10: Jiaolong
column11: was a dance nerd’s delight
column12: a lean and brittle release forged by crate-digging and the need to churn out hours of material for marathon sets at European clubs
column13: and its influence is felt in subtle ways on Our Love.

column1: This album is glassy
column2: warped
column3: and largely digital where Swim was bold
column4: bright
column5: and decisively analog in places; there’s a warmth to it
column6: but much of it comes from Snaith rather than his largely digital soundscapes. That said
column7: Our Love only really glances at straightforward dance composition before choosing to shrug it off and take a different path. Most of the album is too slow and strange for the club
column8: and its songs mutate in ways that are unexpected and offer different kind of rewards. The title track spends four minutes building to a strobe-lit
column9: wildly pulsing frenzy
column10: only to turn left into a lovely string outro arranged by contemporary maestro Owen Pallett
column11: a longtime Snaith pal. The back half twosome of “Julia Brightly” and “Mars” are the two tracks that offer any kind of predictable dance-oriented pleasure
column12: and even they’re a little off-kilter
column13: with the former’s searing synth washes and the latter’s perky flute melody.

column1: The key attribute is ultimately confidence. Our Love is a very assured record
column2: from its unconventional
column3: austere arrangements to its unrelenting focus and thematic consistency. This can be traced
column4: in part
column5: to Snaith’s solid collaborative circle: from respected advisors like Kieran Hebden and his wife to other artists like the aforementioned Pallett and Jessy Lanza
column6: he’s surrounded himself with people he trusts and appreciates
column7: freeing him to take risks and pursue a pure artistic vision. Pallett’s arrangements on the title track
column8: “Silver”
column9: and closer “Your Love Will Set You Free” lend a lightness to an album that sometimes verges on uncomfortable depth; Lanza’s winning feature on “Second Chance” is a welcome dose of female perspective on a record dominated by Snaith’s
column10: her melody and fluttering voice taking the album from one person’s love to something larger.

column1: Speaking of voices
column2: Snaith’s isn’t half bad either: a reluctant vocalist earlier in his career
column3: he’s improved by leaps and bounds since then
column4: lending an imperfect humanity to these songs even if he’s not quite carrying them. His imperfect delivery makes plenty of sense in this context
column5: anyway: you can imagine him warbling these songs to his wife
column6: or turning them into lullabies for his daughter. It’s a subtle cultivation of intimacy
column7: but one that works in driving home the album's central conceit: that the love you feel for your partner
column8: and the life and family you can choose to shape together
column9: can be transformative. It’s hard work
column10: and it’s not always easy
column11: but it pays remarkable and lasting dividends. It can change your perspective and the effect you want to have on the world
column12: and Our Love is a worthy tribute to that messy
column13:
unbelievably powerful force.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21133/homepage_large.77c4aed6.jpg|Playland|2684.0|Johnny Marr|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Music Group']|2014-10-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:23.118433|"

In the Smiths
column2: Marr was the preeminent guitar stylist of his generation. Glam
column3: folk-rock
column4: post-punk
column5: funk
column6: rockabilly
column7: and a certain ineffable Marrness— that ringing
column8: swinging
column9: intricate
column10: atmospheric
column11: hook-dripping soul— all dovetailed into a sound that still stuns. But while his erstwhile Smiths-mate Morrissey has taken his own primrose path down self-parodying mediocrity with this year’s World Peace Is None of Your Business
column12: Marr is doing the same on a lesser scale with his solo career. Which makes sense: Marr never had as high a profile or ego as Morrissey
column13: and that low-key humility has made him a fan favorite.

column1: But who knew that the least satisfying thing Johnny Marr could ever do would be launching a solo career? Yet here we are with Playland
column2: the second official solo album by the former Smiths guitarist (or third
column3: if you count Boomslang
column4: his 2003 album released under the name Johnny Marr & the Healers). There’s not a sizeable difference between Playland and last year’s The Messenger. Both feature listless songcraft
column5: lackluster vocals
column6: and a dull pulverization of every Britpop trope imaginable (not that imagination had anything to do with the making of this record). Worst of all
column7: though
column8: is the oppressive truth lurking behind almost every tired lick and lazy lyric of Playland: Marr can
column9: and has
column10: done so much better.

column1: We root for him
column2: though
column3: and in return he gives us “Easy Money”
column4: Playland’s lead single
column5: a silly
column6: clumsy fumble of a song that can’t click into shape. Is it supposed to remind us that money is a bad thing
column7: or that it’s ironic how millionaire musicians still feel the need to sing about it? It doesn’t matter
column8: because the song's only notable element is Marr’s perpetually dated musical taste
column9: as the slashing
column10: squelching rock of “Easy Money” feels about as fresh and inspired as Kaiser Chiefs.

column1: Playland isn’t all bad: “Boys Get Straight” is as breakneck as the Smiths’ “London”
column2: and that energy almost carries it over the finish line
column3: despite a poverty of hooks. “Little King” isn’t any more original—its sinuous intro could be a page in the Echo & the Bunnymen songbook
column4: an nearly funny gesture seeing as how the Bunnymen were one of the Smiths’ chief rivals in the '80s— but Marr spins that into a tuneful
column5: propulsive bit of diversion anyway. The album’s title track is its only glimmer of Marr’s worship of vintage glam
column6: but what might have started out as filthy
column7: flashy rock in the practice space has been pasteurized to the point of blankness.

column1: Marr’s tendency to sing like his former Electronic bandmate
column2: New Order’s Bernard Sumner
column3: might be flattering to Sumner but proves embarrassing otherwise; the pinched
column4: boyish
column5: breathy style serves Marr adequately on tracks like “Dynamo” and “The Trap”
column6: but it doesn’t come across as conveying emotion and melody as much as it does him doing vocal exercises. If his curious status as a New Order/Joy Division fanboy is in question
column7: he titles two consecutive tracks on Playland— either consciously or not — after Joy Division songs: “Candidate” and “25 Hours”. They do exhibit a trickle-down trace of that same dark
column8: stark atmosphere
column9: but rather than coming across as an homage
column10: the resemblance seems fawning at best
column11: insecure at worst.

column1: A lack of effort isn’t the main problem with Playland; if anything
column2: there’s been too much effort put into it. It’s been fussed over so much that any spark that may have spurred it has been smothered. As Marr continues to staple pages to his résumé—and the prospect of a Smiths reunion becomes even more remote—the disconnect between the iconic architect of '80s indie and the journeyman who’d rather follow than lead grows. In an interview with the NME
column3: Marr cited “boredom” as a big inspiration on <i>Playland
column4:
and all it takes is a listen to prove it.

Say what you will about the hyper-speed of modern life—it doesn’t matter to Steve Gunn. He plays his guitar with a traditional precision
column2: his eyes gazing at the neck
column3: his fingers moving limberly around the frets
column4: a thumb pick doing the most economical work. He’s austere as someone with no need to go anywhere anytime soon. His songs stretch and loom like a dust storm. Time
column5: it seems
column6: bows to him.

column1: Gunn’s career shows a similar sense of patience: zoomed out
column2: it looks like a 9-year crescendo
column3: whose highlights include his earliest limited-run solo guitar improvisations
column4: his work as a duo with drummer John Truscinski
column5: a sideman in Kurt Vile’s band
column6: the spine of the psych-folk supergroup Black Dirt Oak
column7: on up to last year’s Time Off. That last record was a statement
column8: casting Gunn as not just an instrumentalist
column9: but a damn fine songwriter
column10: too
column11: as ambling
column12: cyclical guitars loped and folded among verses
column13: choruses
column14: bridges
column15: and his doleful baritone. They were simple songs
column16: produced with plenty of dust and hiss all over the tracks
column17: and Time Off was Gunn squinting at something big on the horizon.

column1: His latest
column2: <i>Way Out Weather
column3: is the fully formed pinnacle of his career. With a full band and plenty of instrumentation behind him
column4: the care he puts into every nook and cranny of a song is evident. It’s lush but without lacquer
column5: detailed without being dense. These songs live in hollowed out holes of America’s past; it’s as easy to imagine him playing in front of a disused gas station off an Oklahoma highway as it is to hear his band booming out of a roadhouse on the Mississippi Delta. At times
column6: there’s so many guitar tracks it it feels like in the middle of a pickup jam session with Jerry Garcia
column7: Duane Allman
column8: and John Fahey.

column1: Among the strides Gunn has made on Way Out Weather is his singing voice. His baritone has a perfect character to it
column2: somewhere between Lou Reed circa Loaded and a toothless barfly who occasionally breaks into song. He falls off the ends of notes as if the energy to sing them is out of reach
column3: yet he avoids the kind of droll
column4: wondering vocal style used so liberally and effectively by his contemporaries Adam Granduciel and Vile. Instead
column5: Gunn hones in on every pitch
column6: like on the the lilting waltz of “Shadow Bros""
column7: which is the closest thing you'd call a traditional folk song here.

column1: There's so much space inside these songs: the opening title track is a six-minute stroll through tendrils of guitars—a lap steel in the background
column2: a strummed acoustic just beside it
column3: a picked acoustic just in ahead of that
column4: and a clean Fender lead right up front. Even when these sounds aren't washing over you
column5: like the simple country blues riff that runs through “Wildwood”
column6: hearing these melodies is a delight. He sings of private rivers
column7: slowly moving light
column8: fast nights
column9: long days
column10: and moving inside dreams.

column1: It’s not all swaths of guitars and natural nostalgia
column2: though: Gunn turns it up with “Drifter”
column3: a balled up and electric stomper
column4: and Way Out Weather closes with an excellent climax
column5: “Tommy’s Congo”
column6: a swirl of psych
column7: krautrock
column8: Malian folk
column9: and a slight nod to Bob Dylan’s cadence on “It’s Alright
column10: Ma (I’m Only Bleeding)”. Gunn may have been more experimental-leaning on Cantos de Lisboa
column11: his collaboration with Mike Cooper
column12: but this song gathers up all his improvisational tendencies and eclectic influences
column13: bringing unheard textures to his music that are somehow still cut from the same cloth. He closes the album in a voice that's never sounded more certain: “Steady eyes on the crowd to see what’s going down/ Never once looked down at what they’re playin'/ Never look down at what you need to do.” His eyes are trained far somewhere far in the distance
column14:
waiting for what’s next.

column2:
'Paper Bag']|2014-10-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:24.125947|"

The Rural Alberta Advantage isn’t the type of band you’d expect to take three years between albums. At their core
column3: they’re a folk trio and make songs that can put be put together in minutes—Nils Edenloff basically limits himself to the first eight chords a beginner learns on guitar
column4: and the difference between some RAA cuts might just be a hitch in his strum or where he puts his capo. He writes simply worded lyrics about commonplace emotions triggered by often mundane events
column5: and while the additions from Amy Cole and Paul Banwatt are crucial
column6: the arrangements remain minimal. But the long incubation makes sense
column7: as their best music tends to emerge only after a kind of latency period—what initially sounds and feels small ends up resonating over time.

column1: Characters detailed in RAA songs are often in danger of having emotional catastrophe sneak up on them
column2: brought to light by an ex’s keys or the encroachment of hopelessness in a small town. After an overly muted sophomore release in 2011’s Departing
column3: Edenloff wisely sought out more immediate threats to his security while writing Mended With Gold. Taking on the Ontario Rural Disadvantage of Bruce Peninsula
column4: he was subject to the unpredictable cold
column5: as well as the occasional black bear and wolf milling about. There isn’t much lyrical evidence of his Bear Grylls method acting—“To Be Scared” and “Runners in the Night” still speak of more of existential crises than primitive fight-or-flight—but if RAA gained confidence by surviving in the wilderness and recognizing how precious and fleeting our time on earth can be
column6: it’s manifested in what is
column7: by a wide margin
column8: their boldest and most ambitiously recorded album.

column1: The format of Rural Alberta Advantage hasn’t changed; you still get Edenloff’s pine-needle tone
column2: Banwatt’s hyperactive drumming on a minimal kit
column3: and the occasional wispy harmony or simple keyboard texture from Cole. It often recalls the performative recklessness that marked their enduring debut Hometowns—however
column4: the rickety
column5: ramshackle recording has been replaced by a mix that makes RAA sound like a proper rock band. For the first ten seconds of opener “Our Love…”
column6: Edenloff’s voclas and palm-muted acoustics are as thin as ever
column7: but the rest of the band comes in furiously thrashing
column8: and although Mended With Gold doesn’t always match that pace
column9: even the quiet moments lunge out of the speakers.

column1: The production certainly plays a role in this
column2: but RAA’s new strike-first and strike-often musician is due to the band troubleshooting the #1 issue of Departing
column3: which was the baffling marginalization of Banwatt. They haven’t released an album since Jayson Gerycz joined Cloud Nothings
column4: and here it sounds like Banwatt is trying to retake his spot as having the highest ""value over replacement drummer"" in indie rock
column5: a guy who singlehandedly elevates otherwise standard rock songs into something proprietary. If you turn your ear a certain way
column6: the massed choruses of “Terrified” and “To Be Scared” echo the ho-heys of arena folkies like the Lumineers or Of Monsters and Men
column7: though their rusticity and earnestness projects from the inside-out. One can assume Banwatt draws on the pent up stress from his day job as an intellectual property lawyer to ensure the anxiety of Edenloff’s lyrics project from the inside-out as well
column8: and numerous songs on Mended With Gold are custom built for him as a showcase—the second half of “On the Rocks” gives way to a  extremely loud drum solo
column9: ""All We've Ever Known"" is damn near blast-beat folk
column10: whereas “The Build” is pretty self-explanatory. Regardless of your tastes
column11: if you care about drums at all
column12: Mended With Gold is a must-listen.

column1: But while Mended With Gold gives the Rural Alberta Advantage their most broad and expansive sound
column2: the lyrics are at their most broad as well. Edenloff sounds more like In the Aeroplane Over the Sea-era Jeff Mangum than Jeff Mangum himself these days
column3: which only emphasizes how his increasingly plainspoken lyrics lack the distinct character that made Hometowns such a subtle pleasure.  From the titles alone
column4: you can predict what “Our Love…”
column5: “On the Rocks”
column6: and “This City” are getting at
column7: which more represent generalizations of relationship impasses than lived-in descriptions of them
column8: though the latter possesses distinctly Canadian rhyming of “toque” with “rust-covered coupe.” Still
column9: it's only an occasional cut against their charms—RAA don't have the element of surprise like they did on the originally self-released <i>Hometowns
column10: and it doesn't slowly ingratiate the way Departing did
column11:
but Mended With Gold proves Edenloff's songs of lost love can sneak up on you even when the music hits you square on the chin.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20966/homepage_large.e0b2033a.jpg|Inspiral Carpets|32456.0|Inspiral Carpets|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cherry Red']|2014-10-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:24.614730|"

Inspiral Carpets were not the biggest band of Britain’s Madchester explosion in the late 1980s and early '90s
column2: but they gave the movement its definitive dance anthem. The band’s 1990 single “Commercial Rain” crystallized everything Madchester was about
column3: at least where it counted most: on the dancefloor. Swirling and sinewy
column4: it split the difference between hippie trippiness and punk simplicity. Mostly
column5: though
column6: it had a hypnotic hook that was more relentless than even the Stone Roses’ “Fools Gold” or Happy Mondays’ “Step On”
column7: songs that are more widely recognized as embodying Madchester’s ecstasy-fueled zeitgeist. Inspiral Carpets were neighbors of the Stone Roses and Happy Mondays in Greater Manchester
column8: but they always seemed from another place entirely: harder edged
column9: more potently focused
column10: and far less concerned with the finer frills of stardom. If the Stone Roses were Madchester’s Beatles
column11: and Happy Mondays its Rolling Stones
column12: Inspiral Carpets were its iteration of the Who.

column1: Naturally
column2: they were nowhere near as successful as their contemporaries; after a handful of modest hits
column3: Inspiral Carpets broke up in 1995. They reformed in 2003
column4: but seemed ready to collapse once again when longtime frontman Tom Hingley quit unexpectedly in 2011. The group instantly rebounded by recruiting their original singer
column5: Stephen Holt
column6: who had cofounded Inspiral Carpets in 1983 before leaving in 1989
column7: just before they hit their peak of popularity. The result of that reunion with Holt is Inspiral Carpets—their first album in 20 years
column8: and their first proper studio full-length with Holt at the helm.

column1: The biggest difference is Holt’s voice itself. It hasn’t matured or strengthened since the band’s early EPs with him
column2: back when they tended more towards organ-slathered garage rock than the funkier forms of Madchester. Where Hingley sang with understated soul and nuance
column3: Holt is more or less an adenoidal punk barker. He knows two notes
column4: one for each nostril. But where Happy Mondays’ Shaun Ryder compensated for a similar limitation by owning every square inch of his tuneless delivery and injecting it with brilliantly loopy lyrics
column5: Holt just squawks. On “You’re So Good for Me”
column6: he strings together empty banalities like “Something’s gotta give/ I’ve gotta keep on moving/ I’m struggling to be heard/ But my time is coming
column7: ” and instead of putting any conviction behind his salesmanship
column8: he just reads the pitch off the page.

column1: Being the most punk of the original Madchester bands
column2: Inspiral Carpets should mesh beautifully with Holt’s raw vocals here
column3: but the music behind him doesn’t do him any favors. “A to Z of My Heart” trots out every organ riff that ? and the Mysterians and the Music Machine used
column4: making them sound tired instead of tense. What was once impassioned homage now sounds like simple muscle memory. “Let You Down” is one of the album’s few triumphs of appropriation
column5: with a generic
column6: “Gloria”-as-played-by-Ray-Manzarek vamp played by organist Clint Boon with a groovy fury
column7: and a guest verse by grizzled punk-poet John Cooper Clarke that not only shatters the album’s tedium
column8: but also echoes one of Inspiral Carpets’ finest moments: enlisting fellow Mancunian Mark E. Smith of the Fall to wax avuncular on their 1994 single “I Want You”.

column1: Beyond that
column2: only the spirited
column3: psychedelic chug of “Spitfire” and the handclap-catalyzed go-go of “Hey Now” come close to clicking with—let alone recapturing—any portion of the band’s former glory. The remainder of the record is filled out with either bland mediocrities or downright embarrassments such as “Flying Like a Bird”
column4: a sappy ballad that sharply delineates every weakness Inspiral Carpets has
column5: from a dearth of energy to a lack of melody. Strangely enough
column6: one track from this Holt-led album goes out of its way in an attempt replicate the group’s Hingley-era
column7: Madchester peak. “Forever Here” is the only stretch of Inspiral Carpets that dares to be funky
column8: and for a fleeting three-and-a-half minutes
column9: the acid-punk specter of “Commercial Rain” rears its majestic
column10: genre-defining head. Then
column11:
it’s gone.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21115/homepage_large.e8895358.jpg|You're Dead!|5058.0|Flying Lotus|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2014-10-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:25.332751|"

Each subsequent full-length album that Flying Lotus has released seems to start with a personal connection that's grown more all-encompassing the further he gets into his career. From his year of birth
column2: he moved on to the city he found his musical identity in
column3: then out to the very structure of the universe
column4: then deeper inside to the inner world of dreams and the subconscious. His fifth album
column5: You're Dead!
column6: has the stated theme of the one thing every single human has in common
column7: and just about every conceivable style of music is prone to address: the inevitability and condition of death
column8: and how mysterious it really is.

column1: Like many people who've grown past 30 years old
column2: Steven Ellison has lost some important people in his life. Specifically
column3: they were artistic inspirations—from collaborators like Austin Peralta to influences like J Dilla to blood relatives like Alice Coltrane—formative catalysts that made his music and his life what it is. Coltrane in particular is frequently brought up as a familial connection to Ellison
column4: but even if she weren't his great-aunt
column5: her meditative way of being in the world and putting forth music as a way of spiritual connection has carried through deeply into Ellison's own art
column6: even when it appears irreverent or cartoon-ridiculous on the surface.

column1: The title of You're Dead! has that exclamation point for a reason
column2: though. While the spirits of his friends
column3: family
column4: and peers weigh heavy throughout this album
column5: the music itself is frequently light and sometimes shamelessly goofy
column6: treating mortality with the irreverence and fascination of anything inescapable and unknowable. There's little that's morbid and even less that's melancholy about it. In the context of coping with The Other Side
column7: it all feels a lot more like a wake than a funeral.

column1: And consider the guests at this particular wake: pianist Herbie Hancock
column2: likely legacy-minded as he continues to branch out and find new musical environments through his seventies; rappers Snoop Dogg and Kendrick Lamar
column3: the latter whose insight towards death has the subtle heft of somebody who's cheated it while being well aware of those who didn't; guitarist Brendon Small
column4: whose involvement in the gory cartoon absurdity of ""Metalocalypse"" prepped him well for an album that sounds equally informed by Slayer and Raymond Scott. Even the album art and promotional visuals
column5: provided by the body-horror guro manga artist Shintaro Kago
column6: revels in the idea of nightmarish evisceration and dismemberment rendered with an almost playful slapstick weirdness.

column1: The theme sticks out as the most consistent element of You're Dead!
column2: since it's far and away the most free-ranging FlyLo album to date. And yet the album doesn't sprawl out of control
column3: maybe because it doesn't really have the time to: the whole record clocks in at just over 38 minutes
column4: all jolts of sound and quick bursts of motifs. The fleeting cross-sections of chopped-to-bits fusion jazz strung together over the first five minutes—the ascendant cosmic drone and black hole collapse of ""Theme""
column5: the fast-forward bop of Hancock collab ""Tesla""
column6: and the careening hesher-Sharrock guitar licks of ""Cold Dead""—flow from buzz-cluttered headspaces to spacious serenity so unexpectedly yet naturally that the seams never show. (The live-band personnel—including prog/jazz superdrummer Deantoni Parks
column7: Ayler-school saxophonist Kamasi Washington
column8: and ever-present partner/bass wizard Thundercat—do a masterful job in turning concentrated doses of high-speed
column9: complicated chops into giddy bursts of euphoric adrenaline.) Kendrick Lamar's virtuoso obstacle-course run through the d'n'b-tweaking ""Never Catch Me"" is the closest there is to a centerpiece statement of the album (""Analyze my demise
column10: I say I'm super anxious/ Recognize I deprive this fear and then embrace it""). But the tonal 180 into the buoyant
column11: kind of tipsy/faded Captain Murphy/Snoop Dogg teamup ""Dead Man's Tetris""—complete with a riff-echoing gun-cock collage and Street Fighter II K.O. SFX—is less of a jarring shock than a knowing counterpoint.

column1: From there
column2: the album's remaining path through prog
column3: fusion
column4: IDM
column5: and ambient all feels like a necessary comedown
column6: shot through with moments at the precipice of chaos or deliberate ugliness (like the pill-popper nightmare of Captain Murphy croak-wailing through ""The Boys Who Died in Their Sleep"")
column7: but still resiliently calm in the face of death. Ellison's once-sparse use of others' voices is especially haunting at points—Angel Deradoorian's breathily manipulated into weaving through wispy psychedelic soul like some minimalist version of Pink Floyd's ""The Great Gig in the Sky""
column8: or Niki Randa harmonizing at a distant horizon through ""Your Potential//The Beyond"". A lighter hand
column9: even when it's punching up bass drones or pushing through dense walls of complex instrumental interplay
column10: makes the end-of-humanity choral hymn ""Coronus
column11: the Terminator"" and the pull between intense rhythm and delicate melody on ""Moment of Hesitation"" feel infused with just as much wonder and awe as foreboding.

column1: There's the idea expressed through You're Dead!—intentional or otherwise—that making a life's work with the full knowledge of death as the final limiting factor is a strong motivator. Flying Lotus has the notion that death should be the only limiting factor
column2: and when he's put out a work that wrings beauty out of that very thing
column3:
what's the point of fearing anything?

"|19875.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19875-flying-lotus-youre-dead/|8.3|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21137/homepage_large.05355ca2.jpg|A World Lit Only By Fire|32310.0|Godflesh|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Avalanche']|2014-10-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:25.991540|"

“Have you ever participated in genocide?” When I interviewed Justin Broadrick in 2007
column2: he said he was asked that question while applying for a trip to the United States for the first time after 9/11. His anecdote was good for a sick laugh; Broadrick can be funny
column3: despite his reputation as a poker-faced purveyor of extreme metal
column4: shoegaze
column5: and industrial music as a former or current member of the British groups Napalm Death
column6: Jesu
column7: and the resurrected Godflesh
column8: among others. But his silly story about genocide is also indicative of the way absurdity and security can go hand in hand
column9: especially in a world where safety is
column10: at best
column11: a collective hallucination. Its guarantors can’t even keep knife-wielding maniacs from sprinting into the White House
column12: let alone regular people from being beheaded. Existence
column13: even with all its modern safeguards
column14: is fragile
column15: and rarely does it feel more so than when you’re listening to Broadrick’s music.

column1: A World Lit Only by Fire is Godflesh’s first album in 13 years. Their last
column2: 2001’s Hymns
column3: effectively disassembled itself in order for Broadrick to scavenge its chassis for scraps
column4: which he then used to build Jesu. Most obviously
column5: the final track of Hymns is titled “Jesu”— but instead of being a swansong
column6: it was a two-part
column7: 13-minute premonition of what was to come. Jesu went on to indulge Broadrick’s latent love of shoegaze and melody
column8: but it retained every milligram of Godflesh’s heaviness; when Broadrick issued Godflesh’s comeback EP
column9: Decline and Fall
column10: earlier this year
column11: it wasn’t so much a return to form as a transference of force. But where Decline and Fall unlocked the door
column12: A World Lit Only by Fire knocks down the entire wall surrounding it. “New Dark Ages” is the record’s method of entry
column13: and it’s accordingly annihilative: A spindly beat pulls back the skin to reveal sleek
column14: minimalist musculature
column15: and those riffs crush Broadrick’s windpipe as he gets biblical with his opening warning: “Don’t look back/ We’ll dissolve”. The resurgence of fundamentalist medievalism have been a concern of industrial music ever since SPK’s 1983 classic “Another Dark Age”— and “New Dark Ages” casts that creeping fear in a coat of millennial chrome.

column1: Much of the album doggedly refuses to deviate from the template of “New Dark Ages”
column2: which itself isn’t that much of a departure from what Godflesh laid down on their 1989 debut album
column3: Streetcleaner. The roboticized crust of the Godflesh of old
column4: though
column5: has been trimmed to fit an even bleaker era. Instead of being discreet compositions
column6: these songs are segments of a single continuum
column7: amputated from each other. “Shut Me Down”
column8: “Curse Us All”
column9: and “Carrion” flow into each other—inasmuch as anything on such a tense
column10: brittle album could be said to flow—with an almost martial uniformity. The distinctions are in the shades of texture and syncopation. In some places
column11: bassist G.C. Green evokes the corroded-carburetor clang of Big Black; elsewhere
column12: Broadrick’s righteous roar gets caught in the gears of the album’s drum-machine march
column13: if not the hopelessness of its protests.

column1: Broadrick first flexed his skills as a slightly more conventional singer/songwriter in Jesu
column2: but he’d begun exploring tunefulness toward the end of Godflesh’s first run. That eerie blend of ugliness and melody doesn’t crop up often on A World Lit Only by Fire; when it does
column3: it’s for terrific effect. “Life Giver Life Taker” and “Imperator” mix wailing echoes and spectral chants with chiseled riffs and insectoid rhythms
column4: while “Towers of Emptiness” and “Forgive Our Fathers” trail off the same way—with Broadrick’s voice
column5: naked and human
column6: hovering over ghostly drones and incanting the title of the track like it’s a faded memory. “Forgive Our Fathers” is particularly gorgeous; ditching his cyborg-barbarian howl halfway through
column7: he switches to the melancholy coo of Jesu just long enough to trap and loop the song’s lingering anguish in an apocalyptic fugue. As a whole
column8: A World Lit Only by Fire represents music converted into motion—kinetic and mechanical
column9: inexorable and inhuman. Godflesh
column10: never a forgiving band
column11:
has never sounded so relentless.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21093/homepage_large.9b85f5c2.jpg|Cosmic Logic|29484.0|Peaking Lights|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Weird World']|2014-10-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:26.646152|"

Psychedelia is traditionally a means of escape and out-of-body transcendence
column3: but in the case L.A.-via-Wisconsin duo Peaking Lights
column4: its function is more insular and grounding. For creative and life partners Aaron Coyes and Indra Dunis
column5: bliss really is a product of hugs
column6: not drugs: their dubwise
column7: synth-smudged psychedelic pop is as lyrically sentimental as it is musically ethereal
column8: and offers proof that the hot-blooded rush of romance and the dizzying delirium of new parenthood are as potent as any chemical supplement. But in the wake of their 2012 breakthrough LP Lucifer
column9: Peaking Lights are now at the point where their humble recording project has become a full-fledged career
column10: one that requires regularly breaking out of their cocoon. Given that Coyes and Dunis’ music has always pointed a kaleidoscopic lens on their personal lives
column11: it’s only natural that their sound has changed to reflect their new reality—both the joy of interacting with larger audiences
column12: and the anxieties that result when domestic bliss is disrupted by the demands of making a living on the road.

column1: For Peaking Lights
column2: Cosmic Logic heralds a dramatic aesthetic shift similar to that undertaken by Animal Collective on Strawberry Jam or Beach House on Teen Dream
column3: where a once-mystical entity emerged as an extroverted force
column4: hardening their liquefied sound into more modular shapes
column5: and promoting vocals from textural detail to featured attraction. And from a sonic standpoint at least
column6: Cosmic Logic is a triumph
column7: retaining the heady allure of the band’s earlier records but infusing it with enough rhythmic intricacy and fidgety energy to warrant a band-name change to Tweaking Lights. Within the album’s first three seconds
column8: we’ve already been catapulted several galaxies beyond Lucifer’s subaquatic serenity: Where the beats on previous Peaking Lights albums rarely rose above a tick-tock titter
column9: Cosmic Logic opener “Infinite Trips” surges forth with a thundering drum break that provides the bedrock on which Dunis’ calm coo squares off against space-bound synth oscillations and a Daydream Nation-esque guitar pattern.

column1: The songs on Cosmic Logic are half as long as the ones on Lucifer
column2: but equally stuffed with wondrous detail
column3: giving these compact tracks the compressing effect of a squeezed-out toothpaste tube: “Little Light” craftily invokes both slow-motion dub drowsiness and peak-hour piano-house elation; the seemingly slumberous “Dreamquest” intensifies into a twitchy tropical funk; and “Eyes to Sea” piles on acid-house freakery until its titular incantation starts to sound like “ecstasy.” But even with the punchier
column4: dancefloor-friendly presentation
column5: there remains something comfortably cozy about the sound of Cosmic Logic—Peaking Lights may sound more eager to get crowds moving this time around
column6: but they’d still sooner DJ a rager in your apartment living room than a superclub.

column1: It’s too bad then that Cosmic Logic’s entrancing
column2: otherworldly effects are diminished by some nursery-rhyme-naïve lyrics. Of course
column3: Peaking Lights’ lyrics have never been especially deep (unless you’re referring to their traditional position in the mix). But Cosmic Logic forcefully flips their traditional script
column4: placing Dunis’ voice high above the percolating productions where they were once deeply embedded within them. And
column5: unfortunately
column6: this can place undue emphasis on the inflexible quality of her voice and the rote
column7: reductive nature of her words. She may be singing louder
column8: but that doesn’t necessarily mean she’s become more emotionally expressive: “Telephone Call” (chorus: Telephone call
column9: telephone call from space/ Calling all
column10: calling all the human race”) feels less like a comment on our modern-day addiction to constant connectivity than the dumbstruck observations of someone who’s just awoken from a 20-year deep sleep and handed their first iPhone. The YACHT-rockin’ “Hypnotic Hustle” and digi-reggae groover “Breakdown”
column11: meanwhile
column12: render the manic rhythm of daily life as a strobe-lit ballet
column13: but Dunis’ anodyne delivery feels oddly disconnected from the tension/release described within; even when she’s issuing explicit directives for us to get down
column14: Dunis seems to be dancing like somebody’s watching.

column1: But on the late-game electro-disco workout “New Grrrls”
column2: Dunis fully acclimatizes to her new home in spotlight
column3: and opens up to convey something more resonant than the simple
column4: nondescript sloganeering proffered throughout much of Cosmic Logic. On the surface
column5: the song is a roll call of trailblazing female heroes—from Kim Gordon and Yoko Ono to black-power activist Angela Davis and sex educator Betty Dodson—that feels like a shout-out to another song that was itself a series of shout-outs. But it’s a necessary update
column6: wherein Dunis tries to reconcile her radicalized riot grrl past with her seemingly more prosaic present as a parent
column7: and finds the two are fuelled by the same ire: “Can’t stop to be just a mom/ The choice to stay at home is gone/ Worker
column8: lover
column9: mother
column10: wife/ Gotta do it all in this life.” And with that line
column11: this album’s equilibrium-upsetting aural eclecticism comes into sharp focus: even if you’re not a working mom trying to function on four hours of sleep per night
column12:
the buzzing busyness and hallucinatory disorientation of Cosmic Logic are liable to make you feel like one.

"|19854.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19854-peaking-lights-cosmic-logic/|6.5|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20964/homepage_large.af368c1a.jpg|In the Orbit of Ra|32455.0|Sun Ra and His Arkestra|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Strut']|2014-10-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:27.305154|"

It seems uncanny in retrospect
column2: but the first time I encountered Sun Ra’s music was as a teenager watching MTV. The passing of the avant-garde jazz composer born Herman Blount in May of 1993 was reported in the midst of broadcasting “Whoomp! (There It Is)” and “Whoot
column3: There It Is” videos
column4: which seems as incongruous as if news of Captain Beefheart’s passing had merited mention during ""Jersey Shore"" commercial breaks (it didn’t). There’s still no news item that seems quite like a transmission beamed from the stars as having Kurt Loder suggest that viewers investigate Sun Ra’s extraterrestrial 1963 album
column5: Cosmic Tones for Mental Therapy.

column1: With over a hundred full-length albums stretching from 1956 until the early '90s
column2: some hand-painted and self-released
column3: Sun Ra’s recorded work is less a discography than a cosmology. Sun Ra embodied both the history of jazz as well as its future
column4: evolving from big band swing and stride piano to space gospel and white noise blat
column5: with live shows that embraced all of it. He's one of the 20th century's singular human beings
column6: yet one who claimed to be an alien. Before George Clinton's mothership landed
column7: before Cybotron and electro
column8: before Lil Wayne's croak about being a martian
column9: Sun Ra was already floating in space. Depending on what album you investigate
column10: though
column11: you might imagine that Sun Ra made woozy doo-wop
column12: shrieking paeans to Atlantis
column13: landings on the moon
column14: odes to Batman
column15: future disco
column16: ditties about the atomic bomb
column17: or gentle versions of Disney tunes. Which is to say that there’s no exact portal into Ra’s world.

column1: Spanning twenty songs across two discs
column2: longtime Ra reedman Marshall Allen’s well-curated In the Orbit of Ra covers as much ground (or
column3: rather
column4: space) as any one set can. Ra alights on almost all aspects of its bandleader’s multidimensional sound and presents a coherent trajectory through it
column5: alternating between otherworldly explorations and earthbound beats. It opens with the deft melodic turns of “Somewhere in Space”
column6: recorded in 1958
column7: and moves into the drum-drunk seven-minute suite “The Lady With The Golden Stockings”
column8: recorded just two years on.

column1: Those heavy drums and crystalline melodies meld with two of Sun Ra’s more familiar instruments
column2: his electric piano and the space chants of his longtime vocalist June Tyson
column3: on “Somebody Else’s World.” Swift figures of upright bass
column4: drums
column5: bells and twinkling celeste power “Angels And Demons At Play”
column6: creating the sort of winsome miniatures that are reminiscent of Aphex Twin at his most gentle (“Flim” and “Nannou” in particular). The jittery piano figure and afterburner chording of “Rocket Number Nine Take Off for the Planet Venus” might be Sun Ra’s biggest “hit”
column7: a swinging hard bop number that soon opens up to allow room for his triumvirate of reedmen John Gilmore
column8: Pat Patrick
column9: and Marshall Allen to take extended solos
column10: as well as bassist Ronnie Boykins' quiet yet mesmeric solo that hints at the galaxy surrounding
column11: before the ensemble convenes again to chant in unison: “Second stop at Jupiter!” like interplanetary bus drivers.

column1: The second disc dives into Sun Ra’s more outré fare
column2: balancing it with more classic jazz numbers. “Astro Black”
column3: the ten-minute suite from his 1973 album of the same name
column4: sounds like Duke Ellington’s jungle music shot into deepest space. “Astro Black Mythology/ Astro Timeless Immortality/ Astro Thought in Mystic Sound” June Tyson intones like a saleslady from Outer Spaceways Incorporated
column5: the growls of saxophones now react to the radiation emitted from Sun Ra’s prototype synthesizers
column6: which whirr and bleep like malfunctioning satellites. For a taste of Sun Ra’s influence on electronic dance music and minimal techno of all stripes
column7: there’s the dizzying eleven-minute pulsars of “Dance of the Cosmo Aliens.”

column1: While the shrieks
column2: squalls
column3: and space junk noise was what initially drew me to Sun Ra’s music as a teenager
column4: as the years have passed
column5: I now find myself revisiting the twinkling polyrhythmic pieces that comprise the last half of the second disc
column6: highlighted by numbers like “The Nile” and “Planet Earth.” That in the late '80s Sun Ra and His Arkestra would offer up a charming cover of “Pink Elephants On Parade”
column7: from Dumbo
column8: shows the latent childlike wonder coursing through his vast catalog.

column1: But Ra’s music is a mixture of open-eared innocence as well as the darkest blues. Those space chants are but field hollers transported to outer space
column2: far from the world of deeply-embittered segregation he lived through in America. He posited himself as an alien life form so as to embody his sense of estrangement here on Earth. “This world is strange to me
column3:
” he sings on the piano ballad “Trying to Put the Blame On Me.” “I feel alone/ so all alone/ like a different kind of being.”

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20895/homepage_large.fe3330a8.jpg|Shallow|5308.0|Pissed Jeans|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-10-06 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 16:32:27.966146|"

“They want it to be real
column2: like I’m singing songs from my heart
column3: ” hypothesized Matt Korvette
column4: lead singer of Pissed Jeans
column5: in a 2012 interview. “But you’re clearly just performing for people on a stage
column6: just the same as
column7: like
column8: a juggler.” Korvette’s comparison of himself to a carnival performer sums up Pissed Jeans’ longstanding paradox. In real life
column9: Korvette (real name: Kosloff) is an office worker who holds down a “corporate insurance gig”; in Pissed Jeans
column10: he assumes the name of a sports car and fronts a viciously dissonant punk rock band that’s signed to Sub Pop
column11: torchbearers of the squirming
column12: misanthropic sludge that Sub Pop once symbolized. Korvette switches between these two guises when the situation calls for it
column13: ready at the crank of an amp to transform into some kind of writhing
column14: grunt-spewing superhero. Call him The Juggler.

column1: Korvette’s uncanny superpower—to turn the drudgery of everyday life into the stuff of absurdist theater—has become honed over the years
column2: but it was already strong on Pissed Jeans' first album
column3: Shallow. Released in 2005 on the tiny label Parts Unknown and long out of print
column4: it’s getting reissued by Sub Pop with the inclusion of two bonus tracks
column5: “Throbbing Organ” and “Night Minutes”
column6: drawn from their debut 7” in 2004. Those two songs don’t hold a candle to Shallow’s gut-shuddering power; the fidelity is thin to the point of flimsiness
column7: and guitarist Bradley Fry had yet to fully harness his neck-wringing attack. Mostly
column8: though
column9: Korvette hangs in the background
column10: yelping unintelligibly over two tracks that sound a lot like each other: splashes of asphalt gray and muddy brown that fall somewhere between the Birthday Party’s puked-up blues and the Jesus Lizard’s punch-drunk nut-thrusting.

column1: Pissed Jeans’ black-eyed view of punk doesn’t brighten on Shallow—it just comes into focus. On “Ugly Twin (I’ve Got)”
column2: Korvette projects his self-loathing onto a doppelganger; Fry’s riffs buckle under the combined weight of that ingrown hatred
column3: grinding along at a snail’s pace and punctuated by scrambled
column4: Greg Ginn-esque licks. That punch-the-mirror repugnance at one’s own navel-gazing existence takes a darkly comic turn on “Ashamed of My Cum”. Gnawing at his own syllables with all the puzzled-panther ferocity of Darby Crash
column5: Korvette blurs and slurs his masturbatory confessional in an aptly orgasmic yowl of agony.

column1: The shit hits the ceiling in “Boring Girls”. Hacking up hairballs through a face full of Novocain—yet somehow clinging to a hook—Korvette screeches and mumbles about “Oh
column2: I want to kiss those boring girls” while the rest of the band desperately drones. A change seems imminent
column3: but it never comes; instead
column4: the song plunks away at the same nerve-deadening
column5: G-sharp power chord
column6: unsatisfying and unresolved
column7: until it becomes a featureless smear of whatever the opposite of sex is. When the guitar drops out for a verse to leave a gaping absence of noise
column8: the anticlimax is nauseating. Pissed Jeans wrote a so-boring-it’s-fascinating anthem to honor all the so-boring-they’re-fascinating objects of their creepy fixation
column9: which is disgusting and also hilariously perfect.

column1: If there’s an early Sub Pop band that Pissed Jeans are the spiritual heirs to
column2: it’s Mudhoney. The two groups sound little alike
column3: but Korvette and crew have revamped Mudhoney’s slop-trawling skronk for a new millennium—and nowhere is that more evident than on Shallow’s first track
column4: “I’m Sick”. While not on par with Mudhoney’s 1988 debut single
column5: “Touch Me I’m Sick”
column6: the song is Pissed Jeans’ opening shot
column7: a bratty stab at infamy that perversely celebrates their own hopeless prognosis. “I’m dehydrated/ I’ve got diarrhea/ I can’t keep my food down/ My sinuses are clogged
column8: ” Korvette whines violently
column9: and he makes damn sure he sounds like all four of these symptoms
column10: plus more
column11: are afflicting him as the tape rolls. There’s no cure in sight
column12: and no punch line. A year before Twitter came into being
column13: Korvette was already stringing together annoying
column14: myopic tweets about how he feels like shit
column15: then brazenly pretending they’re worthy of an audience. Between that and all the other examples of deadpan
column16: documentarian tedium to be found on Shallow
column17: a strange thing happens: Korvette stops his juggling and does sound like he’s singing from the heart. Only he may not actually be singing
column18:
and that may not actually be his heart.

"|19669.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19669-pissed-jeans-shallow/|7.8|Jason Heller

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21141/homepage_large.880729e9.jpg|Art Official Age|3397.0|Prince|['Rock'
column3: Prince and Warner Brothers did not split amicably. Not only did the superstar write the word SLAVE on his face
column4: he also changed his name to an unpronounceable logo that was quickly translated into English as “The Artist Formerly Known As…” Unhappy with faltering sales in the new decade
column5: he tried to release a quick slew of albums in order to get out of his contract
column6: but Warner insisted on waiting the industry-standard two years between major releases. It must have felt like a demotion after Prince more or less owned the 1980s
column7: a decade when even a flop like Under the Cherry Moon could spin off a hit album like Parade. Despite his complaints
column8: however
column9: Prince never regained his former popularity following his departure from Warner; as he struggled to go his own way and keep up with trends he was no longer setting
column10: his independent output quickly grew prodigious and preeningly self-indulgent
column11: ranging from the triple-disc Emancipation in 1996 to the soggy The Rainbow Children in 2001 to the one-two punch of MPLSound and LotusFlow3r in 2009.

column1: What’s most surprising about Prince re-signing (or resigning?) with Warner Brothers nearly twenty years later is just how much sense it makes for both parties. The label has welcomed one of its signature stars back to the fold
column2: who brings his never-reissued/never-remastered back catalog with him. They’ve already teased a new edition of Purple Rain—the dream we all dream of—and Prince gets some major-label backing at a time when he seems creatively rejuvenated and newly focused. A string of startlingly solid singles led to Art Official Age
column3: which despite its ludicrous title
column4: is the most engaged Prince has sounded in a long while. In particular
column5: “Breakfast Can Wait” is an AM lovemaking jam that schools R. Kelly with its old-school slink and Prince in supreme pillowtalk mode (“Come here baby
column6: let me put you on my plate”).

column1: Musically
column2: Art Official Age is all over the map—gloriously so
column3: in fact—as though Prince is trying to cram a triple album into a single disc. Opener “Art Official Cage” cribs directly from Daft Punk’s more arena-ready moments
column4: building a post-disco banger on some Nile Rodgers-style rhythm guitar. It sounds perhaps too familiar
column5: but the song mimics its source with aplomb and what sounds like Princely arrogance. Cockiness has always looked better on Prince than assless chaps or satin frocks
column6: and the song has a feisty energy that even a new jack swing rap can’t derail. Some of the best songs here are slow jams
column7: like the wishful “This Could Be Us” and “Breakdown”
column8: which sounds like one of the most personally revealing tunes Prince has ever recorded: “Waking up in places that you would never believe
column9: ” he sings with what sounds like deep regret. “Give me back the time
column10: you can keep the memories.” As the strings lift the song out of the depths and laserbeams fire at the edges of the music
column11: Prince launches into some vocal contortions that prove his voice has lost none of its wild mutability over the years. It’s the rare moment of true gravity on an album that sounds like Prince actually had a lot of fun making.

column1: There’s something reassuring about such good spirits coming from him
column2: as it recalls a much younger Prince whose mischievous smile and eye rolls conveyed a self-possession and self-awareness. On the other hand
column3: the few times he nods to an overarching funk/sci-fi mythology—something about being cryogenically frozen for 50 years and waking up in a society with no first-person pronouns—Prince comes across as a grouchy old guy. “Twenty-four karat hashtag
column4: put your phone in your bag
column5: ” he raps on “The Gold Standard”
column6: sounding too much like a man in his mid-50s.

column1: Art Official Age is not a return to form by any means
column2: but a modestly exciting Prince album. That’s certainly more than we could expect in 2014
column3: and it’s certainly more than we get out of PlectrumElectrum. Prince recorded the album with his all-female backing band 3rdEyeGirl
column4: which includes drummer Hannah Ford Welton
column5: guitarist Donna Grantis
column6: and bassist Ida Nielsen. All have backgrounds and even degrees in rock and jazz
column7: so it’s obvious they have immense chops. The rhythm section lock down the grooves on the punk-/surf-rock “Marz” and the strutting “Stopthistrain”
column8: and Grantis (formerly a member of the New Power Generation) riffs and solos on “Anotherlove” with Princely abandon.

column1: What they don’t have is much of a personality. Recorded live in the studio using analog equipment
column2: the album is nevertheless too proficient
column3: too slick
column4: and too professional to come across as much more than anonymous. They show little of the kinky inventiveness of the Revolution or the innate versatility of the New Power Generation; instead
column5: Plectrum is crammed with predictable rap-rock riffs
column6: vague alt-rock menance
column7: and bloozy showboating. Especially blasting from Paisley Park
column8: this is a perversely unimaginative and restrictive idea of rock‘n’roll
column9: with none of the musical freedom that Prince has traditionally shown. One of the great pop synthesists
column10: he has blended so many different styles and sounds so fluidly that his best music sounded positively utopian: a world without charts or genres
column11: release schedules
column12: or label contracts.

column1: Prince and 3rdEyeGirl have good intentions
column2: of course
column3: and at times the album sounds like a rebuttal to the pesky rock-is-dead palaver that so many of the form’s aging practitioners have memorized. “A girl with a guitar is 12 times better than another crazy band o’ boys
column4: ” Prince asserts on “Fixurlifeup”. But he’s decrying prefab pop groups while backed by a prefab pop group
column5: preaching female empowerment while playing up the novelty of an all-female band. Both of these albums sound slightly out of time
column6: but at least Art Official Age
column7: despite its flaws
column8: has the bravado to imagine how the pop music of the future might function. By contrast
column9:
Plectrum merely duplicates the sounds and politics of rock ‘n’ roll’s stodgy past. 

"|19900.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19900-prince-3rdeyegirl-art-official-ageplectrumelectrum/|6.5|Stephen M. Deusner

column3: in fact—as though Prince is trying to cram a triple album into a single disc. Opener “Art Official Cage” cribs directly from Daft Punk’s more arena-ready moments
column4: building a post-disco banger on some Nile Rodgers-style rhythm guitar. It sounds perhaps too familiar
column5: but the song mimics its source with aplomb and what sounds like Princely arrogance. Cockiness has always looked better on Prince than assless chaps or satin frocks
column6: and the song has a feisty energy that even a new jack swing rap can’t derail. Some of the best songs here are slow jams
column7: like the wishful “This Could Be Us” and “Breakdown”
column8: which sounds like one of the most personally revealing tunes Prince has ever recorded: “Waking up in places that you would never believe
column9: ” he sings with what sounds like deep regret. “Give me back the time
column10: you can keep the memories.” As the strings lift the song out of the depths and laserbeams fire at the edges of the music
column11: Prince launches into some vocal contortions that prove his voice has lost none of its wild mutability over the years. It’s the rare moment of true gravity on an album that sounds like Prince actually had a lot of fun making.

column1: There’s something reassuring about such good spirits coming from him
column2: as it recalls a much younger Prince whose mischievous smile and eye rolls conveyed a self-possession and self-awareness. On the other hand
column3: the few times he nods to an overarching funk/sci-fi mythology—something about being cryogenically frozen for 50 years and waking up in a society with no first-person pronouns—Prince comes across as a grouchy old guy. “Twenty-four karat hashtag
column4: put your phone in your bag
column5: ” he raps on “The Gold Standard”
column6: sounding too much like a man in his mid-50s.

column1: Art Official Age is not a return to form by any means
column2: but a modestly exciting Prince album. That’s certainly more than we could expect in 2014
column3: and it’s certainly more than we get out of PlectrumElectrum. Prince recorded the album with his all-female backing band 3rdEyeGirl
column4: which includes drummer Hannah Ford Welton
column5: guitarist Donna Grantis
column6: and bassist Ida Nielsen. All have backgrounds and even degrees in rock and jazz
column7: so it’s obvious they have immense chops. The rhythm section lock down the grooves on the punk-/surf-rock “Marz” and the strutting “Stopthistrain”
column8: and Grantis (formerly a member of the New Power Generation) riffs and solos on “Anotherlove” with Princely abandon.

column1: What they don’t have is much of a personality. Recorded live in the studio using analog equipment
column2: the album is nevertheless too proficient
column3: too slick
column4: and too professional to come across as much more than anonymous. They show little of the kinky inventiveness of the Revolution or the innate versatility of the New Power Generation; instead
column5: Plectrum is crammed with predictable rap-rock riffs
column6: vague alt-rock menance
column7: and bloozy showboating. Especially blasting from Paisley Park
column8: this is a perversely unimaginative and restrictive idea of rock‘n’roll
column9: with none of the musical freedom that Prince has traditionally shown. One of the great pop synthesists
column10: he has blended so many different styles and sounds so fluidly that his best music sounded positively utopian: a world without charts or genres
column11: release schedules
column12: or label contracts.

column1: Prince and 3rdEyeGirl have good intentions
column2: of course
column3: and at times the album sounds like a rebuttal to the pesky rock-is-dead palaver that so many of the form’s aging practitioners have memorized. “A girl with a guitar is 12 times better than another crazy band o’ boys
column4: ” Prince asserts on “Fixurlifeup”. But he’s decrying prefab pop groups while backed by a prefab pop group
column5: preaching female empowerment while playing up the novelty of an all-female band. Both of these albums sound slightly out of time
column6: but at least Art Official Age
column7: despite its flaws
column8: has the bravado to imagine how the pop music of the future might function. By contrast
column9:
Plectrum merely duplicates the sounds and politics of rock ‘n’ roll’s stodgy past.

column3: pairing recent Young Money signees Rich Homie Quan and Young Thug together for an 84-minute release seems like a half-baked idea. Though both rappers roots’ orginate in the variegated modern Atlanta rap scene

column6: totally anthemic single together
column7: ”Lifestyle”

column9: Quan
column10: and occasionally Birdman.

column1: Luckily

column5: he has a deft ear for melody
column6: and the points where he locks in harmonically with Thug—”Tell Em (Lies)” is perhaps the best example—feel magical. Given that his counterpart is wont to do his own thing

column10: where

column12: then
column13: Thug’s approach has never been as polished and effective as it sounds on Tha Tour Part 1. Even though it’s still tough to figure out what Thug is talking about—”CREW CUT! CREW CUT!” he yells on “Flava”
column14: about his preferred t-shirt style—never has his Vine-loop flow sounded so awesome.

column1: This is 84 minutes of mixtape-rapping released by two dudes who have lucrative label deals in place
column2: so naturally

column5: but when they strike the balance—”730”

column7: “Givenchy”
column8: “I Know It”—it’s the stuff of vivid dreams. Operating over London on da Track’s bed of snappy
column9: energetic-but-slightly-warped trap
column10: Quan and Thug are basically the Larry Johnson/Priest Holmes backfield of rap

column1: Birdman’s involvement on Tha Tour Part 1 is comparatively spare but serves an important purpose—to stamp the two latest stars of his stable with his invaluable seal. Young Thug is making the music that many imagined Lil Wayne could make

and it makes perfect sense that Birdman has thrown his weight behind what is probably the best free mixtape offered for download in 2014.
