column3: PC Worship have been the sort of amorphous New York ensemble that can only be defined by a series of question marks. Is this an improv noise collective? A ""mutant soul band""? A casual experiment in home-recording? If so
column4: why is their loft called Le Wallet? Did they really all meet as New School jazz majors? Is it true they build their own instruments? And why is one called ""the shitar""? PC Worship is
column5: in essence
column6: a twisted
column7: low-pitched vision of subterranean psychedelia—variously made of bad-moon-lit trash-punk
column8: droning minimalism
column9: prepared pianos
column10: and Albert Ayler-worshipping sax freak-outs—as imagined by one Justin Frye
column11: who handled vocals
column12: guitars
column13: tape manipulations
column14: and keys as the writer
column15: recorder
column16: and producer of this latest behemoth
column17: Social Rust. Frye has played back-up for experimental synth-cyborg Gary War as well as Baltimore weirdos Teeth Mountain
column18: both of which offer only a surface idea of PC Worship's frayed
column19: pummeling avant-gardism. The questions have no direct answers—though who would want them?

column1: Social Rust sees PC Worship evolving into their most realized semblance of a ""rock band"" yet
column2: collaging decades of downtown New York dissonance while sludging into the future. Along with Frye
column3: the core group is guitarist Michael Etten (also credited for ""sax?"" parts)
column4: bassist Jordan Bernstein of the Dreebs
column5: and drummer Shannon Sigley
column6: as well as numerous contributors of backwards violin lines learned from John Cale
column7: homemade noise generators
column8: circuit-bent tape players
column9: creative piano solos (in other words
column10: running one's hand across the keys lawlessly)
column11: bass clarinet
column12: and organ. Frye
column13: along with another PC guy named ""Bongo Dan"" (credited here for adding percussive flourishes ""on something
column14: somewhere"")
column15: have both worked at NYC museum MoMA PS1—and perhaps they took notes on the cut-and-paste junk sculptures by contemporary artists who carry Dada forward. PC Worship's adventurous style of art-punk is spiritually not dissimilar to that of Butthole Surfers
column16: though it seems more interesting to draw connections to PC's peers: Andrew Savage
column17: of studious New York traditionalists Parquet Courts
column18: is co-releasing Rust on his label
column19: Dull Tools
column20: and the two bands just announced that a supergroup called PCPC will tour with a godfather of similarly Beat-obsessed bohemian punk-noise
column21: Thurston Moore.

column1: PC Worship's journey from tin-can-recorded live jams of squalling feedback
column2: free jazz exploration
column3: and meditative cello to the more formally-realized Social Rust is not unexpected—as early as 2010's Millenial Kreephaus tape on Night-People
column4: they've incorporated heavier punk riffs and conventional drum/vocal structures
column5: despite the tendencies for crackling radio hiss and a gurgling
column6: ghostly
column7: cinematic distance. The organization of sound has been gradual over 2011's Dread Head
column8: 2012's Toxic Love
column9: and 2013's Beat Punk
column10: the ideas all crystallizing to a hyper-present maelstrom on Social Rust. The music of PC Worship's past pulled and pinched at your brain
column11: requiring patience
column12: and now it is more immediate
column13: but no less weird. Instead of collapsing into one another
column14: ideas are given proper canvases.

column1: Social Rust is a masterful act of trickery. The first half works through PC Worship's most accessible material to date—""Odd"" and ""Behind the Picture"" have heavy
column2: visceral
column3: hummable grooves with valleys and explosive swells. The hooks have a throbbing backbone; you could do a stoned headbang to them. ""I'm feeling odd
column4: Frye and co. sing
column5: in unison
column6: over—relatively speaking—a thick
column7: soaring grunge riff. The layered vocals are possessed by an otherness in their deranged multiplicity. ""Odd"" opens with caterwauling
column8: terrifying shrieks
column9: which sound ripped from a horror film
column10: and most of the song glides through a calmly sinister
column11: low-tone poem: ""Smoke dripping
column12: heat seaking
column13: dust breathing."" ""Picture"" features a peculiar tempo change at its midpoint
column14: racing off to an endless
column15: kraut-shaped contortion. A lit
column16: dragged cigarette opens the air-tight
column17: claustrophobic highlight
column18: ""Rust""
column19: which dirges with monotone
column20: free-associating lyrics
column21: capturing all of PC Worship's best ideas in four minutes. (Amusingly
column22: ""Rust"" features a hypnotizing swarm of atonal violin drones by the Dreebs' Adam Markiewicz
column23: who—on the other side of the dim-lit New York spectrum—also put down some of the sophisticated strings on Mr Twin Sister's recent clubby

column1: The mystical tape mutation of ""Gypsy"" opens with a creepy cackle
column2: before summoning clouds of patchouli-scented incense smoke
column3: and it paces Social Rust for the dusty strummer
column4: ""Baby in the Backroom"". ""I look at everybody and think about hell/ I wonder if hell's bad?"" Frye subtly taunts over his most directly pleasing
column5: wearied
column6: and clear-sounding chorus
column7: which still sounds like it ought to be blaring from a shitty boombox. And just then
column8: this melodious side of Rust ducks out: a 44-second attack clears the way for a heavily-saturated closing trio of monolithic exercises in Swans-like endurance
column9: ecstasy
column10: venom
column11: and dread. PC Worship ease listeners in with hooks
column12: then whip them to a pulp.

column1: There's always humor in purposefully derailing a conventionally good thing
column2: especially when it comes by way of quaking no-wave monsters. As such
column3: PC Worship are committed to their ideas—or the perpetual destruction and rebirth of them—but they do not take themselves too seriously. When I saw them last
column4: at the soon-defunct Williamsburg venue Death by Audio
column5: cymbals were pushed over
column6: pointillist sax blurts were mixed with manic cassette fuckery
column7: and an acoustic guitar with at least one broken string was ""prepared"" using a crushed plastic cup.

column1: Among PC Worship's dizzying smatter of tapes and CD-Rs
column2: Social Rust appears to be their fifth LP
column3: but who knows? Their prolificacy seems intended to confuse. PC Worship are analog rock eccentrics who visibly enjoy skewing information—even basic details on their website can take the form of abstracted poetry
column4: and it wouldn't be surprising if they secretly released a whole unknown album on VHS tape with carrier-pigeon distribution. For a band so keen on obfuscation
column5: the notion of making complex musical ideas more palatable isn't just an aesthetic shift
column6: but also an ideological one. Nonetheless
column7: Social Rust proves that real experimentation does not require impenetrability at every turn. Referencing Meat Puppets
column8: Frye writes in the credits
column9: ""I bought Too High to Die on CD from a thrift store and listened to it while I drove across the desert
column10: then someone spilled Cherry Coke on it
column11: which dried
column12: sticky to the CD and I frisbeed it into a thunderstorm sunset outside of Phoenix."" Music is everywhere
column13: and the expanses are chaotic
column14: and understanding the cocophony of sound (and life) is futile. Now
column15: though
column16:
freaks of all-ages and places can hear Social Rust and feel that giddy sense of hope crawling in their skin—these out-sounds are being twisted from someplace new.

On a warm night in September at S.O.B.'s in New York City
column2: actor Omari Hardwick introduced singer/songwriter Luke James as the best R&B vocalist to emerge in the past twenty years. While that's debatable
column3: it doesn't feel hyperbolic
column4: which says as much as needs saying about James' uncanny technical talents: he is a precision singer nonpareil
column5: bold and subtle
column6: with a tender falsetto that sustains muscular force even at the top of its register. It was this earnest
column7: vigorous power and proficiency that defined ""I Want You
column8: the breakout from the 2011 mixtape <i>#Luke
column9: which also appears on his latest
column10: self-titled album. The song would receive a Grammy nomination for Best R&B Performance
column11: propelling a behind-the-scenes talent without an album into competition with long-established stars. (It lost to Usher's ""Climax
column12: which is
column13: granted
column14: one of the decade's best records point blank.)

column1: 30-year-old James is no industry novice; he attended high school with Frank Ocean in New Orleans where he formed an R&B group called Upskale in the late '90s. He soon moved to Los Angeles to pursue music
column2: formed a duo called Luke & Q
column3: and after a few false starts (and an appearance in the video for Destiny's Child's ""Soldier"") linked with Timbaland protégé Danja. After penning records for Chris Brown (""Crawl
column4: his biggest hit
column5: was co-written with Magic!""s Nasri Atweh)
column6: Justin Bieber
column7: and Britney Spears
column8: he embarked on a solo career in 2011. After releasing two mixtapes (#Luke and the 2012 tape Whispers in the Dark)
column9: several singles (the  pristine ""I.O.U.""
column10: from 2013)
column11: and touring the world as an opener for Beyoncé
column12: Luke
column13: who now lives in Harlem
column14: has released his official debut.

column1: Luke James exists in its own universe
column2: paying little heed to the sound of contemporary hip-hop or R&B. Although Rick Ross nabs a guest verse on ""Options""
column3: a tempestuous anthem of desperation
column4: Luke James is otherwise a traditional vocal-driven R&B record
column5: a style unexpectedly off-trend in 2014. In this sense
column6: it stands with the work of artists like Jazmine Sullivan
column7: whose old soul backings are primarily used in the service of tight-as-a-drum songwriting and singing that takes center stage. Although traditional
column8: James' sound isn't as retro as Sullivan's tends to be: at his best
column9: with ballads and mid-tempo explorations of passion and heartbreak
column10: his art is the nexus of nuanced interpretation
column11: personality
column12: a tireless wellspring of emotion
column13: and the virtuosic control which channels that emotion to breathtaking effect.

column1: Not that every song stands outside of time
column2: though—James just has little interest in the late-'90s pop-R&B fixation of current R&B
column3: nor in the dusty textures and breakbeats of whatever remains of neo-soul. Occasionally
column4: his songs do look to the 1980s; the layered
column5: percussive rhythms of ""Dancing in the Dark"" suggest the worldbeat-inflected pop sound of Michael Jackson's ""Liberian Girl"" or Toto
column6: and ""Expose"" is a fun retro-funk closer that would feel at home on a wedding dancefloor. But the album's sonic canvas is mostly unobtrusive: heavy drums are present throughout
column7: and instrumentation will ramp up intensity to match a song's natural climax. But by and large
column8: the backdrop complements James' own cultivation of emotion.

column1: The stakes are set through his singing and songwriting
column2: in part through the transitive properties of James' formidable voice
column3: which proves a thrilling listen: his intense vocals swoop in to lock on one note
column4: only to glide gracefully to the next
column5: a feather caught in the breeze. The album is bold in some ways and hedged in others: It relies wholly on James' singing and songwriting to attract its audience
column6: gleefully shedding the trend-hopping fans eager to conscript outsider narratives of authenticity. The rough vocal styles of the been-through-it-all soul singer
column7: the lurid details of the afterparty's afterparty
column8: the angles that would present him more accessibly to a male audience
column9: are irrelevant here. While James' singing is uncompromised
column10: Luke James feels safer: a collection of powerhouse emotions
column11: it's stylistically noncommittal
column12: beyond its recognition of James' otherworldly talents. An overarching vision
column13: or some kind of formal framework
column14: would be welcome.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: there isn't a weak song on the record. And although long considered out of fashion by the music press (just search the critical history for references to Mariah Carey's ""melisma"")
column3: technical prowess like James' is a feature
column4: not a bug
column5: particularly in his moving ballads. As atmosphere has overtaken performance as a central value in popular R&B
column6: a charismatic star like Luke James is a refreshing anomaly. Luke James may not be a crossover smash for the singer
column7:
but it sets the table for a career with unlimited potential.

Marvin Ramalepe grew up in a northern township in South Africa
column2: and similar to other artists from disadvantaged places
column3: he has distinguished himself by inventing a world. Ramalepe
column4: who produces as DJ Spoko
column5: has wrapped himself in a style he calls Bacardi House
column6: a frenetic amalgamation—named after the rum popular amongst his fans—of house music
column7: kwaito (a South African hip hop variant)
column8: and Shangaan electro. War God
column9: which follows the Ghost Town EP on True Panther
column10: is his first album available in the West
column11: a 20-track tour of Ramalepe's distinct
column12: tireless style.

column1: War God wastes no time introducing itself. There are no intros and outros in Bacardi House
column2: only snares and synths
column3: a torrent of which course through nearly every track on War God. It's a style defined by short
column4: staccato attacks
column5: countless pricks of drums
column6: a steady drizzle of fake horns
column7: fake flutes
column8: and fake keys. This is music imagined and created on a computer
column9: defined by its replicability
column10: its acclimation to headphones and laptop speakers.

column1: The kick drum—deployed in a metronomic four-on-the-floor pattern as often as not—isn't optimized for the big room soundsystems of Europe. Mixed low
column2: it doesn't pin the track down so much as provide a loose structure for Ramalepe's spicular melodies. The tracks
column3: and the snares especially
column4: tend to be mixed dry—with little reverb—lending them presence and urgency. As such
column5: there is no escaping War God
column6: no balling yourself up in its repetitions
column7: no zoning out to an endless succession of barely changing beats. This is poised
column8: almost bitterly attendant music
column9: music that refuses to retreat into the background.

column1: The sounds
column2: which are mostly synthesized
column3: vary between traditional synthesized elements of house and techno (see the lazer-drop kick sounds of ""Bula Ma"") and sounds meant to emulate the woody marimbas and prickly kalimbas more often heard in South African music. The scales scan as distinctly non-western
column4: even as the kick drum offers its familiar concussions. There are few sustained notes on War God
column5: and certainly nothing as somnambulant and passive as a pad; each track is a cluster of notes
column6: most with enough softness and give to prevent the track from becoming too percussive
column7: but nonetheless swift enough to prevent relaxation or stasis.

column1: The material on War God is less alien than the dance styles presented on compilations like Shangaan Electro and Congotronics
column2: two other African electronic musics that have been embraced by fringe Western audiences. Less isolated and singular
column3: Ramalepe's productions feel akin to Lisbon's Principe Discos label—itself music birthed by the African diaspora—conversant in the familiar styles of house music (Principe's DJ Marfox recently released an EP on Lit City Trax).

column1: War God spans 20 tracks and more than 85 minutes. As an immersion experience—a gateway into Ramalepe's harried visions—it's fine. As an album
column2: it falters
column3: gasping for air as Ramalepe offers up yet another four-minute bushel of bobbing tones. Ramalepe rarely employs recognizable samples (outside of percussion
column4: perhaps) and only one track—the heated ""Oreng Mo""
column5: featuring DJ Mujava—employs a vocalist. War God
column6: as a result
column7: feels mournful and uninhabited. Rarely does music this busy also sound this lonesome. At times
column8: it's difficult to imagine these tracks in a mix with anything but themselves. War God's form—a twist on house music—is recognizable
column9: but its atmosphere often feels otherworldly
column10: like Ramalepe has followed the bare minimum number of rules to qualify as modern dance music.

column1: And that's great
column2: even if the material on War God never fully congeals into an album. War God is the product of someone immersed in a singular world; it is necessarily limited
column3: and Ramalepe has a lot less to learn from the average house producer than the average house producer has to learn from him. War God is vital
column4: transfixing music that demands your attention
column5:
and the onus is on you to figure out what to do when it does grab it.

Rivers Cuomo has taken your shit for over two decades and he’s had it up to here. Midway through Weezer’s ninth studio LP
column2: he airs his grievances on a song called
column3: not coincidentally
column4: “I’ve Had It Up to Here”—the most valid of which is that people think he’s somehow insincere. You could describe Weezer’s 21st century output in many derogatory ways and most of it would be warranted
column5: but “dishonest” isn’t one of them. Pick anything he’s done over the past 15 years and ask yourself
column6: “What label exec concerned with the bottom line would possibly cosign this?” Rivers Cuomo is making the exact kind of music he wants to make—it just so happens that it sounds like music for the masses and has no currency whatsoever. Yet
column7: in his finest mock-operatic metal voice

column9: “If you think I need approval from the faceless throng/ Well

column11: but on Everything Will Be Alright in the End
column12: he realizes that he needs it from a familiar source that he knows quite well: people who may have once been Weezer fans.

column1: That said

column5: the lyrics peppered with meta references about Weezer’s past—namely
column6: his lightning bolt guitar strap and that one time he let drummer Patrick Wilson sing lead. You might roll your eyes when he rhymes “rockin’ out like it’s ‘94” with “more hardcore
column7: ” and they will bug out when revisiting 1994 somehow means doing fourth-wall rhyme-bustin’ that was perfected on “El Scorcho” and responsible for “Beverly Hills”. And then there are the wincing
column8: “What year is this?” jokes that will certainly be criticized for “lolz rockism”: taking himself to task because “I forgot that disco sucks
column9: ” thinking that the radio and “those stupid singing shows” are even in competition anymore
column10: or that they had any effect on Weezer.

column1: But something about this song sticks
column2: and it’s not just the hook
column3: though that’s a big part of it—even those who despise Weezer can admit Cuomo has an inexhaustible
column4: infuriating ability to write melodies that lodge themselves in your brain after one listen
column5: whether you want it there or not. During the second verse
column6: Cuomo drops the yuks and sings
column7: “I finally settled down with my girl and I made up with my dad.” He could not be more direct about what “Back to the Shack” truly means beyond its reprise of “Pork and Beans”'s message about being true to one’s self: those represent the twin engines that powered The Blue Album and Pinkerton’s emotional train wrecks
column8: and there's the possibility that “Back to the Shack” might be a sly
column9: sarcastic rebuke against armchair producers and YouTube commenters
column10: a la Danny Brown’s Old: you don’t want the old Rivers Cuomo
column11: so do you want him to rock out like it’s ‘94 or do you just want him to sing about it and make a record of his (broken) heart?

column1: Because you’re only getting one in 2014
column2: and Everything does occasionally rock out with the same joyous abandon of The Blue Album
column3: albeit without its wide-eyed naivety. If you really want to go out on a limb
column4: this is as close as Cuomo is getting to his own version of Benji—a rock lifer moving forward by clearing out his past
column5: the songs almost entirely dedicated to his relationships with his career
column6: women
column7: and his parents. “Cleopatra” and “Foolish Father” have subjects that are pulled right from Cuomo’s mid-'90s diaries—namely
column8: powerful women who frighten and leave Rivers Cuomo
column9: and absentee fathers. Twenty years later
column10: the lesson here is the futility of hating someone who likely did their best
column11: to forgive them and to forgive yourself.

column1: That part resonates
column2: as does the lived-in wisdom applicable to the songs that are about being in Weezer
column3: even when they sorta aren’t. The generality of “Eulogy for a Rock Band” actually works in its favor when you consider it could very well be about rock music itself (for cryin’ out loud
column4: Cuomo’s favorite rock group just declared rock dead). Meanwhile
column5: the platitudes of “Ain’t Got Nobody” give way to a startling
column6: lucid account of Cuomo’s abandonment issues that have spanned his entire life
column7: from childhood to confused
column8: needy rock stardom: “My daddy loved me/ No one could touch me/ Until he went up and left me lonely/ That’s human nature/ We fail each other/ And keep on searching for another.”

column1: Of course
column2: Cuomo ensures that you don’t have to read that far into Everything Will Be Alright in the End
column3: keeping the melodies up front and the gimmicks mostly in his notebook. The effect of Blue Album producer Ric Ocasek will likely be overstated: the lyrics on any previous Weezer album were not the producer’s fault
column4: and from all accounts
column5: the guitar tones and keyboards on that record were all Cuomo’s idea anyways. Either way
column6: these are simple
column7: effective songs that will settle for constant rotation in your head if MTV’s not an option: “Lonely Girl” isolates the second verse of “Only in Dreams” and reworks Cuomo’s Japanese curio “Homely Girl” into a legitimate buzzy throwback. Meanwhile
column8: Best Coast’s Bethany Cosentino—no stranger to criticisms about elementary-school lyricism and stunted relationship dynamics—lends guest vocals to “Go Away”
column9: which is a decent song but an even more important pledge of allegiance.

column1: Heck
column2: even the confounding decisions and filler that inextricably form latter-day Weezer albums are kinda charming. The whistle-core of “Da Vinci” will probably be the only way you’ll remember that Foster the People made a record this year. Meanwhile
column3: the closing
column4: mostly instrumental “The Futurescope Trilogy” probably belongs on Cuomo's unreleased space odyssey Songs From the Black Hole and doesn’t stack up to “The Greatest Man That Ever Lived (Variations on a Shaker Hymn)”
column5: the batshit piece of musical theater that proved Cuomo can set new positive benchmarks for himself in the 21st century.

column1: Everything Will Be Alright in the End doesn’t set a new benchmark for Weezer
column2: but hopefully it can go lengths to ridding them of the ridiculously unfair catch-22 they’ve faced. The past couple of weeks have seen a surprise Thom Yorke album dropped on BitTorrent
column3: the first Aphex Twin record since 2001
column4: and a lavish reissue of Smashing Pumpkins’ Adore
column5: and almost none of them were subject to the kind of truly wacked-out
column6: incomprehensible standards given to Weezer’s ninth album. Granted
column7: Rivers Cuomo hasn’t done himself many favors
column8: as his music has been marked by refusal to evolve in the slightest either emotionally or sonically. Even still
column9: why couldn’t Cuomo just do this in peace? Because even though Weezer and Pinkerton were never embraced by critics in real time
column10: they sure seem to have been embraced by a lot of people who grew up to be critics
column11: who in turn have relished every opportunity to bash Weezer albums as a way of separating themselves from an embarrassing part of their lives where the perspective of “No One Else” and “Pink Triangle” felt like the truth.

column1: There have been many ways to qualify praise for Weezer and with each successive listen
column2: Everything Will Be Alright in the End certainly earns the typically backhanded compliments: “actually not terrible
column3: ” “certainly better than Hurley
column4: ” “probably their best since...Maladroit
column5: that was good right?” Or
column6: Everything could be accepted for what it is and be held to a more manageable standard: how good does a Weezer album have to be before it can be considered actually good?  As it turns out
column7:
about this good.

Brian Eno bought his first Fela Kuti LP in September of 1973. It was Afrodisiac
column2: a record the Nigerian bandleader had cut in London with his group
column3: Africa '70
column4: the previous year. In the liner notes that accompany Fela: Vinyl Box Set 3—which collects seven recently reissued Kuti LPs that he selected–Eno writes that
column5: at the time
column6: he “didn’t really get” polyrhythmic music. He changed his mind. “I remember the first time I listened and how dazzled I was by the groove and rhythmic complexity
column7: ” he writes. “My friend Robert Wyatt called it ‘Jazz from another planet’ -and suddenly I thought I understood the point of jazz
column8: until then an almost alien music to me.”

column1: A few years later
column3: Eno played Afrodisiac for Talking Heads frontman David Byrne. Eventually he would collaborate with the band on its album Remain in Light
column4: a record that drew heavy inspiration from African music. Amid the bonus tracks included on the Talking Heads’ Brick boxed set
column5: there’s an unfinished outtake called “Fela’s Riff”. The introductory phrase of the track–which is really not much more than a half realized jam session–subtly mimic the ping-ponging brass figures of Kuti’s composition
column6: “Alu Jon Jonki Jon”
column7: the opening track on Afrodisiac. All this is to say: Brian Eno was
column8: and is
column9: a big Fela Kuti fan.

column1: For a lot of people
column2: Eno would turn out to be an important conduit to Kuti’s music
column3: whether via his work on Remain in Light or its companion releases
column4: The Catherine Wheel and My Life in the Bush of Ghosts. And while he wasn’t Kuti’s only celebrity champion
column5: he was among the most eloquently spoken. Over the next several decades
column6: his support would steer countless rock bands
column7: experimental artists
column8: and dance producers toward Kuti. The significance of that music—now the subject of documentary films
column9: Broadway musicals
column10: and books—is well established. A Nigerian musician and political dissident
column11: Kuti released dozens of records throughout the ’70s and ’80s that merged strains of jazz
column12: funk
column13: and African traditional music.

column1: And with the possible exception of 1984’s Army Arrangement
column2: there are really no bad Fela Kuti records. So
column3: a boxed set isn’t a bad way to absorb his music. There’s not a lot of filler to wade through. The titles that Eno has picked for Vinyl Box Set 3 are drawn mostly from Kuti’s early ’70s output
column4: including Shakara (1972)
column5: Fela’s London Scene (1972)
column6: and Gentleman (1971). Afrodisiac is included
column7: as well as three highlights from the later part of the decade
column8: Zombie (1976)
column9: Upside Down (1976)

column1: It’s a lot to digest. However
column2: by lining up a number of releases–one 15-30 minute composition after another–it’s easier to get a sense of the dramatic evolution that Kuti’s music underwent throughout the decade. On the collections’ earliest works—Fela’s London Scene
column3: Shakara—the influence of Western jazz and R&B music is clearer. In subsequent records
column4: the key elements of Fela’s Afrobeat sound—the call-and-response vocals
column5: the interlocking tenor and rhythm guitar parts
column6: for instance—become more commonplace. The compositions get longer
column7: more ambitious
column8: and more hypnotic
column9: and the music’s trajectory is mirrored in the LP cover art; gradually
column10: traditional photograph-oriented designs give way to dense multi-colored illustrations. The jacket of London Scene wouldn’t seem out of place next to any number of early ’70s jazz records. I.T.T.
column11: with its grotesque caricatures and quasi-psychedelic color-palate
column12: is from another planet entirely.

column1: Eno’s contributions to the liner notes are thought provoking
column2: but they’re also fairly slight—just a few hundred words of text that provide a handful of anecdotes and a touch of context. As a musician
column3: producer
column4: and conceptual thinker
column5: Eno was a major presence in the music world at a moment when the ’60s vision of rock and roll was gradually slipping away as a dominant force and punk
column6: hip-hop and disco were emerging. The set might have benefited—at least on Eno’s end—from a more substantial reflection on how Kuti’s music was perceived within the context of that time.

column1: Though
column2: maybe it’s obvious that there wasn’t a lot out there like it. The innovations that Kuti’s music generated are easy to take for granted now
column3: but in the context of the mid-to-late ’70s—a decade heavy with
column4: though not necessarily defined by
column5: blues rock—Kuti’s band must have sounded pretty revelatory. The music is constantly moving and mutating
column6: but is also conveys a sense of stasis. Unlike jazz
column7: the songs aren’t shaped by chord changes or modulations
column8: but the gradual accumulation and subtraction of melodic and rhythmic gestures. The bass might hover on a single note or riff for an entire song. The steady crack of the snare
column9: which helps to give rock music its steady push and pull
column10: is constantly shifted and shuffled around. “It rolls
column11: rocks
column12: and snaps and makes you moves
column13: ” writes Eno
column14: speaking about drummer Tony Allen’s rhythms. “And yet it isn’t ever very regular—it’s hard to isolate the part that Tony Allen is playing because he’s constantly moving around it.”

column1: The length of the compositions is also worth noting. One Kuti record might be made up of a single
column2: highly repetitious sitcom-length composition. Where fusion jazz worked in similar chunks of time
column3: it involved sprawl and spaciousness. Kuti’s music is taught and tight
column4: even when it’s drifting past the 20-minute mark. Listening to it demands a different type of attention—one less concerned with events like verses and choruses and more attuned gradual build-ups and changes in density. It’s hard to think of anything comparable at the time
column5: save for the rolling
column6: burbling
column7: and highly repetitive synthesizer compositions being made by German krautrock acts like Neu!
column8: Kraftwerk
column9: and Ashra (some of which were also Eno associates).

column1: Contemporary Afrobeat ensembles seem to have largely ditched these super-extended songs

column3: likely because they run so completely contrary to the marketing and promotional methods of contemporary music. Certainly

column5: which required singles that could fuel radio play and
column6: ultimately
column7: sales. That’s definitely a fight that Fela won; eventually

the record labels just built bigger boxes to put it in.

column8: Zombie (1976)
column9: Upside Down (1976)

column1: It’s a lot to digest. However
column2: by lining up a number of releases–one 15-30 minute composition after another–it’s easier to get a sense of the dramatic evolution that Kuti’s music underwent throughout the decade. On the collections’ earliest works—Fela’s London Scene
column3: Shakara—the influence of Western jazz and R&B music is clearer. In subsequent records
column4: the key elements of Fela’s Afrobeat sound—the call-and-response vocals
column5: the interlocking tenor and rhythm guitar parts
column6: for instance—become more commonplace. The compositions get longer
column7: more ambitious
column8: and more hypnotic
column9: and the music’s trajectory is mirrored in the LP cover art; gradually
column10: traditional photograph-oriented designs give way to dense multi-colored illustrations. The jacket of London Scene wouldn’t seem out of place next to any number of early ’70s jazz records. I.T.T.
column11: with its grotesque caricatures and quasi-psychedelic color-palate
column12: is from another planet entirely.

column1: Eno’s contributions to the liner notes are thought provoking
column2: but they’re also fairly slight—just a few hundred words of text that provide a handful of anecdotes and a touch of context. As a musician
column3: producer
column4: and conceptual thinker
column5: Eno was a major presence in the music world at a moment when the ’60s vision of rock and roll was gradually slipping away as a dominant force and punk
column6: hip-hop and disco were emerging. The set might have benefited—at least on Eno’s end—from a more substantial reflection on how Kuti’s music was perceived within the context of that time.

column1: Though
column2: maybe it’s obvious that there wasn’t a lot out there like it. The innovations that Kuti’s music generated are easy to take for granted now
column3: but in the context of the mid-to-late ’70s—a decade heavy with
column4: though not necessarily defined by
column5: blues rock—Kuti’s band must have sounded pretty revelatory. The music is constantly moving and mutating
column6: but is also conveys a sense of stasis. Unlike jazz
column7: the songs aren’t shaped by chord changes or modulations
column8: but the gradual accumulation and subtraction of melodic and rhythmic gestures. The bass might hover on a single note or riff for an entire song. The steady crack of the snare
column9: which helps to give rock music its steady push and pull
column10: is constantly shifted and shuffled around. “It rolls
column11: rocks
column12: and snaps and makes you moves
column13: ” writes Eno
column14: speaking about drummer Tony Allen’s rhythms. “And yet it isn’t ever very regular—it’s hard to isolate the part that Tony Allen is playing because he’s constantly moving around it.”

column1: The length of the compositions is also worth noting. One Kuti record might be made up of a single
column2: highly repetitious sitcom-length composition. Where fusion jazz worked in similar chunks of time
column3: it involved sprawl and spaciousness. Kuti’s music is taught and tight
column4: even when it’s drifting past the 20-minute mark. Listening to it demands a different type of attention—one less concerned with events like verses and choruses and more attuned gradual build-ups and changes in density. It’s hard to think of anything comparable at the time
column5: save for the rolling
column6: burbling
column7: and highly repetitive synthesizer compositions being made by German krautrock acts like Neu!
column8: Kraftwerk
column9: and Ashra (some of which were also Eno associates).

column1: Contemporary Afrobeat ensembles seem to have largely ditched these super-extended songs
column2: at least on record
column3: likely because they run so completely contrary to the marketing and promotional methods of contemporary music. Certainly
column4: this also applied in the ’70s
column5: which required singles that could fuel radio play and
column6: ultimately
column7: sales. That’s definitely a fight that Fela won; eventually
column8:
the record labels just built bigger boxes to put it in.

Earlier this year
column2: Darkside—the spacey
column3: penetrating collaboration between Nicolas Jaar and guitarist Dave Harrington—sat down with the author Daniel Pinchbeck to talk about aliens
column4: channeling
column5: and other ideas that exist outside the periphery of what most people would consider good dinner conversation. At one point
column6: Pinchbeck
column7: whose experiences with psychedelic drugs are matter not only of public record but professional pride
column8: asks Jaar about his own experiences with the shadow world. Jaar answers that he’s never taken drugs—“just music”—and he goes on to explain that Darkside named their first album Psychic because they felt as though to make the music that they needed to become mediums
column9: bodies through which other beings spoke. “I feel like psychic shops in America symbolize so many things about today’s culture
column10: ” Jaar continues. “The first is that your future is turned into a commodity. But deeper than that
column11: all of these shops are the psychics’ actual homes. They live there. This is their front room. When they close the drapes they have dinner there
column12: amidst these crystal balls and stuff.”

column1: That eerie balance—between the domestic and the mystical—has been at the heart of what most of Jaar has done so far. Work
column2: the second compilation from his label Other People
column3: collects a group of seemingly disparate artists unified by a preference for music that feels like it’s being made just around the corner
column4: in the places where clarity gives over to darkness. Some of it sounds like techno
column5: but techno made in no discernible hurry and with no obvious shape; some of it sounds like dub reggae built from static; some of it is limited to the sound of a single voice and a guitar. All of it shares the distinction of being psychedelic—something that’s playing inside your head and yet coming from somewhere infinitely far away. It’s good music for late nights and unshared couches
column6: especially when afforded a little time for the mind to drift.

column1: Part of Other People’s concept is that it works more like a magazine than a record label
column2: inviting people by subscription and sending them new music at semi-regular intervals. One of the surprising—and somewhat limiting—aspects of Work is just how few of Other People’s artists it features
column3: especially considering that as a compilation
column4: it has the potential to reach more people than the label has subscribers. (Maybe only Drew Gragg and I wish there was more Drew Gragg on here
column5: but that at least makes two of us.) Nearly 28 minutes of Work consists of collaborations between Ancient Astronaut—who is on the label—and artists who aren’t; another ten minutes are outtakes from Darkside’s Psychic. In a way
column6: the compilation serves more as a companion to the music the label has already put out than as an introduction to it.

column1: Work gets over on consistency of mood
column2: which has marked all of Jaar’s projects and more or less everything on Other People
column3: too. All the music here—however unrelated on the surface— belongs
column4: yoked together by an invisible thread; less an appeal to the confines of genre than to mood: the impression the music leaves once you turn it off.  ""I would say that we’re less interested in a linear narrative and more in a larger journey
column5: Harrington said in Darkside's interview with Pinchbeck. ""The feeling should be that you go on a spectral trip from the first sound to the last sound. You enter a space
column6: you explore it
column7: you walk around
column8: and then you enter a new space."" The intention is clear
column9:
even if the trip doesn't end up taking you all that far.

When Steve Reich heard Jonny Greenwood perform his 1987 classic Electric Counterpoint at a Polish festival

column4: unmanageable multiple-orchestra commission for the London Sinfonietta
column5: and watching Greenwood's bracing
column6: devoted rendition

column1: The songs he focused his piece around were ""Everything in Its Right Place""
column2: from Kid A
column3: and In Rainbows' ""Jigsaw Falling Into Place"". In an interview last year
column4: he called the opening series of chords on ""Everything in Its Right Place"" ""one of the classics in Western music

column5: but by the third movement
column6: the lines of transmission grow spotty

column8: but most moments where you won't

column10: stirring up clouds and creating something that feels more like a series of dreams the songs themselves are having than a straightforward tribute.

column1: When Reich's music quietly departs from its source material
column2: the piece achieves lift off
column3: as the form fades and the piece settles into a seething
column4: anxious rhythm of its own. The piece follows the by-now familiar Reich structure—pairs of movements
column5: titled ""Fast "" and ""Slow""
column6: alternating between thrumming low-level unease and calm—and the familiarity has a bittersweet tinge to it. When the piece directly references Radiohead
column7: the piece feels troublingly like a printout

column9: with their scrambled rhythmic pulses and sumptuous string writing
column10: help mitigate this feeling.

column1: Jonny Greenwood's recording of Electric Counterpoint
column2: meanwhile
column3: feels genuinely different. His version
column4: which he's honed live over years and is included on Radio Rewrite
column5: has a nagging
column6: insistent edge
column7: with more space in between the guitars than in the famous Pat Metheny version
column8: as if the tracks are echoing from opposite corners of a massive
column9: empty room. Greenwood's phrasing is choppier; you can hear almost every pick strike
column10: making it sometimes feel like you need to swat away a locust cloud. In Greenwood's hands
column11: Electric Counterpoint suddenly becomes body music.

column1: Greenwood's taken the unusual step of pre-recording 1o of the 11 guitar tracks that comprise the piece. His guitar tone is unmistakable
column2: especially on the second movement
column3: which directly channels ""Let Down"". Oddly
column4: it feels more like more of a meeting of the minds between Reich and Radiohead than Radio Rewrite itself.  There is another piece on the album
column5: a reworking of Reich's <i>Piano Counterpoint

column13:
contrarian spirit of Reich's works than Reich does.

“As an experiment…” began last week’s letter from Radiohead frontman Thom Yorke and producer Nigel Godrich
column3: announcing Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes
column4: Yorke’s first solo album in eight years. The “experiment” was designed to solve the same problem the music industry has been grappling with since the heyday of Shawn Fanning—how to convince the digital world to pay for music. And the means were
column5: if not exactly original
column6: unique for an artist of Yorke’s size: a payment system managed by a version of the file-sharing software BitTorrent
column7: which relies on users sharing small pieces of a file in order to circulate a shared whole. “If it works well it could be an effective way of handing some control of internet commerce back to people who are creating the work
column8: ” Yorke and Godrich explained; it’s a very different sentiment from the one expressed by Radiohead’s management following In Rainbows in 2007
column9: when they described the pay-what-you-want approach for that album as “a solution for Radiohead
column10: not the industry.”

column1: BitTorrent involvement aside
column2: Yorke and Godrich have essentially released music for sale on short notice
column3: something Radiohead did already with their 2011 album The King of Limbs. In 2013
column4: Beyoncé’s surprise self-titled album-cum-multimedia extravaganza represented a generational shift six years after In Rainbows: the catchphrase ""Pulling a Radiohead” was summarily replaced by “pulling a Beyoncé”. On the other end of the spectrum
column5: recent model-busting approaches by Jay-Z and U2 were met with cynicism and disdain. Compared to these high-profile campaigns
column6: the reception to Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes’ distribution gambit has been unremarkable
column7: a collective shoulder-shrug.

column1: Indeed
column2: for a solo release from a member of one of the world’s biggest rock bands
column3: nearly everything about the album feels slight: the title
column4: which is ostensibly a commentary on digital commerce but sounds more like a corporate slogan for a shipping company; the sparse
column5: forgettable artwork; the video for lead track “A Brain in a Bottle”
column6: itself a herky-jerky update of the clip for The King of Limbs’ blooming “Lotus Flower” single; the price
column7: a scant $6 for an eight-track album that would typically go for at least $3 more at most digital retailers; and the runtime
column8: which just barely cracks a half-hour
column9: the shortest non-Radiohead album the singer has been involved with. Yorke—and
column10: by extension
column11: Radiohead—has spent the last two decades making a virtue of evading celebrity
column12: but even by that measure
column13: the presentation of Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes comes across as quaint.

column1: The same goes for the music
column2: which represent Yorke’s strongest embrace of electronics to date. Radiohead once shattered the notion of what a rock band could be sonically
column3: but even their most experimental albums had a beating heart
column4: (not to mention a guitar or two); Yorke’s first solo album
column5: 2006’s The Eraser
column6: was chilly in its electronic explorations but it retained a sense of melody and pathos
column7: while AMOK
column8: last year’s forgettable debut effort from the Yorke-led Atoms for Peace supergroup
column9: contrasted bleep-bloop tendencies with a distinct live-band feel. On Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes
column10: the line between man and machine has blurred to the point of disappearing
column11: with Yorke’s vocals blending seamlessly with glitchy textures and stuttering beats. The result is in one sense the most challenging high-profile release of Yorke’s career—there’s precious little to grab on to in terms of melody and feeling
column12: and you won’t find yourself humming along to anything here.

column1: That said
column2: certain elements of Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes
column3: if given the right amount of attention
column4: can be enjoyable to luxuriate in. “Guess Again!” is possibly the most Radiohead-like track on the album
column5: a mid-tempo traipse of decaying pianos and crunchy backbeats that anyone who’s listened to “Pyramid Song” on loop will find instantly recognizable; the six-minute sorta-centerpiece “The Mother Lode” unfurls with layered vocal-abstracted samples and a skipping rhythmic gait that congeals with Yorke’s delicate high register
column6: climaxing mid-track with a beautiful wordless digression. “Pink Section” brings more deconstructed piano—the most notable non-synthetic sound that appears frequently on Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes—to the forefront amidst a low
column7: whistling howl
column8: and the track nicely segues into closer “Nose Grows Some”
column9: a mix of winding tones and subtly forceful rhythmic backbone with Yorke projecting an exquisite vocal presence at the forefront.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes slips into tedium. The wavering motifs and squelchy low end of “A Brain in a Bottle”
column3: along with the seven-minute rabbit-hole excursion “There Is No Ice (For My Drink)”
column4: present rough
column5: unappealing approaches to beat-building that call to mind Yorke’s dicey attempts at dance music; the piping tones of “Truth Ray” stand in place instead of building to any sort of resolution
column6: and the largely beatless “Interference” represents a similar stasis. “I don’t have the right/ To interfere
column7: ” he sings in the song’s anti-chorus
column8: underscoring the album’s general sense of passivity. As Yorke’s least satisfying work to date
column9:
Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes can’t help but build anticipation for whatever Radiohead plans to do next—his need for a creative foil has never been more apparent.

and never once flinches at how close they swirl to each other.

Classical music without pop signifiers lives in the margins of pop conversation. It’s largely ignored
column2: or at best pitied
column3: and without a visual or cultural anchor
column4: some modern listeners tune out when classical music comes on the speakers. What is Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries without some helicopters flying over a beach in Vietnam? What is Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring without the history of the dawn of time? Moreover

column1: In a series of essays published last year

column3: Lady Gaga
column4: and Daft Punk using music theory to show why these pop songs are
column5: in fact
column6: works of genius. Reading these essays is akin to learning how a magic trick is performed; it ruins the illusion and shows how all music can be reduced to a basic formula; if the best pop music hides that formula

column8: arguably

column11: the seam between pop and classical is sewed tight

column14: and seven composers take the tenets of modern classical music and breathe new life into it. These also are not staid
column15: mannered pieces of music; Balance Problems functions on its own accord and can be enjoyed without signifiers or prerequisite understanding of any formula.

column9: with violist Nadia Sirota playing the lowest note on her viola
column10: taking a breath
column11: then playing the highest note on her viola
column12: a harmonic miles above the staff. Turn it up loud enough and you can actually hear someone’s breath around the pianissimo notes she bows. These moments that bookend ""Music in Circles"" are stark
column13: simple
column14: and successful.

column1: Each piece yMusic performs is filled with minute gestures. Marcos Balter's “Bladed Stance” creates the illusion of depth with the various tempos yMusic play simultaneously
column2: as breathless flute arpeggios zoom by while a violin skitters by
column3: at a slower speed
column4: in the distance. Nico Muhly’s dense title track is perhaps the most ambitious work here
column5: with pizzicato strings bending and sliding around ever-changing woodwind motifs. When an acoustic guitar enters
column6: it feels as foreign as a drum solo
column7: but it also creates a comforting familiarity.

column1: Sufjan Stevens closes the album
column2: and when pitted against the other compositions it comes across as a footnote. “The Human Plague” features the most production on the album
column3: using delayed and gated effects with just one rhythm repeated ad nauseam. Against the dynamic and unpredictable nature of Timo Andres’ “Safe Travels”
column4: Stevens’ contribution sounds perfunctory; but after an album of music that channels a feeling from a century ago
column5: it also represents a reconnection to the form of a modern
column6: simple pop song.

column1: In his indispensable book about the history of modern music
column2: <i>The Rest Is Noise
column3: Alex Ross talked of the changing sentiments of music as it came into the 20th century
column4: especially around the premiere of Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring in 1913. Ross wrote
column5: “… now composers would create a music of the body. Melodies would follow the patterns of speech; rhythms would match the energy of dance; musical forms would be more concise and clear; sonorities would have the hardness of life as it is really lived.” yMusic and the composers reflect that sentiment
column6: recapturing that time before the minimalism and experimentalism of the 20th century
column7: serving as a conduit to a time of tradition
column8:
and channeling the several emotions of the world into wordless compositions.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21068/homepage_large.ce03b090.jpg|House Masters|32507.0|Masters at Work|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Defected']|2014-10-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:38.018891|"

If you went to dance clubs in the 1990s
column2: you heard Masters at Work—probably several times an hour. From 1990
column3: when Kenny ""Dope"" Gonzalez and ""Little"" Louie Vega launched their partnership with a deep house remix of Debbie Gibson's ""One Step Ahead""
column5: when they celebrated their tenth anniversary with a pair of four-CD boxed sets
column6: they were almost unbelievably prolific. In that first decade
column7: Masters at Work released something on the order of 500 remixes
column8: as well as a mountain of their own records under various names (most notably Nuyorican Soul)
column9: and effectively defined the house music sound of that decade: the metronomic piston of Gonzalez's beats
column10: the dissonant jazz and salsa chords of Vega's keyboards
column11: live instrumentation weaving around programmed rhythms
column12: vocals slashed up and looped to reveal the oddest grains in singers' timbres.

column1: And then
column2: after 2002's Our Time Is Coming album
column3: the cascade dried to a trickle. Masters at Work never quite broke up
column4: and they've continued to DJ and to produce the occasional high-profile remix together
column5: but there's scarcely a sign on this four-disc retrospective that they kept going after their golden decade. Their set in the House Masters series isn't exactly a greatest-hits—a MAW compilation that doesn't include Nuyorican Soul's ""It's Alright
column6: I Feel It"" or Hardrive's ""Deep Inside"" doesn't qualify as a collection of their career peaks. Instead
column7: they've assembled this collection to acquaint youngsters with overlooked bits of their discography as well as some of their best-known records.

column1: What they've put together here is two discs of vocal tracks and another two that are more or less dubs and instrumentals
column2: all scrambled chronologically but with a few smart juxtapositions. A pair of disco covers—Incognito souping up the Jones Girls' 1981 ""Nights Over Egypt"" and Nuyorican Soul's faithful remake of the Salsoul Orchestra's 1977 ""Runaway""—serve as a reminder of how much Vega and Gonzalez learned from the grand arrangements of the mirror-ball era. And leading off the second disc with ""I Can't Get No Sleep"" and ""When You Touch Me""
column3: two killer collaborations with salsa star India (who was then married to Vega)
column4: is a strong argument for the power and strangeness of their songwriting
column5: as well as the way they could shape a track around a singer's voice.

column1: Their remixes were sometimes more about overpowering their source material than reworking it. You could feed anything into the gaping maw of MAW—Saint Etienne
column2: uilleann pipes
column3: reggae
column4: Baaba Maal
column5: hip-hop
column6: George Benson—and it would come out as a pumping
column7: DJ-ready house record. Still
column8: when they remixed a vocalist they especially liked
column9: they rose to the challenge
column10: as with the radiant ten-minute version of Bebe Winans' ""Thank You"" that opens House Masters.

column1: When Gonzalez and Vega gave themselves license to experiment
column2: though
column3: they sometimes struck gold; their weirdest throwaways could spawn entire new subgenres. Gonzalez has noted that ""The Ha Dance""
column4: from 1991--a groove built around a tiny sample of the movie Trading Places--probably took them ""like two hours"" to make; pretty much the entire vogue fem music scene revolves around its legacy. ""The Nervous Track""
column5: a hyper-syncopated riff with frantic drumming and standup bass
column6: appeared in 1993
column7: and a year or two later ""broken beat"" sprouted from the Masters' heavy footprints.

column1: The MAW tracks that hold up best a decade or two later (and outside a club setting)
column2: though
column3: are often the ones with unpredictable or spontaneous elements. India's vocal on ""I Can't Get No Sleep"" was edited from a flu-ridden improvisation; ""Deep Inside"" was an ad-libbed fragment from the Masters' production of Barbara Tucker's ""Beautiful People"" (which doesn't appear on House Masters either)
column4: spun out into a record of its own. And if Black Masses' ""Wonderful Person"" isn't the result of someone trying to sing Linda Clifford's 1978 disco song ""You Are
column5: You Are""
column6: forgetting everything but the hook and making up new lyrics around it
column7: then it might as well be.

column1: The moments when one of Masters at Work's collaborators throw them off-balance mean a lot
column2: because they're otherwise so firmly rooted in the conventions of '90s club music—conventions which
column3: to be fair
column4: they helped to establish. Gonzalez and Vega built their career on being a beat factory
column5:
but the most enduring work of the years when they dominated the dance floor came from the times their studio was an experimental lab instead.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20848/homepage_large.ecac8223.jpg|Time To Die|32390.0|Electric Wizard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Spinefarm']|2014-10-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:39.650308|"

The latest effort from England’s reigning doom entities Electric Wizard
column2: Time to Die
column3: deserves every accolade thrown its way. The band’s lackluster 2010 effort Black Masses fell rather flat
column4: trailing its own hailed predecessor with a rote
column5: lifeless performance. It sounded like the band had gotten cocky
column6: resting comfortably on laurels sprouted after the roaring success of 2007’s Witchcult Today
column7: the catchy
column8: menacing genius of which (thanks in no small part to guitarist Liz Buckingham’s inspired riffs) earned a place of reverence within the modern doom canon. It took some time for them to refine their footing
column9: and after shunning live appearances for years
column10: the band began playing live with unprecedented frequency. That added dose of energy has clearly seeped into these new tunes—there’s a rawness and immediacy that will surely translate well into a live setting.

column1: From the first burbling moments and crackling sample from a 1984 ""20/20"" special on ""Acid King"" Richard Kasso
column2: Time to Die holds its listeners close
column3: inviting us into a warped echo chamber of horrors filled with eldritch evil. From their beginnings
column4: Electric Wizard’s whole shtick has revolved around drugs
column5: sleazy horror movies
column6: and drawn-out stoner riffs designed to gnaw through your skull. Songs like “We Love the Dead” and “Destroy Those Who Love God” nod at the band’s gleeful urge to shock
column7: and “I Am Nothing” hints at the darker thoughts that may swirl past the velvet-swaddled nymphs and technicolor gore in its creator’s head. Vocalist Jus Oborn doesn’t really sing; rather
column8: he mumbles
column9: he whines
column10: and above all
column11: he wails
column12: his high warble losing itself in the music as easily as if it were a moonless night on the moors.

column1: Recently recruited bassist Clayton Burgess
column2: of heavy garage punks Satan’s Satyrs
column3: places his stamp on the fuzz-drenched low end while drummer Mark Greening holds court behind the kit
column4: crashing and bashing with impeccable timing and remarkable restraint. This marks Greening’s first time playing and recording with the band since 2002’s immortal Let Us Prey
column5: and he makes his presence known. It takes a veteran to add the amount of pure heft these songs need to stay in line
column6: and Greening makes it look easy. He and Burgess are crucial to the proceedings
column7: especially given the significance the rhythm section holds in anchoring those mammoth grooves and providing support for the all-important riffs.

column1: Buckingham’s swinging saturnine riffs solidify Electric Wizard's reputation
column2: even buried under the customary leagues of distortion and reverb; Oborn holds his own too
column3: especially during those wah-wah solos and moments of cosmic shred on “Funeral of Your Mind”. The garage-rock-tinged psychedelic rocker is the Black Sabbath song that Birmingham’s finest could've written if they had stuck with the drugs and stayed off the telly
column4: and the same could be said of nearly everything Electric Wizard has written: their worship for the Sab Four bleeds through in their work so garishly that it would be funny if the band wasn’t so deadly serious.

column1: “SadioWitch” finds Oborn sneering over a perversely simple rock beat
column2: and “We Love the Dead” is an impossibly murky dirge built upon a zombified tempo
column3: eerie melody
column4: and elephantine central riff with sustain so pronounced you can hear Buckingham’s fingers vibrating over the frets before the psychedelic freakout that caps it all off. Between the ominous media muttering and unconscionably tense guitar drones
column5: “Destroy Those Who Love God” is more than a little unnerving; meanwhile
column6: an eerie Moog synth drives instrumental album closer “Saturn Dethroned”
column7: slowly collapsing and dissolving into the same burbling stream that kicked off the album. It’s rare to see a band as established as Electric Wizard come back from a slump with renewed vigor and a fresh shot of hellfire coursing through their veins
column8: but with Time to Die
column9:
they’ve both surpassed expectations and proved that they’re still as vital as they ever were.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21114/homepage_large.20bbf454.jpg|Chimes EP|22485.0|Hudson Mohawke|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2014-09-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:40.483855|"

Hudson Mohawke's world has been transformed in the years since the 2011 EP Satin Panthers. By teaming up with Canadian producer Lunice to form TNGHT
column2: he reached a level of prominence that would have been unimaginable in 2009
column3: when he was churning out zany pieces of purple on releases like the Polyfolk Dance EP and debut full-length Butter. When an unreleased TNGHT song called ""R U Ready"" served as the backbone for the titanic centerpiece of Kanye West's Yeezus
column4: ""Blood on the Leaves""
column5: it was the cherry on top of an astounding rise. Since then
column6: Mohawke has racked up credits on Yeezus track ""I Am a God""
column7: Drake's ""Connect""
column8: and Pusha T's ""Hold On""
column9: meaning that he had a hand in highlights from three of 2013's biggest rap records. Where he was once bandied about by tastemakers as a potentially innovative force in hip-hop production
column10: he's now earned the opportunity to do so at the genre's highest possible level. Acting as a possible precursor to Mohawke's next
column11: perpetually delayed full-length—he told the NME in March 2013 the album was coming out later that year—the Chimes EP is his first true solo record in over three years
column12: serving as evidence of just how much he's grown in the time since.

column1: The song that gives the EP its title is also its most fleshed-out track. Given the impact Mohawke's had on the ascent of maximalism in contemporary electronic music
column2: it's remarkable how lean ""Chimes"" is: it's loud
column3: and certainly weighty on its low end
column4: but it's not particularly dense. TNGHT bangers such as ""Higher Ground"" and ""Goooo"" shot off sound and light in every direction before falling into earth-shaking climaxes; here
column5: Mohawke's paring down of his compositions parallels that of his Glaswegian contemporary Rustie
column6: whose sophomore LP from this year
column7: Green Language
column8: was proof of a similar refinement. Although ""Chimes"" may mark a step forward in one regard
column9: it's also static in terms of tempo. The remix provided by prolific UK producer Gammer that bookends the EP suffers from the same problem: it's sped up and flecked with added percussion
column10: but it also lacks a push-pull velocity change.

column1: The other two tracks on Chimes are minor but they do expand Mohawke's repertoire. ""Brainwave"" is a brooding synth workout
column2: haunted by soaring choir work reminiscent of M83; it's not hard to imagine the tune filling a slot on the soundtrack of an ambitious sci-fi movie. Meanwhile
column3: ""King Kong Beaver"" is a flash of the hyperkinetic
column4: colorful funk that marked Mohawke's early career
column5: a dalliance into a style that's since been refined and repurposed by younger producers with phenomenal success. ""King Kong Beaver"" also inadvertently serves as a reminder of Mohawke's interesting current position in electronic music: he's undeniably influential
column6: and certainly popular
column7: but his solo catalog still lacks a masterwork
column8: something that would secure his place in the pantheon of active producers. For now
column9:
Chimes does a fine job of sustaining his momentum.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21088/homepage_large.6abe9a31.jpg|Encyclopedia|28199.0|The Drums|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Minor']|2014-09-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:41.094384|"

Among other things they borrowed from the Smiths
column2: the Drums have a tendency to be outraged and subsequently fueled by public indifference and failure—2011’s half-great
column3: half-whatever Portamento was frontloaded by golden singles with dime-thin production
column4: a tacit acknowledgement of their demotion from a Next Big Thing as martyrdom; not coincidentally
column5: the hook on its first single went
column6: “I want to buy you something/ But I don’t have any money.” Three years later
column7: with their third album on as many labels
column8: Encyclopedia makes much stronger overtures to the thinning crowd in a way that's weirdly charming: the Drums are a band who try to succeed on their own terms
column9: but their terms never change. They just try harder.

column1: Unfortunate connotations of its title aside
column2: “Magic Mountain” is meant to be a colossus—lunging out of the speakers
column3: it’s the Drums’ loudest song to date
column4: featuring Jonathan Pierce’s most strident vocal performance and a nasty surf-rock riff that posits Encyclopedia as a potentially evil twin of their bleach blonde self-titled debut from 2010. And those features are subtle compared to what follows. For the purposes of understanding the general ambitions of Encyclopedia
column5: I want you to read the following sentence: “Inside my magic mountain/ We don’t have to be with them/ Inside my magic mountain/ Our hearts are out.” Imagine it being yelled. Then read it again
column6: a dozen more times. That’s “Magic Mountain” and also just about every other song on Encyclopedia
column7: wherein the Drums introduce the chorus right up front
column8: telling you what they’re going to say
column9: saying it
column10: and reminding you what they just said.

column1: Which is fair enough
column2: since the Drums have always been melody-first classicists
column3: and Encyclopedia spans their entire range: you get the melodramatic '60s pop approximation (“I Hope Time Doesn’t Change Him”)
column4: jumped-up pantry boyishness (“Kiss Me Again”
column5: which is far superior to Morrissey’s recent “Kiss Me a Lot”)
column6: and just about every form of '80s indie rock loved by Americans who not-so-secretly wish they were British. Because this is a Drums album
column7: a great number of songs casually mention suicide or some other heavenly way to die—on “U.S. National Park”
column8: Pierce begs to be spared a campground death
column9: which raises the question of what he was doing there in the first place.

column1: This stylistic shift would serve the Drums better if they were a punchy
column2: “don’t bore us
column3: get to the chorus and then get out” sort of band.  Maybe they were at some point
column4: but on Encylopedia
column5: their most hook-intensive album also turns out to be their “experimental” album. These songs don’t need to be more than two and a half minutes long—and yet
column6: most go on for twice that length; “Magic Mountain” repeats its hook only six times even though it seems like twice as much
column7: and there are also multiple fake endings.

column1: The overall arc of Encyclopedia is
column2: appropriately enough
column3: a comprehensive document of the Drums' entire career. They may have annoyed you up front
column4: but damn
column5: those songs were catchy. You wondered how long they could keep it up
column6: and all of a sudden
column7: it was better than you expected. But all of the great songs are in the first half
column8: so just when you think they’re in it for the long haul
column9: they lose you and the expectations are lowered for the next time
column10:
so they can surprise you all over again. The Drums are at least halfway to amassing a pretty great singles comp—they just can’t really call it a Greatest Hits.

"|19850.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19850-the-drums-encyclopedia/|5.9|Ian Cohen

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21057/homepage_large.ee00445f.jpg|Terrible Things Happen|37.0|The Aislers Set|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Slumberland'
column3: but one element that’s been partly overlooked is thrift-store culture. A nation of kids who first saw Molly Ringwald turn a Salvation Army dress into a Cinderella gown—and Jon Cryer claim the Boomer music of Otis Redding for the fledgling Generation X—had grown out of the '80s and into connoisseurs of secondhand chic. Naturally there was irony involved—this was the '90s—and during one of the most prosperous decades America had ever known
column4: slumming it became an archly conspicuous statement. But an aesthetic doesn’t need to be entirely ironic or entirely earnest
column5: and such was the case with thrift. Yard-sale artifacts were throwaways
column6: true
column7: but they were also beautiful: emblems and totems of those who’d owned them
column8: a transmutation of the mass-produced into the personal.

column1: So it would be unfair to dismiss the Aislers Set’s three-album discography—1998’s Terrible Things Happen
column2: 2000’s The Last Match
column3: and 2003’s How I Learned to Write Backwards—as a manifestation of “One demographic’s trash is another demographic’s treasure.” If anything
column4: the recently reunited San Francisco indie-pop group embodied the demise of thrift-store culture as it existed then
column5: straddling the movement’s '90s peak and its gradual decline in the new millennium
column6: when people began cherry-picking their castoffs for Craigslist or eBay—or repurposing them for Etsy—instead of hauling them wholesale to Goodwill. More conceptual bands like Stereolab and Pram
column7: clear influences on the Aislers Set
column8: had already mixed upscale Midcentury and high-brow hi-fi into their bric-a-brac collage. The Aislers Set
column9: on the other hand
column10: had no hope of unearthing Neu! or Astrud Gilberto at their local thrift store—just Wendy Carlos and the Archies.

column1: That’s not to say the Aislers Set’s debut album
column2: Terrible Things Happen
column3: isn’t sophisticated. The outfit’s mastermind
column4: Amy Linton
column5: had previously fronted Henry’s Dress
column6: a cornerstone of Slumberland Records’ early roster and a bridge between Britain’s bygone C86 glory and the U.S. indie-pop scene that exploded in the '90s. Terrible Things Happen
column7: like the remainder of the Aislers Set’s full-lengths
column8: came out on Slumberland as well
column9: and it marked a sea change. Up to that point
column10: punky jangle had been the order of the day
column11: a singsong
column12: buzzsaw whirlwind that Henry’s Dress exemplified. Linton tried new things on Terrible Things Happen: layered harmonies
column13: dynamic shifts between distorted riffs and acoustic strumming
column14: adventurous arrangements
column15: and dreamy
column16: chanson ambience straight out of a David Lynch roadhouse. For every speedy
column17: noisy
column18: birthday-cake splattered track like “Holiday Gone Well”
column19: there’s a lost-astronaut lullaby like “Alicia’s Song”
column20: which even playfully swipes the intro/outro drumbeat of David Bowie’s “Five Years”.

column1: Where Terrible Things Happen dips its toe
column2: The Last Match dives right in. By then
column3: Linton’s project had assumed a more solid lineup
column4: and with it came a shag-carpet kind of luxuriousness. Hints of Saint Etienne and Belle and Sebastian's precious pop abound—Linton’s voice is a burst of minty-fresh breathiness
column5: and there’s a cellophane-crisp shimmer to the production—but it’s the '60s influences that have taken hold. The instrumental “Christmas Song” nods to the sauntering hook from “Time Is Tight” by Booker T. & the MG’s
column6: and accordingly
column7: the entire album uses vintage organs as a gluey connective tissue. “Hit the Snow” is the album’s standout moment
column8: a confection of Brian Wilson ba-ba-bas and finger-snapping
column9: go-go pep. Granted
column10: these signifiers—even the organs—were all easily found in thrift stores in the '90s. The Last Match is the Aislers Set’s near-perfect unpacking of them; listening to the album is like popping bubble wrap
column11: and just as satisfyingly addictive.

column1: How I Learned to Write Backwards sharpened the Aislers Set’s fuzziness
column2: but something small was lost in that precision. The songs themselves are Linton’s most assured
column3: and her self-observational lyrics about pensive days and sleepless nights circumvent the band’s carefully constructed cuteness and slip straight into the heart. There’s also more space and abstraction to the album; “Melody Not Malaise” not only injects a hazy jazziness into the song’s swirly pop
column4: but also implies the chords rather than states them. A snotty-sweet punk interlude (“The Train #2”) and a sumptuously sad
column5: piano-led ballad (“Sara’s Song”) are strong evidence that Linton and crew were only hitting their stride. At the same time
column6: there’s a deflated ennui to How I Learned to Write Backwards. Sleigh bells are shaken tiredly
column7: as if they suddenly weigh a ton; emptiness takes the place of texture. The neo-mod anthem “Attraction Action Reaction”
column8: rather than being a Vespa-revving rave-up
column9: is a subtle
column10: muted homage to the melancholy side of '60s girl-group verve—a tune for the chill-out room at the house party in Quadrophenia.

column1: The Aislers Set came to a halt in 2003
column2: soon after the release of How I Learned to Write Backwards. By then
column3: the indie landscape was practically unrecognizable from what it had been when the band formed. The Shins—a band the Aislers Set toured with—were part of a wave of groups that hit the sweet-tooth of the public at large
column4: and indie’s quick climb to the mainstream had begun in earnest. The kaleidoscope of secondhand sounds and styles that the Aislers Set gleefully hoarded might have been too scattered and fractured for your average kid who just picked up Is This It
column5: especially at a time when America didn’t seem to have much of a taste for deconstruction. But with the reissue of these three chiming
column6: chillingly exquisite records
column7:
it’s clear that their obsolescence—like that of the thrift-store heirlooms that make up their DNA—was merely temporary.

column1: How I Learned to Write Backwards sharpened the Aislers Set’s fuzziness
column2: but something small was lost in that precision. The songs themselves are Linton’s most assured

column9: is a subtle
column10: muted homage to the melancholy side of '60s girl-group verve—a tune for the chill-out room at the house party in Quadrophenia.

column1: The Aislers Set came to a halt in 2003
column2: soon after the release of How I Learned to Write Backwards. By then
column3: the indie landscape was practically unrecognizable from what it had been when the band formed. The Shins—a band the Aislers Set toured with—were part of a wave of groups that hit the sweet-tooth of the public at large

column6: chillingly exquisite records
column7:
it’s clear that their obsolescence—like that of the thrift-store heirlooms that make up their DNA—was merely temporary.

A nation of kids who first saw Molly Ringwald turn a Salvation Army dress into a Cinderella gown—and Jon Cryer claim the Boomer music of Otis Redding for the fledgling Generation X—had grown out of the '80s and into connoisseurs of secondhand chic. column4: slumming it became an archly conspicuous statement. But an aesthetic doesn’t need to be entirely ironic or entirely earnest
