It took 13 years for Japanese shibuya-kei artist Takako Minekawa to figure out a way back into music
column3: and after that protracted silence comes color
column4: exploding out into the ether. Minekawa signed off in 2000 with the Maxi On EP
column5: only to return in 2013 for a collaborative work with former Ponytail guitarist Dustin Wong
column6: the beautifully light Toropical Circle. Here
column7: the pair team up for Savage Imagination
column8: released just over a year later. Everything is a little tighter and brighter
column9: with the personalities of Minekawa and Wong burning harder than before. It’s a jubilant
column10: uplifting work
column11: taking on several shades of happiness as it turns through its 43 minutes. It becomes delirious
column12: then studied
column13: then affable
column14: a process the pair loops through and then turns inside out over and over again. There’s plenty of repetition
column15: but it’s a deceptively complex work
column16: full of tiny details and bursts of what Wong acutely terms “ecstatic energy.”

column1: It’s hard to imagine a more different foil for Wong than Minekawa compared to the music he made alongside Molly Siegel in Ponytail. When stacking those aspects of his work together
column2: Savage Imagination becomes the daybreak after the tortuous night before
column3: resembling a need for tranquility after endless stretches of torn flesh and broken limbs. Minekawa’s a serene presence
column4: helping tease out a softer side to the base rigidity of Wong’s guitar loops. On the bell-like “Dancing Venus of Aurora Clay”
column5: the parts trigger off one another like they’re playing an extended game of tag
column6: with Minekawa the balmy center of it all
column7: swooping in with whoops and sighs in all the right places. At their most playful
column8: on the beautifully cluttered “Ancient Aluminum Forest”
column9: they weave dense layers of sound
column10: with pops
column11: whispers
column12: and sighs all spinning around to the point of lightheadedness.

column1: Both musicians have an acute ear for mixing fine details with light whimsy
column2: causing Savage Imagination to occasionally reflect the spirit of the notoriously fastidious BBC Radiophonic Workshop
column3: especially when sprightly analog synth noises reach prominence. There’s also a debt to the anything-goes sampling approach of '90s producers like the Dust Brothers. “Luminescent Earth Traveler” brings in distorted samples of dogs barking and twisted strings
column4: while “She He See Feel” is all compressed handclaps with a keyboard line that would make Money Mark proud. It’s Wong’s playing
column5: laced through this record like a thick piece of thread
column6: that positions it apart from all that
column7: with his distinct work becoming ever more inventive with each passing record (and there are many of them). Sometimes it resembles a ping pong ball giddily bouncing back and forth at impossible speeds
column8: passing by in a barely perceptible blur.

column1: The heart of this record is divided into three parts
column2: in a series of songs Minekawa and Wong have called their “Dimension Dive” trilogy. It’s the spiritual half-cousin to the outwardly fun hew of the rest of the album
column3: anchored in new age drift
column4: bringing in deliberately conflicting rhythms
column5: working in darker strokes reminiscent of krautrock
column6: and adding a bassier undertow toward its close. The “Dimension Dive” tracks sometimes sound like they belong on a different record altogether
column7: although taken in the grab-bag context of Savage Imagination it just about works. It’s just that elsewhere there’s a more coherent flow from one change to the next—a sense of getting picked up and pulled along in the euphoric blitz of ideas that rushes from one song to the next. That surge of creativity between Minekawa and Wong is infectious at times. Hopefully this is a beginning
column8: not an end
column9:
to their work together.

We’ve reached a point at which the once-hyperbolic term overnight success is literal. Catchy songs and videos find huge audiences instantly but quickly lose their adhesive; stars burn ultra-bright and ultra-fast. But we’re also in an era of quiet
column3: slowly spreading hits—polished
column4: anonymous-seeming pop songs that percolate and achieve ubiquity over many months. They take root on small blogs
column5: find homes in cosmopolitan retail stores and overpriced fitness classes. They’re used in TV shows; they excite a cappella groups. Eventually
column6: as if by some abstract force designed to counterbalance the internet’s star-making warp speed
column7: some begin gradually inching up the pop charts. Songs now become full-on phenomena years after their initial recordings; Icona Pop’s “I Love It” and Disclosure’s “Latch” bubbled up forever
column8: it seemed.

column1: Another artist making such an upward crawl is Tove Nilsson
column2: a 26-year-old Swedish singer and songwriter who goes by Tove Lo. Her résumé includes writing credits for artists like Cher Lloyd and Lea Michele from “Glee”
column3: and she’s firmly rooted in Sweden’s current network of pop characters. In high school
column4: she played music with Caroline Hjelt of Icona Pop (for whom she’s also written songs); she’s linked with Max Martin and production duo the Struts. After listening to her music—bruised
column5: brightly arranged pop songs that feel grand but not excessive—it should come as no surprise that she graduated from Stockholm’s Rytmus music school
column6: the place where Robyn was trained.

column1: Nilsson released a song called “Habits (Stay High)”
column2: and the accompanying art showed the singer with mascara tears streaming down her face
column3: in a photo that looked like it could have been snapped on an iPhone—about a year-and-a-half ago. It’s a big
column4: sticky song
column5: but not so big that it stuns your senses or numbs you into enjoyment. The single
column6: which just recently cracked the top 20 of the Billboard Hot 100
column7: is an exclamation of lost love and self medication; it contrasts a giant hook and chorus (“I gotta stay high all the time/ To keep you off my mind”) with snappy verses filled with quietly distinct
column8: often strange imagery: of Nilsson eating her dinner in the bathtub
column9: getting drunken munchies
column10: seducing dads on playgrounds.

column1: This sort of color—which might feel whimsical
column2: were the content not so dark—pops up frequently across Nilsson’s assured major-label debut
column3: Queen of the Clouds. Her foibles and off-kilter perspective on heartbreak offer shape and personality to a record that might otherwise be written off as too slick or inert
column4: or indistinguishable from a host of peers making competent
column5: spacious
column6: and downcast pop music. She thrives on understated contradictions and grim quirks: While her friends are dating guys who are “turning 53
column7: ” she sneers on “Like Em Young”
column8: she says prefers younger men. She gets drunk during the day and stays that way into the night
column9: not the other way around
column10: she tells us on “Talking Body”
column11: a song that turns a lustful gaze on a male partner. On that song
column12: seemingly low stakes are given great weight
column13: and delivered with dead seriousness: “If you love me right/ We fuck for life.” On a song called “Moments”
column14: she resents her cushy
column15: happy childhood
column16: as though it’s caused her to work doubly hard in order to become an interesting artist.

column1: “I can get a little drunk/ I get into all the ‘dont’'s
column2: ” Nilsson continues on that song
column3: before delivering the kiss-off: “But on good days I am charming as fuck.” It’s this sort of disarming honesty
column4: a coupling of self-doubt and boldness in well-phrased lyrics—not necessarily Nilsson’s great hooks—that stick in the brain while listening to Queen of the Clouds. In two months time
column5: she'll join Katy Perry on an arena tour
column6: and by then
column7: that the majority of the audience members will most likely be quite familiar with her music—and assumedly
column8: they'll be just as delighted to hear the odd
column9:
charismatic little asides in her songs as they will be to belt out the choruses.

Christopher Owens’ career is predicated on the idea that music is the healing force of the universe. The particulars of his own story—raised in a Christian cult
column2: a struggle with heroin addiction—are less important than the notion that music has the power to lift the downtrodden
column3: give strength to the weak
column4: and help anyone feeling down to carry on. One of the tensions that made his band Girls so great is that Owens always seemed like both a performer and a member of the audience; by borrowing melodies and phrases from well known pop hits
column5: he seemed like he was listening and creating at the same time and
column6: by extension
column7: using his music to help both his audience and himself. Because the music faced inward and outward
column8: Girls felt especially communal
column9: and those who clicked with the band connected to something ultra personal and intimate while also feeling like members of the Broken Dreams Club.

column1: Since Girls broke up
column2: the context around Owens’ music has been in flux. His first album
column3: Lysandre
column4: was
column5: he admitted
column6: something he had to get out of his system
column7: a series of themes and musical ideas that needed a home. It drew broadly from the image of the ‘70s singer-songwriter
column8: with some baroque touches like flute and sax to signal “new direction.” If Girls was Owens’ Modern Lovers
column9: Lysandre was his first unsteady step on his own
column10: complete with goofy genre exercises and its own versions of “Ice Cream Man”
column11: i.e. songs that sounded like they were written for children.

column1: A New Testament is much closer to the idea of Girls. It’s got simple songs about love and acceptance and singers steeped in gospel offer swelling background vocals that try to make these songs feel “universal”; the melodies are familiar
column2: based on the most iconic chord progressions; there’s a notable country influence
column3: mostly of the ’50s Bakersfield variety (“A Heart Akin the Wind” has echoes of Buck Owens)
column4: with hints of ’60s Memphis (the guitar part on “Oh My Love” is nicked from “Suspicious Minds”); song titles like “Stephen” and “Key to My Heart” have a familiar ring. At first listen
column5: it comes over like a return to the approach that made Girls so great
column6: but it turns out the connections are mostly on the surface.

column1: Owens’ tendency to borrow from classic pop is starting to catch up with him. These songs are so neat and tidy
column2: with every walking bassline and nifty guitar fill exactly where you’d expect it to be
column3: it starts to feel like watching someone assemble a jigsaw puzzle
column4: snapping one piece after another into place. His vocals stay in his most relaxed register
column5: where he sounds halfway between singing and whispering. Where his earlier music thrived on the contrast between that hushed delivery and more demonstrative musical elements
column6: the operative word here is control. The obsession with form combined with the careful delivery lead to an album that often feels weirdly cold and distant.

column1: It’s obviously unfair to expect Owens to make music in the same vein as Girls—he’s entitled to move on
column2: and we can choose to follow him or not. But The New Testament has so many parallels with his earlier band’s approach
column3: it’s impossible to avoid the comparison. There are moments that transcend the record’s limitations
column4: most notably the hymn-like “Stephen”
column5: a song about the death of Owens’ young brother at age two. Though the choir vocals might be a little forced
column6: “Stephen” works because of its specificity. It’s not so much that Owens is drawing from his own life as that he’s writing about people that feel real.

column1: But on the record as a whole
column2: the plug-in lyrics like “my honeybee
column3: you’re nothing more than everything to me” and “always and forever
column4: you’ll be dear to me” and “I’ve got so much love for you
column5: it’s running over” seem like empty signifiers
column6: lines chosen because they sound like they belong in songs like these. Yes
column7:
Owens once wrote the line ""You've got a lovely smile/ 
I could spend a while with that smile
column8: but in the context of nervy indie rock
column9: it felt fresh and surprising. He's a unique artist who surely has more great music in him
column10: but Owens' work will always be a balancing act
column11: getting the shading and contrast just so; The New Testament feels mostly like one just-OK thing
column12:
easy to enjoy on a pass but much harder to love.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21001/homepage_large.4600c83a.jpg|(What's the Story) Morning Glory?|3129.0|Oasis|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Big Brother']|2014-09-29 00:00:00|1995|2016-06-11 16:32:44.240768|"

It’s hard to remember now
column2: but when (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? was released in the fall of 1995
column3: Oasis were losers. Sure
column4: their 1994 debut album Definitely Maybe had gone straight to No. 1 on the UK albums chart
column5: and sold several million copies worldwide. But in their first true test of post-success fortitude
column6: Oasis could no longer claim the title of biggest rock band in the land. “Roll With It
column7: ” the teaser from Morning Glory
column8: was released August 14
column9: 1995—not coincidentally
column10: the very same day as “Country House”
column11: the jaunty new single from their bitter rivals in Blur (aka the London art-school yin to Oasis’ Mancunian street-tough yang). A year’s worth of tabloid sniping between the two groups—which hit its peak/nadir when Oasis architect Noel Gallagher declared that Blur’s Damon Albarn and Alex James should “catch AIDS and die” —had effectively come down to the UK chart equivalent of an after-school fistfight. And in this case
column12: it was Oasis who walked away licking their wounds—that week
column13: “Country House” outsold “Roll With It” by more than 50
column14: 000 copies to take the No. 1 spot.

column1: As it should’ve: “Roll With It” is nobody’s favorite Oasis song and would be hard-pressed to crack a Top 20 list of the band’s all-time best. It's a catchy enough tune
column2: sure
column3: but its shoulder-shrugged message of “you gotta roll with it” felt atypically blasé coming from a band that had previously endorsed self-deification
column4: immortality
column5: and shagging well-heeled medical professionals in helicopters. However
column6: for a band never encumbered by humility
column7: the decision to go with Morning Glory’s weakest song was
column8: in retrospect
column9: Oasis’ cockiest gesture yet: They were willing to take the first strike in the so-called Battle of Britpop because they knew it was only a matter time before they’d be delivering the knockout blow.

column1: (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? would go on to sell more than twice as many copies in the UK as Blur’s contemporaneous The Great Escape
column2: and
column3: over the following two years
column4: it served as the unofficial soundtrack to England's imminent changing of the guard. But
column5: just as significantly
column6: it achieved a metric of popularity that had proven so elusive to Oasis' Britpop peers: bonafide American success
column7: with the album reaching number 4 on the Billboard charts and selling 3.5 million copies Stateside. (The Great Escape
column8: meanwhile
column9: languished in the lower reaches of the Top 200.) For all their unibrowed laddism and two-fingered paparazzi salutes
column10: Oasis projected a glamorous image of Englishness that was potent enough to stoke the Cool Britannia fancies of those North American Anglophiles who make trips to specialty shoppes to load up on Dairy Milk bars
column11: but (unlike Blur) not so colloquial as to alienate the heartland. It’s the stuff upon which Austin Powers franchises and Brit-themed pub-chains would later be built.

column1: Fortuitously arriving at the mid-point of the '90s—and representing the peak of a Britpop narrative that took root with the retro-rock renaissance of the Stone Roses and the La’s five years previous—(What’s the Story) Morning Glory? is Oasis' absolute pinnacle. If Definitely Maybe presented Oasis' raw materials—’60s psychedelia
column2: ’70s glam and punk
column3: Madchester groove—Morning Glory melted down and remoulded them into a towering sound that was unmistakably their own
column4: with those omnipresent (but never ostentatious) string-section sweeps classily dressing up the songs like ribbons on a trophy. And yet the real triumph of Morning Glory is measured not by the tracks that have since become karaoke classics
column5: first-dance wedding standards
column6: and go-to bathtub sing-alongs
column7: but the exceptional album tracks that never got a shot at certain chart supremacy—like the jet-roar jangle of “Hey Now” (for my money
column8: the best Oasis song never to be issued as a single) and the crestfallen “Cast No Shadow”
column9: dedicated to a then-mostly-unknown Richard Ashcroft of the Verve
column10: a band that would soon reap the benefits of Oasis’ American incursion.

column1: Ironically
column2: the Oasis-whetted appetite for all things English was arguably also crucial to the impending Stateside success of the Spice Girls
column3: who would usher in a wave of preteen-targeted pop that would eventually push guitar-oriented rock acts down the charts by decade's end. And what’s most striking about listening to (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? today is how
column4: at the height of their powers
column5: Oasis seemed to be bracing for their own eventual downfall. The tone of the album is decidedly darker and more reflective than the working-class escapism of Definitely Maybe
column6: be it the foreboding “it’s never gonna be the same” prophecy of opening salvo “Hello”
column7: the title track’s white-lined dispatches from the after-party circuit
column8: or the cigarette-lighter-illuminated comedown of “Champagne Supernova”
column9: wherein Oasis already sound nostalgic for the idealism of their debut album. And while Noel still deals in absurdist metaphor here (how exactly does one slowly walk down the hall faster than a cannonball?)
column10: he also emerges as a more personable
column11: sobering foil to brother Liam’s bratty swagger—not just on his showstopping star turn on “Don’t Look Back in Anger”
column12: but also in the way his backing vocals imbue “Cast No Shadow” with a deeper sense of despair.

column1: This expanded three-disc edition of Morning Glory?—which outfits the original album with 28  bonus tracks—shows just how much Noel was on a roll in ’95. Conventional wisdom suggests Oasis released two near-perfect rock ‘n’ roll albums before a grueling
column2: prolonged process of diminishing returns set in. That’s not entirely true—the truth is
column3: Oasis produced at least three albums worth of spectacular songs
column4: it’s just the one of them was spread out over various B-sides. Fourteen of these were collected on the 1998 compilation The Masterplan (a.k.a. Oasis’ Hatful of Hollow)
column5: half of which is culled from the Morning Glory era and reappears here. And as any long-time fan can tell you
column6: these castaways rank among some of the band’s finest moments: perennial encore standard “Acquiesce” is a perfect sonic manifestation of Liam and Noel’s notoriously embattled but co-dependent relationship
column7: contrasting the former’s sneering verses with the latter’s heartfelt chorus; “Rockin’ Chair”
column8: along with the Noel-sung ballads “Talk Tonight” and “The Masterplan”
column9: evince a subtlety and sensitivity rarely heard on Oasis’ albums proper. And for those who prefer to savor Oasis’ easy-going melodicism minus the Wembley-toppling bombast
column10: the cache of Noel-strummed acoustic demos included here offer lovely
column11: low-key showcases of his songwriting savvy.

column1: Such unwavering consistency was no doubt the cornerstone of Oasis’ early success
column2: but
column3: in hindsight
column4: it also factored into their subsequent stagnation. As this box set makes abundantly clear
column5: Noel Gallagher is a master craftsman
column6: able to construct totemic tunes with even the most modest of means. But he’s never really been one for artistry. No matter how much he professed his desire to be as big as the Beatles
column7: Oasis were never concerned with the Fabs’ creative process—i.e.
column8: how they pulled from contemporary influences ranging from Dylan to Motown to Stockhausen to create truly modernist pop music—so much as their cultural omnipotence. And for a while
column9: Oasis convinced us you could achieve the latter without bothering too much with the former: just write a stadium-sized chorus and the rest will take care of itself. (The relationship between Oasis and their idols can ultimately be measured as such: In 1968
column10: George Harrison released the most freewheeling musical experiment of his career
column11: Wonderwall Music; 27 years later
column12: Oasis would appropriate t<span>he title and apply it to their <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6hzrDeceEKc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">simplest
column13: most universal anthem.) What's the Story (Morning Glory) thrust Oasis to the top of the mountain
column14: but left them with heads full of snow and clouded vision (while a revitalized Blur would later emerge as the band more in tune with The Beatles' adventurous spirit). In the dying moments of “Champagne Supernova”
column15: Liam lets the song’s central question—“Where were you while we were getting high?”—hang in the air
column16: as if to suggest the good times are already gone. And as Oasis would eventually learn
column17:
getting even higher won't bring them back.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21042/homepage_large.257f5828.jpg|NehruvianDOOM|32394.0|NehruvianDOOM|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lex']|2014-09-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:44.794534|"

The veteran mentor/young up-and-comer dynamic almost always has a good story behind it
column2: even if it's a simple one. In 2013
column3: when he was still two years away from the legal drinking age that his show's attendees were at
column4: rising NYC phenom Bishop Nehru shared a bill with MF DOOM in London's renowned 100 Club. Nehru had already seized on the opportunity to rhyme over a DOOM beat the previous year on his early release Nehruvia: the Mixtape with his track ""Lemon Grass"". Even more fittingly
column5: he opened the mix with an interview clip of DOOM venting about the state of the hip-hop industry
column6: one that could've been recorded any time in the last ten years and still more or less held true.

column1: With Nehru operating as an East Coast classicist-minded MC with a '94 revivalist mindset that rivals Joey Bada$$
column2: forging a relationship with DOOM should have solidified his status as a strong young talent. But NehruvianDOOM sounds more like the work of an MC with a little while longer to go and a producer who's sounded more inspired in the past (even in exile). Even at only eight tracks—nine if you count the intro—Nehru's presence starts to tread water
column3: a technically sound voice with solid lyrical structure that isn't quite there yet as far as bringing a unique perspective is concerned.

column1: To be fair
column2: harshing on a teenage rapper still finding his voice is like griping that I Was Made to Love Her is a weaker album than Innervisions. It's easier to shrug at what DOOM brings to the table
column3: actually; his role on this record
column4: touted as the first full-length production job by DOOM since King Geedorah's 2003 album Take Me to Your Leader
column5: is largely relegated to unearthing some of the more underused stuff from his Special Herbs archives. It still bumps
column6: just in a way that a lot of hardcore heads have likely heard before
column7: all blurry soul-jazz and punch-drunk underquantized drums. DOOM's verses
column8: rare as they are
column9: also still show glimmers of the off-the-cuff-sounding
column10: truism-tweaking conversational punchlines that made him so appealing throughout the '00s—but they mostly come across as autopilot or hook-duty versions of his usual self
column11: with the occasional contemporary reference (like a missing Malaysian airplane joke in ""Disastrous"") held up like a newspaper headline in a proof of life hostage photo.

column1: So Nehru's shortcomings are easier to forgive
column2: even if the best you can say about him at this point is that he's lucky to be one of those rare high-school age artists who doesn't let his own naiveté get the best of him. He maintains a solid balance between conceptual wordplay
column3: philosophical musings
column4: and internal rhymes
column5: but it's not quite well-traveled enough to possess a real authority. Which makes sense
column6: in that he's still figuring shit out; a line like ""Am I being idolized
column7: or am I a pair of idle eyes"" in ""Om"" or the frustrated come-up aspirations of ""So Alone"" touch on a nerve of creative-teenager introspection. Those lines are delivered with more finesse than personality
column8: a flat-voiced series of monologues that have their share of nod-worthy internal rhymes but still need refining into a style that outgrows its influences. The number of recent artists who've done that by the time they hit 18 can be counted on one hand
column9: so it's still worth following Nehru's development just to see where he takes his style. But in the meantime
column10: this generation-crossing collaboration feels like a record lodged in a sort of chronological rut
column11:
one where a young artist fronts an old-sounding record that sounds like it could've been released at any point in his lifetime—and helmed by any number of MCs that could've sounded like him.

"|19809.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19809-nehruviandoom-nehruviandoom/|5.6|Nate Patrin

The conversation surrounding London five-piece the History of Apple Pie’s 2013 debut album Out Of View focused on the young group’s rigid devotion to the sound of ‘90s indie rock. This wasn’t a case of laziness
column2: however—they really did sound like a group celebrating the fuzzed-out golden age of college radio. Guitarist Jerome Watson told DeadJournalist.com that they “never intentionally copied or referenced anything
column3: it’s just come from whatever we’ve been listening to and what moods we’re in while we’re demoing
column4: ” but in other interviews
column5: he and his bandmates referenced My Bloody Valentine
column6: Sonic Youth and Pixies as influences—perhaps not coincidentally
column7: the type of acts they often get compared to. Save for a new bassist
column8: second outing Feel Something offers no major changes from their first outing
column9: with the Horrors' Joshua Third returning for production duties; the record's an occasionally solid listen that comes across as pleasant and nothing more.

column1: Granted
column2: the History Of Apple Pie are hardly the only group borrowing liberally from the '90s two decades later—but in 2014
column3: artists such as Parquet Courts and White Lung have taken heavy cues from the same time period in winning fashion
column4: convincing listeners that old sounds can sound urgent. Feel Something
column5: meanwhile
column6: sounds knotted to the past
column7: with many of these songs sticking to a vague
column8: shoegaze-y noise pop formula. “Don’t You Wanna Be Mine” is all feedback-dipped strumming and lead singer Stephanie Min’s vocals
column9: which building up to a distorted guitar hook; the squalling “Special Girl” and somewhat zippier “Ordinary Boy” follow the same formula
column10: and piano plonks on “Tame” aren’t enough of a change-up to set the tune's guitar solo apart from the other ones that pop up across the album.

column1: On Feel Something
column2: the History of Apple Pie’s decision to play it down the middle hampers them. Despite the swirling presence of shoegaze
column3: they never let the guitars overpower Min’s lithe singing
column4: bringing their sound closer to the “pop” side of noise pop. That’s not a bad approach
column5: necessarily
column6: as Min’s voice remains the most consistent element on Feel Something
column7: and it provides an anchor for some great melodies—but this approach also leaves many songs
column8: such as the galloping “Keep Wondering”
column9: caught weakly between two poles
column10: and Min’s lyrics aren’t interesting enough to stand up on their own.

column1: So not much has changed between the History of Apple Pie’s first two albums
column2: but Feel Something does lack one element that made Out of View a stronger listen—namely
column3: immediate songs that barrel forward in a way that transcends spot-the-genre mimicry. There’s nothing wrong with being influenced by the past
column4: but it's important to make such pilfering sound fun. This record offers up a few examples—the psychedelic-edged “Jamais Vu”
column5: the chugging “Snowball”
column6: which also boasts the album’s best hook—that highlight the group’s knack for finding a great melody and running with it. Otherwise
column7: Feel Something is a so-so listen that never rises above the band’s influences.

Alice Gerrard turned 80 this July
column2: and while that shouldn’t necessarily matter when it comes to assessing the singer/banjoist’s new album
column3: Follow the Music
column4: it's worth taking into consideration. Ageism is a real thing in the music world
column5: and that reality is made all the more tragic by the fact that so many of our best artists get better with time. Sadly
column6: ageism is still the safest of all bigotries to harbor; the quest for the new and novel never relents
column7: especially in music. It's ironic
column8: then
column9: that Gerrard is new and novel to most contemporary listeners; despite the fact that she’s been recording for half a century—a discography that includes historic records with Hazel Dickens
column10: such as the duo’s Smithsonian Folkways’ anthology Pioneering Women of Bluegrass—she’s known primarily in folk and bluegrass circles.

column1: Follow the Music might change that
column2: if ever so slightly. The album was produced by M.C. Taylor of Hiss Golden Messenger
column3: who also plays on the record
column4: and Brad and Phil Cook of Megafaun contribute
column5: as well. These are artists whose own work
column6: while never strictly traditional
column7: understands and engages with the folk idiom; that engagement becomes intimate on Follow the Music
column8: but it never creeps into overfamiliar territory. Taylor and the Brothers Cook mostly fade to the background
column9: leaving Gerrard plenty of clear air and open space in which to thrive. Taylor in particular is used to working with legends: As a member of country-rock revivalists the Court & Spark
column10: he enlisted the help of the Byrds’ Gene Parsons (on 2001’s Bless You) and folk-rock icon Linda Thompson (on 2004’s Dead Diamond River).

column1: To Taylor’s credit
column2: you barely know he’s there: Follow the Music is as sparse as prairie grass
column3: even as it teems with a rich
column4: Appalachian greenness. “Bear Me Away” glides on a twangy drone
column5: as much of a plea for release as a surrender to eternity. The metaphysical underpinnings of the album can’t be ignored
column6: nor should they be: this is spiritually harrowing stuff
column7: from the eight-minute
column8: a cappella paean to predatory lonesomeness “The Vulture” to the almost cosmic resignation of “Goodbyes”. Gerrard’s songs cast long shadows; “Wedding Dress” quivers with violin and Gerrard’s spry yet stately banjo
column9: while her similarly arranged reworking of the standard “Boll Weevil” takes on a sinister
column10: at times lascivious symbolism. “I seen a spider runnin' up and down the wall/ He must be going to get his ashes hauled
column11: ” she sings
column12: and the potency of those delivered lines is enough to the ruffle the spine.

column1: As strong as Gerrard’s gifts as an instrumentalist remain
column2: it’s her voice that consumes Follow the Music. On the honky-tonk romp “Teardrops Falling in the Snow”
column3: she weaves her narrative through the loping rhythm with an easy yet aching cadence
column4: holding notes until they strain from the weightlessness. That masterful
column5: effortless tension—not to mention her ability to veer from breezy to steely at the drop of a chord—makes the album’s title track as much of a ghostly confession as an abridged autobiography. But it’s “Foolish Lovers Waltz” that draws the ear the closest
column6: a feather-soft shuffle in which Gerrard exhales
column7: “Whirl
column8: twirl
column9: spin faster now/ They know they’ll never fall/ But the piper always plays his tune/ In the foolish lovers waltz”. The arc of youth to adulthood to middle age and beyond is bound up in that whirl
column10:
and it’s as close as Gerrard comes to meditating on her own longevity. But it’s enough to make Follow the Music a strong case as to why audiences and artists alike would do well to follow her.

"|19660.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19660-alice-gerrard-follow-the-music/|7.4|Jason Heller

column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">But this is a guy who so convincingly sang the words
column5: “Time makes you bolder/ Even children get older/ And I’m getting older too”
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> as if they were his own. There was likely a recognition that Smashing Pumpkins fans who’ve been there since the beginning were becoming adults now
column7: and yeah<span>
column8: I graduated from high school two weeks after Adore dropped
column9: though I’m sure I truly believed that having my emotional tumult soundtrack by Smashing Pumpkins entitled me to feeling like an old soul.

column1: Either way
column2: Corgan once belted “I’m all by myself/ As I’ve always felt”
column3: and previous Pumpkins records offered empathy towards fellow isolators in their preferred quarantine
column4: whether it was in the clouds (Gish)
column5: your past (Siamese Dream)
column6: or your room (Mellon Collie). Without being overt about it
column7: as much as this record was meant to provide “a door” for Smashing Pumpkins’ music
column8: it was an emotional portal as well
column9: to perhaps get outside yourself to risk loving something or someone. And that can be scary—Mellon Collie spoke to hyperbolic and yet safe associations developed in one’s teen years
column10: offering
column11: “Love solves everything” and “Love is suicide.” Love is a lot of things on the feedback-stained long walk home of “Shame”—it’s good
column12: it’s kind
column13: it’s drunk
column14: it’s blind. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column15: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">But Corgan gives his first piece of grown man talk about how it always ends
column16: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">—
column17: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">“You’re gonna walk alone/ You're gonna see this through/ Don't let them get to you."" Delivered
column18: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">in a warm register but a discomforting tone
column19: it reveals the other unifying theme of Adore
column20: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">: moving on in the face of loss
column21: of friends
column22: of family

As a former member of the now-defunct Seattle band Carissa’s Wierd
column2: Jenn Ghetto understands the science of bittersweet confession. She writes psychologically acute breakup stories that show what it means to hurt
column3: but her songs aren’t about pretending to make the right decisions—they’re about telling the truth.

column1: Producer Chris Walla recorded her new album
column2: Cool Choices
column3: and he has a lot to do with its approachability. Ghetto worked with him back when she was still making achy
column4: acoustic slowcore as part of Carissa’s Wierd. That group disbanded after releasing their third album
column5: Songs About Leaving
column7: at which point Ben Bridwell and Mat Brooke went on to form Band of Horses
column8: Sera Cahoone went solo
column9: and Mat Brooke went on to Grand Archives. Ghetto quietly released records as S
column10: most of them sad bedroom confessionals recorded on a four-track.

column1: Cool Choices’ narrative style is familiar: Ghetto’s last records as S were called Sadstyle
column2: Puking and Crying
column3: and I’m Not as Good at It as You; previous songs had titles like “Pathetic”
column4: “Crushed”
column5: and “Outro (The Agony)”. From here
column6: opening the first line on her latest record with “This is how losers feel/ I am a loser” seems like a natural thematic progression. A blithe melancholy subsumes the entirety of this record
column7: which is also her most accessible record to date.

column1: “Like GangBusters” is a jangly
column2: propulsive ballad the lineage of Tegan and Sara’s “Dark Come Soon”—a comparison that I’m wary of making
column3: if only because Walla also produced that track. The harmonies are similarly clean—sharp arpeggios and barrel drumming drive it’s melodies— and Ghetto’s declarations of “you will not take me down” are measured like they wouldn’t feel out of place on The Con. The effect here and throughout Cool Choices is that Jenn Ghetto sounds more like Jenn Ghetto— Walla lends the record a familiar warmth
column4: and better production highlights lyrical gems like “I’m crazy and you’re fucked up” whenever they occur.

column1: Ghetto typically writes with a balance of wry humor and sad yearning
column2: but Cool Choices feels like a maturation in terms of delivery. Her voice luxuriates over Walla’s blended instrumentals with such command that you might forget how broken the lyrics really are. “It’s so hard to see you around here every day” and “I know about the girl you fucked” are words that Ghetto murmurs in the span of the same hook. Elsewhere her voice grows more assertive-—“You never did any of that/ You never said any of those things/ You never even called me back”—as if she’s finally owning a resentment that her whisper-croon could barely relay.

column1: The difficulty surrounding Ghetto's vocal delivery— a sort of stylized numbness—is that when the hooks don’t catch
column2: or when the instrumentation isn’t interesting enough
column3: the songs are easy to forget. The second half of Cool Choices can’t match the first in quality or intrigue
column4: but what makes the album as a whole worth listening to is Ghetto’s ability to burrow into a quarry of sentimental abandon and talk about what it feels like to be vulnerable. Whenever her lyrics are twee or oblique— as with the empty phrasing on “Forever Love”—that sense of intimacy is lost. The record’s higher points—“Brunch”
column5: “Loser”
column6: “Vampires”— stay much closer to the chest. Cool Choices succeeds when it feels like introspection
column7:
and that should always be enough.

There are a lot of layers to peel away to get to the heart of Bernard Szajner's Visions of Dune: brittle
column2: mythic surfaces that have calcified over the years. First
column3: there's all the baggage attached to Frank Herbert's Dune series
column4: to which the French musician's 1979 album was meant as a kind of interpretive tribute; beyond the novels themselves
column5: there are any number of famously star-crossed adaptations
column6: including David Lynch's 1984 box-office bomb and Alejandro Jodorowsky's ""lost masterpiece
column7: whose travails were recounted in last year's documentary Jodorowsky's Dune. And there's Szajner's own fantastic backstory
column8: told so often it has become reduced to a few abstract brushstrokes: born in a cave during the Nazi occupation of France
column9: his parents fugitive members of the French Resistance; inventor of the laser harp that helped make Jean-Michel Jarre famous (and for which Jarre took credit); light-show mastermind behind concerts for Magma
column10: Gong
column11: and the Who
column12: and as such
column13: a primogenitor for everything from Daft Punk's pyramid to Skrillex's space ship; member of the (Hypothetical) Prophets
column14: a sardonic
column15: proto-coldwave duo anthologized on Tigersushi's 2004 compilation So Young But So Cold: Underground French Music 1977 – 1983.

column1: Given all that potential interference
column2: a listener encountering Visions of Dune for the first time might be struck by how immediate it is. You don't need to have read Herbert's novels to appreciate Szajner's undulating electronic compositions. Despite titles that point to characters and themes from the novels and films—""Kwizatz Haderach""
column3: ""Bene Gesserit""
column4: ""Spice""—these are not narrative pieces; they're rippling abstractions as sensuous as the curves of actual dunes. Likewise
column5: they require no visual complement to come alive. Szajner may have made his name with phantasmagorical stagecraft
column6: but Visions of Dune
column7: like the best psychedelic music
column8: is itself a planetarium show that plays out behind closed eyelids. Chimes
column9: bells
column10: and zither-like glissandi add to the otherworldly ambience of its raga-like drones
column11: meditative bass pulses
column12: and chilly filter sweeps; open fifths and modal scales scan as vaguely Orientalist
column13: like the Middle East via Mars
column14: while all the rising and falling frequencies feel like metonyms for the cyclical nature of nature itself.

column1: Structurally
column2: the album alternates between multi-song suites
column3: like the seamless five-song stretch from the opening ""Dune"" through ""Bene Gesserit""
column4: and discrete tracks that take a given idea—a pearly guitar tone
column5: a contrapuntal tangle like a wrought-iron bar puzzle
column6: a pitch-bend fugue—and tease it out to its frayed ends. He's assisted in places by Gong bassist Hanny Rowe
column7: Magma's Klaus Blasquiz and Clement Bailly
column8: the British guitarist Colin Swinburne
column9: and Fondation's Anannka Raghel
column10: who's given the manly-robot treatment on the ominous ""Kwizatz Haderach""
column11: though their contributions are generally submerged within the music's tape-collaged ebb and flow. Structured largely around the movements of arpeggiated synthesizers
column12: the music bears comparison to contemporaneous work of ""cosmic"" synth wizards like Tangerine Dream
column13: Klaus Schulze
column14: and Edgar Froese
column15: though it's also refreshingly free of some of their kitschier excesses.

column1: The proto-post-punk ""Harkonnen""
column2: a dissonant tangle of gnarled electric bass and flangers on the fritz
column3: offers a glimpse of Szajner's later coldwave phase. ""Ibad
column4: a kind of new age proto-techno
column5: is preceded by ""Gom Jabbar""
column6: an 85-second miniature of queasy tones that fall like flakes of mica
column7: and on ""Fremen""
column8: Pac-Man death spirals morph into a surprisingly funky drums-and-synth jam in 17/4 time (if I'm counting correctly). Even further afield
column9: ""Duke"" and ""Spice"" sound uncharacteristically digital for a product of the '70s
column10: and bewilderingly nonlinear even today. With their demonic choirs
column11: glassy sheen
column12: and weird compression
column13: like a jet engine in a teacup
column14: they reveal themselves as distant antecedents of a present-day artist like TCF
column15: he of the unholy blur and apocalyptic affect.

column1: As it turns out
column2: both of those cuts
column3: while recorded at the same time as the rest
column4: were left off the 1979 release; apparently someone at Pathé Marconi
column5: the parent company behind the Sonopresse label
column6: deemed them too ""futuristic."" Perhaps they were right
column7: given how jaw-droppingly out there they sound even now
column8: 35 years later. As both Lynch and Jodorowsky could probably attest
column9: it wouldn't be a Dune project without something getting left on the cutting-room floor. Fortunately for us
column10: Szajner's unique approach to folding space has at last been revealed in its entirety
column11:
and it doesn't seem to have aged a day.

For an ostensible singer/songwriter
column2: Joan Shelley doesn’t say too much—or at least
column3: very much that’s concrete
column4: direct
column5: or explicit. On the stellar and small Electric Ursa
column6: her third album but first to be widely distributed
column7: the Kentucky singer lets prepositions hang with no object
column8: tucks nouns into vivid verb-less clusters
column9: and prefers pronouns that linger with little clear meaning. Electric Ursa includes only eight tracks
column10: but still
column11: Shelley foregoes lyrics altogether on the mid-album dream
column12: “Remedios”. Instead
column13: she hums a simple melody over banjo
column14: piano and gathering drums
column15: as though she were singing a child to sleep with the help of a rural chamber ensemble.

column1: “There’s so much I’m longing to say
column2: but there’s nothing to decide
column3: ” she offers during the hypnotic sway of the love song “Long Way to Night”
column4: as if to apologize for the impressionistic shape of her own words. No condolences are required
column5: really: Shelley’s primary instrument carries both the grain of a wizened Appalachian lifer and the maneuverability of a young torch singer. Paired with a simpatico band of Louisville musicians
column6: her tone gives the words more meaning and weight than additional details or complete sentences ever could. Shelley’s voice fills the space between her pen’s lines.

column1: Several years ago
column2: Shelley recorded a pair of albums with Maiden Radio
column3: a string trio with fellow Kentucky singers Cheyenne Marie Mize and Julia Purcell. They largely covered antiquated American ballads
column4: country tunes
column5: and lullabies
column6: mixing in the occasional original or contemporary number to avoid any old-time novelty pratfall. The tunes of Electric Ursa indeed verify a musical education rich with various transcontinental folk renaissances. “River Low” feels like a letter for back home from a mountain pioneer
column7: confessing both loyalty through love and personal growth. “There’s a calmness in my footsteps
column8: in the new lines on my hands
column9: ” she sings with welcome resolve. The closer and title track
column10: meanwhile
column11: shakes with the same bucolic reverie of Nick Drake and Vashti Bunyan
column12: Shelley linking images of “waning autumn light” and “moments given unto the ether” with a see-saw dynamic that makes you lean in close to records like Pink Moon. Her voice rises into sudden
column13: stainless near-shouts and then slinks back toward a whisper. Beneath it
column14: the rippling acoustic guitar of labelmate Nathan Salsburg affords the simple instrument-and-voice affair the ornate elegance of Pentangle.

column1: But the respective placement of these songs at the album’s middle and then at its end feels like a subtle and deliberate revelation. It’s as though Shelley is reminding the listener of her foundation—that is
column2: centuries of Anglo-American songbooks—only after offering a tour of the grand designs it can support. Collectively
column3: those other songs put Shelley in the surprising
column4: esteemed company of recent stateside singers like Sharon Van Etten
column5: Justin Vernon
column6: and Angel Olsen
column7: songwriters who use modest observations as the basis for big and bold arrangements. When Shelley nests her voice inside of Electric Ursa’s more complicated productions
column8: she stuns. “Something Small” begins as a simple acoustic trickle
column9: with drums obediently echoing the strums. It builds one piece at a time
column10: the music mirroring Shelley’s slow
column11: steady feeling of being trapped by provincialism
column12: loneliness and fate. “It’s all laid out in front for you to take it
column13: ” she sings in the closing chorus
column14: organ pouring in like a wave of unexpected encouragement. The record’s peak
column15: “First of August”
column16: scans as the more mature flipside to a single from <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/10709-for-emma-forever-ago/""><i>For Emma
column17: Forever Ago
column18: the singer suddenly capable of restraint in the face of complete emotional resignation. Of all Electric Ursa’s songs
column19: “First of August” is the most lyrically elusive
column20: with seasons that seem to obey no calendar
column21: a subject that seems decisively indecisive
column22: and an idiosyncratic style that cuts between hillside patois and sophisticated English. But Shelley and the band—all moping drums
column24: hand-wringing electric—make the mix of regret
column25: longing and hope tucked into the lines perfectly clear. The feeling is complete and engrossing
column26: even if the words are not.

column1: Electric Ursa isn’t Shelley’s debut
column2: but it is her absolute arrival. On 2012’s Ginko
column3: issued by the Ol Kentuck label of longtime collaborator Daniel Martin Moore
column4: Shelley worked for similar grandeur. But it felt stiff and forced
column5: as though she had an idea of how she wanted to sound but not the experiences she needed to power it. In the interim
column6: though
column7: something seems to have softened and shifted for Shelley
column8: making her less concerned with the perfection of these productions (there is
column9: more often than not
column10: a ripple of room noise and tape hiss in these songs) than their power. Again
column11: it’s an arc and approach not unlike Van Etten’s
column12: where two relatively minor albums preceded a sudden revelation. Where Ginko was too conscious and precious
column13: Eletric Ursa suggests that Shelley is revealing bits and scraps from private journals
column14: leaving out details to protect or piss off the guilty. Sounds like folk music
column15:
after all.

“Dejected
column2: decrepit
column3: deserted
column4: decayed/ It hangs like old meat on a hook”
column5: Uta Plotkin incants on “Psycho Animundi”
column6: the first song on Portland doom quartet Witch Mountain’s fourth album
column7: Mobile of Angels. She might as well be singing about doom itself. Innovators in the genre abound at the moment
column8: with Pallbearer being the most conspicuous
column9: but doom on the whole doesn’t want or need the pitiful upswing of progress. Rot is eternal and slow; so
column10: therefore
column11: is doom. Traditionalists to their decomposed cores
column12: Plotkin and the rest of Witch Mountain don’t bring many fresh ideas or novel elements to Mobile of Angels. It would be a mistake
column13: though
column14: to assume the album is anything less than a passionate exploration of doom’s horror and power. The meat may be old
column15: but it makes for some stunning mummification.

column1: “Psycho Animundi” couldn’t be more orthodox in its embrace of doom’s monstrous sloth. Guitarist Rob Wrong unspools riffs as if they were lengths of transatlantic cable; vast and cumbersome
column2: they weigh tons
column3: yet they sink with grace. Plotkin’s voice is bluesy and smoky
column4: but it doesn’t necessarily flow. There’s nothing smooth about her phrasing
column5: a staccato cadence that’s as apt to induce panic attacks as it is to lull. That nerve-numbed anxiety gives way to an airier passage full of dust and shadows
column6: not so much a breakdown as a drift-off. “Your Corrupt Ways (Sour the Hymn)” is cut from the same cloth. But where “Psycho Animundi” circles melody without succumbing to it
column7: “Your Corrupt Ways” summons Plotkin’s full command of soulful hooks and acidic sweetness. Wrong’s solos are just as sinuous
column8: but more subtle; rather than vying with Plotkin for attention
column9: they enter into a dialogue with the vocals
column10: a hissing
column11: whispering negotiation that evokes the tone of a fireside chat with the Devil.

column1: Of Mobile of Angel’s five lengthy songs
column2: its title track is the shortest—and also the strangest. A three-and-a-half-minute canticle for organs and voice
column3: it swirls in a spiral of unholy reverberation and corroded faith. “Waking brings no comfort”
column4: warns Plotkin; neither does the song
column5: despite it being a respite from the guitar-compacted mass of the rest of the album. That density reaches its peak on “Can’t Settle”. The song sums up and effortlessly perfects everything Witch Mountain has been shooting for since 2011’s South of Salem
column6: the group’s first album after Plotkin’s recruitment: It’s a voyage into lightless depths of confusion and despair
column7: classically tuneful yet uncompromisingly stark
column8: in which Plotkin cries
column9: “Turn off my heart/ Turn off my mind” while harrowingly amplifying both. It’s also a showcase for Plotkin’s range: throughout “Can’t Settle”
column10: she hits sludge-trawling grunts on par with 13’s Alicia Morgan alongside piercing wails worthy of Heart’s Nancy Wilson. Plotkin is a traditionalist
column11: but she defines those traditions on her own terms.

column1: As modestly masterful as Mobile of Angels is
column2: it comes with a bitter aftertaste. Plotkin recently announced her departure from the group
column3: and while it appears to be on good terms
column4: it’s a blow to a longstanding band that didn’t truly catch fire until Plotkin joined in 2009. Her next musical move
column5: as well as Witch Mountain’s
column6: can only be guessed at; whatever they turn out to be
column7: Mobile of Angels will stand as a crumbling monument to their way of making doom feel both ancient and new. If there’s one positive message that can be drawn from the album’s heart-pressing heaviness
column8: it’s that life doesn’t spring from death itself
column9: but from the silent
column10: gradual putrefaction that follows. “You’ve turned around
column11: shut down/ Without a goodbye
column12: without making a sound”
column13: Plotkin sings on “The Shape Truth Takes”
column14: her layered
column15: partsong-like harmonies swimming through a drizzle of doom at its most delicate. To her credit
column16: she’s leaving Witch Mountain not only with a goodbye
column17:
but with a cruelly beautiful one.

Mystique has always been a key part of rock iconography
column2: which might explain why Julian Casablancas has remained at arms’ length for so long. At his main act’s creative peak
column3: the Strokes frontman had a confounding
column4: emotionally distant aura. A notorious Rolling Stone profile from 2003—right around the time of the excellent
column5: second-verse-same-as-the-first sophomore effort Room on Fire—portrayed him as a contradictory
column6: besotted rascal
column7: as he unleashed invectives against Pringles
column8: haggled with a bootleg CD vendor over a Radiohead album
column9: and repeatedly kissed journalist Neil Strauss on the neck before drunkenly commandeering an abandoned wheelchair.

column1: “I just don’t have anything deep to say...I’ve got nothing to hide
column2: ” he claimed in what Strauss referred to as “the worst interview ever
column3: ” and by the time the Strokes put out the career-deflating 2006 record First Impressions of Earth
column4: he was committing the sentiment to tape. In the years that followed
column5: Casablancas sobered up and more or less faded out of view. Near the end of the '00s
column6: he popped up with a solo album of sugary power-pop in the form of the better-than-you-remember Phrazes for the Young
column7: citing the Choose Your Own Adventure books as sonic inspiration; 2011 brought the Strokes’ fourth album
column8: the curiously flat Angles
column9: which was written and recorded without Casablancas entering the same room as his bandmates. By the time last year’s aptly named Comedown Machine saw release
column10: the Strokes—Casablancas
column11: especially—sounded exhausted
column12: as mediocrity came to define the band’s second decade of existence. Instead of failing outright
column13: the Strokes simply became boring.

column1: Regardless of their place in the rock landscape
column2: Casablancas and the Strokes still represent a certain level of aesthetic “cool
column3: ” at home and beyond. Many acts from the early-'00s new-rock explosion have retained a considerable level of popularity in Europe
column4: and the Strokes themselves have a distinctly French appeal. Casablancas himself reached his own Gallic pièce de résistance by appearing on Daft Punk’s year-flattening musical odyssey Random Access Memories
column5: lending a soft-focus vocal to the metronomic
column6: neon-melancholy single “Instant Crush”.

column1: His latest musical venture
column2: Julian Casablancas + the Voidz
column3: is a group comprised of session musicians and alt-rock barnacles—guitarist Jeramy Gritter was a member of the <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NgugnldIUKM"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">mercifully defunct
column4: reality-show-reject outfit Whitestarr—plucked from Casablancas’ current home base of Los Angeles. The best you can say about the band’s debut
column5: Tyranny
column6: is that it's the most interesting thing Casablancas has done since facing off against Guided by Voices on “Family Feud”; it’s a record that's as adventurous as it is unlistenable
column7: a spectacular failure that smacks of both fellow L.A. denizen and gonzo-pop misfit Ariel Pink’s AM-radio abstractions and “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” ne’er-do-well Charlie’s warped musical efforts. If Angles and Comedown Machine sounded like the work of a group that was running out of steam
column8: Tyranny is a record overloaded with ideas
column9: a palette of vibrant colors swirled together until there’s nothing left but brown.

column1: Casablancas recently told GQ that he’s optimistic about Tyranny’s commercial prospects
column2: which is hilarious if you've actually heard the album. Clocking in at an endless 62 minutes—10 more than bloated First Impressions of Earth—with six of its 12 songs stretching well over the five-minute mark
column3: Tyranny is designed to be impenetrable
column4: a blaring monolith of excess. There are a few ideas buried in the unending screech
column5: suggesting that Casablancas has a raw and unique creative mind
column6: if not the compositional smarts to pull off something this dense. “Take Me in Your Army” and “Nintendo Blood” begin with gorgeous
column7: digitized sighs
column8: 8-bit renderings of the Strokes’ finest
column9: most subtle melancholic moments
column10: but the latter dissolves in an acid bath of guitar squeals and off-beat drum machines
column11: while the former meanders towards a slow-hand guitar solo that smacks of a “shredding” YouTube video made specifically to mock the work of John Carpenter. “M.utally A.ssured D.estruction” packs thrash metal figures and horror movie synths into an energizing two-and-a-half minutes
column12: while the seven-minute-plus “Father Electricity” offers a kalimba-like rhythmic backbone and
column13: after several minutes of useless dithering
column14: a sprightly Afro-pop melody that doubles as the record’s most pleasant surprise.

column1: On the other end of the spectrum is “Human Sadness”
column2: the nearly 11-minute cut released as the album’s first single
column3: ostensibly to confound the expectations of anyone who hadn’t caught Casablancas + the Voidz’s run of incompetent festival performances over the past year. The song is essentially a modern “Bohemian Rhapsody”
column4: if Queen’s pomp-rock classic was twice as long and had only two or three distinct musical movements. After a brief bit of twinkling ambience and a vocal sample referencing the album’s vague theme of capitalistic pitfalls
column5: Disney strings enter alongside an ambling bass line that sounds like a Strokes song played at half-tempo. Then
column6: the song pretty much stays there
column7: Casablancas alternating between a bedside mumble and glass-shattering vocal histrionics as a parade of sounds—a cackling
column8: distorted laugh
column9: ear-bleeding guitars
column10: video game sounds
column11: crashing drums—piles on top of the song’s dirge-like rhythm. Intentionally or not
column12: it plays like “The Story of Everest” in musical form.

column1: “I love being weird/ It’s so weird
column2: ” Casablancas tosses off underneath the grating motifs of “Business Dog”
column3: and this particular line speaks volumes on Tyranny’s try-hard stab at eccentricity. (Good luck hearing it without a lyric sheet
column4: though: the words here are the most endearingly bonkers rantings Casablancas has ever put to tape and the album’s execrable production largely buries his vocals to the point where you can barely hear him.) “He must be on drugs” is a typical invective thrown at artists who flirt with career suicide in the way that Casablancas is doing here
column5: but Tyranny is too willfully weird
column6: too labored-sounding
column7: too beholden to its melted-frequency artifice to be merely the product of a substance-addled mind.

column1: As that GQ article highlighted
column2: the common assumption is that Casablancas wrote the first two Strokes albums
column3: a rock lore factoid that suggests prodigiousness from a guy who’s spent the last 15 years looking like he’s never worked a day in his life; on Tyranny
column4: that guy has simply worked too hard
column5: and that sense of needless toil bleeds through in every bum lick
column6: brick-walled sound
column7: and garbled burst of noise shoved onto the record. Maybe Tyranny will one day have a second life as a misunderstood cult record
column8: but in the here and now
column9:
it sounds terrible and beyond redemption.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21110/homepage_large.81ba4000.jpg|Hey Hey|31860.0|Mapei|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Downtown']|2014-09-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:52.067824|"

Jacqueline Mapei Cummings writes and records polyglot pop-soul that feels deeply inspired by her international upbringing and well-traveled adulthood: she was born in Rhode Island to a Liberian mother and an American father
column2: moved to Sweden with the former at age 10
column3: and has bounced between Portugal
column4: Brazil
column5: and Tunisia in the decades since. Her 2009 debut EP The Cocoa Butter Diaries was made up of gritty
column6: socially conscious rap that garnered comparisons to the work of Lauryn Hill; a collaborative record with French electro knuckleheads Justice was scrapped shortly after. When she returned nearly five years later with single “Don’t Wait”
column7: she sounded completely different
column8: her hard-edged progressivism replaced by cracking analog warmth
column9: extensive vocal processing
column10: and rich
column11: earthy tones. “Don’t Wait” made a decent-sized splash
column12: and the song leads off her debut LP
column13: Hey Hey
column14: a record that represents an ostensible attempt to build on the song’s success.

column1: “Don’t Wait” remains a supremely catchy
column2: texturally compelling piece of music
column3: but it also manages to encapsulates most of Mapei’s strengths and weaknesses in one four minute blast. There’s her voice
column4: a warm and engaging instrument that sounds almost exactly like Alicia Keys; there’s her ear for space
column5: which allows small details like backing percussive snaps and secondary piano melodies to pop instead of being swallowed. And
column6: troublingly
column7: there’s her tendency to lean on clunky
column8: lazy phrasing and lyrical motifs: a line like “Let’s laugh and cry/ Until we die” combines dullness and awkward rhyming
column9: almost grinding the song to a halt even as its positive aspects are present and in motion. Largely
column10: Hey Hey continues on in this way—showcasing a pleasant voice with some interesting musical ideas
column11: stunted by a reliance on platitudes
column12: staid imagery
column13: and tired themes that make it tough to get through the entire album.

column1: There are certainly some lovely moments on Hey Hey
column2: several of which stem from the juxtaposition of classic melodies—and Mapei’s traditionally soulful voice—with contemporary production flourishes. “As 1” is built around an inviting and familiar piano melody that’s augmented with a wide array of synth tones and bubbling rhythms; in some moments
column3: it doesn’t sound far from the joyous and oft-zany electronic music made by Mapei’s Scandinavian neighbours in Norway. Mapei and producer Magnus Lidehäll balance their love of modern synth-pop and their classicist impulses
column4: and position her at the front of the mix whether she’s singing or dipping into her still-dexterous rapping voice.

column1: But her prominent placement at the forefront of these songs only illuminates her weak lyrical spots. “Change”
column2: a perfectly serviceable piece of inspirational pap
column3: is rendered completely benign where it might’ve held some personal resonance or deeper meaning; “Things You Know Nothing About”
column4: ostensibly a stern rebuttal of a block-headed lover
column5: is devoid of detail and stuffed with unconnected
column6: boilerplate cliches like “I believe I was made to love
column7: even as it compellingly moves from zippy
column8: synth-flecked pulses to a funky strut. “Step Up” might be the album’s worst offender
column9: hanging on the slack-jawed repetition of “When you gon’ step up?” and containing the immortally lousy rhyme
column10: “You ain’t an MC
column11: you ain’t no singer/ You and your company could get the finger.”

column1: The sentiment is admirable — it’s seemingly pulled from Mapei’s own experience in the industry
column2: and feedback she might’ve received from executives who thought her somewhere between an MC and a vocalist and unable to succeed at either — but ironically
column3: she doesn’t yet possess the skillset to make the line truly effective. To her credit
column4: Mapei has recognized weakness in her lyricism
column5: going so far as to discuss it in her interviews; in a June chat with Fader
column6: she noted
column7: “I have a hard time expressing myself in English since I think in Swedish. Swedish has become my first language
column8: so I don’t like talking to Americans that much … maybe I am going through some premature phase but I feel really down.” It’s the kind of honest self-evaluation that’ll serve her well as her career evolves; unfortunately
column9:
it’s a piece of self-criticism that consistently holds up when applied to Hey Hey.

"|19870.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19870-mapei-hey-hey/|4.8|Jamieson Cox

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20971/homepage_large.2c08f97a.jpg|Highway Robbery|5547.0|Freeway|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Team Early'
column3: a collaboration between Freeway and Bay Area legend the Jacka
column4: has been held up for years by logistical and legal hurdles—which is a shame
column5: because it's the best and most natural-sounding project Freeway has been involved with since 2007. ""Got with Jacka 'cause he pray like I pray
column6: he growls on the album's second track
column7: ""Dunya""
column8: a reference to their shared Muslim faith. But the two share a lot more than that: they are both pained
column9: repentant
column10: and thoughtful
column11: their lyrics glowing with hard-won wisdom and regrets. They are stubby
column12: stocky
column13: unlovely guys with devoted regional fans
column14: and on Highway Robbery they sound like they've been sitting on the same porch together for decades.

column1: The producers on Highway Robbery include the Jacka's frequent collaborator Jeffro and other Bay Area rap staples
column2: like Traxamillion and Young L; the bulk of the music is low-key
column3: liquid
column4: and unmistakably bluesy.  The guests that float through are on the same wavelength—Trae tha Truth on ""Just Remain""
column5: Freddie Gibbs on ""Cherry Pie"". On ""Write My Wrongs"" Cormega drops by
column6: whose stern and reflective new album Mega Philosophy put some metaphysical weight and writerly bite behind conscious-rap scolding. These are serious rappers
column7: and you don't bob your head to Highway Robbery so much as nod slowly
column8: your eyes squinted from the glare of all the old-head wisdom unfurling in front of you.

column1: Highway Robbery isn't all hard-won old-man jewels
column2: though. There are airy party tracks
column3: too: ""Sunnah Boys""
column4: featuring Killer Mike
column5: high-steps through some jazzy keyboard chords and candy-coated synths.  ""Shuckin & Jivin"" is a lip-licker sex jam from Young L
column6: and it knocks like retooled ""Mr. Me Too"" stripped for scrap. It also represents one of two appearances on the album of wild card Husalah
column7: a human exclamation point who lends unstable energy to any song he's on. Even though Highway Robbery is an independent release
column8: Free and Jacka have somehow managed to liberate a Daft Punk sample
column9: and a high-profile one
column10: for ""One More Time""
column11: and they slow it down and pump it full of low end.

column1: Freeway raps in a lower register than normal
column2: and he sounds incredible; more importantly
column3: he sounds palpably at home. As a member of the scattered early-'00s Roc-A-Fella dynasty
column4: he has a lot of past to compete with
column5: and he's been working gamely against the cultural tide for the last few years
column6: trying to reinvent himself as a backpack rapper and then as a nostalgia act. But here
column7: he finds a milieu that suits him. He and Jacka trade lines with gusto and fire: ""Pray you keep my family safe/ They didn't ask to be here
column8: they shouldn't pay for my mistakes"". The Jacka moans on ""Dunya""
column9: ""No matter how much I smoke
column10: the pain won't burn away."" ""My close homies turned on me for no reason
column11: they're such traitors
column12: Free seethes
column13: adding a gut-kicker: ""My last album was only in fourteen stores.""

column1: Simply put
column2: Freeway always works best when he's got a foil
column3: and the Jacka is his most natural partner since Beanie Sigel slipped sadly off the grid. When you listen to him here you aren't
column4: for the first time in years
column5: pondering Roc-A-Fella. He's talked in interviews about being energized by the grind of artists like Jacka
column6: who has built up a formidable mystique as a sort of Bay Area philosopher king
column7: and frankly
column8: Free should do three projects like this a year: the regional rap landscape is dotted with serious-minded
column9: knotty rappers—Vic Spencer or Lil Durk from Chicago
column10: or Young Moe from Alexandria
column11: with whom he's worked before—who would make perfect complements. Free's hunger is a precious resource
column12:
and it's hard not to want to hear more of it in the world. 

"|19743.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19743-freeway-the-jacka-highway-robbery/|7.9|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21097/homepage_large.acb9389c.jpg|Desiderium|29291.0|TOKiMONSTA|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young Art']|2014-09-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:53.392109|"

Jennifer Lee has never lacked for inventiveness. With a background in classical piano
column2: the L.A. producer who works as TOKiMONSTA is adept at doling out earworm melodies to ground even her most nebulous beats
column3: but what makes her best tracks stand out is the ability to evoke her own freewheeling
column4: stoner charm while wielding a heavy sonic arsenal. Her 2010 debut Midnight Menu was a solid example of the woozy
column5: cosmic glitch-hop that countless West Coast DJs and producers have mined from Flying Lotus’ near-inescapable sphere of influence—and sure enough
column6: infectious cuts like “Gamble” and “Cheese Smoothie” injected that sound with an undeniable stomp that piqued the interest of the Brainfeeder mastermind himself
column7: who signed Lee as the label's first female artist for her follow-up EP Creature Dreams.

column1: Anchored by jazzy
column2: innovative beat patterns
column3: the dubby
column4: refined weirdness of Creature Dreams proved far more compelling than last year's Haruki Murakami-inspired Half Shadows
column5: her first full-length for massive dance label Ultra. The industry upgrade heralded a shift in Lee’s sound
column6: broadening her distinctive bedroom beats into a grab bag of pop and disco-based hooks and meandering slow-step jams
column7: enlisting a roster of contributing vocalists that included NYC's MNDR and hip-hop legend Kool Keith to varied success.

column1: Lee’s latest
column2: the mini-LP Desiderium
column3: also serves as the launching pad for her new label Young Art. The Arama-featuring “Drive” is a chugging dance track that doesn’t do much to distance itself from its Half Shadows counterparts
column4: but things improve on ""Realla""
column5: when Lee ratchets up a fleet of distant air horns and a slow-stepping beat that offsets California vocalist Anderson Paak's mostly frivolous contribution. “Open Air” is in a similar vein with a more suitable vocal offering from fellow Californian Joyce Wrice
column6: whose soulful pipes meet Lee’s energetic groove with more balance. Still
column7: none of the three vocal-assisted tracks tread any ground Lee hasn’t already covered to better effect on previous EPs.

column1: While Desiderium isn’t a particularly formidable entry in Lee’s discography
column2: it isn’t without merit. Highlight “Dusty Stars” dances around a looped sample of Aaliyah’s “Miss You” with odd
column3: interesting time signatures and a catchily stuttering beat; “Steal My Attention” is similarly satisfying
column4: using a repetitious chorus that recalls Midnight Menu’s most club-ready jams
column5: while closer “Sakamoto’s Spring”
column6: with a piano backing track reminiscent of the song’s eponymous Japanese composer (whom she collaborated with two years ago on a protest song condemning the reopening of the Ōi nuclear power plant in Japan)
column7: is a sprightly counterpoint to some of the album’s more routine embellishments. The highlights on Desiderium prove that
column8: vocal-assisted lowlights be damned
column9:
Lee’s beatmaking abilities are still considerable.

"|19858.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19858-tokimonsta-desiderium/|6.4|Eric Torres
