0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21084/homepage_large.de21f0da.jpg|Right from Real|32492.0|Lydia Ainsworth|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Arbutus']|2014-09-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:53.954721|"

Lydia Ainsworth flourishes amidst contradiction. A Canadian artist raised in a ""household soundtracked by Björk
column2: The Beatles
column3: Nirvana
column4: and Arvo Pärt
column5: she taught herself the cello from the age of 10
column6: while insisting that she's terrible at the instrument. Ainsworth nonetheless went on to study film scoring at McGill University and NYU
column7: and landed her first feature-length credit in 2011 for Matthew Lessner's painfully self-aware escapist satire
column8: The Woods
column9: which claimed to ""build upon the...contradictions of young modern day Americans."" Yet it was during these cinematic pursuits that she found a love for pop composition and vocals
column10: and quietly began to write songs from the perspective of her diverse and disparate musical backgrounds. As such
column11: Ainsworth is now a studied classicist with distinctly modern curiosities; her debut album
column12: Right from Real
column13: doesn't attempt to resolve its differences
column14: but rather culls vitality from the meditative space between its opposing forces.

column1: Because of their ties to Montreal's Arbutus Records
column2: comparing Lydia Ainsworth with label mate Grimes may come quick and easy
column3: but the two have little in common outside of a taste for electronics. Right from Real is orchestral pop in the vein of Kate Bush and Bat for Lashes
column4: albeit from an artist who would cite a love for Meredith Monk and Giuseppe Verdi's Requiem in the same breath. Ainsworth isn't as experimental with regards to her songwriting approach
column5: though
column6: nor is she so spiritually cathartic. Much like the Knife's Silent Shout
column7: Right from Real exists in a dusky
column8: cobalt-hued twilight
column9: after the real world has drawn its curtains closed and before the mystical realm starts to come alive. The music illustrates those enchanted hours in detail with soft-sweeping strings
column10: modest electronic tinkering
column11: pointed spates of percussion
column12: and Ainsworth's confident
column13: versatile self-harmonizing.

column1: The eight-song album was released in two parts
column2: and though each standalone EP is strong enough on its own merits
column3: Right from Real only gains more impact as a full package. Early singles ""White Shadows"" and ""Malachite"" sketch out the basics of Ainsworth's musical etymology—the first of which exhibits her knack for spectral moods and string arrangements
column4: while the latter song is darkly affecting synth-pop with an eye on the Visions playbook. (Even the gloving and waacking dance moves in ""Malachite""'s bizarre video invoke the Grimes aesthetic more than something Lydia could call her own.) But the record's bottom section is where Ainsworth speaks to her true potential in a unique yet vaguely recognizable voice.

column1: ""Moonstone"" opens the second half with an incandescent waltz
column2: a more magnetic and creative entry point than the light
column3: orchestral patter of early album track ""Candle""; in a way
column4: it offers a portal into the deepest levels of Right from Real. The slow-swaying balladry in ""Hologram"" seems directed at the idea of desire
column5: which Ainsworth ponders through cooed stanzas and stately piano phrases. ""PSI"" synthesizes Right from Real's overarching thematic and musical elements into a gush of ardent chamber pop. For the most part
column6: the song feels down-to-earth
column7: and yet is unafraid to soar on the wings of powerful emotions without name or purpose
column8: as Ainsworth sends each updraft through impressionist lyrics that zoom in on the divide which separates dreams from reality.

column1: That said
column2: it's still difficult to discern Ainsworth's concrete artistic identity. She's a formally trained singer
column3: musician
column4: and composer with an interest in Baroque art
column5: who also refers to contemporary dance choreographers as ""genius""; she's an artist who performs her music flanked by a violinist and a cellist
column6: but has no problem adding a live snake into her onstage arrangement; her songs rely as much on the delicate '80s pop of Peter Gabriel's So as they do 19th century choral music and Bulgarian folk singing. Throughout Right from Real
column7: Ainsworth refuses to ever be only one thing
column8: so by the end of her debut
column9:
it's clear she's an artist capable of most anything.

"|19846.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19846-lydia-ainsworth-right-from-real/|7.9|Patric Fallon

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21092/homepage_large.d5d8152c.jpg|Popular Problems|787.0|Leonard Cohen|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2014-09-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:54.541268|"

The story of latter-day Leonard Cohen is one of wry acceptance. Fleeced by a manager of his retirement savings between the mid-1990s and mid-'00s
column2: he returned to the stage in 2008
column3: 73 years old and nearly broke after four decades of hard work. The shows he played were better than they needed to be in order to get people to pay for them. At one that I saw in late 2012
column4: he reminded me of a cat
column5: drawing the audience in by pulling away
column6: rolling over and showing his softer
column7: playful side only to snap back into cool focus. It was the first time I had ever seen anyone over 70 skip
column8: and in dress pants
column9: no less.

column1: Come to think of it
column2: it's the kind of story you might hear in a Leonard Cohen song: the aging entertainer forced into the spotlight one last time just to make they money he's already earned
column3: a cog in the same machine that once made him a star. ""It's their ways to detain
column4: their ways to disgrace
column5: goes a line from 1974's ""A Singer Must Die"". ""Their knee in your balls and their fist in your face/ Yes
column6: and long live the state
column7: by whoever it's made/ Sir
column8: I didn't see nothing
column9: I was just getting home late."" In other words
column10: ""broke"" is all the thanks most singers get.

column1: Popular Problems is Cohen's second album in the past two years. As with the 2012 LP Old Ideas
column2: its best songs feel naked and hymn-like but are restrained by an underlying mystery—he sounds like he's telling you everything but he never actually tips his hand. The flat airhorn of a voice he used throughout the '70s has become eerily bottomless
column3: the husk of another voice now gone.

column1: Cohen is still an impossibly cool figure
column2: singing about states of yearning and distress with the confidence of someone who knows that they—like everything—will pass. Even when he sings in the first person
column3: he is heatless
column4: as though watching his own failures from a distant star. ""Did I ever love you?"" he asks at one point. ""Does it really matter?"" The music behind him is a strange
column5: sterile take on country—a form known for its certainty and wisdom
column6: repurposed for a meditation on doubt.

column1: Like all of Cohen's albums
column2: Popular Problems sounds slick but slightly off-kilter
column3: like someone trying to imitate music they've read about but never actually heard. Where an artist like Bob Dylan seemed to use music primarily as an excuse for words and Van Morrison seemed distinctly to be the leader of a band
column4: Cohen occupies a stranger space. His music over the years has been even more exploratory than his writing
column5: changing style with the detached irreverence of a teenager breezing through her closet
column6: from folk to lounge to ersatz disco and cabaret. The reminder here is that no matter how close Cohen seems to the truth
column7: what he does is just another cheap show to keep the crowd entertained. Even in its starkest
column8: most naturalistic moments
column9: Popular Problems cannot—and does not want to—spare you its arsenal of perfect background singers and trumpets made of computer sounds.

column1: Cohen has always had a remarkable way of making sadness sound triumphant and triumph sound sad. In a 2002 interview with Spin
column2: he related a lesson he learned during his years studying Zen. ""Roshi said something nice to me one time
column3: he started. ""He said that the older you get
column4: the lonelier you become
column5: and the deeper the love you need. Which means that this hero that you're trying to maintain as the central figure in the drama of your life—this hero is not enjoying the life of a hero. You're exerting a tremendous maintenance to keep this heroic stance available to you
column6: and the hero is suffering defeat after defeat. And they're not heroic defeats; they're ignoble defeats. Finally
column7: one day you say
column8: 'Let him die—I can't invest any more in this heroic position.'"" The best songs here—""Samson in New Orleans
column9: ""Born in Chains""—occupy that space: weary but optimistic
column10: suffering but renewed.

column1: Because Cohen is a thoughtful person on the edge of his 80th birthday
column2: everyone seems to want to ask him about dying. ""Naturally those questions arise
column3: he said in a 2012 press conference. ""But
column4: you know
column5: I like to do it with a beat."" Which implies that his answers might be simple
column6: but they aren't. ""There is no God in heaven/ And there is no Hell below"" goes the last verse of a song on Popular Problems called ""Almost Like the Blues"". ""So says the great professor of all there is to know/ But I've had the invitation that a sinner can't refuse/ And it's almost like salvation; it's almost like the blues.""

column1: The idea being that heaven and hell are the same thing and you don't even have to leave earth to get there. A compelling thought
column2: but nothing to pray on. And yet the performance is so contemplative and so certain. Maybe it's the Zen
column3: which posits that change is permanent and our only choice is to accept the moment or become just another tragedy trying to force our way uphill. Half the time
column4:
it doesn't even feel like Cohen is singing songs—he's too busy with notes. 

"|19853.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19853-leonard-cohen-popular-problems/|7.6|Mike Powell

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21082/homepage_large.11a357a9.jpg|Singer's Grave a Sea of Tongues|351.0|Bonnie “Prince” Billy|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Palace'
column2:
'Drag City']|2014-09-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:55.231225|"

Will Oldham releases come and go quickly and with little fanfare
column3: so it’s easy to forget just how much music he has released in the last 20-plus years
column4: whether under his given name
column5: variations of Palace
column6: or Bonnie “Prince” Billy. There’s a Spoon-like consistency to his output
column7: even on self-released experiments and one-off collaborations
column8: like the 7-inch he released with Glasgow’s Trembling Bells earlier this year. Some releases work better than others
column9: but the low points are typically few and far between.

column1: Other than his Everly Brothers covers record with Dawn McCarthy
column2: there hasn't been any significant promotional push for a Bonnie “Prince” Billy album since 2009’s Beware
column3: which he addressed around that time: “This kind of promotional thing destroys a lot of the excitement of making records.” So it's entirely possible that some listeners were unaware of last year’s self-titled
column4: self-released record
column5: as well as this follow-up
column6: Singer's Grave a Sea of Tongues—and that’s OK with Oldham
column7: apparently. His job is to make music
column8: and if you want it
column9: you’ll have to periodically check in and go get it.

column1: The one bit of PR for this new album
column2: other than a convoluted album bio (sample: “A sea of tongues boils forth
column3: mountains spurting forth from the magma”) is a 17-minute fictitious interview with “Q101”
column4: in which a hostile
column5: humorous
column6: mostly nonsensical Oldham harasses an interviewer as the poor deejay tries in vain to get some info about the album for the station’s “exclusive premiere.” “Fans are going to be very happy
column7: right?” the deejay asks. “That’s a double-edged sword
column8: ” Oldham responds in the one seemingly truthful moment.

column1: The whole encounter sounds like something Oldham has longed to do in a real interview for years—that is
column2: to outlandishly subvert the promotional machine—and yet this bizarre interview’s purposeful obfuscation is itself a strategy. Saying nothing about the record ensures the songs will speak for themselves
column3: and it’s not a bad tactic
column4: because the hook for Singer's Grave a Sea of Tongues isn't a very exciting one. Nine of the 11 songs are reworked versions of songs from the 2011 release Wolfroy Goes to Town along with that record’s accompanying b-sides
column5: and while it’s not destined to be an essential release from Oldham’s catalog
column6: it’s certainly not a stinker.

column1: Wolfroy was a slow
column2: stark record; guitarist and frequent collaborator Emmett Kelly is the only musician who returns on Singer’s Grave
column3: and instead of Angel Olsen’s distinctive crooning
column4: Oldham recruited gospel singers the McCrary sisters and Chris Scruggs (grandson of Earl) on mandolin and ukulele. The result is a fuller
column5: slicker
column6: and more ornate take on the songs
column7: which are mostly unrecognizable from their originals—but the arrangements are still entirely in the Bonnie “Prince” Billy wheelhouse
column8: incorporating various strains of Southern musics.

column1: The pensive “New Whaling” is reincarnated here as “So Far and Here We Are”
column2: a rollicking
column3: riff-heavy affair that’s over two minutes shorter but doesn’t improve on the original’s eerie
column4: call-and-response chorus. Elsewhere
column5: the McCrary sisters add spiritual weight to “We are Unhappy”
column6: which offsets despairing lyrics (“Nothing is better
column7: nothing is best/ We are unhappy
column8: we are unblessed”) with a bouncy
column9: decidedly happy-sounding banjo. The strongest use of the sisters’ golden voices comes on “Whipped”
column10: previously released as a b-side to Wolfroy’s “Time to Be Clear” and one of Oldham’s cleverest and funniest songs in recent years. “I’m quieter
column11: tired-er
column12: more apt to say/ ‘You go on boys
column13: I’m good; think I’ll stay in today
column14: ’” sings a pussyfooted narrator who then passively admits: “I’ve been chosen to be whipped.” The song builds to a loud climax as the McCrary sisters double the narrator and revel in the admission
column15: “I’m in love
column16: and I am absolutely whipped!” before quieting down again. “I’ll hoop and holler
column17: ” Oldham sings. “If I’m allowed.”

column1: Only two songs on Singer’s Grave aren’t retreads: “New Black Rich (Tusks)”—a comparatively sparse tune set apart by Scruggs’ mandolin and a short
column2: devastatingly beautiful fiddle solo by Billy Contreras—and closing track “Sailor’s Grave a Sea of Sheep”. The latter has a strikingly similar mood and melody to Wolfroy’s “Black Captain”
column3: a eulogy from a sailor to his reviled but misunderstood commanding officer who’s about to meet his end. “What power he has
column4: only I know/ Now I have let my captain go
column5: ” the sailor sang on the chorus. A similar scene plays out on “Sailor’s Grave a Sea of Sheep”
column6: this time from the perspective of a man who sounds much like that doomed captain. “My intentions were pure even when I am sure they felt riddled with evil imposing
column7: ” he sings
column8: then comforts his former protégé: “It’s ok
column9: this is done
column10: let it be so/ And now you can let me go.”

column1: This isn’t the first time Oldham has mined his own material for inspiration: 2004 saw the release of Bonnie “Prince” Billy Sings Greatest Palace Music
column2: and the 2012 EP Now Here’s My Plan featured new takes on songs plucked from his last ten years of releases. On Singer’s Grave
column3: Oldham tweaks the lyrics and song titles here and there to fit these new
column4: peppier arrangements
column5: but he doesn’t appear to be making any grand artistic statement in these re-dos other than making it clear
column6: again
column7:
that he can reinvent himself and his songs in any way he so chooses.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21064/homepage_large.f0deb63b.jpg|Unknown Memory|32505.0|Yung Lean|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-09-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:55.816502|"

Born Jonatan Leandoer Håstad
column2: Yung Lean is an 18-year-old Swede who speaks
column3: raps
column4: and sings over beats mostly created by members of his Sad Boys clique. His general shtick is an approximation of contemporary swag-rap that comes across as a mixture of tribute and parody; he initially attracted notice as a kind of musical meme. Indeed
column5: it’s hard to imagine Lean gaining an audience without visuals
column6: and the video for ""Ginseng Strip 2002"" exemplifies his approach: the baby-faced rapper dons his now-trademark bucket hat and a bad Southern accent
column7: shouting out Makaveli within the clip's opening seconds. His verses are stilted
column8: his movements awkward; he resembles a rap-obsessed misfit from a summer camp who freestyles poorly and doesn’t worry about distinguishing between the positive and negative attention he's receiving. And Lean receives plenty of both: the video has over 2.6 million views
column9: and fans and haters still lob pejoratives at each other in the comments section to this day.

column1: On last year’s Unknown Death 2002 mixtape
column2: Lean’s rapping was wooden but relatively easy to ignore
column3: and those who found themselves responding in earnest to his music may have been attracted to the cloudy instrumentals provided by producers such as Yung Gud and Yung Sherman. On the trance-like “Gatorade”
column4: Lean’s voice was screwed up and down the register so often that he simply became part of an appealingly chaotic mix; “Lemonade” was a blatant Clams Casino rip-off
column5: but the imitation was accurate enough to capture that producer’s appeal.

column1: As a whole
column2: Yung Lean wields the appeal of a charming reality star: he's ridiculous without knowing it. His new album
column3: Unknown Memory
column4: is reminiscent of the second season of ""Jersey Shore""<i>
column5: where it slowly became clear that the cast was in on the joke. The record finds Yung Lean doubling down on every part of his personality that hit home with those initially drawn to his music
column6: while simultaneously scrubbing away the most amateurish (and most likable) parts of his sound.

column1: He’s added two notable tricks to his arsenal: a bastardized form of dub
column2: and a heightened tendency to eschew rapping altogether in favor of Auto-Tuned wailing. This latter development flatters the fidelity of his music—one can easily imagine a track from Unknown Memory passing by anonymously in a public space—but it also makes many of these songs indistinguishable from one another. Consequently
column3: it's harder to ignore Yung Lean's vocals to focus on his more palatable beats; “Sunrise Angel” and “Yoshi City” are relatively interesting production-wise
column4: but Lean’s voice is too high in the mix. His revamped flow
column5: which cements him as a terrible rapper rather than someone who doesn't know how to rap
column6: comes across as more grating than his older
column7: more fruitless attempts at piecing verses together. T<span>he most engaging song here
column8: the Travis Scott-featuring “Ghosttown”
column9: might have been more potent if Yung Lean didn't appear on it at all.

column1: One of Lean’s noteworthy qualities has always been his expression of sad feelings
column2: and on Unknown Memory that tendency is kicked into overdrive. On the hook of “Yoshi City”
column3: he refers to himself as a “lonely cloud”; on “Monster”
column4: over the same brassy synths and a TNGHT-like build
column5: he laments “nothing matters anymore.” “Leanworld” finds the rapper reaching the nadir of this expression—it’s a swampy
column6: soupy production
column7: almost unimaginably irritating in the club-land fantasy it conjures up. These sentiments feel like the performative sadness that’s been explored with much more sophistication by artists like Lana Del Rey; in comparison
column8: Yung Lean’s expression sounds empty.

column1: Yung Lean's tendencies to randomly emote and stunt come in part from approximating the real emotions of the music he takes his cues from—mostly
column2: Southern and West Coast rap ranging from the sad robotics of Future to the anything-goes ethos of Lil B. But he never shows any real emotional investment in the style he’s chosen
column3: and his lyrics and tone don’t reveal much personality beyond “rap fan.” Yung Lean isn’t bringing anything new to rap; instead
column4: he’s making cheap copies of his actual role models
column5: and in doing so he removes the humanity of the rappers he’s imitating
column6:
creating unwitting caricatures of those artists and not much more.

"|19827.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19827-yung-lean-unknown-memory/|3.6|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20885/homepage_large.f5dadfc9.jpg|Something Shines|28928.0|Laetitia Sadier|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-09-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:57.178273|"

“We want to be able to be inspired
column2: contemplate beauty
column3: achieve excellence
column4: and live life to the fullest. But we are governed by an exploitative economic system which is keeping this from happening”. So states Stereolab’s Laetitia Sadier—in her native French—in “Manifest”
column5: a track from We Are Divine
column6: the debut album by her latest outfit Little Tornados. It’s far from her first extracurricular project; she previously played in Monade
column7: and she’s also just released her third solo album
column8: Something Shines. Regardless of how these various projects have been played
column9: produced
column10: packaged
column11: and presented over the years
column12: Sadier’s songs remain similar at their core
column13: and that goes double for We Are Divine and Something Shines. Both albums are full of seemingly simple
column14: subversively sophisticated avant-pop
column15: with Sadier’s breathy
column16: balmy voice as the high point. And as “Manifest” almost painfully demonstrates
column17: both albums follow Stereolab’s tradition of unabashed leftist sloganeering.

column1: In Stereolab
column2: those slogans have always felt more abstract than literal
column3: swirled as they are into pulsing Krautrock
column4: bubbly yé-yé
column5: retro-futurist exotica
column6: and post-C86 jangle. But Sadier always sold her Marxist lullabies with a straight face
column7: and if there’s one thing We Are Divine in particular conclusively proves
column8: it’s that she was never even remotely joking. Little Tornados are a collective of instrumentalists formed around the core of filmmaker (and longtime Stereolab photographer) David Thayer
column9: as well as Sadier; she’s on vocals and bass
column10: while he handles vocals and guitar. In other words
column11: it’s a similar group dynamic to the one Stereolab uses—only with Thayer assuming the role of Tim Gane. We Are Divine tracks like “In the Garden”
column12: “How Many
column13: ” and “Space Liner”
column14: laden with jazzy chords and playful ambience
column15: could pass for decent
column16: latter-day Stereolab outtakes
column17: only looser and less densely layered. But it’s the lyrics of “Manifest” that hew closest to Stereolab’s alchemy of politics and pop
column18: only it gets the balance wrong; over bouquets of vintage synths
column19: Sadier’s pamphleteer-level pleas for freedom
column20: equality
column21: and brotherhood come off as canned
column22: regardless of how exquisitely phrased they are in French.

column1: We Are Divine
column2: however
column3: is not simply a cloned version of Stereolab; Thayer weighs in often with his distinct
column4: low-key
column5: mystic-bohemian ramble
column6: and it brings a winning prog vibe to “Unicorn”; “Ben’s Boat” is a twangy
column7: twinkling instrumental that borders on kosmische-country. The album’s definitive moment
column8: “Have a Balloon”
column9: is dashed and dotted with Sadier’s signature ba-ba-bas and da-da-das
column10: with the occasional jazz-fusion fanfare on horns. The song is gorgeous
column11: but it also gently mocks: like day-glo highlighting in a used Guy Debord textbook
column12: the title and melody work together to magnify the Society-of-the-Spectacle message Sadier has been whispering into our ears all along.

column1: Balloons aplenty can be found on Something Shines
column2: too. Sadier’s third solo album smoothly continues her arc as an artist over the past three decades; like 2012’s Silencio and 2010’s The Trip before it
column3: Something Shines is a satellite orbiting the Stereolab home world. “Quantum Soup” remixes the same elements she’s been surrounded with for three decades: sonar synths
column4: chanson delight
column5: Françoise Hardy-through-a-CB vocals. But here she impishly dissolves the glue that holds them together
column6: until the song fades into a wash of spacious chaos. It’s the inverse of a noise breakdown
column7: and when it all comes back together at the end
column8: it feels less like a reinvention than a reaffirmation. During Stereolab’s prime in the 1990s
column9: Sadier was part of one of the most exciting ensembles in music
column10: genre notwithstanding. She doesn’t fight that overshadowing fact
column11: but she doesn't let it slip by unchallenged
column12: either.

column1: Something Shines abounds with warm
column2: swaying breezes that carry with them the smell of winter. “All of the roots we grew/ We will pull out
column3: ” she warns with a lash of her tongue in “Then
column4: I Will Love You Again”; her voice has never sounded so near
column5: let alone so large. The stiff
column6: sci-fi samba of “The Scene of the Lie” and “Echo Port”
column7: on the other hand
column8: reveals the album’s biggest weakness
column9: and that of Sadier’s solo work as a whole: there’s no avoiding that it comes off like Stereolab with too many of its pieces missing. The chords don’t stick
column10: the melody doesn’t hook
column11: and the delicate
column12: intimate strength of tracks like “Butter Side Up” wind up lost in the shuffle. The slogans pop up again
column13: naturally; couplets like “Meanwhile the ultra-rich in all impunity/ Rots our society” are harrowingly enunciated on the eerie
column14: semi-acoustic “Oscuridad""—but in terms of depth
column15: they don't rise above the quality of radical bookstore bumper stickers. As ardent and inviting as Something Shines and We Are Divine both are
column16:
Sadier seems content at this point to coo to the converted.

"|19659.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19659-laetitia-sadier-little-tornados-something-shineswe-are-divine/|6.7|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21020/homepage_large.8c760388.jpg|Pulsars e Quasars EP|28087.0|Arp|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2014-09-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:57.793149|"

Tussle's music frequently resembled electro-funk-as-astronaut ice cream: dehydrated
column2: alkaline
column3: functional but in an abstemious way. As Arp
column4: ex-member Alexis Georgopoulos has retained his old group's basis in krautrock and modular synthesis but has taken it in freer directions
column5: relaxing out of Tussle's parched technicality across a string of increasingly warm
column6: woolly and hard to categorize records. As Arp's first two efforts form a symmetrical pair
column7: so does new EP Pulsars e Quasars with last year's improbable More.

column1: On the 2007 debut In Light
column2: Arp drifted serenely among cold stars
column3: turning to the ethereal side of Tussle's beat-driven German electronic idiom. Then
column4: he touched down on some clement sunset shore with the grainy
column5: glowing 2010 effort The Soft Wave
column6: hooking into the neo-new-age trend of Oneohtrix Point Never and Emeralds with minimal arpeggio suites. (Seldom has a musician's alias been so on-the-nose as Arp's: It's like if Tim Hecker called himself ""Drone"" or Axel Willner went by ""Loop."")

column1: Having dispensed with the nocturnal and diurnal sides of that aesthetic
column2: Arp made a startling but ultimately comprehensible lateral leap to another part of the '70s electronic pop continuum on More
column3: an art-pop album in the style of early Brian Eno
column4: but more raw-boned and tattered. More omnivorous
column5: too
column6: with sonic touchstones spanning Tin Pan Alley
column7: Motown
column8: '60s garage rock
column9: and '70s glam
column10: all polished to one brassy consistency and decoratively etched with analog electronics.

column1: Following the impeccable abstraction of its predecessor
column2: More's prominent adenoidal vocals and live instrumentation took some getting used to before you could even hear it as the same artist. But there was a sense of continuity in the hushed crackle of analog signals
column3: sealing in the garish songs. If it had come first
column4: Pulsars e Quasars
column5: a more evenly balanced between electronic instrumentals and vocal-led songs
column6: would have made for a less abrupt transition.

column1: Pulsars feels looser and livelier than More
column2: using a pickup band rather than solo multi-tracking. On the title track
column3: a jaunty guitar line
column4: phased slightly green and nauseous
column5: supports a stuffy vocal. After starting simply
column6: the guitars gain definition and start to churn
column7: with waves of distortion like impalpable explosions in the background
column8: toward a cheering cherry sunburst finish. ""UHF1"" similarly begins in a metronomic place before the guitar phases start swooshing and crumpling in the far corners
column9: pumping in a chaotic energy that cues mutations into dance-rock and heroic noise; in both songs
column10: the instrumental melody is stickier than the faintly droll vocal intoning.

column1: Though the psych-pop songs stand out
column2: the instrumental electronic side of Arp
column3: which gets two fine showings here
column4: is arguably preferable. On ""Chromatiques II (Extended Mix)""
column5: an elegant decanter of delicate periodic tones gorgeously fills and drains with morning light. Its many voices grow freer and freer
column6: like a starchy choir gradually easing into gospel expression. Meanwhile
column7: ""New Persuasion (Version by Le Révélateur)"" is a precise and detailed krautrock voyage
column8: with low arpeggios tensed as if about to strike
column9: a lurking bass like footsteps coming up behind you and a synth melody that wafts out like silver smoke on the dark.

column1: There are a couple of weak spots on this EP: ""Suns"" is attention-getting as a blown-out noise intro but is not a piece you'd return to on its own
column2: and “On Returning”
column3: built on a loop of thickly chugging electric guitar chords
column4: presses onward like a huge
column5: mindless drill. It's pretty boring and one-note
column6: but if Georgopoulos' indulgent
column7: decadent tendencies produce the occasional dud
column8:
it seems a small price to pay for the intrigue of looking forward to what he’s going to do next.

"|19789.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19789-arp-pulsars-e-quasars-ep/|6.7|Brian Howe

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21031/homepage_large.a680acc8.jpg|Too Bright|28685.0|Perfume Genius|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2014-09-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:58.303849|"

The first line on Perfume Genius' third album
column3: Too Bright
column4: is a basic observation
column5: one we've heard a million times in songs: ""I can see for miles."" Mike Hadreas
column6: the Seattle songwriter behind the project
column7: sings it over a spare piano
column8: something that won't surprise people familiar with his music. The sentiment
column9: though
column10: is a bit unexpected: Hadreas has made a habit of writing powerful
column11: intimate
column12: and sometimes introverted songs that look closely at his inner life
column13: warts and all
column14: and at the inner lives of the people around him. These words find him peering outward.

column1: The rest of the lyric finds Hadreas acknowledging the cliché
column2: and averting his eyes: ""I can see for miles/ The same old line/ No thanks/ I decline."" What he sees is an ""Angel just above the grid/ Open
column3: smiling
column4: reaching
column5: but he rejects it. Later he uses the line again
column6: on the raucous ""Grid""
column7: with the same decision to look away. At that point
column8: though
column9: ""There is no angel/ Above the grid."" It's been replaced by ""A diamond/ Swallowed and shit/ Then swallowed again."" He adds: ""At least we know where it's been.""

column1: All of this is important to consider because Too Bright is
column2: by far
column3: Hadreas' most extroverted album to date
column4: a record about shattering illusions
column5: defiantly looking away when you feel like it
column6: and boldly staring back at those who hate you. It's also about personalizing your experience
column7: and rejecting the clichés placed on it by outsiders. As Hadreas has explained
column8: ""A lot of these songs are me trying to claim some power in situations that would typically depress or alienate or victimize me...I've seen faces of blank terror when I walk by. Sometimes from seemingly strong
column9: macho dudes—somehow my presence confuses and ultimately scares them. There is a strange power to it that I've only recently begun to understand and embrace.""

column1: Too Bright follows 2012's excellent Put Your Back N 2 It
column2: a quiet record that offered variations on a central sound; sonically
column3: Hadreas pushes things much further here. He recorded Too Bright with previous collaborator Ali Chant and Portishead's Adrian Utley
column4: who also played bass and synth. Additionally
column5: PJ Harvey collaborator John Parish plays drums on a number of tracks that
column6: fittingly
column7: are reminiscent of fuzzed-out Harvey songs. There are still elemental
column8: stripped-down moments
column9: but the sound is generally denser and weirder. For the first time in Hadreas' career
column10: he's giving equal time to the textures as he is with his words. That said
column11: his vocals are more muscular
column12: too
column13: more clear and naked-sounding. His voice takes on a shape-shifting quality on Too Bright
column14: sometimes warping into odd
column15: ambient shapes; on the finger-snapping ""Fool""
column16: his powerful falsetto sounds like it could fill a cathedral and then crack it in half.

column1: ""Queen"" features heavy
column2: fuzzed bass along with synthesized vocal choirs and rhythmic oomph backing the great
column3: cocky line
column4: ""No family is safe
column5: when I sashay."" The frenetic
column6: fucked-up ""Grid""
column7: with immense banshee howls
column8: horns
column9: and repetitious
column10: burly bass is reminiscent of Swans (the video
column11: on the other hand
column12: resembles Tom Petty's ""Don't Come Around Here No More"" as done by David Bowie's Ziggy Stardust persona). On ""I'm a Mother""
column13: Hadreas performs muffled
column14: creepy falsetto that sounds like Antony whispering beneath a pillow. The title track is a ballad with piano and Hadreas' crystalline voice
column15: mixing in chiming clarinet
column16: synth washes
column17: and escalating ghost choirs; ""Longpig"" possesses a booming '80s synth line
column18: ricocheting handclaps
column19: and violent burts and blooms with lines about burying meat for mama. As on Put Your Back
column20: there's a sock-hop quality to many of these songs
column21: especially the closer ""All Along""
column22: but the structure is toyed with and flayed

column1: The approach to writing lyrics here is more elliptical and mysterious
column2: too. There isn't the same kind of fleshed-out narrative storytelling found on previous highlights ""Mr. Peterson"" or ""Dark Parts"". These tracks often zero in on overall textures
column3: but this doesn't mean the lyrics aren't nakedly intimate. ""I wear my body like a rotted peach/ You can have it if you handle the stink
column4: he sings on ""My Body"". On ""Queen""
column5: he tosses out and reinscribes gay stereotypes: ""Don't you know your Queen?/ Ripped
column6: heaving/ Flowers bloom at my feet/ Don't you know your Queen?/ Cracked
column7: peeling/ Riddled with disease.""

column1: There are brilliant insights and images that reveal themselves over multiple listens. On ""Fool""
column2: he makes a dress
column3: lays it out on ""the couch you bought
column4: then bleeds out on that couch in one version and dances in another. He finds power in being able to hold the hand of the man he loves
column5: no longer needing to keep secrets: ""I carry their names
column6: the secret shapes/ An aching braid around my heart/ Traced in the park
column7: an outline I chalk."" And
column8: as he sings on the closing track
column9: ""All Along""
column10: ""I don't need your love/ I don't need you to understand/ I need you to listen.""

column1: He's also shifted his look to match his new sound. In the past
column2: Hadreas donned cozy sweaters and black hoodies; on the golden cover of Too Bright he looks buffed and polished
column3: and in recent videos he's wearing smart suits and designer clothes with colorful splashes of makeup. He's always had a knack for the quietly devastating; there was his basic
column4: simply shot
column5: romantic
column6: and playful video for Put Your Back's ""Hood""
column7: with the beefy gay porn star Arpad Miklos (who committed suicide a year after the clip)
column8: and Hadreas and his mother climbing into a tree at the end of ""Dark Parts""
column9: a song in part about her being molested by her grandfather. Here
column10: he finds a way to maintain that personal feel while strutting down a board room table in high heels.

column1: Hadreas' sexuality is obviously a huge part of his work
column2: but he's above all a human—one who's spoken about battling addiction and sickness and sadness
column3: and one who possesses the ability to write about it in a way that feels universal. A huge part of what makes the work so strong is the generous human spirit that bleeds into it
column4: and Too Bright is the best example to date of the lengths he goes to confront his fears and demons. These songs feel less like songs and more like treasures
column5: ones that fill you with power and wisdom
column6: and as a result
column7: Too Bright seems capable of resonating with
column8: comforting
column9: and moving anyone who's ever felt alienated
column10: discriminated against
column11: or ""other-ized
column12:
regardless of sexual orientation.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21081/homepage_large.00eefcd5.jpg|This Is All Yours|30749.0|Alt-J|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Infectious']|2014-09-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:58.922425|"

Judging from Alt-J's 2012 debut An Awesome Wave
column2: here are the minimum requirements to earn the ""next Radiohead"" tag: be a British band that likes guitars and computers. And yet
column3: with few other groups seeking to fill the hungry post-The King of Limbs void
column4: it was enough to convince the Mercury Prize committee and stateside radio programmers. Even though that record's gawky
column5: akimbo singles recalled Thom Yorke’s “Lotus Flower” dance more than his actual music
column6: it’s been a decade since Yorke and his team had a song that hit the American charts with the impact of “Breezeblocks” and “Tessellate”. If you’re surprised by Alt-J's rapid ascent
column7: well
column8: they are too; their sophomore effort
column9: This Is All Yours
column10: is the Peter Principle on wax
column11: a record that's exactly what you’d expect from a band that finds itself at the top after failing upward and has no idea what their next step is.

column1: This sense of paralysis similarly afflicted their debut
column2: an album praised as “schizophrenic” and “ADD”
column3: the same misdiagnosis given to deskbound people who just happen to be bored and overstimulated. Far more muted and placid than its predecessor
column4: This Is All Yours more closely resembles passive-aggressiveness. On the otherwise cottonball-electro lead single “Hunger of the Pine”
column5: a sample from Miley Cyrus’ “4x4” grinds awkwardly against lead singer Joe Newman. The lyric “I’m a female rebel” is a particularly juicy line of clickbait
column6: as well as one that has nothing at all to do with anything Newman says on the rest of the song; French poet Alfred de Musset is also quoted
column7: but unlike Cyrus
column8: he didn’t have any choice in the matter.

column1: Those are talking points on a song that otherwise would have none
column2: but at the same time
column3: “Hunger of the Pine”’s timeliness is unintentionally an aural thinkpiece on everything grating about Internet-era music consumption—performative poptimism
column4: autoplay ads popping up in buried tabs
column5: and a tidy narrative in which the Upworthy headline writes itself: “Alt-J Sampled Miley Cyrus and What Happened Next Will Surprise You.” Conor Oberst appears somewhere within the barren “Warm Foothills”
column6: and you'll only know that if you read the credits. Oberst’s a slightly more corporeal presence on This Is All Yours than Dave Matthews (Newman‘s unctuous “hike up your skirt a little more” lyricism)
column7: Soul Coughing (the overbearing scare-quotes “quirkiness”)
column8: and every other piece of late-'90s college-alt from which Radiohead used to be a sanctuary.

column1: Mallet percussion
column2: multilingual lyrics
column3: chesty vocal huffs
column4: fumbled acoustics
column5: roundabout vocal harmonies
column6: tentative EDM dipping
column7: Asian monasticism
column8: ""Rule Britannia""
column9: American gothic: they all get sucked into the vacuum of This Is All Yours without leaving an impression. “Intro” does what it’s supposed to
column10: with a volley of vocal overlaps sliced and diced that reestablish Alt-J as more computer literate than their alt-rock peers but humane enough to escape the “electronic” tag. It takes about a minute and a half to get its point across
column11: and then it goes on for twice as long
column12: proving itself to be an introduction to another introduction; “Arrival in Nara” precedes “Nara”
column13: which itself precedes the closer “Leaving Nara” and is even more indicative of the  glassy-eyed robo-soul to come. Ten minutes pass on This Is All Yours with barely a pulse—it's possibly the most deflating post-hype re-introduction since “The Beta Band Rap”—but those guys were at least trying to chase off the squares.

column1: The facepalm rhyming arrives later on This Is All Yours; Alt-J are guys who bonded in their college dorm
column2: so naturally they’ve got their own coded sex talk. During An Awesome Wave
column3: Newman sang
column4: “In your snatch fits pleasure
column5: broom-shaped pleasure/ Deep greedy and Googling every corner""
column6: (if you don't believe this actually happened
column7: look it up)
column8: and who knows
column9: perhaps quoting “Every Other Freckle” will get somebody laid: the options for pick-up lines include
column10: “Turn you inside out and lick you like a crisp packet
column11: “I’m gonna bed you like a cat beds into a beanbag
column12: ” and of course
column13: ""I want every other freckle""
column14: the last word of which Ben Gibbard has proven twice over bears the least erotic phonetics in the English language. Later on
column15: the L-shaped block of Tetris gets namedropped
column16: and that's to say nothing of the hook
column17: “Are you a pusher/ Are you a puller?"" delivered in a barbershop harmony. Combined with the squawkbox honky blues of “Left Hand Free”
column18: “Pusher” is a fair reminder that a Mercury Prize and some incompatible ideas about folk and electronic music only means you're that much closer to becoming the next Gomez.

column1: Regardless
column2: the issue with This Is All Yours has little to do with hype or unfair standards and everything to do with the album in question being really dull and tuneless—a frustrating development for those who still believe in alt-rock as an incubator for unfashionable and undeniably great bands. This Is All Yours is
column3: however
column4: interesting as a proxy for discussion about how this band has managed to achieve a level of success that’s escaped their far craftier
column5: smarter and more accessible British peers like Bombay Bicycle Club
column6: Wild Beasts
column7: Foals—basically everyone but the 1975. To that end
column8: it’s worth noting that This Is All Yours will likely take the #1 Billboard spot in the UK recently held by New Rock Revival revivalists Royal Blood—another act who's deferential to their lofty comparisons but will happily reap the benefits of alt-rock not being dead as long as bands are willing to contort themselves into familiar shapes. “The next Radiohead” remains Alt-J’s best hook
column9: and they didn’t even come up with it.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20913/homepage_large.f27e5503.jpg|Remembrance EP|32418.0|Suicideyear|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Software']|2014-09-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:32:59.660203|"

The music released on Daniel Lopatin’s Software label is Internet native. The context for this music is the digital space—that’s where the inspiration comes from
column2: where the audience is
column3: and how the music finds people. That’s true for a whole lot of music these days
column4: of course
column5: but from the name on down Software makes it explicit. Remembrance is the first proper release by Suicideyear
column6: the project of young Baton Rouge-based producer James Prudhomme
column7: but he’s been around online for a couple of years
column8: putting out mixtapes
column9: remixes
column10: and original productions for rappers. The most widely heard of these to date is his beat for “Hurt”
column11: for Swedish teenager Yung Lean
column12: and it was a characteristic production: slow-to-midtempo
column13: the brittle
column14: rapid-fire electronic percussion fills that have come to signal “trap
column15: ” and spacey
column16: melancholic synth lines appropriate for Lean’s “sad boy” aesthetic. Whatever else you might say about it
column17: Suicideyear makes Internet music
column18: work that clearly draws from the online music world’s abundance; but Prudhomme manages to put his own spin on this cluster of signifiers
column19: finding a way to channel feelings in a distinctive way.

column1: A couple of years back
column2: Pitchfork contributor David Drake wrote a piece for Complex called ""Real Trap Sh*t? The Commodification of Southern Rap’s Drug-Fueled Subgenre"". Among other things
column3: it grappled with how ”trap music
column4: “ emerging from a place of violence and powerlessness
column5: could be transformed into something safe and fashionable through the magic of cultural tourism. ""...The trap isn’t a genre
column6: but a real place as portrayed through art
column7: he wrote. ""A place with real consequences."" I thought of this when listening to Remembrance not because I think it comes at certain styles of rap production from an irresponsible perspective (that ship has probably sailed
column8: anyway)
column9: but rather because Prudhomme takes very specific elements of this production
column10: zooms in
column11: and amplifies them until they become something else
column12: something he can call his own. The tracks on Remembrance don’t sound like they’d be improved with people spitting over them
column13: but they do connect to the emotional world of a certain kind of rap production
column14: with chords and patterns that suggest tension
column15: danger
column16: and
column17: ultimately
column18: melancholy.

column1: Which is to say that Remembrance is haunted by mortality
column2: with synth drones that sometimes sound like organs bringing to mind the darkly meditative contemplation of a wake. Suicideyear combines the clean melodic lines of late-1990s IDM with the slow-burn anxiety of Zaytoven. The emotional range here runs from the stately grandeur of “Caroline” to the yearning “Hope Building A” to the dubbed-out and lonesome “Savior”
column3: with its ghosted digital voices to the chiming “U S”
column4: which sounds like the sort of music Death Waltz would have rescued from an early-’80s horror film soundtrack. There’s plenty of silence
column5: enough for each snare clap and hi-hat flicker to carve out its own space
column6: and there’s also an appealing uniformity to the whole. Remembrance knows the kinds of feelings it wants to evoke and how to make that happen
column7: making for a record that possesses a very particular mood.

column1: It isn’t until the closing track that Prudhomme tips his hand
column2: offering up a slow and gorgeous cover of My Bloody Valentine’s “When You Sleep”. This is a risky move because MBV covers can go wrong so easily
column3: but Prudhomme finds something new in the song
column4: an iciness and feeling of isolation that move in opposition to the warmth found on the most oceanic of albums. It’s a neat trick that also encapsulates what makes Remembrance such a modest but ultimately captivating record
column5:
a way of taking sounds and textures from one context and transforming them into something that feels personal and close.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21066/homepage_large.03c6e4c2.jpg|Commune|30804.0|Goat|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-09-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:00.429176|"

""All great pop music
column2: Brian Eno once said
column3: ""is created by small groups of people misunderstanding other small groups far away."" The Swedish band Goat works from the premise that compounding those misunderstandings can make pop even better. Their faraway small groups of choice are artists who've introduced the fuzz and wah of electric instruments into traditions that developed outside Western pop: Tinariwen
column4: the Congotronics crowd
column5: Khun Narin's Electric Phin Band
column6: the heavier side of the Sublime Frequencies catalog.

column1: The ingenious part of Goat's act is that they've looped those artists' sounds back into drone-rock
column2: expanding the range of tones and rhythms that most of the bands in Spacemen 3's wake have wielded at their disposal. The less exciting part is the way that Goat have couched their open-eared virtuosity in a load of pseudo-mystical play-acting: they perform in masks that look generically ""exotic-ethnic"" but don't actually appropriate any specific cultural associations
column3: they claim to be inspired by the vodou tradition of the northern Swedish town of Korpilombolo (population 529)
column4: and their lyrics and titles are winkingly quasi-primitivist. (One tip-off is the title of Commune's ""Gathering of Ancient Tribes"": note that it's a backronym for the name of the band
column5: and then ask yourself why it would be in English.)

column1: That said
column2: some of Commune is pretty splendid. It's recorded through a thick veil of reverb
column3: which makes for an improvement on the crisper tone of their debut
column4: the 2012 LP World Music; the band's nameless singer now sounds delightfully as if she's screaming down the far end of a wind tunnel. (Goat's members still haven't revealed their identities
column5: aside from occasional spokesperson Christian Johansson
column6: although one of them did apparently convince an interviewer that his name was Björn Ulvaeus.) It's also frontloaded with two of the band's best songs to date: ""Talk to God""
column7: a hypnotic jam built around a single fluttering guitar phrase
column8: and ""Words""
column9: a singleminded acid-rock stomp whose only nod to internationalism beyond International Artists is finger cymbals.

column1: Still
column2: Goat seems to be running short on material on Commune. ""To Travel the Path Unknown"" and ""Bondye"" (named after a Haitian vodou god) are both undercooked instrumentals
column3: and a few other tracks rely on one or two little riffs that repeat until not even a pedal-hopping guitar solo can keep them afloat. The band pulls it together for the closer
column4: ""Gathering of Ancient Tribes""
column5: another Tichumaren-inspired groove that gradually piles on on layers of instrumental texture
column6: until it ends—as the album began—with the sound of a temple bell.

column1: It's easy to understand why Goat would try to frame their music as a spiritual ritual
column2: and there's a tradition of communal mysticism even among the European roots of what they're up to here (see
column3: for instance
column4: the bands that came out of the Amon Düül commune). But they've also locked themselves into an act in which they have to write and dress a certain way without ever breaking character
column5: and in which their gift for bringing together musical ideas from Mali and Lagos and Birmingham and beyond is burdened by the preposterous pretense of being an ""ancient tribe
column6:
and the notion of keeping that act up is the greatest hurdle they face.

"|19829.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19829-goat-commune/|7.3|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20847/homepage_large.20d3ed88.jpg|Slant of Light|31281.0|Mary Lattimore|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2014-09-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:01.024358|"

Unless you’re a liner notes sleuth with a propensity for a certain strain of East Coast indie rock or abstruse folk exploration
column2: the names Mary Lattimore and Jeff Zeigler may not be familiar. In the last five years
column3: the Philadelphia instrumentalists have become indispensible facilitators for other people’s music—the multi-instrumentalist Ziegler as a producer and touring sound engineer for bands like the War on Drugs
column4: Kurt Vile and the Violators
column5: and Purling Hiss
column6: the harpist Lattimore as accompanist for and improviser with a litany of rock musicians such as Thurston Moore
column7: Sharon Van Etten
column8: and Meg Baird. Their individual orbits have often overlapped
column9: too: Lattimore
column10: for instance
column11: played on Smoke Ring for My Halo
column12: the Vile album that Zeigler
column13: in part
column14: recorded. They’ve also led their own respective recording projects
column15: with Zeigler even helming the sessions for Lattimore’s <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/the-out-door/9112-sonic-omnivores/2/"" target=""_blank"">splendid 2013 solo debut
column16: The Withdrawing Room.

column1: Still
column2: Lattimore and Zeigler have built their principal reputations as members of supporting casts—necessary
column3: if not necessarily noticed—but Slant of Light represents the duo’s cautious move into their own distinct territory. Lattimore plucks
column4: scrapes
column5: and slaps her harp
column6: running its sounds through a loop station that not only repeats her patterns but occasionally gives them a prismatic kind of echo
column7: as though you’re watching a picture fade one color at the time. Zeigler routes an assortment of synthesizers
column8: guitars
column9: and melodicas through a small army of effect pedals. Inspired by their work on a live score for the 1968 French film Le Révélateur in Texas’ Marfa Ballroom
column10: Slant of Light consists of four improvisations that are surprisingly broad in focus given the duo’s limited
column11: idiosyncratic instrumentation. They shift between new age gloamings and atonal excursions
column12: phosphorescent crescendos and needlepoint delicacy. “Echo Sounder”
column13: the record’s moment of complete triumph
column14: funnels all of those approaches into one beautiful climb. Zeigler shapes an enormous
column15: swelling hum that still leaves room for Lattimore at the top; she plays patterns and pauses
column16: allowing his electronic whirrs to slip through the rests like a warm breeze. It’s light but not thin
column17: distant but not unfamiliar
column18: engrossing but not all-consuming.

column1: To that last end
column2: Slant of Light benefits from Lattimore and Zeigler’s respective pasts
column3: as their ancillary work seems to have fostered a degree of modesty in their step toward the spotlight. Slant of Light is a slight record
column4: its four tracks just breaking the 30-minute mark; each piece suggests a single statement
column5: meant to express one idea before moving on to the next one. Lattimore’s Lyon and Healy harp has 47 strings
column6: but there's never the sense that she’s trying to show you that she knows what to do with them or the pedals they power. “The White Balloon” is a duet between Lattimore’s high-floating harp melody and Zeigler’s more mid-range guitar
column7: which acts as a terrestrial tether to the bed of electric noise at the bottom of the track. For three minutes
column8: they float with one another
column9: dipping and diving through a ballet just above the din—and then they fade away
column10: adding allure through brevity rather than overstaying their welcome.

column1: Even the album's 12-minute finale
column2: “Tomorrow is a Million”
column3: feels brief. Together
column4: Lattimore and Ziegler twist through beds of soft noise
column5: with scraped and popped harp strings and splintered guitar notes clustering into alien whorls of anti-melodies. The pair’s playing is busy but not restless
column6: moving more in mutual sympathy than selfishness. By track’s end
column7: it’s hard not to wish it didn’t keep going
column8: so you could see where all these quick runs and instant redirections might go if there were no limit. Slant of Light
column9: then
column10: succeeds on the level of the best improvisations. These pieces pry the audience’s eyes off the clock without taking advantage of that surrender
column11: and perhaps that’s the valuable side effect of spending so much time learning how the music of others work—what’s too much
column12: what’s too little
column13: what’s just right. Slant of Light is a short
column14:
humble offering of the latter.   

"|19621.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19621-mary-lattimore-jeff-zeigler-slant-of-light/|7.5|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20984/homepage_large.3e27e54a.jpg|Syro|110.0|Aphex Twin|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2014-09-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:01.790586|"

It’s 2014 and there is a new Aphex Twin album
column2: which means the most conspicuous musical drought this side of My Bloody Valentine has ended. Syro
column3: unlike the Caustic Window LP released earlier this year
column4: is not a collection of material cut during Richard James’ prolific 1990s heyday and shelved. It’s a new album of new music recorded in the last few years
column5: and it’s said to be the first of more to come. Unlike MBV
column6: it’s not that James went away entirely—in 2005
column7: he released a series of Analord 12"" EPs as AFX
column8: and there were a couple of low-key EPs as the Tuss. But with many-monikered electronic musicians
column9: branding is everything: it’s not an Aphex Twin release unless it’s presented as an Aphex Twin release.

column1: Syro is an unusual album to contemplate because its overall approach is not particularly unusual. Older fans of electronic music who followed along with James’ shape-shifting in the 1990s may need to adjust their expectations slightly. On the evidence here
column2: he has no interest in re-inventing his sound. Syro has few extremes
column3: no hyper-intense splatter-breaks or satanic “Come to Daddy” vocals or rushes of noise. On the other end of the spectrum
column4: Syro doesn’t cast James in a quasi-classical light; there's no “serious composer” tracks like “4” or “Girl/Boy Song” that beg to be arranged for string quartet. And there are no “Windowlicker”-like nods to pop
column5: no attempts to smuggle some truly weird music onto the charts.

column1: Without all that
column2: what’s left? Sixty-five minutes of highly melodic
column3: superbly arranged
column4: precisely mixed
column5: texturally varied electronic music that sounds like it could have come from no other artist. James throughout the ’90s was an influence sponge; part of his genius was how he took ideas and ran them through his highly idiosyncratic filter. The bizarro highlights came when he put his own spin on genres
column6: making jungle weirder
column7: pop more unsettling
column8: and piano music more gorgeous. Syro also absorbs many different sounds
column9: from loping breakbeat to drum’n’bass to techno proper to hints of disco
column10: but in a more subtle way. It has a way of making other genres seem like they exist to serve this particular vision. And it’s a confident album precisely because it’s not self-consciously pushing the envelope. Electronic music with a strong beat not intended for the dancefloor was
column11: if not invented by this guy
column12: certainly perfected by him. So with his first trip back from the wilderness
column13: he’s demonstrating exactly how it’s done.

column1: Syro scans as “’90s” in terms of form but is quite modern in its particulars. Music sounded like this in 1996
column2: but it didn’t sound quite this good. Whether James has acquired better machines or improved the way in which he records them
column3: Syro contains some of his most tactile music; it’s a headphone record par excellence
column4: an hour-long feast for the ears. But as exquisite as all the fragments are in isolation
column5: the heart of the record is its steady sense of momentum
column6: all the more remarkable since the tempos are mostly relaxed and uniform. James has spoken of tricks he uses in sequencing to free his music from a ridged digital grid; whatever his methods
column7: his rhythmic DNA is as identifiable as John Bonham’s. There’s a playful swing to his rhythms
column8: with accents that dance on and around the beat
column9: and that unmistakable drive is the frame upon which the album is built.

column1: The album’s formal simplicity keeps the focus on the arrangements
column2: especially in the first half. The ten-and-a-half-minute “XMAS_EVET10 [120][thanaton3 mix]” glides forward like a smooth stone over polished ice
column3: allowing a new element—a sly melodic twist
column4: a stuttering shift in the beat
column5: an unusually bassy groan—to enter seamlessly in every bar. It’s complicated but never busy
column6: myriad parts cohering into a logical whole. “4 bit 9d api+e+6 [126.26]” mixes muted acid squelches with twinkly keyboard melodies
column7: with barely-there voices intoning a few layers beneath
column8: while the opening “minipops 67 [120.2][source field mix]” has wordless singing presented straight—the one new wrinkle on the album—and it’s so naked it’s disarming. The album gets a few clicks harsher in places
column9: as on “CIRCLONT6A [141.98][syrobonkus mix]”
column10: with its assertive bass grind and rubbery video game noises
column11: but it never goes too far in that direction. The care and virtuosity with which these tracks were assembled is immediately obvious
column12: but nothing feels difficult; the record’s easy flow despite it all is one of its primary virtues
column13: and there’s something new to uncover with every listen.

column1: Syro’s tremendous focus on detail marks it as a more muted release in Aphex Twin’s discography. The “What the hell was that?”
column2: once an Aphex touchstone
column3: is nowhere to be found; there’s little here in the way of brute-force appeals to the lizard brain
column4: and Syro is on balance more sophisticated and cerebral. And that silliness
column5: that bratty desire to be noticed
column6: was part of what made the Aphex Twin experience special. Some will miss it. But this record—virtuosic
column7: precise
column8: but also alive with feeling—has something else in mind. It’s telling that the most extreme moment here is also the quietest—the closing “aisatsana [102]”
column9: a painfully lovely minimalist piano piece recorded on a creaky upright with birds chirping away in the background. By that moment
column10:
the feeling of “I’m listening to a new Aphex Twin album” has fallen away and the deeper beauty of Syro starts to sink in.

"|19755.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19755-aphex-twin-syro/|8.7|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20935/homepage_large.d53d7719.jpg|Hyperdub 10.3|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2014-09-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:02.463603|"

It's illuminating to compare Hyperdub's 2009 anniversary comp
column2: 5: Five Years of Hyperdub
column3: with the staggered-release phases of their 10th anniversary series five years later. The half-decade anniversary collection depicted a tight-knit yet adventurous label that took the dubstep-informed foundation of Steven Goodman
column4: aka Kode9
column5: and built it out in every direction that the structure could feasibly hold. Five years later
column6: the label's roster and house style has expanded: 10.1 put forth a label canon that gave footwork
column7: funky
column8: and grime as much attention as the dubstep sound that put Hyperdub on the map
column9: while 10.2 made a cohesive case for UK bass music's incorporation of straight-up R&B.

column1: So it stands to reason that the third volume focuses on another facet entirely
column2: centered as it is around the ambient
column3: minimalist
column4: and experimental side that artists like Laurel Halo
column5: Inga Copeland
column6: and Dean Blunt have successfully tapped into. Yet given the artistic depth of those names and their precursors—most notably Burial
column7: the Bug
column8: and Kode9 himself—it's strange that this volume of Hyperdub's 10th anniversary series is the hardest yet to love. The label's strong history with ambient and left-field music is underrated in the context of their greater role in transforming 2-step
column9: but those experimental tendencies were always in the music
column10: sometimes subsumed but always within reach. With the songs collected here
column11: however
column12: the sum of those efforts seems a bit bewildering: oddly beautiful one moment
column13: disorienting and grating the next
column14: and usually throbbing with some queasy undercurrent of dread that makes it hard to piece together.

column1: The biggest sign that something's off is a deceptively simple fact: there are 23 tracks rolled out over the course of 74 minutes
column2: and twelve of those tracks are an intermission-length two-and-a-half minutes or less. That in itself isn't a dealbreaker when it comes to ambient music—anyone who owns Brian Eno's Music for Films can vouch for that—but this collection of wide-ranging artists
column3: featuring a number of tracks pulled from the context of pre-existing albums
column4: represents Hyperdub's leftfield side with brief and sketched-out pieces (sometimes completely uncharacteristic ones
column5: to boot) that don't go a long way to leave distinct impressions.

column1: The more familiar of those earlier tracks
column2: like Burial's ""In McDonalds"" and ""Night Bus""
column3: Darkstar's ""Ostkreuz""
column4: or Kode9 & the Spaceape's ""Hole in the Sky""
column5: might stir up fond memories. But they're jumbled up and juxtaposed with so many like-minded songs riding on truncated buildups
column6: foggy atmospherics
column7: and beatless drones that the cumulative effect is a shivering blur. It's best to take things piece by piece
column8: then
column9: before reassembling again. Among the briefer selections from earlier albums
column10: Ikonika's Aerotropolis deep cut ""Completion"" finds a new lease on life and outdoes its peers by building smartly over its abbreviated space
column11: wrapping cresting oscillations around a simple
column12: piercing three-note refrain. Cooly G deserves the entry-point nod for the yearning ""Trying""
column13: a cut that draws the more intimate side of her already tactile sound even more forward-thinking
column14: while still featuring a rich bass-ride ambience that keeps the rhythm up front even when the sparse drums drop out.

column1: But the new cuts demand the most attention
column2: especially since they reveal just how wide that ambient influence has spread throughout the label. Inga Copeland's freezer-burnt ""I Am Your Ambient Wife"" rests on the other side of the scale from Cooly G's warmth
column3: never quite resolving into shape but pulling off the sonic equivalent of simultaneously melting and crumbling. Most other tracks hit some fascinating
column4: if occasionally impenetrable
column5: points in between sparse beauty and anxious cacophony; Kevin Martin's double duty as the Bug (""Siren"") and King Midas Sound (""Blue"") reveal that his ruffneck and introspective sides share an ear for calmly drifting chords and the tendency to push bass until it's thick enough to wrap around yourself. Lee Gamble's ""DSM"" drifts through a simple wave of minimalist melody and canyon-reverbed wooden blocks
column6: a calm lull that makes its last-minute bass tremors feel like an ambush; Dean Blunt's ""Urban"" is a moody juxtaposition of a restlessly pacing synth riff and a fragile sax solo that threatens to fall apart just before emerging with the prettiest moment on the whole compilation.

column1: Aside from ""Blue""
column2: all those compositions are of a more substantial length
column3: which is a good thing; the more space the artists have to work within
column4: the better the end result
column5: even when it's the type of fare that vast majority of people who were into into the beat-focused 10.1 and song-driven 10.2 might recoil from. Not every track features quick brushes against ambient
column6: and there's a lot to work with in the album's two longest cuts: the day-glo chrome cyberpunk ascent of ""Liloos Seduction""
column7: from King Britt's 2012 12"" as Fhloston Paradigm
column8: Chasing Rainbows
column9: and Jeremy Greenspan's previously-unreleased pure wall-of-analog nightmare drone ""Gage"". Back in July

column11:
which accurately sums up the atmosphere of bloodstained elegance that turns a lavish scene gruesome.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21043/homepage_large.fc741210.jpg|Black Moon Spell|29648.0|King Tuff|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-09-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:03.038686|"

There has to be some chemical in vinyl that brings out the most embarrassing kind of rockism in people who sing about it. Obviously
column2: U2 would fall victim—you could only acquire Songs of Innocence by doing the exact opposite of crate digging
column3: and yet they put a damn LP on the cover anyway—and even a goofball like King Tuff (aka Kyle Thomas) is not immune. “Black Holes in Stereo” is the tenth song on his new album Black Moon Spell
column4: and it threatens to topple his entire garage-glam enterprise. As you might be able to tell from the title
column5: it’s a tribute to wax for people who felt “Spin the Black Circle” and “45” were a bit too wishy-washy. Imagine what it takes to out-earnest the likes of Pearl Jam and Gaslight Anthem
column6: and then see if Thomas’ lyrics do the trick: “Girls and boys come from outer space and so does music too/ I learned more workin’ at the record store than I ever did in high school.”

column1: Fortunately
column2: he’s got a sense of humor about himself that counteracts all of that
column3: and besides
column4: “Black Holes in Stereo” is actually the truth—for him
column5: classic rock is elementary
column6: glam is higher education
column7: and a masters degree is earned by trolling through the deepest recesses of garage rock obscurity. That’s the world in which King Tuff lives and thrives
column8: where airbrushed van paintings come to life and “stoner rock” still means something Spicoli or Wooderson would listen to
column9: not the slow and low likes of Sleep or Kyuss. Likewise
column10: there are no institutions of the square—and that includes school
column11: monogamous relationships
column12: jobs
column13: and standards of beauty. Black Moon Spell lives life with a foam dome and beer-colored goggles.

column1: This world may be Thomas' construction
column2: but it’s real to King Tuff
column3: and on his self-titled sophomore bow from 2012
column4: he pronounced himself as the universal rock star—songs like “Anthem”
column5: “Bad Thing”
column6: and “Keep On Movin’” were self-fulfilling prophecies
column7: assumed classics delivered with a playfulness and unabashed hookiness that his more mannered peers like Ty Segall and Thee Oh Sees lack. In a way
column8: Black Moon Spell makes King Tuff realer by continuing that narrative
column9: as it’s a post-fame record in that sense: the tales are taller
column10: the drugs are better
column11: the women wilder
column12: and there’s a conquering hero at the record's center to tell us all about it. The title track
column13: “Rainbow's Run”
column14: and “Eyes of the Muse” seem to be tributes to rock mythology itself
column15: King Tuff ascending to the level of the gods before returning to let the common man in on what gets discussed up there.

column1: If the stories are slightly different
column2: for better or worse
column3: the song remains the same. King Tuff is kind of a knucklehead
column4: but Thomas can be a clever songwriter; the slight modulation in the title track’s brown-sound riff makes its very insistent repetition warranted
column5: while “Headbanger” is a love affair between metal record collectors set to riffs that jut like Iron Maiden’s font and melted psych-rock harmonies. And though he’s more hi-fi than most in his field
column6: Black Moon Spell is still all treble and midrange in a logical way—pre-EQ’d to sound like it’s playing in a car’s cassette deck.

column1: But otherwise
column2: if Black Moon Spell doesn’t instantly recall “Bad Thing” (“Beautiful Thing”) or “Keep On Movin’” (“Black Holes in Stereo”) in either structure or melody
column3: it ends up recalling other songs on Black Moon Spell. Both narrower than King Tuff and with a longer tracklist as well
column4: Black Moon Spell scraps the surprisingly lovely midtempo “ballads"" from its predecessor
column5: which allowed a sigh of relief amidst the beer-bonging. He's too genial for the stock characterization of women on “Sick Mind” and “I Love You Ugly” to cause much alarm
column6: though “She was born with a filthy desire/ More sex
column7: more drugs
column8: she can always get higher” is meant as a compliment and thus forces the issue.  Just as disappointing is Thomas’ stock characterization of himself; halfway through his third album
column9: he sings “King Tuff is my name/ I got madness in my brain/ Pleased to meet you
column10: I’m gonna eat you/ Cause I’m batshit insane.” It's a presentation of King Tuff for the sake of King Tuff on a record that already didn’t lack for filler.

column1: On King Tuff’s prettiest song
column2: Thomas sang
column3: “ You always wanna know you’re not alone/ In the unpopular world
column4: ” a show of empathy towards the listener who hadn’t found their own personal King Tuff-style way out of being a misfit yet. He then offered some do-as-I-say and do-as-I-do advice: “I’m going deeper into the unusual world.” He's gone even deeper on Black Moon Spell
column5: but with the release of any sort of emotional tether to Kyle Thomas
column6:
he might've left the rest of us behind.
