At the peak of shoegaze in the early 1990s
column2: bands gravitated toward monosyllabic names: Lush
column3: Ride
column4: Curve. Although they're a generation removed
column5: Whirr's made no secret of their affinity for '90s shoegaze; their name certainly fits the bill
column6: and their music to date has been a love letter to fluid
column7: guitar-rich pop songs. Their 2012 debut album
column8: Pipe Dreams
column9: had more angularity and dynamism to it than 2013’s Around EP
column10: but the basic formula was the same: My Bloody Valentine circa the brain-liquefying Isn’t Anything mixed with the softer suffocation of Slowdive.

column1: Since then
column2: Whirr’s frontman
column3: singer/guitarist Nick Bassett
column4: has put some distance between him and his past—he formerly played in Deafheaven—by forming a side project with Nothing’s Dominic Palermo
column5: the dreamy darkwave outfit Death of Lovers. Bassett also began playing bass with Nothing
column6: which makes far more sense than his stint in Deafheaven
column7: since outside of a few randomly insert palm-mutes
column8: Whirr’s new album
column9: Sway
column10: doesn’t have the faintest whiff of blackened riffage to it. It does parallel Nothing’s foray into spacious melody and downcast massiveness; Bassett
column11: though
column12: is far more of a strict traditionalist
column13: as Sway demonstrates both admirably and otherwise.

column1: Where Pipe Dreams dared to slash
column2: soar
column3: and even rock
column4: Sway sits still. Moody and indrawn
column5: it’s an album that seems to be about nothing in particular; even its song titles
column6: rendered almost entirely in monosyllables like the band’s name
column7: are vague and diffident. “Dry”
column8: “Clear”
column9: “Lines”
column10: “Feel”: These are not generous words
column11: and that sense of abstraction
column12: distance
column13: and distillation is reflected in the music. “Dry”
column14: to its credit
column15: is anything but; aqueous and shimmering
column16: it’s the album’s best track
column17: an ode to the vastness of sadness that uses surges of distortion to smear its melodrama into an impressionistic apparition. Sway may tend toward monosyllables
column18: but it’s not monochrome. Bursts of light and vivid afterimages color the plodding thrum of “Clear”
column19: an immersive song that sounds like trying to swim in a sea of simple syrup. “I will…” sings Bassett under his breath before letting the line melt into the ether. The next word isn’t even discernable
column20: and it’s almost better that way.

column1: On the other hand
column2: “Mumble” is one of Sway’s less compelling passages
column3: a relatively flat and featureless hum; much of the album flows by similarly
column4: despite high points such as the title track and “Lines”
column5: both of which are textbook studies in classic shoegaze craft
column6: complete with foamy
column7: boy-girl harmonies and curlicues of sluggish feedback. But in stripping shoegaze to its essence
column8: something is lost. Above all else
column9: Sway is shoegaze music about what it’s like to like shoegaze music. Even the second-tier shoegaze groups of the early '90s wound up trying to evolve in some way
column10: whether it was Chapterhouse’s electronic-leaning Blood Music or the Boo Radleys’ Pet Sounds-indebted Giant Steps.

column1: Whirr haven’t shown a hint of that kind of adventurousness yet
column2: nor is there proof that they even want to. Granted
column3: there’s something to be said for a shoegaze band that’s stuck in the sort of pensive
column4: hypnotic stasis evoked by their music; but with so many bands right now—including Deafheaven—striving to recontextualize shoegaze for a far different time and place
column5: being trapped in the amber of the past
column6: as beautiful as that can be
column7: has its limitations. In its winning attempt to paralyze you
column8:
Sway may have paralyzed itself.

column3: and keyboard patches

column5: the Books-ish version of electro-pop

column8: chimes

column7: turning the song into a dialogue with itself. She sings other iterations of the sentiment as synth patches and guitars turn to vapor behind her—""forget this time
column8: ""get this time
column9: ""fade away this time
column10: as the song morphs slowly into a meditation on the impossibility of holding onto memories.

column1: Small
column2: pocket-change moments like this give Salt Cathedral's smooth music its few edges and wrinkles. Ronderos is in charge of the sampler
column3: while Losada supplies the tight
column4: supple guitar accompaniment: Live
column5: <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZTZQ4ugwus"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">they have a crackling energy that turns into air-conditioning
column6: slightly
column7: on record. There are moments where the mix is so agreeably anonymous it threatens to become music for empty hotel bars

column9: with its ""Can't Get You Out of My Head""-referring club pulse and ""la-la-la"" hook

column4: samples
column5: and clipped coos all swirl together

column11:
just enough.

Shellac shaved off a few layers of fat for Dude Incredible. The change suits them
column2: although it’s less a change and more a re-discovery of something they once did so well. Gone are the eight-minute-plus opening tracks
column3: gone are the leaden riffs that dragged Excellent Italian Greyhound to its knees. Instead
column4: this record is nine songs of mercilessly lean rock spat out in a half hour and change. This isn’t the sound of a group in its comfort zone
column5: despite appearances to the contrary: Shellac’s status as ATP house band may have been fun as hell as a gig—especially when given carte blanche to bring along pals like Oxbow and Mission of Burma whenever they liked—but the gig eventually grew staid
column6: similar to acts that endlessly trawl the reunion circuit
column7: especially considering that new Shellac songs don’t exactly appear very often. Still
column8: appearances can be deceptive
column9: and those ATP shows were often as bone-crunchingly brilliant
column10: disruptive
column11: and hilarious as any of their other appearances.

column1: Despite all that—this is Shellac’s first album in seven years
column2: following another seven-year gap between their prior two records—Dude Incredible sounds surprisingly vital. The songs came together in a piecemeal style
column3: from sessions at Steve Albini’s Electrical Audio studios over the past few years. There’s an overall focus to the record that belies its haphazard construction
column4: with the second half of the record even bearing a dash of conceptual thinking in its suite of “surveyor”-themed songs (a notion Albini has already batted away as “circumstantial”). Dude Incredible further demonstrates how remarkably patient this band can be; the riffing that drives the Bob Weston-fronted “Compliant” is controlled and targeted on precision
column5: with all three band members locked around a feeling of anticipation that only gets loosened in a burst of seconds-long anger at its close. It’s such an unusual structure—all build
column6: and a payoff so brief it barely exists—that it’s hard to know whether to feel shortchanged or to marvel at their restraint.

column1: Sending out confusing signals is all part of the Shellac regime and always has been
column2: but here it’s faster
column3: funnier
column4: and delivered with far more impact than on Greyhound. The riffing on “Dude Incredible” and “The People’s Microphone” is among their finest guitar work to date; the former is all meatheaded grind morphing into all-out battle charge
column5: with Albini yelling and straining over the top
column6: sounding like he’s lost in a state of total release
column7: while the latter is all twisted
column8: knotty confusion
column9: full of bursts of sublime repetition and turns you never anticipate coming around the bend. The overriding feeling is of all three members locking together so tightly because of a compulsion to be in this spot
column10: offloading a whole load of pain and anger onto the world. It’s a very male energy
column11: of course—the idea of Albini being in touch with his feminine side is amusing
column12: to say the least—but at least he can joke about it
column13: as there’s a reason his song about sexual intercourse
column14: “You Came In Me”
column15: is all over in a little over two minutes.

column1: Something that’s radically shifted on this record is in its weightiest piece
column2: which previously found form in extended works such as the opening cuts of Terraform and Greyhound. Here
column3: it’s spread out over several tracks beginning with “All the Surveyors”
column4: a song about the occupation of many of the Founding Fathers
column5: that lands somewhere between absurdity (medieval chants
column6: Albini cawing like a bird) and heads-down heft that pins you to the mat and never lets go. The bird noises even feel like a callback to one of their heaviest (and best) moments
column7: the thunderous “Wingwalker”. Another echo of the past comes in “Gary”
column8: with Albini again focussing on life in a small American city (Gary
column9: Indiana
column10: in this case) just as he did in a more brutal way on Big Black’s “Jordan
column11: Minnesota”. It’s the quietest moment on the album
column12: but the level of tension remains the same
column13: especially as Albini positively seethes through its central lyric.

column1: What’s most impressive here
column2: and what ties Shellac to their former peers who are either long gone at this point or grinding through the reunion treadmill
column3: is the level of commitment involved. Albini’s a sweaty mess
column4: Weston’s bass only gains more meat to it over the years
column5: and Todd Trainer remains a drummer whose every hit sounds like it hurts a hundred times more than the last. It’s like they took a look at what they were doing and pulled everything apart
column6: rediscovering the level of discomfort that drives them
column7: and working out why they really need to be doing this in the process. Prior records often contained a track or two that were lost somewhere between inspiration
column8: endurance tests
column9: and technical feats (“Didn't We Deserve a Look at You the Way You Really Are” from Terraform ticks all those boxes)
column10: but there’s none of that here. Instead
column11:
Shellac go straight for your throat and don't loosen their grip until the bitter end.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21063/homepage_large.91f0780c.jpg|A Place to Stand EP|31456.0|Youth Code|['Metal'
column3: the driving hearts behind Los Angeles duo Youth Code are madly in love. It all started three years ago
column4: when Ryan George—a veteran punk who cut his teeth playing with straight-edge band Carry On—met heavy metal roadie Sara Taylor at a mutual friend’s gig at a club in their native Los Angeles. As the two’s relationship blossomed
column5: they discovered a mutual adoration of aggressive music: hardcore punk
column6: speed metal
column7: and curiously
column8: minimal electronica. Early on
column9: the duo's dates consisted of long strolls-turned-jam sessions conducted in the LA backstreets
column10: searching for any scrap of metal capable of producing a beat
column11: eager to milk music from even the rustiest old machines. Their low-fi
column12: high-volume vision rapidly expanded
column13: though
column14: resulting in a crushing 2012 demo and last year's glossier (but nonetheless crushing) self-titled debut. These days
column15: Youth Code's idea of a date night resembles a political rally for the Wax Trax! crowd: against a backdrop of riot footage and snarling dogs
column16: Taylor thrashes around onstage
column17: pounding her chest with her fist and unleashing glitch-ridden screams as George plugs away at the ancient keyboards in the corner. They’re two gears operating separately
column18: and yet they share the same cog.

column1: A taster before their new LP arrives
column2: their latest set of tunes
column3: the A Place to Stand EP
column4: is comprised of four original tracks and remixes of four earlier cuts by the likes of Sanford Parker
column5: clipping.
column6: God Module
column7: and Silent Servant. The new EP boils down the grittiness of their early material and the more polished EBM of last year's Youth Code to their common denominators: namely
column8: punk
column9: tempered with an understated pop sensibility. Associations with the former genre have been reiterated by the band numerous times in interviews
column10: both with regards to their musical upbringing (“We’re these shitty punk kids making industrial
column11: ” Ryan shrugged in response to the band’s vociferous reception) and their steadfast devotion to D.I.Y. craftsmanship. But despite Taylor’s recent declaration that her band was “not going to write a fucking pop record”
column12: there’s no questioning the influence of styles well-removed from the hostile terrain Youth Code calls home.

column1: As a result
column2: these songs strike a curious paradox: they're aggressive
column3: noise-ridden
column4: angst-ridden and forlorn
column5: but the soundscapes shouldn’t put off anyone who’s heard a lick of Godflesh or tour mates Skinny Puppy. Sure
column6: Taylor's snarls on opener “Consuming Guilt” sound like her vocal cords were rubbed with steel wool
column7: and the clattering factory noise on the chorus will definitely prove aural candy for the Ministry set; but within the context of the song’s steady four-count
column8: verse-chorus-verse blueprint
column9: the song's melodic flourishes (the mournful keyboards on the chorus
column10: the dark-wavey driving hook) belie a popper construction that solders surprisingly well to Youth Code’s punk worldview. Mechanical ambience and surly new wave make for compelling bedfellows on “For I Am Cursed”
column11: with Taylor’s vocal glitches punctuating George’s piston-pumping beats at odd intervals. “To Burn Your World”
column12: meanwhile
column13: could have been a cut on the soundtrack to some hellish arcade game: the whooshing crescendoes that echo her vocals sound like some sinister power-up.

column1: Given Youth Code’s roots (along with their penchant using for propaganda footage in their stage shows)
column2: it’s unsurprising that their personal politics stretch beyond a musical context. These concerns are laid out in detail on the last new track on the EP
column3: an airing of grievances fittingly titled “A Litany (A Place to Stand)”. As the drum kit totters wildly in the background
column4: a steady stream of sixteenth-notes alternated with quick bass jabs
column5: Taylor warns of all toxic baggage that will be entrusted to the next generation: racism
column6: sexism
column7: homophobia
column8: transphobia
column9: and above all
column10: hatred. Her diction is blunt and arresting—""The time has come where we stop mandating what rights others do with their free bodies
column11: where we stop looking upon other as if they were just bags of discarded
column12: unworthy flesh”—but as the beat rages on in the background
column13: with nary a dynamic shift or noise blast in sight
column14: the track begins to sound like a soapbox postscript without a working compass. This transience overshadows A Place to Stand as well
column15: making it less a unified statement and more along of a sounding board for the musical and political concerns with which the band continues to grapple. Youth Code have handled things pretty well by themselves up to this point—and as any self-taught engineers know
column16:
sometimes the instruments of destruction just need a closer inspection.

Sorry

column18: and their itinerant comment threads. People lodged researched guesses as to Myrkur’s identity
column19: extoled her as black metal’s possible popular savior
column20: and said inordinately hateful things about her label
column21: her gender
column22: and her heritage—all
column24: without hearing very much of her fastidiously rudimentary seven-song

column1: As many have suggested
column2: Myrkur is indeed Amalie Bruun
column3: a successful Danish model who has lived and worked in America for many years and co-leads Brooklyn buzz-pop band Ex-Cops. She’s made pleasant solo singles and albums and worked for Chanel and Scorsese
column4: appeared in that Lonely Island music video alongside Michael Bolton and led Elle on a shopping tour of Brooklyn—all things omitted from the project's initial reveal. After months of conjecture
column5: Myrkur’s publicist finally confirmed the bandleader’s identity a week before the release of the EP
column6: information that went public only the day the record was issued.

column1: “I don’t think any record label prefers an artist who doesn’t want to do any press
column2: ” Bruun said in the interview that revealed her identity. “But it was my requirement or I didn’t wish to release the EP at all.” Maybe that’s right
column3: but doesn’t it seem suspect that months of careful
column4: chatter-inducing concealment ended on the targeted date—a break in the dam of discussion
column5: meant to lift the once-mysterious project into circulation again? This perfect scenario feels more like good marketing than pedestrian coincidence.

column1: But the dust-up and release plan
column2: turns out
column3: are much ado about very little
column4: at least for now. Myrkur isn’t a masterful release full of grand visions and endless intrigue; rather
column5: it’s an occasionally charged listen that is
column6: at best
column7: more confident in its promise than its purpose. Bruun’s underlying approach is a rather simple one—bait and lace primitive black metal with pretty textures featuring a multi-tracked choir of one. Opener “Ravnens Banner” unfurls dreamy harmonies
column8: stretched by echo that suggests the granite walls of a great cathedral. After a minute
column9: her flat-toned electric guitar—a manipulated sheet of sheer static—hangs atop racing drums
column10: credited to Swedish friend Rex Myrnur. The pace staggers
column11: speeds and
column12: at one point
column13: stops altogether
column14: returning for a mid-tempo climax where Bruun’s own lofty tone hangs like drapes over the livid arrangement.

column1: There’s variation
column2: of course
column3: like the placid acoustic-and-electric waltz of “Frosne” and the brief
column4: vocals-only postlude “Ulvesangen.” During the tempestuous “Må Du Brænde i Helvede
column5: ” Bruun even screams
column6: bellows
column7: and grunts
column8: imploring a sort of dark sorcery that she most often leaves to the instruments. But by and large
column9: Bruun looks for compulsion in contrast and
column10: ultimately
column11: the consolidation of these disparate elements. That’s epitomized by “Latvian Fegurð”
column12: which flips between an angelic introduction
column13: a bruising body
column14: and a noisy onslaught—moves that comingle in the song’s final minute. She even adds a bit of alt-rock melancholy (or Mellon Collie
column15: as it were) during “Dybt i Skoven.”

column1: This combination of madness and majesty in black metal is nothing new; Bruun cites Ulver as a touchstone
column2: and that’s something they’ve always done well. Bruun dutifully touts and embraces the form’s longstanding roots in and fascination with classical composers
column3: too. More recently
column4: pillow-topped acts like Wolves in the Throne Room
column5: Deafheaven
column6: and Alcest have attained relative popularity by overwhelming the listener on simultaneous fronts. The real frustration with Myrkur
column7: then
column8: is not the whiff of marketing chicanery or publicity deception; it’s that these songs offer skeletal suggestions of what’s come before them
column9: with the barest of bones doing nothing to support the spirit and vigor that gives the best of this ilk its strength. You get the sense that
column10: lifelong metal fan or not
column11: Bruun is simply trying on these ideas as a musician. She’s yet to commit to living in them. The only thing overwhelming about Bruun’s black metal is the prevailing sense of being underwhelmed.

column1: Remember
column2: though
column3: this is a debut EP in a crowded
column4: active
column5: contentious field
column6: and there are moments here that peak beyond only promise. Yes
column7: Bruun is a professional musician and model
column8: and her premature hype has been powered by a large PR campaign and record label. And no
column9: these seven songs don’t warrant the hubbub they’ve created. But moments of Myrkur move beyond narrative intrigue
column10: hinting at more than this start can deliver. Let’s hope Bruun’s sudden exposure
column11: intentional or not
column12:
won’t prevent her from pursuing them.

At no point during Ontario Gothic does it sound like an album that would be subject to outside expectations
column2: let alone hype. Foxes in Fiction’s second LP abounds with reverb-insulated synths
column3: lo-res drums
column4: Warren Hildebrand’s barely whispered vocals and little else; this is music for and by people who worry about waking up their roommates
column5: not their neighbors. But as a man once said
column6: the underground just spun around and did a 360. Hildebrand’s first Foxes In Fiction full-length
column7: the 2010 release Swung From the Branches
column8: was a charming bedroom databank of feverishly devout Atlas Sound worship with an even more endearing presentation; reeling from the death of his teenage brother
column9: Hildebrand posted a story behind every one of its 22 tracks on his MySpace page. <span>Four years later
column10: Hildebrand's Bushwick-based ""bedroom pop"" cassette label Orchid Tapes
column11: named after a Deerhunter song
column12: has likewise been lauded by the internet-savvy for its presentation—a loose stylistic affiliation of extroverts making introverted art.

column1: Ontario Gothic ditches the tape loops
column2: drones and noise collages that padded out Swung from the Branches
column3: its weight distributed amongst seven fleshy tracks. It’s a concise statement of purpose that showcases a single kind of Foxes in Fiction song: downtempo and arctic in ambience
column4: compositionally minimal
column5: and “pop” in the sense that they contain repeating melodic lines. Though they're not based on samples and loops as overtly as his Bradford Cox mash-notes of the past
column6: they might as well be.

column1: While some of Hildebrand’s fellow Orchid Tapes artists have become persons of interest
column2: Ontario Gothic taps a relative superstar in Owen Pallett
column3: who lends string arrangements. According to the credits
column4: Pallett laid tracks in London years after Hildebrand completed them in his apartment
column5: and they’re sweeping
column6: sumptuous and weirdly conservative compared to his own work
column7: but they give Hildebrand’s otherwise modest and muted music all the luxury it can bear; whenever those horsehairs well up
column8: it’s like noticing an extremely expensive belt on a guy in a T-shirt and jeans.

column1: But in shifting the focus from Hildebrand as scattered and prodigious to someone meant to be evaluated on execution
column2: Ontario Gothic exposes a guy who has a lot of interesting ideas about music
column3: but few interesting musical ideas.  In retrospect
column4: the “pop” songs on Swung from the Branches (“15 Ativan (Song for Erika)”
column5: “Memory Pools”) were notable for their ingenuity
column6: immersive atmosphere
column7: and context; within a primarily ambient record
column8: they stood out by default. At its best
column9: Ontario Gothic is dream-pop projected as a warm
column10: friendly embrace rather than as an enveloping mystery. Chords progress predictably and are grouped in predictable patterns
column11: Hildebrand’s placid melodies do maintain an underlying humane warmth
column12: reverb is a given
column13: rather than a textural tool
column14: and his dynamics are limited to a mesmeric repetition or a building by incremental overlap.

column1: If “March 2011” was dunked in guitar distortion
column2: it could pass for the droning doom-gaze from the likes of Whirr or Nothing
column3: while the relatively uptempo “Glow (v079)” could slide undetected into a more recent Kompakt Pop Ambient mix. But otherwise
column4: Ontario Gothic is truly ambient pop—for all of its homemade and “personal” presentation
column5: there’s little that distinguishes it as the work of Warren Hildebrand. His lyrics are often emotional tracework
column6: indicative of someone in touch with his feelings but often lacking poetic expression: too vague to really hit a nerve
column7: lacking the mystery to inspire further discovery. His imagery is borne of light
column8: shade
column9: water
column10: and the like—“My shadow was drowned in a sea underground” is the standard lyrical fare here. It’s not until “Altars”
column11: a group chorale/requiem with the very idiosyncratic no-fi folk act Julia Brown
column12: that Ontario Gothic actually comes to life
column13: as Orchid Tapes’ communal uplift is presented in real time
column14: recalling a washed out version of the all-hands-on-deck songs that would pop up on Saddle Creek records back when they were young
column15: wildly prolific
column16: and still hanging out together.

column1: That speaks to the appeal of Orchid Tapes in the first place
column2: a collective that stands to snag the interest of anyone invested in the concepts of “punk”
column3: “indie”
column4: “scene”
column5: and “DIY”. So the charm of Ontario Gothic is derived from one of the most thrilling and rewarding feelings one can have as an artist
column6: or simply a consumer of art—that great music can be created amongst your friends
column7: and how the resulting feeling can come across as more inherently special than anything consumed on a mass scale. Ontario Gothic is certainly part of a great story; but as a perfectly satisfying half hour of modest and common dream-pop
column8:
it's not much of a story on its own.

Under the name Drainolith
column2: former AIDS Wolf guitarist Alexander Moskos makes woozy
column3: eerie deconstructions–rock songs slowed and stretched until they become séances. His 2012 LP Fighting! was an unpredictable gem
column4: and his next effort promised more surpise
column5: as he travelled to Colorado to record with Neil Michael Hagerty and Wolf Eyes’ Nate Young. But even he probably didn’t expect those sessions to produce a second record by a spontaneous new band called Dan’l Boone
column6: consisting of himself
column7: Hagerty
column8: Young
column9: and Charles Ballas
column10: a member of Hagerty’s Howling Hex band.

column1: Bringing such large-sized musical personalities together could be a recipe for chaos
column2: and judging by Moskos’ hilariously confusing press notes
column3: the process wasn’t exactly orderly; he claims
column4: “we never knew if we working on the Drainolith record or the Boone record”. But while Dan’l Boone happily courts disarray
column5: these four outward-bound heads manage to keep everything legible. Even at its densest
column6: this is well-lit music
column7: with all the brushstrokes visible and travels mappable. At times it sounds like the musicians are passing through the room separately rather than sitting in it together
column8: but that’s often a plus: the way sounds ping-pong around each track creates a loose tension
column9: tempting you to stick around for what might happen next.

column1: Dan’l Boone opens with a sample from Wolf Eyes’ last album
column2: No Answer: Lower Floors
column3: which could be seen as a statement—but no single voice ever really takes precedence here. Hagerty’s peculiar way around a repetitive phrase gets some sway
column4: and the vocals hit an intense moan common to both Young and Moskos. The sparse
column5: sinister rumble of “Mindface” could pass for Drainolith (or Young’s minimalist solo project Regression)
column6: and the mashed-up howls of “Hostage Rock” briefly catch Wolf Eyes-like fire. But most of the time
column7: Dan’l Boone intertwines sounds without blurring them – the work of a collective rather than hierarchical group. Such creative democracy rewards repeat listens
column8: as focusing on each element reveals new patterns.

column1: Dan’l Boone also provides the simple thrill of the bracingly weird
column2: an effect enhanced by the participants’ track records in demented abstraction. It’s especially tempting—and not too tough —to hear echoes of Hagerty’s ground-tearing work in Royal Trux circa Twin Infintitves
column3: especially in the fuzzy casio-loops of “Thee Testimonye of An Maiden”. But every member injects some insanity to the proceedings
column4: slipping it under the surface like tectonic plates shifting beneath seemingly-solid ground. Part of the craziness is
column5: paradoxically
column6: methodical: Moskos claims that
column7: at one point
column8: he sang a 12-bar blues which Ballas and Young chopped into 300 pieces and randomly rearragned. Nothing here sounds as wacky as that suggests
column9: but undercurrents of randomness course throughout.

column1: Still
column2: after listening to Dan’l Boone
column3: it's understandable to be left with<span> an odd sense of calm. The band’s brand of chaos leans toward the hypnotic rather than the assaultive; all the rambling activity can free the mind from pattern-seeking
column4: letting it ride the noisy currents like a paddle-less raft. It seems like something similar happened to this quartet when they were making the album; perhaps the new surroundings and lack of expectations gave their instincts priority. Of course
column5: Moskos’ recounting could just be myth-making
column6: and perhaps everything here was carefully planned and executed
column7: but what matters is Dan’l Boone sounds spontaneous
column8:
and all the more alive because of it.

Mike Polizze’s worship of the guitar is so single-minded and unshakeable
column3: at times it approaches Neil Young’s own devotion to the instrument. His long-running project Purling Hiss—which started as a solo affair before being fleshed out into a full band—hasn’t ever particularly sounded like Young’s Crazy Horse
column4: but there’s a similar dynamic at play: one moment Polizze is pouring mud all over his lonesome folk ballads
column5: and the next he’s punching the haywire distortion into noise-jam extremes. Purling Hiss’ most recent full-length
column6: last year’s Water on Mars
column7: was produced by fellow Philadelphian Adam Granduciel of the War on Drugs
column8: and it showed a little more discipline and neatness without sacrificing any of Polizze’s prodigious
column9: religious fretwork.

column1: Purling Hiss’ new album
column2: Weirdon
column3: goes even further in that direction
column4: but not by much. It’s tighter and clearer-sounding
column5: but what really makes it stand out is its reconciliation of everything Polizze has dabbled in over the past half-decade. More precisely
column6: Purling Hiss have settled into a sharply defined middle ground: gentle strumming and blown-out heaviness still lurk in the wings
column7: but the sweet spot is punk rock'n'roll. Granted
column8: that still leaves Polizze plenty of room to maneuver
column9: and he does so with lithe agility. “Sundance Saloon Boogie” lays a silly
column10: three-note
column11: clean-toned guitar hook over a jumble of junky riffs; Polizze’s vocals are half chanted
column12: half commanded
column13: and his slop-bucket solo is torn straight from Bob Stinson’s beer-stained playbook. Things are looser on Weirdon’s other punk rippers
column14: including “Learning Slowly” and “Where’s Sweetboy”; the latter is particularly inspired
column15: sapping its energy straight from Raw Power-era Stooges filtered through the Saints’ first album.

column1: Still
column2: this is a contained
column3: controlled album. The leash is stretched to the breaking point on otherwise tranquil “Forcefield of Solitude”
column4: which bears a faint trace of Dinosaur Jr. in Polizze’s narcoleptic drawl. His lyrics don’t amount to much—a spare image here
column5: a catchy incantation there—but they're all served up with unforced melodic ease. It’s a charming approach that works best on “Airwaves”
column6: the album’s hands-down pop gem; with chicken-wire jangle and hokey walking bass propelling him
column7: Polizze kicks on the singsong in a chorus that extolls the virtues of its own ridiculous catchiness. “This is my radio!”
column8: he repeats like a mantra
column9: cramming in an anthem’s worth of joyousness in under a minute and a half. Like the Men’s recent output
column10: “Airwaves” calls to mind the ramshackle
column11: 1980s heyday of SST Records
column12: but its genial twang is more fIREHOSE than Minutemen.

column1: Weirdon doesn’t dwell long on folkier sounds
column2: but when it does
column3: it makes the most of it. ""Reptili-A-Genda"" oozes ghosts and dissonance
column4: but its psychedelic edges don’t obscure the bluesy haze at its core. For all its upbeat
column5: euphoric outpouring of guitar
column6: bass
column7: and drums
column8: the album retains the solitary
column9: cranky strangeness that made early releases like Purling Hiss and Dizzy Polizzy so entrancing. That atmosphere congeals beautifully on “Six Ways to Sunday”
column10: eight minutes of melancholy rumination and overdriven
column11: hideously lovely minor chords
column12: the kind that trawl the pit of your soul if held too long. Polizze doesn’t
column13: though; instead
column14: he submerges and surfaces
column15: a cycle of shadows and sunrise that puts the rest of the album into a similar mood-swinging context. And fittingly enough
column16: the saga-length guitar meltdown—lilting yet monolithic—that meanders throughout “Six Ways to Sunday” sounds eerily like Neil Young at his Crazy Horsiest. Weirdon doesn’t attempt to alter the course or conviction of Polizze’s faith in six strings
column17: a volume knob
column18: and the truth
column19:
but it does make it more compelling than ever.

If you're an instrumental guitar band that resides in Texas
column3: people are bound to compare you to Explosions in the Sky—even if it isn't at all accurate. Longtime San Marcos quartet This Will Destroy You have always been their own act
column4: though: they're weirder
column5: darker
column6: and noisier
column7: and on their fourth album
column8: Another Language
column9: they move further away from post-rock into something that's cut-up and quietly experimental but that maintains a strong emotional pull. This Will Destroy You don't rely on huge climaxes in each piece
column10: and Another Language is patient
column11: with many drifts and phases that make the bigger moments seem even more massive.

column1: The record follows the 2013 live document Live in Reykjavik
column2: Iceland
column3: and it features uplifting
column4: crushingly melancholic instrumentals
column5: which is expected from this band. But the dynamics are more interior than in the past
column6: and This Will Destroy You aren't afraid to explore near-silence for extended moments
column7: as waves work themselves out slowly. Songs end before they seem like they should
column8: which creates an interesting
column9: disorienting effect
column10: and each track feels like it's part of the one before and after it. Pieces shift in the middle of themselves
column11: to the point that sometimes the movements between songs feel more connected than a split in the middle of one; without the tracklist at hand
column12: it's difficult to know what's starting and what's ending.

column1: The quartet's been around since 2004
column2: and in that time
column3: they've gotten better at developing
column4: and deconstructing their own specific approach. On 2011's gorgeous Tunnel Blanket
column5: which was mixed and recorded by John Congleton (who also produced the new album)
column6: they perfected their self-described ""doomgaze"" across eight tracks that sounded like backwoods loner-rock lullabies and rabid anthems that often focused on mortality and death. Though the subject matter is less explicit
column7: you get that feeling here
column8: too. The band's label says Another Language was recorded after a ""prolonged vacuous dark period that threatened to break both the band and the members themselves."" That's fairly vague
column9: but the songs aren't: This Will Destroy You have a way of making feedback talk.

column1: A good comparison point is Russian Circles
column2: specifically the excellent 2013 album
column3: Memorial
column4: another instrumental exploration of end times. But whereas Memorial took on a metallic sound
column5: the atmosphere that This Will Destroy You create is like doom classical. The tone throughout
column6: which they maintain elegantly across tracks
column7: matches the color of the cover art: each song seems like an echo
column8: with moments from the earlier songs repeated and fleshed out
column9: or revisited as a whisper. Sometimes the band come across as a burlier Sigur Rós
column10: and when they get heavy
column11: it makes the room vibrate.

column1: Despite the sonic overlaps
column2: Another Language remains sneakily varied and difficult to pin down. There's rattling
column3: dubbed-out drums
column4: unhinged strings
column5: levigating shoegaze guitars
column6: electronic drifts and blowouts
column7: synthesizers that seem almost sentient
column8: and layers of gentle
column9: toy-box notes over woozy
column10: kitchen-sink noise. The jazz of ""Mother Opiate"" evokes Bohren & der Club of Gore
column11: and on opener ""New Topia""
column12: deep synthesizer washes and plaintive guitars build up for a minute and a half
column13: before slow-motion drums march in front of friskier noises towards a huge
column14: blissful
column15: earplug-rattling wash. ""Serpent Mound"" offers twisting
column16: churning electronics and aching guitars worthy of My Bloody Valentine and the ghosts that band's known to pack into their sprawl; ""The Puritan"" is an ambient refrain that feels like wind drifting across a burnt-out prairie
column17: and the explosive martial pace and windy space ringing inside ""War Prayer"" send chills. Some songs make me think of laying on my back in a planetarium
column18: wondering about friends who've died.

column1: The band makes unexpected dynamic pushes seem easy to pull off and easier to internalize as a listener
column2: but on first listen
column3: each comes as a surprise. This Will Destroy You don't write obvious songs and are at their best when they're being loud
column4: with guitars soaring
column5: the drums frantic but maintaining a precise
column6: plaintive mood amid the chaos. Sometimes
column7: as a new song begins
column8: the band gives off the feeling of someone picking themselves up
column9: smacking the dust off their pants
column10: and starting over again.

column1: When taking into consideration the record's longer stretches and curious excursions
column2: Another Language gives the impression that the band is
column3: in fact
column4: working out its own communication system
column5: following a logic outside of the song constructions themselves. The record ends with ""God's Teeth""
column6: and it reinscribes earlier guitar swirls that churn into a hiss of decaying electronic noise before fading to black. There's a lot in those final moments
column7: especially considering all the push and pull that comes before it. It conjures the way a room looks in the dark

column9:
finally able to sleep.

So Cow frontman Brian Kelly kicks off The Long Con mumbling half-heartedly about ""these kids today."" He ends the record with a toast to his old pal ""Barry Richardson""
column2: whose pub-as-temple theologizing makes the increasingly temperate Kelly just a little jealous. At more than one point on The Long Con
column3: Kelly starts rattling off all the jobs held by his friends and neighbors; these moments play like the tail end of one of those long
column4: winding Sunday afternoon calls home
column5: when you've run through all your personal business and—desperate for material—start catching your mom up on what your friends are up to. Whether he's whiling away an afternoon at the bar with an old Madness record in the background or idly wondering about the inner life of reclusive Queen bassist John Deacon
column6: Kelly seems to be feeling his age throughout The Long Con: he may look the part of a guy in his late twenties
column7: but he can't always seem to see himself in the role. For Kelly
column8:
The Long Con is adulthood—with all its attendant mundanity and fatigue—and he's just another mark.

Produced by Deerhoof's Greg Saunier
column9: The Long Con marks both So Cow's first time in the studio and their first LP as a trio
column10: with Kelly's (mostly) one-man show now rounded out with bassist Jonny White and drummer Peter O'Shea. Rarely is the leap from bent-over-a-Tascam lo-fi to proper studio concern made gracefully
column11: but Saunier leaves the oft-scrappy So Cow sounding brighter
column12: more nimble; they bounce between chatty Television Personalities-styled punkers
column13: nimble kiwi-pop-styled soothers
column14: and wistful pub-rockers with ease
column15: with a more than a couple twisted little turnarounds lovingly cribbed from the Deerhoof playbook. From the beginning
column16: Kelly's matched punk energy with austere
column17: to-the-point hookcraft
column18: and on The Long Con
column19: he gets to stretch out a bit: for every two-and-a-half-minute bruiser
column20: there's a sweet
column21: wistful ""Sugar Factory"" or a moody self-exam like ""Vigilanti Cura"" showing Kelly's quietly impressive range and breaking up the otherwise frenetic pace.

column1: That said
column2: at 42 minutes
column3: The Long Con would've easily stood up to a more judicious editor; take away several slight—if spirited—pop-punkers padding out the album's midsection
column4: and nobody'd be the wiser. There are a few moments when the studio seems to've gotten the best of Kelly
column5: too; the lengthy feedback blasts at the center of ""Second Last Line of the National Anthem"" and the churning stoner-rock send-off to ""I Want Out"" come across as superfluous. Lyrically
column6: Kelly pulls off ""sincere"" and ""sly"" with roughly equal success
column7:
but at several points throughout The Long Con—particularly the angst-ridden ""Turning Into You""—all the personality gets lost in a sea of stock phrases and atypically blunt emotional outbursts.

Still
column8: it's easy to forgive Kelly his indulgences
column9: however minor; this is
column10: after all
column11: the same guy who's trying to limit his intake of ""chicken and black-pepper sauce."" Throughout The Long Con's story-songs and stray thoughts
column12: Kelly keeps circling around the same idea—specifically
column13: that maybe there's something he ought to be doing besides pissing away another Sunday at the pub
column14: wondering if there's something else he ought to be doing. Should he pack it in
column15: get a job
column16:
join the rank-and-file? Or should he ring up his old pal Barry and meet him for a pint or three?

From his perch in the back bar
column17: the faintly bemused
column18: quietly hilarious
column19: easily distractible Kelly tries to figure how he grew old—as old as you feel in your late twenties
column20: anyway—without quite feeling like he grew up. There's no histrionic ""what do I stand for?""-style soul-searching on The Long Con; rather
column21: there's just Kelly—a smirk on his face
column22: a little lager on his breath

Los Angeles Police Department is a blank sign of a name

column5: the 25-year-old who records under it
column6: doesn't provide any hints as to how to read it—there is no detectable whiff of irony in his gorgeous
column7: sleepy songs. If anything

column9: recalling the brief moment
column10: three or four years ago

column12: Tennis
column13: Real Estate)—that

column1: Pollie grew up in Philadelphia but now lives and records in Los Angeles
column2: and his music has the sort of dreamy air that would entertain these sorts of idle fancies. His self-titled debut is a pleasingly rumpled yawn of California pop
column3: ambitious in arrangement and melody and narrow in scope. Most of the richly arranged and spacious songs focus on the ache of being alone or the satisfaction of it. ""I let her go and that was wrong
column4: he sings on ""She Came Through (Again)""
column5: the song title rounding out the story and letting you know that someone important to him is giving him second (or third) chances. ""It's happening again
column6: I can be so selfish/ But you're the only one I can be myself with
column7: goes the chorus to ""The Only One"".

column1: Pollie sings these pretty choruses about alone time in a quiet voice resembling Ira Kaplan's
column2: the kind of plainspoken whisper often associated with public radio announcers. He strums casually
column3: sometimes messily
column4: on an acoustic or a lightly distorted electric
column5: lending the songs on LAPD the sort of just-sitting-around energy that conjured the phrase ""bedroom pop"" into existence. You can practically shut your eyes and see the chord snaking messily around the bed sheets while he sings from a notebook.

column1: But beneath its rumpled surface
column2: Los Angeles Police Department isn't casual or tossed-off
column3: as Pollie has layered all sorts of detail into his songs
column4: which give away obsessions with painstaking craft. He's an off-handedly excellent musician who seems to be just messing around
column5: even when he's racking up triple word scores. The drafty-ceiling melancholy and watercolor sound of Grizzly Bear's Yellow House is all over LAPD
column6: and the way the song structures braid together like the wicker in an Amish rocking chair would probably impress Ed Droste and Daniel Rossen. ""Go Down"" is broken down into globular little sections
column7: one of them a toy-marching-band fugue

column9: where Pollie admits he's ""getting tired of my friends
column10: he layers himself into a stacked choir and harmonizes with himself gloriously.

column1: LAPD is less than half an hour's worth of music—it slots neatly into a morning walk
column2: and because it's murmured and low-key
column3: it's easy music to make friends with without over-scrutinizing. It's a first-cup-of-coffee album
column4: the cotton-wispy music played when people are still peeling back filters of consciousness and gathering the wherewithal to join the world again. Gloriously arranged with a late-summer-light country rock haze
column5: LAPD is big shady tree we can sit beneath
column6:
shielding us from the real world the same way Pollie's curiously anonymous band name does for him.

When evaluating the legacy of pioneering Vancouver duo Mecca Normal in 2009
column2: Beat Happening's Calvin Johnson labeled them as one of just a ""few people that just [doesn't] stop."" Three decades have now elapsed since Jean Smith and David Lester first tore through the political and aesthetic traditions of independently minded guitar-pop
column3: but Johnson's point spoke less to their sheer longevity and more to their sense of urgency with respect to the ideals that they dedicated themselves to at the band's inception in 1984. On Empathy for the Evil
column4: their first LP since 2006
column5: the band works with the same minimalist indie-pop toolbox as ever
column6: but the duo's embraced a newfound sense of melodicism
column7: too
column8: which makes Smith's politicized lyrics easier to swallow.

column1: Despite the influence that Mecca Normal's had on generations of politically conscious indie rock
column2: the sonic muck of those efforts garbled the wide-eyed messages that Smith often tried to convey. On <i>Empathy
column3: however
column4: the tough gnarls of Lester's distorted guitar pricks and Smith's hyperactive vocal workouts are tamed in favor of clarity and transparency. Production help from Kramer (known for his work with Galaxie 500
column5: Half Japanese
column6: and Low) cleans up the requisite fuzz from the band's K days
column7: presenting these songs as unvarnished and uncomplicated rather than serpentine and nervy. As a consequence
column8: Smith's lyrics pop to the foreground of the record
column9: laying bare its heavy thematic concerns.

column1: As ever
column2: Empathy finds Smith sing-speaking her way through giant blocks of text. Rather than break something like ""Naked & Ticklish"" into something that might scan as poetry
column3: she offers a short story about the Rottweilers that have interrupted her recent romantic engagements. It's the prosaic sort of lyricism that pops up in the work of literarily minded songwriters like Mark Kozelek or Craig Finn
column4: but rather than focus her gaze inward
column5: Smith's characters deal with the inequality and power imbalances that mark modern society.

column1: The closing suite of ""Maisy's Death"" and ""Odele's Bath"" deal with the specific story of a daughter learning to deal with her abusive father in the wake of her mother's death—but Smith doesn't simply paint it as a character study
column2: allowing herself a few analytical interjections. A character comes to realize that ""as a female she was interchangeable"" and another ""can't understand her brother’s urge to comply with the universal code of normal."" These heady moments come
column3: as always
column4: in the guise of guitar pop
column5: however warped and misshapen. It's the same sort of rhetoric that's underpinned their work from the very beginning
column6: but after years of striving
column7: the potent thematic work is finally able to sneak through the anxious instrumentals.

column1: More than anything
column2: Empathy for the Evil exists to underscore Johnson's point about the duo: given Smith's persistent thematic concerns
column3: the sense is that they're never going to simply pack it in
column4: but they're not content to retread old ground
column5: either. For Mecca Normal that means pushing their fractured and fractious sound into a production aesthetic more akin to the MOR guitar machine that their initial records raged against. They're still saying all the same things—but on Empathy for the Evil
column6:
they've just decided that they want to say them a little more clearly.

Jeff Tweedy makes sure he's never the best musician in the room. Ever since he learned the ropes from the more experienced Jay Farrar in Uncle Tupelo
column2: he's surrounded himself with players who are either more technically skilled or possess a distinctive style. It’s an odd strategy for an artist who is himself technically skilled and possesses a distinctive style
column3: but over the last 25 years
column4: it's proved a successful approach. In Wilco 1.0
column5: Jay Bennett helped shape the sunburnt pop of Summerteeth and the twitchy roots-noise grandeur of Yankee Hotel Foxtrot; in Wilco 2.0. it was guitarist Nels Cline and drummer Glenn Kotche stretching Tweedy’s songs into kosmische jams. This is not to downplay Tweedy’s contributions to the band he fronts—just the opposite
column6: in fact

column1: Spencer Tweedy doesn’t have the pedigree of those musicians—at least
column2: not yet. He may have played on albums by Mavis Staples
column3: White Denim
column4: and Sarah Lee Guthrie & Johnny Irion
column5: but as of this writing he can’t drink legally. Any allegations of nepotism
column6: regardless
column7: are handily dispelled on Sukierae
column8: the double album that Spencer and his dad have recorded under their shared surname. On these 20 songs
column9: the younger Tweedy emerges as the kind of musician who actively challenges his old man. His playing is rooted in jazz
column10: rock
column11: and avant-garde

column13: Pt. 1” its jittery gallop
column14: “Low Key” its low-key hustle
column15: “World Away” its classic rock rumble. Favoring what might be described as a strum—rolling across toms and kick drum in a rhythm that rocks toward and away from the beat—Spencer ensures his father’s pop melodies never sound settled or merely decorous. Instead
column16: he conveys a jumpy paranoia
column17: as though he and his dad expect to hear the worst news possible.

column1: Listen for his brief pause in the beat on “Slow Love”
column2: which Spencer punctuates with a cymbal crash. It’s a sly trick
column3: which at first seems to disrupt Jeff’s dad-folk tune—as teenagers typically do—but ultimately that small glitch in the song’s momentum commiserates with his dad’s understated rumination on love and commitment
column4: creating a fleeting moment when you can identify the security of a long-term relationship or question it. “What to call it but falling in love
column5: ” Jeff sings
column6: striking that familiar tone of laid-back melancholy. “I never needed to know what is was.” The lyrics are straightforward
column7: but the music injects some ambiguity into the song even as it underscores the father-son dynamic. The song works better when you know it’s all in the family.

column1: There are other musicians on Sukierae
column2: including Scott McCaughey on keyboards and vocalists Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig on backing vocals. But Sukierae is typically at its best when it emphasizes Jeff as the proud singer-guitarist and Spencer as the drummer—in other words
column3: when the music is stripped down to its barest essentials
column4: when it’s at its most minimalist
column5: when even the saddest tunes sound like they were a joy to create. And there are many sad tunes on Sukierae
column6: or at least many conflicted tunes pitched somewhere between celebratory and commiserative. Most of them address
column7: usually in a roundabout way
column8: Susan Tweedy’s battle with non-Hodgkin lymphoma
column9: a malignant but treatable form of cancer. The album takes her family nickname as its title
column10: and the backstory lends the music a different urgency
column11: one that belies the breeziness of songs like “Summer Noon” and “Wait for Love”. Jeff is too experienced as a lyricist to address that subject directly
column12: which would makes these songs either too obvious or simply exploitive—the emotion overpowering the music. Instead
column13: he writes around the crisis
column14: transforming the travails of love and commitment into sharp
column15: deceptively sunny hooks. “Low Key” and “I’ll Sing It” continue the subdued power-pop of Wilco’s most recent albums
column16: but the songs are distinguished by the more austere palette of drums and guitar.

column1: Of course
column2: there’s no reason it needs to be a double album. Reportedly
column3: the elder Tweedy penned 90 tunes
column4: but pared it down to a somewhat more manageable 20. But this isn’t <i>Being There
column5: whose two sides obviously commented on and complicated each other. Instead

column7: both in its aggressive breeziness and its repetition occasionally curdling into tedium. The sprawl is less generous than it is indulgent
column8: rendering the album more intimidating and less accessible than it should be. Only Jeff and Spencer can comprehend the full implications of these songs; the rest of us can grasp them only generally. Perhaps
column9: given the story behind the album
column10:
that’s exactly what they intended.

Even in Berlin
column2: techno is never quite the monolithic entity that it might seem. The formula may be dead simple—a four-to-the-floor beat plus a handful of shadows and metal shavings—but the proportions are always in flux. And as they shift
column3: so does the music's relationship to the dancefloor; so do its imaginative possibilities. Last September
column4: the British producer JR Seaton told Red Bull Music Academy
column5: ""I can probably see myself making stuff that is less to do with clubs in the future."" He had been living in Berlin for four years
column6: and while the city's techno community had drawn him to the city
column7: he was circumspect about the way that club music's strictures can hinder an artist's development. Just a year later
column8: his prediction is already coming true: after a string of EPs that established him as a clever
column9: capable techno producer—part interpreter
column10: part torchbearer—his debut album as Call Super turns sharply away from dancefloor functionality and towards headier expressions.

column1: It's still body music
column2: particularly if you turn it up loud enough that it gets ahold of your ribcage. But it's not so much party music
column3: necessarily. The first thing you may notice is the relative scarcity of four-to-the-floor kicks; there's plenty of pulse running through Suzi Ecto
column4: but it moves in fits and starts. Seaton's obvious affinity for classic electro is a factor
column5: but these aren't the textbook whipcrack rhythms of Kraftwerk and Drexciya. They're softened up and sanded down; there are few grooves here
column6: just bursts. Many of the drum sounds
column7: like the dry
column8: boxy toms of ""Okko Ink""
column9: sound like they come from a Wurlitzer on the fritz
column10: and even the most regular beats come across like metronomes buried deep in a pile of leaves. In ""Fold Again at Last""
column11: an unsteady rhythm of glassy
column12: conga-like tones is all but drowned out by metallic locust buzz.

column1: Ah yes
column2: that buzz: the whole album is alive with it. Seaton has talked about the way his creative process puts the signal chain front and center—that is
column3: his compositional style is less a matter of putting beats and notes in neat rows than generating electronic sounds and sending them careening through a series of effects. It's part alchemical reaction
column4: part Rube Goldberg contraption
column5: and one side effect of his method is the omnipresent crackle and hiss. Not all hums are created equal
column6: however
column7: and it's a sign of Seaton's careful approach to sound design that his buzz sings in a way that's very different from
column8: say
column9: the flat
column10: affectless hiss of Actress. Indeed
column11: while his gunked-up machine aesthetics relate to contemporaries like Actress
column12: Lukid
column13: and the L.I.E.S. stable of basement-rave noiseniks
column14: what distinguishes Suzi Ecto is its sparkling clarity. There are tiny chirping noises everywhere
column15: like a forest full of birds and crickets
column16: all made out of metal. Gloomy
column17: abstracted electronic music rarely sounds so insanely detailed; for all its haphazard qualities
column18: everything feels carefully
column19: even obsessively
column20: crafted.

column1: It's a wonderfully penumbral set
column2: sumptuously grayscale in a way that gives its rare bursts of color all the more impact. In ""Okko Ink""
column3: a snippet of saxophone seems to have been rolled out on waterlogged tape and tacked up in the background
column4: and in ""Sulu Sekou""
column5: there's a melancholic clarinet melody that faintly recalls Djivan Gasparyan's ""I Will Not Be Sad in This World"". It's almost incongruous
column6: this Fourth World outburst nestled among the metal shards
column7: except that it's not

column9: in turn
column10: is a testament to the breadth of Seaton's vision for techno. He's created the most evocative sound world that the genre has seen this year
column11:
and the peak-time dancefloor's loss is our gain.

After years of crafting wispy
column2: yet tempestuous ambient records
column3: the Virginia trio Labradford halted activity after 2001's fixed::context. In the intervening years
column4: the band's members have been involved with similarly groaning and lurching post-rock side projects
column5: but even guitarist Mark Nelson's notable Pan American hasn't quite filled the gap that the trio's grandiose records left behind. Now
column6: for the first time in thirteen years<i>
column7: Nelson and bassist Robert Donne are back together as Anjou. Their self-titled debut holds up to the doomy strains of their pioneering act's best work and defies direct comparison thanks to the clattering efforts of virtuoso drummer Steven Hess.

column1: Like later Labradford efforts
column2: Anjou's sonic bedrock largely consists of wavering ribbons of syrupy synth pads. But where Nelson's earlier records used distended drones in service of songs
column3: Anjou aims for something far more alien. ""Sighting""
column4: for example
column5: relies on little more than the glacial ooze of several slowly keyboard lines to craft a landscape far more foreign than even Labradford's latent Popol Vuh tendencies; it's full of slow
column6: aquatic groans that place it outside  the contemporary boundaries of what a Kranky-signed act often sounds like. Though ""Specimen Question"" is built around snowcapped synth waves that wouldn't sound out of place on a Tim Hecker record
column7: and ""Inclosed"" features the sort of jittery noise that's come to define the recent output of Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltzie. Each track appends twitchy
column8: garbled digital manipulations to the component synthesizer parts
column9: crafting a thoroughly unhinged take on the the typically soporific strains of ambient music.

column1: Hess
column2: who's previously worked with Locrian and Fennesz
column3: helps set Anjou further apart from their contemporaries. Just as the record seems content to lapse entirely into somnambulant keyboard exercises
column4: Hess's distorted percussion scurries into the mix; on ""Sighting""
column5: the glossy synth drones give way to an anxious clatter that evokes Four Tet's abstract drum programming
column6: and the distant digital gridworks of ""Backsight"" call to mind the amorphous throb that Boards of Canada often employ to terrifying effect. Despite how often his jittery concussive rattles make their way into the record
column7: each instance remains uniquely volatile and otherworldly.

column1: Throughout their careers
column2: Nelson and Donne have always been cautious of overcrowding their frigid compositions
column3: at the occasional risk of landing on the wrong side of the line between meditative and monotonous. On the whole
column4: Anjou is similarly thrifty and minimal in its instrumental and tonal choices
column5: but with the addition of Hess' floor tom fire bombs and delirious
column6: kaleidoscopic noise bursts
column7:
the new duo have given drive and purpose to their often opiated work.

For someone whose impulsive music typically focuses on ""right now
column3: Matthew Shipp has seemed pretty nostalgic as of late. Last year he released a Greatest Hits compilation
column4: and I’ve Been to Many Places also mines his past
column5: presenting solo piano versions of songs he previously performed with groups. Look closer
column6: though
column7: and it turns out both records are tied to the present. Greatest Hits encompasses recent history
column8: culling his Thirsty Ear output from 2000 on
column9: and I’ve Been to Many Places has an immediacy that eschews sentimental reflection. Pulsing and bubbling with focused drive
column10: the record focuses more on where Shipp’s mind is at the moment than where it’s been in the past.

column1: On I’ve Been to Many Places
column2: it sounds like Shipp received a shot of B-12 before recording
column3: as sifting through his past has apparently re-energized his present-day self
column4: giving him potent launching points from which to chart untrodden paths. Even when he covers well-worn classics like ""Summertime"" and ""Where Is the Love?""—standards that have been stretched to the point that there’s no elastic left—Shipp somehow unearths treasures buried in their familiar ring. In that way
column5: his playing recalls the rapid-fire tangents that guitarist Bill Orcutt ventured on his 2013 all-covers album A History of Every One.

column1: But compared to Orcutt’s penchant for off-key dissonance

column4: darts in and out of chord changes
column5: and splits notes into branches so quickly that it can prove dizzying. There’s a sense that the distance between his thought and actions is constantly approaching zero
column6: and Shipp has claimed in regards to his music that “You are directly listening to my brain waves
column7: a sentiment nicely summed in the title of ""Brain Stem Grammer"".

column1: It may sound like I’ve Been to Many Places is a frantic
column2: exhausting sprint
column3: but despite the fact that Shipp’s brain is operating in high gear throughout
column4: the album has as many moments of calm and restraint as it does clusters of machine-gun activity. On halting cuts like ""Pre-Formal"" and ""Symbolic Access""
column5: Shipp’s deliberate chords slowly separate until there’s real
column6: palpable silence between them. His reverent take on John Coltrane’s ""Naima"" seems to fade into itself
column7: so when his runs get faster and pricklier
column8: a core gentleness remains. That dual effect—the feeling of still beauty inside busy expression—permeates much of I’ve Been to Many Places
column9: but regardless of tempo
column10: Shipp's sense of thoughtfulness is constant.

column1: Crucially
column2: Shipp never allows any moment to feel arch or pretentious. That’s not easy to avoid when revisiting past work
column3: be it your own or someone else’s; the temptation exists to apply complicated techniques or conceptual frameworks as a way to transform originals
column4: but as Shipp explained recently
column5: “I’m not exactly sure what’s going through my head when I interpret these songs...There might be an agenda on my part
column6: but it gets murky where the actual conscious agenda is coming from.”

column1: As a result
column2: all the deconstructions and rebuildings on I’ve Been to Many Places are more visceral than theoretical
column3: and you don’t have to know anything about jazz modes or music theory to drown yourself in Shipp’s waves—which explains why the album’s best moment is its straightest. Shipp takes two stabs at Roberta Flack and Donny Hathaway’s '70s hit “Where Is the Love?”
column4: <span> and the first runs straight through the verses and choruses in just 90 seconds
column5: injecting them with a gallon of adrenaline. In formal terms
column6: it’s an anomaly—nowhere else does Shipp stick so tightly to his borrowed script—but as he turns momentum into emotion
column7: packing many moods into what seem like nano-seconds
column8:
Shipp perfectly captures what makes I’ve Been to Many Places so exciting to listen to.

Old World New Wave is the pivotal sophomore effort from Los Angeles trio Ides of Gemini. The project involves bassist/singer Sera Timms (known for her moving contributions to the now-defunct desert doom outfit Black Math Horseman) and established metal journalist Jason Bennett
column2: so Ides of Gemini face an amplified level of scrutiny on first approach. Their initial offerings shook black metal
column3: sludge
column4: post-rock
column5: and plenty of psychedelia out onto an atmospheric doom template
column6: and 2012’s amalgamous Constantinople silenced (or
column7: at least
column8: shushed) skeptics handily. The band has since enjoyed an impressive amount of success and have showed no signs of slowing down; the issue they face at this point is that too often they’ve come across as the Sera Show

column1: With Old World New Wave

column8: too. Drummer Kelly Johnston-Gibson’s voice floats in upon occasion to add ethereal backing whispers

column1: The dreamy nature of Ides of Gemini's music doesn’t require much technical flair

column6: but save for a few standouts
column7: these songs tend to gently fade into one another. They need something bigger to push them further—more sound
column8: more power
column9: more band.

column1: Timms’ bass nods along gently beneath Bennett’s more adventurous riffs; his guitar work may not steal the spotlight
column2: but it does take a commanding role
column3: ushering in lush tones that often
column4: intentionally or not
column5: recall the icy sensuality of Beastmilk or bombastic post-rock dynamics. There’s a fuller sense of cohesion on Old World New Wave
column6: as the fat has been trimmed and the influences reined in
column7: leaving Ides of Gemini with a firmer sense of who they are: an atmospheric heavy rock band with a powerhouse chanteuse and doomy inclinations.

column1: The band's always flirted with the occult in both aesthetic and tone

column3: more holistic aura. The ritualistic feel on ""May 22
column4: 1453"" stems both from Timms’ stentorian delivery and the lyrics themselves
column5: which circle around the lunar eclipse that some say predicted the fall of Constantinople. It’s a neat tie-in to the band’s debut
column6: and only one of the album’s many arcane historical footnotes. The rumbling ""Fermemorde"" alludes to medieval vigilantes and political murder
column7: while Timms’ dreamy croon on ""Seer of Circassia"" spills dreams of the ancient crossroads between Europe and the Far East. Ides of Gemini aren’t the kind of band that would typically sing about goats or gore
column8: but the complex
column9: often mystical lyrics are handled with care
column10: underscoring the band’s otherwordly ambitions. Nonetheless
column11: Old World New Wave hypnotizes and intrigues
column12:
but the album often leaves the listener wanting more.

You’re free to listen to Mr Twin Sister’s self-titled
column3: not-quite debut whenever
column4: wherever and however you damn please. But at the risk of assuming authorial intent
column5: the Long Island band would prefer you wait at least until the golden hour before getting started
column6: as no one here is liable to be awake before then. Mr Twin Sister is an exclusively nocturnal being
column7: though it’s not picky about time and place; it seeks quiet nights on the town
column8: wild nights in
column9: twilight
column10: starlight
column11: dusk
column12: dawn
column13: living after midnight
column14: working for the weekend. You can imagine it soundtracking runways
column15: clubs
column16: and kitchen-drinking sessions alike
column17: as Andrea Estella is surrounded by the crisp
column18: luminescent glow of disco balls
column19: streelamps
column20: fluorescents
column21: and anything but natural sunlight. <span>For 37 minutes
column22: Mr Twin Sister pay tribute to the way night allows people to discover who they are and who they want to be.

column1: Transformation and self-discovery would be primary concerns for this band: though the former Twin Sister maintained the same personnel
column2: the context around them has changed to the point where “Twin Sister” is a closed chapter. They’re one of the last remnants of a time when people still used the word “buzz band” to describe up-and-comers
column3: often applied to playful
column4: savvy
column5: photogenic acts that served as a bridge between chillwave’s deconstruction of guitar-based music and the refurbishing of indie as a pop and R&B-based idiom.

column1: Next to Cults’ “Go Outside” and Sleigh Bells’ “Crown on the Ground”
column2: Twin Sister's wonderful 2010 single “All Around and Away We Go” was the definitive song of the time
column3: and they were expected to follow suit toward the verge of modest stardom. When In Heaven dropped on Domino in late 2011
column4: it did a lot of great things
column5: but “coming on strong” wasn’t one of them—it may have been considered too wispy
column6: too twee
column7: and too weird for mass consumption. The past three years have been marked by a terrible
column8: debilitating van accident and minor successes unrelated to In Heaven: early single “Meet the Frownies” was sampled by Kendrick Lamar
column9: while Estella subbed in for Leighton Meester in the Kickstarter-funded Veronica Mars movie. Within the first five minutes
column10: Estella admits
column11: “Finding out the actual year/ Made me realize how much happier I was not knowing.”

column1: In any other year
column2: the album art for Mr Twin Sister would be likened to a demo and taken as foreshadowing of a raw
column3: plaintive reintroduction
column4: a negation of what came before. In 2014
column5: though
column6: it looks a hell of a lot like the Yeezus cover
column7: and while Mr Twin Sister is pretty much the exact opposite of that record’s harsh and uncompromising sound
column8: it is similarly fashion-forward
column9: an amplification of what preceded it and proof that “DIY” doesn’t necessarily have to mean “lo-fi.” Opener “Sensitive” takes two minutes to fade in from a gorgeous blur of whirled synths and chiming ambient sounds
column10: and once its supple
column11: seductive beat drops
column12: Mr Twin Sister blind you with their newfound taste for aggressive opulence. Throughout
column13: Mr Twin Sister is every kind of luxury—it’s more pillowy and firm than the spindly
column14: spiky dance-pop of their past
column15: crystalline on the outside and glittery on the inside
column16: a snowglobe of a Times Square celebration.

column1: Mr Twin Sister sounds flawless
column2: and the fact that they co-produced the album and put it out on their own label aligns with a lyrical streak of independence that runs throughout. A withering dismissal of aggressive men set to assured
column3: lolling pop-funk
column4: “Rude Boy” inverts the dynamic of the Rihanna song of the same name
column5: addressed most directly to narcissists and pickup artists using any public space as a sexually-charged proving grounds. But considering the band’s retreat from indie rock’s buzz-making machinery
column6: the more general barbs (""What makes you so certain that I wanna be forced to notice you?"") could be aimed at any kind of attention seeker or dude trying to blow smoke up your ass. Estella curtly sings
column7: “I’ve got all the drinks that I can handle
column8: ” a statement that takes on a more sinister connotation during “In the House of Yes”. The title is a bait and switch—it’s uplifting
column9: up-tempo and communal dance music
column10: and the narrative takes place entirely within Estella’s head. It might be a reciprocation of their loan to Kendrick
column11: fusing the uneasy cautionary tale of  “Swimming Pools (Drank)” and “Bitch
column12: Don’t Kill My Vibe”’s glorification of “me time.” Dancing alone in her room
column13: Solo cup in hand
column14: Estella jokes
column15: “Now that I’ve had two or three/ I can get a little free
column16: ” and that taste of freedom leads to four
column17: six
column18: and eventually
column19: a quick spiral to the floor. The perfect night out would actually take away everything involved with ""going out
column20: and “In the House of Yes” is an escape from the world and its surrounding problems.

column1: In spite of the disparate situations presented
column2: both “Rude Boy” and “In the House of Yes” are unified by a desire to have some time to one’s self
column3: to figure out what you really want out of life. “Out of the Dark” and “Twelve Angels” follow suit in a more confrontational and direct manner and underline the intent of Mr Twin Sister’s androgynous rename. Amidst the thick
column4: liquid groove of the former
column5: Estella observes and admires women who can naturally put on lipstick
column6: a skirt
column7: and a smile
column8: but its chorus calls into question what “the dark” actually is
column9: and whether the song is meant as a means of shedding more than social anxiety: “I am a woman/ But inside I’m a man/ And I want to be as gay as I can.”

column1: This idea is presented even more literally on “Twelve Angels”
column2: where Eric Carmona takes on the role of a bar-hopping woman in drag. Unfortunately
column3: the band actually plays things too straight
column4: utilizing the most common forms of electro dehumanization—that is
column5: pitch-shifted and doubled vocals getting tossed down into a metallic airlock. In terms of topic
column6: tone
column7: execution
column8: you name it
column9: it’s perfectionist Silent Shout homage. But the derivation makes it a strange fit into such an otherwise idiosyncratic record; immediately after
column10: the instrumental “Medford” serves as a bridge to “Crime Scene”
column11: an acoustic sunrise where the record comes to an abrupt
column12: but satisfying closure.

column1: But Mr Twin Sister doesn't play out as a narrative arc as much as it does like a lifelike
column2: disconnected series of situations. It isn’t a record about being young and love
column3: just one about being romantic in all senses of the word. Its intentions are put most bluntly on the emotional and literal centerpiece “Blush”
column4: when Estella sings
column5: “Is there even a real me/ Or am I just a series of nights?” The band evokes the most sentimental idea of city nightlife on a record full of them—a slowdance on a rooftop
column6: overlooking the skyline
column7: an intimate moment interrupted by saying something foolish and trying to define it: “Have you felt like you would always be alone?” With one line
column8: Estella amplifies the underlying worry behind every feeling of isolation
column9: joy
column10: regret
column11: and excitement that's expressed throughout Mr Twin Sister. But during the duration of “Blush”
column12: the fleeting perfection of the moment makes that a concern for another time; for now
column13: the night is young
column14:
and anything is possible.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21051/homepage_large.fcefece5.jpg|City Wrecker EP|28467.0|Moonface|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar'
