'Paper Bag']|2014-09-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:16.871431|"

Spencer Krug’s songwriting is elastic. In the past
column3: his sumptuous
column4: warbling melodrama has been able to serve as the framework for larger arrangements
column5: as in his prior outfits Wolf Parade and Swan Lake
column6: as well as the minimalism sprinkled in his sometimes-solo projects Sunset Rubdown and Moonface. Like Sunset Rubdown
column7: Moonface began as Krug alone and eventually expanded to an entire band. After Moonface’s 2012 LP With Siinai: Heartbreaking Bravery (which
column8: as advertised
column9: was made with the Finnish band Siinai)
column10: the project was scaled back for 2013’s lonesome
column11: voice-and-piano album Julia With Blue Jeans On. Krug’s follow-up to Julia is the five-song EP City Wrecker
column12: and it operates along the same compositional lines as its immediate predecessor. It was also
column13: like Julia
column14: written and recorded in his temporarily adopted home of Helsinki
column15: and it reflects that same sense of frigid displacement. Krug has the ability to stretch himself
column16: but here
column17: he’s chosen not to
column18: and it sounds like a certain stiffness has set in with regards to his songwriting.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: City Wrecker puts Krug through his paces. The most demanding of the EP’s five songs
column3: “Daughter of a Dove”
column4: is nearly 11 minutes long; the song right before it
column5: “Helsinki Winter 2013”
column6: clocks in at over eight. “Daughter” is the showpiece of the EP
column7: a marathon of cascading runs on the keys broken up by clusters of chords that attack and decay in rapid cycles. Still
column8: he plays with an audible slouch
column9: as if entire galaxies of regret rest on his shoulders: “There is a fallen tree against a perfect January snow/ And that’s as spiritual as I need to be.” Just as it seems Krug is taking the Scandinavian pagan black-metal route
column10: he adds
column11: “So when they said turn up the kick drum
column12: turn up the snare/ I turned away to see my baby put a flower in her hair.” “Daughter” is also City Wrecker’s most embroidered track; in addition to piano
column13: the song’s slow crescendo is built on a flood of crystalline synths
column14: like water swirling under the ice. “Helsinki Winter 2013” is more delicate and less bombastic
column15: a demonstration of Krug’s classical prowess in which he sings
column16: “You belong where you are found/ Overseas
column17: underground.” Coming from a Finland-residing Canadian transplant
column18: it’s a little on the nose
column19: but no less arresting because of it.

column1: “The Fog” doesn’t do much to help dispel the “cold album made in a cold place” cliché that City Wrecker evokes
column2: but Krug
column3: as always
column4: is self-aware to the point of pain. The song trembles and reverberates
column5: with synths that erupt and flutter like blossoms bursting out of a snowfall; it’s vague
column6: without dramatic chord changes or much of a vocal dynamic
column7: and as such cultivates too much of a sedative numbness. Unlike Perfume Genius’ Mike Hadreas
column8: who has struck gold in the past with the same implements used on City Wrecker
column9: Krug doesn’t insert enough tonal distance between his instrument and his voice
column10: which is evident on “Running in Place With Everyone”. The tune resembles a finger exercise mashed up with monotone poetry; it’s pretty
column11: but when Krug coos the song’s title in the chorus
column12: his energy level sounds less kinetic than it does spent.

column1: “The city fell into a sort of boring ruin
column2: ” Krug confesses on City Wrecker’s title track. He’s singing about Montreal
column3: his longtime home
column4: and the lassitude of guilt and longing practically leaks from his lungs. It’s an anthem for burned bridges and scorched earth
column5: as well as the warmest
column6: most flesh-and-blood moment of the EP. His melody is limited
column7: but it makes the most of its cramped
column8: claustrophobic clutch of notes. Where Julia filled almost every available space with either emotional fullness or palpable absence
column9: City Wrecker feels pinched and constrained; the former was a drain to listen to in the best possible way
column10:
while this new one only occasionally breaks the skin.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21047/homepage_large.cfab1949.jpg|Royal Blood|32495.0|Royal Blood|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-09-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:17.465602|"

In the year 2014
column2: the only thing more tired and predictable than mainstream rock is the perpetual reports of its demise. But then
column3: the gatekeepers of tradition need us to believe rock is dying in order to keep selling us a new resurrection narrative
column4: like any consumer product in the mature phase of its life cycle and in need of a good marketing hook. But the audience for rock music never disappeared
column5: it merely pluralized. Classic-rock radio may still play Black Sabbath alongside the Eagles and the Police
column6: but the modern-day descendants of those bands are now funneled through discrete radio formats that serve different demographics. When you consider the combined festival-filling fanbases for metal
column7: indie
column8: and new country (and whatever derisive invented subgenre you’d apply to bands like Magic!)
column9: there’s still a healthy demand for songs played on plugged-in guitars and backed by bass
column10: drums
column11: and (budget permitting) pyro. Rock may no longer be the center of popular culture
column12: but it still occupies vast amounts of space around it. When purists lament its supposed death
column13: what they’re really lamenting is not so much the disappearance of guitar-strapping bands as a dearth of ones we can all believe in.

column1: Still
column2: this circumstance has never stopped the British music press from making a weekly sport of anointing new saviors for the country to rally around. And with Royal Blood
column3: they've hit the jackpot: the Brighton bass-and-drums duo have swiftly become the most universally deified emergent UK rock band since the Arctic Monkeys first thawed out a decade ago. (Perhaps not coincidentally
column4: Royal Blood share management with the Monkeys
column5: whose drummer Matt Helders famously endorsed the then-unknown band through a t-shirt shout-out at Glastonbury last year.) Royal Blood’s self-titled album debuted at No. 1 in the UK last month and was nominated for the Mercury Prize shortly thereafter; now that they’re already duking it out on the top of the charts with the likes of Sam Smith and Ed Sheeran a mere year after their formation
column6: Royal Blood are
column7: for many young Britons
column8: not just The Only Band That Matters
column9: but The Only Band
column10: period.

column1: It’s not as if Royal Blood have been actively advertising their messianic qualities; if anything
column2: they’ve been quick to defuse any such hyperbole. And yet
column3: a little self-aggrandizing swagger would go a long way in making Royal Blood seem like they have any aspirations beyond just cranking out proficient assembly-line riffage as if they’re playing a live-action reenactment of Rock Band. Though Royal Blood confine themselves to a limited instrumental palette
column4: the issue here isn’t so much a uniformity of sound: frontman Mike Kerr feeds his brawny basslines through a NASA-worthy dashboard of effects pedals that can make it sound alternately like he’s shredding on an SG or coaxing alien frequencies out of a Korg. And no doubt
column5: Kerr and stickman Ben Thatcher can lock into a crushing
column6: contorted groove with a telepathic sense of connectivity (like with the epileptic lurch of lead single “Out of the Black”)
column7: as if drop-and-dragging their favorite bits from the Led Zeppelin
column8: Jack White
column9: and Queens of the Stone Age discographies into a GarageBand file to build the ultimate indestructible riff. It’s the pro-forma songwriting that transpires between those brontosaurus blasts that ultimately proves problematic. By using their muscular might to prop up otherwise featherweight tunes
column10: Royal Blood have effectively built themselves a castle and furnished it with IKEA.

column1: Kerr has been particularly vocal about his reverence for Josh Homme
column2: and it’s as much for his singing as his fretwork; as he told Clash magazine earlier this year
column3: “Queens of the Stone Age’s Songs for the Deaf was a massive album for me. That album’s so melodic and so huge
column4: without any screaming.” Accordingly
column5: Kerr’s smooth
column6: steady voice serves as a cool counterpoint to the rockocalypse erupting around him
column7: but unlike Homme’s arch
column8: playfully effeminate delivery
column9: it’s less a subversive device than a subservient one
column10: unable to elevate songs like ""Careless"" and ""Ten Tonne Skeleton"" beyond their humourless
column11: all-too-familiar expressions of blue-balled frustration.

column1: The best a young band working with such a well-worn template can hope for is to imprint their own peculiar personality upon it—see: the White Stripes’ theatrical vamping or Alex Turner’s keen
column2: colloquial
column3: observational wit. There are promising flashes of that sort of attitude here: “Figure It Out” and “Loose Change”—not coincidentally the two songs that bust out of the band’s usual slow-motion boogie and accelerate into feverish finales—find Kerr exhibiting a more flamboyant
column4: cocksure pose he should parade more often. But Royal Blood have a long way to go before cultivating a mythos of their own
column5: outfitting mid-tempo chugs like “You Can Be So Cruel” and “Little Monster” with generic girl-done-me-wrong/girl-do-me-right lyrics that readily conform to the thematic expectations of blooze-rock rather than make any attempt to redefine them. That such an unassuming
column6: workmanlike outfit has been so immediately lionized is ultimately less a measure of Royal Blood’s exceptionalism than rock'n'roll’s overblown inferiority complex: If this is all it takes to save rock
column7:
then it really couldn’t have been hurting that much to begin with. 

"|19814.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19814-royal-blood/|5.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21036/homepage_large.cc584d9c.jpg|Vibe 2|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Future Times']|2014-09-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 16:33:17.996490|"

It’s fitting that the sleeve art for the compilation Vibe 2 featured a thumb moving left-to-right in relationship to a distant object. Diagramming parallax is the effect whereby the apparent position or direction of an object differs when viewed from slightly different vantage points. This recently reissued 2x12” set
column2: which showed up briefly in late 2011 before dropping out of sight for the last three years
column3: now pops back into view after some time has passed
column4: and we hear it from a different perspective.

column1: When Vibe 2 was originally released on the Washington
column2: D.C. dance imprint Future Times
column3: it acted as handy overview of what was happening in the DIY U.S. dance music underground at the moment (if Willie Burns or Terrekke had made an appearance
column4: it would have been near complete)
column5: while also showing the label’s wide and eclectic reach. The label’s sound and aesthetic
column6: as displayed by its primary acts Protect-U and Beautiful Swimmers (one-half of which is producer Maxmillion Dunbar)
column7: is tricky to definitively nail down. There are traces of Chicago acid and Detroit house
column8: New Age wind chimes
column9: the disco-not-disco of Arthur Russell
column10: early '80s African synths
column11: cosmic jazz and jazzercise
column12: jheri-curled modern soul
column13: Funky Nassau’s pliant and plasticine grooves
column14: and more
column15: all of it in a delightful jumble.

column1: Across a succinct nine tracks that never wear out their welcome
column2: the set does disco edits
column3: deep house
column4: gravity-free synthscapes
column5: and acid gurgles to pleasing effect. Vibe 2 also features four contributions from future L.I.E.S. artists back when the imprint had but three releases to its name
column6: a contribution from the prolific Juju & Jordash when the duo were just hitting their stride
column7: as well as some excellent up-and-coming producers operating out of Paris and Berlin. It’s definitely the only time you’ll read in a review that music from L.I.E.S. label boss Ron Morelli is “funky” and “soulful
column8: ” as is the case on the lead-off track “Comeback Dust”. Featuring coos and a sampled plea of “please!” as a house beat echoes all around it
column9: the track is an outlier in that Morelli’s tastemaking (as well as his own solo work) have favored industrial noise and grit ever since.

column1: Then L.A.-based beatdigger turned NYC transplant Tom Noble follows that up with sharp and boxy drum machines
column2: spindly funk guitar
column3: and the woozy boogie keyboards of “Malaco”. With his most recent disco gospel single “Holding On” making its way into Theo Parrish’s crates
column4: it shows that Noble’s ear for a vintage yet modern groove was in place from the start. Frenchman Alexis Le-Tan takes an obscure French synth-pop confection replete with “Tour de France”-era Kraftwerk huffing-and-puffing and twists its synths into a delirious and highly dramatic cosmic-disco track.

column1: While Steve Summers does more subtle and drifting minimal techno today on his Confused House imprint
column2: here he delivers a Mr. Fingers-like cut called “Uncollected Grooves”. And fellow L.I.E.S. alum Steve Moore delivers a slowly unfurling analog synth epic “Volatile Memory” that straddles beatific Balearic and unsettling horror soundtrack
column3: never quite settling on one or the other. A nimble yet funky track from Hunee reminds me that while he’s remained busy as a DJ
column4: little has been heard from the producer since 2011. To put a bow on this comp
column5: the Future Times crew end things on the disco tip
column6: screwing down and dubbing out an old Joe Simon disco track until he sounds a little bit sleazier
column7:
purring “I feel sexy” and continuing to emanate such a vibe.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20846/homepage_large.218870b6.jpg|The Tyranny of Will|32388.0|Iron Reagan|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-09-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:18.622473|"

A decade after his death (two since he left office)
column2: former president Ronald Reagan continues to be a subject of many a musical effigy
column3: but it's been a while since the hardcore community had him as its muse. Enter Iron Reagan
column4: a Richmond band composed of members from notable crossover thrash groups like Municipal Waste and Darkest Hour
column5: who are the jellybean cowboy's latest invokers. While their sound places them as political punk in the vein of Wasted Youth or the Crucifucks
column6: Iron Reagan's lyrical tendencies skew nihilstic and violent with a dash of odd humor. Where Black Flag once instructed the crowd to “Rise Above”
column7: Iron Reagan proudly declare
column8: ""I Ripped That Testament a New Asshole”. It’s a shock-driven approach
column9: sure
column10: but when it comes to expressing displeasure with the status quo
column11: have punks ever bothered to clean up nicely and say “please”?

column1: The quintet's latest
column2: The Tyranny of Will
column3: is a thirty-two minute blitzkrieg that surges forth like the blood spurting from the politician's neck on the album cover. Iron Reagan stick to what they know best: firing off short
column4: potent riffs at a workmanlike pace
column5: and letting the listener sort out the mess for themselves. In interviews
column6: frontman Tony Foresta hasn’t tried to hide the fact that he and the rest of the guys are
column7: largely
column8: winging it: “We suffer from A.D.D. pretty hard—almost everyone in the band
column9: ” he revealed recently to one reporter with a laugh
column10: “so we make music that comes across faster
column11: and more to the point.""

column1: In other words
column2: they’ve got the punk mindset already hard-wired
column3: and so it naturally follows that nine of the album’s songs blow by in under a minute. On the album's most immediate cut
column4: “Eyeball Gore”
column5: power chords stamp and stomp as the band make their impassionately sadistic demands: “All we want is eyeball gore RIGHT NOW!” Think of the song as the album's elevator pitch: the violent fervor of protest music used to incite social change and knife parties. Of course
column6: there are jabs at the cops and the one-percenters (see the hilarious “U Lock the Bike Cop”
column7: in which Foresta warns a policeman that his fixie’s going to get jacked). Most of the time
column8: however
column9: Iron Reagan simply release their furor with no target in particular. “Broken Bottles”
column10: a twisted take on Adolescents-style skate punk
column11: captures the sentiment of that band’s essential cut “Bloodstains” and leaves it to simmer
column12: resulting in a chugging frenzy topped off with a tottering solo. Sometimes
column13: they can’t seem to tell exactly who or what they’re mad at; “Your Kid’s an Asshole”
column14: short and pointless
column15: might as well be the musical equivalent of a typo-laden insult from an email exchange between two soccer moms.

column1: A significant portion of The Tyranny of Will was written while Iron Reagan toured with GWAR
column2: not too long before Dave Brockie (aka Oderus Ungurus) passed. According to the band
column3: the late frontman lent Iron Reagan some inspiration
column4: going as far to contribute gory gross-out ideas for the album
column5: and listening to The Tyranny of Will
column6: a number of similarities emerge between the two entities. Foresta’s podium-side barking bears kinship to Brockie’s theatrical delivery
column7: and while the former has yet to perform in blood-soaked costumes exposing prosthetic genitalia
column8: he plays a comedic villain with aplomb. “I’d rather just set fire/ Than be left to die
column9: ” he threatens on “Miserable Failure”
column10: his energy essential in keeping the group's bare-bones
column11: repetitive fretwork fresh.

column1: For diehard thrash heads who possess patience and a sick sense of humor
column2: The Tyranny of Will should prove satisfying; most listeners
column3: though
column4: will probably find the record's attention-challenged songwriting grating by the fifteen-minute mark
column5: and as the album plays on
column6: the pummeling punchlines don’t hit as hard as they're intended to. As is the case with most overstuffed hardcore albums
column7: The Tyranny of Will lends itself well to a cherry-picking approach; keep some riffs and ideas
column8: and toss the ones that don’t stick. Essentially
column9:
it's ample license to take part in some musical mudslinging—and The Man could always stand to take a good mud-and-blood pie to the face. 

"|19620.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19620-iron-reagan-the-tyranny-of-will/|6.2|Zoe Camp

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21010/homepage_large.d138c563.jpg|Ryan Adams|18.0|Ryan Adams|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pax-Am']|2014-09-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:19.178530|"

There are two versions of Ryan Adams out there in the world jostling for your attention. There’s the singer/songwriter who plays it straight and
column2: on some level
column3: tries to appeal to a mainstream audience that still buys records—that’s the Ryan Adams who duets with Sheryl Crow and records albums like Gold and Easy Tiger

column3: stuck with bubblegum to the back of Negative Approach’s Tied Down. The playing is fast and furious
column4: the tone predictably nostalgic
column5: as Adams indulges his taste for musical extremes. Yet

column8: barely holding together

column1: If that seat-of-his-pants release reveals Adams the punk as a serious artist
column2: then this carefully planned self-titled album undercuts any self-seriousness he might possess as a singer/songwriter. On the cover of Ryan Adams
column3: he looks perfectly stoned or possibly lobotomized
column4: his hair exploding in the kind of bedhead bouffant that requires a lot of time and product. Even the title is delivered with a wink. Is that font Bryan Adams Serif Bold? Adams is too much of a rock nerd for that to be an accident
column5: so it’s possible he’s trolling with a deliberately “bad” album cover for an album of well-crafted and well-behaved tunes released on Norah Jones’ label.

column1: If the packaging is suspicious
column2: the music itself offers a nice twist on the singer/songwriter mode. This time around
column3: he’s less interested in the blah folk rock of the 2011 LP Ashes & Fire. In fact
column4: with its murky production and throwback guitar sound
column5: Ryan Adams sounds like it could have been recorded at any time between 1979 and 1987. There are period-specific nods to deep-cut Bryan Adams
column6: Kenny Loggins
column7: even Robbie Nevil and Richard fucking Marx. “Stay With Me” could be a synth-era Tom Petty tune
column8: its snappy guitar theme recalling the Heartbreakers’ jangly dynamic
column9: and “I Just Might” rustles up a rough guitar lick to conjure the Springsteen of ""Brilliant Disguise"". “Don’t wanna loose control
column10: baby

column1: There aren’t your obvious touchstones

column3: Adams gets the sound just right without being too obvious about it
column4: but some of these songs—specifically “Shadows” and “Let Go”—sound like they were written to fit this particular triangulation of influences. As a result
column5: the rock-historical allusion rather than the music becomes an end in itself. On the other hand
column6: Ryan Adams is a persuasively dark album
column7: one defined by themes of struggle
column8: instability
column9: isolation
column10: and regret. He sings like a man who knows something bad is going to interrupt each song. Adams may spend most of “Am I Safe” telling us that he’s having thoughts instead of telling us what those thoughts actually are
column11: but that clipped acoustic strum conveys a potently jittery paranoia that says a lot more than the lyrics. On “Tired of Giving Up”
column12: he admits that he’s “tired of giving up” and “tired of fighting

column9: build from the ground up

but “My Wrecking Ball” plays like a deeply personal expression of creative paralysis and renewal.

When interviewed about the process behind This Is My Hand
column3: Shara Worden’s fourth LP under the My Brightest Diamond moniker
column4: the operatically-trained singer mentioned writing with a vivid image in mind: an “imaginary tribe of people
column5: gathering around a fire
column6: making music together
column7: telling stories
column8: hearing from the shaman.” The energy of community has fed some of Worden’s best work in the past decade. Beginning with the supporting musicians that helped foster her experimental cabaret pop as AwRY in the early aughts and expanding outward to yMusic’s effervescent chamber music orchestrations on MBD’s last full-length
column9: 2011’s All Things Will Unwind
column10: a sense of collaboration has become as essential to the My Brightest Diamond project as Worden's inimitably acrobatic voice. It’s fitting
column11: then
column12: that Worden has turned that mentality into methodology for follow-up This Is My Hand. Self-produced by Worden with support from keyboardist Zac Rae
column13: This Is My Hand is an often successful exercise in percussive
column14: jagged art-pop that explores themes of self-acceptance
column15: sensuality
column16: and community.

column1: In a frustrating bit of organization
column2: This Is My Hand’s most memorable moments are front loaded in its opening five songs. Lead single ""Pressure""
column3: which begins with a galvanizing drumline from the Detroit Party Marching Band before stacking Worden's soaring vocals against a rhythmic horn section
column4: is unique and oddly beautiful. ""Lover Killer"" employs handclaps and howls for a deceptively joyous meditation on our capacity for both affection and violence
column5: while ""I Am Not the Bad Guy"" evokes an industrial version of St. Vincent with its lurching swagger and pointed
column6: imagistic lyrics (“I’m hungry
column7: I won’t lie/ The cage
column8: the bird
column9: the open sky”). The bracing title track
column10: however
column11: is the true standout
column12: as well as one of Worden’s finest moments. Through powerful repetition of the title’s opening phrase (“This is my…”) with distinct variations on body parts
column13: ideas
column14: and emotions (“fist
column15: ” “voice
column16: ” “heart
column17: ” “hate”
column18: “sex
column19: ” etc.)
column20: the song elegantly unifies into an impassioned and inclusive rally call.

column1: Where the beginning of This Is My Hand presents an invigorating progression of Worden’s sonic palette
column2: the album winds down with a string of slower
column3: ethereal oddities that blunt the concentrated pandemonium of its earlier tracks. ""So Easy"" and ""Resonance"" suffer a similar fate that much of All Things Will Unwind did in that they come and go with little to distinguish themselves
column4: especially heard following the flourishing
column5: self-assured bluster of the opening section. Still
column6: despite uneven pacing
column7: This Is My Hand works on a visceral level
column8: conjuring Worden’s intended image of tribal
column9: fireside collaboration through a rich diversity of texture
column10: detail
column11:
and tone.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20938/homepage_large.ada0cff7.jpg|Punish
column3: and we're all curious to hear how
column4: when given the opportunity
column5: our natural ability to create noise might sound as it rings in our ears. Often this innate form of expression can materialize into learning an instrument or honing a vocal skill
column6: but not so for Sebastian Gainsborough. The Bristol native's Vessel project remains fixated on the possibilities of making and arranging his own noise
column7: using the forms of dub and techno like a means to his esoteric ends instead of the impetus itself.

column1: Released in 2012 through the increasingly experimental Tri Angle label
column2: Gainsborough's debut album was conspicuously titled Order of Noise. But referring to him as a ""noise artist"" or calling his music ""noise-techno"" wouldn't be entirely accurate
column3: even if he does paint with many of the same grim colors. Order of Noise was more gauzy and mystical as it took on the producer's hometown sounds
column4: as trip-hop
column5: dubstep
column6: and industrial were dissected and used as decorative references in its treacherous
column7: fog-choked landscape. Ultimately
column8: this worked best when Gainsborough was simply showing off his handiwork in well-crafted environments; any notion of moving through the space felt faint and illusory. For his second Tri Angle LP
column9: Gainsborough's made another noise-specific techno record beholden to his remarkably generative skills with sound manipulation. His reliance on homespun methods of fabricating instruments gives Punish
column10: Honey a distinctively raw and tactile identity.

column1: The 2013 EP Misery Is a Communicable Disease provides a better entry point to Punish
column2: Honey than the cabalistic Order of Noise. The first full-blown iteration of stark
column3: mechanically inclined techno that Gainsborough put to his name
column4: the EP's three tracks accosted the listener with an unforgiving clamor
column5: entirely unexpected from the Bristolian at the time. Punish
column6: Honey comes across like that
column7: too
column8: and in much the same way. Gainsborough's source materials sound crude and primitive
column9: like the din of reverb around each knotty crack of percussion is drawn from the cold
column10: dry cave dwelling it was recorded in. He distills those prehistoric qualities into a fuel for the stone-grinding engine inside each incessant bassline and crushing stomp of a kick drum. Occasionally
column11: Gainsborough takes a break from the machinery and tosses a few handfuls of granite dust into the air so we can watch it sparkle. Punish
column12: Honey may not be the most hospitable of environments
column13: but there's always a fascinating display working in its shadows.

column1: The album is best taken as a document of unparalleled noise creation
column2: an inconceivable world made from the everyday objects around us; Gainsborough has outdone himself here in terms of mastering this predominate craft. In this context
column3: however
column4: noise isn't everything
column5: and structural refinement doesn't seem to be a priority for Gainsborough. Most of Punish
column6: Honey pushes a sense of melody that—whether due to the instruments making the sounds
column7: or the outsider mentality of the producer himself—is inherently off. The nauseous moans of ""Red Sex"" and ""Euoi""'s whiny racket become less palatable with each turn on the carousel that makes up Gainsborough's debased techno. This infatuation with musical ""wrong""-ness is a defining characteristic across the nine-track LP
column8: so it's unfortunate that necessary counterbalances (compelling arrangement
column9: emotional arc
column10: memorable hooks) aren't consistently utilized.

column1: Perhaps such criticisms are of no concern to Gainsborough
column2: though
column3: because his approach does work staggeringly well when each disheveled factor is in alignment. ""Drowned in Water and Light"" recalls the full-moon majesty that made Order of Noise so alluring
column4: rendering that haunted splendor aside lumbering rhythms and seismic heaves. The centerpiece of <i>Punish
column5: Honey
column6: ""Anima""
column7: sets a Suicide-sourced synth pattern against swarms of ghostly detritus
column8: rolling drums
column9: and omnipresent organ chords
column10: a claustrophobic production that works because you feel it shift and expand while it churns. ""Kin to Coal"" operates on similar gears
column11: but is fashioned in a lean
column12: sinewy way with jackhammers and hacksaws. Unquestionably
column13:
Gainsborough's sonic ingenuity continues to be his greatest asset; his growth as an artist hinges on accepting that others can't always enjoy his noise as much as he does.

There’s a particular kind of freedom many Japanese rock musicians enjoy
column3: a weird side-benefit of inheriting Elvis from post-WWII American GI radio and never much worrying about fealty to blues or folk traditions. It’s a freedom from the burdens of authenticity
column4: in other words
column5: that makes an artist like Shintaro Sakamoto possible. The raunchy psych-rock Sakamoto played with his band Yura Yura Teikoku was
column6: through its origins in San Francisco and London and Detroit
column7: a authentic product of psychedelic and narcotic influence. Yet as Julian Cope explains in his study of Japanese psychedelia Japrocksampler
column8: the Japanese heads who built upon and translated the post-Nuggets era into their own language
column9: laying the groundwork for Sakamoto himself
column10: most often eschewed drugs completely
column11: opting for other avenues through which to get to the same dizzying musical highs.

column1: As a solo artist
column2: Sakamoto is so unconcerned with authenticity to a musical tradition that on record
column3: he quite nearly disappears completely. On the 2012 LP <i>How to Live With a Phantom
column4: he mastered an ersatz lounge-pop that skewed as much portmortem as postmodern. The lightest
column5: oft-cheesiest products of Western '50s and '60s pop—from the Free Design to French yé-yé and Martin Denny’s “exotica” soundscapes—have long appealed to Japanese record nerds for whom “soul” is often a very foreign concept
column6: and Sakamoto is no exception. On his second solo album <i>Let’s Dance Raw
column7: he doubles down on his love for such sounds
column8: assembling them into a whole that suggests as much the heady late '90s as the go-go '60s.

column1: A slight shift from Phantom’s chippy disco guitar licks and smoky organs
column2: Raw finds Sakamoto immersing himself in Hawaiian steel guitar
column3: Brazilian cuica
column4: and banjo—an instrument which
column5: he suggests on “You Can Be a Robot
column6: Too”
column7: can be plucked and looped in a way that sounds like thousands of tiny gears operating in perfect concert. If there's any recognizable Western spirit animals for Raw (other than “Sleep Walk”)
column8: it's Beck—the heavy-lidded proto-serious iteration
column9: that is
column10: from 1998’s Mutations—and indie-pop gadabout and arranger-for-hire Sean O’Hagan with the High Llamas
column11: whose '90s LPs Santa Barbara and Hawaii absorbed the Americana ambitions of Van Dyke Parks and ironed out the quirks
column12: creating a heavily-stamped
column13: pristine musical passport. Like Beck’s “Tropicalia”
column14: Raw is a perfectly executed version of what Westerners might call global kitsch: a series of evocative tourist postcards showing sunny scenes from Rio and Honolulu.

column1: What makes Sakamoto unique
column2: though
column3: is not simply his knack for turning the exotic West into a glimmering watercolor
column4: or his capacity to craft a simple groove redolent of Steely Dan’s gaudy disco swan song Gaucho—though “Like an Obligation” more than qualifies—but doing so with the kind of fashionable indifference mastered by predecessors like Beck
column5: Grace Jones
column6: and the dazed
column7: obsessive Yokohama teenagers wandering through Memphis in Mystery Train. Yes
column8: Sakamoto digs into countercultural sociology on “Obligation” and “Birth of the Super Cult”
column9: two blunted treatises against the staid social structures that still dog much of Japanese society. But before we call him a prophet
column10: let’s keep in mind his alternative: sliding “a small chip between your eyebrows” and becoming a robot. <span>Sakamoto has an odd way of working
column11: sure
column12: but it's also liberating: when you disregard authenticity as your compass
column13:
it’s amazing how far you can travel.

“In the event of my disappearance/ Please don’t make me demand my fear
column2: ” mumbles Hamish Kilgour on “Hullabaloo”
column3: the longest and weirdest track on All of It and Nothing. It's the official solo debut of the co-founder of the legendary indie-rock band the Clean; the group’s other main member
column4: Hamish’s brother David Kilgour
column5: has long been polishing his popcraft on his own
column6: most recently on End Times Undone. But it’s taken Hamish this long—a third of a century after the Clean’s first records—to get around to making his presence definitively felt as a solo artist. And here he is

column8: of course.

column1: “Hullabaloo”

column4: it encapsulates the album’s extremes. It starts out as a murky psych-folk. Halfway through

column6: that drone has melted into a cosmic-jazz smear of reverb and drifting note-clusters
column7: with random instruments ebbing and flowing through the vacuum. The phrase “ice cream cake” has never been uttered with more menace. Compared to David’s tight
column8: immaculate
column9: guitar-savvy compositions
column10: Hamish sounds downright dizzy. It doesn’t even resemble Hamish’s own laidback vibe in his long-running project the Mad Scene. But that disorientation is what makes the album so atmospheric. Well
column11: that and tracks like “Rave Up (For the Yellow Dogs)”

column13: moaning
column14: chanted mantra aided by slinky marimba that recalls Hamish’s work with Theo Angell four years ago on their all-raga album under the name Cloudcraft.

column1: Hamish dips into his past liberally on All of It and Nothing. The album was recorded by Gary Olson of the Mad Scene (and also of The Ladybug Transistor)

column3: off-kilter whimsy of “Going Out” and “Crazy Radiance” hew closer to Daniel Johnston’s cracked-glass vision of folk-pop. (The cover of All of It and Nothing
column4: with its jumble of sketchy juvenilia
column5: could even pass for one of Johnston’s.) Mostly
column6: though
column7: Hamish’s shambolic strumming and clumps of acidic imagery pick up the loose threads of Clean Out of Our Minds
column8: the 1983 bedroom-made album he and David released in 1983 under the handle the Great Unwashed
column9: as if the past 30 years never happened or simply didn’t matter.

column1: Rather than forging something distinct and discreet with his first solo album
column2: Hamish has cast his imagination backward and let it roam. On “Turn Around”
column3: he seems to be making up the lyrics on the spot
column4: freestyling in a mock-Lou Reed deadpan
column5: “Self-nostalgic/ Avoid the tragic.” His voice sinks into the song
column6: utterly committed to noncommittal. Still
column7: it seems like something more ineffable than laziness is compelling him. “This is the last...”
column8: he sings on the album’s final track
column9: “The Last Song”
column10: apparently unable to summon the wherewithal to complete his sentence. Then he continues
column11: “…marks the end of this album/ And the journey isn’t over quite yet/ Mistakes were made.” Instead of self-deprecating
column12: All of It and Nothing is a meditation on invisibility and absence

column14:
but it’s all part of the vanishing act.

Time was
column2: the recipe for a superstar artist to create a Big Event Album was well known—a few teaser ads in the music mags
column3: a lead single for radio
column4: some late-night talk show appearances
column5: then sit back and watch the fans line up at the record store on release day. But now that basically every entity in that sentence has been culturally marginalized
column6: and the propeller churn of social media refuses to tolerate slow-burn marketing
column7: the best—and
column8: perhaps
column9: only—way to get everyone talking about your record at once is to release it with no warning. U2 being U2
column10: they’ve taken that strategy one step over the line into indisputably queasy territory
column11: aligning with their old friends Apple to insert their new album
column12: Songs of Innocence
column13: into all of our libraries without consent. By updating the old Columbia House Record Club scam to the digital age
column14: U2 and their Cupertino buddies have created a new avenue of opt-out cultural transmission
column15: removing even the miniscule effort it takes to go to a website and click “Download.”

column1: That U2 would willingly play corporate house band at a watch announcement to achieve this rollout in 2014 surprises exactly nobody; the album release was even framed by Bono himself as the 10th-anniversary celebration of a commercial. But the insistent mode of distribution says a lot about the band’s addiction to attention in their 38th year. “Part of the DNA of this band has always been the desire to get our music to as many people as possible
column2: ” Bono wrote
column3: and after the commercial squib of 2009’s gloomy No Line on the Horizon
column4: everything about Songs of Innocence seems desperate to be the global
column5: cultural “experience” fix U2 needs to survive
column6: even if it means giving away the album for “free.”

column1: Accordingly
column2: the music itself aims for a one-size-fits-all
column3: vaguely inspirational tone
column4: with a lean approach to details despite the press kit assertion that it’s all “very
column5: very personal.” So a song about Bono meeting his wife is given the non-committal title of “Song for Someone”
column6: and a song called “The Troubles” isn’t a callback to the prolonged Northern Ireland conflict that inspired their first great song
column7: but a bunch of self-pitying platitudes (which uses guest Lykke Li to mimic adult-contempo Duran Duran hit “Come Undone”). Even Bono’s opening love letter to Joey Ramone is only given specificity by the title’s parenthetical
column8: a generic “last night a [fill-in-the-blank] changed my life” tale that could be adapted to the idol of your choosing. It’s all emotional content left intentionally formless
column9: vaingloriously hoping to fit around the experiences of millions.

column1: Songs of Innocence also continues a decade-long trend of U2 showing little interest in re-examining themselves as a band or as pop stars
column2: the approach that sustained them artistically throughout the '90s. Despite jettisoning their Eno/Lanois/Lillywhite comfort zone in favor of Danger Mouse
column3: Paul Epworth
column4: and a host of other moderately intriguing producers
column5: Songs of Innocence is perhaps the album where U2 most self-consciously plays itself—or more distressingly
column6: risk causing a temporal paradox by swiping moves from mantle-carriers Arcade Fire and Coldplay
column7: akin to time traveling to the future and sleeping with your own grandchild.

column1: A few promisingly weird moments
column2: such as the eerily synthetic Beach Boys chant at the start of “California (There Is No End to Love)” or the breathy rhythms of “Raised By Wolves”
column3: are quickly diluted by stock verse/chorus structures. The watery disco-punk beats of “This Is Where You Can Reach Me Now” and “Volcano” are thin gruel for a band that once seemed aware of current pop trends
column4: however ill-advised the attempts were to engage with them. Only “Sleep Like a Baby Tonight” manages to feel fresh from start to finish
column5: with burbling synths and pillowy strings occasionally disrupted by the Edge at his fuzziest-sounding. Elsewhere
column6: there seems to be barely any resistance to the gravity of doing what a U2 song is supposed to do and little else.

column1: That gravity has a name
column2: and it’s four letters long
column3: and at this point even those letters are wearing sunglasses. The two brief moments where Bono drops his global-rock-ambassador persona—the deranged
column4: filtered first note of the “Raised by Wolves” chorus
column5: the brief return of the “Lemon” falsetto on “Sleep Like a Baby Tonight”—are jarring enough to expose just how overblown his crooning is on Songs of Innocence. While the album’s liner notes contain a moving
column6: train-of-thought reflection on a childhood made up of witnessing car bombings and sneaking into Ramones shows
column7: almost none of that insight makes it into the actual songs
column8: which are a celebration of self-absorption: “You are rock and roll” quickly amended to “You and I are rock and roll.”

column1: Perhaps the upcoming companion album
column2: inevitably named Songs of Experience
column3: will contain all the darker
column4: cynical stuff from these sessions. Regardless
column5: U2 have already squandered any remaining integrity to invent this needy
column6: invasive breed of the Big Event Album
column7: an Album that lacks any kind of artistic statement to deter from the overwhelming Brandiness. Where Beyoncé used her iTunes sneak attack late last year to make a bold pop proclamation of sexuality and feminism
column8: U2 have used an even more audacious release platform to wave their arms and simply say
column9: “Hey! Everybody! We’re still here!” Bono may have self-deprecatingly described Songs of Innocence as “the blood
column10: sweat and tears of some Irish guys...in your junk mail
column11:
” but it’s not even that interesting—it’s just a blank message.

James Ford and Jas Shaw of  Simian Mobile Disco have spent the last decade cresting waves and skirting irrelevance to arrive at where they are today. After splintering from rock quartet Simian in 2005
column3: Ford and Shaw turned toward the type of high-energy
column4: melodically palatable electro that came to be known for a mercifully brief spell as “blog-house
column5: ” releasing one of the genre’s most colorful and striking full-lengths in the form of the 2007 debut Attack Decay Sustain Release.

column1: The title of SMD’s 2009 follow-up
column2: Temporary Pleasure
column3: suggested the London duo’s dance-pop might be getting stale
column4: so the following year saw them take a successful left turn into hard techno territory
column5: launching the Delicatessen label and releasing an enjoyable batch of roilers in the form of that year’s singles collection Delicacies. At this point
column6: SMD aren’t exactly underrated—their 2012 LP Unpatterns was a just-okay collision of their techno and electro tendencies—but their longevity has perhaps gone underappreciated
column7: as recent collaborations with techno heavy-hitters like Irish duo Bicep and German veteran Roman Flügel have spoken to the duo’s adventurousness and steady sense of industry.

column1: SMD's new album Whorl plays like an expected follow-up to the pleasantly forgettable Unpatterns rather than a confirmation of SMD’s still-revered live show. Much of the 64-minute set emphasizes texture over dynamics
column2: content to exist as background music. This
column3: in and of itself
column4: is not the worst thing that could happen: Ford and Shaw are experts at the nuts and bolts of sound—the former is also an in-demand studio producer and songwriter—so the drifting ambience and analog burbles of Whorl are
column5: like ice sculptures
column6: glimmering in their plainness. The swirling
column7: beatless one-two kiss of “Redshift” and “Dandelion Spheres” take on pleasing
column8: meditative shapes
column9: but the downtempo fare presented elsewhere—the frizzy
column10: disjointed atmospherics of “Z Space”
column11: “Nazard”’s questionable flirtations with chillout—simply dissipates upon contact.

column1: As ever
column2: SMD are most engaging when creating body-moving
column3: uptempo fare: “Calyx” percolates and whines to a pleasing climax
column4: with piping tones dancing on its surface
column5: while “Tangents” builds to an anthemic swirl of synth lines anchored by a steady
column6: hissing 4/4. Most notably
column7: “Jam Side Up” rides a cascading melody for nearly six minutes
column8: building and breaking a beat around it with a sense of patience that makes for an impressive mid-tune peak. These three tracks are clustered in the middle section of Whorl
column9: possibly to mimic the structural build of a live performance
column10: but the shiftless sounds that come before are more likely to trigger a click on ""pause"" rather than create anticipation for what’s to follow.

column1: Just last year
column2: SMD released Live
column3: an untouchable document of their onstage capabilities that stands as their most pleasurable recorded statement. On Live they distilled their two primary modes—their harder
column4: abstract side and their more explicitly pop-leaning past—into something cohesive and enjoyable
column5: but the set also highlighted the duo’s Achilles heel: they’re more of a singles outfit (as many dance acts are) and when they’re constrained to the album format
column6: tedium creeps in. That’s been the case since Temporary Pleasure
column7: and it’s the case for Whorl
column8: too
column9:
a record that finds SMD operating at half-speed when the accelerator is pedal is close within their reach.

column3: Los Angeles singer/songwriter Jhené Aiko has skirted the periphery of R&B stardom
column4: thanks to an early association with the Omarion-led R&B boy band B2K
column5: later work with Kendrick Lamar’s Black Hippy crew and more recently
column6: Kanye mentor and Def Jam exec No I.D.’s Cocaine 80s collective. Much of the conversation about Aiko posited her as a musical foil for her more widely known rapper friends. Her debut mixtape Sailing Soul(s) flourished by co-opting the minor key melodies and navel gazing oversharing of R&B radio’s wistful sad boys
column7: but her delivery hewed a touch too vacant
column8: her words too indistinct
column9: to carry an entire project. Last year’s “The Worst” was a Technicolor reveal
column10: a performance involved and emotional enough to shake frequent comparisons to cult pop-R&B stoic Cassie and break Aiko on a national level without a celebrity co-star leading the way. Even if the accompanying Sail Out EP was still a rap friends roll call
column11: “The Worst” proved she could go it alone if need be
column12: rapping and all.

column1: Sovereignty seems to be the mission of Aiko’s proper debut Souled Out. Throughout the album
column2: the predominant voice heard is hers; barring some choice backing vocals from songwriter to the stars James Fauntleroy
column3: the lone celebrity guest spot is a bottom of the ninth appearance from Common on the album closer “Pretty Bird (Freestyle)”. It’s a high-risk measure
column4: a glut of solo mood pieces from an artist many may only have experienced a few lines at a time on friends’ choruses. But anchoring Souled Out are Aiko’s advancing command of her instrument and a more daring approach to melody. These songs ask more of her than the mopey
column5: low-register Drake-fan-service of her earlier material. Her voice skips and flits across these compositions with a confidence that defies the limits of her range. Aiko has zeroed in on her strengths as a performer (stoned perseverance
column6: stoned exhaustion) and tailored Souled Out specifically around them. The breathy resignation of “It’s Cool” fits the song’s pursuit of a distant love interest hand in glove
column7: while “Wading”
column8: awash in unrequited romance
column9: emotes with desolate
column10: echoing vocal runs.

column1: Aiko’s writing can be a liability
column2: though. In avoiding the Ester Deans
column3: Ryan Tedders
column4: and Sias that workshop many of her peers’ hits behind the scenes
column5: she gives Souled Out a distinctly personal edge and an earnest
column6: lived-in feel. It also means there's sporadic lapses into pat aphorisms that do few favors for the record's ""melody first
column7: lyrics later"" songwriting approach. Opener “Limbo Limbo Limbo” gets overwrought quick: “She was just as basic as the universal language of love.” “W.A.Y.S.” folds Buddhist monk spirituality into Cheshire Cat turns of phrase: “You have got to lose your mind just to find your peace of mind.” “There’s really no fail
column8: there’s really no winning/ 'Cause nothing really is
column9: and everything really isn’t.” “Lyin King” dabbles in pop psychology: “Mr. Serial Lover
column10: I wish your mother loved you like I could’ve.” Like Sail Out’s bonus track “Comfort Inn Ending (Freestyle)”
column11: Souled Out’s nightcap “Pretty Bird (Freestyle)” finds Aiko vocalizing free verse for one of the album’s most impassioned performances. But the thematic conceit—Aiko having run out of things to say—doesn’t need four minutes of exploratory scatting to bear out.

column1: With Aiko’s writing flowing freely from relatable distress to hotbox reverie
column2: Souled Out’s producers
column3: composers
column4: and players are tasked with minding the turbulence. Sailing Soul(s) and Sail Out architect Fisticuffs sneaks a few cuts in
column5: buoyed by a handful of contributions from No I.D.
column6: Röyksopp
column7: Kid Cudi mainstay Dot Da Genius
column8: and others. Though Souled Out’s cast is diverse
column9: its sound is of a piece; end to end
column10: it surges with a lush
column11: aquatic gravitas
column12: distinctly R&B but never confined to genre conventions. “W.A.Y.S.” pairs contributions from Thundercat and Clams Casino
column13: bombing gently plucked guitars with massive
column14: echoing drums and cross-breeding both artists’ trademark sounds to dramatic effect. “Spotless Mind” imagines a world where a post-Police Sting discovered drum machines instead of turtles and lutes
column15: before spinning out on a loping guitar coda reminiscent of “Strawberry Letter 23”
column16: while the plinking bells and wraith-like synths of “Wading” might’ve graced a Cure record in another era. Souled Out’s production is a warm bath of understated musicality
column17: even if it’s occasionally a bit too drippy and sleepy for its own good.

column1: Souled Out capably buffs Jhené Aiko’s strengths and shellacks her faults
column2: but the moments where she steps out into the depth of her story transcend the synergy of a group of musicians with good chemistry. On “Promises”
column3: Aiko speaks to her daughter

column5: and to her deceased older brother
column6: whom she petitions for strength in trying times. The heartrending vulnerability of the trek through Aiko's fears into a knowing acceptance of the fragility of life
column7: the randomness of misfortune
column8: and her eagerness to keep at it in the wake of an irreparable loss
column9: is quietly devastating. “W.A.Y.S.” (short for “Why aren’t you smiling?”
column10: one of her brother’s final Twitter transmissions) is a mantralike message of hope charged with as much determination as self-suggestion
column11: a perseverance she has had to speak into existence. Hers has been an arduous road
column12: but with Souled Out
column13:
Jhené Aiko has begun to knead adversity into sustenance.

Unless you’ve spent at least a few of your formative years in Florida
column2: you can’t know how uniquely shitty Florida can be for a young person. There’s a vibrant music scene there
column3: of course
column4: but it’s a direct outgrowth of a climate—economic
column5: political
column6: and cultural as well as meteorological—that can be suffocating. This is the land that nursed Deicide and Assück
column7: Floor and Against Me!
column8: Neon Blud and Cult Ritual. More recently
column9: it also birthed the Ukiah Drag. Featuring members of
column10: among other outfits
column11: the aforementioned Neon Blud and Cult Ritual
column12: the band hails from the Tampa and Gainesville areas

column1: In The Reaper’s Quarters was presaged by last year's four-song cassette Jazz Mama Is Cryin
column2: which staked an immediate claim on entirely alien territory: some imagined badland where the Gun Club’s death-blues

column5: though

column10: adenoidal geekiness— Stan Ridgway hosting a Halloween party as the Crypt Keeper
column11: cranking his Mexican radio until the air turns to goo.

column1: The Ukiah Drag’s list of influences stray a bit too far afield on “Wait and See”
column2: a cover of the Lee Hazlewood song that doesn’t do enough to distinguish itself from the admittedly gorgeous original; the barrel-chested vocals wind up resembling Calvin Johnson
column3: and not in a good way. There’s a jarring
column4: melancholy sincerity to the song that doesn’t sit well with the Ukiah Drag’s swamp-ass psychedelia
column5: although it’s salvaged somewhat by a lazily monstrous guitar solo. Taken together
column6: “Final Prayer” and “Drip from the Fang” offer the most concentrated burst of rancid bog-juice that In The Reaper’s Quarter keeps on tap. Situated back-to-back
column7: the two songs span the band’s gleefully constricted scope: “Drip from the Fang” coils and springs like rusted clockwork
column8: a snake with its head cut off and unable to tell that it’s no longer alive. That twitchy
column9: zombie-like vibe subsides to a simmer on “Final Prayer”. Stitched together out of poltergeist moans
column10: dry-ice fog
column11: and twangy licks that crawl about with their bellies in the dust
column12: the track lurches and lumbers as Ramiriez sets his bleary sights on the mirage-haunted horizon: “Next to you/ In your kingdom/ That’s where I want to live/ Take me there.”

column3: too. The group is now in self-imposed “New England exile
column4: ” and In The Reaper’s Quarters was recorded in New York
column5: “off the banks of the Hudson River
column6: ” according to them
column7: produced by the Men's Ben Greenberg. Still
column8: the album evokes the essential otherness of Florida
column9: if not the stifling essence of Florida itself
column10: and that’s for the best. Plagued by affluent retirees
column11: voter suppression
column12: and sinkholes
column13: for fuck’s sake
column14: Florida is—amid all its lushness—a place of death and decay
column15: the reaper’s quarters
column16: indeed. “Diggin’ down deep!” Ramiriez yelps on the lopsided
column17: organ-soaked “Her Royal Grip”
column18: knowing full well that Florida
column19: barely above sea level
column20: isn’t a place where you can dig very deep at all. Then he adds

geography is neither a trap nor a means of escape. It’s a shallow grave to play in.

Neill Jameson ranks among the great defenders of and disciples for United States Black Metal. He’s been making and refining his own antagonistic strain since the mid-1990s
column2: leading Krieg through some of the most important
column3: compelling and twisted stateside versions of the form. He’s run a label and become a crucial distribution point for many acts
column4: welcomed outsiders into the dark fold
column5: publicly defended the acquisition of Thurston Moore by his supergroup Twilight
column6: and dismissed insider and old friend Blake Judd as an expression of the genre at its solipsistic worst. He’s advocated for progression in the form by endorsing the firebrands of Liturgy while maintaining that the genre must stay tough and unruly unless it wants to become as weak as water. “I have boots that are older than most of these people’s interest in black metal
column7: ” he once said
column8: swiftly encapsulating his admixture of old-school aggression and excitable acceptance. “I figure black metal is probably just a curiosity for the white-belt crowd.… I’m not as bothered by it as some people are; it’s just the evolution of things.”

column1: Transient is Krieg’s first album in four years
column2: second since a necessary hiatus
column3: and first featuring Jameson surrounded by a new quartet. Moreover
column4: it’s an hour-long expression of Jameson’s defensive and defiant attitude
column5: as it sprawls from a base of recalcitrant black metal in intriguing
column6: unexpected directions. A uniformly desolate album
column7: Transient is a claustrophobic listen that provides the illusion of walls closing in and ceilings coming down
column8: even as its sound opens wider. Though the core of Krieg and these 11 songs remains primitive black metal
column9: epitomized by mid-album melee “Atlas with a Broken Arm”
column10: the album serves as a reminder that Jameson has never been one for stasis. He’s shifted Krieg’s lineup between most albums
column11: covered the Velvet Underground in a croaking acoustic guise
column12: and massaged a broad spectrum of influences into this band. Transient leans hard into those outlier aims: Some moments shimmer with the pop-metal buoyancy that temporarily worked as Nachtmystium’s calling card
column13: while others burrow into slow
column14: strong doom wallops. There are orchestrated power electronics interludes and hardcore stomp-alongs
column15: solemn spoken-word passages and taut post-punk counter-riffs. Jameson’s boots are ostensibly meant for hiking.

column1: But credit goes to Jameson’s irascible voice—here
column2: the best it’s ever been—for threading together these disparate musical thoughts and giving the record its overriding sense of desperation. No matter the particular song’s style or structure
column3: he plays the part of the reprobate. He bellows like a bully during the hardcore half of “Return Fire” and screams in agony when it downshifts in the back
column4: a madman melting in his own sweat. Krieg recorded Transient at the Rhode Island studio Machines with Magnets
column5: a room perhaps best known for its work with The Body. You can hear that duo’s echoes during the brilliant cover of Amebix’s “Winter”
column6: which pivots from brief black metal builds into bottomless doom tirades. Above a rhythm section that suggests orchestrated artillery fire
column7: Jameson lashes out as though he’s being interred by the force of his own band. In fact
column8: he delivers much of Transient as though he’s singing beneath the outfit
column9: fighting to be heard among the din of guitars and drums. That choice makes Transient both bleak and beguiling; Jameson sounds trapped
column10: but you want to lean in close
column11: dangerously so
column12: to hear what he has to yell. Even during “Walk With Them Unnoticed
column13: ” that particularly upbeat and racing number
column14: his hoarse tone comes tucked just beneath the lip of the lead
column15: making even the album’s most breathless and accessible bit feel hazardous.

column1: Though Jameson emerged as a one-man black metal band
column2: first under the name Imperial and later as Krieg
column3: he’s a rich collaborator
column4: too. His roster of past alliances and collaborations is the length of a few paragraphs
column5: and he’s one of only two people to appear on every Twilight album. He’s made doom with March into the Sea and tortured prismatic weirdness with N.I.L.
column6: and his willingness to work with others is a crucial component of Transient
column7: a record that benefits from pulling Jameson out of his own head. Opener “Order of the Solitary Road” starts slow
column8: turns into a sprint
column9: manages to pick up the pace yet again and ultimately staggers off into the distance; it’s a full-band feat
column10: motivated by the drums but pulled along by Alex Poole’s spectacularly assorted riffs. In the span of six minutes
column11: he lands a perfectly slow
column12: steely melody at the start and
column13: near the middle
column14: a grim
column15: low-lying theme.

column4: Integrity’s Dwid Hellion and Thurston Moore trade stanzas about absence and loneliness. “The only home I know anymore is that of discomfort
column5: ” Moore reads

column10:
providing what started as solitary laments from a one-man band the benefit of misery in good company.

Desperately trying to scratch an itch you just can’t fucking get at: Ten years later

column4: I’m a Machine
column5: the 2004 debut by Toronto’s Death From Above 1979. That lack of intimate connection and tactile resolution is echoed in the failed interface hinted at in the album’s title. DFA 1979 just couldn’t get no satisfaction—and when the band blew up in the mid '00s
column6: they promptly imploded
column7: only adding to that nagging tingle. Here was a duo gathering the shrapnel of so many scenes that exploded earlier in the decade—garage rock
column8: stoner metal
column9: dance punk—squeezing them into a tightly wound mass of fuzz and force
column10: only to let it all slip through their fingers.

column1: DFA 1979’s two halves
column2: vocalist/drummer Sebastien Grainger and bassist/keyboardist Jesse F. Keeler
column3: parted ways in 2006. Grainger kept sporadically busy as a singer/songwriter; Keeler moved his electro-slanted side-project MSTRKRFT to the front burner. Now
column4: after an initial onstage reunion in 2011 that marked the mending of broken fences
column5: they’ve delivered The Physical World. So much has changed since You’re a Woman
column6: and so little
column7: too: Julian Casablancas
column8: Karen O
column9: and Interpol are still around
column10: and coincidentally
column11: each of them has even made noise this very week. (It’s enough to make you wonder if they all secretly synced up with each other to enhance their retro-'00s brand synergy.) But it’s been a decade since Grainger and Keeler showed up to that particular party with 12-packs in hand
column12: and they were a little late
column13: arriving just as it was beginning to simmer down. Granted
column14: they helped send it off with a bang; a last spurt of debauchery before everyone either hooks up or passes out
column15: You’re a Woman raged like there was no tomorrow.

column1: The Physical World—wiser and more wary than its predecessor—is that tomorrow
column2: the one that was never supposed to come.  It doesn't so much sound like You’re a Woman was 10 years ago as it does 10 months: “It’s the same old song
column3: just a different tune
column4: ” Grainger rasps on “Right On
column5: Frankenstein!”
column6: an efficient yet spirited dance-punk procedural that wouldn’t have sounded out of place amid You’re a Woman rockers like “Turn It Out” and “Cold War”. The Physical World is built out of pieces of the band’s own past
column7: but it hangs together beautifully
column8: all sleek musculature and acrobatic riffs. There’s not as much scraping
column9: lunging
column10: or dive-bombing on the album as compared to You’re a Woman
column11: although that doesn’t keep The Physical World’s title track from glitching and spazzing in a fugue of pseudo-metallic collapse: “Go bridge won/ Has strung out/ Build up/ Tear it down
column12: ” Grainger wails
column13: resembling a cyborg caught in a robotic purgatory. “Oh no
column14: not again/ I get the feeling this is never gonna end.” The song dissolves in a haze of wheezing keyboard
column15: like some creaking
column16: rickety
column17: steampunk version of itself.

column1: Solipsism and self-recycling aside
column2: Grainger branches out into new territory
column3: at least for DFA 1979: a conceptual arc
column4: if not a narratively coherent one. ""Virgins"" and ""White Is Red"" hinge together like a great
column5: two-part TV episode
column6: full of lurid melodrama and teen-angst iconography; summer school
column7: skating in pools
column8: and innocence left in the backseat of a car all pop up in ""Virgins""
column9: which pounds and writhes with Ted Nugent-meets-Josh Homme swagger. And while the similarly highway-themed ""White Is Red"" seems like a sequel of sorts—""Frankie was a heartbreaker
column10: I didn’t know it at the start/ She was only 16 when she went and broke my heart
column11: Grainger croons with all the grit of a natural-born balladeer
column12: or at least Brandon Flowers with a better grasp of the Boss— it doesn’t overtax the link. These are loose associations
column13: motifs that float around and occasionally complete each other
column14: the type of subtlety that the Grainger of You’re a Woman wasn’t concerned with. Balling and brooding were his two settings
column15: and he toggled them frantically
column16: never seeming to find what he was looking for
column17: so he's clearly spent the last 10 years doing some growing up.

column1: In a recent interview Keeler did for Stereogum
column2: he talks about his and Grainger's metamorphosis from hormone-pumping post-adolescents to grownups with families and
column3: of all the crazy things
column4: lives. “Back then we didn’t have any kind of life outside of the band
column5: ” he says
column6: speaking of the DFA 1979's pre-breakup years. “The band was everything; it was literally all we had. Now we both have lives of our own outside of the music we make together. And that’s really important. Everyone needs to have a life.” Calling The Physical World a work of maturity would be selling the album
column7: and maturity
column8: short: “Cheap Talk” and “Government Trash” zoom like rockets and stomp like dinosaurs
column9: full of snotty
column10: boyish abandon
column11: while “Trainwreck 1979” dabbles in mirror-gazing and mythologizing. The album is
column12: above all
column13: pragmatic—a more judicious application of the band’s mixed-use energy—but it doesn’t do so at the expense of soul.

column1: The Physical World’s most gripping song
column2: “Always On”
column3: paints a dystopian scenario drawn from DFA 1979’s own experience as the objects of expectation as well as the downward spiral of music-industry boom-and-bust. Grainger sneers
column4: “If we brought Kurt back to life/ There’s no way he would survive
column5: ” and he’s not only talking about the vicissitudes of the pop world that Kurt Cobain loved and hated
column6: but also of the social-media membrane we’ve all become cocooned in. “Show me something new/ Something I can like
column7: ” he begs in singsong horror as he hops across a bed of sharpened hooks
column8: unable to reconcile
column9: consummate
column10: or otherwise bridge the schism between what exists online and what can only be touched by skin. With The Physical World
column11: Grainger and Keeler haven’t entirely scratched the itch they instigated a decade ago. But they’ve learned to live with the burn
column12:
and that’s the next best thing.

Tennis are still a young band
column2: but their career to date would make a great case study for those trying to understand the multi-faceted
column3: oft-destructive power of narrative in the world of contemporary music coverage. Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore emerged as the summer of 2010 started to take on heat
column4: armed with a handful of breezy
column5: weightless singles and a story that seemed salvaged from a rousing game of Indie-Pop Mad Libs: a young couple (insert relationship) from Denver (city) bought a sailboat (unconventional vehicle) and recorded an album about a journey on said vehicle
column6: working under the name Tennis (sport). That album
column7: Cape Dory
column8: was released in January 2011
column9: and could’ve been knocked over by a stiff sea breeze: the melodies within were pleasant but thin
column10: and the cute story that lay at the album’s core wasn’t enough to render the music it inspired particularly compelling. The band has had a hard time escaping that plot point in the years since Cape Dory was released; it’s hard to find an interview or piece of coverage that opens with something other than a mention of Tennis’ stint on the waters of the Eastern Seaboard.

column1: <div>
<div>It’s too bad
column2: because the band has largely moved on from the sound and sensibility of their early career; in fact
column3: much of their work since has felt like a reaction to the story that lit a spark under them in the first place. They added a drummer
column4: James Barone
column5: and embraced bittersweet
column6: autumnal melodies that paired well with lyrical darkness and a touch of fuzz. Subsequent releases like 2012’s second full-length Young and Old and 2013’s fine Small Sound EP were brought to life with help from well-known producers like the Black Keys’ drummer Patrick Carney and indie rock vet Richard Swift
column7: and their best moments (“Origins”
column8: “Mean Streets”) hinted at a level of craftsmanship and depth their early material sorely lacked. Their new record
column9: Ritual in Repeat
column10: finds Tennis continuing to mature and highlight their strengths—Moore’s growing voice
column11: an ear for melody—with the help of yet another prominent producer
column12: Spoon’s Jim Eno.

column1: Ritual in Repeat is a nicely confident album
column2: one that takes a simple formula—play Moore’s sweet
column3: thin voice against sour
column4: brooding arrangements
column5: and eventually break open into sticky
column6: yearning choruses laden with harmony—to a few unexpected places. The influence of the complex
column7: emotionally ambiguous pop music of the late ‘60s and ‘70s (a period that casts a shadow over much of the band’s work) is still present
column8: but there’s also tendrils of slinky funk (“I’m Callin’”)
column9: contemporary dream-pop (“Viv Without the N”)
column10: and spectral thesaurus-folk (“Wounded Heart”) snaking their way through the album. Almost every song has a muscle and weight to its arrangement that complements Moore’s vocal work. She’ll never have the power or gravitas of some of her contemporaries
column11: but she’s gotten much better at writing material that suits her skill set
column12: namely agility and an ease with harmony.

column1: <div>The agility comes in handy
column2: because Ritual in Repeat occasionally sounds a little too cluttered and dense for its own good. The band and producers pile fragments of melody and instrumentation on top of each other
column3: and it can become tough to pick out the most rewarding musical thread. It’s a record that could benefit from the application of what could be termed the Chanel principle
column4: an adaptation of the designer’s famous quote about getting dressed: before you leave the studio
column5: look in the mirror and take one thing out of your song.

column1: <div>Tennis has matured on the lyrical front in recent years
column2: too: Ritual in Repeat focuses on complicated relationships and self-examination
column3: rather than the vagaries of travel or the various meteorological events that marked the band's early work. The album's characters are always looking for validation
column4: whether from a partner or some higher power; they look to their lovers
column5: in the mirror
column6: and to the heavens for some sort of sign that they're doing things right and moving forward. Sighing opener ""Night Vision"" finds Moore ably setting the scene for the latter kind of search—you can see her sitting on a wooded porch
column7: staring in vain into the middle distance
column8: thinking about mistakes she's made and people she's left behind. Her voice hangs with the quiet
column9: private dissatisfaction of people who seem to have everything they could ever want
column10: and it imbues the band's songs with a nuanced
column11: compelling sadness. This very specific feeling is only occasionally obfuscated by her diction
column12: which is showy to a fault; songs like ""Needle and a Knife"" and ""Wounded Heart"" are literate to the point of distraction
column13: stuffed with ten dollar words where they could be simple and sharp.

column1: <div>Tennis are clearly capable of that level of acute writing
column2: because they use it to succinctly sum up their band's appeal on back-half highlight ""This Isn't My Song"": ""Only simple melodies/ Find their way into your memory...It's nothing profound/ Just a sweet sound."" It's a smart reading of their strengths
column3: and even a little cheeky when taken alongside Ritual in Repeat's cover and larger subject matter: if you're inclined to Tennis negatively
column4: they look like a group of blank people offering bland sweetness devoid of deeper meaning. While the band might've fit that description at one point
column5: they've since grown past it
column6: so if you're one of the listeners who dismissed their earlier work as banal and bourgeois
column7: know that Tennis has since earned another chance.

Every discussion of Ballet School becomes a discussion of “the 1980s” within a few sentences
column2: and this one will be no different. What’s interesting is how everyone involved seems to have a tacit understanding of what “the 1980s” means and how it narrows an entire decade into a few signifiers—this band doesn’t represent the 1980s and its attendant political discord or technological advances
column3: nor does it ever account for the incredible leaps in punk
column4: metal
column5: hip-hop
column6: electronic
column7: you name it. It doesn’t even include Michael Jackson or Prince or Bruce Springsteen.

column1: Rather
column2: “the 1980s” establishes a few movies and their soundtracks as the entire cultural zeitgeist
column3: with inexcusably old-looking “teens” and their irrepressible hormones set to perky
column4: up-tempo rhythms and an emotional tenor where the “Me Decade” filters down from Wall Street to high schoolers obsessed with true love and self-actualization. This style of music might be more prominent now than it is was 30 years ago and multinational trio Ballet School seem to be aware of that; their name could pass for a Dean Cameron-starring caper flick
column5: the title of their debut might be too precious for even an M83 instrumental
column6: and its lead singer has a chameleonic voice that ""Saturday Night Live"" could've used during the Nora Dunn era. Their first single was called “Heartbeat Overdrive” and the title alone probably makes any analysis of this record redundant.

column1: Point being
column2: The Dew Lasts an Hour ain’t an album
column3: it’s an arms race
column4: and Ballet School are at their best when they’re pushing the nuclear option. After a two-minute ambient intro that exists mostly as a reminder that Ballet School are an indie band on a label operated by Cocteau Twins' Simon Raymonde
column5: “Pale Saint” and “Ghost” put all the signifiers at full-blast—guitars and keyboards are glazed and glistening under the same effects
column6: pealing
column7: swirling
column8: and billowing to corroborate a narrator that never gets their head out of the clouds. Real drums are processed to sound like synths
column9: and vice versa. They cut footloose at a manic pace
column10: bright pink leggings endlessly pumping on a StairMaster. And Ballet School compensate for a lack of originality with enthusiasm—Rosie Blair’s melodies may not be all that memorable
column11: but she sure sings the hell out of them.

column1: If their predilection for the sounds of “the 1980s” has a particularly modern slant
column2: it’s that Ballet School operate under the premise that populism is inherently good—Blair gives Kate Bush and Mariah Carey equal stature
column3: which leads to some unfortunate ululation and vocal cloudbusting that undermine the reverie. The Dew Lasts an Hour is more effective as ambience than pure pop; there’s a dissonance between Blair’s skyscraping and the modest production
column4: which actually situates the record in 2010 more than it does 1984. That was a particularly productive year for mid-fi indie bands who immersed themselves in reverb and blurred the line between 4AD and MTV
column5: including the first Twin Shadow and Wild Nothing albums
column6: and Abe Vigoda’s overlooked goth-pop about-face Crush.

column1: But with the aforementioned
column2: you could sense that the sound was secondary
column3: a preferred filter to express either deep-seated trauma
column4: window-watching loneliness
column5: or slow-burning intensity. Ballet School’s emotional center
column6: on the other hand
column7: is much tougher to find—during “Cherish”
column8: Blair belts
column9: ""Love is the only reason left to live/ Hey
column10: yeah
column11: yeah/ Love is the only lesson left to give/ Hey
column12: yeah
column13: yeah
column14: which absolutely works within the skyward arc of its hook. You’re supposed to feel it rather than analyze it. But after its auspicious start
column15: The Dew Last an Hour tries to convey similar sentiments amid agreeable
column16: midtempo synth-pop that skimps on the pop and piles on the twinkling
column17: harmonized guitars and vaporous melodies. What begins as a cooling blast of fresh air dissipates into pleasant ambience.

column1: As the story goes
column2: Blair met guitarist Michel Jun Collett as a busker in Berlin and bonded over a shared appreciation of Cocteau Twins. The facts check out: throughout
column3: they show an eagerness to please
column4: their originals could pass for covers and they obviously and really
column5: really like the Cocteau Twins. But that’s about it.  For now
column6: The Dew Lasts an Hour is a proxy for “what we talk about when we talk about ‘the 1980s
column7:
'"" not so much for talking about Ballet School themselves.
