The creative arc Lee Gamble’s music has taken is a strange and wonderful thing to behold. It began with a literal tearing apart of his influences
column2: and then set off on a journey to see how much further away he could progressively move from them. His first full-length release
column3: Diversions 1994-1996
column4: tore passages from jungle mixtapes
column5: stripped all the beats out
column6: and reimagined them as dysfunctional bad dreams. The word “abstract” is never far away when people reach for descriptions of the London-based producer—and with good reason. His second release for Pan
column7: Dutch Tvashar Plumes
column8: was a hollowed out shell of techno
column9: where all semblance of form and shape was lost long ago
column10: leaving only fragments of a former good time. Gamble’s music is staged in an unusual place
column11: somewhere between the unreal and the all-too-real
column12: where wretched drug experiences at past-peak club hours somehow end up in a form of metaphysical drift into the following morning.

column1: KOCH is a sprawling record
column2: containing 16 tracks spread out over more than an hour. It takes time and patience to figure out what Gamble is going through
column3: and even then
column4: there are no easy answers. It’s a work of complexity
column5: although its parts
column6: when isolated
column7: don’t necessarily form knotty riddles. “Motor System” quietly pounds out a rudimentary beat while flattened voices curl around it
column8: suggesting a highly mechanized form of industrial music. Often there are layers of distortion coating everything
column9: such as on “Caudata”
column10: where Gamble constructs graceful shapes over a wall of fog
column11: putting it in a similar place to Leyland Kirby’s work with old 78 rpm records on An Empty Bliss Beyond This World. Another technique he’s fond of is spinning out the club experience in slow motion
column12: or making it feel like it’s happening in a place that’s far away but just close enough so the tiniest welt of bass can still be heard (“You Concrete"").

column1: The overriding feel on KOCH is one of removal
column2: of distant observation. Gamble’s music has the feel of someone floating above it
column3: looking in
column4: only tangentially participating in what’s going on. Beats are muffled
column5: signals echo for an eternity; on “Head Model”
column6: there’s acres of room between the parts being triggered
column7: but it never feels like there’s a ton of space opening up. Instead
column8: it’s all dense
column9: claustrophobic reflection
column10: with many of Gamble’s tracks trapped in one very specific moment without any forward flow at all. Occasionally there’s movement
column11: but even that verges on the cyclical. “HMix” begins with a charge of muddied beats and bass
column12: only to get filtered into reedy compression that resembles the worst kind of amphetamine headrush. There’s a similar mindset here to others who have attempted to scoop out the innards of electronics to see what remains—Actress
column13: Autechre
column14: Pan Sonic—but Gamble is in an even more detached place
column15: where the inclusionary side of club culture appears utterly alien.

column1: An emergent motif on KOCH is the awkwardness Gamble siphons into his work
column2: where parts only just fit or threaten to fall out of sequence altogether. “Ornith-Mimik” is all glistening
column3: high-pitched tones sloppily vying with a straight pulse and random video game interference
column4: while “Gillsman” is so purposefully clumsy it gains a drunken lop to its stride. It fits perfectly with the sense of separation this album is built on
column5: as this is not music that has easily definable origins beyond Gamble’s headspace. It all revolves around small glances and split-second patterns
column6: resembling the minutiae of club culture
column7: taken and amplified into a bigger space where there’s barely any room left for it to breathe. At times
column8: KOCH is so microscopic it feels like there’s barely any place left for this music to go. But Gamble keeps finding new ways to take it apart and reassemble it
column9: to the point where something so closed off
column10: so concerned with the smallest of gestures
column11:
feels thrillingly open.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20961/homepage_large.97940e31.jpg|Weaving|32454.0|Jo Johnson|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Further']|2014-09-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:29.927888|"

That Jo Johnson once played in Huggy Bear probably bears little relevance to her debut solo album. The standard-bearers for riot grrrl's UK faction
column2: Huggy Bear were noisemakers with a gleeful vengeance
column3: courting chaos and ecstasy in buzzsaw punk anthems that made good on Emma Goldman's maxim about revolutionaries cutting rugs. The most overtly political thing about Weaving
column4: on the other hand
column5: is a dolefully Dickensian track title
column6: ""In the Shadow of the Workhouse""
column7: and the noisiest thing here—well
column8: actually
column9: there isn't one. Sonically
column10: these stately
column11: meditative ambient fantasias are a world away from Huggy Bear's manic flare-ups. If we're trotting out biographical bullet points
column12: Johnson's membership in London experimental techno promoters Bleep43 has more bearing on the sound and shape of Weaving
column13: which seems determined to reimagine New Age music as another form of techno—or
column14: perhaps
column15: vice versa.

column1: But I get a kick out of the Huggy Bear factoid; it's like discovering that a talented kid you admired in high school has grown up and made good in a field completely different from the she was best known for—as though the varsity basketball forward were now a video-art savant
column2: maybe
column3: or the chess club champion had turned into a critically acclaimed chef. Because whatever Johnson's backstory
column4: Weaving is a remarkably accomplished take on ambient music
column5: and the fact that this is her debut album makes you wonder where Johnson has been hiding all this time.

column1: Just five songs and 41 minutes long
column2: Weaving is a modest affair
column3: which works in its favor: short enough to get through in one sitting
column4: compelling enough to want to loop indefinitely. It wears its influences on its sleeve: Laurie Spiegel's chiming electronic tones and clean-lined arpeggios
column5: Suzanne Ciani's bright-eyed new age naïveté
column6: the zen clarity of Aphex Twin's Selected Ambient Works Volume II and
column7: to a lesser extent
column8: the pinwheeling proto-trance of Edgar Froese and Klaus Schulze. As such
column9: Johnson finds common cause with contemporaries like Donato Dozzy
column10: Ricardo Donoso
column11: Steve Hauschildt
column12: and Mark McGuire
column13: but her work really couldn't be confused for any of theirs
column14: either.

column1: What most distinguishes Johnson's approach is her patience. Her repetitive sequences offer the most tantalizing kind of bait and switch: an arpeggio will tumble over and over and over again
column2: to the point at which it feels less like a musical motif than a piece of the landscape or a law of nature. Only then does the bottom drop out
column3: or a new note enters the mix
column4: and the whole scene is flipped quietly on its ear. She often favors ringing open fifths and octaves
column5: and plangent major sevenths forever on the verge of resolving
column6: but she also knows how and when to introduce just enough dissonance to prevent the music sounding too pristine
column7: too conflict-free; just consider the cricket-limbed white-noise pileup of the opening ""Ancestral Footsteps"" or the fat-fisted organ chords of ""Weaving""
column8: stacking overtones upon overtones like a beam of white light shot through a prism.

column1: There's nothing pro forma here. Every twist of the filter feels significant
column2: and every new sound (or silence) seems quietly fraught with meaning. The title ""Words Came After Music"" apparently stems from a book arguing that music was a pre-linguistic system of communication
column3: and Weaving makes good on the expressive capabilities of rhythm and repetition and pure
column4: keening frequency.

column1: While the first four tracks are nominally beatless
column2: the closing ""Silver Threads"" establishes a kind of footbridge between ambient music and techno. The first five minutes are all faint
column3: dusted drone
column4: luminous and diffuse as William Basinski's The Disintegration Loops; then
column5: almost imperceptibly
column6: broken kickdrum and hi-hat rhythms rise up out of the mist. Suddenly we're in Sandwell District territory
column7: and you can sense Johnson beginning to feel her way toward an entire new world of ideas that may not have fit elsewhere on the album
column8: with its soft edges and reverent air. Could Johnson also turn out to be a Dettmann-like purveyor of steely dancefloor grit? Given how gracefully she's managed the leap between punk rock and electronic shamanism
column9:
I wouldn't rule anything out at this point.

"|19733.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19733-jo-johnson-weaving/|7.7|Philip Sherburne

Karen O opens “NYC Baby”
column2: a minute-long track off her solo debut
column3: with a quiet “One… two… ready go…” She whispers the words carefully

column5: the song sounds like a nursery rhyme set to a wisp of a melody
column6: building on obvious rhymes (city/pity) and worrying a single sentiment (she misses someone) until it’s threadbare. It’s not a song so much as it is the memory of one
column7: something hummed while doing housework or waiting for the subway. Crush Songs is an album full of count-offs
column8: flubbed notes
column9: and background noises
column10: each one signaling an unrehearsed quality to the music. Karen O sings and plays like she wants as little time as possible separating the idea for a song from its execution. Some even sound like she’s writing them as she sings them.

column1: That these fourteen tracks sound like demos rather than fleshed-out tunes is the whole point. A crush is a fleeting emotion
column2: a moment of intense affection rather than the drawn-out ups and downs of love or obsession. “When I was 27 I crushed a lot
column3: ” O writes in the liners
column4: underlining for emphasis. “I wasn’t sure I’d ever fall in love again. These songs were written and recorded in private around this time.” It’s clear she wanted to get them down on tape before their respective crushes dissipated
column5: and the album culls recordings made from 2006 through 2010. Mostly it’s just O strumming her guitar and singing softly
column6: although occasionally she adds a drum loop
column7: backing vocals
column8: and what sounds like a harpsichord.

column1: It’s an intentionally modest album
column2: perhaps a reaction to the overstuffed Mosquito or to the KO at Home demo leak. It certainly sounds like an extension of her soundtrack work for Where the Wild Things Are and Her
column3: but perhaps it’s too modest: these are all very short songs
column4: with only three out of fourteen surpassing two minutes
column5: and the whole thing runs a short twenty-six minutes
column6: barely registering as a full album. That such brevity is thematically appropriate doesn’t make it any more musically satisfying. Most songs
column7: including first single “Rapt” and even the Doors cover “Indian Summer”
column8: fade out quickly before they’ve even established much in the way of melody or stakes. Only a few sound complete in this lo-fi state: A paean to Michael Jackson
column9: “King” conveys a perfectly apt sense of childlike innocence through both its running time and its playful imagery: “Is he walking on the moon? I hope I don’t find out too soon.” The spoken-word part on closer “Sing Along” heralds some of the album’s most emphatic vocals on the album
column10: yet just as it’s getting interesting
column11: the song stumbles to an abrupt and unceremonious stop.

column1: In its off-the-cuff aesthetic
column2: Crush Songs isn’t too far removed from Karen O’s early work with the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
column3: except that the shrieks of “Art Star” and “Black Tongue” have been replaced by acoustic strums and falsetto notes. For the past decade or so
column4: she has proved herself one of the most surprising and in-the-moment performers of the young century
column5: through not only her vocals but her entire self-presentation: the smears of lipstick
column6: the pre-Gaga outlandishness of her outfits
column7: the unlikely balance of confrontation and communalism she projects from the stage. Even when seemingly every band out of New York was landing a record deal
column8: Karen O lent her band a colorful volatility that their peers couldn’t be bothered to muster. While others played it painfully cool
column9: she put herself as far out there as she could.

column1: So it’s all the more disappointing that
column2: despite the rawness of these recordings and the private nature of their creation
column3: O sounds weirdly noncommittal on Crush Songs
column4: as though the sparse demo arrangements were a form of holding back. It’s no coincidence that the album sounds best when there are several ideas and instruments in play at once
column5: as with the drum loop and harpsichord on “Visits”. But how much better would “Body” sound with even a rudimentary band behind her? How easily might the Yeah Yeah Yeahs turn that half-hearted hook on “Rapt” into a show-closing punk anthem? In the end
column6: very little is gained from the austerity of the presentation on Crush Songs
column7:
and we can only imagine what is lost.

Sloan’s decades-long journey from moody Halifax art-school-shoegaze label purgatory to cool
column2: paternal pop-rock has been characterized by their affability and genial demeanor. Those admirable qualities have overshadowed the band’s considerable ambition: they’ve slapped together double albums
column3: concept albums
column4: and multi-song suites
column5: all stuffed with winding melodies and tight
column6: idiosyncratic vocal arrangements. Commonwealth
column7: their eleventh studio album and first in three years
column8: following graceful career highlight The Double Cross
column9: pays titular homage to both the band’s Canadian heritage and their democratic songwriting partnership. It also manages to break new ground
column10: no small feat when you consider they’ve been at this for a quarter-century: instead of their usual mishmash of each member’s compositions
column11: each of the band’s four members has one full side to themselves
column12: all coming together to make up a sprawling double album. The result is a widely varied collection
column13: one that sheds light on each member’s distinct individual sensibilities and reveals the true strength of Sloan’s usual collaborative refinement process.

column1: There's signature traits that have marked each Sloan album since their 1994 breakthrough Twice Removed. The band is so often
column2: and so easily
column3: defined by their creative debt to the great pop and rock bands of the ‘60s and ‘70s—the Beatles
column4: yes
column5: but also Big Star
column6: Todd Rundgren
column7: and Kiss—that it’s easy to lose sight of their more idiosyncratic strengths. They've never been a band inclined to linger on an idea or melody
column8: even when putting together 30-track odysseys like 2006’s Never Hear the End of It. They get in and get out
column9: expressing themselves with the most possible potency before moving on to something else
column10: and their economy has only improved as they’ve gotten older and more experienced. Every member of the band has written at least a handful of indelible
column11: soaring vocal arrangements
column12: many of which have marked their biggest hits
column13: and all of them possess a distinct
column14: pleasing voice
column15: from Chris Murphy’s nasal charm to Jay Ferguson’s sweet
column16: boyish tenor
column17: with tension in the conflict between their differing tones. They never deny themselves another go at a chorus or hook
column18: never resist another guitar solo
column19: never reject a potential source of pleasure. This set of qualities have made Sloan a beloved band in their home country across multiple generations
column20: even as more ambitious and self-conscious groups have won larger international fanbases and acclaim.

column1: With that larger sense of identity in mind
column2: how does each member’s side deviate from the established Sloan template? Over the course of their four mini-sets
column3: they run from ornate orchestration and delicate melody to heavy-handed riffage and brute force
column4: a range that’s rarely been expressed so widely on their other records. Jay Ferguson’s side hews closest to the Sloan sound that’s familiar to most listeners: straightforward melodies
column5: a balance between melancholy and sunny
column6: peppy tones
column7: and intricate harmonies involving all four members. The purity and delicacy that set his voice apart from his peers in the band remains intact
column8: and he uses it to sell both haunted ballads like “Three Sisters” and brisk stompers like “Cleopatra”. Those two songs close out a mini-suite that includes highlight “You’ve Got a Lot on Your Mind”
column9: and when a quick callback to that song’s melody is snuck into the final half of “Cleopatra”
column10: it’s like waking up and rediscovering a bunch of leftovers after an incredible dinner the night before.

column1: Lead singer Chris Murphy—who’s written more Sloan songs than any of the band’s other members—strikes a middle ground between Ferguson’s gentleness and guitar-based muscle; his songs are differentiated by his sardonic wit and ability to generate a sense of propulsion. “Carried Away”
column2: punctuated with handclaps and jangling tambourine
column3: chronicles the dissolution of an open relationship and ends up seeming like a spiritual sequel to Murphy’s classic Pretty Together single “The Other Man”. On “So Far So Good”
column4: he doles out perhaps the perfect example of his balance between gravity and comedy: “Don’t be surprised when we elect another liar/ Did you learn nothing from five seasons of The Wire?""

column1: The two sides that close out Commonwealth—courtesy of lead guitarist Patrick Pentland and drummer Andrew Scott—are less immediately engaging than Ferguson and Murphy's sides
column2: though for different reasons. Pentland
column3: the writer of most of the band's biggest hits
column4: typically strikes a fine balance between meaty power chords and pleasant melody; here
column5: he opts for sludgy
column6: slow-moving psych-rock riffs
column7: dirtied by an array of effects. It's a major break from the album's first two sides
column8: but not a particularly enjoyable one
column9: and it's hard to get through the full set without yearning for the brightness and levity of the album's first half. Scott's suite marks a return to easily digestible composition
column10: but it's contained within a formidable package: his one song
column11: ""Forty-Eight Portraits""
column12: stretches multiple movements over nearly 18 minutes. It's an impressive show of mental fortitude from the band member who usually tends towards complex
column13: thematically dense tracks
column14: employing a wide range of instrumentation and moving through several distinct moods
column15: but it's not done any favors by its form. It can be tough to find alternate entry points into ""Forty-Eight Portraits""
column16: and it's ultimately rendered somewhat impenetrable.

column1: Perhaps the most accurate characterization of both ""Forty-Eight Portraits"" and Commonwealth as a whole is that of a noble failure. It's an interesting experiment
column2: albeit less fulfilling than the band's best and recent work—but quality and relative position within their deep catalog aside
column3: the album's very existence is heartening. Midway into their third decade together
column4: Sloan aren't content to rest on their laurels or well-honed compositional skills. Instead
column5: they continue to push themselves
column6: refining their craft and toying with concept and form. This combination of curiosity and creative restlessness has rendered them more vital than bands half their age; nearly 25 years after ""Underwhelmed""
column7:
they're still trying to win you over.

On paper
column2: the Black Twilight Circle collective is the most exciting thing to happen to American black metal since Weakling's Dead As Dreams. The tight-knit group of musicians swap around instruments and bands like a cough in flu season and churn out a seemingly endless succession of limited run
column3: lo-fi cassette releases in the collective tradition of France’s<a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_L%C3%A9gions_Noires"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> Les Légions Noires

column1: Mexico's Xibalba and Brazil’s Corubo pioneered the so-called “indigenous black metal” concept

column2: then

column5: too. The Black Twilight Circle’s magnum opus
column6: Tliltic Tlapoyauak
column7: stretches two hours of new music from both established and brand-new members of the collective over three LPs. The collection starts with Kuxan Suum

column6: twisting light
column7: fluttering guitar lines into perverse shapes. Kallathon follows Volahn’s example
column8: relying more on a slower
column9: simpler structure and veering towards full-on on atmospheric halfway through. The atmospheric

column11: and said flute distinguishes itself as the dominant voice within the song

column3: bubbling-under producers: Shlohmo
column4: Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs
column5: Lil Silva
column6: and Sohn have all put their magic on her vocal tracks
column7: and she's built a coherent catalog by sucking the color out of their work
column8: like some ravenous musical Marceline. When it works
column9: the effect is mezmerising
column10: with an atmosphere that hangs thick in the room like incense. But as with any scent so strong
column11: it can just as easily linger and turn stale. Compare the Shlohmo-assisted ""Brain"" with last year's ""Waiting Game""
column12: produced by Sohn. The former seems like a match made in heaven
column13: but Banks ends up duetting with Shlohmo's distorted squalls
column14: and the two lock step into one blandly weary march. ""Waiting Game""
column15: on the other hand

column17: and the only flourish is some wafting gospel vocals in the background.

column1: ""Waiting Game"" is Banks' best moment
column2: a tortured torch song directed at another performer: ""What if I never even see you 'cause we're both on a stage/ But don't tell me listen to your song because it isn't the same."" It originally appeared on London

column4: Jamie Woon
column5: and Tim Anderson. They're also responsible for ""This Is What It Feels Like""
column6: a should-be-smoulderer that can't quite ignite—imagine the writhing bassline from Ginuwine's ""Pony"" turned limp and lifeless. The tender ""Change"" comes from the same EP
column7: while ""Warm Water"" is a holdover from last year as well. Goddess ends up with the hodgepodge feel of a music industry product that was forced to exist
column8: rather than an album that came together naturally.

column1: If London caught Banks at an especially vulnerable moment
column2: showing off her range and raw emotion
column3: then Goddess tries too hard to push in either direction
column4: alternately shrouding her in smoke (""Stick"") or hammily over-emoting (""You Should Know Where I'm Coming From""). Opener ""Alibi""
column5: another Sohn-produced cut
column6: has an impassioned chorus
column7: but her multi-tracked voice dissipates on impact
column8: too wispy and rehearsed. On ""Goddess""
column9: her run-on mushmouth obscures an otherwise fiery scorned lover narrative
column10: and the same goes for the jaunty ""Fuck 'Em Only We Know""
column11: where she practically whispers the chorus as if she were afraid to let a profanity slip.

column1: Buried deep in the album is ""Beggin for Thread""
column2: a brief respite of (relative) sunshine with perky drums and a lilting chorus. Catchy in spite of its desperate lyrics
column3: there are moments where she sounds unpretentious and charming
column4: which is more than you can say for the rest of Goddess. Banks' aesthetic often feels far too cultivated; it's all trendy misery assisted by equally fashionable producers
column5: without any substance to hold it all up. Whenever she does try to get personal
column6: the phrasing and lyrics come off stilted and awkward
column7: the hallmark of a novice songwriter (""What if I said I was built on bricks of carelessness and crumbs?""). Armed with a voice that can go from brooding and low to spine-tingly icy in the span of one musical measure

column9:
and instead seems content to wallow in the same depressive rut for an exhausting 59 minutes.

M.C. Taylor is working for the weekend. “When Satuday comes
column2: I’m gonna rock my soul
column3: ” he promises on Lateness of Dancers
column4: his fourth full-length as Hiss Golden Messenger. “I might get a little crazy
column5: I’m gonna drink some whiskey.” As the piano pounds out an insistent bundle of chords and the guitars carouse and stumble against one another
column6: Taylor draws out that last word
column7: savoring the syllables as though they’re the only thing getting him through the week. The song is less about raising hell and more about chucking your woes aside
column8: unburdening yourself of your trouble and finding precious freedom in merriment.

column1: Harvest is the general theme of Lateness of Dancers
column2: not only marking one season’s labor to ensure survival through the next but also celebrating that work with a bit of whiskey and soul-rocking. Mixing regional folk and country traditions with strains of rock and R&B
column3: these songs strike a tone of convivial toil. Taylor has been working in the music business for nearly twenty years: first in the hardcore band Ex-Ignota
column4: later with the San Francisco outfit the Court & Spark
column5: and most recently and most productively as Hiss Golden Messenger.

column1: Lateness of Dancers
column2: named for a Eudora Welty short story
column3: marks a transition commercially
column4: if not creatively: Taylor’s first three albums were issued by North Carolina upstart Paradise of Bachelors
column5: but this new one is his first for Merge. Taylor may have recorded these songs well before he signed that contract
column6: but compared to previous albums
column7: the arrangements on Lateness are airier
column8: the tempos bouncier
column9: the playing brisker. Largely absent from Lateness of Dancers
column10: however
column11: is the uncertainty that frayed the homespun Bad Debt (recorded at Taylor’s kitchen table)
column12: the prodigal rambling that mapped out Poor Moon
column13: and the spiritual inquisition that made Haw one of the hardiest country records of the decade. These songs are more about the reward that a Saturday provides.

column1: At times Lateness of Dancers may sound too light
column2: but after so many albums made during and about crises of faith
column3: that tone is not unappealing. Taylor invited some of his North Carolina neighbors to back him on these songs
column4: including guitarist William Tyler
column5: brothers Phil and Brad Cook from Megafaun
column6: Mountain Man’s Alexandra Sauser-Monnig
column7: and occasional Messenger member Scott Hirsch. They give the lightness of Dancers a real-stakes feel. On the would-be AM radio hit ""Lucia"" and the holler epic ""Day O Day (A Love So Free)""
column8: the rhythm section in particular instills these songs with a not-quite-carefree spryness that sounds more like Memphis than North Carolina—but generally
column9: they sound charmingly unrehearsed
column10: as though they’ve simply gathered on someone’s back porch for the evening. There’s even a chorus of crickets in the interlude between the title track and “I’m a Raven (Shake Children)”.

column1: Even when things turn dark
column2: the music sounds unbowed. “The misery of love is a funny thing
column3: ” goes “Mahogany Dread”. “The more it hurts
column4: the more you think you can stand a little pain.” Yet Taylor’s delivery is not anguished—more curious than rueful about the travails of romance—and when Hirsch’s organ and Tyler’s Stratocaster take over on the coda
column5: that little pain actually sounds inviting
column6: perhaps even a reward in itself. For some listeners
column7: especially those who might discover Hiss Golden Messenger through this Merge debut
column8: this persistently breezy tone may render the songs inconsequential
column9: and certainly Lateness lacks the gravity of its predecessors.

column1: But that just means this album sounds best in the context of the Hiss Golden Messenger catalog—as a comment on and a celebration of the spiritual and creative toil on the previous albums. It's a much less private record than what came before; in fact
column2: Taylor relishes the company of his fellow Tarheel musicians. “I beat my drum
column3: everybody to come running
column4: ” he sings on closer “Drum”
column5: a new recording of a song that he first set to tape years ago. On Bad Debt
column6: it sounded like a quiet folk manifesto
column7: as though he was laying out plans for a new chapter in his career. On Lateness
column8: the song has the feel of fellowship

column10: tambourine
column11: and banjo. Taylor sounds like a country preacher greeting parishioners as they leave the sermon some bright Sunday morning

column13:
spirit it away.” He no longer carries the burden alone; we all shoulder it together.

Among the pantheon of grizzled rock ‘n’ roll survivors
column3: Robert Plant doesn’t enjoy the same iconoclastic reputation as
column4: say
column5: Neil Young or Tom Waits

From the synth-smoothed pop of his 1980s albums to the deep-seated obsession with late-’60s psych-folk that flourished on 2002’s Dreamland to his dust-up with bluegrass belle Allison Krauss on 2007’s Grammy-winning Raising Sand

column10: cathedral-shattering shrieks) that defined his ’70s tenure in Led Zeppelin. In recent years
column11: he’s come to resemble the golden god who’s fallen down to earth

column14: Arthur Lee) he feels should be just as famous as he is

column1: For his first studio album in four years (and Nonesuch debut)

column1: So for those who worried Plant was settling into a roots-rock comfort zone post-Raising Sand—a theory reinforced by a move to Austin and reports he would only reunite with Jimmy Page on acoustic material—Lullaby reasserts his sense of globe-trotting adventure while retaining the low-key elegance of his post-millennial output. While the song rarely remains the same for Plant
column2: the methodology does: Really
column3: what he’s doing here stays true to the original spirit of Led Zeppelin—i.e.
column4: retrofitting Depression-era folk and blues for contemporary audiences—in a 21st-century globalized
column5: WiFi-accelerated context
column6: bringing together sounds archaic and modern
column7: rustic and exotic
column8: visceral and vaporous. But after years spent reinterpreting the work of others
column9: Lullaby sees Plant stepping up with his first batch of original songs in nearly a decade
column10: answering his band’s derring-do with some of the most bravely confessional writing of his career.

column1: Recorded in the wake of a failed relationship with folk singer Patty Griffin—Plant’s foil in his Cajun-spiced Band of Joy revival from 2011—and a retreat from his temporary home in Texas back to the Black Country
column2: Lullaby doesn’t readily announce itself as a break-up album. It begins with a radical reworking of the 1940s standard ""Little Maggie"" that essentially serves as a warm-up demonstration of the Space Shifters’ pancultural panache
column3: keying on the percussive fingerpicking of the Stanley Brothers version and translating it into stuttering breakbeats
column4: fuzz-covered synth pulses
column5: and the disorienting drone of Camara’s ritti
column6: a one-stringed West African instrument that produces a high-pitched squeal halfway between a violin and clarinet. And with Plant adopting an unobtrusive
column7: airy vocal presence amid the dizzying whirr

column1: Ironically
column2: for an album recorded on Plant’s home turf
column3: Lullaby feels more aesthetically informed by his travels away from it

column5: continent-hopping sound resembling a whirlwind highlight reel from which Plant coaxes moments of quiet reflection. There are coy nods to his past: ""Pocketful of Golden"" shares its opening line with Zeppelin’s totemic ""Thank You""
column6: though its heady sway more closely resembles Plant’s 1983 hit ""In the Mood"" given a bellydancer spin. And ""Poor Howard"" joins his equally impoverished buddy Tom in Plant’s canon of winsome countrified shuffles (and revives the ""pretty little girl with a red dress"" archetype of Dreamland’s ""Red Dress"" in the process). ""Turn It Up""
column7: meanwhile
column8: is the Space Shifters’ chance to get the Led out

column10: but Plant cheekily uses the moment to address the plight of a veteran artist who still gets the majority of his airplay from records he made 40 years ago: “I’m stuck inside the radio/ Turn it on
column11: and let me out!”

column1: Inevitably
column2: with such a free-ranging mandate
column3: there are times where the Space Shifters’ melting pot yields an indistinct gruel: ""Embrace Another Fall"" is Lullaby’s most epically scaled track—loading up on ominous orchestral textures

column6: and a grafted-on passage of an ancient Welsh folk song
column7: ""Marwnad yr Ehedydd""
column8: courtesy of guest vocalist Julie Murphy—but winds up sounding like some late-’90s chillout-comp castaway. Similarly
column9: the closing ""Arbaden""
column10: another reworking of ""Little Maggie"" to bookend the opener
column11: ends the album on an unsatisfying

column13: with Plant seemingly unsure of how the song’s melody fits into its percussive

column15: only for the track to fade out inconsequentially before everyone can get on the same page.

column7: paisley-patterned pop of ""Somebody There"" present golden opportunities to savor Plant’s ageless
column8: eminently graceful voice—especially given that such opportunities appear to be running out. As he recently told The Independent

column11:
there’s enough inspired alchemy here to earn Plant the right to bring it on home.

column13: Our Love to Admire
column14: is typically pinpointed as the moment Interpol started their steep
column15: steady decline.

column1: The chilly reception Our Love to Admire received at the time now seems a little unfair
column2: and possibly the result of cultural fatigue; 2007
column3: after all
column4: was certainly not 2002
column5: and Interpol’s stubborn refusal to show any progress after five years of visibility was a sign to many that the band’s slavish unoriginality was growing stale. In reality
column6: Our Love to Admire represents Interpol at their most Interpol-iest—streamlined songwriting
column7: crystal-clear production
column8: lyrics directly referencing cocaine
column9: a song called “No I in Threesome”—and if it’s not their best album
column10: it’s certainly a hell of a lot better than what followed. The swaggering melodrama and shiny-suit dark pop of Our Love to Admire was
column11: more so than ever for Interpol
column12: redolent of bands from the ‘80s; this time
column13: though
column14: they approached the modern-day equivalent of Duran Duran’s empty-headed brilliance
column15: a fitting full-circle since Carlos Dengler was known to wear a Duran Duran T-shirt during rehearsals for Bright Lights.

column1: Regardless
column2: Our Love to Admire was not a commercial leap
column3: and so Interpol entered a new decade with a return to their old bosses at Matador and their fourth
column4: self-titled album. Easily the band’s worst record to date
column5: Interpol was bereft of hooks
column6: choruses
column7: and other elements that make listening to music enjoyable. Four years later
column8: they've all but disowned the record
column9: judging by their set lists. So it’s understandable to approach the band’s fifth album in 12 years
column10: El Pintor
column11: with suspicion. The album’s title means “the painter” in Spanish
column12: but it’s also an anagram for the band’s name
column13: and the similarities to its predecessor don’t end there: as with Interpol
column14: this new one’s 10 songs long
column15: self-produced
column16: with studio vet Alan Moulder handling mixing duties. The phrase “approach with caution” comes to mind.

column1: El Pintor isn’t “more of the same” in one specific way: it’s Interpol’s first album without Dengler on bass
column2: following his departure in 2010; although Dave Pajo served as his replacement on the tour promoting Interpol
column3: the band’s a trio now
column4: with frontman Paul Banks taking on four-string duties. Dengler’s absence is felt not least by the people in the band; Fogarino recently admitted to NME that Dengler’s talents were “a huge part of [Interpol’s] sound...You couldn’t take that away.” But El Pintor sounds like the work of a band revitalized
column5: for the moment at least. There’s considerable energy in these songs
column6: with just enough melodic smarts for El Pintor to rank as the fourth-best Interpol album—a dubious achievement
column7: sure
column8: but the failure of Interpol makes even that surprising.

column1: There’s nothing here that touches the band’s creative peak
column2: but any of El Pintor’s songs could hang with Interpol’s strongest deep cuts. With a red-herring of an opening that resembles the stately Antics opener “Next Exit”
column3: “All the Rage Back Home” is the strongest up-tempo Interpol single since Our Love to Admire’s “The Heinrich Maneuver”
column4: propelled by Fogarino’s jet-engine drumming and a chorus delivered by Banks
column5: in his distinctive whine
column6: that sounds as wistful as it does festival-ready. The tricky licks of “My Desire” fondly recall Our Love to Admire’s “All Fired Up”
column7: while album highlight “Anywhere” cannily fuses the patient urgency of Bright Lights’ “Obstacle 1” and the proclamatory riffs of Antics’ “C’mere”.

column1: If you’re starting to notice a trend here
column2: then the ultimate failing of El Pintor is apparent: this is the sound of a band feeding on its past
column3: a move that counters the bloodlessness of Interpol with a formula that is as moderately effective as it is uninspired. The slow
column4: elegant majesty of “My Blue Supreme” is a re-trod of Our Love to Admire’s chiming “Rest My Chemistry”
column5: the insistent throb of “Ancient Ways” essentially resembles Antics’ “Not Even Jail” rejiggered slightly
column6: and so on.

column1: The sole surprising moment arrives two-thirds of the way into “Ancient Ways”
column2: when Banks breaks into a brief falsetto that shatters even Randy Jackson’s definition of “pitchy”; it’s quite possibly the most embarrassing thing Banks has ever done on record
column3: and we’re talking about a guy who once sang the lyric “You’re so young/ Like a daisy in my lazy eye” with serious conviction. Lyrically
column4: Banks has long been a punching bag
column5: but his middle-school-poetry approach has grown endearing over time—and it’s also all but vanished from this decade of the band’s work. The most memorable lyric Interpol provided was when
column6: in a bit of unintentional hilarity
column7: Banks moaned “I’m a nice guy” on album opener “Success”; here
column8: it’s on “My Blue Supreme”
column9: in the form of the telling pre-chorus utterance “Only one in a hundred make it/ We fake until there’s nothing to fake.”

column1: These lines could be interpreted a few ways—a commentary on the stylishness that Interpol once so exuded
column2: a self-castigation of the band’s own derivative tendencies—but it could also be seen as a statement of survival. Circa Antics
column3: the major-label-subsidiary market was flooded with Interpol soundalikes that ranged from not-bad to not-terrible to flat-out-awful; they sounded like copies of copies
column4: and by the time the major-label system sunk their claws into the real thing
column5: the whole thing resembled an endless series of funhouse mirrors. With El Pintor
column6: Interpol don’t sound as much like Interpol as they do a band that really wants to be Interpol; it’s a sad notion for anyone who once held this band’s music dear to their hearts
column7: but taking into account what came before
column8:
it’s a miracle that Interpol still exist in this capacity at all.

"|19693.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19693-interpol-el-pintor/|5.9|Larry Fitzmaurice

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20934/homepage_large.2b57f16e.jpg|Endgame|29535.0|Ital|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2014-09-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:38.061150|"

There was always the structure of austere
column2: minimal house beneath Daniel Martin-McCormick's first wave of releases as Ital—it's just that he didn't consider austerity as enough of an end. The two Ital albums that straddled 2012
column3: Hive Mind and Dream On
column4: scattered gristle and grit across otherwise pristine surfaces
column5: whether in the service of the former album's alluringly creeping deep house builds or the latter's spark-flinging energy flashes. The music toed a loose boundary between meditative and unsettling
column6: with both hooky dissonance and tactile ambience working on the base of an intricate 4/4 pulse he seemed just as eager to rivet down as he was to tear up.

column1: But what happens when you peel that noise away? For Endgame
column2: the first Ital full-length to outpace the relatively compact statements of Hive Mind and Dream On
column3: the results tend to drag and blur together even as the ideas are scattered across ten different tracks. Signs of earlier attention-getting juxtapositions linger
column4: like the discolored concrete scars where an empty storefront's signage used to be—remnants of familiar symbols clearly meant to be there
column5: yet conspicuous because of their absence.

column1: It sounds immersive
column2: sure: the record was mastered by Berlin go-to engineer Rashad Becker and mixed by psych/dub/noise polyglot M. Geddes Gengras
column3: and the subsequent atmosphere and attention to detail that brings means it's a fairly satisfying listen just as pure sound. But even when there's a deep subtlety to the percussive layers and focus-shifting chords at the core of these songs
column4: there's not always something to carry them once you're done acknowledging their gradual mutations. The way cymbal loops ricochet off one another (""Relaxer"") or shift from synthesized notes to percussive shards like liquid getting flash-frozen (""Dancing"") can be head-turning. And even if you could make a checklist off the obvious ideas here—there's even a take on vintage acid house (""Coagulate"")—Endgame makes a good case for a dual role as head/body music. Soak in its metamorphoses and stare into space
column5: or let it roll through your system and make every joint feel ready to unwind—there's some decent diversions here.

column1: But the characteristic discomfort and abrasion that set Ital apart from the more anonymous corners of minimal house and techno is dialed back to the point that
column2: half the time
column3: the music dissipates instead of builds. There's an exception or two
column4: though: in particular
column5: ""White II"" leads a late-album charge that finally works with the idea that this stuff can be bristling and intense in the right configuration. There's some honest-to-god suspense in the build
column6: even before high-frequency synth chords start piercing the surface like skin-searing plasma bolts—but it also erases the fuzzy memories of minimalist minor-key gloom that came before it
column7: as though the previous seven tracks were the calm before the storm that he'd usually structure a single track around. The whole album feels like a good enough time if you throw it on in the background
column8: but as a follow-up to a deeper body of work that rides on fascinating ugliness
column9:
why not hope for something that actually commands your attention instead?

"|19706.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19706-ital-endgame/|6.5|Nate Patrin

'Idée Fixe']|2014-09-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:38.656576|"

Jennifer Castle is an enigma hiding in plain sight. On the surface
column3: she’s a Canadian singer/songwriter like so many others
column4: often performing with just a guitar and a stool
column5: singing songs that conjure bygone country
column6: folk
column7: and blues traditions and that are lyrically steeped in richly detailed agrarian scenery and the travails of being a working mom. But Castle’s music is not so much of the earth as floating above it
column8: untethered to the natural order of time and space and often eschewing typical verse/chorus/verse structure to roam according to its own wandering spirit. As Lou Reed famously sang
column9: “between thought and expression lies a lifetime
column10: ” and that’s where Jennifer Castle’s songs live—that grey area where observation mutates into rumination
column11: and where the physical world dissolves into psychic terrain.

column1: Castle's career path has similarly defied linear logic: After recording two albums as Castlemusic
column2: the Toronto-based singer began releasing albums under own name in 2011
column3: the first of which was titled
column4: somewhat confusingly
column5: Castlemusic. (In that time
column6: she also became an in-demand guest vocalist
column7: appearing on albums by local luminaries ranging from Doug Paisley to Fucked Up.) But as is the case with formerly aliased songwriters like Will Oldham and Bill Callahan
column8: the birth-name reclamation has coincided with a greater focus and clarity. Pink City is both Castle’s most warmly intimate and sonically immaculate work to date
column9: forgoing Castlemusic’s naturally psychedelic reverb for a pristine
column10: chamber-pop presentation that places Castle’s radiant voice front and center
column11: amid malleable instrumental backdrops that introduce subtle shifts to substantive effect. Backed by Owen Pallett's palatial string arrangements and a gaggle of veteran Toronto players who’ve long straddled the boundary between the city’s indie-rock and improv-jazz scenes
column12: Pink City is the sound of Castle hitting the pause button on the universe to linger on the beauty and absurdity of the everyday.

column1: For newcomers
column2: Castle exudes an instantly familiar quality: her melding of classic '70s AM-radio gold sounds and indie-schooled idiosyncracies imagines Joni Mitchell on Drag City
column3: while her nocturnal reveries often bring to mind Neko Case—not in voice
column4: but in the way her songs feel both desolate and expansive at the same time
column5: invoking bucolic scenery not to merely admire the view
column6: but to emphasize our humble position within it. (If Case was to ever issue a sequel to Canadian Amp
column7: the daydreamy piano-based serenade “Nature” would be a prime candidate.) But Castle’s deceptively sweet
column8: wry lyricism project her peculiar personality on a widescreen scale
column9: with Pallett’s string swells serving as the portal between her inner and outer worlds. The opening “Truth Is the Freshest Fruit” establishes an idyllic scene of flower-haired hippies frolicking in San Francisco’s Golden Gate park
column10: but it ultimately represents a faded portrait of bliss that Castle can only dream of attaining; as Pallett’s orchestral shrieks pierce through the mix like an encroaching migraine
column11: Castle repeats the line “born at the end of the year” with all the ennui of someone who’s endured a lifetime of having their birthday overshadowed by Christmas and who’s never enjoyed a celebratory piece of cake in the summer sun.

column1: Similarly dispiriting images abound on Pink City
column2: from the communal farmhouse dinner scene on the pedal-steel-powered “Sparta” that will soon be blotted out by the coming winter (whose chilly gusts are summoned with an “Undun”-worthy flute solo)
column3: to the helpless
column4: childless narrator of “Nature” who’s resigned to her lot in life. (“I lift my skirt/ For the economy.”) And yet Pink City rarely feels like a downer of a record; with the exception of the incongruously melodramatic “Broken Vase” (and its “Riders on the Storm”-like vibraphone trickles)
column5: Castle isn’t so much interested in mining despair as the fortitude required to overcome it. <span>(Even if you're in absolutely no financial position to quit your day job and buy a houseboat
column6: the soft-rockin' escapist anthem “Sailing Away” will at least help you keep the dream alive a little while longer.)

column1: In Castle’s hands
column2: even the most seemingly mundane scenes of domestic drudgery simmer with hot-blooded suggestion: the fingerpicked folk narrative “How or Why” is a tale of flora and fawning
column3: functioning as both botany lesson (""digging holes in December means tulips in May"") and an affectionate account of a brief
column4: torrid whirlwind affair. Tellingly
column5: the closing title track revisits the same soil
column6: but long after its nutrients have dried out: “Your old gardens remind me of what’s new in my life
column7: ” Castle sings over a sax-smoked cabaret torch song. But even as she treads upon dead earth
column8: Castle’s connection to nature is potent as ever: with Pink City
column9: she reminds us of how good it feels to be alive
column10:
even when life gets in the way.

"|19652.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19652-jennifer-castle-pink-city/|7.9|Stuart Berman

There’s a beautiful story behind Wooden Aquarium
column2: the third full-length from British Ameri-indie devotees Mazes. It involves travelling to an upstate New York town where their gear was stolen
column3: conditions turned wintery
column4: and the band had to dig their way through thick snow to get to the studio each day. That paints a romantic picture of both isolation and commitment
column5: with the band hunkering down to record as the world turned white around them. While the circumstances surrounding Wooden Aquarium suggest escapism
column6: the music found inside is all grazed knees and furrowed brows—a brush with reality instead of a retreat from it. Mazes’ last album
column7: Ores & Minerals
column8: was a shift away from the slacker-lite indie of their debut. This album is a smaller turn of the wheel
column9: albeit one still indebted to scruffy 1990s guitar-rock figureheads of a plaid-shirted vintage.

column1: The question of identity is something that comes up often with this band
column2: and other British acts (Yuck
column3: in particular) whose adherence to thick walls of guitar fuzz makes it clear they’ve grown up on a strict diet of J Mascis and Ira Kaplan riffs. At least Mazes approach such cross-continental thievery with a dose of wit; the standout cut from this record
column4: “Salford”
column5: pings back and forth across the Atlantic many times. Guest vocalist Heather Strange twists American vowels around singer Jack Cooper’s distinctly English take on the Greater Manchester borough of the title
column6: while the music is a straight throw-down between Pavement and Prolapse
column7: pitching it somewhere between tunefulness and abrasion. In a lyrical sense
column8: it’s Mazes’ most English song to date
column9: making Strange’s contribution feel like a buffer to prevent them from revealing too much of themselves—which in itself gives the song an odd
column10: unique weight.

column1: Cooper rarely stretches the band beyond “Salford”
column2: instead settling into a set of unfailingly polite indie-rock songs centered around gently ambiguous lyrics. There’s an affable swipe at those who think Mazes lean too far to the other side of the Atlantic in the title of “Explode Into Colo(u)rs”
column3: although it’s crafted from a mélange of clear-cut Sea & Cake guitars and the spare atmosphere of old Swell records. The general position of Wooden Aquarium is inward-facing
column4: with highs coming when the band disconnects from traditional songcraft
column5: such as on the merge of chattering voices on “RIPP”—making it something like the well-turned-out cousin of Gang of Four’s “Love Like Anthrax”. There aren’t quite enough moments like that here
column6: and the album could benefit from bringing back some of that diversity in its back half
column7: when it settles into a long bout of well-meaning but ultimately forgettable wistfulness.

column1: Cooper has said he doesn’t like getting compared to other acts
column2: but there’s never a sense that he’s working too hard to get beyond his influences
column3: such as the moment where he adds a little Posies with a dash of Real Estate by way of the Feelies (“Mineral Springs”). The difference between those bands and this one is in the finer details—Real Estate’s best songs
column4: for example
column5: are just a touch brighter
column6: sharper
column7: and more memorable than the ones Mazes have presented here. It’s not the borrowing that’s the problem
column8: it’s the execution and delivery
column9: coupled with moments of distinction (“Salford”
column10: “RIPP”) that suggest this band could touch down in a better place on a more regular basis. On Ores & Minerals
column11: there was a measure of spaciness that’s been lost here
column12: perhaps surprisingly considering the circumstances of its birthing. If that album was a leap
column13: this one is a step
column14:
and a gingerly one at that.

"|19729.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19729-mazes-wooden-aquarium/|6.7|Nick Neyland

There's a large
column2: unusual amount of bullshit to wade through when attempting to engage with SHXCXCHCXSH
column3: a duo from Sweden who make dark techno in a manner that seems to purposefully dissuade outsiders. The duo's identities are anonymous
column4: a ploy that in 2014 is more likely to camouflage 10-year industry vets than shy upstarts. Their name—presumably an attempt to phonetically reproduce a drum pattern—seems designed embarrass anyone asked innocuously by a co-worker
column5: ""Hey
column6: what are you listening to?"" and will likely inspire more copying and pasting than any other artist releasing an album this year. Most importantly
column7: they produce a style of UK techno that
column8: owing its roots to industrial and experimental music instead of Kraftwerk and Parliament
column9: can sound particularly sexless and austere. Indeed
column10: a Google image search (copy
column11: paste) scouting a glimpse of the duo returns a set of results that are hilariously monochrome.

column1: It's worth keeping all of this in mind because the duo's second album
column2: Linear S Decoded
column3: seems all the more impressive for making you forget
column4: or at least forgive
column5: all of these barriers to entry. A humid
column6: moldering set heavy on atmosphere
column7: Linear S Decoded is also rhythmically tricky
column8: sly
column9: and
column10: if you squint
column11: playful
column12: nodding fondly toward ambient and rave music. This
column13: as well as the fact that SHXCXCHCXSH have gone out of their way to craft a capital-a Album
column14: set Linear S Decoded apart from a growing wave of European producers working in techno's blackest margins
column15: a trend that has produced some intriguing works but also a lot of dour
column16: gloom-gloom-hisssss-gloom pounding.

column1: Linear S Decoded spends a lot of time hovering in place
column2: refusing to build momentum—a rarity in a genre where continuous pounding is a prerequisite. There are lots of heavy
column3: distorted noises and no shortage of four-on-the-floor kick patterns
column4: but nothing that should be described as truly punishing; as a result
column5: Linear S Decoded never feels like punishment. They've replaced UK techno's sadistic carnival with a mossy softness
column6: a reminder that while factories and cities decay and corrupt
column7: so do cabins and farmhouses. These are the same ideas that SHXCXCHCXSH explored on their 2013 debut
column8: STRGTHS
column9: an album that too often resorted to dull thudding.

column1: Like a child stopping just short of anything that might merit scolding
column2: SHXCXCHCXSH paw at viciousness without ever committing to it. Songs that might've been unrelenting
column3: throbbing assaults take long strolls through azure ambient passages (""The Roots"")
column4: or they move in fits and starts
column5: eventually collapsing into broken beat litter (""The Under Shore""). The album crests during ""This Hmming Raverie""
column6: offering a serrated synth riff that
column7: in a different context
column8: might've been a cheesy
column9: hands-in-the-air rave anthem.

column1: And it's a fair assumption that SHXCXCHCXSH wouldn't mind if you did throw your mitts skyward. About their name
column2: at least
column3: they have a sense of humor: when asked how to pronounce their name
column4: they responded
column5: ""The Hs are silent. Except that
column6: you do it like it’s written."" Or see the sodden knolls of the final track
column7: cheekily titled ""Monolithic Conclusion"". SHXCXCHCXSH have a light touch with heavy sounds
column8:
and as a result Linear S Decoded is the rare album that allows you to wallow in the techno muck and come out feeling vitalized.

"|19793.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19793-shxcxchcxsh-linear-s-decoded/|7.3|Andrew Gaerig

No matter what phase of Earth you’re considering
column3: be it the enormous and electrostatic drones of the band’s earliest and heaviest days or the swaddled blues elegance of their post-millennial reboot
column4: there’s one simple and unifying link: Dylan Carlson is a paragon of guitar control. On Earth 2
column5: he wielded his instrument and amplifiers with a powerful precision
column6: creating sounds that weren’t only big but also topographically rich; you could study the curves and crags of his sound as if you were reading a three-dimensional map of the Cascade Range. When Carlson rebuilt Earth as an instrumental rock band a decade ago
column7: he used his guitar to cut a filigree of exquisite riffs through the bedrock of Adrienne Davies’ patient drumming. Hearing him play during The Bees Made Honey in the Lion’s Skull suggested a woodworker cutting soft
column8: delicate shapes into an enormous oaken block. Whether working on the monolithic scale of Earth’s origins or through the microcosmic scope of its rejuvenation
column9: Carlson has always handled his duties like a master puppeteer with supreme
column10: expressive sway.

column1: The most telling moment
column2: then
column3: of Earth’s latest LP arrives with “Even Hell Has Its Heroes”
column4: an instrumental that finds Carlson fighting against Earth’s need for stricture and structure with bona fide guitar solos. Above a bed of dense
column5: multi-tracked guitars
column6: he even trades licks with Built to Spill's Brett Netson. The song begins as archetypal latter-day Earth
column7: the notes pneumatically bolted to the beat. Carlson’s tone
column8: however
column9: is a bit more pointed than usual
column10: and he and Netson soon unspool the song’s theme into spirals of variations
column11: taking liberties with their leads rather than submitting to Earth's usual economy. Supported by Netson and producer Randall Dunn
column12: Carlson is free to step out near the seven-minute mark; you can almost picture him with his eyes closed and jaw titled skyward
column13: fingers feeling the strings and flying across them rather than calculating where and when the melody must land. It’s one of the most electrifying moments in Earth’s inconsistent quarter-century history
column14: a genuine rock ’n’ roll climax for a band that’s mostly marched slowly
column15: steadily into the middle distance.

column1: Those licks speak to a restlessness that defines Primitive and Deadly
column2: the first Earth album to feature vocalists since Carlson sang a little in the mid-’90s and since Kurt Cobain and Kelly Canary signed on for the group’s earliest work. Former Screaming Trees frontman Mark Lanegan slips inside two tracks
column3: sending up his dark-eyed observations about destructive dawns and grim landscapes with his static
column4: speak-sing clip. Despite Lanegan’s stentorian voice
column5: he gets lost inside Earth’s latticework
column6: his voice often feeling more like a footnote than a new feature. “Children
column7: children
column8: get ready/ You better get ready/ It’s new revelation time
column9: ” he musters during “The Serpent is Coming”
column10: trying to twist some soulful cadence into his stiff proclamations but coming across like a revival preacher being overrun by his congregation. During “Rooks Across the Gate”
column11: he reads the text of some macabre fever dream
column12: the Carlson-penned lyrics suggesting the murder ballads he’s encountered in his studies of European folk. Despite the scare of the material
column13: though
column14: Lanegan undersells the images. It’s possible to ignore his echo-enhanced voice altogether
column15: to overlook it in favor of the sharp rhythmic interplay between Carlson
column16: Davies
column17: and bassist Bill Herzog. The idea of Earth’s desolate music augmented by harrowing visions solemnly delivered is an intriguing one
column18: but Lanegan’s execution is inchoate and underwhelming. Next time
column19: perhaps Nick Cave
column20: David Tibet and Julian Cope can be on standby?

column1: Where Lanegan missteps by giving Earth a kind of deferential distance
column2: Rose Windows singer Rabia Shaheen Qazi succeeds by using their music as a platform. She commands during “From the Zodiacal Light”
column3: the album’s first single and 11-minute centerpiece. Invoking Ozzy Osbourne and Sandy Denny
column4: she perches above the band to deliver a sermon of fear and salvation. Bewitching and intimate
column5: she represents the vocal fulfillment of the balance between black
column6: white
column7: and gray that Earth has pursued with guitars
column8: drums
column9: and bass for the last decade. The band moves perfectly with her and the words. During the song’s more fraught moments
column10: the trio tenses into moments of feedback and pause; late in the track
column11: when Qazi lingers between the future and failure
column12: the band slinks into a similarly indecisive circle. This is doom metal
column13: delivered with the very grace and meticulous design that’s characterized Earth’s second life.

column1: Earth has now existed for longer and made more records as a set of subtle
column2: almost-quiet instrumentalists than as the jolting
column3: pioneering volume lords that first earned Carlson a reputation. And though the albums made between 2005’s Hex; Or Printing in the Infernal Method and the two-volume Angels of Darkness
column4: Demons of Light set offered variation with a rotation of keyboards
column5: basses and cellos
column6: they all mined a similar aesthetic. Primitive and Deadly even begins by recapitulating every phase of the band’s career
column7: as opener “Torn by the Fox of the Crescent Moon” attaches the finesse of latter-day Earth to a touch of downtrodden
column8: heavy doom. But Earth have seemed overdue for a change
column9: and these songs collectively represent a promising half-step toward it. This is the closest Carlson has ever been to leading a rock band
column10: to fully offloading his exceptional sense of control into a systemic and thorough whole. This isn’t quite
column11: as Lanegan suggests
column12: “a new revelation
column13: ” but sure

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21017/homepage_large.a2ff4a53.jpg|Seen It All: The Autobiography|4718.0|Jeezy|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam']|2014-09-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:42.233410|"

With few exceptions
column2: the release of a major-label record from a hip-hop veteran tends to be inherently sad
column3: a merciful end to its struggle for existence. It carries constant reminders of the indifference it faced in numerous record label offices: catchphrases and namedrops that would’ve been timely had the record dropped a year or so ago
column4: big-name producers appearing as courteous gestures and for quick paychecks
column5: a tracklist riddled with guest verses and collaborations that somehow seem reverent and disrespectful at the same time. As with Jeezy’s previous LP
column6: 2011's Thug Motivation 103: Hustlerz Ambition
column7: all of these things are present on Seen It All: The Autobiography. Similarly
column8: the fact that it’s any good at all might be a greater testament to Jeezy’s skills than his albums that are actually great on their own terms.

column1: You might’ve noticed that Jeezy's dropped the “Young”
column2: but that’s the only time the transitional nature of Seen It All is entirely his doing. The guy is in a spot that makes executive decisions more difficult: he’s still bankable
column3: but not an A-lister. He calls out Def Jam's endless meddling by name in “Me OK”
column4: all while threatening to drop his album on Atlantic. But since it’s the hottest track here
column5: the bosses ostensibly let it slide. Moreover
column6: Jeezy struck up a valuable alliance with DJ Mustard and even if you don't remember a single track from TM103
column7: it still sold 233
column8: 000 copies in its first week.

column1: He’s given tracks from Mike WiLL Made-It and Drumma Boy
column2: which barely sound that different from what Shawty Redd provided Jeezy on Thug Motivation 101: Let’s Get It. But their beats lack that record’s assured sound. Jeezy’s more respected than influential right now—the sound of Atlanta rap bears more in common with the vocal and lyrical unorthodoxy of his former rival Gucci Mane or current collaborator Future—making Jeezy a classic rock riffer in a post-punk world
column3: which means he’s lasted long enough to possibly appeal to the purists who dismissed him back in 2004.

column1: It’s not necessarily an insult to call Jeezy a punchline rapper at this point. That’s what he’s always been
column2: really—his bars were all slogans
column3: ad-libs
column4: and smart/dumb similes that were delivered so confidently
column5: you could only briefly eye-roll before ad-libbing right along with him. He made light of this on The Recession’s “Word Play”
column6: which silenced the “lyrical” heads with half a bar—“I’m way too intelligent/ To play with my intelligence.”  And here
column7: Jeezy delivers a host of howlers with the aplomb and lack of quality control you’d expect from a stand-up working out new material. He’s got birds like Chick-fil-A; however
column8: he’s on the block on Sundays
column9: unlike Chick-fil-A. He boasts about having a cooking show on Netflix called “The Best Bricks”
column10: which
column11: come on—at least call it “House of Birds” or ""Orange is the New Crack"". He also rhymes “Plaxico” with “Texaco” like Gucci Mane
column12: and “Atlantic” with “Atlantic” like Rick Ross
column13: so you're left reminiscing about a time when all three rappers were all actually still beefing and making great music.

column1: This makes Seen It All intermittently enjoyable
column2: even if it completely cuts against the presumed goal of presenting Jeezy as an elder statesman of the South along the lines of Bun B or Scarface. It’s a transformation that’s occurred by circumstance rather than growth; the dude doesn’t tell stories and
column3: while pithy
column4: he doesn’t spit wisdom. Jeezy’s music is post-triumph and visceral
column5: channeling the power of what it feels like to be Trapper of the Year four years in a row even if you're doing concentration curls or a heavy load of laundry
column6: or you're just enduring a long commute back from your office job.

column1: And that’s still the case
column2: as Seen It All: The Autobiography doesn’t deliver on either one of its titular promises. Here’s what we can tell about Jeezy’s life: he experienced much success as a drug dealer prior to rapping
column3: he has a lot of guns and has fallen out with friends over money
column4: and he really thinks you should try Tequila Avion because it's fucking awesome. Given the number of times it's mentioned
column5: Seen It All could pass for a longform Avion commercial; you'd think the first 35 years of Jeezy's life were mere prelude to being named a ""Multicultural Advisor"" for the brand.

column1: Which results in Jeezy being shown up by every rapper who’s willing to offer something close to full disclosure. If not remorse
column2: Lil Boosie shows the real consequences of his jail sentence on “Beez Like”
column3: bemoaning how he missed the first time his daughter had her period. And though he has nothing to gain by doing so
column4: even Jay Z is willing to name names and get specific about his days herbin' 'em in the home of the Terrapins.

column1: Otherwise
column2: you've heard it all on Seen It All: there’s something called “Been Getting Money” and you could probably come up with 85% of it in your head before your first listen. (I’ll spot you “ft. Akon” as a hint.) Conversely
column3: a Jeezy track named ""Black Eskimo"" could never live up to what you think it might sound like. There’s a six minute song with Rick Ross and the Game
column4: which is no fun now that they’re all getting along with each other. The deluxe edition contains “Fuck the World”
column5: which features R&B seat filler August Alsina and is only notable for being a Jeezy love song that isn’t as embarrassing as “Tear It Up”.

column1: But none of this really seems to matter right now
column2: because a 38-year-old man was shot and killed at a Wiz Khalifa concert and Jeezy was recently held in custody with five of his associates on $1 million bail. It will inevitably be used as a “teachable moment” about Jeezy and hip-hop as a whole and make Seen It All a footnote
column3: but those are the least of the problems presented here—a man is dead and Jeezy may have had something to do with it
column4: and even shittier is that you’re reminded of Jeezy’s <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/53511-young-jeezy-arrested-on-charges-of-battery-false-imprisonment-and-terroristic-threats-against-son/"">other
column5: very disturbing 2014 run-in with the law. So maybe the vagueness of Seen It All actually works in its favor: had it been autobiographical
column6:
it may have been even more inherently sad than it already is.

""Oh Lord
column2: I reckon I'm not much just by myself."" So begins ""The Cowboy's Prayer""
column3: a couple stanzas of boot-and-saddle wisdom made famous by Roy ""King of the Cowboys"" Rogers. In 2011
column4: Mutual Benefit's Jordan Lee happened upon a recording of Rogers reciting this ""Cowboy's Prayer"" at the tail end of a cross-country trip he'd taken in the aftermath of Hurricane Irene. Lee
column5: his mind reeling from the scenes of displacement and destruction he'd witnessed in Irene's wake
column6: found something to cling onto in Rogers' time-worn adage. ""Lord
column7: when trails are steep and passes high
column8: Rogers' benediction reads
column9: ""help me ride it straight the whole way through."" These lines quickly became something of a mantra for Lee
column10:
and he named The Cowboy's Prayer—his final EP before his 2013 breakthrough Love's Crushing Diamond—after Rogers' cattleman's litany.

Lee's pre-LCD EPs—many of which are still available for free download on Bandcamp—split the difference between ambition and naiveté; one needs not look much further than Lee tethering a natural disaster and a TV cowboy's sign-off for proof of that. Taken together
column11: however
column12: and a picture starts to form: an eager kid
column13: earnest to a fault
column14: equally besotted and bewildered by the world around him
column15: looking to make some sense of being young in the old
column16: weird America. Lee's penchant for dressing up his dewy pastorals in heavy syrup was in place pretty much from the jump
column17: but on those early EPs
column18: there's a frequent disconnect between the two sides
column19: one he would eventually close as the years trickled on. At its best
column20: the five-song
column21:
15-minute Cowboy's Prayer feels like a dry run for what Lee would accomplish with Love's Crushing Diamond.

Opener ""Auburn Epitaphs"" matches an effects-spackled piano loop with a pair of ambling guitar figures
column22: as Lee—his voice sweet
column24: the sound of a guy still Figuring It Out—grapples with the supposed futility of writing about something larger than himself. The plaintive
column25: banjo-led ""Passenger"" breaks into a cloud-parting chorus before the whole thing's swept up in swirl of spectral synths. With the benefit of hindsight
column26: it's easy to see all the elements of LCD there in this opening twofer. Yet the balance isn't quite right: the songs are more halting
column28: and the accoutrements distract nearly as often as they delight. The faint pulse and nest of wriggling keyboards that kick off ""The Cowboy's Prayer"" seems to betray Lee's fascination with the so-called ""lap-pop"" of the early '00s
column29:
a curiously uncharacteristic experiment that lets a heavy-handed arrangement to crowd out the threadbare melody behind the fluttering electronics.

Going back through the early EPs
column30: it's clear Lee's knack for letting involved arrangements blow through his songs wasn't always in place the way it happened to be on on LCD. By the time The Cowboy's Prayer rolled around
column31: he'd found a way to keep the scraping strings and rustling chimes from overpowering the songs; yet ""The Cowboy's Prayer"" itself is an overreach
column32: the kind of I'll-try-anything juvenilia Lee had to work out of his system before landing on the more surefooted sound of LCD. With its flickering triangles
column35: ""Backwards Fireworks"" takes its sweet time getting going. But once Lee starts in on the ""burning highway effigies"" he'd witnessed—or maybe dreamed—on his post-Irene jaunt through the country towns
column37: a fractured middle-American fairy tale set to the plunk of a couple-three banjos. Unfortunately
column38: instrumental closer ""招魂""—which translates to ""evocation"" or ""spiritualism""—seems more ""sketch"" than ""song
column39:
a backdrop begging for a little more action in the foreground.

In a 2013 interview with Pitchfork's Ian Cohen
column40: Lee described a chance meeting with a St. Louis-based violin player named Jake Falby that helped shape the sound of Love's Crushing Diamond. ""The record originally had Casio violins… but after he did these beautiful arrangements
column41: I spent another eight months tweaking it so that it was absolutely perfect to me."" Though Lee remains Mutual Benefit's only permanent member
column42: it's clear that what he'd envisioned for The Cowboy's Prayer—that searching
column43: starry-eyed Americana—came to fruition on LCD through time
column45: and more than a little outside help. Lee would soon shed some of the more intrusive
column47: letting the conceptual dot-connecting fall by the wayside
column48: and bringing his songwriting closer to the forefront. By the time The Cowboy's Prayer—clumsy in parts
column50:
Lee was clearly closing in on something. But it wasn't until Love's Crushing Diamond that Lee would follow that path straight the whole way through.
