By Nick Zammuto’s measure
column2: the Books didn’t end well. ""I’m still too close to it to talk about it without getting angry
column3: the vocalist/multi-instrumentalist for the defunct collage-pop duo told Pitchfork back in 2012. When asked about the pointed lyrics on his self-titled solo debut from that year
column4: he opened up a little bit more: ""Everyone’s got a brass robot in their lives that they want to tear a new one
column5: right?"" He went on to refer to his last record with Books member Paul de Jong
column6: the meditative 2010 effort The Way Out
column7: as ""an optimistic attempt to see if it could still work""; although the record stands as the slightest in the Books’ singular catalog
column8: its mix of new age affectations
column9: torrents of rhythmic underpinning
column10: and straightforward humor never suggested the work of two people having trouble staying in the same room from each other.

column1: Even though Zammuto described his inaugural solo bow as ""about making that difficult decision to cut your losses and move on
column2: the record brimmed with a giddy sense of wonderment. Endings are hard
column3: though
column4: and two years later
column5: it doesn’t quite seem like Zammuto has come full-circle in the grieving process. The video for ""IO""
column6: a single from his second solo album
column7: Anchor
column8: seems innocuous at first
column9: a documentation of Zammuto and cohorts building a large-scale catapult to set soaring a variety of objects into the surrounding scenery (perhaps a visual equivalent to the artist’s more frenetic musical moments). It seems to be all in good fun—that is
column10: until the 1:20 running mark
column11: in which the HP computer used to make The Way Out is loaded
column12: launched
column13: and smashed into the ground. When it lands
column14: Zammuto himself is seen gleefully running after it with a sledgehammer
column15: which he makes use of on the surviving hardware.

column1: So the specter of  failure still looms over his work
column2: and it’s hard not to see Anchor as an extension of that mood. The frozen
column3: wintry album art is the inverse of Zammuto’s verdant-spring look
column4: and what’s inside is similarly chilly
column5: a downcast collection of tunes that counts as Zammuto’s most low-key work since the Books’ underrated 2005 LP Lost and Safe. The record marks a specific shift in Zammuto’s sound—more straightforward
column6: less nervy
column7: a Rube Goldberg device replaced with a single manual lever—but there are a few moments where his earlier sound shines through. ""Need Some Sun"" rests on daisy-chained thrums of bass strings
column8: Zammuto’s silvery voice weaving in and out of the web the four-stringed instrument weaves; a burst of bleeps gently disrupts the sparseness of ""Great Equator""
column9: while album closer ""Code Breaker"" engages in some intricate tonal work that should please anyone who’s taken comfort in former Emeralds member Mark McGuire’s expansive rock hypnosis.

column1: Otherwise
column2: Anchor lacks excitement and Zammuto’s trademark ingenuity. He sounds uninspired and bored
column3: with arrangements that rustle unhurriedly and a sense of stiff formalism reminiscent of Andrew Bird collaborator Martin Dosh’s conservatory-school post-rock solo work. Even in Zammuto’s and his former band’s most uninspired moments
column4: their music sounded like little else out there. By comparison
column5: Anchor goes as far to feature a cover of sorts
column6: unheard of in Zammuto’s little corner of the world—specifically
column7: a rendition of the traditional folk song ""Henry Lee""
column8: which has been covered before and with greater success. Zammuto’s take is static and muted
column9: with a small cinematic wash providing the tune’s only source of tension.

column1: Anchor’s quiet
column2: indifferent drift is disappointing
column3: but the album’s biggest misstep
column4: paradoxically
column5: is also its boldest cut: ""IO""
column6: which pairs flatulent bass with a swaggering vocal performance from Zammuto and a drum beat befitting Eddie Money. The brief entrance of stiff
column7: obtrusive strings underlines its inherent off-putting qualities
column8: and even though it appears on a record that could use some thrilling moments
column9: “IO” is the wrong type of disruption. Still
column10: even though Anchor is a truly disappointing work from such an inventive mind
column11: it’s not enough to suggest that he’s reached the point of creative bankruptcy. Perhaps it’s best to think of Anchor as more catapult fodder
column12:
another artifact to be launched into the air and destroyed in search of a fresh start.

Few dance music producers have established a voice quite as singular as Roman Flügel's. That's ironic
column2: because in his two decades as a solo artist
column3: he's recorded gritty acid fugues
column4: limpid deep house
column5: knotty breakbeat hardcore
column6: and clean-lined minimal techno
column7: among other styles
column8: both pure and hybrid. His cheeky 2004 single ""Geht's Noch?"" was an unwitting midwife to a squawking strain of big-room EDM; the following year
column9: he teamed up with the vibraphonist Christopher Dell for Superstructure
column10: a collection of diffuse
column11: freeform techno-jazz. (For most club music producers
column12: a release like the latter would be the outlier in his or her catalog
column13: but in Flügel's case
column14: it's the populist
column15: over-the-top club jam that remains the exception.)

column1: But Flügel's signature remains legible in pretty much whatever he does
column2: despite the stylistic diversity of his catalog. (That range is one reason he's used so many aliases over the years
column3: including Roman IV
column4: Soylent Green
column5: ro70
column6: and Eight Miles High
column7: in addition to his and Jörn Elling Wuttke's shifting collective identity as Alter Ego
column8: Acid Jesus
column9: Holy Garage
column10: et al.) He's got a way with rippling
column11: wriggling drum patterns
column12: and his knack for daubing on tonal elements proves him to be a skilled pointillist. His ear for nuance and his feel for balance let him take the most shopworn sounds—an unadorned drum machine
column13: a crackling breakbeat
column14: a wily TB-303—and make them sound
column15: if not exactly new
column16: indisputably his.

column1: That's truer than ever on Happiness Is Happening
column2: which builds on the principles he set out in 2011's Fatty Folders in playful and sometimes surprising ways. Reflecting a newfound sense of focus in his work
column3: the latter was his first album released under his own name; the new one widens its scope without forsaking any of its cohesion. At its core
column4: the record foregrounds a strain of house music that's wispy but wiry
column5: favoring all his usual trademarks: scratchy analog drum machines
column6: lush pads
column7: quirky little quasi-melodies
column8: and glassy FM synthesizers with the sour clang of oil-drums half-submerged in water.

column1: A few of the tracks easily could have fit on Fatty Folders or any of the club-oriented EPs he's released between then and now on labels like Dial and Live at Robert Johnson. ""Stuffy""
column2: sounding anything but
column3: is classic Flügel: a percussive
column4: energetic workout marked by brittle drums and a colorful
column5: pinging melody. The expressive way that the track's cymbals twitch and flare confirm him as one of our most talented hi-hat programmers. ""Your War Is Over"" plays with similar ideas
column6: as kalimba-inspired synthesizers pluck against watery chords; though nominally four-to-the-floor
column7: the kick drum is little more than a shadow of itself
column8: which aids the track's weightless drift. ""We Have a Nice Life"" plays with dance-floor convention in similar ways
column9: opening with two minutes of beatless drones before pulling itself up by its bootstraps—well
column10: its arpeggios
column11: anyway—and morphing into a jaunty set of variations on an Italo-house theme
column12: all whispery shakers and laser zaps. (There are only about four elements in play
column13: yet no two bars of the song are the same
column14: proof of Flügel's commitment to composition as a process of perpetual mutation.) And the slower ""Tense Times"" stretches those same Italo influences
column15: like rubbery bass arpeggios and rich
column16: major chords
column17: into a dubby fantasia that sounds like the Orb gone disco. It's muscular but dreamy
column18: the kind of contradiction that Flügel savors.

column1: But a goodly portion of Happiness Is Happening finds Flügel stretching out and trying out new styles—or styles new to his catalog
column2: anyway.  The delightful ""Friendship Song"" borrows the chord changes from Grimes' ""Oblivion"" and turns it into a Depeche Mode song circa Speak & Spell
column3: and ""Wilkie""
column4: similarly springy and similarly naïve
column5: strikes up a dialogue with the New Order of Power
column6: Corruption & Lies. (That might sound to you like a wholly unnecessary exercise
column7: but once you hear the way he handles the subject matter—gentle but authoritative

column9: this time by fusing the snap and crackle of early '80s electro with the apocalyptic klaxon blasts of early '90s rave music

column1: Two songs in particular show what a versatile producer he can be.  The opening ""Connecting the Ghost"" explores a slow-fast ""motorik"" pulse
column2: its stately
column3: chugging beat a foil for Flügel to indulge in creamy textures and squealing oscillators; the quick-stepping ""Occult Levitation"" offers little more than a steady patter of lawn-sprinkler hi-hats and rosy sunrise glow. Both
column4: in their way
column5: are genre studies—Krautrock and techno

column8: deft touch
column9: and expressive
column10:
unmistakable voice.

It’s hard to imagine a project better suited for the age of enormous festival gigs and indie auteur-focused action movie soundtracks than M83. In the 13 years since Anthony Gonzalez and then-collaborator Nicolas Fromageau released the project’s first
column3: self-titled record
column4: the kind of big tent
column5: feelings-forward electro-rock hybrid that they made has become
column6: in some permutation
column7: the base stock of most popular indie acts. While My Bloody Valentine were—and remain—a good point of reference for M83’s sonic textures
column8: Arcade Fire are perhaps a better touchpoint for their overall approach: lead with emotions telegraphed big and wide enough to fill a stadium
column9: and let the guitars and synthesizers fall into place around them.

column1: This trilogy of reissues beautifully tracks the evolution of Gonzalez’s work from student film
column2: to limited-release
column3: to blockbuster. It also marks a very clear progression from an accessible
column4: emotional electronic music project to what Brandon Stosuy aptly described as “high-concept emo embossed with glittery snow angels.” The story of these three records is not that of Gonzalez filling his music with progressively more embellishment
column5: but rather of Gonzalez learning how to reorganize the core of his musical vision around that embellishment. The glass baubles of M83 became the rhinestone earrings of Dead Cities
column6: Red Seas & Lost Ghosts
column7: which became the crystal chandeliers of Before the Dawn Heals Us.

column1: Sure enough
column2: M83’s self-titled debut album is their stateliest and most deliberate work. The album’s song titles point further towards an emo narrative
column3: but the music itself only hints at this kind of heavy-handed heartstring-tugging; for better or worse
column4: this is M83 introducing themselves as an electronic project with strong emotional undercurrents
column5: and not much deeper than that.

column1: Dead Cities
column2: Red Seas & Lost Ghosts is a transitional record that bridges the gap between M83’s relatively understated beginnings and their bombastic recent output. Listening back 11 years later
column3: it’s notable how messy Dead Cities is; though it still operates in something that resembles an electronic music paradigm
column4: much of its energy is crowded into the upper-midrange frequencies that usually pile up when layering distorted electric guitars. A synthesizer-heavy crescendo is often followed by a bigger
column5: heavier crescendo
column6: with more sounds and ideas piled on even if there isn’t really room for them. Dead Cities makes its case through sheer scale and force of will
column7: constantly running up against the limitations of its own construction. It's dramatic music embroiled in its own internal drama
column8: and it succeeds on slightly different terms from any subsequent M83 record.

column1: Nowhere is this particular formula better articulated than “Run Into Flowers”
column2: the debut single from Dead Cities and one of the most achingly
column3: incessantly beautiful songs Gonzalez has ever released. It layers buzzing synthesizers
column4: dramatic synthesized strings
column5: humming synthesizers
column6: gently sung vocals
column7: and even more synthesizers to create a vast
column8: overpowering swell that starts big and only seems to grow bigger. “0078h” builds to a dizzying crescendo
column9: as beats collapse over themselves and synthesized voices ping-pong unintelligibly like a computer struggling with its own sentience. Even the bleepy and bloopy “Cyborg” builds to a satisfyingly organic conclusion that honors its part-human
column10: part-robot namesake.

column1: And indeed
column2: it’s that human element
column3: in the form of the human voice
column4: that comes to greater prominence post-Dead Cities. Before the Dawn Heals Us marks a number of notable changes from its predecessor
column5: including the departure of Fromageau and the reworking of the M83’s aesthetic from tasteful electronic minimalism to broad-stroke ""Miami Vice"" expressionism. To whatever extent Dead Cities seemed corny when compared to other electronic albums
column6: Before the Dawn Heals Us is corny and overstated by nearly any measure. But on Before the Dawn Heals Us
column7: Gonzalez actually makes room for all the bombast of his songs. The single “Don’t Save Us From the Flames” finds Gonzalez embracing not just the energy of rock music
column8: but also its dynamics. The drums—or
column9: rather
column10: “drums”—protrude forcefully
column11: rather than getting swallowed up in synthesizers and static. There's a clear and appreciable distinction between lead synths and synth pads. Verses pull back
column12: choruses kick forward.

column1: And then there are the vocalists—including
column2: fittingly
column3: actress Kate Moran—who are cast more like players in a movie than singers on an album. From “Can’t Stop”
column4: which sounds like one of those '70s soft rock infomercials pitched up and put on a loop
column5: to “Car Chase Terror”
column6: which narrates pretty much the exact scenario its title describes via a woman’s voice over the phone
column7: each of the best songs on Before the Dawn Heals Us not only find a unique voice
column8: but also a unique way of situating it. Insofar as Dead Cities evokes people
column9: places
column10: and things through sound and texture
column11: Before the Dawn Heals Us puts those people
column12: places
column13: and things front and center in a very literal way.

column1: Sure enough
column2: the remixes included in the bonus EPs are instructive primarily because they tease out these individual elements
column3: lay them out in a more linear fashion
column4: and give them room to express themselves in a less frantic and busy context. One gets the sense that
column5: when presented sequentially
column6: each of the instrumental tracks in a single M83 song could fill up an entire record. The B-sides included here fall predictably short
column7: largely because they seem to lack the over-the-top commitment of their album counterparts. These songs are
column8: for sure
column9: host to their own subtle charms—but subtlety is not Gonzalez’s strong suit
column10: nor is it what this kind of music calls for. M83's records certainly don’t fall apart under close scrutiny

Makonnen Sheran dubbed himself iLoveMakonnen when he was on house arrest in 2008. He had been headed for the Air Force
column2: but a tragic accident with a friend's gun
column3: which Makonnen described in heartbreaking detail to BuzzFeed
column4: ended with his friend dead in a car shortly after their high school graduation. Sheran
column5: who was in the car
column6: was implicated
column7: and his life's direction changed.

column1: He spent his resultant exile trawling MySpace and broadening his musical tastes—the Killers
column2: Bloc Party
column3: Adele
column4: and Lil B
column5: whom he enthusiastically interviewed on his blog. He also posted rough cuts of his songs
column6: which fumbled ecstatically toward some synth-heavy fusion of all of them. Some were raw
column7: unformed blobs
column8: but there were hints of an aesthetic moving beneath. He reached out to everyone he admired and began quietly laying the groundwork for his career.

column1: All this context is already old news—at least
column2: since Drake cleared his throat and launched Makonnen's career into the stratosphere. His latest release
column3: the iLoveMakonnen EP
column4: features production from Metro Boomin and Sonny Digital. He's at the center of the rap conversation
column5: but he also represents the most recent goal post in the ongoing expansion of what a rapper can be.

column3: coke
column4: Molly and lean—and throws together some bars on ""I Don't Sell Molly No More"". But mostly
column5: he sings
column6: and he does so in a rich
column7: untrained
column8: wobbly voice
column9: with an expressive tenderness unheard of even in a rap world with Drake at its center. (When Drake hopped on Makonnen's ""Club Goin Up on a Tuesday
column10: he had to adopt an even-softer voice than usual.) ""I wasn't trying to be no hip-hop
column11: Makonnen told BuzzFeed
column12: describing the development of his sound. ""I didn't give a fuck about drums. But I knew what to do to get the looks I wanted to get.""

column1: The fourth song on the iLoveMakonnen EP
column2: ""Tonight""
column3: is an airy
column4: strobing house song
column5: with a hip-tugging syncopated bass line and diaphanous layers of synths floating above like hand scarves. Makonnen's melodies have a theatrical swoop to them; ""Sarah"" has the arc and fever pitch of a Broadway power ballad
column6: and on ""Too Much""
column7: he lets his voice dip into a Nate Dogg-y basso profundo before leaping into a startlingly unvarnished higher register
column8: his voice shaking and nearly cracking.

column1: The mood of the EP is primarily lovelorn and wistful
column2: with a series of songs directly addressing the girls in his life. Each of them gets named directly—Brianna
column3: Shoshanna
column4: Sarah—and it's hard not to attribute this behavior to Drake
column5: who made all his long-gone exes famous. Drake probably leapt on ""Tuesday"" because he heard a burgeoning star bearing his direct influence
column6: and he likely signed him directly to his OVO imprint for the same reason—as Jay Z said in the 2000 concert film Backstage
column7: when you find your successor
column8: you sign him.

column1: When Makonnen raps
column2: as on ""I Don't Sell Molly No More""
column3: he sounds nothing like Drake. There is something loose and bemused in his voice: This isn't really what I do
column4: his vocal tone says
column5: but hey
column6: I'll give it a whirl anyway. There are echoes of his favorite rappers
column7: people like Gucci Mane and the all-important BasedGod
column8: in his cadences and patterns
column9: but the song itself is a prop
column10: a chance to try out some juicy-sounding words. Makonnen's music fairly beams at you with this self-satisfied serenity: even his songs about selling drugs have the weightlessness of a stage full of paper-mache props.

column1: This might sound like a criticism
column2: but that play-acted feeling is one of the most satisfying parts of Makonnen's world. Like Atlanta's previous two rap breakouts
column3: Makonnen has used his unique talents to build a reality-distortion bubble
column4: a place where rap's rules slide off the sides. That bubble swelled to a big enough size that we get to pass through and explore it
column5:
and watch rap giants try to contend with it.

"|19774.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19774-ilovemakonnen-ilovemakonnen-ep/|8.0|Jayson Greene

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20843/homepage_large.1b6356c5.jpg|Clearing the Path to Ascend|4719.0|YOB|['Rock'
column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Neurot']|2014-09-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:45.995727|"

It’s been over forty years since Black Sabbath
column3: Pentagram
column4: and their kin founded the Church of Doom
column5: one of metal’s oldest and most enduring houses of blasphemy. These days
column6: metal’s gnarled family tree has blossomed into a dizzying number of subgenres
column7: but almost all of it comes back to doom
column8: regardless of tempo or texture. Doom may center itself around stoned stupor
column9: Satanic camp
column10: and sick riffage
column11: but it also possesses a meditative musical mode buried deep inside it
column12: a glassy-eyed glance into life’s grimmest mysteries.

column1: Earlier this summer
column2: Arkansas's Pallbearer provided a winning example of this approach with their esoteric
column3: genre-ignorant Foundations of Burden
column4: and now the always-crushing YOB have returned with a similarly-striving epic called Clearing the Path to Ascend. With seven excellent albums and over a decade of experience under their belt
column5: the esteemed Oregon outfit have long since established themselves as one of the most progressive acts of their generation. Psychedelic rock
column6: stoner rock
column7: stoner metal
column8: blues metal
column9: ambient: all reside comfortably in YOB’s wheelhouse
column10: coalescing and collapsing on a path that stretches as far as the listener’s imagination. The band's most recent effort
column11: 2011’s Atma
column12: took its inspiration from the Eastern concept of “the higher self”—a theme they fleshed out with droning
column13: circular mantras and monolithic instrumentation. YOB take similarly transcendent strides on Clearing the Path to Ascend
column14: reshaping the traditionally-forlorn moans and groans of doom into an amorphous roar that
column15: however hellish
column16: shimmers with something resembling hope.

column1: As is typical with YOB (and doom in general)
column2: enlightenment doesn’t come easy. Clearing the Path to Ascend contains only four tracks
column3: each surpassing the ten-minute mark and the heaviness of a black hole. On opener “In Our Blood""
column4: philosopher Alan Watts offers some soothing instructions—“Time to wake up”—before gingerly stepping aside for a rude awakening: Mike Scheidt’s banshee-like wail
column5: accompanied by swooping
column6: sullen guitars. Bassist Aaron Rieseberg and drummer Travis Foster handle the majority of the heavy lifting
column7: but it’s Scheidt’s singing that drives the band’s metamorphic energy. He’s not a singer so much as he’s a shaman
column8: using his diverse range of grotesque death growls and plaintive melodies to toy with the listener’s preconceptions
column9: especially where identity is concerned.

column1: Such is the queasy fun of ""In Our Blood""
column2: Scheidt's sixteen-minute trip to hell and back. His thin
column3: feeble tenor coasts along smoothly for the first several minutes
column4: but before long
column5: something wicked reaches beyond the void and snatches up the melody
column6: leaving in its place the sound of utter ruin. Scheidt's chameleonic vocals present the band with an ever-replenishing resource from which they derive some of the album's most lasting material: the unfurling
column7: feminine ""Unmask the Spectre""
column8: which is situated alongside ""Marrow""
column9: the album's defiant death knell of a closer.

column1: YOB’s latest record stands as one of their densest
column2: so it's good that the band's greatest asset
column3: their impeccable pacing
column4: remains intact. “Unmask the Spectre” plays out as a masterclass in dramatic tension
column5: its punishing core buffered on both sides by moody
column6: barren sludge. At last
column7: Scheidt finally unleashes his thunderous yell
column8: a solo nipping at its heels—and before long
column9: he's whispering again
column10: dragging everything back into the gloaming. The power of darkness depends on contrast
column11: so by spacing out their otherworldly confrontations
column12:
the Oregonians ensure that the true path lay ever in sight.

"|19617.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19617-yob-clearing-the-path-to-ascend/|8.2|Zoe Camp

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20943/homepage_large.ff147fee.jpg|Mean Love|9729.0|Sinkane|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['DFA']|2014-09-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:46.414942|"

Ahmed Gallab has spent the last six years slowly refining and reducing the scope of his music. When the Sudanese sometimes-session musician started on his own as Sinkane
column2: his work resembled the rustling
column3: windswept breeze of post-rock—2008 debut Color Voice and the following year’s self-titled effort could’ve been easily mistaken for the sprawling instrumental work coming out of Chicago in the late ‘90s. But as he vacuumed up more sonic influences
column4: the music contracted. Mars from 2012
column5: Sinkane’s breakout effort
column6: was an appealing mix of Afropop rhythms and dance music’s slinkier tendencies
column7: as Gallab restrained his leg-stretching tendencies with pop-focused structures that nonetheless possessed a jammy feel. His latest
column8: Mean Love
column9: is his most direct and concise collection of songs yet
column10: distilling his compositional talents and reining in any attendant looseness.

column1: This overall trajectory isn’t dissimilar to that of the band he’s most known for contributing to
column2: Brooklyn aesthetes Yeasayer
column3: who made a name with distinctly proggy
column4: expansive-sounding music before whittling down their rougher edges. But while Yeasayer have experienced a creative decline in their search for a simpler expression
column5: Gallab continues to improve his sense of songcraft. Earlier this year
column6: he acted as musical director for ATOMIC BOMB! The Music of William Onyeabor
column7: a celebration of the Nigerian synth-pop pioneer that included contributions from David Byrne
column8: Devonté Hynes
column9: and Hot Chip’s Alexis Taylor
column10: among others. On Mean Love
column11: Gallab exudes a similar sense of adventurousness
column12: and he liberally wields Afropop influences with confidence; the cascading horns and easy
column13: continuous beat of “New Name” resemble the hypnotic ebullience of luminaries like Tony Allen and Fela Kuti poured into a small-scale mold.

column1: Showcasing a stylistic restlessness that works in Gallab’s favor
column2: Mean Love’s try-anything spirit is sometimes reminiscent of the electro-pop of Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bundick
column3: with Gallab’s smooth professionalism replacing Bundick’s good-natured amateurishness. More favorably
column4: Gallab’s pleasing upper vocal register and genre-bending tendencies recall Dan Snaith
column5: the mastermind behind the influence-inhaling Caribou project (Gallab was a live drummer for Caribou for a time) who’s proved a master in creating pop music that’s emotive
column6: brainy
column7: and brawny. Snaith’s airy voice tends to float over the music
column8: and Gallab similarly hovers over the slow drumbeat and jettisoned synths of “Son”
column9: the album’s lyrical high point. ""Son"" finds its creator ruminating on familial pressures and the eternal conundrum of finding a place within one’s point of geographical origin: “There’s a pressure to being your eldest/ There’s such pressure to make you the proudest...I will not forget where I came from.”

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Gallab tackles slow-moving funk
column3: spaced-out psychedelic pop
column4: and peppy tropicalia with confidence. His creative malleability is impressive
column5: even if the results don’t always excite; in particular
column6: a few cuts on the album’s back half (the languid title track
column7: “Galley Boys”
column8: the twangy closer “Omdurman”) take on countrified shapes with brushes of slide guitar
column9: a stylistic turn that is structurally sound but not as engaging as Mean Love’s other genre excursions. It seems almost unfair
column10: though
column11: to criticize Gallab for the minor crime of engaging with a sound that’s not as inherently interesting as what he’s proven capable of elsewhere
column12:
as Mean Love cements his reputation as a capable musical wanderer willing to engage with a variety of sounds. 

"|19715.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19715-sinkane-mean-love/|7.2|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20905/homepage_large.03429b91.jpg|Blaze of Glory|32416.0|Game Theory|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Omnivore']|2014-09-04 00:00:00|1982|2016-06-11 16:33:46.881231|"

College rock is an archaic term at this point in the taxonomy of music—it became subsumed by alternative rock right around the time R.E.M. first went platinum—but even as a relic of the 1980s
column2: the genre retains a distinct identity. Sophisticated
column3: precocious
column4: cerebral
column5: and self-aware enough to playfully poke at its own pretensions
column6: college rock played a key role in the evolution of '70s post-punk into '90s alternative—a path that Michael Azerrad only touches on in his parallel
column7: punk-heavy chronicle of the '80s American rock underground
column8: Our Band Could Be Your Life. Above all else
column9: college rock was an archly clever form of guitar pop
column10: the kind that found a home on college radio stations in the '80s. It had no qualms about fostering wider ambitions
column11: though; it didn’t need to directly address the college experience
column12: let alone be played by college students. Yet the entire
column13: decade-long lifespan of college rock can be neatly bookended by two songs penned by college-spawned bands
column14: and that even reference specific schools by name. The later of the two is “U-Mass”
column15: released in 1991 by Pixies; the earlier one is “Bad Year at UCLA”
column16: released in 1982 by Game Theory.

column1: Game Theory may be the quintessence of '80s college rock
column2: but the band is synonymous with Scott Miller. The singer-songwriter—who died in 2013 at the age of 53 and was the group’s only constant member throughout its eight-year existence—formed the band in 1982 as a reassembly of his prior outfit
column3: Alternate Learning. Blaze of Glory
column4: Game Theory’s debut album
column5: came out the same year. In the wake of Miller’s death
column6: it’s being given a deluxe
column7: expanded reissue
column8: an extravagant treatment for a record that was recorded in Miller’s old bedroom at his parents’ house in Sacramento not long after he finished his studies at nearby UC Davis. Alternate Learning was his college band
column9: and their two releases—1979’s ALRN EP and 1981 Painted Windows full-length—created a template not only for Game Theory
column10: but for much of college rock to follow. The name Alternate Learning even sounds like the missing link between alternative rock and college rock.

column1: Four selections from ALRN and Painted Windows appear among the fifteen bonus tracks on the Blaze of Glory reissue
column2: and they’re a potential-rich premonition of what would come; Painted Windows’ “Another Wasted Afternoon” is baroque on a budget
column3: a wannabe Left Banke or Zombies daydream strained through post-punk starkness and denuded of ornamentation—unless you count frantic polyrhythmic drumming and ice-rink organ fills as frilliness. And ALRN’s “What’s the Matter” is as close to punk rock as Miller ever came
column4: a distorted rush of sunny melody that feels like a beach-party Buzzcocks.

column1: Alternate Learning’s cocky innocence holds up wonderfully
column2: but Game Theory served as Miller’s graduate program in pop songcraft. While at UC Davis
column3: he’d bunked with a fellow aspiring songwriter
column4: Steve Wynn
column5: who moved to Los Angeles and formed the Dream Syndicate in 1981. But where the Dream Syndicate (and the Paisley Underground movement that sprouted up around it) updated West Coast psychedelia for a post-punk world
column6: Game Theory rolled itself out on new-wave training wheels. As opposed to Alternate Learning
column7: who deserve to be ranked just below the Feelies in the jittery-nerd pantheon of the American post-punk era
column8: Game Theory branch into Devo-esque
column9: back-’n’-forth jerkin’ on “White Blues”; that engagement with the new wave zeitgeist circa 1982 goes deeper on “The Young Drug”
column10: whose keyboard-clipped angularity and furtive Beatles worship echoes what XTC was up to at the time. “It’s not 1962”
column11: Miller yelps on “The Young Drug”
column12: and it might as well be a psychedelic manifesto for the skinny-tie set.

column1: While never as kaleidoscopic as his Paisley Underground counterparts
column2: Miller spikes Blaze of Glory with one of his most flagrantly trippy compositions
column3: “Stupid Heart”
column4: a venom-dripping
column5: flange-smeared odyssey of romantic dystopia. Nothing screams “my college years” like petulantly bitter love songs
column6: and Miller goes on obliging. On “All I Want Is Everything”—as peppy as ALRN’s “What’s the Matter”
column7: only minus the pseudo-punk fuzz—Miller sings
column8: “Don’t ask me why/ I get so happy” as he spits the ironies and paradoxes of attraction into Cupid’s teeth.

column1: “Sleeping Through Heaven” is Blaze of Glory’s keenest glimpse into Miller’s inner workings. He named Game Theory after the mathematical analysis of conflict
column2: decision
column3: and logical strategies—Miller himself wound up working in computer engineering—and the lyrics to “Sleeping Through Heaven” lean heavily toward that titular theme. “I will play the deck no matter how much it’s stacked
column4: ” he sings with wispy
column5: soaring melancholy
column6: before delivering an anthem-worthy slogan: “I want to go bang on every door/ And say
column7: ‘Wake up
column8: you’re sleeping through heaven.’” There’s an underlying lushness to its otherwise Spartan
column9: synth-braced structure— a flowering around the edges that recalls contemporaries like the Psychedelic Furs
column10: although Miller himself more closely resembles Robyn Hitchcock in all his Soft Boys glory. He goes on to add
column11: “Maybe I’m too dumb to stay depressed”. Miller’s lyrics are as subtle
column12: self-negating
column13: and quixotically triumphant as his flippantly complex chords and melodies. Post-collegiate ennui might be the most privileged state of existential angst imaginable
column14: but Miller milks that First World problem for all the pathos it’s worth. As Franklin Bruno writes in “Blaze of GI—: Scott Miller: An Appreciation” from The Pitchfork Review #2
column15: “‘Sleeping Through Heaven’ knows what it wants to say
column16: and enough about how it needs to be shaped to put the point across.” More than anything
column17: that emerging confidence in the face of the gaping chasm of the future is what makes Blaze of Glory so exhilarating.

column1: But it’s “Bad Year at UCLA” that emblemizes Blaze of Glory. The song is iterated three times on this reissue: there's the album version
column2: a charmingly rickety live version
column3: and a thirty-second acoustic reprise that’s more of a crosshatched sketch. Combined
column4: they flesh out the full range of Miller’s vision at Game Theory’s outset: from singer/songwriter idleness to twitchy new-wave populism
column5: “Bad Year at UCLA” combines Miller’s various ambitions into a single
column6: vivid document. “You’re wondering if pain so beautiful/ Should earn a happy ending
column7: ” he bleats
column8: his voice boyish and vaporous.

column1: Game Theory are often pegged as power pop
column2: but that genre
column3: as great as it can be
column4: is comparatively junior high to Miller’s post-grad ruminations on purpose
column5: destiny
column6: and the vicissitudes of lust. Blaze of Glory’s title sardonically hints at some kind of fatalism
column7: as if the album might have been Miller’s first and last real stab at immortality. Illustrating his own contradictory nature
column8: he packaged some of the original copies of the LP in a trash bag. Instead of being a desperate one-shot
column9: though
column10:
Blaze of Glory wound up as an inspired beginning.

"|19679.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19679-game-theory-blaze-of-glory/|7.2|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20990/homepage_large.c88cbb16.jpg|Barragán|395.0|Blonde Redhead|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kobalt']|2014-09-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:48.204360|"

The next-to-the-last song on Blonde Redhead’s new album
column2: Barragán
column3: is titled “Penultimo”. Since when have Blonde Redhead been so literal? Since 2010’s Penny Sparkle
column4: if we’re being honest
column5: a lackluster album that traded in the trio’s lush
column6: fathomless mystique for little more than a cellophane wisp of no-calorie beauty. It sparkled
column7: and that was about it. Four years have passed since then
column8: and while it may be perfectly reasonable to expect the group responsible for entrancing albums like Melody of Certain Damaged Lemons to return to form at some point
column9: that point is not reached on Barragán.

column1: Calling Barragán halfhearted would be giving it too much credit
column2: both effort-wise and emotion-wise: it’s a cold fish of a record
column3: dead-eyed and clammy. Singer/guitarist Kazu Makino has always kept her voice solemn and controlled
column4: but the sense that there's something vast being held behind that mask is gone. ""The One I Love” is about as compelling as tears plopping into a bucket
column5: a hollow exercise in vague
column6: impressionistic storytelling set to an limp art-pop track of acoustic guitars and flutes. “She does nothing all day/ But sit down and cry
column7: ” Makino chants like a bored chorister. The ennui is so on-the-nose
column8: it’s oppressive.

column1: The album is stubbornly unassertive. “No More Honey” is the closest Barragán comes to featuring a flesh-and-blood song
column2: but lead guitarist Amedeo Pace’s swells of My Bloody Valentine-like riffage are kept on a short leash
column3: then quickly shooed away. Ambient noises are sprinkled throughout—birds
column4: what sounds like a typewriter
column5: echoes of echoes with no discernable source—but they serve no purpose other than punctuating the emptiness of the music surrounding them. It’s a recurring theme
column6: but one without a point—unless
column7: as with the shuffling
column8: exhausted-by-its-own-existence “Penultimo”
column9: Blonde Redhead are trying to write songs that are featherweight and leaden at the same time.

column1: Blonde Redhead began dabbling in electronic sounds on 1998’s “Missile + +”
column2: and they go down a similar path on two Barragán tracks
column3: “Dripping” and “Mind to Be Had”. Neither use those icy pulses to decent effect; the former teases with glimpses of ghostly melody without fully coming into focus
column4: and the latter is a nine-minute slog of ping-ponged monotone. “Defeatist Anthem” sums it up best: Makino coos and sighs expectantly
column5: and for a second
column6: it seems like something—anything—might take flight. Then it just squirms in a circle of listless prettiness. “We wanted to make something timeless and pure
column7: and perhaps a little minimalist too
column8: ” drummer/singer Simone Pace recently said in an interview. Instead of timeless
column9: though
column10: Barrágan is static; instead of pure
column11: it’s blank; instead of minimalist
column12: it’s stingy.

column1: This year marks the 20th anniversary of Blonde Redhead’s second single
column2: “Vague”/“Jetstar”
column3: their first for Steve Shelley’s Smells Like Records imprint. Accordingly
column4: the single sounded a lot like Sonic Youth
column5: from its soft
column6: discordant buildup to its cyber-psychedelic climax. The band went on to master that nervy dynamic
column7: and many others
column8: during their late '90s/early '00s peak. They effortlessly recontextualized avant-rock
column9: electro-pop
column10: shoegaze
column11: and white noise. Their back catalog is a deep well of potential to draw from
column12: and it's enough to make you wish that Penny Sparkle had only been a fluke. Four years later
column13: though
column14:
all Blonde Redhead has to show for its lengthy studio hiatus is another too-obvious bauble.

"|19760.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19760-blonde-redhead-barragan/|4.3|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21021/homepage_large.a57800d3.jpg|Indigo Child|32477.0|Raury|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-09-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:48.712932|"

Eighteen-year-old Atlanta songwriter Raury is exactly the type of performer that makes record companies salivate in 2014. Though the sound of his full-length debut Indigo Child is tough to pin down
column2: listening to his music easily conjures comparison to beloved acts of this generation: André 3000
column3: Bon Iver
column4: Kid Cudi
column5: Frank Ocean. He is reminiscent of Lorde
column6: another teenage shuffling disparate interests—rap
column7: folk
column8: EDM—into something logical. And like Lorde
column9: Raury has a nose for the sky-scraping moment and knows how to make a big song seem personal. If you had to bet on an artist-on-the-verge becoming a big star
column10: there are worse bets.

column1: Indigo Child serves as a perfect introduction to Raury’s style-sampling aesthetic
column2: as well as the blizzard of sometimes-undercooked ideas he brings to the table. On “Superfly”
column3: he borrows liberally from the melody of Kid Cudi’s “Day 'n' Nite”
column4: switching from rapping to reaching for the heavens with a soulful breakdown. “God’s Whisper” aims unabashedly for an exultant campfire singalong and mostly nails it; “Wildfire” is a string-laden track resembling something a teenage André 3000 would have made if he had never met Big Boi
column5: steering Raury into a trance-like climax where he paraphrases Lil Wayne’s “The Block Is Hot”. Though the ideas come from a variety of points existing on the pop music spectrum
column6: Raury’s warm production helps Indigo Child achieve a general coherence
column7: a testament to his ability to organize the swirling nature of his sound.

column1: Indigo Child shows all the hallmarks of promise
column2: but the music doesn't always live up to the prevailing comparisons that have been thrust upon the teenager. Though many of Raury’s ideas are strong and linked together in interesting ways
column3: sometimes he doesn't quite hit his mark. Album closer “Seven Suns” is an eight-minute
column4: staring-at-the-sun style melter that feels gratuitous
column5: while the record's other large-sized
column6: orchestrated moments feel a little hollow (""Chariots of Fire"") with lyrics that take on the form of of empty teenage philosophizing (“I shared my cigarette with her/ I fucked her every Wednesday evening/ Why do you always use that word/ When you don't even know its meaning?”). Overall
column7: Indigo Child is an intriguing blueprint for Raury's talent
column8:
and watching Raury continue to put it all together going forward will definitely prove fascinating. 

"|19790.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19790-raury-indigo-child/|6.5|Corban Goble

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20982/homepage_large.954bc789.jpg|Beyond the Black Rainbow OST|6562.0|Sinoia Caves|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar'
column2:
'Death Waltz']|2014-09-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:49.398658|"

As a kid growing growing up on Vancouver Island
column3: Panos Cosmatos spent hours at his local video store
column4: which was then still a new kind of business in North American suburbia. He would browse the endless racks of VHS boxes
column5: especially curious about the fantastical illustrations that lined the horror and science fiction sections. His mother and father (a cinematographer and director whose most famous credits are Rambo: First Blood Part II and Tombstone) wouldn’t let him watch scary movies
column6: but as Cosmatos told Filmmaker Magazine
column7: he would “spend hours looking at the box covers… just imagining my own versions of them.” Decades later
column8: those made-up stories would eventually coalesce into his first feature-length film
column9: 2010’s Beyond the Black Rainbow
column10: a mesmerizing period-piece headtrip sci-fi horror thriller that inevitably became a cult favorite.

column1: As origin stories go
column2: that’s a good one. And it’s borne out by the film itself
column3: which borrows liberally from the past but proves less specifically referential than
column4: say
column5: any Tarantino flick. On first viewing Beyond the Black Rainbow seems visually arresting yet thematically vacuous: The story crawls
column6: yet (or because) each frame is meticulously composed and shot. There’s a strange doctor treating a young woman who is so sedated she can barely speak and whose long
column7: black hair obscures her face to give her the appearance of a j-horror wraith. There’s the suspicious Arboria Institute
column8: straight out of a Cronenberg flick; there are red stormtroopers called sentionauts
column9: two doomed heshers
column10: and the coolest Lotus Esprit since The Spy Who Loved Me. On repeated viewings
column11: however
column12: all of these fantastical elements begin to push forward certain themes—generally
column13: an older generation preying on a younger one. More specifically
column14: it seems to locate the roots of the present generation’s addiction to mood-altering drugs in the Baby Boomer’s pursuit of enlightenment through mind-altering hallucinogens.

column1: Because the film delivers so much of its information visually rather than through expository dialogue—a trick more filmmakers should try—the music must be both bold and nonintrusive
column2: gingerly reinforcing the imaginary 1983 milieu without rendering it as novelty. Working under his Sinoia Caves alias
column3: Jeremy Schmidt has crafted a soundtrack that nods to the early VHS era but is never too specific in its nostalgia; this is music made to tell a story
column4: or at least part of one. Schmidt
column5: a member of the Canadian indie-prog outfit Black Mountain
column6: knows this territory well: In 2002 he released his Sinoia Caves debut
column7: The Enchanter Persuaded
column8: which expertly mixed cosmic synths and kosmische sequencers. Schmidt took a few years to subtly and meticulously rearrange the major suites from his Black Rainbow score into a work that alludes to the movie but should work for people who’ve never even heard of Panos Cosmatos. In doing so
column9: he has done what neither Daft Punk nor M83 could pull off: He has created a soundtrack that works as an imaginative and often moving standalone album.

column1: Just as Cosmatos drew from his own memory to craft the movie
column2: Schmidt seems to have composed this music based on hazy memories of old soundtracks. There are sly nods to John Carpenter and Goblin
column3: Jan Hammer and Jon McCallum. He uses voices well
column4: an old trope that horror flicks have used to imply some ritualistic terror but here sounds more benign—as though Schmidt is peopling Cosmatos’ often empty frames. On opener “Forever Dilating Eye”
column5: a bodiless choir sings the wordless theme
column6: then fades into a quick pulse of dwindling syllables. The effect is that of humans being broadcast via unreliable technology. Those strange vocals reappear at times throughout the album
column7: until they are finally answered by a mechanistic monotone from the movie about better living through chemistry.

column1: “Elena’s Sound-World” recalls Giorgio Moroder’s work for Oliver Stone
column2: but what’s more impressive is how sympathetic the song is toward the title character
column3: imprisoned in the weird Arboria Institute. The pulsing sequencers and bodiless choir of voices not only sound startlingly tender (echoing the sensitivity with which Cosmatos finally shows her face)
column4: but the song grows larger with each measure
column5: as though imagining a wide world beyond the confining walls. On the other hand
column6: “Run Program: Sentionauts”
column7: with its towering organ riffs and prismatic synthesizers
column8: conveys nothing but danger and dread as it reimagines a Popol Vuh Herzog score as a teen slasher soundtrack.

column1: In other words
column2: this is music that tells a story—that
column3: crucially
column4: makes its own powerful statement—even when detached from Beyond the Black Rainbow. It ebbs and flows in dramatic arcs
column5: from the fluttery hush of “Arboria Tapes – Award Winning Gardens” to the foreboding synths of “1983 – Main Titles.” The album builds as it proceeds
column6: such that the errant drones and earth-rattling chords of the seventeen-minute “1966 – Let the New Age of Enlightenment Begin” supply rising action and the eerie prog bombast of closer “Sentionauts II” creates a climactic conclusion. In both the film and its soundtrack
column7: there is a constant sense of opening out: Elena’s world grows larger and larger as she ventures from her cell into the wide world
column8: while Schmidt’s score similarly sounds like it is forever dilating
column9:
at least until the last synthburst fades.

Two young boys stare out from the cover of Double Youth
column2: and only one of them is Roberto Carlos Lange. The New York-based
column3: Florida-born producer/singer who goes by Helado Negro doesn't remember who the other one is. Face-painted and serious
column4: they both seem to be taking a moment out of one of those perfect childhood days to oblige a parent's request for a keepsake. The cover of Lange's fourth LP is a photo of a photograph that he found unexpectedly in his parent's house; its tears
column5: curls
column6: and age spots are captured in full as part of the composition. Fittingly
column7: Double Youth
column8: the boldest and most intricate Helado Negro work to date
column9: grapples with memory and its uncanny tendency to wear away despite our best intentions to preserve it.

column1: Double Youth follows a trio of ambient
column2: mood-based EPs
column3: shifting emphasis to structure
column4: motion
column5: and beats. It's the first time that Lange's lyrics
column6: which as always shift effortlessly between English and Spanish
column7: aren't the most concrete feature in his music. Synth figures grind together like clockwork on ""It's Our Game""
column8: which owes some of its playfulness to Jimmy Tamborello's work with the Postal Service and as Dntel. The bass line that tumbles through the song acts more as a counterpoint to Lange's phrasing than a part of the rhythm section
column9: although the line between the beats and everything outside the beats here is a porous one. The 8/8 time signature becomes something for Lange to challenge
column10:
not submit to.

Later
column11: ""Myself On 2 U"" entertains a Boards of Canada-esque flutter while gulps of analog synths and backing soprano map out the chords. The menacing ""Triangulate"" rides a bristling industrial bass whose ascending phrases seem to leer at Lange's layered chants. ""We'll take our time/ And we'll crawl to you
column12: he sings
column13: as if extracting threats from the dissolving context of a dream. Throughout Double Youth
column14: Lange's words follow dream logic rather than concrete narrative. He uses language not as a key to the album's core but as another texturizing element
column15: rolling out commands that sound more natural in Spanish than they ever could in English: ""llamame"" (""call me"")
column16: ""dejame"" (""let me go""). On ""Queriendo""
column17: he pronounces the Spanish equivalent to the album's title
column18: ""doble juventud""
column19:
a phrase whose syllabic density gives it an inherent rhythm of its own.

The album's gentle hallucination crystallizes on lead single ""I Krill You""
column20: a slowly unfolding suite with a patient melody at odds with its rapid techno pulse. Lange builds the song only to break away at its midpoint to a synthetic choral moment
column21: leaping lucidly from the club to the cathedral. ""It's a dream
column22: a dream
column25: calling to an unseen other with the sort of longing that usually only survives inside Arthur Russell albums. Spritzes of synth brass stand in for slashes of cello; the beats pile
column26:
but never overwhelm.

Double Youth plays as an exercise in reconciling forgotten artifacts with present memories
column27: as anyone who's had the chance to rifle through their former possessions and discover evidence of a totally alien former self knows the uncanny feeling that's articulated so effectively on Helado Negro's latest. The album's title refers most transparently to the twin figures on its cover: two boys being young side by side. But it can also describe the shadows we leave for ourselves
column28: the youth we remember crashing into the husks of youth we discover. Helado Negro animates that conflict
column30:
but harmony in the gaps between selves.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20880/homepage_large.fdaf1f55.jpg|Live in Ravenna|28493.0|Moon Duo|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2014-09-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:50.693831|"

Like their mothership act Wooden Shjips
column2: drone-rock outfit Moon Duo—aka Shijps builder Ripley Johnson and musical/romantic partner Sanae Yamada—are not ones for dramatic dynamic variation. They instantly set a psychedelic scene and then spend the next several minutes retracing it
column3: until all the lines blur into a sound that’s constantly morphing and hypnotically static at the same time. However
column4: for this new
column5: limited-edition live album
column6: the duo effect a change that
column7: if not radically reorienting their core aesthetic
column8: at least turns their very band name into one big typo.

column1: While Johnson and Yamada’s job descriptions respectively bill them as singer/guitarist and keyboardist
column2: Moon Duo’s recordings to date have deployed drum machines to bolster their motorik momentum. However
column3: their summer 2013 trek through Europe marked the first time they lugged a proper kit on tour and enlisted a full-time stickman
column4: John Jeffrey
column5: who
column6: following a recommendation from the band’s manager
column7: was hired without so much as a single audition. Of course
column8: it helps that Moon Duo aren’t the sort of band to trouble budding percussionists with complex arrangements or tricky cues to remember. But the show documented here presented Jeffrey with a trial by fire all the same—by having him furiously hammer on the same beat for upwards of 10 minutes at a time in the thick of what was apparently a brutal heat wave. (And even though the Ravenna show was performed at an outdoor beachside stage as opposed to a claustrophobic club
column9: the stifling temperature still prompts Johnson to make a mid-set plea for towels.)

column1: You can feel all that sweat and humidity dripping off this recording
column2: which corrodes the skillfully sculpted fuzz and laser-like rhythmic precision of their studio albums with enough grease and grime to constitute a fire hazard. And with Jeffrey’s imposing kick-drum thump and chain-whipped
column3: tambourine-rattled backbeats added to mix
column4: Moon Duo feel come off less like the blissed-out soundtrack for melting into your rec-room shag carpet than a gang of toughs ready to start a rumble on an overcrowded dancefloor. The big-boom effect also illuminates how Moon Duo savvily update the influence of their canonical psych-punk forbears: the beefier versions of “Mazes”
column5: “I Been Gone”
column6: and “Goners” refashion the Spacemen 3 as the ultimate go-go party band; “Free Action” reroutes Suicide’s “Rocket USA” into a foot-stomped heartland hoedown.

column1: Aside from that last track—which gets distended to double the length of the version heard on 2012’s Circles—Live in Ravenna surprisingly doesn’t stretch Moon Duo’s hypno-rock rave-ups too far beyond their original parameters
column2: nor does it yield any significant rethinks of the material. So
column3: on top of capturing the band at an intriguing new phase of their evolution
column4: Live in Ravenna effectively functions as a handy
column5: compact compilation of Moon Duo’s three albums to date (if underscoring their uniform vibe). For more casual trippers
column6: this could be all the Moon Duo you need—but don’t sleep on the digital-only bonus track
column7: “Set It On Fire”
column8:
which caps off this hot August night with an incendiary collision of Fun House fuzz and “Tomorrow Never Knows” drum rolls that makes you hope an official rebranding into Moon Trio isn’t too far off.

Juan MacLean represents something of an archetype DFA artist: a reformed indie rocker who immersed himself in synth gadgetry and surrendered to the groove. He typifies the behind-the-scenes
column3: slave-to-the-music vibe from which so much dance music springs
column4: and like any great dance artist
column5: Maclean's best work has come via his singles (""Happy House""
column6: ""You Are My Destiny""). If James Murphy was the quarterback of the DFA roster
column7: then Maclean was the president of the AV club.

column1: If there's any extra urgency or excitement surrounding Maclean's third studio album
column2: In A Dream
column3: it's that DFA now lacks a flagship act
column4: and Nancy Whang—frequent collaborator
column5: In A Dream cover star
column6: justification for the definite article preceding the Juan's name—seemed to be a burgeoning creative force herself in the waning days of LCD Soundsystem. Her work on In A Dream is among her best: brassy and affecting
column7: she sings like a punk rocker whose feet have warmed to disco but not her heart.

column1: Which is just as well: Maclean and Whang have been distilling the funk/punk out of this project since 2005's still beloved Less Than Human. To wit: within about a minute of the album's start—the cardio motorik of ""A Place Called Space""—we're treated to a searing guitar lead. What Maclean and Whang have settled on here is a more muscular
column2: downtown version of the type of reedy disco-pop that Lindstrøm & Christabelle explored on Real Life Is No Cool. In A Dream is hi-def synth boogie
column3: flexing and preening in ways its forbears simply couldn't
column4: as if old Ze Records and italo-disco classics had spent the last 30 years in the gym packing on studio wherewithal and audio fidelity.

column1: When everything comes together
column2: In A Dream is spectacular. ""I've Waited For So Long"" whips around hurriedly as Maclean and Whang trade verses and choruses. ""Running Back To You"" is a slo-mo bass gargle
column3: with Whang's salt-corroded vocals bristling against the perfectly formed contours of the bass synth
column4: which Maclean walks carefully on a leash for the song's duration. ""A Simple Design"" is the most compact
column5: finest ever summation of this partnership
column6: a simple
column7: danceable track that finds the two dancing around each other
column8: Whang's ""la la la""s providing ample space for Maclean's flights of fancy before she grabs the chorus by the throat and caresses it gently.

column1: Problems that have persisted throughout The Juan Maclean's output crop up here as well. Maclean is a less frequent and less irksome vocal presence than on prior records
column2: though he's still uncompelling
column3: pushing through the shoulda-been-anthemic peaks of ""Love Stops Here"" with affectless utterances. Maclean is a masterful synth programmer but not a singular one
column4: and so sometimes In A Dream resembles those beautifully built urban townhouses
column5: trading sturdiness for creativity and sapping some of the fun in the process.

column1: That's the harshest grenade you can throw at In A Dream
column2: though: it's too comfortable and robust. When the duo come in for the requisite 10-minute
column3: album-closing jam
column4: it feels earned
column5: and it's motive and charming enough not to bore. In A Dream is Maclean and Whang's most fruitful
column6: balanced partnership
column7: and if it fails to truly make a star out of either of them
column8:
it cements them as the kind of ever-evolving collaboration DFA was built on.

Nonchalance can be brash. Across three albums in the late 2000s
column2: Vivian Girls' mix of girl-group sweetness

column4: and proto-grunge sludge won them an adoring cult

column6: Ramone (born Cassie Grzymkowski) has continued to evince a dedicated dispassion. Kickball Katy
column7: the bass player
column8: has stepped to the front over three increasingly confident albums with the melancholic
column9: day-dreamy La Sera. Ali Koehler
column10: the drummer
column11: has also taken over the mic for the intrepid fuzz blasters of Upset. Founding Vivian Girls drummer Frankie Rose graduated into the richly colored synth-pop epitomized by 2012's outstanding Interstellar. Ramone
column12: by contrast

column1: The Time Has Come is Ramone's solo debut

column1: As with most of Ramone's work
column2: there's an admirable lack of apparent affectation across the album
column3: which should help make it welcome in all places predisposed to love—or even just like—her back. Reverb-soaked and shambolic
column4: with the occasional tambourine or fluid guitar solo
column5: the songs address dark days (""Song of Love"")

column7: and enduring affection (""I Send My Love to You""). Despite the low-key recording setup
column8: flourishes here or there break up the potential monotony
column9: as when the nocturnal acoustic gallop of ""I Don't Really Wanna Go"" goes off into psyched-out lava-lamp burbles. Even when Ramone tends toward the tender-hearted melodies of great '90s indie-pop duo the Softies on ""Sensitive Soul""
column10: she stays deadpan enough to allay the twee-allergic.

column1: Lo-fi bedroom pop prophet Ariel Pink guests on bass for almost every song
column2: but his presence is understated. The Time Has Come's press materials cite '60s Greenwich Village enigma Karen Dalton
column3: and though the title has been used many times
column4: one notable instance is English folkie Anne Briggs' breakout 1971 album. The grassroots movement where Ramone's effort would fit best is '90s indie culture
column5: right down to the handwritten look of the cover text and the doodles on the record's inner label.

column1: Part of that culture
column2: of course
column3: was the idea of the slacker. Ramone flirts most directly with that image on ""I'm a Freak""

column5: ""a bad egg just ready to crack

column7: particularly on the dirge-like ""Joe's Song""
column8: she comes across instead like someone who likes her perfectly good eggs a bit undercooked. This is the paradox in which Ramone finds herself: her allure is partly her insular don't-give-a-fuckness
column9: but that can only get her so far. It's hard to say whether she would benefit from the more generous approach to do-it-yourself recording seen on Karen O's ""Rapt"" or even Out Hud member Molly Shnick's self-titled Jean on Jean album several years back; she's not them. This much is clear: The Time Has Come is two songs shorter and about the same number of minutes longer than the Vivian Girls' 2008 debut album

column12:
but the time for Ramone's next nonchalantly brash big statement may be still to come.

column7: do it
column8: do it

column1: There’s a scene in Jeff Feuerzeig’s 1993 documentary Half Japanese: The Band That Would Be King in which the band is performing on a makeshift stage for the residents of Duplex Nursing Home in Boston (made famous by David Greenberger’s long-running zine Duplex Planet). column2: Ga. trio started out as an avant-doom band—1996’s Courtesy and Good Will Towards Men featured broken piano interludes and a tortuous cover of Leonard Cohen’s “One of Us Cannot Be Wrong.”—then

column2: there are moments where it feels like a killer lyric from Tanner or Creston Spires

it's hard to accept Things as Tanner’s true return.

The debut album from Nickelodeon star-turned-pop force Ariana Grande
column2: last year's Yours Truly
column3: had charming qualities that also turned out to be unsustainable. Marked by the sort of puerile whimsy that can only really happen once a career
column4: it split the difference between doe-eyed doo-wop and remember-the-'90s pop-R&B (the latter intentionally courting the ensuing Mariah comparisons). Grande proved just the type to pull off this sort of broad-stroked pastiche: she’s a theater kid at heart
column5: slipping in and out of characters with practiced finesse (she’s got an arsenal of impressions on YouTube
column6: from Britney Spears to a crying lamb). In a way
column7: it was a risk—these sorts of throwbacks were
column8: if not totally unfashionable
column9: decidedly out of season.

column1: But it was a calculated risk
column2: one that blatantly positioned Grande as a wholesome
column3: PG-rated alternative to the ratchet Mileys of the 2013 pop spectrum. Despite her obvious training—what more can be said about That Voice?—there was a pointed adolescence to Yours Truly
column4: down to the eerily infantilized (and wisely scrapped) initial album art. And the Instagram-filter nostalgia
column5: though pretty damn adorable
column6: often rendered the project impersonal. Though it’s her calling card
column7: Grande’s voice doubles as a weapon and a shield; amid all the puppy-love ballads
column8: the album’s emotional centerpiece had her professing her undying love
column9: not for a boy
column10: but for a piano. And fittingly so: the emotional charge of Grande’s music comes from the rush of singing as an act
column11: the clear delight she takes in the power of her own voice
column12: moreso than whatever she’s actually singing about.

column1: On My Everything
column2: Grande ditches the manic-Disney-dream-girl ballads and goes straight for the bangers; while it may not be as consistent a statement as Yours Truly
column3: it’s refreshingly grown-up. It’s no coincidence that the album’s two lead singles were produced by Max Martin
column4: the guy who practically defined millennial pop bildungsroman and
column5: 14 years ago
column6: penned “Oops!…I Did It Again” and “Stronger” for a transitional Britney. They might be the year’s strongest one-two punch of singles: “Problem”
column7: with its alluringly strange reverse-build-up (Grande’s howling pre-chorus primes us for an even bigger release
column8: only to drop impishly into Big Sean whispers
column9: mirroring the un-met expectations of the song’s bad-news boyfriend)
column10: and the Zedd-produced stomper “Break Free”
column11: a colossal kiss-off that doubles as a “Stronger” for the EDM age. Grande’s side-step to the dancefloor feels pre-ordained
column12: rather than a cash-out: “Break Free”’s festival-closing ambition perfectly pairs with her stadium-sized voice
column13: and injects some much-needed femininity into EDM’s typical machismo.

column1: Where Yours Truly was willfully off-trend
column2: My Everything reveals a better understanding of “cool
column3: ” even if it occasionally misses the mark. Here
column4: Grande exists gleefully in her own age
column5: rather than gesturing vaguely towards a second-hand idea of “retro.” Even when the plinky soda-fountain sounds of her debut trickle back in
column6: as on Cashmere Cat-produced “Be My Baby”
column7: the effect is more Terius Nash than Pinterest-board pastiche. The features represent more grown-up choices
column8: and coax some stunning performances out of typically middle-of-the-road guests: the Weeknd skulks out from the shadows and into the light on throbbing big-room ballad “Love Me Harder”
column9: and A$AP Ferg delivers arguably his best guest spot ever on the Christina Aguilera-nodding sex jam “Hands On Me”.

column1: It’s fitting that the two most sexually explicit songs on the album are some of its best; Yours Truly’s blinky innocence would’ve bordered on patronizing if carried on any longer. It’s bigger than sex-positivity
column2: though—Grande’s directness in general is what's so refreshing. Where she once coyly avoided her crush’s gaze
column3: here she stares him dead in the eyes with to-the-point come-ons like “May be a little thing
column4: but I like that long.” In a recent New York Times feature
column5: Grande says longingly
column6: of the uphill battle against her squeaky-clean image
column7: “Maybe one day I’ll get away with something naughty.” This certainly feels like a start.

column1: Thanks to those chameleonic theater roots
column2: Grande’s always been able to pull off rap crossovers better than peers like Katy Perry
column3: but despite the handful of successful guest spots
column4: her taste in rap features remains tragic. My Everything’s worst moments revolve around hokey appearances from serial cornballs Big Sean and Childish Gambino. The former drops clunker after clunker on “Best Mistake”
column5: making a mockery of the song’s serious tone with hysterically awful lines like “How can we keep the feelings fresh/ How do we Ziploc it?” The latter takes the “he’s cheating… with a MAN!” storyline and rubs its face in its own feces with the beyond questionable punchline “Yes
column6: I’m a G
column7: from the A
column8: and they ask Y” (get it
column9: guys?)—as though the message wasn’t already made painfully obvious by the dorky
column10: distracting “I’m Coming Out” sample running underneath Grande’s vocals. It's a bizarre choice for a singer whose occasional unintelligibility is already something of a meme.

column1: Still
column2: despite its missteps
column3: My Everything feels like Grande’s arrival as a true pop fixture
column4: not just a charming novelty. Where she once felt like an actor dutifully playing the part of blinky-eyed
column5: malt-sipping romantic
column6: here Grande slowly but confidently comes into her own; and while her personality may still take a backseat to her technical skill
column7: it’s beginning to wink through the theatrics. Turns out
column8: so-called mini-Mariah can hold her own in 2014; and while the best songs here may not be timeless
column9:
they certainly feel right for right now.
