“New Jersey ain’t the whole world.” These are clearly the words of someone who never called it ""home"". It may not be the whole world
column2: but for many of its artists
column3: it’s a universe
column4: one where you can spend an entire career creating rewarding art. Real Estate
column5: Titus Andronicus
column6: and Lifetime are all considered quintessentially “suburban
column7: ” and they are nothing alike—and the same goes for Garden State and the movies of Todd Solondz. Bruce Springsteen and “The Sopranos” are revered for their realistic works of fiction
column8: Bon Jovi and ""Jersey Shore"" less so for their fictional works of ""reality""; a fine line exists between archetype and stereotype. Its economy and geography is every bit as contradictory and complex—New Jersey’s wealthiest pockets are stuffed with families fleeing New York City and Philadelphia
column9: while its own metropolises are some of America’s most notoriously blighted. It’s named the Garden State for good reason
column10: while its beaches are a punchline for pollution. The state represents American sprawl and dichotomy crammed into a manageable space—the perfect map for Cymbals Eat Guitars to project LOSE
column11: a sprawling
column12: complex
column13: and fascinating document of American indie rock.

column1: It’s a fitting occurrence
column2: though still surprising. Most bands rep Jersey from the start; in 2009
column3: Cymbals Eat Guitars briefly identified as an NYC band
column4: though their music existed on MySpace and encompassed the Pacific Northwest
column5: drawing heavily on Built to Spill and Modest Mouse. By 2011’s Lenses Alien
column6: they settled in the pop culture void of Staten Island
column7: while the album seemed to take place entirely within Joseph D’Agostino’s head. An often compelling record
column8: D’Agostino has since admitted that it makes more sense if you’re high
column9: but also that its unwieldy songs are almost impossible to play if you’ve had more than two beers.

column1: So LOSE is a homecoming in multiple ways—D’Agostino looks back on his upbringing and New Jersey’s vast catalog of pop culture folklore while the band makes the occasional anthemic moments that elevated Why There Are Mountains the primary purpose of each song. The near-replication of its length and chord progression casts “Jackson” and a sequel to Mountains’ massive opener “...And the Hazy Sea.” However
column2: where the latter exploded on impact and played only on the vertiginous disparity between its volcanic eruptions and minutes of calm
column3: “Jackson” evenly and expertly delivers its peaks in a variety of ways —D’Agostino patiently works towards an arcing chorus worthy of its Elliott Smith influence
column4: while a triumphant guitar solo emerges from the kind of post-rock blur that would typically signal the closure of a Cymbals Eat Guitars song. The riff from “Warning” adds a couple of sour
column5: flatted notes to the jangly progression from “Shore Points
column6: ” which soundtracked a leisurely drive down the coast on Lenses Alien. In a thrilling sprint towards a brash chorus
column7: “Warning” recklessly slams on the gas without checking the brakes.

column1: Cymbals Eat Guitars aren’t the same band that made Why There Are Mountains. In fact
column2: they’re an actual band now
column3: rather than a cast of supporting players beholden to D'Agostino's ideas. The Lenses Alien lineup returns with a new drummer (Andrew Dole) and a new rhythmic drive; producer John Agnello lends presence and texture
column4: rendering these topographic songs 3D
column5: while the rhythm section acts as D’Agostino’s OnStar—he’s still free to wander wherever
column6: yet there’s a framework and a destination. When he hits on a tangent
column7: he’s given direction an ultimate resolution
column8: so Cymbals Eat Guitars have the confidence to strike out to stranger territories. “Laramie” manages to span the lonesome crowded west and Muscle Shoals soul before levitating to an astral
column9: pedal-stomping freakout. “Chambers” and “Lifenet” are slices of Staten Island living delivered as slick
column10: heartland radio rock. It's all presented with unity rather than erratic dilettantism; ""indie rock"" is Cymbals Eat Guitars' domain and they cover its entirety.

column1: And yet
column2: the music is once again outdone by D’Agostino’s lyrics
column3: deeply personal and relatable
column4: referential without being academic
column5: prone to poetic flight and realistic grounding. Lyric writing in rock music—or
column6: really
column7: any genre—rarely possesses the substance and depth displayed on LOSE. During an aborted drug deal in “Chambers”
column8: Wu-Tang Clan get an offhand shout
column9: and Shaolin’s finest would envy the spiced-out
column10: scene-setting vividness given to “Warning”—“Pennants stiffen on the strip/ Wind is whipping through the tinsel fixed to the dealership/And you're looking mighty ghostly just like Bowie on Soul Train/ Wrapped in your sable.”

column1: RZA would also approve of D’Agostino’s writing regimen
column2: which uses a cornucopia of pharmaceuticals as a muse and meditation as a mental exercise. As a result
column3: LOSE fixates on small moments of startling lucidity and figures out where they fit into the bigger picture. During bookends “Jackson” and “2 Hip Soul (Floyd’s Tomb)”
column4: New Jersey’s more obscure
column5: shameful race relations come to the fore—the former evokes a possibly apocryphal band of Native American outlaws during a meditation on the afterlife
column6: while “2 Hip Soul” lends a redneck’s comeuppance a mythical quality high school rumors tend to acquire. A classmate falls face-first into a firepit at a kegger
column7: returning with a load of pills and a compression sleeve under his John Deere hat and Carhartts
column8: potentially karmic retribution for his hobby of carving swastikas into trees and clubbing ostriches with PVC piping at the local zoo.

column1: During “Chambers”
column2: D’Agostino recalls his parents buying him a dog
column3: the subsequent passing of which served in a retrospect as a way “To learn about loss/ The slow education.” His insight captures a different and devastating lesson about death on the stunning power ballad “Child Bride”. D’Agostino’s tender acoustic fingerpicking only serves to make his confessional memories all the more shocking—“You were my best friend/ Until your dad slapped the living shit out of you.” Its title serves as cruel foreshadowing for someone whose path was set as a youth by circumstances beyond his control; an alcoholic mother instigates a sudden relocation
column4: the friend sells off all his possessions
column5: moves south and catches D’Agostino at a show in Orlando with a new girlfriend and a crack addiction. He offers a hit and D’Agostino refuses
column6: because “My heart would explode
column7: ” either from the drugs or just from the stark realization of how he and his friend ended up in the same place. The final chorus soars
column8: while D’Agostino lies crushed
column9: realizing he’s been given nothing but opportunity and support—and here he is
column10: wasting his 20s getting high in less unflattering ways.

column1: Yet
column2: D’Agostino thoroughly understands how he and countless others get to this point
column3: and it’s explored in its entirety during LOSE’s thesis statement
column4: “XR”. It’s the song that most explicitly references the death of Benjamin High
column5: D’Agostino’s closest friend and musical collaborator
column6: and the inspiration for the newly introspective and self-disclosing lyrics.  The awful coincidence of his last name is used as a sobering double entendre during a beer-raising coda—“High is just a tingling behind my eyes/ Got no serotonin left.” Before he gets to that point
column7: “XR” wraps up an entire adolescence of escape into drugs and rock ‘n roll within 2:30 of rabble-rousing
column8: harmonica-huffing cow-punk. D’Agostino barks through a distorted microphone
column9: “Here I am again at Ben’s MySpace grave
column10: ” and traces back to how
column11: at first
column12: drugs are used to accompany incredible
column13: fleeting moments of youth. Then
column14: they become a means of trying to get that feeling back
column15: as a trip to the record store results in buying CDs for “ripping rails
column16: not listening to.” And finally
column17: it becomes a way to push through the numbness of being unable to generate a substitute—“Wanna wake up wanting to listen to records/ But those old feelings elude me.”

column1: Those feelings are most closely associated with the Wrens throughout LOSE—D’Agostino and High take a road trip to Philly for a house show and their van-ride duet of “I Guess We’re Done” (“I’ll do the Kev and you can do the Charles”) is recalled on “Laramie”. Cymbals Eat Guitars owe a lot to that band—they described them as “our Beatles”
column2: and Charles Bissell produced Why There Are Mountains. In some ways
column3: Cymbals Eat Guitars got to live the experience the Wrens related on “This Boy is Exhausted” and “Boys
column4: You Won’t”—playing to empty rooms with a complete lack of buzz
column5: taking up deadening day jobs after having blown their college years. They also learned that if you make a record at the level of The Meadowlands
column6: you can foster a fanbase willing to wait over a decade for new music. So even if D’Agostino’s lyrics are rife with death
column7: depression and doubt
column8: LOSE exudes earned resilience
column9: of getting through shit and getting your shit together. Since it's more clear than ever that the Wrens—and Built to Spill and Modest Mouse—aren't currently going to provide those feelings that currently elude listeners
column10:
Cymbals Eat Guitars have realized the challenge facing them all along; the result makes the distinction between protege and peer nearly indistinguishable.

Chicago has undergone a creative renaissance in the past few years
column2: one of a depth few anticipated. Compared with earlier regional moments
column3: where local buzz propelled a handful of artists to the national stage
column4: the Internet's clear-glass window into this world—and the increased marketing savvy of even its least-established teenagers—has made the city's multiple scenes appear saturated. This is further exaggerated by the reams of imitators the city's bigger stars—Chief Keef and Chance the Rapper—have inspired. With limited oxygen in a competitive space
column5: a raft of rookie artists have stubbornly hoisted themselves into the air
column6: grasping for whichever angle best fits.

column1: With the release of The Water(S) earlier this month
column2: 6'5"" Alabama-born
column3: Chicago-raised rapper Mick Jenkins towers above most of the city's newcomers
column4: literally and figuratively. Like collaborators Chance the Rapper
column5: Saba
column6: and No Name Gypsy
column7: he's a product of Chicago's vibrant poetry scene
column8: and a sharp disciple of a similar lyrical tradition. Jenkins is a conscientious person
column9: a writer drawn to literary symbolism
column10: punctuating the poetic obliqueness of his bars with barbed truths. His debut
column11: 2013's jazzy Trees & Truths
column12: was loose and indistinct. The improved songcraft of The Water(S) tightens his focus
column13: yet each track feels of a piece
column14: its cohesive sound reflective of the album's titular metaphor.

column1: This mixtape does bear an evident debt to Kendrick Lamar
column2: and at times
column3: The Water(S) feels like an album-length tribute to Kendrick's ""Sing About Me
column4: I'm Dying of Thirst"" and ""Swimming Pools (Drank)"". Although the first few songs take on amorphous shape of album tracks
column5: Jenkins' very first verse grounds them in ""The Art of Peer Pressure""-like action and movement: ""It was 91st and Laney
column6: we were six deep
column7: steppin' up the stairs/ Black Buick with a slick creep
column8: moving down the block
column9: we had froze/ Felt the tension in my toes…"" But Mick Jenkins' bold delivery is nothing like Lamar's introverted one. Even when Jenkins' poetical hand gets a bit too free with the pen
column10: his verses are drawn together by the unbroken stride of his words. He stands apart thanks to a rap style that gives muscle to a moral position.

column1: As Guru once said
column2: it's mostly the voice: deep and sonorous
column3: Jenkins' vocals resonate with a particularly masculine brand of authority. Where Chance the Rapper's voice affects a manic
column4: elastic character
column5: or Vic Mensa aims for empathic transcendence
column6: Mick Jenkins is practical
column7: decisive
column8: and no-nonsense. Uninterested in high-minded frivolities
column9: he often sounds like he's getting to the point
column10: even when he isn't: ""Everybody wanna be the back of a D-Rose"" is a bit of coded language (Derrick Rose's jersey has the number one on the back)
column11: but his delivery still gives this wordplay pointed gravitas. Serious and dignified
column12: he wears his voice like a Sunday suit.

column1: This confident rhetorical style is underpinned by the anxiety of a person who perceives that the world has issued him a false bill of sale. Clear-eyed
column2: he recognizes the superficiality of his peers' wealth and status obsessions and the counterfeit choices the world has presented them. For Mick Jenkins
column3: ""water"" represents spiritual nourishment
column4: clarity
column5: purpose
column6: qualities essential to life yet too easily ignored by the distracted. This isn't just standard young adult nonconformism—although it is that
column7: too—but in the context of Chicago's South Side
column8: where ""Little niggas got guns now/ And they carry them to the fuckin' beat
column9: a matter of life and death. Mick Jenkins combats this anxious frustration with aggressive confidence
column10: willing his truth to reshape a warped reality.

column1: The album's best songs foreground his words. The sparse
column2: unsettling ""Jazz""
column3: which twists with terse ambiguity
column4: lets his vocals take center stage. Statik Selektah's ""Black Sheep"" gives the back half some sleek momentum
column5: while the frenetic ""Who Else"" upends the casual atmosphere with some of Jenkins' most focused writing. But The Water(S) peaks with the climactic DJ Dahi-produced urgency of ""Dehydration""
column6: where each word seems underlined for maximum dramatic impact. Closer ""Jerome"" with Joey Bada$$—the album's most atypical track—feels like an exuberant Lost Boyz tribute
column7: and a welcome exultation after a record of stern intensity.

column1: In sharp contrast with Mick Jenkins' brolic tone
column2: the album's leisurely production is soothingly therapeutic
column3: all smudged-graphite edges. Where his first album was jazzy in a general sense
column4: The Water(S)' languid guitar lines and airy atmosphere bathe the music in soft-focus blues and greens
column5: a watercolor that recalls the placid cool of '60s modal jazz. The connection between aggression and relaxation is essential: his vocals keep the chilled production dynamic
column6: while the reassuring ambiance is immersive
column7: sanding the rough edges on occasionally weighty material.

column1: Heaviest of all is ""Martyrs""
column2: released as a video at the end of last year. The visuals include a flashed simulacrum of Chief Keef's ""Don't Like"" video
column3: but with Jenkins and each dreadlocked extra wearing a noose. The beat
column4: like Kanye's ""Blood on the Leaves""
column5: co-opts a conceptually loaded sample in Billie Holiday's ""Strange Fruit"". His lyrics attack youthful hypocrisy and conformity
column6: the empty pursuit of money and sex
column7: and his peers' susceptibility to these traps. This is his truth
column8: and a welcome counter to the blithe attitude many rap fans have carried over the last two decades of violence in the form. All the same
column9: as Mick Jenkins grows in stature
column10: he may experience the sensation of having people agree for the wrong reasons; that his words
column11: as potent as they are
column12: could easily be co-opted by those who would demonize teenagers for their own oppression—a mirrored experience of what may have gone through Keef's mind the first time he saw a crowd of white fans rap the hook to ""I Don't Like"". One's eyes can never be too open
column13:
but at least we can trust Mick Jenkins to tell us how he sees it.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20937/homepage_large.762e5eaa.jpg|10 Summers|32441.0|DJ Mustard|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Roc Nation']|2014-08-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:56.683504|"

DJ Mustard completely owns popular rap and R&B in 2014. Both scenes (where they are separate
column2: and where they bleed together) have long been defined by super-producers
column3: but few—including Timbaland and the Neptunes
column4: whose names can’t help be evoked in this conversation—have had runs as successful as Mustard’s
column5: who has placed no less than 15 songs on various Billboard charts this year. That list includes some of the year’s most enduring songs—from Kid Ink’s “Show Me” to Tinashe’s “2 On”—but more to the point is Mustard’s total and overwhelming ubiquity. It's not uncommon this year to turn on the radio
column6: hit ""play"" on a playlist
column7: walk into a party or enter a store
column8: and hear a succession of Mustard’s beats. His sound has become so attached to mainstream urban music that it’s almost impossible to decipher where DJ Mustard ends and contemporary rap and R&B begins.

column1: But we should never confuse quantity for quality
column2: and Mustard’s sound is too divisive for him to be hailed as a universal genius like some of his predecessors have been. The criticism of his beats is obvious even to his supporters: they are simple and repetitive
column3: not just individually but when taken together
column4: often just an easily digestible series of pulses and snaps. Recently
column5: a video posted to Reddit that catalogs a series of Mustard-produced singles built around the incessant chant of “Hey!” generated a thousand-comment thread of skepticism if not derision. The criticism—that any idiot with a working brain and two hands could churn out these beats—is not lost on the man himself. “Everybody say it’s so easy to make my beats
column6: ” Mustard Tweeted a few days ago. “[Well] take a swing at it you should be rich [in] no time cause I am.” The tweet was punctuated by two emojis that are crying while laughing.

column1: Yet Mustard is nothing if not an innovative producer. His innovations don’t have the creative breadth of Timbaland
column2: no doubt
column3: but they are innovations nonetheless
column4: and they have helped sustain the top-level of an art form that has been floundering commercially for years. One thing Mustard doesn’t get enough credit for is solving the Rubik’s Cube that is black music in the EDM era. Prior to his rise
column5: pairings of rap and R&B with dance music—from successful crossovers like Pitbull
column6: Usher
column7: and Chris Brown to mid-tier artists like Waka Flocka Flame and Just Blaze working the EDM festival circuit—were shotgun marriages borne less out of creative inspiration than survivalist instinct. These collaborations were mostly garish and sad
column8: but Mustard found a way to bring house music (back) to rap and R&B by making it an outgrowth of his own bleepy
column9: up-tempo beats. He did it first with Ty Dolla $ign’s “Paranoid”—which nicks the organ-like keyboard sound of many a ‘90s house song—and then with “Show Me” and Jeremih’s “Don’t Tell ‘Em”
column10: both of which lift parts of actual ‘90s house songs. The latter two have been pop crossovers at a time when most black artists have found a ceiling over their heads
column11: and they have positioned Mustard less as a rap strip-miner and more as a sort of spiritual heir of Afrika Bambaataa and “Planet Rock”.

column1: But most importantly
column2: Mustard has given rap and R&B music a center. The genesis of his sound is in Atlanta club music spanning Lil Jon to Travis Porter and parts of multiple generations of West Coast rap from Dr. Dre to Too $hort to Keak Da Sneak
column3: so naturally
column4: many of Mustard’s early songs acted as a bridge for the contemporary rap scenes in the South and West. But as his popularity has grown
column5: his net has widened: not just from rap to R&B
column6: but also from artists in Atlanta and Los Angeles to others in the Midwest (Jeremih) and East Coast (French Montana
column7: Wiz Khalifa). Whereas producers du jour of recent vintage such as Lex Luger and Mike Will elevated a certain region’s artists over others
column8: the simplicity of Mustard’s beats has proven to be malleable for artists with different approaches and fanbases.  Though many are still suspicious of his sound
column9: Mustard is a uniter instead of a divider.

column1: Despite all of that
column2: it’s impossible to forget that DJ Mustard comes from Los Angeles. His music pulls from many places but its heart is L.A. and that blood pumps through its veins. You can hear it in the squelching
column3: rubbery bass on tracks like “Show Me”
column4: YG’s “My Nigga”
column5: and his own “Vato”
column6: but also in the sneering swagger adopted by many of the rappers who slide onto his beats. That Mustard is L.A. and L.A. is Mustard seems to be the motive behind 10 Summers
column7: his first album under his own name. Though the title makes a grand claim—that Mustard will be rap’s overlord for 10 straight summers—the album itself is a small
column8: almost humble gesture toward his hometown
column9: a sort of epilogue to My Krazy Life
column10: the YG album produced largely by Mustard that instantly entered the conversation of classic L.A. rap full-lengths.

column1: Mustard seems to have let his poppier
column2: dancier side dominate his productions as of late
column3: but 10 Summers pulls his sound all the way back to the beginning
column4: with a set of tracks that explicitly connects him to the everlasting influence of Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg’s G-funk. It opens with a trio of songs that are reverent and distinctive only in the context of contemporary rap
column5: but Mustard and the local rappers that lead off the album—from bigger names like Nipsey Hussle and Dom Kennedy to lesser-known entities like TeeCee and RJ—are skilled and able imitators. The whiny synthesizers and quaking bass of these opening tracks is Mustard’s sound at its most elemental and it sets the table for rapping that often amounts to very good impersonations of Snoop Dogg (the hook on “Low Low”) and Too $hort (the opening verse of “Ghetto Tales”). Though some might have wanted Mustard to piece together a star-studded album
column6: he opens 10 Summers with an argument a certain type of chef might make: that doing the classics really well can be more satisfying than constantly trying to reinvent the wheel.

column1: In fact
column2: it’s when all the big names show up that the album drags a bit. “No Reason”
column3: with YG and Jeezy
column4: is a fun little Frankenstein of “Who Do You Love” and “My Nigga”
column5: but what follows are a pair of tracks with big names that have the stale air of DJ Khaled’s bloated projects. “Giuseppe” is just about the most average Mustard song that either 2 Chainz or Jeezy—both frequent collaborators—have ever appeared on. And “Face Down”—the big ticket item featuring Lil Wayne
column6: Big Sean
column7: YG
column8: and Lil Boosie—is a poorly mastered mess that is far less than the sum of its parts. After the delightfully slinky “Down on Me”—in which Mustard draws another line
column9: this time to New Orleans bounce music—the album dips to its lowest point with the annoyingly squeaky Iamsu! vehicle “Can’t Tell Me”.

column1: 10 Summers closes with four R&B tracks—two songs and two interludes
column2: all of which act almost as palette cleansers after the unrelenting hardness of the previous eight numbers. The two full tracks—“4 Digits”
column3: a showcase for up-and-coming vocalist Eric Bellinger
column4: and “Deep”
column5: a radio-ready single if Mustard wants to push it—go down like cold beers on a hot day
column6: memorable for their understated perfection. But more tantalizing are the interludes (which are hopefully previews of full tracks)
column7: one from Tinashe and the other from Ty Dolla $ign. They clock in at barely over a minute in total but are deeply tuneful
column8: and they suggest that Mustard has digested the same funk and soul records that inspired a L.A. luminary like DJ Quik and that he’s more versatile than people want to believe.

column1: Both interludes are also presented as random radio dispatches
column2: and on the Tinashe interlude Mustard makes another reference to criticism of his omnipresence. It opens with a short skit in which a man and a woman switch on the radio only to hear a string of Mustard tracks. “I’m tired of this shit
column3: ” the man says to the woman as “Paranoid” plays in the background. She flips the dial and we hear T-Pain’s “Up Down (Do This All Day)""
column4: to which he responds
column5: “Hell nah
column6: bitch
column7:
I’m tired of this nigga.” She turns the dial once more and we hear the new Tinashe track. It’s a fair warning. 

"|19709.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19709-dj-mustard-10-summers/|7.7|Jordan Sargent

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20980/homepage_large.f180b23e.jpg|Blacc Hollywood|28233.0|Wiz Khalifa|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic']|2014-08-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:57.304304|"

Wiz Khalifa’s half-decade tenure as Snoop Dogg’s weed rap heir apparent has been restless: after scoring his first hit with the Pittsburgh Steelers anthem “Black and Yellow”
column2: he followed up with Cabin Fever
column3: a collaboration with Flockaveli architect Lex Luger
column4: and Rolling Papers
column5: with ebullient pop-minded production from ‘Burgh locals I.D. Labs and dance-pop whizzes StarGate. Cabin Fever 2 matched wares with Bay Area production squad The Invasion and L.A. rapper Problem
column6: then O.N.I.F.C. traded it all in for plush
column7: moneyed cloud rap. On this spring’s 28 Grams
column8: it was back to the trap
column9: and Wiz’s third album Blacc Hollywood nobly attempts to pin these rangy genre excursions down onto a single album.

column1: From the smooth jack of Ghost Loft’s Kitsuné America 2 single “So High” to ace placements from radio titan Dr. Luke and usual suspects I.D. Labs and Sledgren
column2: Blacc Hollywood’s production choices are inspired—but you could never mistake it for possessing an adventurous streak
column3: thanks to the waxen array of prurient drug raps at center stage. It’s possible for an artist to be too on brand
column4: and Wiz’s music is almost monomaniacally obsessed with outlining how much weed he has amassed and his plans for burning through it. He’s got his own strain of Afghan kush (“KK”)
column5: he breaks it up with a grinder (“So High”)
column6: he smokes it out of his own brand of rolling papers (“Raw”)
column7: he does this every day (“Stayin Out All Night”)
column8: sometimes in his car. (“We Dem Boyz”). Blacc Hollywood is a blur of late night bottle service orders and wake-n-bake seshes that imparts more elite weedhead bonafides than hopes or dreams.

column1: But people don’t come to a Wiz Khalifa album to plunder the mysteries of the heart—they come to party. The issue
column2: then
column3: is that Wiz doesn’t sound like the guy rocking the party so much as the one out back baked as shit and melting into a couch. There’s a wispy resignation in his voice and a faint
column4: noncommittal thread in the songwriting that sends a few of these songs across the line from pop accessibility to plasticity. “Hope” invites a group of gold-digging clubgoers to “Come fuck with the stoner and get stoned.” “The Sleaze” informs us that Wiz “Just copped the newest thing” and “did it with ease
column5: ” without divulging what
column6: exactly
column7: he bought. “So High” caps every line with an enthused “Uh-huh” refrain
column8: but rather than wringing humor or menace from the device (a la Juvenile’s classic “Ha”) Wiz hurtles a stream of minutiae about what happens after he lights up. (“In my car
column9: uh-huh/ Cruisin’ down the street
column10: uh-huh/ So stoned I’ma need something to eat
column11: uh-huh”)

column1: Sometimes the pared down songwriting approach succeeds. “Raw” rides twinkling synths and 808s with a spirited Gucci Mane flow so in pocket you forget it’s kind of a commercial. Lead single “We Dem Boyz” delivers the album’s biggest
column2: easiest thrill by dispensing with rapping almost entirely
column3: sliding into a pillowy Detail production with a dash of Auto-Tune and a lyric sheet largely comprised of the titular chant: “Hol’ up
column4: hol’ up
column5: hol’ up
column6: we dem boyz!” Wiz isn’t a character possessed of the right mixture of slapstick and real danger to pull this kind of rarefied goon posturing off without a wink
column7: but the absurdity is easily half the fun.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Khalifa wins when he calls in a friend. “House in the Hills” reunites him with How Fly costar Curren$y for an aspirational banger that’s home to some of the album’s best pure rapping. “KK” avoids disaster by turning its second half over to Memphis drug rap legends Juicy J and Project Pat. Taylor Gang newbie Ty Dolla $ign’s blithe hooks on “Hope” and “Still Down” are among the album’s best
column3: and Nicki Minaj’s assist on verse three of album closer “True Colors” curtly immolates just about everything that came before it. Wiz fares much better when challenged
column4: and the more real estate he cedes to guests
column5: the less opportunities he’s afforded to trip himself up.

column1: Blacc Hollywood is peak Khalifa—bleary eyed
column2: genteel and
column3: eager to please—but these qualities are just as often foibles as strengths
column4: as a glut of pop-rap neck-massages bears out. Melodies coast
column5: but they don’t always stick; everything’s too mannered
column6: too clean
column7: and the album is marred by a clinicality further punctuated by its bonus tracks. Cuts like “You and Your Friends” and “On Me” are looser and dirtier than anything on the album proper
column8: and while the “We Dem Boyz” remix guts much of what made the original great
column9: and “Incense” is essentially a bath of half-intelligible Auto-Tuned vocalizing
column10: they stand out for taking risks. With Blacc Hollywood
column11:
Wiz has an easier time locating a pliable median between the varied whims of a fickle national audience than crafting a singular persona that draws them to him.

"|19751.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19751-wiz-khalifa-blacc-hollywood/|5.6|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20889/homepage_large.b5ba2d72.jpg|After the End|30479.0|Merchandise|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2014-08-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:57.904336|"

We tend to measure the speed of 21st-century living by the furious rate of cultural output
column2: but an even more accurate gauge is how quickly once-entrenched ideals can change. To wit
column3: in a July 2012 interview with Pitchfork
column4: Carson Cox of Tampa post-punk outfit Merchandise offered up this definition of success: “There’s a new warehouse space called Cyborg City
column5: where we just played an amazing show. There were a ton of fucking people there. There were
column6: like
column7: 70 fucking people.” Fast forward two years
column8: and that same guy has just released an album that sounds like it was designed for stadium crowds of 70

column1: Of course
column2: Merchandise are hardly the first punk-schooled band to eventually pursue loftier aspirations. But where many big-label debuts from former indie darlings often amount to putting lipstick on a pig
column3: Merchandise are using their promotion to 4AD to
column4: as Cox recently put it to the NME
column5: “start a new band with basically the same name.” And he’s not just talking about the group’s expansion from a drum-machined trio to a proper five-piece. Rather than nudge themselves toward the center by subtly sanding away the edges of their texturally dense art-pop epics
column6: on After the End
column7: Merchandise catapult themselves to the rightmost reaches of the dial
column8: and
column9: in the process
column10: transform into their idea of what the archetypal mainstream rock band should be—which is actually so far off the mark from what mainstream rock actually is in 2014 that it positions Merchandise as far away from centrist pop-culture as they were when they were playing gigs in storage units.

column1: Merchandise’s continually surprising evolution and capacity for challenging their core assumptions have mirrored those of another band of once-evasive hardcore exiles who have grappled with growing up and out of punk (and who are led by an outspoken frontman with a penchant for endlessly scrollable interviews): Fucked Up. Except instead of embracing 1970s rock-operatics
column2: Merchandise have become greatly enamored with the Big Music of the mid-’80s and the buttoned-up college-rock of the early ’90s. (In retrospect
column3: last year’s debut single for 4AD—the unwieldy 14-minute Spiritualized-scaled behemoth “Begging for Your Life/In the City Light”—now feels like a last-gasp exorcism of their arty eccentricities.) On After the End
column4: the band downplay their perennially fashionable Smiths/Cure/New Order influences and tether themselves to more unabashedly populist signposts that have
column5: thus far
column6: proven resistant to hipster reclamation: Post-I.R.S. R.E.M.
column7: pre-Spirit of Eden Talk Talk
column8: the more meditative end of the Pearl Jam canon.

column1: After the End is a record that is so determinedly mild-mannered
column2: it essentially amounts to a declaration of war: against dominant notions of cool
column3: the act of hiding your feelings behind a wall of noise
column4: and the idea that anti-pop experimentation is inherently more noble and challenging a practice than writing a simple
column5: emotionally direct love song. If the preceding Children of Desire and Totale Nite saw Merchandise concealing their ever-irrepressible new-romantic hearts under thick layers of squawking saxophones
column6: wailing harmonicas
column7: and droning repetition
column8: here they are laid bare and encased in brightly lit glass boxes like a gallery installation.

column1: An album this guileless is bound to be polarizing
column2: for the very fact that it resolutely resists the urge to provoke. (The tranquil opening instrumental “Corridor”—featuring
column3: no shit
column4: wind chimes—essentially functions as a citronella candle to ward off any indie ideologues lingering about from proceeding further.) But whether or not you accept Merchandise’s makeover
column5: one thing is indisputable: This album sounds fucking fantastic. And remarkably
column6: just like Merchandise’s previous releases
column7: it’s a home recording. (Most of the band live together in the same house
column8: Monkees-style.) But if much of After the End was laid down in Cox’s bedroom
column9: it sounds like the band are performing a concert on the roof
column10: absorbing the twinkle of the stars
column11: the hum of crickets
column12: the vapor trails of planes flying overhead
column13: and the endless expanse of the sky above. The shimmering acoustic guitars sound like they have dew collecting on the strings; the smooth synth textures reflect the warm nocturnal glow of the city at night.

column1: But like the War on Drugs’ recent Lost in the Dream
column2: After the End chisels through the surface pleasures of baby-boomer-baiting soft-rock to coax out a deep-seated distress. When a once-volatile band slows down and cleans up its sound
column3: it tends to signify that a certain degree of contentment has entered their lives—that past pressures and stressors have been cast aside and the ease into middle age has begun. After the End
column4: however
column5: highlights just how messy and painful that process can be
column6: that severing ties with one’s past—whether it’s romantic partners
column7: local music scenes
column8: or entire belief systems—inevitably results in broken skin and frayed nerves.

column1: Cox isn’t merely singing in a lower register for sexy-crooner effect; he sounds positively beaten down
column2: as if a drowsy drawl is all he has the strength to muster after dealing with the fallout of his decisions. (As he sings on the lush and languorous “Looking Glass Waltz”: “Won’t someone please help me/ I’m too young to feel this old.”) And unlike previous Merchandise albums
column3: he doesn’t allow himself the luxury of working out his frustrations through extended
column4: cathartic hypno-rock jams: the seemingly easy-going jangle pop of “Enemy” fades out mid-verse
column5: as if to suggest the tensions simmering within remain unresolved; the tightly wound “Little Killer” sounds the alarm for when the light that’s never supposed to go out starts to flicker.

column1: At times
column2: the disconnect between therapeutic function and clinical form is too vast to reconcile—the chipper
column3: snap-along saunter of ""Telephone"" doesn't so much ease the anguish of waiting for an important call that never comes as conjure the dad-rock muzak you hear when your dentist's office puts you on hold. And the weight of all this anxiety and self-doubt starts to drag down the band—and the album—by the time we reach the penultimate title track
column4: whose melodramatic
column5: piano-pounded lurch neither erupts into chaos nor yields to ecstatic release. (“The sky is falling all around us
column6: ” Cox sings in his best Mark Hollis-ian moan
column7: and the forecast doesn’t improve from thereon out.) But the beatific closing serenade “Exile and Ego” suggests Cox has found
column8: if not inner peace
column9: then at least the resolve to move on. “I ain’t no cowboy
column10: I got no six guns
column11: ” Cox sighs
column12: rejecting the outlaw mythology of another slick acoustic ballad about going it alone. Because as After the End reminds us
column13:
the best way to disarm your adversaries isn’t with weapons—it’s by staring them right in the eye. 

"|19663.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19663-merchandise-after-the-end/|7.0|Stuart Berman

Ever since Dinosaur Jr. reconvened nearly a decade ago
column3: J Mascis has favored his Martin almost as much as his Jazzmaster. In fact
column4: if you don’t count reissues of the band’s 1980s albums
column5: his acoustic output has nearly matched the three full-band albums that each justified the reunion and then some. Released in 2006
column6: Live at CBGB’s: The First Acoustic Show made stripping down for a legendary venue sound suitably punk
column7: even if it remains the textbook definition of “For Fans Only.” Much more essential is Several Shades of Why from 2011
column8: Mascis' first true solo album of new material
column9: which featured mainly just Mascis and his Martin. It’s a quiet
column10: gorgeous collection of fragile indie folk tunes made all the more powerful by his wounded-old-man croak
column11: his dexterous picking
column12: and his overall sense of restraint. And now there’s <i>Tied to a Star
column13: which picks up more or less where Several Shades of Why left off.

column1: In other words
column2: we may be entering a new chapter in Mascis’ career
column3: one where the Martin and the Jazzmaster receive equal play. This isn’t
column4: thank god
column5: a case of an aging musician making a last-ditch stab at mainstream success by turning self-consciously serious; these albums are still too weird for that. On the other hand
column6: his acoustic material does sound relatively limited
column7: as Mascis is not quite as expressive on the acoustic as he is on the electric. When he plugs in
column8: he can bend notes into a language that is both new and familiar
column9: conjugating active verbs from punk and metal
column10: translating concrete nouns from blues and folk. He’s one of the few guitar gods whose technical prowess never sounds like an end in itself
column11: but simply a means of getting his point across. Which is not to say that he doesn’t occasionally showboat
column12: but that he showboats with great purpose.

column1: When he unplugs
column2: however
column3: Mascis can be a little less communicative and compelling. Several Shades of Why worked because the setting emphasized his vocals and lyrics
column4: both of which are occasionally drowned out by Dinosaur Jr.’s infamous din. Moreover
column5: his playing showed a different approach to the instrument
column6: as though he had relearned the guitar and devised new strategies to put his songs across. As a result
column7: the music balanced a potent world-weariness with a new creative spark
column8: and the songs succeeded precisely because they weren’t adequate vessels for the emotions he was trying to exorcise. It was a lovely
column9: lonely album full of delicate melodies and tenderhearted
column10: albeit somewhat elusive
column11: sentiments.

column1: By contrast
column2: Tied to a Star lacks some of that album’s sense of discovery and precariousness. It’s much more confident and cagier
column3: which may have to do with the fact that this isn’t strictly a Mascis solo record. He corralled a loose backing band for a four-man acoustic jam
column4: including Pall Jenkins of the Black Heart Procession
column5: Ken Maiuri
column6: and Mark Mulcahy. Instead of lonely
column7: quiet folk
column8: we too often get strummy chumminess
column9: which places Star uncomfortably close to ‘90s jam-band territory. The opening chords of “Every Morning” have a bouncy insistency that portends a Sister Hazel song
column10: while the instrumental “Drifter” churns a vaguely Middle Eastern groove that might emanate from post-Jar of Flies alt-rock radio.

column1: Fortunately
column2: there’s more to Tied to a Star than those questionable touchstones. Most of these songs hit the same vein as Why
column3: framing Mascis’ singing and playing as idiosyncratic rather than anonymous. In fact
column4: the best moments are those when he ditches the band altogether. “Come Down” underscores his gentle intro with a looming wall of distortion
column5: as though reluctant to let the listener get too comfortable. Opener “Me Again” and “Stumble” showcase Mascis’ wounded-old-man vocals and especially his strong falsetto
column6: serving as a good reminder that his voice has somehow gotten better with age. Over a quiet
column7: spryly picked guitar theme
column8: his voice meshes well with Marshall’s on “Wide Awake”
column9: conjuring a lonely
column10: late-night mood: two lovers on opposite ends of the telephone line. Only the intrusive crash cymbal on the bridge breaks the spell
column11: but the song recovers on Mascis’ fluid guitar solo—which is played on electric
column12: for what that’s worth.

column1: In fact
column2: almost all of the solos are electrified
column3: which shows just how limited the Mascis + Martin set-up can be. He’s a figure of such towering goodwill in the indie world that it’s tempting to excuse or explain away his missteps. Certainly
column4: Tied to a Star stumbles whenever the band sit in on a song
column5: but his cohorts aren’t necessarily to blame. What’s truly disappointing about this uneven album is the fact that they could find no other mode of playing together besides the old
column6: the familiar
column7: and the unwelcome. There’s nothing embarrassing here
column8: just a few miscalculations amid some typically strong material
column9:
but Mascis has proven that he can muster more joyous ingenuity and imagination than he does on Tied to a Star.

"|19532.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19532-j-mascis-tied-to-a-star/|6.4|Stephen Deusner

Can you name a band that's less cool than Opeth? For a quarter-century
column2: Mikael Åkerfeldt’s ever-amorphous set of Swedes has let the effort show with every sound
column3: song
column4: and surprising genre twist. At various points in Opeth’s career
column5: their style has been categorized as progressive rock
column6: death metal
column7: or progressive metal
column8: though each of those terms felt
column9: at best
column10: like undersized umbrellas for a band actively coercing bits of jazz
column11: Romanticism
column12: blues
column13: British folk
column14: pop
column15: and new age into their musical madhouse. Opeth is so demanding that
column16: a decade ago
column17: they opted to issued two separate albums—the clenched Deliverance and the much more calm Damnation—rather than package them as an intended
column18: insurmountable double album; still
column19: sold separately
column20: each half of the dichotomous pair broke or pushed the one-hour mark and twisted and turned with a maniacal and delightful zeal. Åkerfeldt’s work has never sounded unaffected or effortless; Opeth have
column21: instead
column22: worn labor and fastidiousness as badges of honor
column23: open rebuttals to any sense of classical cool.

column1: In turn
column2: Opeth is one of modern music’s great paradoxes. They are one of the world’s most popular and enduring heavy acts
column3: having charted every album they’ve made since Damnation in at least half-a-dozen countries. And their international following is a cult of often-unwavering allegiance. To wit
column4: should you arrive at an Opeth show without an Opeth shirt printed in thick and vivid paint
column5: you’ll find that the aforementioned code of cool has been temporarily reversed. Even among the faithful
column6: though
column7: the feeling that Opeth can be forced
column8: overindulgent or obtuse is an abiding one; it is the baggage concomitant to the band’s audacity
column9: the side effect of the quest to shoehorn a dozen things into ultra-dynamic metal. But that same effort enables one of Opeth’s greatest unifying assets: the overwhelming rush that their best music can provide
column10: where a tizzy of elements sends the listener into a tailspin. Line up their catalog from one end to the other
column11: press play
column12: and be stunned by the number of moments (however calculated and meticulous they may be) where audience orientation vanishes. Their complications are their bait.

column1: But Pale Communion
column2: Opeth’s first album in three years
column3: lacks the absolute willpower and prevailing ambition of the band’s best work—that is
column4: the core that made the awkwardness sufferable. This is only the third album where Åkerfeldt foregoes his versatile death metal vocal delivery
column5: following the path of 2011’s Heritage and 2003’s Damnation. He alternately supplants it instead with a singsong lilt
column6: a folk-rock affability and an alt-rock theatricality. Notably
column7: this is the first Opeth LP to arrive since Storm Corrosion
column8: Åkerfeldt’s 2012 full-length release with longtime collaborator Steven Wilson. Half of that album featured the London Session Orchestra
column9: an influence that resurfaces throughout Pale Communion.

column1: In fact
column2: such strings web together the record’s two-song finale—and
column3: really
column4: the 16 minutes of music that save Pale Communion from abject disappointment. “Voice of Treason” is dramatic and lunging
column5: with tumescent strings providing the ballast beneath the song’s seven-minute rise toward the thrall. Just ahead of the end
column6: there’s a momentary blast beat
column7: an enormous wash of strings
column8: and a burst of heroic vocals from Åkerfeldt. “Have you ever seen the aftermath of giving up?” he howls
column9: the band exploding around him. And the stately strings that sweep beneath closer “Faith in Others” are the platform from which Opeth lifts toward a post-rock surge. It dissipates slowly
column10: as though the sound is being peeled apart layer by layer. Opeth surprises and engrosses here
column11: ending this album better than they do most anything else.

column1: Pale Communion often feels too polite to overrun and too guarded to sustain Opeth’s familiar sense of total upheaval
column2: where the listener struggles to remember which end is up and which way is forward. Take opener “Eternal Rains Will Come.” The song first weaves complicated rhythmic shifts against spools of sharp guitar and distorted organ
column3: a compelling mix that suggests a florid spin on math-rock. But after a pause
column4: the quintet springs ahead into a straight beat
column5: flimsy funk dancing beneath quick harmonies cribbed from “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes."" The instruments coil again toward the end
column6: with the guitar and drums pirouetting in sudden sync. But it’s a hyperactive soft-rock climax
column7: an effete attempt to reach new heights.

column1: Much the same holds for “Elysian Woes
column2: ” a trickle of acoustics backed by flute-like synthesizers  and led by Åkerfeldt in a rather miserable crooner guise. And “River” is the stiff Swedish approximation of fluid Southern guitar rock. Padded again by acoustic guitar and generous organ
column3: the first half is more pure prairie league than Allman Brothers anthem. But even the ricocheting instrumental midsection and spring-loaded coda feel preordained
column4: like the very blatant ends of Opeth’s Southern rock trial. Likewise
column5: “Goblin
column6: ” Opeth’s carousel-like horror score tribute
column7: is as obvious as its name
column8: while “Cusp of Eternity” implies Bono taking an acute
column9: unfortunate interest in the power of djent guitars. Even as it twists and turns through several solos
column10: the destination feels fated
column11: Opeth’s usual inexplicable intricacy given over to plug-and-play automation.

column1: These arrivals of the expected are Pale Communion’s most damning symptom. In the past
column2: Opeth have made their inspirations and aspirations obvious
column3: but their avid recombinations suggested an array of infinite possibilities. Even if you couldn’t abide the inflexibility of their methodical grandeur
column4: it was hard to condemn the immense effort and imagination involved. But Pale Communion only toys with the building blocks
column5: revealing influences that were already apparent but refusing to invigorate them alongside each other. It’s not that Opeth isn’t cool here. It’s that these eight songs run cold on new energies and ideas
column6:
a rarity for a catalog custom-made to overwhelm.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20841/homepage_large.88351661.jpg|Bitchin Bajas|31611.0|Bitchin Bajas|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-08-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:33:59.612689|"

The line between homage and mimicry is so blurry that it sometimes doesn’t even exist. But is it possible to arrive at homage by jumping over the divide
column2: and diving into the deep end of mimicry? It sounds like Bitchin Bajas are testing that theory on their self-titled double LP. Band founder Cooper Crain hasn’t been shy about his influences
column3: citing 20th century minimalists such as Terry Riley as guiding lights. But this time around
column4: the antecedents are clearer than ever. The aforementioned forefathers and a bunch of others (try German drifters like Cluster and Popul Vuh) pop up all over Bitchin Bajas—and since there are only eight tracks spread across the album’s 77 minutes
column5: they get lots of space to reveal themselves.

column1: Even though there's lots of references to be heard on Bitchin Bajas
column2: very little of this record sounds plagiaristic. It's almost like listening to the thought processes of Crain and bandmates Dan Quinlivan and Rob Frye
column3: rather than what they think goes on in their heroes' minds. They manage this not despite their influences
column4: but because of them; there are no gratuitous divergences
column5: no forced curveballs to prove the trio aren’t stealing. Their blending of past musical personalities creates a new one
column6: much the way a thoughtful cover can change your view of the original. Bitchin Bajas journey so far into their inspirations that they find something of their own inside.

column1: Bitchin Bajas is largely comprised of long journeys. 18-minute opener “Tilang” could exist as a single release on its own
column2: progressing from mournful Stars of the Lid-like strings to rippling organs
column3: whistling flutes
column4: and harp-like glissandos. The way those sounds fold into each other recurs throughout the album
column5: as the trio devise methods to make many voices (woodwinds
column6: synths
column7: xylophones) sing the same tune. The constant cross-dissolving can occasionally sound generic: “Field Study” opens with clichéd field recordings of water bubbling
column8: birds chirping
column9: and insects creaking. But even that piece resolves into something unique
column10: as subtle beats make the music more about psychic relaxation than nature worship.

column1: Relaxation may seem an unambitious musical goal
column2: but Bitchin Bajas are proud to chase it. Crain said last year that “making music that is relaxing and comforting to us is important
column3: ” and the band even made a separate cassette version of Bitchin Bajas dubbed Relaxation Mixes that eliminates what they call “the intense peaks.” So naturally there’s little abandon on these two LPs; the trio only sound like they're losing control during the overlapping synth squiggles of the 12-minute “Bueu”.

column1: But Bitchin Bajas' relaxation plan works because they’re committed to it. There are no forced attempts at edginess
column2: even though their simple techniques keep the music loose and live-sounding. This purist approach puts them in the company of other recent post-new age wanderers—bands like Emeralds and Mountains
column3: who are best when they sound most committed to their laid-back causes. For all their reverence toward the past
column4: Bitchin Bajas know how to live in the present – there’s no knowing distance here—so at its best
column5: Bitchin Bajas doesn’t give you ideas about sounds
column6:
but the sounds themselves.

Melbourne's Twerps have cited the Clean and the Go-Betweens as influences
column3: but their new EP
column4: Underlay
column5: doesn't skate by on jangle-centric nostalgia. With older tracks like ""Jam Song""
column6: they proved that they could ride a central groove while exploring different avenues; on Underlay
column7: they find a similar balance between precise and unsteady. ""Hypocrite"" is a stellar example of this
column8: as Rick Milovanovic's bass climbs and rollicks
column9: consistently competing with the guitar for the spotlight. Meanwhile
column10: drummer Alex Macfarlane (no relation to bandmate Julia) darts in several directions throughout the song
column11: ramping up at the chorus and simmering toward the finish. The only time the band ever sound stagnant is on the instrumental title track
column12: which is utilitarian—an unvarying two minutes
column13: but a needed transition between ""Wait Til You Smile"" and ""Consecutive Seasons"". It's boring
column14: and it bolsters the argument that Twerps are at their best when they stray from their set path.

column1: If there's an MVP here

column3: who sings the best two of the EP's eight songs. Her contributions are the most lyrically complex and melodically satisfying on the album; in the upbeat pop tune ""Conditional Report""
column4: she notices a hole in the Flemish glass window
column5: which is letting the wind into their house. ""How did we end up like this
column6: she asks
column7: maybe about the situation with their house
column8: maybe about something bigger. ""Raft"" is deceptively heavy
column9: considering its warm melody
column10: using a raft in a flood as a potent image that alludes to anything from emotional tumult to straightforward survival. McFarlane's songs here are excellent examples of how this band can communicate so much with such a sparsely populated lyric sheet.

column1: Lead singer Marty Frawley shares this talent: ""I'm just so damn sick/ I'm so sick of it all
column2: he sings on Underlay's closer ""Consecutive Seasons""
column3: a line that underlines Twerps' skill at writing songs fraught with universal
column4: emotionally familiar sentiments. Another line in ""Consecutive Seasons""
column5: however
column6: sounds more specific: ""And I don't want to sing 'Dreamin'/ It's lost every single meaning."" The line is a derisive namedrop of a highlight from 2011's Twerps
column7: an album filled with lyrics inspired by the blossoming relationship between bandmates Frawley and Julia McFarlane—songs that Frawley said left him feeling ""exposed."" On ""Consecutive Seasons""
column8: Frawley sounds uncertain
column9: discontent
column10: and tired
column11: a look that pairs well with the song's soft
column12: bittersweet
column13: jangling melody.

column1: There's a video that the band made last year to tease their next album where Frawley ""scolds"" each member of the band
column2: telling them to get back to work and that they haven't ""earned"" their soft drinks. It's a funny video

column4: he and his band made a well-performed
column5: well-written
column6:
focused statement on Underlay.

Just four minutes into Rustie's Green Language
column2: some 20 seconds before the close of the second song
column3: there's a brief fade-out that's more like a fake-out. By this point
column4: the album has blown through more than ten percent of its running time with what is essentially a pair of introductions. The opening ""Workship"" offers two minutes of gleaming synthesizers streaming chemtrails of white noise; vast and cinematic
column5: it suggests a three-way fusion of John Williams
column6: M83
column7: and Oneohtrix Point Never. Then
column8: ""A Glimpse"" materializes out of a mist of birdsong and running water
column9: as carousel-like arpeggios accelerate and a sawtooth synth lead goes supernova. It's even more widescreen than the opener
column10: but it still feels like a scene-setter rather than the main attraction.

column1: That what makes what happens next feel so sneaky. The song fades out
column2: and after near silence and another smattering of birdsong
column3: there's a rumble like a gathering storm played back on fast-forward. And then
column4: BOOM: an actual electric guitar! Shredding! It couldn't sound further from the Glasgow producer's wheelhouse
column5: which is to say that it would be hard to think of a move more in line with his trickster's M.O. But before you can say
column6: ""I hear you're throwing your computer out the window because you want to make something real; you want to make a Van Halen record
column7: the joke
column8: if that's what it is
column9: is over. ""A Glimpse"" is presumably just that—a fleeting peek at a much stranger and more audacious record than Green Language ultimately turns out to be.

column1: It's not entirely unsuccessful
column2: not by any means; with some tweaks it could've been a great album. The Glasgow producer's chops have never sounded punchier
column3: his synths never shinier or more serrated. Following his cock-rock feint
column4: ""Raptor"" soars like a Kevlar-plated phoenix
column5: synthesizer glissandi strafing all over the damn place
column6: rat-a-tat 808 snares firing like a rivet gun. The light it throws off is dazzling; listen back to Glass Swords and it suddenly sounds practically lo-fi in comparison. The sheer amount of sonic information he packs in is almost overwhelming: is that the sound of an alarm clock in the background
column7: or just some kind of residual tinnitus ring from all those harmonics being piled on top of one another? And what's up with the angel cooing above it all?

column1: When Glass Swords came out
column2: Rustie's approach was so unfamiliar that the music was discussed primarily in terms of its impact—""maximalism
column3: a term also applied to his peer Hudson Mohawke—and its texture. He helped us out with titles like ""Ice Tunnels"" and ""Crystal Echo""
column4: not to mention those dazzling quartz obelisks on the cover—imagery that felt like a DMT-inspired mission to unlock the secrets of synaesthesia once and for all. But things are different now. The kinds of sounds he privileged on his debut album—'80s-inspired slap bass
column5: hyperkinetic electro-funk
column6: the lysergic riffs on Southern hip-hop that he termed ""aquacrunk""—have become popularized and re-naturalized. That last bit has become particularly true as the dubstep scene
column7: the primary context in which Rustie was once considered
column8: has cratered
column9: its former practitioners gone looking for other styles to adapt or colonize.

column1: Foremost among those is ""trap""; Rustie's dalliances with the form make him look more like a follower than a leader. Case in point: ""Attak""
column2: a blistering number featuring the Detroit rapper Danny Brown. The tune's not without its charms
column3: especially a synth lead that interpolates an echo of Duran Duran's ""Save a Prayer"" between Brown's marble-mouthed spray—and those machine-gun snares are a nice touch. But it feels like he's reaching for a hit
column4: or at least a festival anthem
column5: and the same could be said of ""Up Down""
column6: featuring the grime rapper D Double E from Newham Generals
column7: although at least the latter's wormhole bass and gamma-ray high-end are more in keeping with Rustie's usual methods.

column1: The main issue with Green Language is that it feels scattered. ""He Hate Me""
column2: featuring Gorgeous Children
column3: is a fuzzy cloud-rap track with a beat that sounds like Rustie's mashing his fist on a home organ; after D Double E and Danny Brown's double-barreled bellows
column4: the rappers' whispery voices fall flat
column5: and the wind goes out of the album's sails. With ""Velcro"" we're suddenly plunged into a bewildering collision of Nintendo
column6: Daft Punk
column7: and trap; ""Lost""
column8: featuring Numbers signee Redinho
column9: is a talkbox-revival jam that aims for Zapp but hits closer to Chromeo.

column1: Just as the album begins with a succession of intros
column2: as though opening up a set of Russian nesting dolls
column3: it goes out with a series of alternate endings. The ecstatic R&B of ""Dream On"" would have been an excellent place to finish
column4: but ""Lets Spiral""
column5: with its helicopter-rotor hi-hats and helium arpeggios
column6: is essentially a companion piece to ""A Glimpse""
column7: and the final song
column8: ""Green Language""
column9: is just 1:54 of underwater Windham Hill riffing laced
column10: once again
column11: with running water and birdsong. There's nothing wrong with Rustie's ambient abstractions; they may be structurally slight
column12: but they pack a surprisingly powerful emotional wallop. Ultimately
column13: though
column14: you get the sense that he can't decide between two competing visions: that of the festival-anthem trap lord
column15: and the new age cosmonaut. The battle that ensues is exhilarating and frustrating in equal measure: as a producer
column16: Rustie's skills are in top form. But instead of the epic hero he wants to be
column17:
he's tilting at glass windmills.

This year is the 20th anniversary of Basement Jaxx's first release
column2: EP1—and it's easy to forget how straightforward and underformed it was. But that's the case for just about anything compared to the mindbending pop-house they'd concoct throughout the late 1990s and early 2000s. Remedy
column3: Rooty
column4: and Kish Kash made for such a definitive early-career run that their overloaded
column5: Frankie Knuckles-via-Tex Avery sensibility shone through even when they felt like they were starting to coast. Theirs was a sound that could find a context for Siouxsie Sioux and J.C. Chasez on the same record
column6: hopping between indie-kid nods and marquee pop dreams in a way that highlighted just how across-the-board house music and its offspring could be. Even when 2009 releases Scars and the Zephyr EP threatened to tone them down
column7: there was always an ambush around the corner
column8: like the offbeat engagement with grime and dubstep on their masterful score for 2011 sci-fi cult classic Attack the Block.

column1: But house
column2: garage
column3: and bass music are currently crowded with new-gen acts that owe a lot of their appeal
column4: acknowledged or otherwise
column5: to Jaxx's precedent of sweat-flinging cartoon intensity. And with the records they dropped five years back already hinting at a long goodbye to bombast
column6: Ratcliffe and Buxton seem content to let their heirs pick up the slack
column7: as Jaxx themselves ease into restraint on Junto. This new album's a strange one
column8: albeit in the sense that it's not really strange at all: the closest there is to a left-field guest is Mykki Blanco
column9: whose one verse is played twice on the two-and-a-half-minute ""Buffalo""—and if you cut out that track's fleeting hit of scattered d'n'b mayhem
column10: Junto is easily Basement Jaxx's most conservatively minded full-length.

column1: Sure
column2: this album is still recognizably theirs at points. The boogie-shuffle ""We Are Not Alone"" has some characteristically anarchic burbling squelches trickling through its boogie-shuffle churn. ""What's the News"" gathers together gelatin-cube bass
column3: dizzy synth chirps
column4: and bongo breaks into the kind of dub-disco cruise that would've fit in nicely in the back half of Remedy. There are still signs of jet-set eclecticism that incorporates pan-Latin salsa/bossa (""Mermaid of Salinas"")
column5: UK Afro-Caribbeanisms (the Shakka feature ""Rock This Road"")
column6: and slickly diced-up '80s funk (""Summer Dem""). And the vocalists
column7: while mostly semi-obscure outside dance music circles
column8: are almost uniformly powerful—with special credit to Meleka
column9: whose surprise-star lead turn on ""We Are Not Alone"" packs a sly passion that she hinted at while harmonizing with Kelis on Scars' title track. It's a fundamentally sound record as well as one that's easy to move to
column10: never content to stay in one place for too long but not all that scattershot when it comes to going off the experimental deep end.

column1: But let's face it—Basement Jaxx is not a group that's at their best when they just bear down and focus on the fundamentals. Even when Junto showcases them at their best—that'd be the knockout ""Unicorn
column2: which is both the liveliest single on the record and their most shameless vintage house throwback since ""Do Your Thing""—the sense of adventure is missing. It's a point-missing exercise to shrug at lyrics
column3: of all things
column4: when it comes to dance music—but when there's a precedent of hooks like ""I'm too far gone
column5: I've gone too far""
column6: ""Don't let the walls cave in on you""
column7: and ""Ain't nothin' goin' on but history/ But it's alright
column8: don't panic"" lending an untethered mania to earlier Jaxx classics
column9: the titular refrains of ""Power to the People"" and ""Never Say Never"" are relatively lacking in that giddy sense of control loss. And without all the deliberate craziness and cluttered what-next noise that always threatened to overload those jams
column10: what's left
column11: while still danceable and upbeat
column12: seems a little trad. Now more than ever
column13: there needs to be something blatantly neon-bright and iconoclastic enough to offset all the midtempo
column14: gloomy sad-boy house that's thrown current sound systems a bit out of whack. And while Junto is at least happy enough to lift spirits
column15:
it feels like they've left it to others to reintroduce anarchy to the dancefloor.

“For the moon never beams/ Without bringing me dreams
column2: ” goes one of Edgar Allan Poe’s most famous works
column3: the poem “Annabel Lee”. It’s one of the blueprints for what would eventually (and often reductively) become the post-punk aesthetic of goth
column4: and Brighton-based trio the Wytches have gulped down that influence greedily on their debut album
column5: Annabel Dream Reader. The record is swamped in menace
column6: murk
column7: and star-crossed heartbreak. Singer/guitarist/organist Kristian Bell has a vision
column8: and it isn’t a bright one; along with drummer Gianni Honey (whom Bell played with in the rickety
column9: charming the Crooked Canes) and bassist Daniel Rumsey
column10: The Wytches’ frontman cloaks himself in gloom. Beneath the trench coat
column11: though
column12: beats a love of grainy garage-punk
column13: slapback-echoing surf-rock
column14: and schoolyard-strength psychedelics.

column1: Annabel Dream Reader is a monster-mashup of atmospheric proportions
column2: and that works to their benefit
column3: at least musically. “Beehive Queen” is a fetching shambles of a song
column4: teeming with subaquatic twang and Bell singing in a strange
column5: psychosexual vibrato. “Crying Clown” flirts with stoner-rock heaviness; “Weights and Ties” border on power balladry. There isn’t that much of a dynamic inherent in the Wytches’ hybridized sound
column6: but they maximize it. “Wide at Midnight” is a study in tangles and tendrils
column7: full of little melodic licks and abrupt bursts of distortion and screams. Bell is an erratic songwriter
column8: and that works in his favor; what could have easily been a myopic
column9: compromised mess is actually a grab-bag of unhinged sonic surprises.

column1: Bell’s lyrics
column2: on the other hand
column3: are more painstakingly considered—although maybe they shouldn’t have been. Annabel Dream Reader is a concept album
column4: but the plot is as loosely formed as most concept albums
column5: consisting mostly of repeated themes
column6: linked images
column7: and recurring characters. In that regard
column8: the record mostly works; its arc—from ill-fated introduction to tragic epilogue—is solid
column9: even if it adds little to the experience of actually listening to it. Where Bell falls flat is on the lyric sheet itself. Too much of it reads like a parody of notebook-scrawled
column10: adolescent anguish
column11: if not flat-out doggerel. “I know you and I took the last of the light/ From a bulb that resembled a tear
column12: ” he sneers with metaphor-mangling glee on “Digsaw”. “Keep away from this active breeding/Of dogs like men of masculinity
column13: ” he all but babbles on “Wide at Midnight”
column14: lines that transcend cringe-inducement
column15: to the point where your brain might go on strike after hearing them.

column1: The lowest lyrical point is “Fragile Male for Sale”— a song whose title alone is a linguistic misdemeanor— which proudly features the line
column2: “You must be a dancer 'cause you’re dancing in me”. If that doesn’t reek enough of Moleskins and cloves
column3: Bell goes on to inject “Summer Again” with bombs like “I undid your dress/ You climbed up my jeans/ We wept for each other.” He seems to be shooting for the mystique-soaked romanticism of one of his obvious idols
column4: Jack White—the album was recorded by Liam Watson at London’s Toe Rag Studios
column5: the producer and room behind the White Stripes’ Elephant— but this is some strictly Aiden-level cliché-craft. “Track 13” is the album’s final song
column6: and its final line is “Stop reading me
column7: Annabel”. If Bell were ribbing himself about how wretched his lyrics are
column8: it’d at least be amusing
column9: but that might be giving him too much credit.

column1: Of course
column2: Bell’s lyrics aren’t intended solely to be read off the page; they’re meant to be listened to with full accompaniment
column3: and in that sense
column4: he’s almost able to compensate for his own handicap. “Burn Out the Bruise” is built on a dark
column5: whiplash drone as well as Bell’s spirited
column6: mid-exorcism caterwauling; it’s enough to overshadow the fact that he’s singing drivel like “Your claws slipped through like I was made out of glue/ But it wasn't enough to help you burn out the bruise.” That spirit is the key to the album’s charm; the Wytches’ willingness to hurl caution to the wind is exhilarating
column7: even when it verges on the precious and cartoonish. Outclassed by their own ambition
column8: the band has aimed Annabel Dream Reader toward the lofty heights of Poe’s glum
column9: fog-shrouded majesty—and winds up hitting
column10: at best
column11:
late-period Tim Burton.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Monkeytown']|2014-08-27 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:02.559447|"

Pity the 12"" producer. Their releases are compartmentalized into a tier somehow less important than a full-length
column3: treated as mere precursors to something bigger and better; they face pressure to translate their art into the ironclad LP format
column4: and to satisfy general expectations of what an album is supposed to be. So pity Dark Sky
column5: because they are
column6: at the least
column7: three consistent 12"" producers who had little choice but to issue their first full-length five years into a respectable career built solely on short-form records.

column1: Carlo Anderson
column2: Matthew Benyayer
column3: and Thomas Edwards are among the few remaining vestiges of UK bass music
column4: 2009's cryptic genre tag meant to encompass dubstep
column5: house
column6: and techno ideas via their most physical frequencies. After originators like Joy Orbison and the Night Slugs camp gradually shifted focus to singular elements of the hybridized genre
column7: Dark Sky continued to hone their knack for hyperreal sound design and rattling subs well into 2013. It wasn't until the In Brackets EP
column8: which saw release on Mister Saturday Night in April of last year
column9: that the trio seemed at all interested in a less aggressive palette. From the title track on down
column10: this iteration of Dark Sky took a moodier
column11: contemplative
column12: and even jazzy approach to bass-loaded soundsystem music—an exciting growth spurt for a group whose only moments of reflection ever materialized in the passing seconds before a massive drop. Dark Sky were broadening their horizons
column13: gracefully.

column1: An extensive and reliable discography like Dark Sky's is entirely why Imagin
column2: their debut album for the Modeselektor-helmed Monkeytown label
column3: should work—but it's also entirely why it doesn't. The three producers have sidestepped their natural upward trajectory in exchange for some of the riskiest and most predictable moves an established electronic artist can make on the first LP. Needless
column4: anticlimactic intro? Check. Uninspired vocal tracks? Check. Shoehorned pandering to longtime fans? Check. Tepid flirtations with previously unexplored genres? Check. Between scattered glimpses of what made these producers worth keeping tabs on
column5: Imagin falters because it sounds like Dark Sky second guessed their strengths in the face of delivering an album on someone else's terms.

column1: In contrast
column2: Imagin shines whenever it isn't contorting to fit preconceived notions of format. After two false starts
column3: ""Voyages"" breathes life into the tracklist with its percussive clatter and slippery synth acrobatics
column4: sounding like the best possible outtake from Four Tet's Beautiful Rewind sessions. Brawny banger ""Odyssey""—a spacious
column5: electro-slanted production that has been floating around since 2012—reclaims your attention after ""Lucid""
column6: ""Vivid""
column7: and ""Nothing Changes"" spend 10-plus minutes meandering between placid trip-hop references and narcotic electronica. These scattered resurgences aren't weakened by the valleys that bookend them
column8: but Dark Sky's fleeting moments of clarity make for a record which feels like two-thirds setup and one-third delivery.

column1: ""Manuka"" epitomizes the largest issue at the core of Imagin. Donning snappy drums and a snaking bassline
column2: the track is easily among the record's strongest moments; with a little editing
column3: it could go blow for blow with past heavy hitters like ""Zoom"" and ""Shades"". But right in the middle of Dark Sky's slick
column4: well-calibrated tune is a pitch-shifted vocal sample mucking about like a scratched disco 45 spinning 12 RPMs too slow. It's a gratuitous bit of production work that cheapens ""Manuka"" whenever it appears
column5: and this practice of garnishing perfectly capable songs with mismatched bells & whistles—that is
column6:
pursuing a supposedly mature sound through indistinguishable singers and superficial lyrics—bogs down music that would otherwise thrive on its dynamic structure and engaging sound design.
