Mike Watt is legendary for many things
column2: most of them having to do with his time as the bassist of Minutemen
column3: fIREHOSE
column4: and the reformed Stooges. But he’s also renowned for being so approachable
column5: a humbly gregarious guy who’s likely to be standing around his equally legendary van after a solo show
column6: shooting the shit with whomever feels like hanging out. He’s even been known to let fans hop in the van and go for a ride—anyone who’s ever seen the Minutemen documentary We Jam Econo can attest to the fact that he loves to drive and hold forth at the same time—and that open-door policy is reflected in the generosity of soul his playing has always possessed.

column1: Watt’s current band Il Sogna del Marinaio is the musical equivalent of one of those shit-shooting sessions. Along with a pair of Italians
column2: guitarist Stefano Pilia and drummer Andrea Belfi
column3: he recorded 2013’s La Busta Gialla
column4: a promising workout of sinewy rock that nonetheless felt halting and awkward. It was a prelude to Canto Secondo
column5: the trio’s superior second album. Where La Busta Gialla was made over long stretches of time
column6: and almost entirely across long distances
column7: by a band that started recording only a week into its existence
column8: Canto Secondo flaunts an ease and familiarity that can only come through collaboration and experience
column9: not to mention proximity. The bulk of Canto Secondo was recorded with all three members in the same room at the same time
column10: and it shows in tracks like the instrumental “Alain”
column11: with its lopsided prog ambulation propped up by Watt’s melted-rubber low-end
column12: and “Mountain Top”
column13: a circular
column14: gently jangled meditation that has the feel of a post-punk koan.

column1: “Sailor Blues” is Canto Secondo’s longest track
column2: and at a trim five-minutes-plus
column3: it demonstrates just how concentrated and concise the trio’s internal language has become. From Pilia’s knotty yet fluid guitar lines to Watt’s punching
column4: dancing bass
column5: the song descends into an ethereal wash of soft-focus distortion and playfully unresolved bends of melody. The touchstones become more sharply defined on “Us in Their Land”; in a start-stop fit of squealing virtuosity that anxiously mashes My War-era Black Flag into Starless and Bible Black-era King Crimson
column6: the song hastily builds a scaffolding
column7: clambers up it
column8: then pulls it out from under its feet. Pilia’s whispery
column9: heavily accented poetry not only clicks
column10: it evokes a strange kind of dreamy menace
column11: working strictly on a level of phonetic atmosphere.

column1: The problem with any musicians Watt might pick up
column2: here and in the future
column3: is that they’re drawn to Watt because of his legacy
column4: and rightly so. But that also means they’re playing in his shadow
column5: and that they’re fans first and foremost—which can lead to songs like “Animal Farm Tango”. “Humans are not welcome in the sick animal farm tango
column6: ” Watt recites in a gravelly
column7: avuncular
column8: spoken-word segment as dry as post-apocalyptic dust
column9: sounding for all the world like Allen Ginsberg on The Clash’s “Ghetto Defendant”. The music itself
column10: though
column11: is reminiscent of something much closer to home: the Minutemen’s “Do You Want New Wave Or Do You Want the Truth?”
column12: all fluttery notes and swaying spaces. But Canto Secondo’s strength is in its effortless balance between Watt’s formidable past and his still potent future. Better yet
column13: that balance feels instinctual
column14: and at times downright spiritual. Il Sogna del Marinaio may not have come anywhere near Watt’s formative bands in terms of sheer songwriting
column15: or the ability to rattle the heart and mind—but on Canto Secondo
column16:
they’ve settled into a groove that’s taken on the gabby pattern of a classic Watt spiel.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20894/homepage_large.8e7507d5.jpg|Manipulator|27962.0|Ty Segall|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-08-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:04.600501|"

Since popping the cork on his career back in 2008
column2: Ty Segall has become synonymous with the word “prolific.” But unlike so many artists who commit their every passing whim to tape
column3: in Segall’s case
column4: it’s not just an impulsive quirk or random data dump—it’s the very engine that pushes him to greater heights. Whether it’s the sad-eyed garage-rock of the 2011 LP Goodbye Bread
column5: the scorching psych-punk of Slaughterhouse from 2012
column6: or the acoustic stoner reveries of last year’s Sleeper
column7: the increasingly narrow windows between Segall’s discrete releases seemingly inspire him to knuckle down and fully inhabit a specific aesthetic before conquering the next one. It’s hard to feel overwhelmed by the vast amount of material he releases
column8: because each new album has revealed a different facet of both his sound and personality
column9: and built up anticipation for where he might go next.

column1: With Manipulator
column2: Segall arrives at his own personal promised land
column3: the place where all the divergent paths he’s travelled intersect. As Segall has revealed in interviews
column4: Manipulator represents the inevitable pause from his usual breakneck pace
column5: its 17-song
column6: double-album sprawl the product of an unprecedented (for him) 14-month writing process. You can feel that extra attention to detail on every song here: In sharp contrast to his previous album-to-album (or
column7: in the case of 2012’s grab-bag Twins
column8: track-to-track) stylistic shifts
column9: the songs of Manipulator represent a perfect melting-pot synthesis of Segall’s many sonic signatures
column10: as if each component—from the British Invasion-inspired melodies to the glam-rock affectations to the berserker guitar solos—was carefully measured out in beakers and test tubes before being mixed together. “He’s going to make a movie/ Of his entire life
column11: ” Segall sings on the gritty acoustic groover “Green Belly”
column12: and even if he’s not referring directly to Manipulator’s career-spanning breadth
column13: he certainly embraces auteur theory here
column14: playing pretty much all of the instruments himself. (His trusty Ty Segall Band appears together on just one track.)

column1: Manipulator sticks within a clearly demarcated comfort zone—i.e.
column2: the turn-of-the-’70s classic-rock canon spanning The Who Sell Out to Raw Power—but manages to touch upon every significant development in rock ‘n’ roll during that period. Want string-swept Bolan-esque serenades? Meet “The Singer”. A glitter-smeared proto-punk face-melter? Check “It's Over”. Jeff Beck-era Yardbirds mod-rock romps? Keep it real with “The Faker”. Ornate Forever Changes-worthy psych-folk? You can’t beat “The Clock”. A Grand Funk'd boogie that yields a drum-banging breakdown just like the one on Rod Stewart’s version of the Temptations’ “(I Know) I’m Losing You”? Get your fill with “Feel”. But perhaps the most pervasive influence of all is David Bowie circa The Man Who Sold the World—not just in Segall’s fanciful
column3: faux-Brit diction (a quality he shares with his equally effete pal Tim Presley
column4: aka White Fence)
column5: but in the way he welds electric shredding to percussive acoustic underpinnings
column6: with the stripped-down strut of “Tall Skinny Lady” and “The Clock” bringing to mind the Bowie/Ronson match-ups on “Black Country Rock” and “Width of a Circle”.

column1: And yet
column2: even though his musical frame of reference is fixated upon an era that began 20 years before he was born
column3: Segall is very much consumed by modern problems. As to be expected from someone who hasn’t updated their Twitter account in three months
column4: Manipulator takes a skeptical view of technocracy
column5: its lyrics dotted with allusions to surveillance
column6: privacy invasion
column7: identity theft
column8: and TV addiction. In this light
column9: the album’s acoustic/electric symbiosis feels emblematic of the tug-of-war between old-world authenticity and new-world convenience playing out in Segall’s head. (As if the aforementioned “Feel” doesn’t make his preference for IRL connections explicit enough
column10: he answers it with another song called “The Feels”.) Of course
column11: like any tried ‘n’ true garage-rocker
column12: Segall still has girl trouble on his mind—but
column13: in this case
column14: it’s trouble with a girl addicted to her devices named
column15: natch
column16: “Susie Thumb”.

column1: With its fuzzed-out Kinksian hooks
column2: “Susie Thumb” is an obvious choice for Manipulator’s lead single—and
column3: really
column4: they could all be singles here. But that’s a comment on both Segall’s consistent craftsmanship and the songs’ very similar sense of scale
column5: the latter of which ultimately prevents Manipulator from becoming the career-crowning milestone its protracted gestation period suggested. Manipulator may be 50 percent longer than the average Ty Segall record
column6: but it doesn’t always make the case that it had to be. The issue isn’t song quality so much as a flattened topography: Whether they emphasize regal violins or squealing leads
column7: the tunes here are pitched at the same cruising altitude and rarely upset their steady
column8: maraca-massaged choogle. As such
column9: Manipulator feels less like an epic Side-A-to-Side-D journey and more like an hour-long CD that would benefit from some editing (particularly when the songs start to feel like dopplegangers of one another—see: “The Crawler” vs. “It’s Over”). As his red-hot
column10: silver-lipsticked recent appearance on Conan proved
column11: Segall is ready for prime time. However
column12: the ample generosity of Manipulator highlights the cruel paradox of showbiz: When you give the people everything they want
column13:
you can’t leave them wanting more.

"|19668.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19668-ty-segall-manipulator/|7.8|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20970/homepage_large.205b8ff0.jpg|Angels & Devils|539.0|The Bug|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2014-08-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:05.123782|"

Kevin Martin has been re-interpreting street musics—mostly dancehall
column2: but also grime and dubstep—for nearly 17 years as the Bug
column3: one of many aliases he’s worked under in a long career in underground music. He’s proved himself the rare artist capable of placing these sounds into more outre contexts without sacrificing any of their ferociousness. His last album
column4: 2008's London Zoo
column5: was full of menacing
column6: fevered ragga that helped make explicit the connections between dancehall
column7: grime
column8: and the still-burgeoning dubstep scene. It was an album that proved especially enlightening to non-UK audiences
column9: putting a point on several elusive trends. He returns here with Angels & Devils
column10: an album that retains the precise brutality of London Zoo but feels labored in comparison.

column1: Martin works slowly in genres that move quickly
column2: and Angels & Devils arrives as grime has once again taken root as both a commercial and underground force: London Zoo all-star Flowdan can now be heard regularly on stations like Rinse FM toasting over mixes by DJs like Elijah & Skilliam
column3: while newcomers like My Nu Leng offer potent blasts. Dubstep is...well
column4: no one really knows what dubstep is in 2014. Dancehall persists
column5: perhaps juiced a little by a generation of adoring rappers. Martin is unconcerned. Angels & Devils
column6: an uneven collection
column7: continues to skew dancehall toward the vanguard of British electronic music
column8: extending an artistic handshake that’s been in effect for more than 20 years (and longer
column9: should you want to move past electronic music).

column1: On Angels & Devils
column2: Martin bifurcates his interests
column3: offering six songs of muddy dirges and six tracks of raucous
column4: MC-aided bangers that will be familiar to fans of London Zoo. Presenting oneself as two competing forces is an artistic gambit that runs roughly from Ancient Greek theatre through Nelly's Sweat/Suit
column5: and Angels & Devils slides comfortably between those poles. The problem is that Martin divides the album exactly
column6: offering first six slow cuts—""angels""
column7: presumably—and then the ruffneck ""devil"" cuts. As a conceit
column8: it fails
column9: stultifying the album's flow and condescending to listeners regarding Martin's range: of course he's capable of slower
column10: foggier productions
column11: but did anyone think London Zoo needed more ambient passages?

column1: Of course
column2: slo-mo
column3: waterlogged ephemera—be it dusty takes on R&B or traipsing down dub’s ever-expanding wormhole—is a pervasive trend in current British electronic music
column4: leading to a lot of limp-wristed trip-hop variations. Grouper’s Liz Harris opens the album with “Void”
column5: her airy
column6: tip-toeing vowels as far as you can get stylistically from Flowdan without phoning Josh Groban. Martin’s lurching bass and gunmetal snares threaten
column7: and Harris proceeds unaffected
column8: as neither artist knows what to do with the other. Gonjasufi
column9: meanwhile
column10: sounds all too comfortable on “Save Me”
column11: offering up the kind of moaning
column12: industrial balladry you might find on a Liars album. It's not all bad: avant-chanteuse Copeland's lemon-sucking croon is fine foil for Martin’s bass rattle
column13: and Miss Red proves that even on softer material
column14: a Jamaican patois bests offsets Martin’s bouts of heavy
column15: as she turns “Mi Lost” into a sonorous sendup.

column1: The album’s second half is more familiar
column2: and better. We’re treated again to three Flowdan cuts
column3: and once again the combination of Martin’s fury and Flowdan’s resonant basso proves potent. Flowdan sounds good saying almost literally anything
column4: and he delivers the occasional quotidian detail—“Why don’t my wife even like me?”—in the same confident bluster as his threats
column5: which is both sneaky and funny. Manga
column6: a bit more histrionic
column7: turns the wild
column8: splintering square waves of “Function” into the record’s best banging-on-the-dash party. In this context
column9: Death Grips
column10: who growl menacingly on “Fuck a Bitch”
column11: sound stiff (and they always sound atonal).

column1: Still
column2: these tracks surge
column3: bleeding adrenaline: Martin sows chaos and his collaborators keep things just under control. When the tempo and aggression are dialed back
column4: the dynamic turns; Martin’s still a talented sound designer
column5: but the whipping
column6: centrifugal force that binds his tracks together is missing. That force is largely absent for the first six songs of Angels & Devils
column7: and the album is trying as a result. The ruff cuts that close the album are your reward
column8: and they are as rattled and rattling as ever
column9: proving Martin still has a deft touch with the underground
column10:
provided the underground gives him something to work with.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20746/homepage_large.0145f370.jpg|Neuroplasticity|30393.0|Cold Specks|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute'
column3: nothing is right
column4: ” Al Spx sings at the end of “A Broken Memory”
column5: the first song on Cold Specks’ second album
column6: Neuroplasticity. But
column7: coming from her
column8: the line is as much proud affirmation as it is grave prognostication—because it’s precisely the kind of purgatory she calls home. The music of Cold Specks exists somewhere between log-cabin warmth and wintry forest chill
column9: between exquisite elegance and raw release
column10: between young compulsion and old-soul wisdom. And this ambiguity extends to Spx herself: she has the kind of voluminous voice that can fill an entire church without the aid of a microphone
column11: but she’s not one for the showboating theatrics of the pulpit. (For all the Southern Baptist allusions her music inspires
column12: she’s actually a lapsed Muslim.) And yet her adoption of an alias suggests a certain appreciation for artifice
column13: and reminds us that we shouldn’t confuse the in-your-face intimacy of her songs for autobiography.

column1: Of all the evocative words in the title of Cold Specks’ 2012 debut
column2: I Predict a Graceful Expulsion
column3: the most telling was “predict.” That album heralded the emergence of a striking talent with immense potential
column4: but you also got the sense that Spx was being extra-cautious and meticulous on her maiden foray
column5: and that the real fireworks would come once she got more comfortable as both a bandleader and spotlight-conditioned singer. Neuroplasticity is an encouraging next step towards that
column6: but it’s not so much Spx that’s changed as her backing band
column7: who seem less like they’re respectfully following their frontwoman’s lead as forcefully unleashing the simmering tension that’s always been an undercurrent in her work.

column1: Of course
column2: hanging out with Swans helps. Neuroplasticity is another summit for the mutual-appreciation society that was forged when Cold Specks covered Swans’ “Reeling the Liars In” for a 2012 Record Store Day EP
column3: earning Michael Gira’s endorsement in the process. Spx’s recent guest appearance on To Be Kind was actually her returning the favor for Gira’s two previously recorded cameos on Neuroplasticity
column4: which aren’t so much showcase turns as demonic possessions
column5: his unmistakably grim tones quietly echoing Spx’s lyrics on the roiling “Exit Plan” and the cabaret-ballad creeper “A Season of Doubt” like an inner voice instructing her to do terrible things. At 35 minutes total
column6: Neuroplasticity is only 43 seconds longer than the Swans song Spx lent her voice to
column7: but the band’s specter hangs over the record like the blackest of clouds
column8: infecting everything from the diseased Dixieland squawks of the opening “A Broken Memory”
column9: to the climactic
column10: mallet-swinging crashes of “Old Knives” to the foghorn-powered
column11: percussive thrust of “Absisto”. The result is the most captivating music Spx has produced to date
column12: made all the more so by the authoritative poise she projects in even the most calamitous surroundings. Her cryptic yet commanding words comfort and unsettle in equal measure—after all
column13: this is a singer who can deliver a line like “all I got is love and grace” with the same clear-eyed conviction as “I smother with you with silence until you choke on dead air.”

column1: However
column2: even within a compact 10-song set that sees her boldly bolstering her sound
column3: Neuroplasticity encounters pacing problems that undermine its mission. In particular
column4: the trio of tracks that comprise the album’s mid-section—“A Quiet Chill”
column5: “Exit Plan”
column6: and “Let Loose the Dogs”—sees Spx lock into familiar melodic and structural patterns
column7: tackling an opening hymn-like verse with minimal accompaniment before the booming drums kick in to send the chorus aloft with clockwork proficiency. Even the refreshingly anomalous “Bodies at Bay”—which introduces a gliding motorik rhythm that will endear Spx all the more to her Broken Social Scene bosses at her Canadian label
column8: Arts & Crafts—ultimately halts its spirited momentum for a slow
column9: swaying
column10: skyward chorus
column11: as if walling Spx back into a comfort zone that much of this record makes great strides in dismantling. The takeaway here is that
column12: two albums in
column13:
Cold Specks have the graceful part down pat—but there’s room for more expulsion.

"|19521.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19521-cold-specks-neuroplasticity/|7.4|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20799/homepage_large.cbd3d071.jpg|The Man Upstairs|1956.0|Robyn Hitchcock|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Yep Roc']|2014-08-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:06.391654|"

If you’ve seen The Lego Movie
column2: the phrase “The Man Upstairs” has some ominous overtones; to everyone else
column3: it’s just a euphemism for God. It’s not clear which connotation Robyn Hitchcock might have been shooting for when he titled his new album The Man Upstairs—after all
column4: he’s no stranger to either religion or animation—but it’s likely there’s no overarching theme at play here. The veteran post-punk folksinger has assembled 10 songs
column5: half of them covers
column6: that don’t seem to mesh in any way other than the fact Hitchcock is singing them.

column1: The first time I saw Hitchcock live was in 1996
column2: when he was splitting a solo acoustic tour with Billy Bragg. Hitchcock’s set was striking
column3: and not just because of the flagrant contrast he and Bragg were gleefully milking: one the whimsical troubadour
column4: the other the craggy firebrand. The two
column5: of course
column6: have more in common than that reductive binary would have you believe
column7: but Hitchcock stood out in one clear
column8: shining way: He’s not just a storyteller
column9: but a shaggy-dog raconteur
column10: as well as a chatty chap who’s more than happy to weave his songs (and those of others) in and out of lengthy tangents and stream-of-consciousness palavering.

column1: In that sense
column2: The Man Upstairs is much like a Hitchcock gig: it meanders
column3: and it has a lovely time doing so. “Trouble in Your Blood” is a study in fragility
column4: all feathery strumming and tentative cello. If it has a vaguely Nick Drake-esque aura
column5: that’s because the album is produced by Joe Boyd
column6: famous for his work on Five Leaves Left and Bryter Layter
column7: as well as everyone from Pink Floyd to Fairport Convention. But Hitchcock’s voice is his own: nasal and astringent
column8: the polar opposite of Drake’s
column9: but no less melodic or emotive on tracks like “Comme Toujours”
column10: which sports sharper
column11: fingerpicked guitar beneath Hitchcock’s charmingly lopsided French. “I’m not trying to be clever
column12: ” he sings
column13: and he makes it sound like the cleverest lyric ever uttered.

column1: The album’s cover songs fare just as well. In Hitchcock’s hands
column2: “To Turn You On”—one of the most starry-eyed tracks from Roxy Music’s Avalon—into a less languid
column3: more quietly urgent plea. The Doors’ “The Crystal Ship” is the closest The Man Upstairs comes to psychedelia (in other words
column4: not very)
column5: and for a singer-songwriter who once repurposed psychedelic music so cannily
column6: it’s an unsatisfying glimpse into what the album might have sounded like with a lusher
column7: fleshier approach—not to mention a more developed idea behind it.

column1: Boyd’s production is subtle
column2: soft
column3: and breathy throughout The Man Upstairs
column4: but for such a notable studio legend
column5: he doesn’t bring much to the table besides that. His pairing with Hitchcock is a matchup that practically oozes masterpiece potential
column6: only here it seems squandered on a set of songs that feel like breezy throwaways. The Man Upstairs’ best track is Hitchcock's version of the Psychedelic Furs’ “The Ghost in You” that manages to extract far more of a haunted atmosphere from the song than the band who wrote it
column7: great as they are
column8: ever did.

column1: Then again
column2: Hitchcock has a thing for ghosts
column3: and it’s indicative of his knack for interpreting other artists
column4: and storytelling in general
column5: that he’s able to funnel his own obsessions through songs he didn’t compose. Here
column6: though
column7: it's simply not enough. Hitchcock has stated that he loves The Man Upstairs because it’s not “just another singer-songwriter laying their freshest eggs
column8: ” but with Boyd at the controls—and Hitchcock at the mic—that’s exactly what this album could and maybe should have been. The Man Upstairs has warmth and charm galore
column9: but it needs someone
column10: anyone
column11:
reaching down to more strongly pull the strings.

"|19573.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19573-robyn-hitchcock-the-man-upstairs/|6.3|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20839/homepage_large.28e2cfad.jpg|Fabric 77|28849.0|Marcel Dettmann|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2014-08-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:07.224323|"

Let us now hail the horizontal axis. As electronic dance music has increased in mainstream popularity
column2: the dominant force has been vertical: the drop
column3: the fist-pump
column4: the collective leap in the air
column5: the upstretched finger
column6: the meteoric rise of the superstars themselves. DJ sets play out like roller coasters
column7: a succinct succession of tension-building ascents and sudden
column8: precipitous plunges.

column1: But not all dance music works like this. Techno
column2: for instance
column3: typically has placed far more emphasis on the horizontal plane
column4: with long
column5: gradual crossfades lending the illusion of a seamless and endless continuity
column6: and extreme repetition furthering a sense of stasis-in-movement. That's particularly true of the kind of techno associated with Berlin's Berghain club
column7: and it's even truer of Marcel Dettmann
column8: one of Berghain's best-known residents. His productions and his DJ sets alike are less like a rollercoaster than a landscape of gently rolling foothills; less like an elevator than a moving walkway with a barely perceptible rise. His Fabric 77
column9: his first mix CD since 2011's Conducted
column10: is almost Escherian in the way it folds four-to-the-floor beats into a series of improbable twists and turns that nevertheless seem
column11: somehow
column12: to unroll eternally in a straight line. Are we floating in space
column13: or marching in place?

column1: Like a growing number of DJs who have used their respective Fabric mixes to showcase their own music—Ricardo Villalobos
column2: Omar S
column3: Shackleton
column4: Guy Gerber—Dettmann devotes the bulk of his set either to his own productions or tracks he's released to his MDR label. (The majority of the latter he describes as ""unreleased demos""—that is
column5: cuts submitted to the label that he's been playing out for a while now
column6: as long as three years
column7: in the case of Rod's ""RSPCT""—and while they are all slated for eventual release
column8: they make Fabric 77 a goldmine for Dettmann trainspotters curious about the composition of his current club sets.) That 15 out of 19 cuts bear his fingerprints
column9: either as producer or A&R
column10: underscores the extent to which DJing
column11: for Dettmann
column12: is a means to the creation of a kind of totalizing aesthetic; it's DJing as gesamtkunstwerk.

column1: There might be a temptation to describe that aesthetic as ""minimal
column2: but it's too roughly textured for that
column3: evoking splintered wood
column4: charcoal lumps
column5: mud puddles in a rutted road. Arte Povera would be a more accurate reference point for both the mix's rough-hewn analog sounds (chalky hi-hats
column6: tarnished oil drums
column7: paper-bag rustle) and its function-first sense of structure
column8: which is only as elaborate as a line of paving stones or a loom for weaving burlap. The artists responsible for the tracks selected for the mix include Terence Fixmer
column9: Answer Code Request
column10: Dario Zenker
column11: Norman Nodge
column12: Joey Anderson
column13: Carl Craig's Paperclip People
column14: and quite a few producers with a fairly low profile so far—FBK
column15: François X
column16: Lockertmatik
column17: Marcelus
column18: Wincent Kunth. I hesitate to go into much detail about individual tracks
column19: however
column20: because music like this resists description
column21: and the very point of the mix is how the component parts function as a composite whole.

column1: There's nothing like immediate gratification to be found in this hardscrabble landscape
column2: but there are plenty of highlights that attest to Dettmann's mastery of detail threaded through its loosely-woven zone-out. Midway through Rod's ""RSPCT""
column3: the beat drops out and leaves only a syncopated foghorn bleat
column4: pealing like Teflon tympani
column5: its dotted eighth-note rhythm briefly offering a countervailing pulse before the downbeat comes stumbling back in. There are the looped chants of Nodge's ""BB 1.0""
column6: which I somehow missed the first dozen times I listened to the mix. In Dettmann's ""Lightworks (Ø [Phase] Remix)""
column7: there's a glassy woodblock (or is that woody glass brick?) pattern so quietly insistent that you begin to wonder if it's been running through the mix from the every beginning
column8: without notice. Then
column9: by the time you finish that thought
column10: it's gone. Between Answer Code Request's ""Transit 0.2"" and Dario Zenker's ""Nearlin""
column11: we're treated to what might be the call and response of two mating woodpeckers
column12: set against a dusky backdrop of swirling dust and seductive gloom.

column1: But even fans of patient
column2: hypnotic
column3: ultra-reduced techno may find Fabric 77 too subtle for its own good. Or perhaps it's just too uniform? His 2011 mix for the Music Man label
column4: Conducted
column5: had more readily apparent character
column6: veering from the lush Detroitisms of Reel by Real's ""Sundog"" through the paranoid pinball wizardry of the Analogue Cops' ""Why You Love Me"" and on through the gothed-out clang of Morphosis ""Too Far""; Conducted covered plenty of ground
column7: but here
column8: the cuts are so similar in tone and intensity that one wonders if the mix would sound any different if he re-recorded the set according to an arbitrary reshuffling of the sequence.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: as a journey that's not quite a journey
column3: this can take you far outside yourself. Throughout
column4: Dettmann's use of shape and texture makes me think of little clumps of lichen clinging to darkly lustrous sheets of slate; it's a fitting metaphor for a mix that proceeds like a long hike along a mountain ridge
column5: far above the tree line
column6: watching over a world that peels away below. In a musical landscape littered with drops
column7:
there's a relief in four-to-the-floor beats like these never quite seem to touch the ground.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20950/homepage_large.c0c1c6ba.jpg|Brill Bruisers|26449.0|The New Pornographers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador'
column2:
'Last Gang']|2014-08-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:07.966320|"

The evolution of New Pornographers hasn’t been measured by changes in their core sound so much as in energy level
column3: with a discography that can essentially be plotted alongside a DJ console’s BPM lever. And since their 2005 masterwork Twin Cinema—an album that perfectly balanced their formative power-pop freneticism with loftier
column4: widescreened ambitions—that lever has been gradually sliding down
column5: with Challengers from 2007 and Together from 2010 emphasizing more patiently paced set pieces that tiptoed the fine line between gracefully decompressing and killing the buzz altogether. But even if such gambles cost them a few ADD-addled admirers along the way
column6: you get the sense the New Pornographers would soldier on at their own leisurely clip even if no one was listening. Because
column7: for the principals involved
column8: the New Pornographers are less a band than a holiday resort
column9: “a vacation from rock'n'roll music
column10: inside rock'n'roll music
column11: ” as resident siren Neko Case once put it. And boy
column12: do they ever need it now.

column1: Since the release of Together
column2: the band’s principal songwriters have experienced the highest of highs and lowest of lows: Dan Bejar produced his most immaculate
column3: universally acclaimed Destroyer album to date with Kaputt; conversely
column4: bandleader A.C. Newman and Case each released sobering
column5: uncharacteristically introspective solo records written in the aftermath of deaths in their respective families. So if the previous two New Pornographers records sometimes had a procedural air about them (with each vocalist checking in to collect their three-song rations)
column6: the vim and vigor of Brill Bruisers forcefully reasserts just how important and therapeutic the enterprise is to all involved. And that album title is brilliantly apropos for both the song-factory connotations and intimations of violence: here
column7: the New Pornographers resemble not so much a supergroup as a gang
column8: wielding hooks like shivs
column9: guitar riffs like machine guns
column10: and synths like laser beams. The opening title track isn’t just a blown-out bubblegum pop song made from a box full of Bazooka Joes—it’s a swarming
column11: instantly thrusting you into a dizzying flurry of “bo-ba-ba-bo” harmonies coming at you from all sides. The steady beat of latter-day New Pornographers may remain
column12: but it’s delivered with the force of a body check.

column1: While greatly indebted to pop movements of the past—from ’60s psychedelia to ’70s glam to ’80s new wave—the New Pornographers have never felt like a purely retro exercise
column2: their best songs too jacked-up and exuberant to lapse into studious classicism. But Brill Bruisers feels like their most contemporary recording to date
column3: and a great deal of credit for that lies with the person who
column4: historically
column5: has been the one least likely to be mentioned in a New Pornographers review— Blaine Thurier—and fellow keyboardist Kathryn Calder. In contrast to Together’s cello-dramatic sound
column6: Brill Bruisers foregrounds their playing
column7: not to opportunistically recast the band as au courant synth-pop
column8: but to restore the forward momentum that was in scarcer supply on recent records
column9: from the starbursts that propel Case’s daydreamy turn on “Champions of Red Wine” to the zippy oscillations that power Bejar’s triumphant “War on the East Coast” to the meaty tones that lend the authoritative march of “Backstairs” (the band’s most imposing rocker to date) a little extra spring in its goosestep.

column1: Thurier and Calder's elevated roles speak to the more integrated teamwork in effect on Brill Bruisers; while tracklists on past records could be easily segregated by singer
column2: there’s a greater degree of vocal trade-offs and harmonic interplay that heightens the communal
column3: celebratory sense of occasion. And with the Fleetwood Mac attack of “Fantasy Fools”
column4: the delirious “Dancehall Domine”
column5: and Tommy-sized closer “You Tell Me Where”
column6: the New Pornographers deliver the sort of pure pop head rush they haven’t unleashed in years. (Bejar is an especially feisty mood
column7: hurtling himself into his trio of heart-racing contributions like a drunk who’s just found out the wedding he’s at has an open bar—all the while
column8: in true contrarian fashion
column9: showing up to the New Pornographers’ most modernist album yet with a batch of songs that require harmonica solos.) As ever
column10: the exact meaning of the songs are evasive
column11: but their ascendant arcs readily cast them as underdog anthems for whatever great challenge you face.

column1: Within such a maximalist context (not to mention a bulky 13-song tracklist)
column2: acoustic-tempered
column3: middle-geared songs like ""Marching Orders"" and ""Wide Eyes"" can't help but pale next to the aforementioned showstoppers. But Brill Bruisers' most revelatory
column4: parameter-expanding songs are actually the most stripped-down: Calder’s quick-hit “Another Drug Deal of the Heart” serves the same reprieving function here that Tobin Sprout’s minute-long melodic morsels did on Guided by Voices’ classic mid-’90s records
column5: while Newman’s “Hi-Rise”—boasting a circular harmony assembled from clipped vocal tics—imagines what the posthumous
column6: animatronic line-up of his band will sound like at a 22nd-century intergalactic tiki-bar residency. As legend has it
column7: when recording the New Pornographers’ 2000 debut
column8: Mass Romantic
column9: Newman’s primary instruction to Case was to “sing like a robot”; with the futurist sound of Brill Bruisers
column10: the whole band embraces a more electric version of itself—bulked-up in chrome-plated armor
column11: firing on all cylinders
column12:
and ready to steamroll anything in its path.

"|19722.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19722-the-new-pornographers-brill-bruisers/|7.7|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20946/homepage_large.2a8a78ff.jpg|De Oro|32444.0|Jason Feathers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Totally Gross National Product']|2014-08-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:08.546209|"

The first thing you may want to know about the mystery band Jason Feathers is that it features Justin Vernon
column2: aka Bon Iver. The second is that their album
column3: De Oro
column4: is a hybrid of swamp-rock and rap that trades on myths of the southern United States as a sinister place where laws are flexible
column5: morals are optional and pleasure is central. Think Spring Breakers
column6: the Musical—a fever dream you might enjoy being part of
column7: provided someone figures out how to remove your conscience first.

column1: The third thing is almost a foregone conclusion
column2: and best stated as a question: Why? Vernon is a powerful musician who could command his fans to pay attention to any number of interesting projects
column3: and in certain cases
column4: has: Volcano Choir
column5: the stonery soft-rock pastiche of Gayngs
column6: and so on. De Oro
column7: though—a collaboration with Gayngs’ Ryan Olson
column8: Bon Iver drummer S. Carey
column9: and the Minneapolis rapper Astronautalis—has the petulant air of music that knows it will be heard based on the people playing it
column10: complete with the attempt to obscure who those people are
column11: but not so well that it can’t be easily figured out. Behold a vaguely condescending backstory casting De Oro as an “after-bar-impromptu-musical-round-up” held “[j]ust outside Flori-bama” between a “red-chested god-bassed Southern rapper in a fancy white suit” and his “flashily-clad cronies.” All we’re missing is someone eating grits in a Cutlass up on blocks.

column1: Of course
column2: the history of pop music is filled with alter egos
column3: stage personas
column4: and people generally pretending to be someone other than who they are. But when you start landing what sound like punch lines about the Golden Corral buffet line
column5: one wonders if you’re wrestling with the realities of someone’s identity or just making fun of it. So feel free to shudder with mild disgust as an Auto-Tuned Vernon bellows
column6: “I am young as fuck
column7: I am young as fuck
column8: I am young as fuuuuuuuuck” or
column9: worse
column10: “God damn
column11: we in the southland now!” because they’re dumb lines no matter who sings them but especially insulting in context
column12: like a pimp-and-ho party held in the yard of a white frathouse. The humor lies entirely in the circular logic that they're jokes to begin with.

column1: De Oro’s most interesting moments are its quietest ones. See “Sacred Math”
column2: a nightmarish piece of ambience wherein Astronautalis—or his alter ego Creflo
column3: pick your poison—strings together a series of vignettes about spring break
column4: each one more hollow than the last. “Spring Break ’89/ We were choppin’ crab legs into lines/ The Old Bay did burn and we bled out our eyes but we agree it was a really great time
column5: ” he whispers
column6: the last line repeated in some effort to convince himself that it’s true. Here
column7: De Oro really is in step with Harmony Korine—and not the glitz of Spring Breakers but the muted depravity of Gummo
column8: whose scenes of small-town life seemed calibrated to make you feel fascinated and disgusted at the same time.

column1: As the hot licks pile up
column2: I keep thinking of Das Racist
column3: who managed to dismantle clichés about rap by embracing them
column4: or about Vernon and Olson’s own work with Gayngs
column5: which recreated soft-rock with a reverence just skewed enough to open up soft-rock as a concept—its parameters
column6: its rules
column7: what made it tick—without just devolving into cracks about boats and cocaine. Here we have a few well-connected guys hacking around and occasionally playing hickface
column8: occasionally with great empathy but more often just for the fun of it
column9:
which is I suppose just another way to say ""America.""

If you've read about Connections
column2: you've probably seen them compared to Guided By Voices. There are a few reasons for that: both hail from Ohio
column3: Connections' particular brand of rock'n'roll bears a resemblance to Robert Pollard's
column4: and even though they're a fairly new band
column5: they're proving themselves to be similarly prolific. But no prolific band emerges from a vacuum. Connections' Kevin Elliott and Andy Hampel were in 84 Nash (and released albums on Pollard's label Rockathon) starting in 1995; that band broke up around 2005
column6: and five years later
column7: the two guys started hanging out again
column8: recording songs together in a Columbus basement.

column1: Their rekindled partnership apparently ignited a particularly fruitful period of songwriting. Along with Elliott's brother Adam (who also drums in Times New Viking)
column2: Dave Capaldi (from El Jesus de Magico)
column3: and Philip Kim
column4: they released two very good albums last year—Private Airplane and Body Language—as well as the Tough City EP. Now
column5: there's Into Sixes
column6: their latest record which was recorded (and pressed) at Columbus' legendary Musicol Recording Studio. The challenge for this one
column7: then
column8: is to at least maintain the same consistency they brought for their first two albums while hopefully churning out at least one song as satisfying and immediate as
column9: say
column10: ""Mall Lights"".

column1: And there's at least one such highlight: ""Beat the Sky""
column2: a power pop gem that ebbs and flows for maximum impact. There are direct
column3: fuzzy power chords
column4: which occasionally pull back and give way to a beautiful
column5: elegant central melody. As a whole
column6: the album doesn't sound expensive or lush
column7: but Into Sixes is thoughtfully produced regardless
column8: and the no-frills recording quality brings forward whichever instrument is doing the most exciting work in a given moment. Solos frequently swoop in and breathe new life into a song just as it nears over-repetition.

column1: Most of Into Sixes' biggest successes are its most powerful moments—it's tough to beat the beefed up Twilley/Seymour/Exploding Hearts-style churn of ""Cruise Control""—but Connections also excel at slowing things down. Teardrop-ballad ""Home by the Sea"" starts out slow and mournful before bolstering the sound and introducing some optimism
column2: singing ""It'll be OK"" while ushering in another well-placed guitar solo in the process. It's hard to imagine a better ending to this record
column3: too
column4: than the upbeat
column5: jangling acoustic closer ""Awesome Beach""
column6: with bittersweet sentiments that are executed beautifully: ""I can't hold you/ My arms are on fire.""

column1: There's plenty on Into Sixes to suggest that Connections are one of the best new power-pop bands going
column2: but the band occasionally falters
column3: too. ""Minister of Ah Ah Ah""'s structure feels rote and unvarying
column4: with not much to break up the handclaps and blurted vowel sounds. The band's slower moments risk losing momentum
column5: too: the start of ""Extremely Boss"" is a bit clunky
column6: but they thankfully pivot away into a direction that possesses more energy and drive. In that way
column7: Connections are a resilient band
column8: one with a seemingly effortless knack for writing and arranging a dozen great songs every few months. They aren't show-offs
column9:
but they do what they do expertly.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20876/homepage_large.6d80a133.jpg|Ganglion Reef|27851.0|Wand|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City'
column3: the debut album by Los Angeles’ Wand
column4: is printed with the kind of map that might appear in the front of a fantasy novel
column5: full of fanciful coastlines and tidal whorls. It seemingly depicts Ganglion Reef itself—an imaginary island that the members of Wand might just frequent from time to time
column6: perhaps transported there by the same psychotropic substances that fuel their music. Travel
column7: after all
column8: is what Ganglion Reef is all about: the passageways between one place or state of mind to another. Accordingly
column9: it moves.

column1: Frontman Cory Thomas Hanson is a mover himself. In addition to playing (usually fleetingly) with a wide array of fellow L.A. garage-rockers over the past few years
column2: from together PANGEA to Meatbodies to Mikal Cronin
column3: the singer/guitarist/keyboardist helms the electronic pop project WHITE. Hanson just can’t sit still
column4: and accordingly what makes Ganglion Reef so euphorically hypnotic is the way it translates his itinerant
column5: hyperkinetic tendencies into song. “Clearer” stomps and throbs through a barrage of zap-gun bursts and bongo-punctuated
column6: acid-flashback breakdowns; beneath it all
column7: riffs the size of thunderbolts hurl the song through wormhole after wormhole. Hanson’s breathy
column8: elfin voice glides overheard
column9: but it’s only half as ethereal as his steam-calliope synths and creamy smears of distortion.

column1: The albums most fantastic voyage is “Fire on the Mountain (I-II-III)”
column2: an epic that manages to condense itself into a relatively compact five minutes. Unpacking it is effortless
column3: but not without effect; Hanson’s high
column4: glassy coo is light years away from Lee Landey’s infernally heavy bassline
column5: and the gulf between them is a vacuum that yanks at sanity. The airlock is completely breached by the time the track hits its second movement
column6: a spasm of Paleolithic proto-metal that wrestles with Hanson’s progressive-folk sprawl. It’s way too much to fit coherently into a single song
column7: but coherence isn’t the endpoint. When an aural lightshow of intertwined synths and guitar solos lifts and soars like the Verve with a sci-fi fetish
column8: it feels like infinity has cracked open.

column1: Hanson’s fantasy bent is even more pronounced on “Strange Inertia (Ctrl Alt Death)”
column2: a shakily scrawled love letter to other dimensions that expends every Crayola in the box
column3: and “Flying Golem”
column4: a surrealist lullaby that resembles ""Adventure Time"" fanfic set to singsong psychedelia. Fantasy gaming is referenced more explicitly on “Generator Larping”—but instead of coming across as a live-action role-playing session of World of Warcraft
column5: it spends six minutes daydreaming the Beatles’ “Tomorrow Never Knows” as rendered in a Neu!-like cascade of sine waves and pulses. There’s a faint krautrock undertow to Ganglion Reef
column6: but it’s motorik for a sandy beach instead of the Autobahn.

column1: Plenty of new psych-rock albums are content to fill the signifier checklist and then just sit there
column2: but Ganglion Reef is as much a vehicle as a destination—and rather than wallowing in inner space
column3: it’s a gateway to other worlds
column4: not so much an escape as an intrepid exploration. It’s fun
column5: sure
column6: but it’s also thrillingly restless
column7: at times almost desperate. “Run for your life
column8: ” Hanson chants on “Broken Candle”
column9: an organ-toggled
column10: kaleidoscopically melodic dreamscape that could be an evolutionary offshoot of the Zombies’ “Brief Candles”. It sounds like winsome nonsense
column11: but it’s telling. Prowling and propulsive
column12: Wand are musical sharks; if they stop swimming
column13: they’ll die. No wonder Ganglion Reef is the liquid
column14:
liminal domain they made for themselves to dwell in.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20817/homepage_large.f6f58b30.jpg|The Process of Self-Immolation|32379.0|Alraune|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2014-08-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:10.026763|"

Alraune came up out of an already fertile local scene in Nashville and siphoned off some of the city's brightest musical talents to join their crusade. After signing with Profound Lore on the strength of a demo
column2: their debut album is a tour de force
column3: and the quartet have made it clear that they're exactly the sort of band that deserves a leg up out of obscurity. The album eases in with a chiming
column4: distorted
column5: medieval-sounding intro before diving straight into the fracas; the songs are structured in unexpected
column6: interesting ways
column7: and as wimpy as the ""atmospheric"" or ""progressive black metal"" tags can be
column8: Alraune give them some much-needed bite. This is raw
column9: cathartic black metal devoid of pretension or compassion
column10: but it does allow itself a few liberties in its pursuit of the greater evil.

column1: Drummer Tyler Coburn (also of Yautja and Gnarwal) plays a crucial role in the band
column2: and he's one of the most present metal drummers out there right now. Every kick
column3: every fill
column4: every perfectly calibrated beat sends tremors through the songs
column5: muscling in on the guitars’ traditional supremacy with a dazzling display of talent and ingenuity. As much as Alraune worships black metal’s purest forms
column6: Tyler’s jazz-influenced drum style adds a skittering
column7: unpredictable quality to the recording that renders it experimental by default. It livens up the otherwise colorless interludes in the deceptively languid “Simulcra”
column8: slashes through corpsepainted melodies with technicolor streaks on the title track
column9: and easily keeps pace with the ferocious guitar work on album highlight “Kissed By The Red”.

column1: “The Process of Self-Immolation” is the most straightforward track on the album
column2: with its driving tempo
column3: unhinged howls
column4: and icy Second Wave tremolo that bleeds into crystalline melodic leads. The inhuman level of control Coburn holds over the rhythm section cows J. Weilburg's tectonic bass into a supporting role without smothering its propulsive hum
column5: and gives the guitar free rein to buck and howl without impunity. The album's other crown jewel
column6: ""Exordium""
column7: is positively explosive
column8: as Z. Allen and J. House pound out the chords in a dual frenzy
column9: twisting and tearing through one another's work while preserving a wild kind of cohesion. Stern
column10: clenched-teeth threefold vocalizations complete the sonic tableau
column11: issuing forth from the corroded throats of Allen
column12: Weilburg
column13: and House to wax hoarse and commanding in equal measure.

column1: The album only sports five tracks and could've stood to include at least one more song
column2: if only because five just isn't enough. But The Process of Self-Immolation is a thoroughly impressive debut
column3: one that successfully bridges the gap between the black metal of old and its newer incarnations without sacrificing any of the darkness or the strangeness that makes the genre so great. Alraune has hit upon something special here
column4:
and deserves your undivided attention.

column4: JJ have created and charmingly articulated their own small romantic world
column5: a place that mixes dreamy sadness with drug lingo and the language of hip-hop with airy soft-pop atmospherics—all of it the product of two seeming stoners who can't be bothered to leave their house. The Swedish duo of Joakim Benon and Elin Kastlander were viewed as anonymous at first

column4: new-classical-style

column8: smeary vocals

column1: It's followed by the single ""Dean & Me
column2: which opens with this image: ""I know I'm drunk/ I know it's late/ But I will call you anyway."" The title and us-against-the-world vibe is reminiscent of M83's ""Kim & Jessie""
column3: as the slightly drunk protagonist goes on
column4: ""Something inside me tells me we should be together...I'm dancing with stars and they dancing with me."" The entirety of V carries a similar John Hughes-by way of-Saturdays=Youth vibe
column5: albeit one viewed thru the lens of The Breakfast Club's ""weirdo"" Ally Sheedy character rather than Molly Ringwald.

column1: Such a worldview is typical for JJ

column3: the acoustic ballad that closed out the group's 2009 debut jj n° 2. Benon and Kastlander are drawn to echoes and self-references
column4: elements that are part of many relationships. It's since been revealed that jj n° 2 and the 2010 follow-up jj n° 3 were originally supposed to be released as a double album; instead
column5: they were released separately and followed by various EPs and even shorter releases
column6: and accordingly it's easy to see their catalog as sketches for the ideas presented on V.

column1: The album's first six songs are among the best JJ have ever recorded. There's the wintry ""All White Everything""
column2: and the focus on elements of ""white""
column3: especially snow

column5: morning-sunrise version of Crystal Castles

column8: despite the strings and electronic gurgles

column10: windswept
column11: soaring vocals. (Like much of V
column12: the lyrics possess strong imagery: ""I don't know how these drinks keep coming by/ Oh no
column13: boy
column14: they make me see you so bright just like tonight."") The bubbling ""Fågelsången"" folds into a tropical vibe complete with bird sounds
column15: reminiscent of jj n° 2's ""From Africa to Málaga"".

The temptation at the suggestion of a collaboration between Jenny Hval and Susanna Wallumrød is to bristle. Yes
column3: they are both female Norwegian singers—strong leaders and writers with consistently compelling visions for the music they make
column4: too—but that’s where the similarities seemingly cease. Hval is the tempestuous imp to Wallumrød’s version of graceful austerity. Wallumrød has reworked the songs of Henry Purcell with a classical harpist and offered her perfect
column5: patient coo to sublime covers of Thin Lizzy and Black Sabbath
column6: Tom Petty and Will Oldham; last year
column7: she issued a beautiful song cycle with the chamber group Ensemble neoN. Hval
column8: meanwhile
column9: began 2013’s Innocence is Kinky by whispering
column10: “At night/ I watch people fucking on my computer” over a slyly lurid beat. She embraces sonic bedlam and mischief
column11: funneling both into songs with deeply psychological underpinnings. The pairing feels tantamount to asking Chan Marshall link up with with Annie Clark because they’re both critically appreciated American female singers.

column1: But that stylistic frisson and the shared willingness of Hval and Wallumrød to explore such tension is one of the greatest strengths of Meshes of Voice
column2: the transfixing result of a 2009 live collaboration and one of the best records of either’s career. These 15 interconnected pieces unfold a surrealistic saga where the narrator wakes to find “I have lost my soul”—at the bottom of a black lake
column3: no less. The tale twists through dream states
column4: mythological allusions and impressionistic analogies
column5: which the sounds match through a web of halcyon ballads
column6: harsh-noise expositions and fragmented art-rock. Meshes of Voice mirrors the multimedia ambition of Laurie Anderson and aligns itself with the self-referential complexity of Joanna Newsom and Dan Bejar. It's a singular world built of two very individual talents
column7: each gifted with the plasticity to turn a mere live collaboration into a true relationship.

column1: As the title implies
column2: the dual stars are the singers’ voices themselves. Wallumrød has the sort of stainless tone that could lead soft jazz outfits toward the tops of adult-contemporary charts. That ease is epitomized by “A Sudden Swing”
column3: where she rises and falls alongside the curves of a piano’s path with classical beauty. Hval is more of a chameleon and jester
column4: though
column5: her voice able to shift from spoken-word scorn to singsong lilt without notice; her imagination and versatility suggest a thornier Björk. During “Running Down”
column6: she funnels the phrase “milk pleasures” through software that makes her sound like a broken automated teller
column7: repeating a meaningless robotic mantra. But by song’s end
column8: she’s purring a blanket-soft lullaby against the horizon.

column1: The voices are only the fixtures
column2: however
column3: the reference points for a trip that races headlong into altogether unexpected territory. There seem to be few risks that either partner is unwilling to take
column4: no set of shocks for which their style is too precious. Hval has tinkered with noise before and even said she likes to write songs over beds of it
column5: but “I Have Walked This Body” is a commitment to cacophony—and a total triumph with it. They sculpt static and feedback with the skill and finesse of Aaron Dilloway or John Wiese. Wallumrød submits to it
column6: her manipulated air slipping inside the mess as if that’s where it has always belonged; elsewhere
column7: Hval adds gorgeous harmonies to “O Sun O Medusa
column8: ” her refracted notes trailing Wallumrød like a comet’s tail.

column1: While there are some mostly pretty songs and completely chaotic numbers
column2: Meshes of Voice compels by ignoring such binaries. The soft beauty “A Sudden Swing” ends under sinister threat
column3: droning strings and circling percussion bubbling from beneath the pristine piano like a toxic leak. Hval delivers a childlike chant during “Milk Pleasures
column4: ” her voice suggesting a pixie. But she sings of mongrel body parts and milk running down pale legs
column5: as Wallumrød answers with distant
column6: ghastly echoes. Meshes of Voice depends on the reputations of its makers
column7: but it delights most when they let those legacies fall away or
column8: at the very least
column9: bend in new ways.

column1: Meshes of Voice is very much a unified program of music
column2: where songs drift into one another and vestiges and premonitions blur what might otherwise be absolute boundaries. The long industrial exhalation at the end of “I Have Walked This Body”
column3: for instance
column4: creeps beneath the resplendent piano of “O Sun O Medusa”
column5: where it’s picked up and suddenly romanticized by a bowed double bass. Those are mechanical links
column6: though
column7: as the more important bonds are the repeating musical and lyrical motifs and the way that the four-piece ensemble shifts them every time they arrive. “I Have a Darkness” is a glowering monster
column8: with a din of static and stunted signals spilling from disembodied vocals. Toward the end
column9: though
column10: a distant seraphim choir sings the words “honey dew” on repeat—not beating back the noise
column11: but certainly pushing against its shadows. Several minutes later
column12: Wallumrød sings
column13: “Dawn came quiet/dawn came cool/The inside of my eyelid is glazed with honeydew.” The source of that earlier sound is finally revealed; her voice is low and powerful with defiant confidence
column14: overrunning a harmonium drone that crackles beneath her.

column1: Just before album’s end
column2: Wallumrød begins another song with the same stanza and the same strength
column3: Hval’s robotic voice circling behind her in an instant of sudden unity. These moments offer arrows toward a resolution
column4: to the moment in the finale where Hval “pulled out my heart from the seaweed.” The narrative here often feels slippery and unattainable
column5: like a “Kubla Khan” dream that’s been recorded in front of a live audience. But the repetition supplies the signposts
column6: assurances that you too can outlast this nightmare of mirrors and confusion.

column1: That adventurous perseverance has a lot to do with why Meshes of Voice is so successful. Hval and Wallumrød
column2: refined and distinct stylists
column3: committed more to the value of this concept than of their own reputations. They seemed to bristle less at the the idea of being typecast as a popular female Norwegian singer than not being able to turn that expectation into something more than pretty covers of popular songs or abrasive explorations of the psyche. As immersive and deep as the lake around which it revolves
column4:
Meshes of Voice adds a new dimension to the output of both its makers.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20737/homepage_large.aed8b91d.jpg|Chrome Cactus|30243.0|The Young|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2014-08-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:12.650420|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1a45pirnf9c.1.6:0.1.0.$19512/=1$19512.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div><span style=""font-family: Georgia
column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Considering that record collectors are the only people who use the term
column3: you’d think “record collector rock” wouldn’t be a pejorative. But the inherent self-deprecation actually demonstrates a deep respect for the creative process: the typical aficionado expects far different things from the music nerd at the bar and the person up there on stage. It’s perfectly fine for your friend to just rattle off whatever they’re listening to of late and
column4: hell
column5: it can be enjoyable when musicians acknowledge their influences and figuratively do the same—provided they’re able to express not just what they’re inspired by
column6: but also why. The Young don’t do anything of the sort on Chrome Cactus; even worse
column7: they're ""record collector rock"" that doesn’t even have an interesting record collection.

column1: This is not to say the Young lack good taste—they just have nearly the same exact taste as nearly every other upstart guitar band that wants a minute of your time. At the very least
column2: they put on for their city of Austin
column3: adhering to the presumable spirit of SXSW; which is
column4: to veer off in a multitude of directions while still using both parts of “indie rock” to determine their true north. Are they into psych-rock? Oh
column5: definitely. Kraut-rock? Of course
column6: that’s the good shit
column7: man. ZZ Top and Tom Petty?  Hell
column8: big part of their upbringing. The Jesus and Mary Chain?  I mean
column9: who doesn’t like Psychocandy? The syllabus of Chrome Cactus reads like the most basic indie rock bio-as-OKCupid profile: it’s not intriguing in the slightest
column10: but it hits all the right SEO points.

column1: And like most astute but unambitious crate diggers
column2: you get the sense that the Young rep JAMC because it allows them to hide behind distortion
column3: psych
column4: and Kraut—because when it comes to writing hooks
column5: those formats sorta let you off the hook. Hans Zimmerman’s voice isn’t tuneless
column6: it just has the range of a touchtone phone. He wields Chrome Cactus' inert melodies like blunt objects
column7: nudging at the rhythm section’s endless boogie only in the slightest. The Young don’t even really play motorik-style rhythms
column8: as just about everything here ends in the same place it started
column9: at the same volume. Add in Zimmerman’s nasal wheeze
column10: and the dominant sound of Chrome Cactus is ""Silversun Pickups without the 'Guitar Hero' riffs""
column11: which means the Young does a better job of making you reconsider Silversun Pickups than that band’s own singles collection.

column1: That said
column2: it’s only offensive if you’re insulted by killing time; Chrome Cactus is actually a useful calling card for a band that could open for 95% of all major-indie guitar acts and be pleasantly ambient in a live setting
column3: with nothing in their catalog that would disturb a conversation. But as Chrome Cactus’ captive listening audience
column4: the closest you get to genuine pleasure is a perverse relief over the most mundane things allowing you to differentiate one track from the next.—we're talking about details as insignificant as an acoustic guitar (“Apaches Throat”)
column5: a Beavis-esque vocal melody (“Moondog First Quarter”)
column6: and a riff that kinda-sorta sounds like Stone Temple Pilots’ “Meat Plow” (“Mercy”).

column1: Even when record collectors use the term “record collector rock
column2: ” they likely respect the fact that making any kind of record is hard work. The process of summoning inspiration
column3: writing songs
column4: fine-tuning them in a live setting and laying them to tape—this takes so much self-belief
column5: so much sacrifice
column6: so much effort. How can you not bleed
column7: sweat or cry on the track even the tiniest bit?  By most metrics
column8: Chrome Cactus is one of the least interesting albums of the year; focus solely on how a presumable rock record managed to be so nondescript
column9:
and it’s one of the most interesting.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20923/homepage_large.b07137ed.jpg|Chorus|32428.0|Literature|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2014-08-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:13.158276|"

Literature are sort of asking for it with their name. The connotations are mostly stuffy
column2: but it’s also a wink at the band’s relationship with the indie-pop canon they figure into. Their new album
column3: <i>Chorus
column4: sounds like an English band emulating an American band around 1984; as it happens
column5: Literature are actually four men from Philadelphia (including former Pitchfork contributor Kevin Attics). Their sound sums up so much history: the antsy enthusiasm of the Feelies
column6: the twinkling tone of Johnny Marr’s guitar
column7: the “Go on
column8: then” romanticism of Buzzcocks. But instead of coming off as a retread of bands dead and gone
column9: it charms with humor and heart—a record with feeling
column10: even if it feels like something you already know.

column1: Chorus is Literature's first LP recorded for indie powerhouse Slumberland
column2: and accordingly they've cleaned up their act compared to their earlier recordings. The first iteration of their indisputably English-sounding “Tie Dye (Your Life)”
column3: which was originally released as a 7” in 2013
column4: sounded like it was ripped from a hand-me-down cassette; the re-recorded version that appears here is smoother without losing any energy and the instrumentation packs a proper wallop. The difference in fidelity is akin to hearing a song coming out of someone else’s car versus hearing it from your own stereo.

column1: The uptick in sound quality is a lovely makeover
column2: and accordingly Chorus is a lovely record. Listen to the way singer Nathan Cardaci’s voice stretches to cover the soaring melody on “The Girl
column3: The Gold Watch
column4: and Everything”
column5: later switching between sigh and croon within the sentimental bloom of “Court/Date”. It’s as quick and sweet as a stolen kiss—just three songs pass the three-minute mark
column6: and only one slows the pace from “nervous” to a swaying but still fairly lively “drunk”. Like Real Estate
column7: their songs work with such a select number of jingly-jangly sounds that they risk approaching mere repetition
column8: but Literature's approach comes across as a pointed tonal consistency. It’s not laziness that pushes them to look backwards
column9: and so a lyric from “The English Soft Hearts” sums up Literature’s mantra: “Time I’ve got is fading faster/ Take me back I’ll hunt and gather”.

column1: In some regards
column2: it’s a little out-of-date to be a guitar band
column3: but there are rewards to be found by mining the past. In seeking their answers from the indie rock firmament
column4: Literature have found something freeing
column5: as Chorus sounds surprisingly fresh. More importantly
column6:
it sounds like the record their previous recordings hinted that they wanted to make—a task that isn’t always easy when history's nipping at your heels.

"|19695.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19695-literature-chorus/|7.1|Jeremy Gordon
