If you remember Castanets from the freak-folk apogee nearly a decade removed
column2: you might wonder whatever happened to Raymond Raposa
column3: the collective’s wonderfully reedy and observational anchor. From 2004 until 2009
column4: Raposa seemed to be one of that loose scene’s most avid explorers. He worked through busted-up cowboy songs and musique concrète hums to create a patchwork empire from blues
column5: folk and country
column6: sewn together with thread drawn of gentle psychedelia.

column1: He kept busy
column2: too
column3: amassing a wide network of collaborators (Sufjan Stevens and Jana Hunter among them) and averaging an album and a split or single a year. While several of his peers
column4: like James Jackson Toth and Phosphorescent’s Matthew Houck
column5: have remained prolific and even reached unforeseen levels of popularity
column6: Raposa all but disappeared after 2009’s middling <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13474-texas-rose-the-thaw-and-the-beasts/""><i>Texas Rose
column7: the Thaw and The Beasts. After a string of rather monastic solo offerings
column8: he changed his name to Raymond Byron and the White Freighter and recruited a proper rock band to record 2012’s Little Death Shaker. But the new project’s roadhouse grit was mostly a half-measure; Raposa spent a large portion of the record wading through the same sad-bastard penury as Castanets. He’d aimed to turn left and
column9: instead
column10: ambled into little more than a circle around himself.

column1: A decade after the first Castanets LP
column2: Raposa has reprised the name for Decimation Blues
column3: a fragmented 12-song album that trends toward the same path that he already spent five albums exploring. Raposa creeps through “Cub”
column4: his voice careful and a touch tragic when suspended over a slow
column5: halting mix of banjo and piano. “Pour it Tall and Pour it True” is a countrypolitan waltz about anxiety and alcohol
column6: grace by gentle saxophone and whammy-bar guitar. It sparkles beneath its tarnish. There’s a hopeful honky-tonk jangle
column7: and at least one number where Raposa plays the part of a beady-eyed bandit
column8: living life at the lip of violence. A series of geographical and temporal postcards
column9: Decimation Blues is
column10: at times
column11: as beautiful and broken as the best of the Castanets’ catalogue
column12: with songs that shape the confessions of a perennial lamenter into hymns for the mutually benighted.

column1: After a decade with and a departure from Castanets
column2: Raposa still seems to be hamstrung by his own indecision with the project. Castanets always embraced uncertainty by reaching out in the dark for the best new ways to render his old worries. Decimation Blues does that while playing catch-up for the years Castanets missed. Half of the tracks here are inchoate and sometimes embarrassing experiments with beat machines and colorful keyboards; they’re so rudimentary that they lampoon the gravity of Raposa’s words. “Be My Eyes” puts a stuttering techno throb and manic drum fills behind a plea so somber it feels at times like spoken-word deposition. Taking either element seriously
column3: let alone the surf-guitar solo or the indulgent vocals effects
column4: is its own fresh challenge. “My Girl Comes to the City” couples a swaggering beat and a distorted bassline
column5: both of which seem cribbed from Imagine Dragons
column6: with copious vibraslap. Raposa plays the part of the weird
column7: itinerant
column8: musical uncle trying to prove to his niece that he can write a hit song. Maybe this one should have stayed a family secret.

column1: The nebulous moments aren’t without their rewards. Raposa sings above looping
column2: loping saxophone and a barely strummed acoustic guitar during the sublime “Tell Them Memphis
column3: ” routing his frail falsetto through something like a vocoder. Sure
column4: it makes him sound a bit like Bon Iver
column5: but more important
column6: it gives this bittersweet farewell to friends a trickle of implied tears
column7: and the effect is transfixing. The shuffling “Out for the West” skips into a jubilant Casio solo at its midpoint
column8: an unlikely shift for an elliptical glimpse at the popular ephemera—Vanity Fair magazine covers and Sean Penn movie roles
column9: Portland Trailblazers overtime victories and old Nike basketball sneakers—that ground our pedestrian narratives. But the move strangely fits the song’s discursive theme
column10: like an allusion to a radio hit Raposa might have heard while buying his kicks at the Value Village in 1994.

column1: Many of Raposa’s fellow freak-folk survivors have found compelling ways to sort through or slough off some of the influences that once made their music so unruly. With Wooden Wand
column2: for instance
column3: Toth has developed multiple backing bands and guises that
column4: last year
column5: helped him move between albums of craggy Crazy Horse jams and inward
column6: abstract folk-rock. Houck has pushed more toward cosmic country and left the shambles of his salad days behind. Hunter has a rock band now
column7: and CocoRosie's doing something like disco. But Raposa remains the wanderer and the tinkerer
column8: with his flirtations webbed only by unease
column9: the battle against it
column10: and his marvelous burl of a voice. Decimation Blues marks the start of Raposa’s second decade in the same wilderness as Castanets
column11:
even if he’s now got some new toys for navigation. 

"|19556.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19556-castanets-decimation-blues/|5.9|Grayson Haver Currin

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20940/homepage_large.ae2e32a9.jpg|I'm Not Bossy
column3: the first single on Sinéad O’Connor’s 11th album
column4: <i>I'm Not Bossy
column5: I'm the Boss
column6: is one of her sloganeering songs
column7: for lack of a better word. It opens with a heady rush of words
column8: half-rapped and half-sung
column9: that race into the triumphal chorus. The song has no time for the niceties of verses or bridges as O’Connor elaborates on the idea of church: “Take me to church but not the ones that hurt/ ‘Cause that ain’t the truth.” On paper
column10: such repetition might seem lazy or at least unimaginative
column11: but there’s power in the device. O’Connor sounds increasingly defiant and demanding as the song progresses
column12: injecting the song with a hearty dose of ambiguity. “Church” could be any church or
column13: if capped
column14: the Catholic Church
column15: with which she has had a strained relationship for most of her life. More generally
column16: it could be some refuge or safe haven; the bedroom or
column17: more specifically
column18: a mind-obliterating orgasm. It could be a musical groove
column19: a moment of in-the-pocket synchronicity that sounds spiritual. By emptying the song of specifics
column20: O’Connor manages to make it all the more meaningful.

column1: “Take Me to Church” is also a song about new beginnings. The sense of disconnecting oneself from the past puts I’m Not Bossy on par with its predecessor
column2: 2012’s How About I Be Me (And You Be You)?
column3: on which she testified to the ignominy of romance with gravity
column4: dignity
column5: and what sounded like a new and sharper sense of self-possession. On the other hand
column6: it also sounded musically regressive
column7: setting her vocals against fairly innocuous guitar strums and drum loops<i>. I’m Not Bossy
column8: I’m the Boss
column9: is much more musically adventurous
column10: not to mention more lyrically ambitious; it’s also a bit more self-conscious
column11: which means it never packs the same punch as its predecessor.

column1: There has always been a knee-jerk assumption (even by this reviewer) that the “I” in O’Connor’s songs is O’Connor herself—that her one lyrical mode is bluntly confessional. Bossy
column2: however
column3: sounds like an extended attempt to get outside herself and tell someone else’s story. The album cover signals as much: this is O’Connor playing dress-up
column4: shedding her own skin and slipping inside someone else’s
column5: and the album plays like a coming-of-age story told from the perspective of a young woman just realizing her own sexual desires. On “Dense Water Deeper Down”
column6: she’s justifying her attraction to the kind of men her mother warned her about. “Your Green Jacket” and “The Vishnu Room” (the latter being the album's original title
column7: before it was swapped with the Ban Bossy-referencing title it has now) negotiate the terms of commitment and desire
column8: but “The Voice of My Doctor” violently shatters her illusions and introduces harsh consequences to loving so intently. As the album progresses
column9: the woman develops a stronger sense of her own identity and self-worth.

column1: At times
column2: this overarching concept taxes O’Connor’s songwriting abilities. She has a plainspoken
column3: conversational style that tends toward artlessness: “I love you more than I ever loved a man
column4: and I’m shy
column5: ” she sings on “The Vishnu Room”. “I want to make love with you more than I ever wanted to.” On the other hand
column6: as a singer she inhabits the character unreservedly
column7: letting those blunt phrases convey the excitement and naïve intensity of new desires. Her technique of layering her voice into a small choir of Sinéads occasionally takes the urgency and edge out of her voice
column8: but during the second half of Bossy
column9: where those emotions grow suddenly more complex
column10: she shows the full expressive range of her voice and sounds more commanding than she has in years. She spits venom on “The Voice of My Doctor”
column11: conveys shaky determination on “8 Good Reasons”
column12: then bends her notes bitterly on “Harbour”
column13: ratcheting up the angst until the song explodes into a loud
column14: caustic outro that recalls the thunder of her 1987 debut
column15: The Lion and the Cobra.

column1: Musically
column2: O’Connor paints with a much broader palette than she did on How About I Be Me. The acoustic guitars and drum loops are still there
column3: but on “Kisses Like Mine” a full backing band bolsters her sexual bravado with snaky Nuggets rock. “The Voice of My Doctor” is even heavier—a sludgy number whose barbed guitar licks echo the narrator’s fierce outrage. That narrative range of sound makes the prayer-like hush of closer “Streetcars”
column4: with its reverbed keyboard and whispered vocals
column5: sound all the more poignant. O’Connor is pushing herself on every song here—maybe not always in the right or most obvious or safest directions
column6: but always with some purpose. A quarter-century into a career that has swung unpredictably from acoustic dissent to big-band jazz to reggae and dub experimentation
column7:
she continues to lay claim to every musical possibility and refuses to define herself with only one particular style.

The story of Willis Earl Beal is the stuff crate-digger dreams are made of: a diamond-in-the-rough discovery—complete with a commanding
column2: charismatic persona and seemingly bottomless well of output—rescued from a lifetime of certain obscurity and exposed to the wider audience he deserves. But his is also a cautionary tale of the dissonance that can result when an idiosyncratic artist used to working on their own terms must conform to the promotional demands of the traditional music industry. After 2012’s Acousmatic Sorcery first brought his cassette-crafted ingenuity overground
column3: Nobody knows. did everything it was supposed to: that is
column4: afford Beal the resources (Cat Power cameos and all) to scrub up his soot-covered soul and make a play for the indie A-list. And yet
column5: it only took months for the arrangement to come completely unraveled.

column1: Of course
column2: it’s easy to romanticize obscurity when the artist in question has yet to catch their big break; it’s much less so after they’ve seemingly squandered it. But Beal’s return to the self-release grind feels like a deliberate retreat—not just from the ascendant career path Hot Charity were plotting out for him
column3: but from the theatrical
column4: chameleonic Tom Waits-like guise upon which he first made his name. Experiments in Time is an album released at a career crossroads that’s very much about being at a crossroads—professional
column5: romantic
column6: or otherwise. “What do you want?/ What do you need?/ You’ve gotta make a decision/ How to proceed
column7: ” Beal offers by way introduction on the opening
column8: open-ended “Questions”
column9: and there are countless other self-reflexive ruminations just like that here
column10: each wrapped in a hauntingly minimalist ambience that sounds like what staring at a blank canvas feels like.

column1: For Beal
column2: the titular experiment in time involves seeing just how much he can slow it down while maintaining the slightest semblance of a song. Trading in the visceral for the ethereal
column3: he couches his anxieties and dark-night-of-the-soul introspection inside weightless
column4: formless hymns that threaten to vaporize before your ears. This is the blues rendered in whites and greys—an expression of pain and catharsis that’s ultimately anesthetized by the smooth
column5: omnipresent
column6: foghorn-like synth hum that permeates these songs (and whose fade-ins/outs often provide the only delineation between where one track ends and another begins). The one cogent link to Beal’s past work is a new version of the Acousmatic Sorcery track “Monotony”—once a poignant
column7: off-the-cuff lo-fi lullaby about the doldrums of boredom
column8: it reappears here as an oppressively sullen
column9: blank-stare recitation that all too easily lives up to its title
column10: and serves as an unintentional mission statement for this intensely monochromatic album.

column1: Experiments in Time’s spare presentation inevitably puts all the emphasis on Beal’s voice
column2: which has shed the carny-barker growl of old and mellowed into a silken croon. It’s a wonderful instrument to behold when Beal has a fully sculpted song to work with: the soft
column3: cymbal-tapped “Slow Bus” (one of just two songs here to deploy any kind of rhythm track) is a hot-summer-night R&B reverie summoning the quietest of storms
column4: while the ghostly one-man doo-wop of “Heads or Tails” enhances its air of melancholy and regret through oh-so subtle but strategic chord changes. But those are rare instances where Experiments in Time feels like a blueprint for a more grandiose master plan; mostly
column5: these songs just linger like an impenetrable mist (the codeine cabaret of “I Am” being the most suffocating)
column6: with precious little in the way of melodic logic or purposeful arrangement to give them any kind of shape or
column7: more importantly
column8: dramatic tension. This makes the anomalous closer “Now Is Gone” feel all the more startling
column9: like a Band-Aid being ripped off your skin: by outfitting this beautifully bruised piano ballad in a tape-hiss patina and a vulnerable
column10: frayed-nerve vocal
column11: Beal offers us a glimpse of the more captivating album that could’ve resulted had he applied his bloodletting lyricism to equally raw and restless performances. Hopefully
column12: Experiments in Time is something Beal just had to get out of his system during a moment of solitary reflection
column13: before reconnecting with the gusto that made his previous albums so intriguing. While there is much to admire about Beal taking such an abrupt left turn at this crucial juncture in his trajectory
column14: in this case
column15: it’s one that
column16: more often than not
column17:
leads to an aesthetic dead end.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20797/homepage_large.121e33f9.jpg|Document and Eyewitness|4611.0|Wire|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Pinkflag']|2014-08-14 00:00:00|1981|2016-06-11 16:34:15.285328|"

Wire’s start-stop lifespan ground to its first halt in 1980
column2: just months after the release of the iconic post-punk band’s third full-length. That album
column3: the icy
column4: insular
column5: Eno-esque 154
column6: became their swansong—at least
column7: until they resurfaced with an updated
column8: less punk-indebted sound via 1987’s The Ideal Copy. But there’s an often overlooked album that ushered out that first creatively abundant era of Wire: Document and Eyewitness. At the time a posthumous release
column9: the 1981 record centered around an infamous concert in February of 1980 at London’s Electric Ballroom—a gig that would turn out to be Wire’s last for a long time. The concert’s infamy stems from the fact that
column10: at that point in their evolution
column11: Wire had pushed their art-student tendencies to the breaking point
column12: turning what was expected to be a pogo-fueled punk show into a Dadaist
column13: performance-art spectacle complete with Morris-dancing bells and a live goose.

column1: Wire imploded onstage that night in a paradoxical mix of surreal exhibitionism and anticlimactic frustration. You had to be there—but most weren’t
column2: and therein lies the eternal problem with Document and Eyewitness. The album is being given an expanded
column3: remastered
column4: and resequenced reissue
column5: but it doesn’t change the reality of the recording’s technical flaws
column6: not to mention the issues with the performance itself. The sound is unsteady and splotchy
column7: and the band
column8: always keen on deconstructing itself
column9: has clearly taken that ethic to its inevitable dead end. The only song off Wire’s astounding first three albums—1977’s Pink Flag
column10: 1978’s Chairs Missing
column11: and 1979’s 154—that they deign to play is their seminal punk hit
column12: “12XU”. Well
column13: they kind of play it: it’s introduced in a faux-crowd-pleasing sneer
column14: then only a fraction of its riff is briefly performed
column15: drone-like. For a song that was designed to feel fragmented in the first place
column16: “12XU (Fragment)” is a gesture of contrarian conceptualism taken one level too far.

column1: The appeal of Document isn’t its fidelity or comprehensiveness
column2: but its small yet pivotal place in Wire’s continuity. A bounty of new compositions are busted out on the Electric Ballroom setlist
column3: as well as the album’s eight other live tracks from around the same time. (The last of those non-Ballroom songs
column4: “Heartbeat”
column5: finally and authoritatively iterates an album track—in this case
column6: the stark
column7: eerie centerpiece of Chairs Missing). “5/10” lurches and echoes in a near-industrial thrum; “We Meet Under Tables” is a psychedelic waltz ostensibly designed to cause nausea. They burst with promise
column8: and history has proven it; most of them wound up appearing in reworked
column9: vastly improved form in the years to come—most notably on singer-guitarist Colin Newman’s third solo album
column10: 1982’s Not To
column11: and Wire’s own 2013 album
column12: the superb Change Becomes Us. Thirty-three years later
column13: Wire’s powerful resurrection of those songs has rendered huge chunks of Document as smaller in sound and far less essential.

column1: The remainder of Document is made up of a handful of rare studio tracks—including two singles
column2: 1981’s “Our Swimmer” and 1983’s “Crazy About Love”
column3: a handful of brittle
column4: immaculate songs that would have felt right at home on 154—and a clutch of clunky
column5: lo-fi rehearsal recordings that overlap the live tracklist and add little to the overall listen. Two of those new additions to Documents
column6: however
column7: are insightful. “Ally in Exile” is an acoustic demo played solo by Newman—hushed
column8: haunting
column9: layered with shimmering effects—that far outstrips the full-band live version elsewhere on the album. And the fourteen-minute “Part of Our History… Emerges” is shambolic
column10: Public Image Ltd.-like jam packed with sarcastic
column11: cut-and-paste references to Wire’s own album cuts
column12: the ones they’d all but abandoned by then. “Practice makes perfect/ I’ve got sand in my joints
column13: ” sings Newman
column14: taunting himself with the titles of two of the songs Wire fans would kill to hear performed live
column15: then and now. That kind of perversity oozes from the album
column16: and the expanded reissue has only made it thicker. Wire never wanted to be a satisfying band
column17:
yet they somehow became one—which leaves the otherwise bold impulse behind Document and Eyewitness curiously inconclusive. 

"|19571.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19571-wire-document-and-eyewitness/|6.0|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20861/homepage_large.54ff4472.jpg|The Golden Echo|32335.0|Kimbra|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-08-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:15.934289|"

Following a boost in visibility from Gotye's mega-hit ""Somebody That I Used to Know""
column2: Kimbra's L.A.-recorded second album The Golden Echo is her wager for staying power
column3: but too often it overstays its welcome. The Los Angeles-via-Melbourne-via-Hamilton singer reportedly cut the already-overlong album down to 12 tracks from 70
column4: leaving cherished collaborations with Dave Longstreth and Flying Lotus to languish in a negative zone; while those ostensibly difficult decisions might suggest a ruthless approach to editing
column5: the resulting album suggests that she's either a poor pick
column6: leaving out some of her choicest shit
column7: or doesn't know how to refine her ideas beyond adding to them until they sound overstuffed.

column1: Gone is the alt-pop piper of ""Settle Down"" which had her lining up next to the Regina Spektorites; in its place
column2: Kimbra attempts to sub a sprawling
column3: clamorous vision where pop music is all things at all times. Bold and vulnerable
column4: naked and swaddled
column5: topical and timeless; the desire to reconcile these contradictions is everywhere on The Golden Echo
column6: but it's a struggle to untangle them. Polarizing first single ""90s Music"" acts as a mission statement for the rest of the album
column7: milking yester-yesteryear's R&B and flavoring it with kawaii affectation and a trap beat. ""90s Music"" sounds like it came from the temporal singularity
column8: and if the other 11 tracks on The Golden Echo matched its coherence
column9: it'd be an unmitigated success.

column1: This potentially alienating take on pop places her as a contemporary of Janelle Monáe
column2: except where Monáe's explicitly performative nature served as a rallying point for reconciling post-modern dehumanization and globalization
column3: Kimbra seems too infatuated with the attendant spectacle to offer any comment. As an eclectic producer
column4: Kimbra places herself to the left of the mainstream
column5: but only just so: more straightforward tracks like ""As You Are"" and ""Nobody But You""
column6: as well as the disco slink of ""Miracle""
column7: alternate between lazy and capitulating modes. ""Miracle"" is perhaps the most egregious example of this occurrence: luscious
column8: punchy
column9: and faithful to the genre
column10: ""Miracle"" could've been the strongest track on the album if it didn't drag on for a minute and a half too long. If ""90s Music"" is emblematic of The Golden Echo's squandered potential for success
column11: ""Miracle"" is emblematic of all its shortcomings.

column1: In spite of all that
column2: amongst this interminable mess are enough moments that show Kimbra to be one of the most adventurous pop artists going. <span>She nearly one-ups Passion Pit at their own game on the breezy
column3: gluco-sick ""Carolina""
column4: while the languid
column5: lovelorn ""Rescue Him"" casts a distorted shadow of Justin Timberlake. For now
column6: though
column7: Kimbra's status as ""That singer from the Gotye song"" woefully underserves her full potential
column8:
but so does The Golden Echo.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20904/homepage_large.57fa3fe2.jpg|Dark Pool|32415.0|Black Rain|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2014-08-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:16.660801|"

In thirty-three years of uncompromising music-making
column2: New York musician Stuart Argabright remains unheralded
column3: both in his own city as well as in other underground music circles. With a discography that stretches back to the late 1970s via bands like Ike Yard and Death Comet Crew and a dancefloor hit in 1984’s “The Dominatrix Sleeps Tonight”
column4: Argabright is tough to slot. He has pioneered musical forms like no-wave
column5: hip-hop
column6: post-punk
column7: leftfield disco
column8: early industrial
column9: and proto-techno (including releases on revered labels like Disques du Crépuscule and Factory Records)
column10: yet Argabright rarely receives mention in overviews. Electronic music festivals might overtake Gotham for month-long residencies to pay tribute to the city’s musical legends
column11: yet none have given someone like Argabright his proper due.

column1: Granted
column2: Argabright carries a penchant to both reside and delve into the sounds of the shadows. In 2012
column3: the London imprint Blackest Ever Black unearthed a soundtrack that Argabright collaborated on with fellow Death Comet Crew member Shinichi Shimokawa as Black Rain. It was originally conceived and recorded for the disparaged 1995 sci-fi noir Johnny Mnemonic
column4: a Keanu Reeves vehicle that's now nearly lost down the pop culture memory hole—but Argabright and Shimokawa’s soundtrack remains vital
column5: even nearly two decades on. The dark pulsing tones of their work were resonant in the new century
column6: especially in the more abrasive tones perpetuated by producers like Shackleton
column7: Sandwell District
column8: Vatican Shadow
column9: and labels like L.I.E.S. With the duo’s first album in 18 years
column10: Dark Pool
column11: they plunge ever deeper into that chilly pitch-black template.

column1: Age has in no way abated the duo’s penchant for isolating and building up alley-dark
column2: harrowing tones out of their drum machines and hardware. A feminine robot voice at the album’s start suggests a glitching billboard leftover from Blade Runner and that mood carries throughout the turbid 11-track album. A stark vocal is set at the center of “Profusion”
column3: and its balance between the ethereal female voice and foreboding electronics suggests Andy Stott’s work with Alison Skidmore's operatic vocals on Luxury Problems.

column1: But where Stott would use the beat as a bludgeon
column2: Argabright and Shimokawa prefer small and sharp needle-like sounds: Tibetan chimes
column3: distant bashed metal
column4: disembodied drones. Nearly five minutes into the album
column5: a metallic beat breaks up the sinister ambience of “Watering Hole”
column6: though it doesn’t remain in focus for long
column7: the track giving away again to abstraction. Only on “Endourban” does a skittering
column8: heart-quickening drum machine beat run throughout the track
column9: the roars that rush around it suggesting a chase down an abandoned subway tunnel.

column1: The songs at album’s center are the most visceral
column2: showing how their influence on the likes of Sandwell District and Vatican Shadow might now reflect back on the duo like a mirror darkly. Distortion
column3: overdriven circuitry
column4: red alert arpeggios and metallic-plated drones rise and fall amid the throttling beats of tracks like “Burst” and “Data River.” The complex patterns that emerge on “Night in New Chiang Saen”—part EKG
column5: part leaking pipe on a downed wire
column6: part unmanned jackhammer—suggest early Autechre. Throughout
column7: the productions of Argabright and Shimokawa move deep into queasy dark ambient territory
column8: yet there’s a noir-ish
column9: cinematic sense pervading every track
column10: suggesting an imaginary film soundtrack
column11:
even if Keanu Reeves is nowhere to be seen.

"|19678.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19678-black-rain-dark-pool/|7.5|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20822/homepage_large.0ecc2578.jpg|Lost in Alphaville|3558.0|The Rentals|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2014-08-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:17.199479|"

Rock bands inevitably get old and start to suck
column2: but Weezer are an exceptional case of this. It’s not as if
column3: since resurfacing from their post-Pinkerton hiatus back in 2001
column4: they gradually turned into a less interesting
column5: more pedestrian version of their younger selves (a la the Rolling Stones). They’ve intentionally become a total
column6: aggressive affront to them
column7: as if their entire post-millennial career has been one extended
column8: James Franco-worthy performance-art stunt in baiting anyone whoever took them seriously. It’s hard to think of another band that has so eagerly created such a chasm between what they first presented themselves to be (in Weezer’s case
column9: a Pavement that could sell records) and what they turned out to be (a Smash Mouth that sold even more). And that cognitive dissonance is weighing on the hearts and minds of old-school fans all the more heavily this year
column10: as we celebrate the 20th anniversary of The Blue Album while bracing for the next inevitably disappointing chapter in the history of a band that long ago stopped writing great songs in favor of writing dumb songs about writing great songs.

column1: It may be a complete coincidence that Matt Sharp is dropping his first proper Rentals album in 15 years smack dab in the middle of this fray
column2: but it’s a welcome thrown-bone nonetheless for those who were first drawn to Weezer for their winsome underdog charm (which got pissed away forevermore sometime during the first talkbox solo on ""Beverly Hills""). It’s hard to say if Sharp was solely responsible for the enduring greatness of Weezer’s first two albums (though he has taken the band to court to essentially prove as much)
column3: but it’s no exaggeration to suggest they were never the same after he left in '98. And where his solo vehicle the Rentals first surfaced as Weezer’s skinny-tied alter-ego—with breakout single “Friends of P” piggybacking on The Blue Album’s MTV momentum—it has since come to signify their complete anti-thesis: a sly psych-pop outfit that
column4: despite an evermore ambitious scope and consistency of vision
column5: remains humble and easily approachable in demeanor.

column1: The Rentals have always been an opportunity for Sharp to play fantasy camp with a rotating cast of players
column2: whether presenting the band as Cold War-relic Soviet tech-pop technicians on 1995’s debut/faux-comeback Return of the Rentals
column3: or rounding up a leisure cruise of Britpop all-stars for 1999’s Seven More Minutes. However
column4: Lost in Alphaville follows an extended
column5: and only sporadically productive period of hibernation
column6: marked by a somber country-rock-inspired song cycle issued under his own name in 2004 and a collection of ambient
column7: piano-based instrumentals released as the Rentals in 2011 to benefit victims of the Tohoku earthquake and tsumani (but
column8: understandably
column9: wholly lacking in the sugar-buzzed pop generally associated with the brand). So when Sharp sings “it’s time to come home” on Lost In Alphaville’s splendorous opener of the same name
column10: he’s not just setting some nostalgic childhood scene of moms summoning their kids for supper—the synth swirls
column11: morse-code melodic tics
column12: and fuzz-covered chug practically serve as beacons for Sharp himself to return to his comfort zone.

column1: Once again
column2: Lost in Alphaville reveals Sharp’s strengths as a casting director: moonlighting Black Keys drummer Patrick Carney lends the retooled Rentals some heretofore unrealized heft
column3: while Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig of honky-tonk harmony outfit Lucius capably provide the “oohs” and “ahhs” once supplied by everyone from that dog’s Rachel and Petra Haden to a pre-SNL Maya Rudolph. With the sunbeamed pop highs of “Traces of Our Tears” and “1000 Seasons”
column4: Lost in Alphaville essentially plays like Return of the Return of the Rentals
column5: and the glammed-up “Stardust” even winks in the direction of the Rentals’ biggest single while acknowledging the scourge of one-hit-wonderdom (“Once
column6: I had a friend/ A short-term friend/ But now she’s gone”). But all this retro-gazing isn’t just some convenient ploy to reintroduce this band to a '90s-nostalgic marketplace; as Sharp has admitted
column7: Lost in Alphaville was inspired by a return to the Barcelona locale that informed the hedonistic narratives of Seven More Minutes and
column8: as such
column9: is the most pensive
column10: sobering album in the Rentals’ canon
column11: establishing a tension between the band’s gleaming futurist fantasias and a festering
column12: dreams-unfulfilled ennui.

column1: Accordingly
column2: Sharp’s voice has turned less assertive
column3: more conversational with age
column4: not so much a singer anymore as a sigher. But while he wisely defers to Wolfe and Laessig to deliver the album's biggest hooks
column5: his unwavering wistfulness still has a way of flattening out Lost in Alphaville’s emotional terrain and lending the album a steady-to-a-fault temperament
column6: to the point where there’s little difference in impact between a downcast new-waved ballad like “Damaris” and an orchestro-rock gallop like “Irrational Things” (which imagines an alternate universe where Mercury Rev scored the Peach Pit After Dark gig on ""90210"" instead of the Flaming Lips). Fortunately
column7: the album’s closer
column8: “The Future”
column9: proves to be something more than just another sci-fi-themed spin on the Rentals’ patented robo-rock. Breaking down his usual schematic into a flurry of backward loop effects
column10: propellered percussion
column11: and Dirty Projections-style vocal acrobatics
column12:
the track sees Sharp capping off an album that’s very much about looking back—upon his life and his band’s past sonic signatures—with a bold step into the unknown.

"|19596.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19596-the-rentals-lost-in-alphaville/|6.9|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20811/homepage_large.a0e6e3eb.jpg|Get Hurt|27103.0|The Gaslight Anthem|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Island']|2014-08-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:17.902321|"

Who says the Gaslight Anthem doesn’t have a sense of humor? You know
column2: besides everyone who’s heard a single note of their music. But Brian Fallon has to be fucking with us when he says that Get Hurt is “completely different than anything we had ever done before” and that it was inspired by “a lot of poetry books and a lot of Bob Dylan.” He should know this is inherently funny
column3: because the Gaslight Anthem is a band almost exclusively defined by their relationship with Bruce Springsteen
column4: and now here they are
column5: announcing a total artistic rebrand by namedropping the two main influences of the Boss’ earliest days. Here’s the thing
column6: though—Get Hurt is completely different than anything the Gaslight Anthem has ever done
column7: in large part because it is inherently funny. They just seem to be the only ones not in on the joke.

column1: The running subtext is that Gaslight had as much Bon Jovi in them as they did Bruce
column2: but it’s a subtle joke
column3: since Get Hurt draws from a specific time when those guys were essentially two sides of the same coin: both are Jersey boys who packed stadiums with anthemic
column4: synth-gilded rock songs that used role playing and blue-collar archetype to distract you from the storyteller’s celebrity. The main difference is that Bruce made you think he actually worked at a carwash
column5: whereas Jon wanted you to think he was a fucking cowboy. There is nothing inherently wrong with Gaslight Anthem going this route; their whole cross-armed
column6: “real rock ‘n roll” moralizing was tired even before Handwritten
column7: and more power to them if they turn out to be the rare band who can summon the endearing qualities of Jersey hair metal. Why should southern boys like Luke Bryan and Eric Church have all the fun these days?

column1: The problem is that The '59 Sound’s still-pretty-awesome Eddie and the Cruisers mall-punk shtick is the only thing that comes naturally to the Gaslight Anthem
column2: and while Get Hurt finds them admirably trying to do anything but that
column3: the results are the strain of incompatible parts—a band with the heart of a Dodge Challenger and the assembly line and plasticine production of a Kia. 99% of all Gaslight Anthem reviews fail to mention any other member besides Fallon
column4: and it’s just as well; thanks to Mike Crossey’s atypically expensive-with-broke-taste production
column5: Fallon might as well be emoting in front of a House of Blues version of Chuck E. Cheese’s animatronic band. When the title track fails to hold the line on Toto-style power balladry
column6: you wish they were honest with themselves and hired Mutt Lange instead.

column1: With every bungled attempt at pop
column2: metal
column3: or pop-metal
column4: Get Hurt just rewrites its own worst case scenario. The plodding pentatonic riffs and dour
column5: lower-octave vocal harmonies of “Stay Vicious” at the very least renounce any ties to previous Gaslight Anthem records
column6: though a complete alt-grunge overhaul just results in a twang-free Manchester Orchestra. Throw in a stiff
column7: stuffed-pants strut and a gospel choir on “1
column8: 000 Years”
column9: and you’ve got the kind of radioactive song of the South that even Kings of Leon won’t touch anymore. On “Stray Paper”
column10: Fallon’s vocals climb honky’s ladder three rungs too high
column11: strangulating
column12: “You better never tell nobody but God all the things I’ve seen”; the only possible explanation is that he’s attempting an Afghan Whigs parody nobody asked for.

column1: Still
column2: <span>when all else fails
column3: Fallon remains the focal point as the most sincere guy in rock
column4: and Get Hurt is the first time he’s written exclusively in the first person. Following his divorce
column5: as well as a retreat from both substances and social media
column6: he's got material to draw from—<span>and yet
column7: he still maintains the same guys ‘n’ dolls vernacular
column8: asking the listeners to meet the new Nathan Detroit
column9: same as the old one. During “Stay Vicious”
column10: Fallon admits
column11: “I still love rock'n'roll and I still call somebody ‘baby’.” Disregarding the rockism
column12: sexism
column13: mansplaining
column14: and ageism that can be perceived in this lyric
column15: it's easy to appreciate the honesty
column16: at the least
column17: of a guy admitting to being an anachronism. And he is true to his word—on numerous occasions throughout Get Hurt
column18: he uses “baby” as a term of endearment.

column1: For example: “Baby
column2: I was born on the 4th of July/ Exploding like a firework”
column3: a key lyric from “Rollin’ and Tumblin’”. <span>Point being
column4: Fallon’s been working for so long within the iconography of “real music” that he can’t seem to express any real emotion without running it through some kind of Boss Babelfish filter. There are two ways to hear him finish the line
column5: “Since you only get high on the weekends
column6: uh-huh”—either “Why don’t you feel me tonight” or “feed on me”—and this is from a song called “Helter Skeleton”. During “Red Violins”
column7: Fallon gravely intones
column8: “20 pounds of curses came to visit me tonight
column9: ” and even if it wasn’t a metaphor mixed three wrong ways
column10: 20 pounds seems like a pretty manageable weight. And then there’s pitiable non-resonance of the title track: “I think I’m gonna move to California/ Momma can you say a prayer for me?/ I heard they never get so lowdown/ I heard they never bleed...not like we bleed.” Cue the cheers from the Stone Pony
column11: but not before another damn grease monkey Greek chorus.

column1: Credit where it’s due: this is Fallon’s divorce record and Gaslight Anthem’s “highly produced” synth-rock record
column2: and yet they somehow didn’t just follow the path of least resistance towards recreating Tunnel of Love. Nor did they have any real incentive to change things up—not when they could probably just ride out their caricatured
column3: blue collar punk-hagiographer thing into the Sunset Strip the same way Social Distortion do to this very day. And it’s still so completely sincere that every time you laugh at Fallon
column4: you also feel some kind of pity
column5:
so the only thing they truly nailed on Get Hurt was the album cover: an inverted heart that just ends up looking like a cartoon ass.

"|19585.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19585-the-gaslight-anthem-get-hurt/|3.0|Ian Cohen

“This might be the earliest we’ve ever played
column4: and the most complete as far as songcraft goes
column5: ” quipped John Dwyer
column6: frontman of Coachwhips
column7: during one of the band’s reunion shows this March. “So you can really dig in on the nuances of each of these pieces of mastery.” Not that Dwyer needs to be self-deprecating about the music he released with Coachwhips between 2002 and 2005—it's embedded in the music itself—but something happened in the short months between Coachwhips’ 2002 debut album
column8: Hands on the Controls
column9: and their second album
column10: that same year's Get Yer Body Next ta Mine. A band that seemed happy to take the piss out of their own garage-rock shamble suddenly found their swagger.

column1: Hands on the Controls is almost tentatively titled—like a teenager taking the wheel of the family car for the first time—while Get Yer Body Next ta Mine practically screams in its self-assertion. Hands was reissued last year
column2: and now Get Yer Body is following suit; while it still doesn’t fall anywhere near the psychedelic richness of Dwyer’s subsequent band Thee Oh Sees
column3: it works more weirdness into the gloriously lopsided equation. Get Yer Body’s best song
column4: “1000 Years”
column5: is robotic to the point of motorik
column6: a sack of pure slop poured into a glistening
column7: shivering skin. The sci-fi vibe goes deeper on “UFO
column8: Please Take Her Home”
column9: a Frankenstein’s-monster-in-zero-gravity stomper that starts and stops in a frenzy of thwarted
column10: paranoiac inertia.

column1: John Harlow’s drumming is a study in applied stupidity
column2: all busted sticks and busted knuckles
column3: but Mary Ann McNamara’s keyboards truly push Dwyer’s primal sound into other dimensions. Schoolyard taunts are translated into single-fingered organ lines
column4: and they’re always half a hair off the beat and off-pitched
column5: imparting an air of bruised discordance to an already abusive batch of songs. “I Put It In
column6: Way Down South” is Dwyer at his most Billy Childish-ish
column7: employing his hero’s distinctively unhinged
column8: riff-voice-riff-voice pattern like he’s toggling the light switch in a drunk tank full of troglodytes.

column1: Strangely
column2: it’s when Coachwhips eases up that Get Yer Body starts to really rock. “Yes
column3: I’m Down” is the closest the record comes to approaching poignantly emotive fare
column4: and while the song’s beat is frantic
column5: its melody is stretched over a Suicide-like drone that evokes a hollow loneliness. The album’s title track is downright slow and ultimately clairvoyant
column6: evidence that before Dwyer tired of rattling garage rock’s skeleton and began his quest for something more lush in Thee Oh Sees
column7: he was already tinkering with creepy-crawly proto-psych.

column1: The reissue of Get Yer Body has been remixed and remastered
column2: and Dwyer has touted it as “loogie-shined
column3: ” but there isn't a vast sonic difference between the original release and this reissue. Mostly
column4: the mud has been scraped off the edges and plopped back into the middle; there’s a heft and jolting clarity to all the fuzz
column5: and the vague murkiness of the original recording has been replaced with a higher resolution. It doesn’t appreciably change the experience of hearing it
column6: but it does signal the fact that Dwyer has started taking Coachwhips’ legacy a little more seriously. Garage rock once reveled in its own vaunted authenticity and organic messiness; everything needed to bleed
column7: and many of the genre’s practitioners and fans still feel that way. But Get Yer Body was a big step toward demonstrating that garage didn’t need to be overly druggy and/or arty to be soulful and peculiar—and that
column8: yes
column9:
there may even be room for nuance in these trashy pieces of mastery.
